review: dadada

There were moments I had loads of fun, and there were also some moments where I wanted to rip and tear my fucking head out. I'm talking to you marauder. Also the gladiator should be called the iator because the only thing I was glad about related to that beast was when it died.
On a more serious note,
unlike some people, I like the game play loop (chainsaw for ammo, flame for armor, ect.) I also like the platforming, like a lot. Maybe that's because I like platforming games. I could see that someone who just wants to kill demons wouldn't like wall climbing and dashing to reach platforms, but I personally like that. There is only one kinda negative thing I have to say and it's how pickups look. They look very arcade-like, and it's a little weird to be tearing open the chest of a gargoyale one second and then seeing your helmet in a bright green color labeled as a extra life the next.

And let's add Denuvo because everybody asked for it and wanted it so bad.

Edit: Denuvo is going to be removed!

WHEN YOU CHOOSE EASY MODE AND ARE GIVEN HARD INSTEAD...

Look I'm getting older and I hate games that stress me out. My job is enough stress thanks... It's why I stopped playing souls games. When you play a game and it feels like you heart is beating out of your chest and you cant settle for hours after playing because it amps you up that much THAT'S NOT GOOD FOR YOU... Your body will tolerate it in your teens and 20's but eventually your health will be effected. That's just reality kids...

So imagine how frustrated and disappointed I felt to play through on easy mode and find the difficulty ramp up to insane levels. I got to the fight with the Khan Maykr and yes I quit and deleted my game... When I had one platform left to fight on because the others were on fire and I was surrounded by enemies getting pulverized on all sides by both them and the Khan Maykr. Then I get killed after about 10min of fighting I was out... 

It was actually once I got to Taras Nabad things started getting stupidly difficult and I stopped enjoying myself. Up to this point I was having a great time and the lore was fantastic and I was totally invested.

So I look to games like this so I can play on easy and enjoy myself. Because easy mode for me is gaming enjoyment across the board.  It's how I chill out... When a game stops being fun it's time to quit.

To the Dev team: if you cant make an actual easy mode then don't advertise the game as having one. This is likely just a major imbalance issue. But still, I payed good money for this.

To those who are looking at this review saying 'git good'. A quick google search will reveal the tons of hits showing how many people felt this game was too hard.

review: Doom Eternal takes the best parts of Doom 2016 and turns it up to eleven. The extremely fun and fast paced combat is improved with new weapons to wield and power ups to the Praetor suit. The levels are dense, detailed, and extremely colorful compared to 2016. My favorite addition is the new movement mechanics of dashing and monkey bar swings that make fighting even more fluid than before. Last but not least the story is rich and ties the elements of Doom from past and present into one well written campaign.

Doom Eternal should be played is a different beast than its predecessor Doom (2016). While both games are great, and the story, graphics and music are very similar, the mechanics are quite different. I will try to briefly address this.

The game looks great, the textures are better than Doom´s and the effects have been improved. Weapons look better overall, and the game taking place in well illuminated settings allows the implementation of beautiful sights. What´s better, it is amazingly optimized, so you won´t have any problems with a medium gaming PC.

The music in the last two games is paramount. This is it. It´s what it should be. It´s perfect. If you have a good setup you´ll enjoy the use of bass with overdrive and thunderous guitar riffs. Although it is often frenetic because of the adrenaline and fights, sometimes string and brass melodies will accompany you through your journey.

I think the most important part of this game is how it´s measured against it´s prequel, Doom (2016). This game makes the former Doom game look slow. Yes, Doom Eternal is just pure action. Enemies will give chase, they won´t hesitate and are pretty damn aggressive. Run from them into a corner and you´re dead. Think too much and you´re dead. Stop for a moment and... you get it. This game has new mechanics that should be practiced immediately. If you try to play as you would Doom (2016) you will be humiliated over and over. At the beginning the new mechanics and information can be cumbersome, but keep trying and it will be an awesome experience. 

However, the game to me seems more difficult. It´s not just shoot them till they drop dead. Doom Eternal is strategy. You have to know the weakness of your enemy, you have to be able to switch weapons accordingly,  You have to plan. All of this while you try to run and dodge fireballs and melee attacks from enemies all over the screen. Whatever difficulty you played Doom (2016) in, try lowering one level for this one, at least at the very beginning.

Review after buying and 1 hour of gameplay : 
I bought, hated and refunded this game. This is the gist of my original review
- the graphics and the world are boring, like something Arkane Studios with come up with, with their tiny Donald Trump-hand sized assets.
- there's about as much ammo as a hardcore zombie survival game, so most your focus will be on chainsawing to replenish, then going out of ammo almost immediately afterwards
- cliched combat - do you like getting suddenly locked in a room and swamped? They got you fam, literally.
- too many darned controls again - remember how id said they wanted to take the shooter back to its origin by keeping it simple? well, it's no longer simple. Grenade launcher? Blood punch? Double jump? Wall climb? Come on - I'm a simple man who's here to shotgun demons in the face
- But the worst, the thing that kills this game stone cold dead is the jumping ... lots and lots and lots of double jump button smashing and oh you failed? Well, now you have to double jump smash just to work your way back to the place you failed at. Infact, you realize pretty soon that there's actually way more jumping than there is shooting in this sad garbage fire of a game

Review after trying it again :
I decided to give the game another try. Bought it again, tried it again, persevered through the annoyances and actually enjoyed it . But I'm still voting it down, simply because of the jumping. There isn't much "Doom" this time, half of it is combat, the other half is still just jumping around like a Mario game. It's a shame really, this game should have had a lot more meat on its bones.

Doom eternal is a phenomenally well tightly designed game that is more akin to arena shooters than any other fps. The criticisms that this game is shit cause it's too restrictive and don't allow the player to have fun and be creative is baseless and unfounded, 2016 gave you the power fantasy, in eternal you have to earn it and that's most people's problem with the game you gotta actually think and be tactical about it. The different weapon combos, runes and suit upgrades allows for different playstyles so long as it adheres to the funzone, Eternal encourages player creativity more than 2016 ever did. 2016 rewarded the most power heavy weapons, Eternal rewards smart and skillful high level play.

You got a dozen different things to think about every second and it requires a different thought of play than other shooters, even competitive ones. Dude I couldn't get past the first arena in Gore Nest till I lowered the difficulty to Hurt Me Plenty, now I only play Master Levels on Nightmare yet people be bitching about how the game is unfair and is shit, the point of the game constantly harrassing ya is to get ya to a better level of play. If you still want to buy I suggest to buy it on sale but very worth it at full price.

Doom Eternal improves upon it's predecessor in almost every way. Plays even faster, every gun is amazing, more demons, bigger levels and another excellent soundtrack from Mick Gordon. Doom Eternal has a much bigger emphasis on resource management than 2016, with a bunch of new mechanics that ensure the player will always have ways of restocking their health, armour and ammo. Demons are much stronger and more aggressive, and the game does not hold back in throwing every type possible at you in its various combat arenas. All your weapons have different strengths and weaknesses against the various enemies in the game requiring you to constantly swap between your various guns and mods in order to effectively take out tougher enemies. All of this adds to a much faster, more refined and at times more punishing game than Doom 2016.

Score: 10/10

Pros:
+ New mechanics like the dash, blood punch, flame belch, ice grenade and meathook add so much depth and strategy to the games combat.

+ Plenty of weapon variety, every weapon is effective and unique from each other. 

+ Levels are bigger and have plenty of collectables and secret combat encounters.

+ Narrative is by no means superbly written, it is Doom after all, but it is still a very entertaining, dumb, b-movie style adventure.

Cons:
- Multiplayer isn't bad, but it's certainly mediocre. Currently the only gametype is 'Battlemode' which pits two player controlled demons against a fully armed slayer. It can get rather boring after a while, and matches often boil down to either the slayer being insanely good and wiping out the demons, or the complete opposite with the demons tearing the slayer apart in no time at all. Multiplayer in general is just lacking in content with only Battlemode at the moment.

Doom eternal is amazing. The combat is super satisfying, and when you die its usually your fault not because of some bs. The level design is greatly improved over doom 2016. The sound track is perfect for a game like this because it makes you want to rip and tear until it is done ( I especially loved the heavy metal choir). The story is pretty basic but that is ok, in a game like this your supposed to just have fun and shoot, but there is readable lore for the people who want more backstory. I do have to say that I'm disappointed with the final boss because ( to me at least) it felt repetitive and tedious. But that is pretty much my only problem with the game. I would say something about the multiplayer but I have not been able to play that end of the game because every time I join a lobby every one els instantly leaves, sending me back to the main menu.  My only other complaint is that stupid purple goo that makes you go super slow. Except for that everything els is amazing, so stop reading reviews and buy the game already.

Phenomenal and over the top, as a proper sequel should be. For every high, there was a low, however.

TL;DR: I liked it...mostly. YMMV.

Pros

- Round-trip journey through locations like Earth, Mars, and Hell with some tremendous art direction
- Plenty of variety of baddies, even though they were in overwhelming numbers at times
- Weapons felt "just right" and powerful

Cons

- Monkey bars were fun for the first 20 or so times I encountered them, then they got old like the Skylines in BioShock Infinite
- Frustrating first-person platforming (outside of battles) slowed down the pacing, and not in a good way
- Never enough ammo, switching guns every 10 seconds was disorienting

Once I got into the rhythm of the game, it really fired on all cylinders. Quite grin-inducing at times.

In the end, I think this sums it up nicely versus Doom 2016:

I played Doom 2016 on Normal and could spend an afternoon or an evening of it, eager to return to the game. It felt vast.

I played Doom Eternal on Easy and got exhausted after just a level or two. It felt compartmentalized.

Overall, it's just a new type of frantic and frenetic gameplay that some players will enjoy while others will not.

P.S. I also enjoyed the "Cannot Connect to Bethesda.net" mini-game.

I want to preface this review with stating this is an excellent game. The genre of FPS has been kind of stale and has slowly shifted from Survival/FPS/Battle Royale into a "tactical" shooter experience. This is a defiant example of what great people can do with long standing franchises when given proper care.

The gameplay is a 100% improvement from the previous reboot of the DOOM series (DOOM 2016). There are more things to manage, more gameplay opportunities and a significant increase of rewarding skill based gameplay. The game is definitely more overwhelming than the previous game, which can be considered a good or bad thing, depending on your engagement and the focus.

The length and pacing of the game is a little different from the previous game. While some people are arguing that a certain enemy type breaks the flow of the game and that there is an annoying slow goo, it's much better than the first. The game keeps you much more engaged until the end and progresses just fast enough to keep it interesting, but not so fast that it expects you to master skills within seconds (unless you run the game on Nightmare for the first time, which I do not recommend).

The music is a complete step up from the first game. It's a total shame it will be the last album from Mick Gordon and I am not sure if the game will ever be the same without him. Speaking of which, I was a little disappointed to find out they only had the soundtrack for Collector editions month after the fact, instead of with Digital Deluxe editions (which costed $40 for basically 3 skins that aren't in game, 1 that is available in game and a weapon sound pack on launch. Pretty meager if you ask me and I was almost certain they said the soundtrack was included, but I wasn't going to pay the $250 CAD for it, that's a little much for what you only really want is the game).

The optimisation of this game is stellar. Not once did I fall  under 144 FPS which is something you don't really say from triple A titles these days. I could even push over 300 FPS if I tweaked some settings. The graphics though, well, that's a different story. There are some textures that are clearly 10 years old and I am not joking when I say this. There are some textures that remind me of Fallout 3. There are also lots of mirrored textures which was done to save on download size for the game. Which is nice for people with slower internet, but I don't think it would be that much bigger for even 512x512 resolution textures in this area.

Well it seems you've made it this far and have been wondering "well why is this a negative  review?" It's simple. There are more gamebreaking bugs that have been adding into  the game recently than there had been on launch. There is a bug where if I press shift very quickly while mid air and switching weapons, the game crashes. This is unacceptable, because I was playing a master level which does not let you load from checkpoints. What's even worse is that I play on Nightmare, so master levels aren't exactly a walk through the park. Hell, I would even argue that a master level on ultra violence is close to being harder than most slayer gates on Nightmare. Regardless, this crash happened to me twice. I disabled the overlay effect in the options menu and tried  to replicate the bug, but it seemed to have been fine... until I crashed on the first level of the game on One Life Mode Nightmare. It's a shame, because this is one of my top games of all time.

There is now a new bug that I have been encountering where the sticky bomb mod for the shotgun would not properly damage enemies and the arachnotron turrets. This is very frustrating and I have lost many lives and lost many Ultra-Nightmare runs because of this.  

 Denuvo didn't really impact my performance, but that's probably because of my system. I can't really notice a difference of 320 ish FPS increased from 300 ish FPS when it was removed, especially when my monitor is only 144HZ. It's nice they removed it but it seems the cheaters are rampant in Battlemode so I won't be playing it soon™.

Please fix this bug, otherwise this is easily one of the most important games of the 8th console generation.

Doom Eternal feels like everything I've liked about Doom up to ten. Opinions and the overall reception of this game are completely subjective. This game's genre isn't a shooter. it's just Doom, a title worthy of it's own genre. A player's enjoyment of this game is what they they want out of it. Looking for a fleshed out story with unique characters and an interesting end? Well, then end certainly is interesting, but this isn't a narrative driven game, and I've found myself better enjoying it when sitting back and sticking a shotgun round into a demon's skull. Personally, I would 100% recommend this game, totally give it a try. This game is a jumping on point for the Doom franchise. I certainly found a new love for the series after playing this game, and it is certainly worth a shot, or multiple, since there's a lot of shooting.

If you liked Doom 2K16 you NEED to start playing this game. Worth full price even no doubt.

*OLD REVIEW*
As much as I love this game I have to leave this review because as of right now I cannot play for more than 20 minutes without the game crashing. When the game first launch I was able to finish it in a few weekends and had an absolute blast the game feels amazing. Now a few months and updates later I can barely get the game to launch let alone play uninterrupted.  I have reinstalled my graphics drivers, validated the cache integrity, reinstalled the game, put antivirus software on silent mode while trying to play, lowering graphics settings which before weren't an issue. I have put in console commands to skip the opening movies but I still frequently get either freezing during loading, random ctd, or a black screen when attempting to load the main menu. I have not seen these issues addressed and will change my review if they go away but for now I can not recommend something that crashes more than a Bethesda title.

-EDIT I was rather doubtful of being able to find a fix listed in the articles commented as I'd been searching online for a couple of weeks without luck but I decided to try the one thing that I'd realized I'd ignored: Borderless windowed. This eliminated the need to skip the intro movies and I haven't had a crash  since I implemented this but the game does feel much more stable with this implemented. part of the reason I'd neglected this issue was that I thought I had already been running in that setting. For those having trouble getting to the main menu due to black screens try +com_skipIntroVideo 1 in the launch commands to skip the intro videos so you can access in game options to change over.

review: Once you get the hang of it, it's just as fun as Doom 2016.
The game is very different from Doom 2016 but in a good way. Its even more fast paced and the brutality is turned up to 11.

Not really into the way the more recent Doom games are going, all the futuristic weapons, multi color flashing demons etc, I miss the regular old shotgun and the chain gun, and maybe even the pistol haha!  But that being said, it is a pretty good game.  You can tell a lot of work went into it.  If you like the previous Doom, you will like this one

Is Doom Eternal a good game? Definitely. Is it as good as 2016? fuck no.
Eternal expands in all the wrong directions with annoying puzzles, trash platforming segments, boring 3rd person cutscenes, long linear maps, a nonsensical plot and an awful change in tone from the pitch perfect 2016. 

-LOST IN DLC PLOT?
Doom Eternal begins with you having somehow escaped hell and flown a space castle to earth, with Vega now running on some space computer. How did this happen after the events of 2016? Don't know. I was half expecting some flashback levels but I guess its left to the story DLC to explain...

-THEY CLIMB NOW!
What new features did you think would be in doom Eternal? if you said hours of climbing up and down walls, well you are a fucking liar. The player must now perform circus tricks, jumping from wall to wall over spinning flames. However if you fail it just teleports you back to the start anyway. So not only is the entire platforming process immersion breaking and annoying, it is also pointless.

-TELL ME A STORY FLOATING KEYCARD!
Remember in 2016 when you ripped a guys arm off for his finger prints. These animations did a great job of both grounding the player in the world and showing your character's personality. In eternal these animations are replaced by giant glowing spinning pickup icons... making the whole thing feel cheap in comparison.

-PURPLE FLOORS OF GARBAGE
In place of any environmental story telling, Eternal fills its levels with annoying cut and paste environmental hazards. Pipes spit out fireballs for no reason, burning chains spin endlessly, and purple goo sticks the player to the floor. Removing all of these things would be an improvement.

-EXPOSITION OF AWFULNESS
The game is drowning in unnecessary lore and cringe third person cutscenes that make little sense unless you trawl through the codex pages. The dialogue is awful and often you will have little idea what anyone is talking about or why events are happening.
2016 minimized taking control away from player, yet was still able to tell a better written and more compelling story.

-PLAY THE WAY I TELL YOU
Environmental puzzles must be solved exactly how the designer intended, want to break a fragile chain? you can't just shoot it with a rocket... an elaborate series of switches and jumps must be performed before the player can punch it. Often these puzzles and their solutions make no intuitive sense, and add nothing to the game whatsoever. Many other changes to gameplay have been implemented to force the player to play a certain way. By far the stupidest of these was reducing the players melee damage to 0, meaning that you cannot melee stagger and glory kill zombies. Instead you must carefully shoot zombies an exact number of times to stagger but not kill them... what fun!

-TUTORIALS INCREASED BY 75%
Intrusive tutorials will now literally kidnap the player into another dimension, imprisoning them within a stupid metal cube. Inside the stupid cube players must press the correct sequence of buttons to be vomited back up into reality.

-AESTHETICAL DECLINE
While trying to invoke nostalgia the art style ends up being boring and uninspired, with many great designs from 2016 such as the possessed being replaced with generic glowing eyed zombies. Other redesigns such as the Revenant are pretty bad.
The old thematic minimal UI of 2016 is replaced by a bunch of "very cool" tacky buttons and icons, complete with key bindings over each icon in case you forget how to shoot. Actual useful information like when abilities come of cool down is lost amongst the mess, when a simple icon flash next to the crosshair would have sufficed.

Doom Eternal
After loads of updates and painful patches I can now review the game when its working at its finest.
This game is almost a far cry from doom 2016, as much as they are most related to one another they as much different from each other in feel and purposes.
While doom 2016 was an immersive, dreadful, clean and fine reimagining of a modern doom game that would make you head bang, comfortable and feel like an actual Doom slayer...
Doom Eternal is just an experimental, bright, rough and intense experience with a very light tone. Not like doom 2016 ever took itself overly serious but this might be the total opposite "taking itself seriously".

The game is grand looking but aint beautiful.
Engaging but not putting you in the slayes shoes. 
Full of lore but not believable.

To enjoy this game you must forget about its predecessor, and dont dare compare them while playing.
Tho textures are sharper, lightings are smoother, loading are faster...
Doom 2016 still surpasses Eternal by modeling, color scheme and texture verity, in my opinion also in art style.
Doom Eternal shines at its combat and intensity, its action and the reliance on your reaction, its progression and aggression.
Take a deep breath, think and execute everything you know at your own pace, at your own difficulty and get this adrenaline working.

That is all I can say about Doom Eternal single player.
6.95/10 the game misses in my opinion on atmosphere and feel but the combat and the game itself are well made.

+ Didn't encounter many bugs
+ Decent story

- Battlemode to me is forgettable

[h1] DOOM Eternal is the best shooter of this decade I honestly doubt anything will come close to DOOM Eternal now. [/h1]
DOOM has always been special to me and the same goes for the millions of fans out there and I as a fan certainly wasn't disappointed in the slightest when I finally got to sit down and play the game I have been so hyped to play. DOOM Eternal is so much more than just a simple DOOM 2016 copy and contains much much more gameplay variety both in terms of how you manage ammo but also how you take down demons. DOOM Eternal is a very different game in some areas compared to 2016 but is that bad? Personally I don't really think so. It has plenty of new ideas thrown in there to make the game fresh but still keeps the fun combat that DOOM is known for. I can't wait for the expansion to come out but I will update my review once I have gotten the chance to play it. 

DOOM eternal gameplay: You will recognize the gameplay from older DOOM games as It's still the incredibly fast paced shooter we have all come to know and love. DOOM Eternal does however have a few differences in terms of how you do combat this time as Chainsaw = Ammo = Firelauncher = Armor and you can use grenades too like explosives and freeze grenades to stun some enemies making them easier to take down. You don't have a lot of ammo so the chainsaw suddenly become a bigger gameplay element and some like this idea and some don't but personally I really enjoy it as it gives the game an extra layer of strategy over DOOM 2016. Not only does DOOM Eternal feature new elements in combat. The more you play, The more new tactics you will learn and the more you will understand how the weapons work on different demons. DOOM is a lot about fast movement and knowing how to take down your enemies efficiently. This is why DOOM has such a big replay value as you feel you can always do better. I personally feel like the more time I spend playing DOOM Eternal the more I learn the flow of combat and it's a what makes me so dedicated to DOOM as it's all about mastery to me. My goal is to play on Ultra Nightmare and eventually with enough practice on nightmare I will get there. It's fun and I am having a great time blasting through the campaign and it never gets boring to me. 

Story: DOOM in my personal opinion has never really been about a deep or meaningful story and it's just kinda there to give you something outside of the already fast and so satisfying to play combat but there is a story in DOOM Eternal and it's okish. It's nothing extremely important to me and it never was in a DOOM game but it's there and it's fine. I know what I am here for when I buy a game like DOOM and it's not exactly a deep or crazy in depth story I buy a game like DOOM for anyway. It's the fast combat, Fun weapons and addicting non stop action there makes DOOM what it is. 

Soundtrack: DOOM Eternal's soundtrak is metal but what I like about DOOM Eternal's soundtrack is that it also puts modern elements like electronic/dubstep to the mix like DOOM 2016's soundtrack did. Personally I don't really mind this and it doesn't destroy the tone of what DOOM is in my opinion as it still keeps the heavy guitar sounds in there which to me is what DOOM has always been about when it comes to the soundtrack. The first DOOM's soundtrack was inspired by 90s Thrash Metal and artists like Alice In Chains, Pantera, Slayer, Judas Priest and Metallica which makes it a game unlike the rest in the series but I have to admit that DOOM 2016's soundtrack and Eternal's soundtrack is very unique in tone and sound too as modern elements to Metal isn't really a bad idea in my view. I don't really see much of a point arguing on whether or not one genre is better over the other as DOOM Eternal and 2016's soundtrack is more than enough proof that they can go hand in hand and provide an interesting and brutal sound each in their own way. 

So what is missing? 
DOOM Eternal is a fantastic game and absolutely is the best the series has ever been. DOOM 2016 revived the old school FPS formular once more and brought back DOOM into the modern day of gaming which i highly respect ID software for as the FPS scene of gaming was dominated by modern military shooters. I wanna make it clear that DOOM's singleplayer campaign is fantastic and I have spent almost all my hours ingame playing only the campaign but I feel it's missing the classic Deathmatch modes there made DOOM not only a fantastic singleplayer experience but also an awesome multiplayer shooter. There is a battlemode in the game too but I don't really feel that can compare to the classic Deathmatch DOOM is known for so I really hope they will add this someday during DOOM Eternal's lifespan.


Conclusion: DOOM Eternal has been praised for it's addicting combat, music and just how fun and over the top it is and DOOM will always be my favorite shooter ever made. DOOM Eternal was everything I as a fan could hope for and it seems to be the case with the rest of the fanbase. I don't actually think I have played a single bad DOOM game yet and that goes to show how ID software understands how to make shooters. Some things end but DOOM is Eternal my friend. 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M5XhV3YarKg
Literally the most badass game ever made. I haven't had this much fun with a shooter in a decade.

This game is Doom 2016 but pretty much everything is better. From the feel of the guns to the new demons, to the new mechanics, it's all just better. Although there is one thing that I absolutely love. And that is the slayer gates. These things are super tough trials that you can find in most stages of the game, and they are the biggest power trip in the game. These trials will throw enemies from late game levels while you're at say level 5. You will have to use every single tool you have at your disposal to survive one of these things. You constantly have to monitor your health, ammo and armor while dodging attacks and considering what demon to go for with what weapon all at a moment's notice. These trials are tough but still don't feel unfair. When you die it's almost always your fault, and it doesn't feel as infuriating as dying by random chance. And that feeling that you were almost there but just didn't make it keeps you going. But when you finally beat a slayer gate, it feels so incredibly amazing that it's hard to describe. This, I think is Doom at it's best. They are balanced well enough that a competent player should be able to beat it in a few tries on normal or hard difficulty, but still feel that rush when you finally beat it. But the thing that really makes you feel powerful is that, despite the odds stacked against you, you are in control the entire time. With your mobility, you decide when and where the fight happens, (to an extent) and this I think, is what really makes Doom so much fun. Another thing that massively helps the experience is the amazing soundtrack. When your battling through hordes of demons while BFG Division is blasting in the background just makes you feel like a badass. Although one negative I have about the game is the marauder. The real issue I have with the enemy is not that he was a bad boss fight, (In fact it was a fantastic boss fight) or that he's a hard enemy, but that when he shows up as a regular enemy, you have to kill literally every other enemy so you can focus on this one enemy, which really breaks up the pace of the game. The real problem however, is that he is in control, which as you might have noticed is the complete opposite of what makes Doom fun, and that is my real problem with him. Although, he fortunately doesn't show up very much, so he's not that big of a negative. Finally I'd like to cover some of the criticism this game gets, one of which being the heavy restriction of ammo. In my opinion I think it achieves its goal of having people switch their weapons more, which I think makes the game more fun. For example, in Doom 2016, I found myself almost exclusively using the Super Shotgun, which, while fun to blast through hordes of demons without a care in the world, it became somewhat boring, because you had no incentive really to use any other weapon unless there were demons outside of it's effective range. (And this is Doom we're talking about, so not many) In Doom Eternal however, despite it having the meat hook which lets you get into a demon's face for massive damage, the ammo restriction discouraged only using the super shotgun, (among other things) which I think gives the game much more depth as you have to really think about what weapon you're using and if it's worth using all that ammo. This game is definitely worth getting for 60 moners and absolutely worth getting for 30 moners.

tl;dr: Slayer gates are awesome and are the high point of the game, marauder (as an enemy) bad because it makes you do the opposite of the slayer gates, the restriction of ammo gives the game more depth, and it's definitely worth 60 moners.
There's never enough ammo. NEVER ENOUGH! And way too many ridiculous platform/jumping puzzles. They lost sight of what DOOM is supposed to be. SAD!

review:
Lets get these two main issues out of the way very quickly.

First, there is only one water section that I never look forward to... In regards to gameplay negativity, that's about it.

Second, if you aren't running this game on modern hardware, expect Hell to be risen on your graphics cards. You need a pretty beefy GPU if you want to get good and consistent frame rates at simply 1080p resolution. I'm playing this on a 2080ti and even then when I touch the area where my graphics card is on my computer halfway through a level, it feels like a campfire so be cautious of that.

With that out of the way, THIS IS THE GREATEST GAME I HAVE EVER PLAYED IN MY LIFE!!!

You boot up the game for the first time and it immediately throws you in mayhem. You're already slaughtering demons all the way up until you beat the final boss (except during that water section) with little to no breaks in between.

This game is a roller coaster ride that even people who hate shooters will love. The pacing of the gameplay also never stops ramping up each level. You encounter new enemy types, you solve some cool puzzles, you steadily get new guns and fun weapon mods, and the lore is so interesting that it's one of the first games where I genuinely had interest in reading the codex forms (albeit, I still tend to prefer just audible voice acting for storytelling overall). You learn more about the Doom Slayer's origins and you expand on the his original crew, the stories of hell, and more.

And about the dialogue, it's bone chilling... Without spoiling anything, this game will creep you out with it's dialogue on death and torture.

And I'm gonna be real, in any shooter game, exploring always felt worthless. Until now, I never managed to find any game that felt worth while for looking around the environment and scavenging for more stuff. THIS GAME... it's always fun. The collectables for more content and weapon mods were wacky and some even led to more demon slaughtering opportunities.

And I'm not kidding... THE SLAYER GATES will tire you out. Every slayer gate completed lead me to shutting off the game and wanting to go for a walk with a water in hand. They made you exhausted but it was still always so fun to the point where even when I lost, I was eager to reboot the level and try again until I won. Let that be the prime example for how fast and fun this game is.

Just be cautious, it does noticeably have a larger learning curve than Doom 2016. Playing this game on higher difficulties will require A LOT of button memorization considering there are like 8 (technically 9) weapons, 20 suit techniques, a truck load of weapon mods and mastery mods, and you need to be really good at tracking the ammo you have in all weapons and the cooldowns on your equipment since one wrong decision will definitely cost you especially if you want to do an Nightmare run.

And the Battle Mode... It's pretty good. Although it isn't the first thing I'd prefer to jump into when I boot up the game, if you want a different experience, it doesn't disappoint. It's still super fast, it incentivizes fast-paced gameplay with knowing your mechanics and cooldown management, and if you have friends, it's a fun way to interact with others.

TO CONSOLE PLAYERS... Don't play this on console let alone use an Xbox controller on PC.

Please... just... just don't.

You lose a lot of options for button swapping making weapon swapping slower and clunkier, making turns in an environment this fast-paced just punishes you, and it's just overall a hindrance of what you can accomplish just with a standard keyboard and mouse on PC.

100/100. Buy it. Don't miss out. This better get Game of the Year. It deserves it.

Campaign:
PROS:
-Gameplay
You run, you dash, you jump, you slaughter, you punch, you RIP. AND. TEAR. Even on tiny baby difficulty, this game kept me on my toes and constantly going "Oh SHIT!" every other moment.

-Plot
Somehow they made Doomguy even better, with his lack of care or judgment towards others. Your job is his job - to kill. Nothing else. The maps can be hauntingly frightening and also absolutely stunning and gorgeous.

-The Meathook
YES.

-The Unmakyr
Y E S .

CONS:
-Ammo.
Especially if you compare it to D2016, it's borderline annoying how low your ammo is in Eternal. The low ammo will have you pulling out the chainsaw on any innocent zombies you see, but I couldn't help but feel that sometimes needing to chop down zombies for ammo would interrupt my flow of decimating Hell's creations.

-Crater-sized plot holes (that you possibly might need to pay for in the future if you want to know)
There is 0 connection between the ending of Doom 2016 and the entire game of Doom Eternal. It's definitely a sequel, but it refuses to acknowledge that.

-The UAC
The little hologram pops up and it gets very cliche very fast. And also very annoying. Stop talking to me, cyberlady. How do you even know I'm here killing demons? Aren't you supposed to be a pre-recorded message? I hate you, cyberlady.

Multiplayer:
PROS:
-It's quick.

-...

CONS:
This isn't one of those "git gud" gamemodes. It merely lacks entertainment.
It's an extremely busted 2v1 match-making system. You can play as The Slayer, or you can team up with someone and both of you can select to play from a handful of Demons. (haha who am i kidding, you're either playing as axeboi or flyboi)

I typed a whole entire spiel about how busted Battlemode is, but I'll just leave it as this: If you want to enjoy Multiplayer mode, play as a Demon.

I begged God Himself for a co-op survival mode that you can play with buddies. One where you can sit back, sip on a beer, and slaughter demons with your friends or online players. My fingers shall remain crossed, though at this point, I'm starting to lose blood circulation.

The exact opposite of its recent predecessor, which can be summarized as going from one arena, getting locked in, mobs spawn, kill all mobs (and hunt down stragglers) to unlock and progress to the next arena for a rinse and repeat. This is killing light packs of mobs between pointless jump puzzles. For me, two hours in and still getting hit with new mechanics, back to back to back to back to back to back. To be honest, it's painful, and I lost interest real quick. I had expected a nice after work, low thinking gorefest but got drowned in the pointless mechanics.

Not joking, a *stupid* number of new mechanics. Some for combat, many not. There are several disparate skill trees that have painfully little impact. Numerous combat mechanics (off the top of my head): sixish new finishers, flame thrower thing, ice & standard grenades, two new melee types, all the weapon modes (and their upgrades); it just goes on and on. There's forced exploration and secret hunting for weapon and armor upgrades. Oh, and the frequent jump puzzle  ... because doom needed that, right? Complete with swinging from bars, wall climbing, and double jump resets; hello Mirrors Edge anyone?

Many of the mechanics are forced. For example, you have little ammo capacity and are forced to weave in slow finishing moves into combat (which can be minorly sped up in the skill tree), one to replenish ammo, another move to get health, and another for armor.  Feels like all the rejected mechanics for the previous games were green-lighted here. Again, for me, it takes away from the authentic Doom Experience and belittles it to a forced cadence of artistically expressed finishing moves.

Not my cup of tea.

Let me know if the drowning mechanic onslaught tapers off...

review:
Dear god, yes!

This game is brutal; one of the most intense and overwhelming FPSes I've played... ever. If you are overwhelmed, don't be afraid to set it to an easier difficulty. Don't be afraid to set it on I'm Too Young To Die, if you must.

Doom 2016 was good, even if it did have a slight aftertaste of the devs still playing it safe and pulling their punches even as they were changing the FPS genre and Doom's public image forever. They were coming off of 8-10 years of building Doom in the wrong direction, so it's forgivable. Doom Eternal doesn't hold back from the start, and things get even more crazy going forward. Everything is bigger and more over the top than Doom 2016. Earth is a cataclysmic mess and it's pretty clear that the only person who is able to stand up and survive all this crap is the Doom Slayer. And, most importantly, we get to see Heaven, finally, and what exactly the demons are and why souls are made to suffer in Hell.

I can't recommend this game enough. The full price is very much worth it.

Take UT2004, make it single player then add blood, gore and black metal. Doom eternal is fast paced, dark first person shooter with rather arcade gameplay.  Every monster has it's unique way of dealing with, so it's never like "just shoot everything that moves".  Despite almost all fights are very intense there is always plenty of ammo and health. Levels are beautiful, blood and guts are everywhere yet it's aesthetically pleasing somehow.

Okay, i'm just gonna say it. This is the best doom game
I love games that don't hold your hand and just puts you in a battle for you to learn on your own. Doom eternal does just that. It chokes you almost to death and then throws you in a pit of chaotic demons. And once you learn that. You crawl out and beat the shit out of Hugo Martin for throwing you down there.

If you play this game and actually learn from it and you don't feel like a badass destroying everything in sight, then shit and cry again and go to Super Weenie Hut Jr's.

pog

First things first: It is a good game and worth its money.

I've only played the single player as the 2016 Multiplayer didn't really satisfied me and I wasnt yet in the mood to give Eternal's Multiplayer a try.

My (personal) trouble is: I've enjoyed Doom 2016 far more.

That may be partially due to the fact that Doom 2016 was completly different from shooters at that time, while Doom Eternal is now "just another" iteration of Doom 2016 (and that point doesn't really qualify as a con). But it also feels like the Devs fell into some "more, bigger, better" traps and lost some of the original spirit.

Encounter design "felt" better in 2016 than in Eternal.
For my personal taste, the Devs went a little bit too far with item scarcity in favor of farming with special abilities. In combination with the fact that many enemies almost require a specific weapon to avoid spending too much ammo, the micro management takes some of the enjoyable, instinct driven havok of the first game away - at least in my eyes.

Don't take this as a real con, but depending on your experience with it's predecessor, maybe dampen your expectations a bit.

In the first age, in the first battle, when the shadows first lengthened, one stood. Burned by the embers of Armageddon, his soul blistered by the fires of Hell and tainted beyond ascension, he chose the path of perpetual torment. In his ravenous hatred he found no peace; and with boiling blood he scoured the Umbral Plains seeking vengeance against the dark lords who had wronged him. He wore the crown of the Night Sentinels, and those that tasted the bite of his sword named him... the Doom Slayer.

Tempered by the fires of Hell, his iron will remained steadfast through the passage that preys upon the weak. For he alone was the Hell Walker, the Unchained Predator, who sought retribution in all quarters, dark and light, fire and ice, in the beginning and the end, and he hunted the slaves of Doom with barbarous cruelty; for he passed through the divide as none but demon had before.

And in his conquest against the blackened souls of the doomed, his prowess was shown. In his crusade, the seraphim bestowed upon him terrible power and speed, and with his might he crushed the obsidian pillars of the Blood Temples. He set forth without pity upon the beasts of the nine circles. Unbreakable, incorruptible, unyielding, the Doom Slayer sought to end the dominion of the dark realm.

he age of his reckoning was uncounted. The scribes carved his name deep in the tablets of Hell across eons, and each battle etched terror in the hearts of the demons. They knew he would come, as he always had, as he always will, to feast on the blood of the wicked. For he alone could draw strength from his fallen foes, and ever his power grew, swift and unrelenting.

None could stand before the horde but the Doom Slayer. Despair spread before him like a plague, striking fear into the shadow-dwellers, driving them to deeper and darker pits. But from the depths of the abyss rose The Great One, a champion mightier than all who had come before. The Titan, of immeasurable power and ferocity. He strode upon the plain and faced the Doom Slayer, and a mighty battle was fought on the desolate plains. The Titan fought with the fury of the countless that had fallen at the Doom Slayer's hand, but there fell the Titan, and in his defeat the shadow horde were routed.

And in his terrible rancor between worlds and through time, the Hell Walker found the wretch who shall not be named, but in his heresy was loyal to his evil cause. The wretch adorned the Doom Slayer in a mighty armor, wrought in the forges of Hell, impenetrable and unyielding. With sword and shield of adamantine strength, the Doom Slayer set to banishing all that were left unbroken by his savagery to the void. Yet as the mighty Titan fell and dread engulfed the armies of Doom, the demon priests of the Blood Temples laid a trap to capture this scourge of Hell. Insatiable, even by the vanquishing of the Great One, the Hell Walker sought prey in the tombs of the Blood Keep. And blinded by his fervor, the lure drew him in. The priests brought down the temple upon the Doom Slayer, and in his defeat entombed him in the cursed sarcophagus. The mark of the Doom Slayer was burned upon his crypt, a warning to all of Hell that the terror within must never be freed. There he lies still, and ever more, in silent suffering.

Some things about this game threw me off, especially compared to Doom 4. The hub map feels out of place in the doomiverse. The levels, while visually stunning, didn't really make me think 'Doom'; More 'Gears Of War'. I personally preferred the enemy design of the previous entry, the grotesque grittiness has been lost to bright, easily-identified colors.
And the soundtrack was entirely forgettable.
That said, the gameplay and action were improved in almost every single way. Everything listed above was made up for by the sweet, sweet action. It really is a better game than Doom 4, I just personally prefer the look and sound of 4 slightly more.

If you liked Doom 2016 then you will like Doom Eternal! Less gritty and dark as its previous release, Doom Eternal offers a glimps of how Doom would have been if the Tech existed during the original launch in the 90s. The dynamic gameplay is exactly what you would expect from an arena shooter. 10/10 would absolutely recommend to anyone who loves these kinds of games.

Do not buy this unless you can get it for at least 50% off.
The positives to this game are the visuals. The developers went with what the original doom enemies look like and enhanced them.
Now for the negatives.
- As others pointed out, this game is more of a platformer in that there is a lot of jumping involved. It almost seems like there is more jumping than killing in this game.
- The weapons: You are constantly running out of ammo, then to top that you will have to use certain weapons with certain enemies which is constant instead of certain weapons with for certain situations. NOBODY ASKED FOR THIS.
- I am okay with the junk zombie enemies constantly re-spawning in groups, this made it feel a little more like doom wen you can kill groups of zombies, but I REALLY HATED that the only way you could replenish is to have to kill an enemy in order to get health, armor, ammo, OH and in order to get that stuff it all depended if you set them on fire, froze them, or just blow them up with a grenade.
- The levels are linear. Yeah you end up back at a center room but once you completed a path, there is something that stops you from going back that way for most levels. Only level that came close to feeling like the originals was the Gore Nest level which was level 7 I believe.
- It is the same crap as Doom 2016, you enter a area or room and fight it out with a bunch of demons, after you kill them all you can move on. Nothing like the original where you had the excitement of unknowingly walking through a hallway and wondering if the wall next to you will just open up to have a bunch demons spill out onto you.

Honestly, the original Doom, Doom2 are so much better with all the free mods out there.

One of the most addictive games i have ever played and never stops getting old and is far superior than DOOM 2016. If you hear criticisms like "low ammo,too cartoony, can't be creative, muraders are bad, or too hard," they either haven't experimented with the sandbox or don't get the DOOM franchise at all. 
 
    Lower ammo capacity makes you more on your feet and keep an eye on your resources, doesn't make it bad.The DOOM games have always been about managing resources and DOOM 2016 failed at this, so this was them correcting this mistake and making it more viable to manage. DOESN'T MEAN YOU HAVE TO CONSERVE AMMO DO NOT DO THAT!! 

  The cartoony artsyle is a homage to the original DOOM games. They have always been cartoony, the whole plot in DOOM 2 was a revenge plot for a pet bunny for fuck sake.

   People think you can't be creative in the game because "you have to shoot a grenade in the caco's mouth" This is the worst option in the game since you have to wait for the animation and have to be precise with the shot. Doing weapon combo kills the caco's instantly but people only played the game once and complained about it without experimenting which is pathetic.
  
   The murauder is a really good enemy and have to learn his moveset. If you think "oh I don't like getting good at killing an enemy" then you are being really ignorant and not looking what the game is. Yes, the murauder pressures you in the arenas, so does all the other enemies, you just have to get gud bottom line. He is a joy to fight once you understand his moveset and role he places in the arenas
   
   This is a game you really have to see what the devs are trying to accomplish and not play the game once then complain it's bad. Don't believe the negative reviews with these kind of complaints, they have only played the game once and don't know what the franchise is about. I mostly blame DOOM 2016 for this since that game created a group of players that only stuck with one gun and why DOOM 2016 is really bad and horribly balanced on an objective level. This is the superior DOOM game and i would recommend anyone who is skeptical to pick this up. Don't be so harsh judging the game at first, trust me this game will kick your ass a lot at first, but once you understand what the game is trying to do you will love it. Don't judge this game by the first playthrough.
UNF!
Unspeakable

I will preface this review with these few statements: I haven't played the game since Empowered Demons was about to come out (Updating it today for the spooky event). I pre-purchased the game for both the hype but also DOOT skin. I have played Doom, Doom 2, and DOOM (2016), haven't played Doom 3, although the first two were more ports and eventually in Eternal. Haven't tried DOOM64 yet! Most of my content is on the single player portion but roughly 40 hours were spent in Battlemode.

"Rip and tear until it is done!" The motto of this game,huh? Well, I like to think so! It feels more fast paced and fun than playing 2016 was, even with some oddities. So, how to really start? I'll start with the campaign for y'all.

Campaign~
The singleplayer campaign isn't hugely long, at least not for me. It was a nice good length, you can rip into demons and just enjoy the gameplay, its got lore and a plotline for those who really want it but it can be entirely skipped if you go by the cutscenes. The layouts aren't the most innovative but it doesn't need to be in my opinion, with the nice little parkour sections to just delight in, nothing really complex, just simple stuff for the most part. The puzzles aren't really that hard to get, it's more about the combat stuff, with plenty of different demons to crush and gut with your arsenal. I will warn new players ahead of time, the ammo economy is strange, you don't have a lot of ammo but you use a chainsaw on the fodder demons to refill your reserves. The grenades, flamebelch, and even the new form of melee (Blood Punch is the main one, chainsaw too for ammo, another weapon later on!) are all a bit different than I expected, not in a bad way, freezing enemies or burning them for armor is handy, chainsawing demons is also so stress relieving! The boss fights are interesting in my opinion, they sometimes are frustrating or even can be enemies you'll see again later! The combat can get hectic sometimes, at least on Nightmare it was for me, although muscle memory helped me until then so I built up new memory! As unprofessional as this review will be, here is all my opinions. 9/10 Campaign

Arcade Mode~
This is something I only played a little bit but I did find it fun, let me use stuff I normally might not get to! I will be including the cheats you can earn in the campaign in this category since it was a lot like it, same with Master Levels. So, the cheats are absolutely a treat worth replaying levels and looking for secrets more! The best cheat in my opinion is the QuakeCON audience! I like getting cheers while gunning down demons! The Master Levels are interesting, harder versions of the level you played before, I only had the Cultist Lab one for playing since I played it shortly after beating the game the first time, it was a fun mission to replay with everything from Prowlers to Cyberdemons now! Extra Singleplayer Content 10/10

Battlemode~
I didn't hate this mode, actually love the mode itself! It's not bad, just could use bug fixes from my memory, maybe more options to choose from. The mode is fairly simple, it's two player demons and their minions against the Doom Slayer player, demons win the round if they kill the slayer, slayer wins when having both demons dead at the same time. You can choose an upgrade each round, tie breaker lets you pick a powerful ability or upgrade. My gripe is that it could use more than JUST Battlemode, along with proper matchmaking by at least skill. 7/10 for Multiplayer Content, Battlemode is fun and interesting.

Cosmetics~
They look nice, fairly easy to get too. I personally like how it's all free with the battlepass it has, free content is always a blessing. Monthly cosmetics are good, snag ones from themes you like, they've ranged from meme-ish with the hipster to cool throwbacks like Hack To The Future stuff. 9/10 Cosmetics, just personal opinion on them.

Overall~
I think if you enjoyed 2016 doom or want to try a game for stress relief, I recommend to you this game! If you liked the original doom games, try it! Even better is that if you collect all the cheats, you can play Doom and then with the password you can play Doom 2! (Or maybe it's the other way around?)

It's great strictly gameplay wise. Doom 2016 meets a MOBA is the best way I can describe the new mechanics and systems. Sadly, the combat is the only part I can praise. Everything else feels against what Doom is about and is much closer to the original Darksiders. (Update: while reflecting on this the combat itself feels very Darksiders too because of the psuedo-moba elements. So essentially, think Darksiders 2 for combat, but environments are Darksiders 1, but it's an FPS.)

The story is ok I guess, not that it should be as up-front as it is. It ruins the pacing set by the combat and only feeds to a loud minority that care about lore in a Doom game. Plus there are already plenty of plot-holes between the Eternal and D16 alone.

Many environmental hazards just suck. They aren't fun and don't affect demons at all, so they can't be used strategically to help dispatch demons.

The boss fights are all really lame. Personally I would argue the only good one is the Khan Maykr fight, but even then a certain mechanic regarding the floor (despite the boss being a flying enemy) makes it hard to say that much.

The chainsaw rework is polarizing. I'll just say that any any points in favor of the change are easily disputable and it just comes down to whether or not you like reloading in a Doom game.


The Marauder ought to be given a further reach with his axe attacks. This way he'll be a much more aggressive enemy and the "middle" zone that you can retaliate is much more defined.
(update: he was actually changed in a patch to make him easier in some way. I'm not sure how they changed it, but my balancing idea is more applicable to how he was on release day)

Many of the demons made to look like Doom 2 demons look like trash. The Archviles are probably the best looking out of these, but somehow the classic sprite still looks better. This point comes down to opinion though, so take it as you will.

Battlemode got hacked to hell and back within days of release. An anticheat patch was released, but that causes some other issues, such as input delays in story mode, or the reportedly game just not working on Linux.

Those are all issues from my day 1 experience that I can just think of right now. I'll probably update this at some point with more actual gameplay issues.
Outside of gameplay, a recent patch added an aforementioned anticheat program to help Battlemode and an upcoming Dark Souls-essque invasion system. The issue is that the program requires Kernal level access to your computer, similarly to Valorant. This is terrible because this essentially means that to play you must allow full access of your PC to ID, which could be catastrophic if the system was cracked. (Update, this has been removed, but i'm leaving this section here because the fact that it was ever a problem is a problem.)

Update as of 5/19/20:
Also I just remembered that the enemy AI bugs for everyone at least once. No matter what, you will find at least one demon just standing around in a corner somewhere each playthrough. Pain elementals just don't work though because their projectiles, lost souls, are the most broken part of the game. In my entire playthrough, I don't think I got damaged by a lost soul once because they were too busy bouncing around like rubber balls.
After remembering this and thinking over my previous criticisms, I don't think this game is worth buying. Support the series emotionally to hell and back and hope the sequel is just like it if you prefer it to 2016, but there's no way to look at anything regarding this game and not feel duped for buying it.

Update as of 9/25/20:
It has been months since the game's release and not all of the Master Levels (more challenging versions of campaign levels) have been released. Besides that, a whole new DLC campaign was announced as well. While I can't yet talk about the gameplay for either, I find it extremely disheartening that the fans had to wait through two delays before the game's release and even the people that pre-ordered the game for $90 still don't have the full game. During all of this though, Battlemode has gotten several sets of unique cosmetic rewards for playing. I'm not sure why, but that just feels ass-backward to me.
In addition to this, patches are still being released to fix bugs in the storymode, despite the game's two delays suggesting there wouldn't be as many bugs as there were. I can't even give this game an "A for effort" anymore, unfortunately. Still as disappointed as day one and I hope that the next DooM game doesn't suffer from the same pitfalls that held back such amazing combat.

The combat is faster,and even more brutal,with absolutely stunning glory kill animations that never get old.It makes you use every single gun and master them,the Arenas are made to test every ounce of your mastery,they are fun/beautifully designed,yet exceedingly challenging,every single game mechanic WILL by the end of the game be mastered (that's what it took me to beat nightmare difficulty).

[h1] Mick Gordon,the only thing i fear is you  [/h1]

Gordon has single-handedly carried both Doom 2k16 and Doom Eternal,this man's soundtracks make the combat and gore achieve ungodly amounts of insanity and adrenaline,some of these tracks are my favorite's and i listen too them everyday,but i think he did a better job in 2k16,it had much more "unique" tracks compared to Eternal.

[h1] Doom Eternal and the Quest for Ammo  [/h1]

This game has insanely low amounts of ammo compared too 2k16.You will have to chainsaw a lot while playing to get the ammo back,this was enough for the game to be refunded by a good amount of people.

I can understand,and i agree,there have been many times that i had to run across the arena to chainsaw kill a guy for ammo,i personally don't mind this at all,and i love the glory kill animations,but this could prove to be a big problem for some people.

[h1] Buying Doom Eternal isn't a question,it's the answer  [/h1]

While it has ammo problems,the rest of the game shines brilliantly,a polished masterpiece of demon killing and violence,i believe if you can give this game a fair try,you won't be able to go back too Doom 2k16,atleast i can't.

DOOM ETERNAL

The DOOM reboot from 2016 got a sequel! Did it live up to it's expectations? In my opinion, yes and no. While the game is faster-paced, a lot of the arenas decreased in size, which actually ended up messing with the core mechanic of DOOM, running-gunning-and-looting.

The story gets you started, once again right away with the action. This time, they got rid of your pistol and just gave you the pump shotty. This was a good design choice, as I felt like the pistol in the previous game was kind of annoying to use and didn't serve any real purpose other that to be that gun that you use as a very last resort, but enough about that. The story is better than 2016 DOOM, with the Sentinels, the Doomguy origins, it's vastly more interesting than learning about the foundations of the UAC.

The gameplay is faster-paced thanks to Doomguy getting a dash ability. While this ability is great for getting across the arenas, it also makes you realize just how much they've cut down on your space to fight in some areas/arenas. While I believe this is fine for the secret encounters, for normal arenas this is unacceptable. The Mars base and even Hell in 2016 I felt had a lot of verticality to their arenas, where as even here with the dash upgrade i wasn't seeing much. There were jump pads but those often ended up screwing me over to find a demon on top waiting to punish me. The chainsaw actually ends up being really useful, as it has a charge that you can use on lower demons to farm ammo if you're having trouble finding some in the arena. The collectibles are really fun to find and the cheat codes are funny/insane to use.

Before I get to the art design, i'd like to touch briefly on the multiplayer. Firstly, it seems the promised mechanic of invading another players' story mode is still in the works, so it might get better. However, as it stands, the multiplayer is very barebones. Battlemode can be fun, but not for more than 3 matches in a row sadly. The mechanics and gameplay of it are interesting, but we lost DOOM 2016's PVP, and I feel that it's a huge step backwards and something they could've maybe looked into porting or revamping.

The art style is... different. The gritty and dark looking demons have been changed over to look more like their original DOOM counterparts. While I can't say i'm a fan of what they did to the Revenant, all the other demons (especially the Cacodemon) look better. The weapon redesigns are also very welcome.

First, I would say if you liked DOOM 2016 for just the story then I liked this game's story for around 2 play throughs. Other than that I would not recommend this game for it's multiplayer or "seasonal" rewards. I would give this a sideways thumb just because it's not the greatest. The developers could have done so much better with the online also I have had problems with the punchable objects. I sometimes can't punch them (they don't activiate) or I can't climb on them until after multiple tries.
 
I liked the game at first. The "seasons", multiplayer, and parts of the campaign kinda made it boring after a while. First the "seasons" you level them up by playing the campaign, online, and doing weekly challenges (random stuff in campaign and online). The challenges are usually I thought 6 campaign and 2 online. Now it looks like 3 campaign 3 online. I would be fine with that if the online wasn't garbage. 

Online is 1 vs 2 either you suck at Slayer and get obliterated or you and your teammate demon are obliterated by an overpowered Slayer there are barely any even matches. Also with online if one person leaves the lobby the closes so if you are a high level, low levels tend to leave causing you to wait forever by a cycle of find lobby, lobby closes, back to main menu. I wish they kept the same online as the previous DOOM at least that one was fun to play. 

The campaign gets stale after running completely through it multiple times. I beat the game beginning to end around 4 times now. I made a new save after my game bugged and said I didn't do something. Now I just put a bunch of cheats on and blast through a mission to get the weekly challenges done in less than 30 minutes and it's boring as hell. I am tired of the same thing over and over again. There is a "demon prison" (small re-playable arena) in the game but I could never really use it because it fills after missions (I don't really know) but once I beat the game, I never get the chance to actually use it. 

Also you get a lot less experience for the season if you replay levels. I kept making new saves to level it up because you need or needed (I didn't really check this season) 100 of thousands of xp and you only get less than 10k per mission when you replay them. You mainly get xp in the campaign from the mission challenges which once you complete them you can no longer get xp from them. So the campaign is basically useless to replay for xp unless you do the weekly challenges.

Hopefully they add more stuff with the dlc besides campaign and maps for online. The game lost all of its "wow" for me. I feel like its more of a job then a game at this point. The main problem is the campaign is a series of arenas that have the same enemy spawn points every time and give little to no reward. I literally just run through with the BFG and kill everything in seconds and go to the next arena (with cheats on). 

I still play the game to complete the weekly challenges whenever they release a new "season" until I get it all. Also I will play through the dlc campaign.

The game is great. 

The recently added DRM is terrible and was added after the fact, without my consent. This should be illegal tbh.

Edit: They deleted it. Thanks for removing your forcibly installed malware which shouldn't be there in the first place.

Let me start by saying that I fucking love this game. It's one of the best brand-new FPS games in ages, it's one of my personal favorites, and it's a contender for my game of the year. Unfortunately for it, it won't actually WIN that spot, because I waited until this year to play Outer Wilds, one of the greatest games ever made and the most perfectly-designed videogame since Our Lord and Savior Portal. But were it not for that misfortune, Doom Eternal would be up there.

What I love about this game is what a lot of people kind of hate: It's incredibly tightly designed, with a lot of interlocking systems designed to make fights constantly intense, frantic, and brutal in a way that pushes the player towards maximal physical skill (in terms of reflex) and a massive amount of snap decision-making. It feels exhilarating and amazing and it's totally unlike any other FPS out there that I've played. It also feels like a logical progression of Doom 16's design choices, which moved away from the traditional gameplay loop and design of older Doom games and towards a new loop that emphasized keeping you in the fight longer. That loop means that fights have to carry a huge amount of load that they really didn't in old Doom games, which had as strong an emphasis on exploration and resource management as anything else. Doom Eternal's solution is to embed resource management into fights in a way that feels less tacked-on than Doom 16: Glory Kills were always an integral part of Doom 16's loop, but they technically weren't required, and the chainsaw was a definite afterthought for players because come on. Especially once everyone realized how broken Rich Get Richer was... 

Anyways, this makes fights more interesting and frantic by pushing a lot more cognitive load onto the player. And the whole game is more brutal due to the do-what-we-want-or-die design philosophy. And I think all of that works beautifully. However, not everyone wanted or expected that kind of design. Maybe they weren't clued in enough to realize just what a departure Doom 16 was, maybe they weren't paying attention when the team was talking about Doom Eternal pre-release (Hugo was very forthright and honest about what the game would be). Maybe they thought they'd like they'd like the new direction and didn't. The point is, I feel like a lot of the negative buzz about this game comes from people who were expecting something other than what they got. And honestly? that's okay. Not everyone has to like the new direction. It's a pretty radical shift if you're a shooter fan of any stripe, and if it's not to your taste, that's alright. I wouldn't say that the game is badly designed: it does exactly what it sets out to do. The question is whether you'll like it. I really really did, you might not.

I also really like the game aesthetically. Doom's gone full goofy comic book, with a bright, colorful design that makes everything pop a lot more than it did in Doom 16: The piss filter is 100% gone. A lot of the design is very early-2000s-console-gamey, and I mean that in the best kind of way: this game just wants you to be entertained, and it puts its all into that. It has this whole hub environment in the Fortress of Doom that's full of fun design, interactive elements, neat collectibles (including a set of the best music from most of id's older titles which you can freely play as you roam around), a ton of different references, callbacks, and gags, and a 486DX running The Ultimate Doom and Doom 2. It's not serious, it's a metal album come to life, and it's a celebration of Doom and of gaming in a general sense. Which just feels fitting: This is Doom, for crying out loud, a series that helped define modern gaming culture.

That doesn't mean the game is perfect, however. Doom 16 had a wonderfully self-aware, in-on-the-joke way of building its world. It knew we didn't care about any of this crap, and it never put the brakes on to try and make us care. Somewhere along the line, I think people on the team forgot about that. Eternal cares more about its story and spends more time on it than it should. And sometimes it works and the cutscenes are funny and enjoyable. Other times... erm, not so much. I wasn't really into hearing a bad monologue from a female scientist who sounds like she's about to orgasm over T H E  D O O M S L A Y E R ' S meaty demon-slaying... shotgun. Yes, that is what it sounds like, and if you didn't realize, congratulations, you can't unsee that image now. If I have to suffer, so do you. id, you make out the doomslayer as unironically awesome like that, because he's silly and stupid and inherently tongue-in-cheek. And I KNOW you know that, because you had him quote the Doom Comic in a slightly better cutscene (only slightly better). And Hugo, I know you like lore, but... time and place, man.

And that's really the issue with stacking this against Doom 16. Doom 16 is a perfectly crafted transitionary game. It doesn't have as clear a sense of identity mechanically as Doom Eternal, but it masks that through really good presentation. Doom Eternal has a much clearer design center, and in terms of gameplay I'd say it's straight-up superior. But a lot of what surrounds that gameplay is weaker than the framework of Doom 16.

For those of you vanilla Doom fans, who are against all of this, just... well, go buy Ultimate Doom and Doom 2 on Steam. Steam remains the best place to get these, because you get the original WADs, no pills. However, the Steam release now also comes with the new Doom releases, as it is elsewhere, and these provide a great way to jump into the wide world of Doom mods without the complexity of source ports (but get a source port eventually, so you can see the rest of the doom modding scene. It's beautiful).

A fantastic sequel to the rebooted Doom 2016. Doom was always about the single player experience - I've never cared for the multiplayer aspects so my review will not be about that (though from what I have played, ID can do better).

This game is worth it for the single player alone. Games these days tend to come with a well thought out storyline as a way of keeping their users engaged, while providing context of the character(s) and their choices in game. Doom 2016 & Eternal are no different, and they do not disappoint.

ID mentioned they were building an entire universe for Doom, and that's exactly what they've done. The story picks up ~10years after the events of Doom 2016. The Slayer arrives to see Earth fighting a losing battle against the forces of Hell, and his journey to save them takes him across the universe, into Hell and 'Heaven'.

We learn a great deal more about the history of the Sentinels & Argent D'nur - and while this game answers a lot of the questions we had after Doom 2016, it has now left us with more questions!

------------------
POSITIVE ASPECTS -
------------------
- The graphics/sound remain incredible and true to Doom.

- The storyline is very in-depth and well planned out(see my lore guide).

- The monsters/weaponry have been improved (although they were already awesome in Doom 2016).

------------------
NEGATIVE ASPECT  -
------------------
Doom Eternal introduced wall climbing, as well as a few platforming options such as 'monkey' bars to swing off, and hovering platforms to jump across.

The wall climbing works, and they have been plausibly added to the landscape. However the monkey bars and hovering platforms are simply out of place and don't logically fit in.

-----

I've seen other players complain about the minimal amount of ammo - this isn't an issue if you have a very basic ability to manage resources. There are plenty of pickups around and heck, use the chainsaw on a demon once and you most of your ammo back.

review: You know what? I am incredibly disappointed in this game. I absolutely loved 2016 DOOM and I looked forward to this for a long time with eager anticipation. First of all the graphics are impressive. However I found the level design in the early stages to be poor with annoying tomb raider style climbing and leaping mechanics. Also, for some reason the combat seems much harder than 2016 DOOM. Despite always being on the move I found myself overwhelmed and constantly running out of ammo and having the damnedest time farming it through the special kills I needed to do. I found it aggravating. I think it introduced too many extra mechanics and buttons to be a proper fun Doom game. Also the story and lore is way too much. Keep it simple stupid. In theory I really want to play it to completion, but I dunno if I will.

As someone with a crippling fear of gore I bought this as a joke. Yeah playing this for the first 2 hours made me increasingly sick and nauseous but I'll be damned if I didn't say ripping and tearing demons was incredibly therapeutic. Graphically gore looks pretty damn nice especially when I realized the more chunks you can see blown off the demons actually displays their health. Doom Eternal is actually one of my first arena shooter type games. I learned quickly when it comes to movement Its highly imperative that I keep moving and understand the build up of the map to avoid completely surrounded and overwhelmed ([i]which admittedly still happens to me a lot[/i]). If you have heard literally anything about DOOM you know by now the sound design will not disappoint. Dynamic sound design makes for interesting high octane metal gracing the combat and beautifully collaborating and changing with each shot you take and weapon you choose to use. If DOOM ETERNAL's score doesn't get you hyped and moving you need to see a doctor. 

Overall I'd give doom a solid 9.5/10 my only issues being minor bugs I've encountered such as getting launched into the air by mancubus' (mancubi?) and some issues regarding the menus. Additionally I also dislike some of the areas between the high action arenas, sometimes I found it hard to navigate or figure out exactly what the game wanted to me do. Other times it seemed like the path between the arenas were dull and repetitive. I found they were always filled with the tentacle enemies which I didn't really find to be anything but an annoying appearance  I definitely recommend this if your a fan of literally any shooter, experienced tactical shooter vets who want a fun aim trainer, and even the single player steves and sallys out there that want games to play without worrying about other players and team balance. This games is a high octane thrill that never disappoints.
