This is my favourite first person shooter this generation hands down. It improves on everything Doom 2016 did and makes it 10x more intense. I love the movement in this game, once you activate the movement rune there is nothing stopping you! You can glide around the arena shredding demons! The double jump and dash work hand in hand with the meaty sounding weapons and the grappling hook of the super shotgun to give you the most satisfying way to kill anything in any first person shooter out there. I simply love the enemy variety and how you have to balance ammo and health while smashing some demon faces in. The glory kills are so well made and I like that it is based on the angle you come from. I see people complaining about the Marauder but he was only hard the first few times after which he was actually very easy. His holographic animal thing is quite annoying but it's a good thing it doesn't have much hp. The story is also very interesting and I recommend diving into the lore through the many youtube videos out there. 
The visuals are absolutely stunning and the sense of scale is conveyed very well, especially the Earth stages show the mass destruction caused by the demonic invasion. Last but definitely not least is Mick Gordon's masterpiece of a soundtrack. It is so visceral sounding going from some freaky ass humming to thumping guitars, truly masterclass work.
The multiplayer is not to great, I like playing as the Marauder but the servers are absolute trash. It feels horrible to play because it feels like I'm on 800 ping 75% of the time. 

The multiplayer is also forced on you by the weekly challenges which I do not like. They have a lot of work to do when it comes to the multiplayer.

Performance is top notch, with my GTX 1080 at Ultra Nightmare graphical settings I was getting above 80 fps pretty consistently. It very rarely dipped below 60 but that was only for a few seconds and from my knowledge happened only twice. (Once in a Nekravol arena and once in the final boss battle where I got surrounded and died.) 

I 100% recommend this game to anyone who likes arcade shooters and action games. It's a 10/10 hands down. I love this game, LOVE IT. I can't wait for the DLC expansions, until then I'm going back to hunt the collectibles and find the remaining Empyrean Keys.

EDIT: Done with all the collectibles, and have finished the Doom Hunter Level on Nightmare. Boy was that a sweaty experience! 3 tries to beat it though :P
Nightmare is far more challenging than Ultra-Violence and I love the edge of your seat experience it gives you! 

Tl;dr Amazing arcade shooter, a must buy!

EDIT: Connection issues have been resolved.

review: love the idea of this game its so fun i love the idea of glory kills love the little secrets in the game its just an all out fun game highly reccomend it

it‘s good, but i can‘t deny a slight disappointment.

doom eternal is good. very good. in fact, it’s one of the best shooters in recent years. but since the hype around it was massive, the game just can’t live up to the expectations.

technically, the game is almost flawless and runs super smooth and stable, even on older systems. i‘m running it on a system with a gtx 1060, an intel i7-7700 and 16 GB RAM on almost completely maxed out settings and not a single crash, stuttering or slowdown. Not that the grafics are extraordinarily detailed or demanding, but it looks definitely very good and is very well optimized on the technical side.

gameplaywise however, it‘s a little bit of a letdown. it’s basically unchanged from Doom 2016, which is a good thing, but some mechanics where shifted towards a little slower pace in my opinion. in doom 2016 you could just pick up ammo, health and armor and but here you mostly have to acquire it through either chainsawing, glory-killing or burning your enemies. the max ammo you can carry is rather limited, so if you just want to revel in the gunplay without carefully considering when you have to use your chainsaw, glory-kills and flame-thrower, you‘re gonna have a bad time. many people say, this makes the gameplay rather tactical, but i think, it just slows the game down and is downright tedious at times. the chainsaw for example doesn’t seem to work on bigger enemies, so if you run out of ammo while fighting a hell knight and there are no smaller demons left to kill for ammo, good luck.

doom eternal is supposed to make you feel powerful, but due to the almost constant shortage of ammo and a very limited arsenal the first couple of hours do almost the exact opposite. it really took a couple of hours to get into a rhythm of constantly changing between shooting, chainsaw- and glory killing, and using the flamethrower. after 6 or 7 hours, the game starts to be a bit more fun, but i am not lying when i say that i was rather unimpressed and slightly bored during the opening hours.

Then, there are all those platforming sections that really feel out of place. overall, the movement feels very smooth and responsive, but to die several times because you miss a jump is just annoying. In the first doom games it was technically impossible to jump, and now in Doom Eternal we have to dodge some rotating flaming bars and jump over bottomless pits like Super Mario.

another thing is all the story and lore-stuff. i am usually really into the stories of games. in doom 3 i read every pda and fully embraced the atmosphere. but in doom eternal the story just feels off and unnecessary. all the readable codex stuff indeed is a bit distracting and builds a sharp contrast to the constant over-the-top-action. it’s just weird to slay two dozens of demons, then stop dead in your tracks for a minute to read a codex entry you just picked up.

the music is another mixed bag. it’s basically the same as in doom 2016, which was not bad but i can’t help but feel that a straight thrash metal soundtrack without all that weird kinda dubstep-electronics-stuff mixed in would do wonders for the game.

Doom 2016 somehow slipped under the radar for me 4 years ago, but when i finally got to play that game, i was pretty surprised how good it was. And i‘d say, compared to Doom Eternal it’s still the better game. i even heard one of my favorite reviewers on youtube say, that doom eternal would revolutionize the genre again in ways the first doom, quake and half-life did. i wonder how much that guy was paid to say this, but it’s far from it, especially since doom eternal is so similar to Doom 2016 as Doom II was to Doom I.

In the end, I’ll have to be honest: I liked doom eternal but i had more fun with Doom 64 🤷🏼‍♂️

Definitely one of the best games of 2020, and not just an energetic improvement to DOOM 2016. Found a few glitches though; e.g, a Cacodemon leaving behind the spinning asset over its head at level 4, or even being stuck at a corner at level 6 (ARC Complex).

With Doom Eternal, id Software made the bold choice of looking at their previous game and trying to do everything better, opting for a tighter focus on resource management in combat and an understanding of the enemy. The Slayer's arsenal functions less like John Wick's menagerie and more like Bob the Builder's belt, with each enemy type demanding a different tool for the job. Though this works to heighten the combat loop of the game, it functions as a dramatic tonal shift from the power fantasy of the 2016 remake, to now feeling like one man against a literal descent of demons. Whether this change strengthens or weakens the experience is ultimately down to the individual player. At a technical level though, everything here is superior to the 2016 remake, and it should not go unnoticed how consistently Mick Gordon has been killing it with these soundtracks. A masterful fps that is definitely not for everyone.

A worthy sequal to DOOM 2016, but not without a few flaws

The main issue being the headshot "pop" sound, which really takes away from the games immersion, while this sounds like a small thing, personally, its too silly for the games style.

Another issue being a lack of ammo, which in of itself isnt a problem but the fact you cant kill enemy's with melee (untill you unlock a skill, which has a recharge time) can make some fights drag out longer than they would have im DOOM 2016.

Im a big fan of the colours, bright, glowing ammo pickups, health packs and more give the game a unique feel, along with the generally better gameplay mechanics, better story and of course, new soundtrack.

To summarise, the game is brilliant, but not without its flaws. Personally i feel DOOM 2016 to be a better game in terms of the overall feel and style, with DOOM Eternal a better game in terms of story, gameplay, replayabality and essentially every other aspect.

100 hours in and I still cant beat ultra-nightmare... D:E remains just as fun, challenging and intense as the first hour. This game would be complete with a practice mode (they even built a map for it which currently has no use outside of 1 quick campaign intermission) and a proper multiplayer mode *cough-slayer-cough-deathmatch-cough* and the cosmetic rewards for pvp are rather lackluster, but I still enjoy the platforming and mayhem of the campaign. It's also worth mentioning that even if I do get tired of D:E's gameplay, I can still play Doom I & II from within Eternal itself, which kind of blows my mind tbh. Looking forward to the DLC.

My biggest problem is lack of actual multiplayer, as I don't consider BattleMode anywhere near as exciting or competitive as traditional deathmatch or CTF. If BattleMode is all D:E will ever have to offer as far as multiplayer, then soon I will be pretty much done ripping and tearing.

Oh boy Doom Eternal, where do I start?

When first playing through about the first half of the game, it was everything I could have ever asked for.
Around the time I got the meat hook grappling thing I was a little bummed as I thought it was a suit upgraded but it's locked to the super shotgun. Still cool, but I would have loved grappling to any surface, (like I thought it was going to be.)

Overall most enemies are fun and pretty tough in certain groups. Some are pure cancer.

The first 75% of the game, this was my new favorite videogame. The last 15% or so it was grueling, brutal, and just irritating to the point of not being fun at all. The other 10% is just time waste-y platforming that loses it's luster quickly that is kind of sprinkled throughout.

I love hard games, but there are a few enemies in this game that straight up make me not have a good time.

It is fairly short for a AAA 60 dollar game.

I really only think it's worth that price if you are an absolute Doom NUT, like I am.
That being said, the game took me around 18 hours to finish on ultra violence on my first playthrough, which is very solid for an FPS but... still pricey.

Holy... f**k,,,

Story: Not strong, but it's Doom. The goal isn't exactly a deep story, so it gets a pass. However, the story is more in depth than DOOM (2016). As a matter of fact, it added on to that story, and merged their arcs with the classic DOOM games. Very impressive. Not many series can pull that off.

Gameplay: Phenomenal. You still run fast, jump high, and juggle big guns and a chainsaw. But it addition, you can dash, and the Super Shotgun has a meat hook that will pull you towards enemies to SMACK THEM IN THE FACE...but with buckshot. Powerups were more scarce, but that's easy to overlook. And the Doom Blade... The Slayer is predator. Sweet!

10/10: Inside Every Demon is a Rainbow... you just need a chainsaw in order to see it spill out.

At first I disliked DOOM Eternal. It felt like the game was trying to hold my hand by telling me the best way to defeat enemies. The level design was too linear, while the 60 FPS cut scenes felt overly smooth, taking away any cinematic quality. Also, I didn't feel that there were significant improvements from DOOM 2016 in regards to gameplay and story.

Well I'm certainly glad that I pushed through my initial impressions and gave DOOM Eternal a real shot, because this has been one of the most satisfying FPS experiences I've ever had. The story is decent, the graphics are fantastic, and the sound is excellent as well. But it's the gameplay mechanics that make DOOM Eternal so damn fun to play. Once you find the rhythm in how to use each weapon in any given circumstance, you will find yourself in Shooter heaven. The feeling of "hand-holding" that I had with all the pop-ups of how to fight certain demons turned from annoying to welcoming, as I wanted to become as an efficient DOOMSLAYER as I could. Each demon you fight (aside from the weaker ones) has there weakness to certain weapons, and their mods. You can upgrade those mods as you progress through the game, and as the game gets more challenging, you unlock more mods and skills.

While DOOM Eternal gives you many tools to kill demons like the badass DOOMSLAYER that you are, it is at the same more more unforgiving than helpful. You find yourself in situations where you die over and over again by hordes of demons who's main goal is to brutally end you. However, that is when DOOM Eternal is the most enjoyable.  Gamers like a challenge, and this game provides one of the most fun and rewarding challenges you'll have in a long time.

Rooms look like this: one texture, one pillar and few props, and mirrored two times and elongated. Graphics looks like copy paste work, done in a haste and without artistic vision or any illusion of "realism". Few levels are great.

In doom1993 enemy corpses remained on the ground forever, you could see the history of what happened, but in doom eternal as well as in doom2016 everything is cleaned up before you can even look back, again a downgrade in standards.

Every enemy encounter locks you in some space which is a downgrade, in doom1993 and doom2 everything was dynamic, enemies could wander around the map, game felt alive. 

Secrets are no longer secret, damn.

The story is beyond bad. They wanted to make a story but did not refer to the previous doom's story in ANY way, did not continue the cliff hanger, even though almost all the characters are straight from the previous game. And the levels of cringe are through the roof.

Gameplay is good but boring level design does not allow the gameplay to be excellent.

I hate frequent cutscenes or locked animations that bring nothing to the experience.

I think that doom 3 was a big budget game from Id with talent put in it. 

Rage 1 also had some  ambition in it, but Doom Eternal made terrible decisions in many departments making it a boring game. And I am most sorry to witness it.

I will not very happily thumb this game down, ultra-nightmare playthrough appeal is not enough to save this game.

great game on it's own.. but it's a downgrade when it's compared to 2016 (which is one my favourite games ever). technically a masterpiece.. but it feels like developers want you to play it the way they want.. you actually have to use certain guns (especially grenade launcher) and tactics and special moves etc.. not enough ammo armor medkit around etc.. freedom is kinda gone ..

Anyhow, I am love single players, so Doom was  a no brainer .  I love the fact that its so easy to learn despite having a bazzilion things to do with all the different controls, the reload mechanism is unique and i absolutely love sawing those demons in half 

I used to game in my early twenties and then life happened and it was somehow left behind . Lockdown this year meant lines blurring between work and home and i needed some ME  time to decompress and i thought i would install some new games and get back into it . I have been buying , installing and not playing games from sometime now 

I have spent 34 hours to complete this thing and i absolutely loved every minute of it .
The spawing of demons gets repetative in a way but if you give a day or twos break , the fun is back in hacking and slashing as the maps are new and then there are secret items and things to discover

The accompanying story board and lore is detailed as fun entertaining to read as well 

Thanks to the dev for letting me relive a piece of my childhood again , hopefully this older me sticks to the habit this time around , its a great start for sure.

The game is really good, and there is no bad Denuvo anti-cheat software in there anymore, messing with your operating system kernel. I had this review as a do-not-recommend, but since things have been fixed up, we can now recommend the game again.

It is DOOM 2016, cranked up to 11. The game engine is one of the fastest and most crisp engines in many years. It is able to run 1440p stable at around 140fps on my GTX 1080, which is quite the feat. In turn, fraggin monsters feels very very good when everything is this fluid. You'll have to move and be fast.

I'd say if you enjoyed DOOM 2016, you should definitely try this game, especially if you like fast paced gameplay and the need to constantly update your game plan. There are many more dash and move options in this game, so evading fire becomes an important part of the game play as well. Forget about cover-shooting.

Doom Eternal is an improvement over 2016 in so many ways that its hard to go back. While it's hard to describe, the initial difficulty can be a bit off putting as well as the platforming sections. But after you add some upgrades, there's a zen-like appeal that you can wipe out a dozen demons in room with you barely taking a scratch.

Of course, it's by no means an easy game since enemies are relentless in this game and I've had my fair share of getting boxed in although the extra lives systems gives you nice safety net. The performance is great on my 1060 despite the fact that I disabled dynamic res scaling and had some options set to low but it runs buttery smooth. There are some frame drops when using the ice bomb and I had two crashes in the game's final boss.

It's a solid package for a campaign that'll last you 13-15 hours depending on how much you want to go secret hunting and if you're a Quake/Doom fan there's a lot of references you'll get. Music is top notch as well and there's never a dull moment in the game.

While it's a nitpick of mine, the tone of the game changes midway with less funny moments happening with it being more akin to 2016's story but it didn't detract from the experience. There are moments big and small which make this a damn fun roller coaster ride.

The only main negative I have is the constant "Unable to Connect" messages that pop you back into the menu instead of being a one-time check when you boot up the game. I've gotten a lot of collectibles so I didn't mind going in offline mode.
Huge guts, beautifully rendered in a nightmarish hell-scape just waiting to be ripped and teared. So, rip and tear till your hearts content.

I swear I wanted to punch my monitor because I was so into the music and demon killing. 10/10

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

I got this game because i really enjoyed Doom(2016) and the classic Doom and i can say this game improved off of 2016. First the gameplay is great with the addition of movement tools like the dash and meathook you have to move all over the place while shooting and it's really enjoyable, the glory kills are great with the wristblade adding new ways to rip and tear, the new demons add some interesting things with the ones that were present in 2016, the guns feel amazing to use such as the supershotgun and ballista are so fun to use together, and the ammo system encourages using variation if you run out of ammo along with managing your health and armor. The music is great, the combat music fits well with what you are dooing in game and the ambient music is fitting to the areas and eerie. The multiplayer is a bit rough because new players can be put against high level people in my experience and be decimate but the way that it works still is fun with the demons using their unique abilities while the slayer has to move around constantly while still targeting the enemy players. Overall the game is extremely fun with lots of replayability with ultra nightmare mode and master levels with multiplayer as something to change up gameplay and with the new dlc coming out soon the game could be eternal.

Great game, had much fun playing it. The game was one of the reasons to buy a new PC, because my old laptop video card stopped being updated but it was totally worth it as the graphics is a candy to the eye.The sequel lives up to the original reboot, but the plot/worldbuilding itself was kinda strange addition. The worldbuilding is kinda funny thanks to the added UAC holograms promoting hell invasion, but the looking for the codex pages and reading them was not the best way for a fast paced game which is DE. The plot is not not bad, but having plot in such a game does not add much to the overall impression, as the gameplay is a farmore important part.Speaking of which, it was good as earlier, so if you enjoyed the 2016 Doom, you will enjoy the sequel. What I find a bit misfitting is greater focus on acrobatics and several large parts dedicated to it and the need for constant abilities (grenades, chainsaw, sword, punch etc) use, so you need to keep focus on those.Music is great, but what else would you expect?All in all highly recommended a well-polished and fun game, BFG 8 (000) / 10 (000)

I've played most of the DOOM games, and liked the 2016 version best.This one doesn't do it for me - it's basically just try to defeat onslaughts of demons, then walk a little, then rinse/repeat.There's not much of a story, no character development, no puzzles, etc - it's basically Serious Sam or The Killing Floor but with the DOOM aesthetic.Grind up demons to over-the-top metal music - fun in 30-60 minute increments, then - more of the same - yawn.EDIT:I've lowered the difficulty and it makes the game more playable (for me). My previous comments still stand - it's basically kill one horde after another.I wish Steam had more than just "Yes" and "No" for reviews - stars would help so I could give it mediocre rating.Also, I'm having tons of audio problems - I use a Bluetooth headset (Uproar) that works with every other game I've played. However, DOOM seems to have a lot of issues, particularly with Bluetooth headsets. In my case, the game can sometimes start without sound, or sometime the sounds quits mid-game. Either way, it's a nightmare to get it working again. I usually have to reboot to fix it. I've tried several of the 'fixes' online and none work. I guess if you want to play, you should simply not use Bluetooth...Ridiculous!EDIT:Ok, I've continued to play despite the audio problems (not resolved). Instead, I've used my wired headphones instead of Bluetooth and I don't get any audio issues at all. I still think this is ridiculous that this game causes these issues and they haven't been fixed by Bethesda.But, at least it's allowed me to play uninterrupted, and since lowering the difficulty, the game is better than I first suggested. Mind you, it's still basically killing horde after horde, but the environments get better as does the gameplay.I'm changing my rating to thumbs up, but just barely. If this were a stars-based rating it would be 3 out of 5,or only 60%. Don't pay full price  - get it as cheap as you can, don't use Bluetooth, and maybe you'll like it.

review: It's just good

Take the core gameplay loop of the 2016 Doom game, turn it up to eleven, implement a forced weapon cycling with weak points and optimal engagement tactics to form one of the greatest FPS shooters of modern era.Nightmare difficulty especially will challenge the living hell out of the experienced doom-slayer, with ammunition becoming a necessity and quick-switching guns becoming absolutely vital for survival against the new Marauder-type of enemies.

They added lots of cool new features and mechanics, but then got all cringey with the story and dialogue.It's super fun and challenging (I recommend starting on Ultra-Violence, if you beat the crap out of Doom 2016) with lots of variety in how you can engage combat situations.It's a solid 9/10 and I hope that they put out more single player content in the future.P.S. the purple goo can go fuck itself.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------UPDATE 05/16/20: New update includes kernel-level access DRM/Anti-cheat software.No thanks. graphics: 10/10 great optimization and graphics overallmusic 9/10 the music is excellent, not the best, but pretty darn good.story 7/10 a bunch of collectables give the story. beyond that its just endless arena and uninspired jumping puzzle. it makes Zelda puzzles look like a masters degree..mechanics: 7/10 mechanics are really well thought out, however beyond the nutshell its a typical fps game with an upgrade system. if it wasnt for doom eternal's more unique upgrade tree it would have gotten 6/10.  Personally I feel doom games should not have upgrade trees.gameplay and difficulty: 6/10 doom 2016 felt like something special and smooth. While gameplay is more refined in eternal the difficulty is overtuned. While the marauder is beatable after you understand him it just is not fun fighting him. every time one appears I sigh and say to myself "its one of those again"...The over activity of the game play makes me feel like im a mentally ill person running through a hallway and jumping up and down, and very often I find myself running into a wall and getting stuck. I beat the game in nightmare mode which should say something, but overall I disagree with the direction of the game.Average score 78%.If it weren't for the games graphics and decent music this game would be absolute garbage.It's a shame. Maybe I would have gone lighter on it if it wasn't called "doom" as it just doesnt feel like a doom game.

This made me lose motivation to play the game after i had to put it on the easiest difficulty just to beat one of the first few levels. Now that i have came back to the game however, and am now on the mars core level, the game is much more enjoyable. My only critique of the game are how OP the doom hunters are (everyone complains about marauders yet i killed one at arc base in 10 seconds) and how hard the early game is compared to the late game. Other than those the game is extremely fun, but i wish there was more content besides a 10-20 hour campaign and multiplayer.

Absolutely fantastic game. After playing through the campaign, it is what a sequel to an already great game should be. It improves on the FPS experience from the first, the campaign missions all add difficulty as you gain more abilities and weapons, and the combinations of weapon mods and abilities are endless. Also the addition of DOOM Slayer skins (as well as demon skins) was a fantastic touch. It may be considered micro-transactions but they are the best kind as they don't affect gameplay and are purely for the enjoyment of the player. Loved the first DOOM and this one is even better. Now, I'm about to go back and find all of the collectibles, challenge areas, and up the difficulty on a new play through.
shotgun man bad

Hectic, run-and-gun, face melting game play. Never feels punishing because it's your own fault for picking a harder difficulty. Gameplay occasionally feels overly complex with the number of ways to kill demons and replenish your health/armor/ammo but is amazingly satisfying to blaze through a battle pulling off the right combos to barely skate through alive. I highly recommend you play Doom 2016 before this one because both the story and gameplay are direct evolutions of it.

The Denuvo anti-cheat program seems to have been removed as the patch notes say and as of the posting date of this review that seems to remain true. It felt like a dirty, underhanded trick for Bathesda do add that software after the game came out and I stopped playing entirely for that time period. All that said, the fact that they listened to the community and removed it makes me respect the company at least a little and I can now continue to enjoy this fun-as-HELL game:)

Generic Scifi Shooter™ 2020. That's the impression I had in my mind throughout the game. 

Sadly I didn't enjoy this as much as the other reviewers.  The entire game felt like someone had decided that the new Doom game should actually be more of Borderlands, more of Destiny and some sprinkles of other shooters, but less of the things that made Doom fun.  Like it or hate it, I believe this is the direction that Doom is now heading in,  it's trying to appeal to other players.  

There's now a central hub, and you're on a ship.  You can unlock different parts of the ship.  The entire ship felt entirely unnecessary and a waste of space.  It broke immersion and the sense of continuity of the story.  The bland, disembodied voice of a ship's computer accompanies you and tells you what to do.  At the end of every level, there are stats and rewards thrown at you, and every unlock, progress or reward is accompanied by beeping and booping to give you a sense of pride and accomplishment™. 


👎 There are a lot of [b]mechanics[/b].  There are [i]too[/i] many mechanics.  
The Doom execs decided that players like points.  So they added points to everything.  Weapon mods and runes and batteries and suit points and arsenal points and crystals and on and on and on, I can't even remember now.  It felt overwhelming and once again unnecessarily excessive. They also decided that players love achievements so part of weapon upgrades are hidden behind mini-achievement progress. 

As if that weren't enough, even the monsters have mechanics that affect your choice of weapons.   
Certain weapons with certain mods work better against certain monsters, you must remember those or risk wasting ammo.  

Ammo is now a scarce resource, and instead of being able to enjoy the mayhem of monster swarms, you are now managing ammo, switching weapons, and looking for the nearest fodder to chainsaw to get some ammob ack.  It's no longer that you can enjoy your favorite [i]kind[/i] of weapon, you must play in the way they want you to play. 

Among all the mechanics, the thing that spoiled it most of all was the commandeering of glory kills; where these were once satisfying ends to certain encounters, these have now become a means of replenishing health and a means of surviving.  

With so many 'burdens' to bear, the fights no longer became fun, they became a chore. 

👍👍👍 Despite all the above negativity, what kept me going was the [b]environments[/b].  I'm a fan of beautiful environments and artwork, and the game's mixture of Biblical, SciFi and Hellish themes I found captivating.  I definitely enjoyed exploring and platforming my way through these beautiful settings.  Strangely many people disliked the platforming aspects but they seemed well designed to me

😐 Some also-mentions; the music didn't feel anywhere near as powerful or impactful as Doom 2016, it was sort of there, but not really noticeable.  It felt like an afterthought.

And I experienced some crashes; annoyingly several of them occurred right at the final boss fight when trying to use the BFG (also a scarce ammo).


Overall, not recommended as it didn't feel enjoyable as a Doom game. The game was forgettable and I was eventually waiting for it to end.  

But seeing as I am in a minority, I'll add that if you're going to get this, get it on sale.
AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA

review:
NOTE: This review is for single player only

This game is amazing. There are a large variety of weapons and abilities that can be used to craft a unique playstyle. Some of my favorite weapons are:
1. Super Shotgun: instantly DECIMATES lower-class demons and decently damages heavy demons. combining all that with a grappling hook that can set enemies on fire gives you a work of art.
2. Plasma Rifle: the base weapon isnt very exciting, but the weapon mods make it amazing for certain scenarios. For example, the Mircowave Beam is amazing for killing agile demons such as Whiplash, and although Heat Blast has horrible range, it can be useful if youre crowded in by fodder demons. 
3. Chain Gun: Similar to the Plasma rifle, but with different abilities, such as a turret, where the chaingun becomes 4 chainguns, but it overheats quickly. the second ability is a shield, which tempararily abosorbs damage. both are good in certain scenarios.

Overall, The game is rich with story and secrets, from the DOS pc in the Fortress of Doom, to finding Daisy around the game. Combat is perfected in every way, with even the first weapons getting some use later on. If you can master the flow of combat with quick reactions, you'll be blazing through the game in no time. And the atmosphere is beautiful. from the music impeccably crafted by Mick Gordon and Chad Mossholder, from the stunning views of Exultia and Taras Nabad, to the perfected hellscape of Nekravol, it is a masterpiece. My only gripe with it is that there are a handful of movement bugs that can cause people to literally fily.

FINAL SCORE: 94/100

review:
-This is the most visually striking FPS I've ever played.  The 2D art is phenomenal, too.  The scale of the environment is immense with many environments feeling daunting. 
-Enemy AI is really good most of the time.
-Exploration is generally rewarded
-Zero glitches or bugs found in about 9 hours of playtime.  (Good work Bethesda, et al.)

The minuses

Franchise has taken on the flavor of Super Mario Bros. - with demons!  There seems to be so much finicky (double) jumping and gymnastic pole swinging that it seriously detracts from the game.  For example, there are inexplicable wall cannons that shoot hazards you need to sprint through.  Just make a side-scroller if you want to subject players through perfectly timed jump sequences or hazard traps.  You have to magically climb/jump certain designated areas, but yet can't climb the simplest of environment structures. There is a ton of it in the game.  Also, invisible walls abound so prepared to be frustrated on a regular basis. 

My biggest gripe has to do with being forced to use particular weapons to specifically deal with different demon types.  In the midst of battle, you have to remember to switch to Weapon Z so you can switch to Weapon Z alternate mode B so that you can aim a shot to a designated weak point on location C of a particular type of demon.  You can no longer play how you want to play.  If you are a shotgun afficianado, tough sp!t because you are pretty much forced to use a different weapon at the drop of a hat.  Do you like a good machine gun-ish weapon?  You're up the creek because you have to press a different button (or combination) to deal with other regular run-of-the-mill demons.  In Doom 4 you were at least allowed to use the weapon you want even if it was inefficient.  With Eternal, if you're not using a grenade on thus and so, or lobbing this projectile on this other whatchamacalit, you'll have to dial down the game difficulty too much in order to succeed.

Demons are now immune to friendly fire from different demon subtypes.  They react to them, but no damage is done. (It used to be immensely satisfying in other Doom games to watch them get pissed off and fight one another.)

You are forced to use the chainsaw because resources are so scarce.  You must melee (with a demon!) to get magical armor to spill out of them even though they wear no armor themselves.  Brightly colored magical bits  spill out of them that your character automatically sucks up like a vacuum cleaner.  The chainsaw itself runs out of fuel itself very quickly for some inexplicable reason.

The Glory Kill aspect has gotten way out of hand.  You need to habitually stagger enemies on a regular basis so you can get health through your magic-glory-punch.  You can't perform the headshot you want to many times so that you can wound an enemy to the point of staggering.  They then blink like Christmas lights  (and then fast blink when they're close to being un-staggered) so you know when to run to them and perform a Glory/finishing move.  It ceases to be fun really quick.  I don't remember it being this intrusive in Doom 4.  What happened?

The lack of a quicksave still haunts the game.  Do you have a life, or limited time to play a game?  Doom Eternal doesn't give a soggy wet turd, because you will be replaying from a past checkpoint if you dare to leave the game.  

I was 20 years old when the original Doom hit the scene.  It changed the gaming landscape for me.  The franchise has morphed into a mandatory jump-y/swing-y/climb-y glory punching exercise that is more button/key-clicking than it should be.    This might be the first Doom game I don't finish.

Honest talk, everything in this game is just perfect. The game has beautiful graphics, everything was looking so realistic, and it's what I love in games. Gameplay was interesting and fun. I had never played a game, that was this fast, But it made it FUN!

Shortly, you go around getting a revenge on some demons (I think responsible) and killing some smaller demons on your way. The killing is the best part, and it really made me feel strong, really. You have a lot of ways to kill the demons; Glory kill, shoot, punch, rip & tear...
All weapons are great, and some of them helps you keep the flow of the game. You also get the Super shotgun, and it has a hook pulling you towards the enemy.
There is also an online game mode, which is pretty fun too. two guys, play as demons, one as the slayer. but one negative thing is that when I tried it, I got into games with people much more experienced than me, making it quite a challenge, sometimes unfair.

I'm fairly new to the Doom scene. The last Doom game I played was Doom 3 back in 2004. I decided to get this game when a buddy of mine suggested it during the summer sale. I wasn't really interested but I went ahead and bought the game. I was not disappointed. From the start, the game throws you in without any tutorials and you begin your quest to kill all demons. There are some hints to show you some game mechanics but if you don't want help, you can easily turn them off in the menu. The music is amazing! I loved every single encounter I had because the music pumped me up to rip and tear everything in my path. You can't catch your breath for a sec without something spawning in or fighting in a mini arena. The story is a little weird to me but only because I haven't played the first Doom(2016). The controls are really good and I enjoyed dashing around and flying in the air. You really have to plan your moves carefully to get the most out of your weapons. There is a multiplayer which I have only played about 10 times. It's a lot to take in but having a friend who can dumb it down helps. It's basically a 2v1 match where the demons must kill the doom slayer while they spawn in demons for help. Over all I had lots of fun and played it again just to grab all the collectibles. Did I mention the music is insane? If you're not a fan of metal, you will be by the end of the game.

TL;DR: DOOM Eternal is a great buy, whether you played DOOM 2016 or not. Treat yourself.

[h1] Graphics: 10 [/h1]

I run a high-end system, so I'm able to enjoy DOOM Eternal in all its graphical fidelity. Regardless of how good your system is,  the game looks terrific. Demons are universally gruesome in a good way and react satisfyingly when you glory kill them. The most impressive aspect of the graphics is the environments. Whether you're on Earth, the homeworld of the Sentinels, or the Doom Fortress, environments never cease to amaze in some way. Backgrounds are full of interesting things to look at, including remnants of battles between colossal titans or gorgeous architecture that's fallen into disrepair. Clipping and other graphical glitches are practically non-existent, and the FPS is butter-smooth. Did I mention the gore? If you have blood lust, this game will satisfy it.

[h1] Sound: 10 [/h1]

This game has perfect audio design. More metal is crammed into this game than DOOM 2016. Whether Mick Gordon composed it or not, it imitates his style well enough that most people won't tell the difference. Speaking of, he did compose some tracks in this game that are god-tier, and you may be able to point them out yourself without trying or being familiar with Mick's style. The music absolutely enhances the gameplay and it simply wouldn't be DOOM Eternal without it.

Every weapon has its own distinct sound that doesn't borrow from any other game, and I've taken to relying on the dash sound effect to keep my dash fully operational in the heat of battle (smart strategy FYI).

[h1] Control: 9 [/h1]

The game can be played with either a keyboard & mouse or a gamepad, though I prefer the former. It takes time to master the Doom Slayer's movements in order to best evade incoming fire and plan an attack route, which is a good thing. The game can become brutally difficult through no fault of the control scheme. You can re-bind keys if you have issues, though the default setup works for me. The only issues revolve around me hitting the wrong key for, say, the chainsaw (default key is C), in the heat of battle. I don't think that would happen if I played on a controller, but the speed at which the game moves with a mouse is simply irreplaceable.

The Doom Slayer is fast and fluid in his movements. Even the platforming is quick and enjoyable. It makes DOOM 2016 feel slow as shit.

[h1] Fun Factor & Longevity: 9.5 [/h1]

Believe me when I say you won't find a more enjoyable single-player FPS experience. DOOM Eternal blasts away the competition with its high-octane action that's smarter than it looks and pulse-pounding soundtrack. The Campaign consists of 30-40 hours of gameplay in one run. I wanted to experience it on harder difficulties after I was finished, and the game presents a few single-player modes for you to sink your teeth into. The Campaign can be played through Extra Life mode, which challenges you to finish the game without losing all your lives, and through Ultra Nightmare mode, which sets the difficulty to the highest setting and ends your Campaign-long run, with a marker to mark your progress, if you die. It's super intimidating for a newcomer, but after finishing the Campaign once, you might wanna give them a shot.

The multiplayer is okay, I guess. It's more thematic than it was in DOOM 2016 (and a bit better), but it's not a draw. More progression and better multiplayer would serve to beef it up. The single-player content is the reason to own this game.

[i] The Ancient Gods: Part One [/i] has yet to come out as of this writing. It'll be significant DLC for the Campaign, extending its lifespan. Apparently you don't even need DOOM Eternal to play it, but don't do that to yourself. Buy and play DOOM Eternal, then be psyched to play the DLC when it comes out October 20.

[h1] Respect for the player: 9 [/h1]

In a video game landscape in which video game publishers and some developers treat their consumer base like mentally challenged apes, DOOM Eternal doesn't. It gives you all the hand-holding you'll need and no more. More importantly, there are no microtransactions whatsoever in the game itself. There is, however, a Digital Deluxe Edition that's poor value, so just get the Standard edition and you'll be set.

[h1] Final Score: 9.5/10 [/h1]

I told you to get it already. Get it. Enjoy it. Rip & Tear.

While I recommend Doom Eternal, all I really want to say here is that the Marauder, an enemy that shows up 2/3 of the way through the campaign, is just cheap shit that tanks the flow of the game and comes close to ruining it.

Every other enemy in the game can be killed through overwhelming force.  Even though a few of the tougher ones have weak spots you are encouraged to attack, you can still lay into them with whatever gun you choose.  This comes at the cost of potentially using too much ammo, which is already scarce, and making things harder on yourself.

This doesn't apply to the Marauder though.  There is really only one way to kill him.  He has a shield that blocks all attacks (when you shoot his shield he spawns an attack dog that you also have to kill).  The only way to damage him is to wait until he drops his shield and comes rushing at you with his melee weapon, in this instance (literally a split-second window) you are now able to damage him.  Weapons that do the most instant damage are the only real options.  (BFG and Chainsaw don't work on him, only normal, non one-hit-kill weapons.  This just adds insult to injury.)  About 7 or 8 close range, direct hits with the super shotgun will put him down.  That's repeating the routine of waiting for him to even be able to take damage 7 or 8 times.  Not fun.

In the tutorial it mentions that in order for him to not shoot you (which does huge damage) or send out his dog (which happens from you shooting his shield) you need to maintain a relative distance to him.  This is fine for the first couple of times you face him, where he is basically considered a boss fight and only low-level enemies fight with him (a boon actually, since you can use them to regain your health), however, towards the later part of the game he is mixed in with other powerful enemies that don't allow you to simply focus on him.  This becomes extremely frustrating, as you're dying from him, his damn dog, or some other enemy behind you.

If you want to get gud here, then expect to be dying a lot and repeating these sequences often until you happen to get through it without really knowing what you did to succeed.

This isn't Doom.  It's Quicktime Event: The Game. 

Doom Eternal isn't really a shooter game at all.  FPS aspect of this game is merely incidental.  You're really In between the melee-fest are a lot of pseudo jumping puzzles that come far too frequently - many that border on completely monotonous and forced.  

Ammo drops have been purposely nerfed to the point where the only option you have is to sorta damage things until you can glory kill them.  This is the entire basis of the game design in Doom Eternal and it's really annoying.  The movement speed has been slowed to the point where you're completely dependent on character upgrades to get anywhere effectively. And yeah, all the jumping puzzles. Actually, this game feels exactly like God of War 3.  The lore, characters and wall climbing all scream GoW 3 - good for it's day, but most of these design choices Id lifted just feel out of place.  

While generally the game looks great and runs at very high FPS with little tweaking, the arenas area also very small and the area you're allowed to traverse at any time is quite limited.  Id has come up with a game design that I'm sure they think is clever and "strategic" but it's not - it's just annoying and boring.  Once you figure out all you have to do is glory kill literally every single enemy, there's not much to it and the holes in the rest of the game begin to show very quickly.  Doom 2016 was really excellent but the studio didn't really capitalize fully on the potential.  This could just be a tap to win mobile game.

I'm not a long-time Doom fan. When I played Doom 2016 though, I felt like a convert. It was fun, it was fast-paced, you had to be instinctively aggressive to get through. I only had to get through 3 levels before I decided to purchase this game. And when I finished Doom 2016, I installed this one and started...

The Slog. This game feels off-beat. It feels like a chore. In Doom 2016, I was the Doom Slayer. In Doom Eternal, I was the Doom Janitor. Hallway after hallway of similar battles, occasionally entering a room where some big-shot is there to lecture me on the plot. I was very quickly bored of this game.

The Disconnect. This game didn't feel like it followed Doom 2016 at all. Sure, there were references and characters reappeared, but it felt more like they rebooted it after the ending of Doom 2016. No references or apologies from Dr. Hayden for banishment. No explanation for the 'Fortress of Doom'. Or where Doom Guy was when the invasion started. Or really... anything.

The Story. There was one?! And there are multiple reasons for the surprise. First off, Doom Guy ignored the plot whenever it  dared show up in Doom 2016. In Doom Eternal he bows his head to the plot whenever it feels like monologuing at him (and us). Also, the story... doesn't explain anything consistently. Sometimes, it talks to the Doom Guy, assuming we all know what's going on. Sometimes, Doom Guy appears to not know something that it later says he should definitely know.

The Realization. I paid full price for this because Doom 2016 was awesome. This game did a good job telling me that good games only happen once per franchise, so I'll just play 2016 on repeat and forget I made the mistake of getting this.

The Lesson. If you liked Doom 2016, keep playing it. The only familiar things this game has is the visuals and the soundtrack.

review:
In a sense, Doom Eternal, much like it's 2016 predecessor, is more of evolution of Quake than of the original, but mostly because Quake itself was an evolution of the original Doom.
Fast, challenging and unapologetically fun. An old-school shooter for the new age, 9.5/10 easily one of my favs in the last decade.
metal

Edit.. No longer recommend this game..  TLDR. Finished the game. The original content is still good, Any innovations since Doom2016 were bad decisions, and the marauders especially were bloody terrible ideas.


Because the game is functional, has good moments, and is generally a good game, compared to most other things out right now, I have to reccomend it.
Compared to the original Doom 2016, it is a major ****ing dissapointment though.
at the start of the game, it is entirely an ammo management game.. constantly running out of ammo. This is mitigated a little later on, with the chainsaw being available more often, and having to sink all points into carrying more ammo.
So often the pace is ruined by super tough enemies, which require special methods to kill, making half your arsenal useless. (The cacodemon early on, and the fckin annoying Marauder later on)
The arsenal is okay, but certainly missing some of the weapons from Doom2016. 

It seems like all new innovations on this sequal, were the wrong choices, compared to Doom2016.

Edit.. havent tried Multiplayer. Assume it is still a steaming pile, like it was in 2016.

doom eternal is a very fun and good game as it improves on what doom 2016 did and adds some stuff to make the experience feel different and harder. story sees doom guy going on an adventure to kill bad guys and stop demons from fully taking over earth (which is bad). gameplay is similar to doom 2016 but there are new movement and attack options such as a dash ability which is useful for dodging attacks. you will fight many different demons and they are all different in their designs, attacks and ai. there are new enemies too such as the doom hunter and maruder, which start off as bosses but come back in later levels. controls are responsive and you can change your keybinds to suit your style (VERY IMPORTANT!). this game can be hard so it is required to learn the game and use your strengths effectively or else you will be dead. overall this is a fun game and if your a christian person wanting to shoot demons and send them back to their country then this is the game for you, go buy it! 9/10.

Finished Doom Eternal 4 times on Xbox. Now I'm on PC playing the higher difficulties. 
Personally I enjoyed Doom Eternal's campaign allot. it's the smoothest and fastest game I've played in a while. Everything from the soundtrack to the movement makes you feel like a complete bad ass. 

The theme of Doom is there but the spirit isn't. It feels more like a hero shooter, as it forces you to use certain weapons at the right time. Doom's always been about: "use whatever the hell you like to tear shit up".  It does not make the game itself worst in anyway, but just Un-Doom like compared to 2016...

I also agree that the platforming is the worst part of the game. I feel like we never asked for it. When you don't have all the abilities it can get frustrating. In a game like Doom, platforming becomes a chore because it detaches you away from combat. 
 
To all the new anti-mainstream-gamers who are praising and defending this game to death on Youtube. You should play more popular old-school shooters (Doom, Quake, Dusk etc) to understand why people don't really appreciate this game. You'll notice why Doom Eternal isn't a smooth transition to veterans of the genre.  

Is Doom Eternal bad? By all means NO. Go Play it. But.. I'm just bringing awareness as to why people don't like this game. Because they're always hated upon for having a different opinion. It's very ignorant.

Following Doom 2016, Doom Eternal came with a wave of anticipation ahead of it's release. Unfortunately, I do feel as if the general consensus has been lukewarm towards the game, with some finding issue with the game's difficulty causing many to bounce off. I do actually get it. Though all enemies have an exploitable weakness or two, you will come across an enemy type during the second half of the game that requires a form of super shotgun ballet to defeat. 

I'll confess, I first completed this game on Xbox One when it was first released. Whilst I had such a blast with Doom 2016 and played through it multiple times on ever hardening difficulties. I found Doom Eternal extremely hard and had to drop the difficulty down to easy just to limp on through to credits. I did initially find the game to be a disappointment and kind of didn't want to talk about it after I finished it. 

But then I played it on PC with a mouse and keyboard. And the difference was night and day.

I feel stupid now for ever trying to play this game on a controller when it is so clearly a PC game through and through. On mouse and keyboard everything just clicks. For instance, unlock the heavy cannon scope and the rune that slows down time when you aim whilst falling through mid-air grants you these precious windows to line up your shot and your next plan of attack. The game basically gives you that 'discombobulate' moment, where you assess your surroundings, check which resources you need to replenish and which nasty you need to 'deal' with first. You constantly need to be refuelling your health, ammo and shields, it's the old Id mantra that has been at the heart of Quake 3, fight then recover.  

Not since Sekiro, has an action game actively pushed you to always be on the attack. Not since Sekiro has a game given me that sense of well earned elation for defeating those particular hard sticking points. By the end of the game, I practically look forward to the marauder encounters, as I had become more proficient at tackling them. It's the same feeling I have against some of the more memorable bosses in Dark Souls. A kind of respect and the anticipation of a good fight.   

The only place where the Doom Eternal falls down, is the story - which tries to explain the origins of the Doom Marine. After Doom 2016, which felt so refreshing in it's depiction of the main protagonist, it feels like a bit of a step backwards unfortunately.
  
Apart from that Doom Eternal is one of the best action games on the market. It's a more involved beast than it's predecessor, but it's a game I keep coming back to. Ramping up the difficulty. Ripping and Tearing. Can't wait for that DLC. 

I don't see how I'm supposed to play other normal shooters after Doom Eternal.

Doom Eternal is a game that demands your time and respect. For the first ~1/3 of the game, it was an exercise in frustration as I got my butt kicked over and over playing on the ultra-violence difficulty. I later dropped it down to hurt me plenty, even "i'm too young to die" at times. My suggestion would be to play at a higher difficulty to hone your skill, and drop it down as you need to, to get through the game. Make sure you are practicing using the full selection of skills and weapons, this game demands you utilize your entire arsenal to be an effective slayer. If you have a mouse with extra buttons, assign things to them like the chainsaw, grenade launcher, weapon mod switch, grenade type switch. Get used to the combat loop, and loop around the arenas, never stay still. Once you get good with the full arsenal, the game has an unmatched flow thats extremely satisfying, but it can be extremely difficult as well. Great reward awaits once you increase your skill though, and the skill ceiling is extremely high. I havent event touched the nightmare difficulty level, maybe someday. 
I went back to play doom 2016 after beating eternal, hadn't played it in like ~8 months. It feels so basic and slow compared to Eternal, I dont think I can enjoy it anymore like I  used to. Eternal has raised the bar.

Overall the game is fun and beautiful. The graphics are improved from 2016, it runs fully maxed out at ultra nightmare 1080p on my RX 5500XT 8GB, i5-3570/16GB DDR3, which is a modest spec sheet by todays standards. I cap the framerate to 72fps to keep it in freesync range, it sticks to 72fps 100% of the time, never stutters. Very well optimized, but it really needs 8GB VRAM to shine.

I havent tried the multiplayer yet, because it just doesnt appeal to me. I wish they would have included traditional MP modes, I really enjoyed the multiplayer in 2016, it was like a modern Quake. Oh well.

it's just really fun. Skip all the cutscenes and turn off dialog, though. The story is terrible and nearly ruins the character of Doomguy, but in terms of gameplay, its one of the best shooters ever- no joke. Every single weapon is so cool and it's really fun to play the harder difficulties. i'd recommend playing the first run on ultra-violence, and, assuming you like it, turn up the heat to nightmare because it is just so fun to execute all the movement and aiming and abilities, especially when you're forced to do it flawlessly.

review:
Gameplay wise its better than Doom 2016 in every way and might even rival Doom 64 for the top Doom game of all time. Okay, Doom 64 really wasn't all that great.

I have a couple of issues with the game's lore. It really borrows a lot of terminology from Christianity, but then it b-lines into some alternative dimensional reality. It seems like the story was hesitant to call the Makyrs angels, but, of course because of their shape, white color, etc. It's pretty easy to tell these creatures are modeled after traditional ideas of angelic beings. To me this theme is quite generic and has been carried out in too many games. I liked it better when it was one man's quest to kill demons. The whole, heaven conspiring with hell against earth, or earth being caught between some war between heaven and hell theme is a bit overplayed. Of course, all of this is implicit as we're not told who created earth, the angelic beings are the creators of Urdak and use other dimensions or realms to their advantage. They are, in many ways, just as evil as the demons.There's also some weird force evolutionary story behind all it, again, it's just overplayed and seems like the writers took little in the way of risks. Like what if heaven were truly good and hell were truly evil? That would be a novel idea in a video game haha. Anyway, its the most story driven Doom yet and even with the generic elements to the story, the Slayer is an interesting character and the overall game benefits from the additional narrative. 

Finally, I love the fast paced action, resource planning, the use of the blood punch, and the glory kills system. All of these things work together to create a little strategy in combat, but not so much that its overdone. I am not a big fan of the gore, I know, you are playing one of the goriest games ever made, but for me it is truly the game play that really kept me coming back to this game. I wish there were more games like this that didn't necessarily have to be so blood soaked. I honestly hope that Retro Studios (Metroid Prime series) has played a lot of this game, because the action and platforming employed here would be absolutely brilliant in Metroid Prime 4.

Doom 2, 2.

So initially upon release I rated the game positively but as time goes on and I revisit the game, there are too many missteps taken by the devs that I cannot ignore.

- The Hub world feels incredibly out of place and lazy, the game ends up feeling disjointed with so many distinct locations and hardly anything to glue them together smoothly.
- The weakpoints completely break the game for me, you are instantly punished for not using the weapons/weakpoint needed to take down some enemies. It makes the freedom of Doom 2016 basically disappear. 
- Why is there so much platforming all of a sudden? I understand a little bit for battles to add verticality, or having some for exploration; this game takes it to a new extreme though, it's excessive. 

While the game has a fantastic soundtrack and does feel amazing to play, these negatives ultimately turned me off and I never completed it. It just doesn't live up to the masterpiece that is Doom 2016, I've completed that game about three times and it's sad this game was such a big departure from that. Hopefully the third game will go back to Doom 2016's style.

DOOM eternal is soo much better than doom 2016 imo. in 2016 i had to pace myself HARD when trying to get through that game. sure it was fun but i got bored after like 1 mission. The game just felt so repetitive that i could only play through it one mission every day or 2 to finish it. this happened 2 years ago when i played it for the first time, and it happened to me again when i played it in january in preparation for this game. When i got eternal i couldn't stop playing until i beat it. I beat it in like 3 days as opposed to like 3 weeks with 2016 cause i never got bored. DOOM eternal also has the same number of levels as 2016, but the levels are longer. I even replayed it immediately after i beat it on nightmare difficulty cause i was loving my time with the game.

in 2016 all the weapons felt absolutely useless except for the super shotgun. that thing had like hundreds of bullets, you could shoot it twice before every reload, and it did insane damage. In eternal all the guns have a purpose because they toned down the max ammo of the weapons. Now most people didn't like this change and i'll admit i didn't like it either for the first couple hours, but it grew on me cause it forced me to think strategically and not just turn my brain off from extremely easy mindless combat.

DOOM eternal does have some things that i don't like but those are few and far between. I think there are too many buttons to keep track of. most of the time i would just forget entirely that grenades exist and never use them and i only started using some of the other stuff like flame belch around halfway through the game. I think the multiplayer is some of the worst multiplayer iv'e ever played, but the campaign is well worth it on it's own. I think the purple goo and the tentacles were an awful idea, and they shove the story down your throat too much, The marauder used to be a big issue i had with the game but as time went on he got easier, especially with the super shotgun-ballista combo.

Most of the problems everyone else has with this game i love. people hate the dash and the small amount of platforming they have to do. I absolutely LOVE the dash and i never found the platforming hard or a reason to dislike the game. Most of the people who say that probably just have never played platformers and/or are extremely bad at them. A lot of people don't like that the game feels more arcadey. So what if the graphics are a little more animated and brighter that doesn't detract anything from the game itself.

Now lets just hope this DLC will be just as good as the base game or better! But i'm sure it will be.

Having played this game for 60 hours (at the moment), i can safely say that this game didn't disappoint me at all. In fact i think its a masterpiece and  a lot better or maybe i should say its an upgrade to Doom 4. Dont get me wrong  Doom 4 is an excellent game.
The graphics, soundtrack and level design is amazing. The plot is really great.

[h1] Extra life & Abillities [/h1]
I really love how they added extra options and useful abilities in this game that you have to unlock or it is given to you so that you get the most out of the game.The downside is that it isnt consistent with the previous Doom game and by that i mean the options and abilities in this game arent available in the previous one. Like for instance you can climb walls or slow down time briefly to make an accurate shot. 
Its not really a big deal but to me it feels like im playing a whole new separate Doom game instead of an continuation of Doom 4

Also feel like the developers nerfed the game a bit with the Extra Lives and Reinforced Sentinel Armor option. Again, not a big deal. There were some moments in Doom 4 where i couldnt progress in the game because of some annoying demons that i had to deal with and the only way to get passed them is to lower the difficulty. 
In this game you just waste a 1up and continue fighting with the same difficulty without having to redo the battle again. This kinda saves you some frustration.

[h1] Weakness & Customization  [/h1]
They added some new demons in the game to create some variety on the battlegrounds. What i really like is that they also added some weakness to each demon if you want to kill them efficiently. You dont necessarily have to use their weakness to defeat them. You can  also choose to attack some of them  head on.
If i could pick one demon that annoys the hell out of me, i would choose the Arch-vile. Seriously i cant get near him or he'll burn me. I cant attack him head on because of his flame wall and even if i hit him he''ll teleport somewhere else and continue with summoning demons. Sometimes an  BFG shot wont kill him even though hes not hiding behind his flame wall. Demons like the Arch-vile need precision and fast reflexes

I can clearly see the developers spent much time on it because not only did they try to make the game look gorgeous with stunning graphics but they even created an customize-able UI and you can even change how  your slayer or demon looks like

[h1] Battlemode [/h1]
In all honesty, i dont like this mode. The main reason why I dont like it is because the other day I witnessed on a stream where two players were playing as an Revenant and they easily won all rounds in less than 2 minutes.This was by the way not just in one game but in several games. Sounds really fun, right? 

[h1] Improvements [/h1]
Things that im missing in this Doom game:
- A Deathmatch next to Battlemode.
- Few missions where you  infiltrate or fight as a demon. So far there was just one moment in the game where i had to go as a Revenant. What was the point of introducing the ability to poses an demon if were not going to use it often in other missions?
- Seeing the resistance instead of hearing them in broadcast at the fortress. I know theyre not the main focus but it wouldnt hurt if they got some screen time and it would make it a bit convincing about humans trying to survive the demon invasion.
- An option to convert your points to other type of points. At moment if have a lot of Praetor suit points that I dont need anymore because I already unlocked all of the suit abilities.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]
Overall it has a excellent single player campaign and I definitely recommend it.
Very intense and fast-paced. Would be sick if the demon skins applied in the campaign as well though!

Doom Eternal is, without hyperbole, one of the best FPS's of all time, with one major catch that will make or break the game for you -- it is built from the ground up to be played only one way, with not much room to experiment. 

There are a few missteps (most notably the purple sludge sections) but overall Eternal blows DOOM 2016 out of the water. With each gun being a tool with specific purpose, and like 4 cooldowns to track, it feels like a multiplayer hero shooter at 3x the speed. It's crazy intense, and when you finally master its gameplay loop, supremely rewarding. The graphics are downright gorgeous. Load times are almost instantaneous even without a SSD. The score by Mick Gordon has thrown off the semi-dubstep-metal leanings of DOOM 2016 and is now EVEN BETTER. The collectibles and secrets are well worth finding. The deep world building and lore from the previous game return, but the story is front and center this time (with a few surprises) and it does a stellar job at selling the Doomguy/player as the stuff of legends.

Eternal already has great replay value, and while id Software have been slow with the promised stream of new content, the Nightmare difficulty and Master Levels ensure I'll be playing this for many more hours. One of the best games of all time, really.

Ok. to start off, this game is no joke, it is the best shooter i have ever played, so i tried to review it, as briefly as possible.

GAMEPLAY
This is the most fun you will ever have in a fps, no camping with sniper rifles, no holding position and waiting for the enemy, just sheer fast paced violence. As you progress trough the campaign, you get more and more abilities and upgrades, and by the end of the game, you will blast trough doom hunters without even noticing it. Also have to mention, the game is actually pretty hard until you get the hang of it, so i recommend to start on the ultra-violence difficulty and anything lower (of course, if you aren't used with the gameplay).

STORY
Ok, so the lore is really deep, but it is disposoable. That is why most of it can be found in the codex entries you collect trough the game. It's a choise id software had to make, because DOOM isn't really a strory driven experience. Again, if you want to, you can learn all sorts of stuff about the doomguy and the night sentinels etc.

SOUNDTRACK
I am a metalhead, if I might say, so there is no surprise I think this is excellent. Even if you don't like djent, and metal music in general, you will still appreciate the soundtrack, it just fits perfectly within the gameplay. Watch the documentaries on Mick Gordon's youtube channel, he provides a lot of info about the thing that went into the making of this masterpiece.

MULTIPLAYER

OVERALL
<<9.66/10>>
