Before I start with the review, it‘s good to know my accomplishments in the game and how I get to the game and information about this review.

I‘ve completed game on the Nightmare (Highest difficulty) and I‘m trying to complete Ultra-Nightmare (In Doom Community known as „The Path of Eternal Torment“)
I‘ve completed master levels (Extream versions of some levels) The Cultist Base and The Arc Complex on Nightmare.
Because DOOM is my most favourite franchise, I‘ve pre-ordered it for 60 euros.
This review is only my view on this game, I‘m not inspirated by any other review on DOOM Eternal.
In this review I‘ll compare DOOM and DOOM Eternal campaign. Also I‘ve tried to make it spoiler-friendly
With this in mind I‘ll start with my review.

Arcade / Serious
I always thought that DOOM is a serious franchise.  
DOOM (2016) was perfect in it's serious feel and althrought there weren't many enviroments, all of that enviroments seemed functional and realistic. When were you walking through the UAC buildings everything seemed to had purpuse. On the other hand, you could easily get killed, because you thought that this is a ledge, but it isn't.
DOOM Eternal has more of a Arcade game feeling, than the serious. It still look good and enviroment is still interesting to look at, but it has much less of details than in DOOM. Also some levels do not seem functional. For example, when I was at the Cultist Base level, I got into a room, where you had some square that was surrounded by abyss and you had to jump across some poles that were at the side of that room. At first I thought that it‘s great, I know exactly what to do. But when I get across I just thought: „Why would anyone build inside a building a square, dig up an abyss and put poles on the sides of that room?“ Also the game has in some cases very strange colors. For example, when you chainsaw an enemy, he drops all kinds of ammo, just like in DOOM. But now all of the ammo has different colors, so it looks like the enemy just vomited rainbow.

Story
The story is perfect in both DOOM and DOOM Eternal
In DOOM, story is telling about locations you are walking in, enemies, Doom Slayer, characters and interesting objects, also with some history of UAC and hell. The story can be learn from data logs, scattered around locations of campaign, so its only up to you, if you want to read it.
DOOM Eternal story is made the same way. There are still data logs (Now documents) and it‘s still only up to you, if you want to read it. But now, I think that DOOM Eternal is better with story. DOOM Eternal expands the story of UAC, enemies (In case of enemies, they have put additional information, on how to defeat them. Again it‘s up to you, if you want to read that informations), Doom Slayer, hell and some objects, but also adds the story about Earth, heaven, and a Sentinel world.

Music
Mick Gordon did wonderful music again. I won‘t talk about the problems Mick Gordon had with Bethesda. He still had his hands on that soundtrack (And his guitar). And his idea of metal choir was brilliant. Thats all I can say.

Gameplay

Weak points
DOOM Eternal enemies now have weak points. Very controversial function. But I was happy to see that in game. And even more happy that it‘s not necessary to dominate the game. In fact, weak points are important only at the beginning of the game. Then you can simply ignore it, because you will have weapons strong enough to be able to ignore it. Interesting is, that DOOM Eternal have given new meaning to weak points. Of course there are still headshots and new weak points that when shot will deal more damage. But more importantly, weak points are designated in two ways.
First one is specific weapons on specific enemies. This was seen in DOOM, but in DOOM Eternal it‘s much more important to use right weapons on enemies. Because if you don‘t you will lose LOTS of ammo.
Second one is weak points, that‘s good to shoot at. And not because it will do more damage. But because shooting at some weapons of enemies, will DESTROY them and you will disable certain attacks that the enemy had with that weapon.

Mobility
DOOM had one big problem. The Slayer was slow. In DOOM Eternal this problem is solved much better than just increasing movement speed. They add the dash ability. With increased movement speed, it would be too easy to dodge incoming attacks. But with dash you actualy have to click a button to dodge a attack. And believe it or not, that‘s a huge difference. Dash can be used in parkour, combat and travel. You will always use dash, because if in DOOM was rule, that standing still is death, then in DOOM Eternal moving without dash is death.

Enemies
There is one very popular rule in DOOM. If you see an enemy, shoot at it until it dies. But in DOOM Eternal, you must think how you want to kill the enemy. DOOM Eternal enemies are more complex than DOOM enemies. Some enemies have slight resistence against some weapons. For example the heavy demons (I prefer calling them mortaly challenged, than demons. It can be an offensive term) have slight resistance against plasma rifle and heavy assault rifle. The shield troopers that were so unpopular in DOOM are still present, but that shield has weekness. The plasma rifle does very big damage to those shields and if enough bullets have been shot, the shield will explode, killing trooper and damaging nearby enemies. Shooting with other basic weapons at those shields would be an unbelievable waste of ammo.

Parkour
In DOOM, there were some parkour and it was already a problem, because if you would fall into the void, it killed you instantly. Something that‘s extremely stressful on Ultra-Nightmare. DOOM Eternal has parkour that doesn‘t kill you, but it has maybe too much of it. Not for me, I consider it easy. In most cases. But I‘ve let my friend play DOOM Eternal and I saw, that he‘s bad in parkour. It soon became boring. He was failing to accomplish those parkours and I had to do that for him. If you are a person, that have problem with parkour, then it will be a big problem. The parkour is meant to cool you down from a arena you were figting in, but if you spend 10 minutes on one parkour, then it‘s very boring.

Difficulty
The difficulty is something interesting. It works the same as in DOOM. The higher difficulty the more things you‘ll have to do in a short time (This was probably designed by adding more damage to enemies and by making enemies more aggressive) In DOOM Eternal, many people are complaining, that even on I‘m too Young to Die (Easy difficulty), it‘s still very hard. But it‘s good, because in DOOM, there were still a small amount of things you had to care about. In DOOM Eternal, there is much more pressure on you, because you have much more functions, and every function has it‘s own button. To explain this little bit better, in DOOM, the only important buttons for me were: Movement (WSAD, Space), shoot (Left Mouse, Right Mouse), melee (F), weapons (1-8, G), and equipment (CTRL).
And now DOOM Eternal: Movement (WSAD, Space, Shift), shoot (Left Mouse, Right Mouse), melee (E), weapons (1-8), equipment (R, G, and some changing button I dont remember), and special equipment (V, T, C).
All of this equipment have to be used at right time and because some people simply are not fast enough to control all these functions, they fail even on Im too Young to Die.

Overall
Overall DOOM Eternal is a great game. While the game graphicly is not of a improve from DOOM. The gameplay of this game is truly a revolution. If you want to dominate the game, then you have to adapt your tactics to weapons and enemies of this game.

For those people who read this till the end, I thank you, and I believe that I gave you some useful information to build on your decision on buying this game or not. For those people that didn‘t read this till the end, I thank you, and I believe that if find, that you don‘t like this game, then you will just simply ignore it, and move onto other great games.

epic game fr

Quantity over quality.

Doom Eternal is more. More demons, more demons, longer fights, and on paper that's great. In practice, it becomes a matter of learning to manage chaos. Keeping track of every demon quickly becomes impossible.

Eternal doesn't hold back. It feels like the kind of game that would be perfect to jump into a few days after finishing the original, because the difficulty jump is noticeable right from the start. Part of it is, as is the tradition, Doomguy has lost all his weapons and upgrades from the previous game. And that inflates the difficulty early on, particularly on Ultra-Violence, and it feels awful rough as a result. I died. A lot. And not to really tough enemies, but relatively basic ones.

As I upgraded, though, the game opened up. New tactics and means of survival became available. And once that happened, the game became fun again. Doom Eternal needed to start you off stronger and have the upgrades be more gradual, or at least deliver them faster. Once you get the hang of everything, it's a blast to fly around the map, picking off demons and delivering killing blows while never remaining too far from death.

But there's some issues. Additions of "weak points" and more subtle weaknesses of certain demons remove some of the violent, creative problem solving from the 2016 Doom. If you're not hitting Cacodemons with a shotgun grenade, you are generally Doing It Wrong, which is a disappointment. Conversely, the ability to shear certain demons' weapons off is a useful tactic, but it's usually not as effective as just... killing them. 

Though the challenges return from 2016 Doom, they vary in quality. Some of them just a nice encouragement to master a certain skill, but some are the tiresome "execute this demon in one specific way". The worst are a particular shielded type of demon you have to fight in one specific way. Or you're Doing It Wrong, and you're dead. Similarly, bosses often require a specific target or weapon, or you're... Doing It Wrong. I just wanna shoot a thing with a cool gun, not get quizzed on the dev's ideal way to dissemble a Mancubus!

It also goes on [i]long[/i], definitely longer than it needed to. At certain points I just felt exhausted with the gameplay because it was the same loop over and over, often with little pacing or breathers inbetween. I ended up welcoming lore and dialogue just to break things up. Still, it's definitely a challenge, and once your kit is filled out, utterly satisfying to punish demons.

This features a lot more platforming, and while most of it isn't too hard, it involves more blind jumps and pattern recognition than I'd like. It feels like we just needed enjoy to make sure we understood the new platforming elements for actual fights, but there are timed areas, chained jumps, and just a lot of leaping around to do that largely feels put in there because they added the platforming elements than it being that exciting on its own. In addition, there are the aforementioned "blind jumps" from time to time, where you can't recognize your destination or next step until you're already into the process of defying lava.

With all my complaints, it may be surprising for me to give it a thumbs up. And that's because the core gameplay from Doom 2016 is still there, in the end. It involves a much more defensive approach to combat, moving and picking your fights and often punishing the more aggressive gameplay of its predecessor. But I did appreciate that it was willing to be unbashedly a [i]video-game[/i], harkening back to elements like extra lives, more power-ups, and gimmicky stages.

But it's also more unfocused as a result. Doom 2016 was a stronger game, but Doom Eternal is still good. It just keeps trying to be things that it's not.

After putting roughly 160 hours into this game, there a few things I can say in regards to it.

Translating the classic Arena Shooter has been a difficult task for most AAA devs over the past few years, where many of the original shooters have seemingly deviated off their original roots by adding things such as regenerating health and a multiplayer with loadouts, DOOM Eternal breathes a new life into the arena shooter genre by adding a host of new mechanics and movement abilities that call back to the roots of Arena FPS games while keeping things fresh and exciting.

Movement is absolutely phenomenal, and weapons such as the Meathook can send you soaring at speeds unrivaled in most modern FPS. 

Combat is fluid and exciting, and far more interesting opposed to DOOM 2016. Weapons are varied, monsters require forethought instead of a constant drip feed of one weapon. It allows your earlier arsenal to still remain relevant as you progress through the game.

The sound design is fantastic, and weapons have a metallic clank to them that makes them feel less like cannons and more like metallic death machines. Enemies explode into gory chunks that splatter and slosh around as they collapse into gory pinatas. I also don't need to sing Mick Gordon's fantastic work on the soundtrack; it's universally known that DOOM Eternal's soundtrack is one of the greatest Video Game Soundtracks of all time.

The story is nothing to write home about...but there's clearly an attention to detail and love for the universe that was seemingly lacking from the series third entry.

The multiplayer is a mixed bag, though the devs are constantly adding and updating things to balance it out, and all upcoming content has been confirmed to be free.

I definitely recommend this game. Absolutely my GOTY for 2020.

Are you kidding? Of course I'd recommend this. It's a modern Doom game.

I have over 100 hours in Doom 2016, and this is just as good, though it's definitely not the same. I actually really appreciate the changes they made though. If you want Doom 2016, go play Doom 2016. It's still an absolutely incredible game, one of the best of it's generation, and it's not going anywhere. Doom Eternal is not trying to be Doom 2016. Doom Eternal is Doom, but bigger and crazier in EVERY SINGLE WAY. More demons, more glory kills, more weapons, more mods, more random equipment, more random gameplay mechanics (that unequivocably make the game better, I dare you to find one person who DOESN'T like the dash ability), more boss fights, more unique environments, more everything. If you like Doom, especially the predecessor to this, you owe it to yourself to at least give it a try. 

Fair warning though, it is a hell of a lot harder than any of the games before it. I beat 2016 on Nightmare multiple times, and it's the only difficulty I play on anymore. I have yet to beat Eternal on Nightmare. There are times when it just feels unfair.

If you want a game where you can just turn off your brain, use 1-2 guns. and coast through the campaign, Doom Eternal is not the game for you.

Doom Eternal demands that you use your brain in combat. This isn't Doom 2016 where the Super Shotgun and Gauss Cannon are all you need. You will need to use every tool in your arsenal to succeed, especially at higher difficulties. 

Weapon switching is absolutely critical. Different weapons are more effective at taking down certain demons, as certain demons have weak points that can be exploited. The plasma rifle is excellent against energy shields, while the scoped version of the Heavy Assault Rifle can shoot off a Mancubus's or Revanant's cannons. 

Another thing you'll notice is that pickups are scarce. But, they're really not. The demons ARE the pickups. You want some armor? Light some demons on fire and kill them. They'll drop it. You want health? Glory kill some demons, or upgrade your ice bomb and blood punch, so that demons will drop health when killed by these abilities. You need some ammo? Use your chainsaw. Unlike 2016, fuel will recharge when you run empty. These complaints of people "running out of ammo too quickly" are the complaints of people who refuse to adapt to this game's mechanics. If you prance around using one weapon, you'll run out of ammo for that gun quickly. If you don't utilize fodder demons for resources, you will die.

Having so many abilities can feel overwhelming at first, but once you keep playing, it'll all come together, and when it does, it feels REALLY GOOD. The combat, which is the core of this game, excels in every department.

There's a bit more story in the form of cutscenes, but if this doesn't interest you, you can skip the cinematics. The story can be expanded upon by reading the codex entries you pick up throughout the levels you play. The story wasn't a piece of art, and it wasn't bad. Like 2016, the story just serves to push you into more demons, but this time around, there's a bit more lore for those who are interested.

If you're buying this game, and you've played Doom 2016, don't play it like you played Doom 2016. Once you start learning the mechanics, you're going to have a blast playing this game. All in all, it took me ~11 hours to beat the single player on Ultra-Violence difficulty. This was without doing all of the extra challenges and secret exploring. 

I've yet to play the multiplayer, but based on single player alone, I highly recommend this game to any FPS enthusiast.

Everybody wants to be a curator and give long reviews like they are describing $12,000 whiskey. What can I say that you haven't heard? The game has great heavy metal music, extreme visceral insanity, and a story line that you don't play for. I have issues immersing myself into games, but I can happily say that this game immersed me more than I ever have, at least in recent years. The reason why its immersive is because of its simplicity. You just shoot things, run fast, and bathe yourself in the blood and intestines of ugly demons. With modern games requiring more strategic thought processes, they have been creating a greater distance between the player and the game, well, at least for me. DOOM requires very little thought to excel; You are player, everything else is enemy, shoot enemy to win, use gun, win. It is a wonderful break from today's oversaturated first person shooter genre. If you have grown tired of the common shooter, take a break with DOOM, you won't regret it.

I thought it was borderline impossible to make DooM 2016 better. Like, I really had to nitpick to find anything wrong with that game. Slick gunplay, great music, and lots of demons to rip and tear. What more can you ask for? 

More of everything apparently, because that's what DooM Eternal is: everything that made 2016 such a good experience but cranked up to 11. The combat and gunplay cycle is quite a lot less forgiving, which takes some getting used to but that makes it quite a lot more satisfying when you manage to take down armies of the damned by yourself. There is a bit more of a balancing act here, I found myself needing to balance my weapon use to get certain resources (armor, health, ammo). I personally enjoyed that part, ymmv though. The music is also even more dirty, aggressive. Hellish. Mick Gordon really did well with 2016's OST, but Eternal's knocked it outta the park. Really is a shame the OST can't be bought anywhere, I'd give quite a lot to see that happen. The demons are fantastic as well. Classics like the Pinkies and Revenants are still here, while others like the Archvile return just to make life more difficult. Not only are there more demons, there are even more ways to kill them.

The only complaints I have? Maybe a bit much hand-holding. And ffs pls release the OST k thencc.

Otherwise I'd rate this game a solid 9/10 for taking everything good about 2016 and making it better.

I love this game. It is quite a different take from D2016 though you'll see the cross-over. 

Overall, I really enjoy this game and of my FPS this is the one I continue coming back to. Nothing quite feels as awesome as when you're playing this; you're unstoppable. You feel like a god. If you go back to any other FPS, it will feel sluggish and outdated. 

The platforming was not as bad as I imagined. My only true dislike is the extra lives system (which really come in handy later in the game so you don't get slowed down with death) that you often receive before a difficult arena but you do not get input on whether they should be used or not. Extra lives are automatically used. I wish I would get a prompt asking me if I want to use one. My first play through and every arena wiped the floor with me. Often there is a strategy to learn or mistakes to be avoided. 

The hardest demon is the archvile, use the crucible on them already and get it over with. The marauders are annoying at first but you develop proficiency over time. Don't worry about making mistakes or  developing your own system of fighting--it will come over time and the game will help you to make the best choices. 

My only other big suggestion is that you look online for the appropriate mods for each gun. The best mods are not the same as D2016. Sticky bombs on the shotgun is amazing. Makes the shotgun useful and primary for me again.

ID Software manage to revive this old franchise starting from DOOM 2016 that introduced many things and improvement especially to the combat system. This time they crank it up all the way to the highest level they can possibly imagine and do. What I love about DOOM Eternal is they try to position themselves as a unique breed of FPS in the age of generic fps that rely heavily on stealth, battle royale and etc, DOOM Eternal encourage you as the DOOM Slayer to aggressively engage with demons to better control the fight. You have many tools and weapons to slice and dice the demons. There are some game mechanic such as chainsaw for ammo, glory kill for health and flame belch for armor. These 3 mechanics is very important to better fight and survive hordes of demon especially in higher difficulty. On top of that, DOOM 2016 and DOOM Eternal is very rich in lore and storytelling about the Slayer himself. Throughout the game, you will found codex entry that explain events and answer some questions from the previous game. It is very interesting to say that the lore present itself kinda like ancient history but feel like comic book which is really great and I love that. But, if you don't care about that it's okay too. As the game progress, you will empowering yourself and master the combat system to become the ultimate killing machine against the Hell forces. The feel of fighting Marauder is so frustrating at first time, but beating Marauder at high difficulty (I played on Ultra-violence and Nightmare) is so good. I don't care much when it comes to people complain about Marauder because some of them keep mindless shooting attitude without changing to new tactics and other weapon. Instead, they just use super shotgun which is totally lazy. Nevertheless, this a great game and masterpiece of FPS in many years. I do hope that DOOM Eternal will be crown as the GOTY because the game is really great and interesting. Besides campaign, I can't really say anything about Battlemode. because I haven't play yet. But, new update improves the game in lot of ways, some in campaign and Battlemode. The new upcoming Ancient Gods DLC P1 is very promising as the campaign expansion that will take place after the event of main campaign. Maybe some new Master Levels will come out sometime after the DLC that gear towards experience player. Also, I'm looking forward to the Invasion mode that ID Software teased us back at Quake Con 2019 where the player can invade other player campaign as a demon. As we all know, the mode got delayed because the world turn upside down this year and many of us need to work from home. Same thing goes for the developer as well. Not to forget that some player such as _proteh_ start to heavily mod this game to test their skill by putting 10-20 super heavy demons with 3 Marauder at the same time in an arena. This is really insane and fun ways to play the game, just to show what the player can really achieve.

When I first heard of this game, I was hyped. DOOM 2016 for me was and still is one of the greatest shooters and video games I have ever played, and having played through Eternal probably a dozen or so times now, I can safely say it surpasses its predecessor and then some. 

The game plays differently from 2016 in that you are forced to be thinking constantly, managing your resources, burning enemies for more armour, chainsawing for ammo, and glory killing for health. You need to be constantly switching weapons to counter the different demons and the threats they pose. It's a fast-paced, metal as fuck chess game that will make you feel like a god each time you conquer an arena and really put Austin Power's hair on your chest.

Their definitely is a learning curve with this game; the new mechanics like managing resources and taking them from your foes can take time to get used to, as well as the speed of the combat. Once you master it, you truly enter the "fun zone."

In terms of art style, Eternal has abandoned the dark, gritty look of 2016 in favour of a bright, colourful, arcade-like aesthetic. I like the style a lot myself, as it gives off this badass, comicbook appeal, further reinforced by the over-the-top nature of the gameplay and the story.

Some people have complained about the over-abundance of platforming in the game, as their is quite a lot of it. Personally, I find the platforming to be very enjoyable, as you get a moment of levity between the relentless battles as you traverse these massive, gorgeous looking, unigue environments. No two levels look the same, which really adds to the replay value. Further adding is the abundance of secrets and collectables hidden throughout. You can find collectable figures of all the demons, which can be viewed in the Slayer's man cave. You can also find tokens to upgrade your suit, further bolstering your power and abilities.

Story-wise, the game picks up some time after 2016, though it is never explicitly stated when this is. It throws you right into the action, and leaves you the task of understanding whats going on by finding the lore pages and delving into them. I quite enjoy this system, as it lets you have fun and get right back to killing demons, without having to sit through lengthy cutscenes expositing all the info. The game leaves you to fill in the details, and even without the lore pages, you still get a grasp of the basic driving force behind what it is your doing and why your doing it. You are never left completely in the dark, and given just enough information to make you want to take a break and learn more about the characters and the universe your in. All the cutscenes too can be skipped thankfully, which I often find myself doing on repeat playthroughs.

The music was once again done by Australian composer Mick Gordon, and he did not let down, delivering a soundtrack that perfectly captures the speed and tone of the game. Filled to the brim with tons of new and amazing heavy metal tunes, as well as several renditions of classic DOOM tracks. This soundtrack is a blast to headbang to.

As for the multiplayer, id Software developed BATTLEMODE, where three people get into two teams; one is a single, fully loaded DOOM Slayer, and the other two play as demons of their own choosing. Currently, their are five demons playable: Revenant, Marauder, Mancubus, Pain Elemental, and the Archvile. The first team to win three rounds wins. Personally, I really enjoy this mode, as both the demons and the Slayer. That said, the matchmaking isn't the best, and often pairs you with either players with too little experience, or too much. Plus the Bethesda server is pretty shitty, and won't let me join matches more often than I'd like, despite my fast internet. Regardless, it's still a fun and enjoyable experience, once you get over the learning curve.

All in all, I can't praise this game enough. For me, it truly deserves its title as the Terminator 2 of video games, as it took all the stuff that made DOOM 2016 a glorious bloodbath and made it faster, more stimulating, and fun. If your a fan of classic FPS titles, or just faced-paced shooters in general, I would highly recommend DOOM Eternal. You might need to lower the difficulty til' you get used to the mechanics, which the game lets you do at any time, but once you understand them, you can truly rip and tear your way to victory. Now get out their and prove your worth, great Slayer!

Doom Eternal is a masterpiece on every level. The combat loop, level design, weapons and weapon mods, player movement, equipment launchers, enemies, bosses, platforming, sound design, art design, graphics, technical game optimization, story, lore and BMF status. Everything comes together beautifully to make this game experience the new gold standard for FPS gameplay. This game pushes you to be a better FPS player. You need to be mobile, constantly assess your situation (ammo, armor, health) and switch between weapons to cycle through different ammo types (shotgun, rifle, rockets, plasma etc..). The basic combat loop: Switch weapon mods on the fly based on the threat, switch to your super shotgun and meat hook off a flying enemy to reposition, flamebelch a group of fodder enemies to get some armor, chainsaw to regain ammo and assess your situation, target enemy weak points to eliminate priority threats, glory kill for great success, double jump to a monkey bar and double dash to reposition again. If you can adapt your playstyle to fit the combat loop of this game, you feel like the baddest dude around. Mastery of this is hard but so satisfying. Doom Eternal is one of the best games I've ever played. 1,000% recommend.
The only problem with this game is that at some point it ends. Life is temporary, but Doom is Eternal, Rip and Tear, until it is done.

tl;dr at the bottom

the campaign for doom eternal is one of the most addictive and fun experiences ive ever had playing a singleplayer video game. i highly recommend that you try it if you are down to learn how to survive by using your aggression to both kill everything and get all of your resources back from doing so.

i could gush on and on about how much they did a good job making this campaign really fun and how it feels really rewarding when you use the right tool for the job, but i don't think i need to

the multiplayer, battlemode, is a different story though. its like crack cocaine lol. not many people get into it but if you do, you will get extremely addicted to an unhealthy level then crash and feel the negative effects

if you are good enough to learn how to play the mode, playing with an enemy that is either a little bit above or at your skill level is very very very fun. however, said games are extremely rare as the battlemode playerbase has dropped down significantly from launch.

as of the time of this review, the latency is still incredibly bad, with a near 2 second delay from where you are on your screen compared to everyone elses. this is really really bad, especially with a game where dashing out of the way of things can mean life or death and then you get shot around a corner and explode into little bits.

trying to get into battlemode now will likely not get you anywhere. either you will stomp fellow new players or learn the ropes with somebody in the official battlemode discord, until you get destroyed by a high level player/lag/something else, then ultimately quit.

i highly recommend that you buy this game for the outstanding singleplayer, as well as the coming single player dlc packs, and the (hopefully) more casual invasion mode. 

i do not recommend that you try out the multiplayer, as from what ive seen from my own personal experience and that of my friends, it will most likely end in you just feeling bad about either your skill or the state of the mode. just go play quake champions or any other arena shooter if you want that stuff.

tl;dr after 1000 hours, final verdict is that ultrakill is better

This game is truly a masterpiece. Near perfect level designs fast paced keep you on the edge of your seat combat. What a great game. It offers much more than Doom 2016 and it was quite an adjustment. I started my play through on Nightmare and the learning curve was STEEP. The earlier levels are much more challenging when your toolkit is lacking. But as the game progresses and you gain access to more mods, you find yourself fighting very challenging encounters with relative ease. That being said, you can die VERY quickly on nightmare. I cannot imagine playing this on Ultra Nightmare. I would not do that to myself.

One lesson I will pass on, as it was a really important thing that I needed to learn. The goal of encounters is to kill the heavies and and super heavies. Perhaps I should have realized this earlier, but for some reason it did not click intuitively for me. I started trying to whittle down easier enemies so I could work towards killing heavies and super heavies, and kept finding myself getting overwhelmed. They will spawn indefinitely. Killing the others will end each encounter. The rest are fodder for the chainsaw or flame belch, which needs to be done as often as possible.

I was disappointed to see the story didn't pick up exactly where 2016 left off, because it ended with a cliffhanger. The story of this game is much richer than 2016 (though still light), but does not connect in a meaningful way to 2016. It is still interesting though.

Have not tried multiplayer yet, but it looks like a ton of fun.

i really like this game, but there's just some glaring issues that i can't really get past. for one, the crashing is RIDICULOUS. i can't even open take a screenshot without it soft locking and closing. to be fair, this could be attributed to my computer, but i can run red dead redemption 2 on ULTRA, so i highly doubt it. game play wise, there's things to like and things to dislike; i know many complain about the ammo system, but i think it's an interesting concept, the problems with game play to me come in when you consider the movement and some mechanics. sometimes i'll just clip into the environment instead of climbing, i'll try and jump over an enemy only to hit an invisible wall, the bloodpunch can hardly work the way i feel it was intended (to space out crowds, avoid being cornered), and by god by GOLLY do i FUCKING hate the platforming; whoever purposed the idea let me tell you, i hope it wasn't fucking ID software, because it is atrocious.  also something worth nothing i suppose is that i feel as though this game can actively punish you for charging into combat head on, like in the 2016 doom? i don't see this as a pro or a con, just a tweak of the game play that could be considered; me personally, it's something i'm a fan of,  but i could see how it'd turn people off. there are, of course, good parts; for instance, i feel like the system of damage where you take chunks of enemies flesh off with each shot is a brilliant choice; its a very nice way to keep track of your damage, when the game works it works, you can really pull off some satisfying moments if you push yourself to it, as i said earlier, i don't think the ammo system is bad (not necessarily great), the enemies are varied and each have their own exploitable weaknesses to the point i could say that it's a fair challenge, although i feel some enemies attacks can border on being annoying for the sake of annoying; namely the carcass' shields.

tldr; overall, the game can be buggy and messy, with some good moments few and far between the occasional tedium, but i had enough fun i can confidently say it's a great game. 7/10.

Doom Eternal is a great 2020 update of the classic Doom! that we all remember.  Unfortunately ... well, games have moved on from the glory days of Doom!, and the graphics improvements and some new weapon upgrade perks don't stop Doom Eternal from being fundamentally shallow and boring.  Run around killing things.  Run around killing more things.  Run around killing still more things, perpetually low on armor and ammunition.  You can only carry sixteen shotgun rounds at a time?  Seriously?  With all of the trash mobs on infinite respawn?

Sorry and all that, but these days I want more depth to my games than this mindless twitch-fest.

GOTY 2020

+ The singleplayer campaign is really good but has its issues just like any other AAA title. Worth $40-60 as-is. Might update review when DLC comes out.

- The multiplayer is BAD. It has promise but it has two major issues:
. - It's incredibly laggy. As the Slayer, look forward to a full second of delay between action and response vs mobs. One seconds of waiting for health after a kill, one seconds of waiting for an enemy to light after setting them on fire so you can get armor, one seconds after damaging before you can glory kill. It's utter nonsense. I can't tell you the demon's experience of the lag due to the other issue:
. - As a demon, good luck finding a competent teammate via matchmaking. Come in with a friend or lose. Don't have friends who own Doom Eternal and want to give Battlemode a try? Too bad!
- I do not trust the developers to "fix" Battlemode. They have been announcing plans to add a competitive mode and still haven't fixed major issues from day 1 (such as the lag). They added Denuvo Anti-Cheat POST-LAUNCH which you HAD to install even to play singleplayer (up until they removed it due to backlash).

The game launched with an ambitious season pass system, which is... okay I guess? I imagine you have to put 10-20 hours into battlemode for each season (which lasts a month, I think) in order to get all the loot you paid for, but there's just not enough variety in the gamemode to warrant that much effort for most people, especially with the above mentioned issues. There's also weekly challenges that you can complete for extra season pass EXP such as play 10 matches, kill 2+ demons 15 times with the chain gun, etc. but... It's just not doing it for me. 

TL;DR - do not buy for the multiplayer, do not have high hopes going into multiplayer. It's laggy and there aren't enough people playing it to warrant necessary changes for matchmaking.

review: after the first 60 seconds of this game i knew I found that awesome mix of blood, pain, and testing of patience I needed. A well crafted, fast paced shooter that hits home in all the right ways. the inclusion of a dash makes you feel more fluid and faster than 2016 DOOM. The difficulty scale is very comfortable to, on normal and below its welcoming for new players, and challenging for veterans on harder difficulties. If you want to crush demon skulls as much as the next man, this is your game. Obviously recommend a pickup on a sale, but know if you like high octane FPS shooter with interesting, but sometimes difficult to grasp story, your in for a treat.

I played it a bit. Its okay, I guess.
It's doom, It's good, what do you expect

It's Doom with extra fluid movement and added strategy.
Most of the negative reviews are people disagreeing with these changes, I am thankful for them.

The combat has a formula. 
Enemies are weak to specific weapons and you will find yourself juggling between them to most efficiently slay the demon filth. Ammo capacity is pretty limited so you will need to use your chainsaw when you find yourself low on ammo. Platforming quickly in combat is necessary and really adds to the enjoyment of encounters. Then there's also a flamethrower, grenades and weapon mods to play around with.

There are a lot of things to juggle while playing this game and it requires focus.
So if you got fog brain or are easily frustrated you might not have fun.
Once you get a hang of the controls the game gets gud.

Good to know DOOM 2016 was just a fluke on id's otherwise common modern trend of releasing exactly what their fans don't want. The platforming sucks, the cutscenes, hub world bs and even more complicated upgrade system are even more abundant and out of place - these weren't in DOOM 2016 and we were better off for it. The gunplay forces you to use all your weapons in a way that really restricts how you can approach fights, and it starts to feel super repetitive compared to the previous game. 

There was a good game hiding in here at some point, but there's an almost Disney-esque sense of "oh wait, this is popular we should have this too" level of bloat which is not only a massive slap in the face of DOOM fans, but a pretty damning indicator of what has happened with id's relationship with Bethesda. Tim Willits leaving before this game even released is a pretty good indicator of things going south.

If you're going to buy this, wait for it to inevitably go on 75% discount. If you're a classic DOOM fan, avoid this completely, you'll just get upset.

DOOM 2016 was a masterpiece, Eternal is like a gameplay mod where it keeps most of the complicated assets and replaces everything else with garbage.

This is a really fantastic VIDEO GAME
It is very fun to play. It is worth it.
But, in short, this game is like the Matrix Reloaded for better or worse.

The biggest issue is the narrative arc the creators imposed on this game. The 2016 Doom story is fantastically stupid simple. You're alone on a Mars mining base overrun by demons. EVERYTHING IS SO FUCKED! Wires are dangling from stuff, demonic shit has been going on. You alone have to get rid of this problem. COOL. Simple. The sense of place and the stakes at hand were very palpable in that game. 

Whatever story they are trying to tell in this Doom Eternal game is absolutely bonkers. I'm almost done playing this thing and I have no idea what the goal is or where I am 90% of the time. The stakes are so high (Earth is overrun by demons) that it almost feels like it doesn't matter. The initial planning of this game should have left this whole thing on Earth. There is so much to explore. It is also telling that a lot of the fan art I've seen related to this game tends to take place on the Earth levels. That is the most inspiring and relatable place you seem to visit in the game. Then you take this special portal to these cyber-medieval castles don't seem to have anything to do with anything. BUT. These random places are amazingly rendered. Each zone is so nicely detailed, intense, bizarre, and hilarious in it's own extreme way. 

Which brings me to my thesis. The Matrix Reloaded was a sequel to a film that needed no sequel. I was content to just see The Matrix. But I guess somebody felt the need to make this sequel. That movie takes Neo and the gang all around the world to who knows where, introduces way too much lore about Zion or whatever, has a council meeting, and all this baggage that doesn't really amount to much. BUT. This movie is so fun to watch. The fight scenes are so elegantly choreographed, extreme, intense, and fantastical much like this Doom Eternal. You probably won't watch the Matrix Reloaded to learn the mechanics of the Zion infrastructure, as you wouldn't play Doom Eternal to learn the history of the Sentinels. The narrative, if pushed aside, is just the vehicle for the ridiculous action portrayed in both Doom Eternal and The Matrix Reloaded. The reason I write all this is because I am disappointed at the opportunity missed by the game developers in creating this game. It's hard not to compare this to Doom (2016) and I would conclude that this is a completely new invention in the series. However, unlike the Matrix Reloaded this is a VIDEO GAME and it lives up to that genera to the highest degree. It is very fun and intense.

I think if I had not played Doom 2016 then this would be a instant recommendation, but I have played it extensively so what I wanted from a sequel doesn't match what was supplied. The low ammo / always near death approach just doesn't sit well with me. I like the story and the citadel bits etc, but the core combat has changed enough to leave me cold.

So it's Doom. It's fast paced, brutal, pulse thundering action that makes you feel like an absolute badass while tearing through demons both big and small with a plethora of weapons. Negatives first as there isn't much. 
This is a much harder game than the first, and the lack of a pistol with unlimited ammo that can make dispatching the random zombies that wander around more annoying. Your melee also no longer kills on its own, it only stuns enemies until you charge a blood punch that creates an area of effect of damage around you. 
There are some very annoying enemies, with most being fun to figure out, and some just being annoying ammo sponges until you figure out how to take them down. 
The slayer challenges don't replenish your ammo after doing them, and if you fail them you can try again, minus all the ammo you used trying the first time. These can be very annoying to try and try again. 
And now on to the positives! 
The soundtrack is brutal and wonderful and features previous ID game tracks as bonuses to be found through the world. 
The game, both graphically and stylistically looks amazing with the monsters looking slick with blood and gore with each being easily distinguished from each other. This is a seriously pretty game. 
The game runs great and can easily be customized to suit your rig, running well both on my 1080 sli desktop, and my 1070 laptop with some tweaking. 
The Doom Slayer is highly customizable with cosmetics galore and secrets that reveal more and more ways to make the Slayer more your style, and unlockables given through combat. 
The weapons are brutally satisfying to use with each having their own niche in combat, though some are more useful than others. Does anyone actually use the assault rifle scope? Hm... micro missiles, scope... micro missiles, scope... I know what I went with! 
The BFG is a weapon of last resort due to low ammo found through the game, but is satisfying to use as always. 
The game is not as tight and focused as Doom 2016, but this is a very worthy successor to the previous installment and I look forward to see what comes in the DLC coming in October, if you like first person shooters with some mild horror elements and brutal close combat, buy this game and have a metric ton of fun!

Doom is back to it's amazing self, and I love it. I definitely should have updated this review sooner. Basically, all the complaints about instability and such from my old review have been reverted/fixed. Can whole-heartedly recommend now. Now if only we could get some more master levels.




                      **OLD REVIEW**


From near perfection, to buggy mess. 
That's the best description of Doom: Eternal. When the game launched all the way until the May update, Doom: Eternal was a masterpiece. After the update, the game has become horribly unstable, and potentially a security threat for PC users. The game added Denuvo Anti-Cheat, which has kernel level access, meaning that essentially it has the highest level of access to your computer. Not only is it a potential security threat, it has also caused frame drops, near constant crashes, and *potentially A.I. bugs.
Many enemy A.I. act very differently / much less aggressive. For instance, Marauders. However, that one may have been an intentional balance change, which I do not like, as they are very much able to be defeated.
Speaking of balance changes, the toxic water environmental hazard has been made essentially harmless for seemingly no reason. The purple goo that slows the player has been nerfed to be basically non-existent.
Overall, the game has been made unnecessarily easy, even on the hardest difficulties. Or it would be, if it weren't for the horrible instability that the game has now. 
Before the May update, Doom: Eternal would have been one of my favorite games of all time. I played it on launch day and 100% the campaign on Nightmare within the first weekend and loved every minute of it. Now, I wouldn't wouldn't recommend this game at all, and have personally uninstalled it. Even though I have the Deluxe Edition with future DLC content on the way, I won't be playing it again as long as these problems continue to exist.

TL;DR
From one of the best and most optimized FPS games ever to unplayable, buggy mess that has had it's difficulty nerfed to its detriment.

This is a rip-snorting, headlong, in-your-face thrill ride, with so much blood and gore you'll either laugh like a maniac, or lose your lunch. A satisfying sequel and upgrade to the hot mess that was Doom (2016), with considerably better flow, and a mapping system that actually serves its purpose. If you've wearied somewhat of the increasingly realistic format of recent shooters, this high-octane romp will blow away the cramp and cobwebs you've developed from skulking and sniping, as it really rewards you for getting stuck in to the action, up close and personal. Beyond the dizzying violence, this is also a startlingly beautiful game in places - at least in those environments that haven't gone totally to hell (literally), where the fleshy nightmare decor is staggeringly grotesque - either way, the visuals are a splendid achievement, with a phenomenal amount of attention to detail throughout. At whatever level you play, expect to die a LOT, but it shouldn't bother you too much, as it makes the sense of accomplishment when you do finally succeed that much greater. Great fun for anyone with a strong stomach and quick reflexes. Rip and tear!

Doom Eternal is about as good as the first one. If you liked the first one, you probably won't be disappointed unless you're expecting the game to be exactly the same as Doom 2016.

Genre: First Person Shooter
Difficulty: Challenging

Pros:
+ Slaughtering demons is still fun
+ Still challenging without being unfair.
+ Music is still incredible and suits the game perfectly.
+ Demons have exploitable weaknesses.
+ New enemies
+ Returning enemies from the 90s Doom games, such as the Archvile.

Cons:
- ID Software and Bethesda once turned the game into a security risk by adding Denuvo anti-cheat (which is not the same as Denuvo anti-tamper, which generally just affects performance). The security risk is gone, but still, what were they thinking?

Verdict: 9/10, one point deducted for the Anti-Cheat incident. Worth full price.

Doom Eternal is incredible, utilising all combat and mobility mechanics is exciting, a feast for the eyes. Every weapon has purpose. Quick switching and setting hot keys is a must for the best experience of this game. The game is richer in lore than other Doom games. With cutscenes during and at the end of levels, these can skipped for those less interested.

The combat is greatly enhanced, with new mechanics that have cranked mobility up to 11, and allow for a varied way to collect and manage resources. A great change that forces the player to show some level of competence. You have to "earn the power fantasy".
The game is more balanced than Doom 2016. It requires more strategy and thought from the player. The guns are tied to mechanics (weak points, shields, staggering etc.) which lead to plenty of room for experimentation and showmanship.

Some levels are very long, this is a double edged sword. The game is more epic, yet it shows how mentally exhausting it can be at times. 
Platforming can be mildly annoying but is usually simple and can be rewarding if you find a path shorter than intended or have improved at traversal.

Doom Eternal has an arcade style with a neon HUD and inclusion of an extra lives system, there is plenty of audio and visual cues to aid the player. It is a true video game, clearly inspired by classic Doom. The art style differs from Doom (2016), and may take getting used to, but it helps the game look so majestic. The graphics are a big step up. The demons' designs are more inspired and distinguished this time around and great detail was put into their animations (for the glory kills in particular) that help make the demons feel alive, or rather unalive...
The most impressive visual enhancement is the demonic gibbing, seeing the body parts of the demons disintegrate is very satisfying.

 Unfortunately some bugs have been introduced with the first 2 updates (Update 2.1 has fixed most of these), the game may also crash occasionally.
In the campaign, some sequences such as using battery cores can be grating to sit through on replays.
The multiplayer, Battlemode, is quite limited. This was intentional as the game is singleplayer focused. However, with only 1 game mode, there isn't much replayability. 

The lack of an expansive multiplayer mode is far from a problem. With plenty of multiplayer shooters out there, Doom Eternal presents a campaign that easily wins it the title of my new personal favourite shooter of all time.

You will not get a true taste of Doom Eternal in a measly couple of hours or a single playthrough for that matter. The game is best experienced at Nightmare difficulty, its very much worth working your way up towards it, it's challenging but greatly rewarding. The master levels further prove Nightmare difficulty's brilliance with its fast, adrenaline inducing pace.

Cementing itself as one of the strongest entries in FPS, Doom Eternal is a blast to play.
The game is not a casual experience. It is fast paced and wants the player to prove they have what it takes to be in the shoes of the Doom Slayer, to RIP and TEAR!

If you liked Doom 2016, this is a no-brainer! It is excactly what a sequel should be: more and better!

If you haven't, but you like shooters with an emphasis on fluid and challenging gameplay that keep you on the edge of your seat from beginning to end: this is also your game! 

I actually found the lore to be quite interesting and well done. It is a bit cheesy, sure, but interesting enough to give all the mayhem a little context and keep you engaged. Especially in the codex there is quite a lot of lore to read, and it's much more comprehensive than you might think or expect from a game like this. But if you don't care about any of that, it never gets in the way of the action if you don't want it to.

The shooting mechanics are fluid and great, just like in Doom 2016. But there are much more tactics involved than before. Every monster type has it's own weaknesses and strengths. You will need to switch weapons and approaches depending on the enemies mid-battle all the time. If you get the hang of this, it feels amazing to 'dance' through the levels, dealing out damage like an absolute badass! Every weapon has it's uses throughout the entire game. Absolutely amazing game-design.

The only thing I would critique about this game, is that I missed the industrial look and feel of the levels from Doom 2016. Doom Eternal's levels are mostly open areas in (post-apocalyptic) suburban settings. This makes for excellent gun play and opportunities to dance around the stage, but I liked the mood of the science stations and factories in the 2016 game a bit more (the Hell levels in that game were not my favourite). But this is just a minor gripe. 

I enjoyed this game very much and would recommend it to anyone who likes challenging action-oriented shooters!

Rip and tear, until it is done. Enough said. Extremely worthy successor to Doom 2016 and the games that inspired it from the early days of video gaming. Extremely fun combat mechanics, awesome mobility, beautiful levels, beautiful enemies and weapon models. The guns all feel useful and varied, which adds something to the combat. In Doom 2016 I felt I could do the bulk of the game with the shotgun, but with the new mechanics in place here, there are serious benefits to swapping between weapons tactically, especially on the higher difficulty settings (am playing on Ultra Violence and it feels pretty good). 

Performance is outstanding. I have everything on high (textures on ultra nightmare) and am getting very solid 90+ fps at 1440p on a (Ryzen 2600X, GTX 1070 Ti) but closer to 120 fps. I could tweak it for higher fps I'm sure, but the performance is super smooth as I have it right now and it looks great. 

11/10. Highly recommend. Still looking for an Animal Crossing easter egg. Will increase score to 12/10 if I find one. 
Edit: addition of Denuvo has resulted in -12 added to score. New score -2/10.

After the success of Doom 2016 i thought nothing could top it. When Doom Eternal was annouced i thought it would be in par with the previous game, I couldn’t have been more wrong. Doom Eternal isn’t just an amazing game, its a revolutionary one. Literally everything from the gameplay to the story to even the music has been drastically improved which i didnt even think that was possible. You have your typical Doom loadout including shotguns, plasma rifles, and the BFG. Their are a couple of new additions to the arsenal like the ballista, the crucible, and the unmayker. The only problem is that since the ammo for the crucible is only in the last three levels, the weapon is kinda useless when replaying the earlier levels. The story is awesome with stunning places and badass demons and dialogue. One of the things that i love is the popular fan theory that the Doom Slayer is the original Doom Guy from the 1993 game was confirmed in a very deep and intense cutscene. Lastly, the customization for the Slayer and the various demons you play in tehultiplayer mode are very funny and creative my personal favorite being the classic Doom Guy Skin. This game has me very excited for the future of not just Doom but fps games in general. I strongly urge everyone to give this game a try.

My god DOOM Eternal is f*cking good, here's why...

Oh and if someone complains about "WAAAAHHH THEY ARE ADDING FORTNITE-LIKE SKINS" or "DOOM SHOULDN'T HAVE A STORY, ITS ABOUT THE RIP AND TEAR WAAAAAAH!" then I will delete them because they are actually not criticism, instead of it's just people complaining and haven't actually played all the way to the end. Anyways, now that's out of the way. Read on.




Music- Do I even need to comment about it? I dig alot of them (IE Meathook, The Only Thing That They Fear is You, ect)

Story- It's a nice little story about Earth being invaded by demons and DOOM guy is just there to stop it. Nothing that bad, but hey it's a nice way to have a break for some of the action.

Voice Acting- It's fine. That's all.

Level Design- Pretty good, although I had to search for guides multiple times because my dumb brain can't figure out shit. And simple puzzles are also a nice change of pace. (Though you can speedrun some of them)

Enemies- Very fun to fight, except the Marauder. Should've been a miniboss in that one level. That's it.

Secrets- Very fun to collect and actually give you some boosts. 

Weapons- Beautiful, sad that they got rid of the pistol. (Though you can somehow bring the pistol back into the game and I also like how the pistol looks)

Characters- Not bad, I wish some of them could've been written better. But hey, I don't really care.

Bonus stuff- The Hub is also a nice change, and has it's own training area. The Finale Boss was ok. Multiplayer was a bit eh. 

Total Rating 7/10

FPS were never my favorite kind of videogame even though I've been gaming on consoles for the last 15 years. Doom 2016 made me change my mind about first person shooters and well, Doom Eternal is just better. I initially bought Eternal on my One X and was impressed with the gameplay and soundtrack, but always wanted to experience the game in more frames per second, so I made my very first gamer PC with the aim of playing this game in 100+ FPS. 

If I liked this game on the Xbox, playing it with mouse and keyboard (I'm still getting used to it but I like how it plays), playing it with an IPS monitor at 1440p 144 Hz and G-sync is a completely new experience that is definitely worth what I've invested. Looking forward to the new DLC! Hope is just as great as the main game has been.

review:
They took everything from the first one and made it better.

One thing I would note is that in DOOM 2016 I played with a controller because the game recommended that I did. This time, I tried to use a controller and then switch to M&K and had a much better time on M&K. When I was on controller in 2016, I was also playing on Hurt Me Plenty but I decided to go with Ultraviolent this time so it may just be that you only need M&K on harder difficulties.

I'm playing on an 8700 and a 2080 and I was able to play with ultra settings with high frames (not sure what the number is exactly). GeForce Experience seems like it doesnt have every single graphics setting cataloged so make sure you go into the game settings and disable motion blur yourself because GeForce did not disable it for me.

I'm running the game off of a Samsung 970 EVO M.2 and load times are consistently less than 5 seconds when I die in the game. This is in contrast to the 20+ seconds I was getting on PS4 in DOOM 2016 and about 10 seconds on a Samsung 860 EVO SSD also on DOOM 2016.

Pros:
Epic gameplay.
The best music in a game
Very relaxing. Just sitting back and watching my villagers interact with one another is beautiful in a way.
Graphics look beautiful. Very colorful and vibrant
Cartoony, which I... oh we talking about DOOM Eternal? Oh. 

Epic gameplay
-The best music in a game [but better] 
-Very relaxing. Just sitting back and watching billions of demons being slaughtered with my ---bare hands is beautiful in a way.
-Graphics are almost like it's real [Minus the "goofy" demons.]
A tad cartoony, which i like.
-The developers like listening to the fans. I like that. By the way, dont cancel your purchase of this game when you see the Denuvo reviews. It got removed a while back, so no malware.
-Calls back to the older games [DOOM 1, 2, etc.]
-Good multiplayer [even though a bit repetitive after a little bit]
-A challenge, but not so challenging that you smash your monitor into your pc and shove your keyboard in your skull. Plus, I'm Too Young to Die
-Requires raw skill. You have to stuff that crap up your eye sockets and nose just to get a shiny yellow Slayer. It's worth it, though
-FINALLY. A GAME WHERE BATTLE PASSES ARE FREE!
-Literally the only buyable things are extra campaign things. The Rip and Tear pack [Which you get for 5 bucks, not just a preorder bonus] costs 5 bucks and doesn't go away, AND has DOOT! Revenant so that doesn't count.
-They updated DOOM 1/2 so we can have the classic doom rewards on Steam.
So I updated it.
Here is what I originally said about it. Laugh at my absolute idiocracy.
"The Classic DOOM rewards. Golly. Darn. I would say a cuss word here but i'm a good boi. So I wont. Instead, An introverted slacker will complain about how he needs to spend 15 extra dollars to get some pixels recolored and a new title.
Actually no. I won't. As I said, I'm a good boi. Just please make it so I don't need to buy the Bethesda versions of these games. This one game already ate up 65 dollars. I don't want to spend another 30 bucks on this game"

Cons:
-Bethesda requires your info. A LOT OF INFO. But I've sold my soul to the internet, so not a problem for me. And it was worth it.
-Story.. well... uh... there is some... i guess???? But it's really boring to sit through and read the 50+ codex entries there are.
-Bad matchmaking for the multiplayer. I was teamed up with a level 7 and against a 198. That isn't fair matchmaking. Help.
-The battlepasses are a real grind. There should be like 12 challenges. Maybe 16.  Because I just want a shiny slayer with green stuff around him. Please. Give me this.
-The Deluxe Edition should have 60 bucks taken from it when you have the base game. I don't want to spend 90 bucks solely to make my weapons sound different. Or at least give us another Rip and Tear pack which includes that slayer and weapon sound pack. Lets make that 10 bucks. 90-60=30. 30-20 [which is the Year One Pass] = 10. 10 bucks.
-Broken Slayers Club system. I cant do fan art. I have to grind by READING. Maybe just give me things for stuff I do in-game? That would make leveling ACTUALLY useful. 
All in all, a stellar game. 10/10 would recomend.
But really. Make the Deluxe Edition cost 30 bucks if we already have the base game. 10 if we already have the base game and year one pass. Please, id. Please do this.

Doom Eternal is a totally excellent game, and I'm very glad to be able to change my review to a positive one since the Denuvo Anti-Cheat was removed from the game. Suffice it to say that if you enjoy FPS games, this is a fantastic one. Slick as hell with the gory fun of smashing your way through hundreds of demons. Great!

The game looks absolutely amazing with tons of detail, great design all around, and a fun system where demons fall apart as they take damage. It's also optimized very well, such that even if your hardware is not the best, you could still probably play it. Sound is also great, with a sick djent metal soundtrack by Mick Gordon, and some very satisfying sound effects of guns and demons alike. Voice acting was also done well. 

I must say, I was not initially sold on the changes to combat they made from Doom 2016. There is a lot more strategy involved with how you approach fights, and in the first few levels I felt quite weak. As the game goes on though, you power up and increase your skill as well, so pretty soon I was mashing my way through crazy hectic fights without too much trouble (I only played on Hurt Me Plenty, I'm sure Nightmare is very intense). Once the muscle memory of chainsaw, flame belch and grenades all got worked in to the run-and-gun formula, the game really kicks up to another level. Extremely satisfying to play and designed to push you without breaking you down too badly. Marauders are a divisive enemy, since they can only be handled in very specific ways, but I found that they mixed things up in a fun way and they weren't too infuriating. Whether you like the combat in Eternal or 2016 better is a matter of personal preference, but I think the changes made here really do a service to this title.

I tried the multiplayer a bit and it's fine, not really my cup of tea. Matches are very quick and can feel one-sided depending on who you go up against. It was fun to try for an hour or so after finishing the game and getting the collectibles, but I won't spend more time on it.

Doom Eternal is definitely one of the most impressive games I've played. It took me some time to warm up to it, but once it clicks, nothing else is like it. Remember if you're having trouble that you can always go back to earlier missions to get those upgrades you missed or farm for extra lives (you'll need them, you die a lot) without losing your progress in the campaign. After I finished the main game, which took me about 16 hours, I went back through the levels and cleaned up the rest of the collectibles and slayer gates, which was a fun diversion and made me appreciate the game all the more. The best part of going back to earlier levels is you can use cheats (not for slayer gates though) which were very fun. Try running around at super speed blasting everything with an unlimited-ammo BFG. Very cathartic. Overall, this is an excellent sequel. Doom fans, rejoice!

DOOM Eternal is one of my favourite games of all time. The level design is amazing, the difficulty is perfect, the gameplay loop is satisfying, and the flow of combat is unmatched with no other game (in my opinion). The sound design is great and the graphics are fantastic. While the story isn't exactly the best, the gameplay blows it out of the water. DOOM Eternal takes DOOM (2016)'s ideas and makes them so much better. If you are a fan of classic arena shooters, you should play this. If you are a fan of modern cover shooters you should play this. Although I do recommend playing DOOM (2016) first. The multiplayer is lacking, however, but that's not the main focus of this game. I can't wait for the DLC.

Update:
The developer has asked for an updated review based on fixes, i.e. the removal of Denuvo.  Here's my updated review.  First, fixing issues later after a product's release doesn't wipe away the damage that was done by having a game out there in a broken state.  I trudged through and finished the campaign with the issues in place because that was when I had time to play.  You only get one chance to experience a game for the first time, and Bethesda ruined that experience.  I see no reason to let them off the hook for that because they cleaned up later.

If we're talking about the campaign itself and imagining what it would have been like to play it without problems, then there's a great experience to be had there.  It's not a particularly long campaign, but it's a satisfying journey, assuming that you're getting the chance I didn't to play through it in its present, non-broken state.  My biggest frustrations at this point have to do with the lack of things to do beyond the campaign.  

Multiplayer:  Battlemode, simply put, is a great big mess.  An asymmetrical game experience with unnecessarily complicated mechanics lifted from MOBAs where you're dropping bizarre AOE zones and running around in circles is absolutely the last thing I would have ever expected, or wanted, from a Doom game.  Gone is 2016's satisfying multiplayer deathmatch mode into which I've poured hours with friends, mastering challenges, unlocking customization options, and reveling in a classic multiplayer experience.  Battlemode is an ill-advised, crass experiment that does absolutely nothing to up the ante of the 2016 multiplayer experience, let alone replace or even mimic it.  Frustratingly, much of the game's unlockable and ongoing content seem to be tied into this mode which, for me, is absolutely useless.  I could have (and did) tell Bethesda leading up to this release that I would have no interest in a mode like this.  I was far from the only fan to say so.  Yet here it is.

Also gone are 2016's replayability-boosting Snapmaps.  While I appreciate the game's clear desire to embrace bespoke content, the campaign offers limited replayability.  The "cheat" cards that you unlock seem to be designed to incentivize replays, but the novelty quickly wears off.  Snapmap created the possibility of co-op experiences with your friends, something this game also entirely lacks.  Yes, there were a lot of trash snapmaps, but yes, it was also a great deal of fun to experiment and find the hidden gems.  It was like the old days of downloading Quake 3 maps to mess around with.

If you think it's unfair of me to compare Eternal to 2016, then I'd ask when it's ever been looked on favorably for a highly-anticipated sequel to deliver far less content and far less replayability than its predecessor.  This game absolutely underdelivered in that regard, and so as much as its campaign is worthy of praise, the game itself is by no means a worthy successor.  Neither is it worthy of a Triple-A price.  Wait til you can get it for half price, slam through the campaign, then call it good.

If Bethesda would like to see a *favorable* re-review of this game, then they should consider taking great strides (especially with upcoming DLC) to reintroduce classic multiplayer, cooperative elements, and replayability.

Original review: "Taking a screenshot locks the game, if you can get it to launch at all, that is.  It's about a 50-50 proposition.  Oh, and I didn't have any of these problems a week ago.  What gives? 

Fix your mess.  I paid a triple-A price for this to have it work like broken early access garbage.

It's only made all the worse by the fact that the game is ridiculously fun.  It's like you've baked a fresh hot pizza and served it in a box made out of used bandages."

Masterpiece. One of the best FPS I ever played.

Play Doom 2016 first, then this. Doom 2016 is like driving a well made luxury car with perfect suspension and power steering. Doom Eternal is like hopping into an Indy 500 car flooring the gas while being chased by a cruise missile. 

It's very fast, but also very nuanced. You have more variety in enemies which can make some encounters pretty tough when they team up. Ammo is more sparse and the chainsaw is less of a super weapon now and more part of your bread and butter rotation. Shoot guns, chainsaw fodder, repeat. Run out of health and you have to glory kill or use your super op blood punch with the health back perk. Use your shoulder mounted flamethrower to get armor. Use freeze grenades to get health, lock down real tough enemies, and just do more damage. Use grenades to stagger and deal with trash. It all fits together in an extremely high paced puzzle.

Movement is still important as it was in 2016. Dash, double jump, monkey bars, super shotgun grappling hook off enemies, jump pads, and teleporters all help you out in avoiding slipping into a blender of hell knights and cacodemons. Weapon swapping is also still important, and now for once they found out how to make sniping an important part of the gameplay rather than a useless gimmick. Enemies have weakpoints you want to hit to severely nerf their firepower and avoid getting zoned into a corner, and some enemies are weaker to certain weapons like the ballista which does extra damage on flying enemies and is very useful on pain elementals. 

Enemies range from the laughable such as gargoyles and imps, to the ones that are dangerous in group settings like the carcass, to the ones that will destroy your ass 1v1 if you don't know what you're doing like the marauder and the archeville. They all fill their separate niche and become extremely threatening when working together, which can make encounters become unique puzzles that challenge your reactions and decision making skills. 

Things I don't like? Multiplayer sucks. I get what they tried to do, but it just doesn't work. One person is the very strong slayer, and two other players are demons with their own unique skills. I played it for about an hour before never touching it again. I'm glad they didn't do something incredibly dumb like try to make a BR, but this really isn't a solution to the issue of how to revive classic fps multiplayer. A CTF mode would have been much more preferable. 

Second thing I don't care for, although it isn't a bad idea, is the daily xp system. They add skins and new content that you can unlock by doing weekly and daily challenges like glory kill this many imps or whatever. It's not terrible, but there's also little incentive to do it. They are limited time only, but unless you really care about getting a new rocket launcher skin you probably won't bother. 

All in all, great game. Very hard, but fun and the best cardio you're going to get playing a video game.

After playing for over 120hrs I've realized this game really isn't great at all.  At first it feels a bit weird and different than what you would expect, then it starts to suck you in and feel like it's fun, but by the end of it all you realize that frustration is what this game brings and not fun.  If you don't play the way the devs want you to, you lose.  There is no freedom or creativity in how you traverse the battlefield.  When I got to the final boss on nightmare I literally quit and didn't even want to do it because I didn't feel like I would actually be accomplishing anything.  This is even more apparent after doing a full nightmare play through of Doom 2016.  When you return to Eternal from there you realize that all the fun you were having is gone, and it quickly turns into a why bother.  

And to sum up exactly why it isn't fun...

In Doom 2016 it is all about movement, shooting, glory kills, and exploration.  That is it.  And you can go about it however you want too.

Doom Eternal is all about movement, precision, and resource management.  Shooting is there, but it doesn't work without the precision and resource management.  Glory kills are there, but they are harder to do and more situational because it is tied to resource management.  And exploration is kind of there, but the map basically tells you where everything is including the fights so it really isn't there.

And git good is just a stupid thing to say.  I'm fully capable of doing it the devs way on nightmare.....it simply isn't fun and not worth my time.

This is the ULTIMATE DOOM.

Doom Eternal is everything I missed and wanted in shooters.

Like in the previous and way previous installments, you are slammed into action with your shotgun and told to 'go nuts'.

The levels are jam-packed with secrets and interesting vistas, which makes exploration a lot more fun than in 2016. I hear a lot of whining about 'platforming', but the puzzles that actually involve small platforms and jumping occur perhaps a handful of times in the game; they're not even that difficult unless you have two ham hocks for appendages and the reaction time of a retractable bridge on a large river. The way I see it, each was put in to replace a sterile corridor.

If you're afraid of not finding everything on your first try: No sweat. You have an option in your FORTRESS OF DOOM that allows you to replay any mission. The lower difficulties are made just for that, to get you to master the game at any speed you want. Hell, if you don't feel like too much of a challenge, you can pop in a cheat code, which you find here and there in the game as secrets, and enjoy the game with instant death ammo, endless ammo, endless lives or confetti spewing out of your enemies while the nerds in Quakecon cheer you on.

If you do feel like a challenge, there's plenty of ways to increase how hard the demons whoop your ass if you slip even once. It's not even about turning them into bullet sponges, it's about increasing the damage your enemies deal, how they react to you, how many of the real nasty ones the game throws at you etc.

That out of the way, there are some things that could've been done without.

The extra life system isn't bad and an interesting addition, but I wish I had the option to reload a save rather than waste another life, just because I was backed into a corner by 5 Mancubi while every Gargoyle spat their green goo in my face.

The gunplay is very different than in any shooter that has ever existed, but it does seem more like a gimmick than an actual system. At first, I ran into the foible of relying on a single weapon, switching to a backup when I ran out of ammo, while using specific weapons only to target the weak points of certain enemies. The game doesn't want you to play like that and will punish you for it. 

Once I started quick-switching between one and another weapon to take down demons, each one of them died remarkably faster and I ran out of ammo less. The thing is: There was no strategy in this. Everything just disappears faster, when I spam between shotgun, arbalest and rocket launcher like some demon-slaying juggler, all the while mixing it up with grenades, frost grenades, the shoulder-mounted flame belcher and chain-sawing enemies once I've ran out of ammo. 

Perhaps I am just more towards a methodical shooter, but I can't be the only one that sees the gameplay of Doom Eternal turns into a chaotic mess on higher levels.

The online multiplayer is a really cool and innovative idea but it kind of sucks playing it with strangers. If you want to give it a go I recommend getting the lads together and playing that way. Those are just nitpicky minor problems though, DOOM Eternal is a strong contender for my favourite game of all time.
