I was that guy who thought Doom 2016 was fun but way overrated.  A step in the right direction but had a long way to go to really bring it home.

In the first few hours of Doom Eternal almost everything I disliked about 2016 appears to be fixed.  Instead of taking hours to get going this game throws you right into chaos out the gate (literally a slipgate).  

Less talk more action, the combat flows faster, the levels design is more three dimensional (but still not nearly enough tbh), and the music sounds more complete with a gritty industrial rock sound instead of just loud reverberating bass farts.  I like the platforming and the added vertically, and I will never for the life of me understand how looking up and down stumps so many modern fps players.  Eternal does have a story with cutscenes, but you can skip them all unlike the forced dialogue scenes in 2016.  I still think glory kills are kind of gimmicky and overused but I'll live and let live with that one since most people like it.

review: FUN!!!

This game offered what has to be the most fun-per-dollar with no grind that I have had in years.
DOOM 2016 was good, but it felt lacking something. It seems that in DOOM Eternal, they found it. 
It was a very enjoyable experience balanced between kill kill kill and the occasional exploration and little puzzles here n there. The combat is fast, fun, and challenging. My favorite part was seeing and feeling myself adapt and get better at dealing with the harder demons and fights. Very rewarding. 
The story was packed with content. Attention to detail, everything felt explained in full to me. The longer the Icon of Sin is on earth, the stronger it will become. and the codex entries are a fun read. 
Havent tried multiplayer yet.
One of my demon characters has a tiger skin and thats amazing.
Very much looking forward to the DLC coming soon

100% get this game and play it if you enjoy shooters

This would off been one of the best single player shooters ever. Definitely has the best combat system I know of. I'm more a sniper guy but then again you're rewarded if you can quick scope actually.

One thing that's pissing me off though is the ledge grabbing and path seeking inbetween fights. It's really getting out of hand in this title. A game that steals my team with stuff that I didnt sign up for wont get a recommanded. That's that.

Though I understand that if you're a single player gamer only, this game basically has no other fps coming close in terms of action and complexity of combat. 

Now normally I would be forgiving if this game had replay value but unfortunately no, if you wanna go back in the campaign you have to play the level in one go. For me someone that only plays a game for 10-20 minutes in little breaks of long programming sections this is impossible so I cant replay the game. 

I would say I dont regret buying it but if you dont mind watching guides how and when to jump/ dash or where to find certain items and you want a good action arena shooter then get this game on discount.

EDIT: 8/31/2020
God. So. Yeah. It's a Doom Game. We get it. But it's unforgiving. It's rough. 
It's not like it's a bad game! Really, it's not. It's just not...fun. It's not fun. There. I said it. The game's not fun. It makes me use cheese strats 24/7 and, yknow, I'm not bad at that, but if I have to cheese constantly, it's just kinda...tiring? Boring. 

Anyways, the meat and bones of this is a doom game, sure, but it's just so goddamn boring that it's a chore to stream it. 

It's one of those games that you just sorta. Turn your brain off for. And it's mindless and repetitive and it's done almost nothing to really improve on DOOM 2016's formula. While that's not necessarily a bad thing in and of itself because of how DOOM 2016 was hailed as being pretty damn good, it's also just sorta...stale. 

The game's stale, and I wouldn't buy it for full price, if I were you.

If there ever were a game that would make the astounding 2016 reboot obsolete, it would have to be the sequel - and hoo boy, does it deliver!

introducing several new mechanics that became second nature nearly instantly - and polishing old ones to near perfection - Doom Eternal is pretty much in a league of it's own right now, with no other game I can think of coming close to producing a comparable dopamine rush when playing.

It does fall short of absolute perfection - the multiplayer 'Battle Mode' doesn't appeal to me a whole lot (which is a polite way of saying 'not at all'), and there's no additional content to play once you've finished the campaign - at least until any DLC lands.

Those two criticisms aside, this is absolutely amazing stuff which you should be playing right this instant.

DOOM Eternal

- This game is like being on crack and having super powers to rip and rear through demons. The insane speed of the gameplay and pure brutality is something to behold. Without question one of the goriest and bloody games made to date. It brings back memories of the first time seeing the chainsaw glory kills in Gears of War. 
	- The game is no joke hard at times, you'll probably be playing through this on the lowest difficulty if you aren't used to really fast paced FPS games. I wouldn’t recommend playing this with a controller, its not like a causal walk through a COD campaign.  Not knocking them, just understand this game packs a challenge.
	- Graphically beautiful with plenty of customizable filters and effects, so you can make Doom have the tone you want. 
	- Very well optimized, you can easily get this game looking good and have high FPS over 60. Just don’t believe you have to have everything on Ultra. Mess around and see what you noticed. With everything maxed, it does have some FPS dips, especially at 4K. 
	- Plenty to do, the games campaign length feels perfect. You'll spend roughly 30 hours or more getting through it. Then you'll want to play through again to see what you missed. Rare that a game makes me want to repeat it.
Highly recommended if you want a good single play FPS campaign to dig your teeth into. Haven't tried multiplayer as of yet.

Everything I loved about Doom 2016 is gone.

I loved Doom 2016. I loved it more than I could have ever thought possible. When I finished it I was hungry, starving for more. I enthusiastically picked up Doom Eternal, echoes of the rave reviews ringing in my ear, eager to get my fix. Yet halfway through the third level my frustration and disappointment are immeasurable.

It would take an essay to explain in depth how much is wrong with this game, and I don't feel like writing that much, so I'm going to bullet point my grievances.
-The combat shotgun sucks now.
-Ammo for everything seems to deplete far quicker than before, and far quicker than is acceptable for the challenges now posed.
-There is never enough ammo, and no the chainsaw doesn't make up for it because.
-The chainsaw never seems to have enough fuel, and there's no proper indication of how much fuel you have and how much fuel you need.
-The basic punch does no damage. THE BASIC PUNCH DOES ZERO DAMAGE.
-The dash sucks, and gets far too much focus in the now numerous and overbearing parkour puzzles.
Rune challenges are gone, and I loved those.
-Explanations for upgrading things is done exclusively through neon tutorial boxes rather than Vega talking you through it, making the entire thing feel more sterile and lifeless. Yeah, maybe it didn't make much sense that the computer could upgrade your weapons more by tracking you being a badass in each level, but at least it made you feel connected to the game more than this.
-Every arena has more enemies, they move faster, they attack WAY more, and they're all harder to kill. A challenge is one thing, but when I have 5 enemies literally crawling up my butt (literally they attack from behind at ALARMING rates) and gibbing me before I can even realize they're there it's no longer a challenge, it's plain unfair, and I played on normal difficulty because I'm not a masochist and just wanted to have fun.
-The flame thrower that gives armor was a nice idea in theory, it's terrible in execution.
-Extra lives are the worst idea they could possibly have had when making this game. It's supposed to make you feel clever and rewarded for getting an advantage by exploring. But the game is designed to make it required to progress at a reasonable rate. Which then in practice just makes you feel like a loser for dying and having to be rescued by your extra lives. It would have been better to just balance the combat around NOT DYING.

I can think of only 2 things that I think are improved in this game from the last: the map feels better, and codex items are easier to spot. That's it. Everything else feels worse. I regret buying this game. And I regret the time of my life wasted playing it for the few hours I did.

This is one of the few times I wish I had a middle option for recommendation. I’m not a huge fan myself, but I don’t think it’s a bad game.

If you liked Doom 2016, you may or may not like Doom Eternal. It’s a different type of game built out of the same bits. Much more chaotic and much less focused. It’s Doom 2016 cranked up to 11, and not in a good way. 

They added a bunch of new mechanics but none of them do anything interesting.  Now you can press a button to get armor just like the way you can press a button to get health. You can punch things when your punch things meter is full. Certain enemies have weaknesses where you shoot a particular weapon at them or shoot them in a particular place, but exploiting those weaknesses ends up feeling like a chore. It all just ends up feeling pretty hollow.

The bad story in the first game was easy to ignore. The bad story in this game is so bad that I can’t help but be irritated any time anyone is talking. 

It’s still pretty fun sometimes, but it’s one of those games I sit down to play and an hour later I realize I’ve just been zoned out and bored for most of that time.

That’s just me though. I can see the appeal for people who aren’t me. It’s fast paced and challenging, and the act of shooting things is as much fun as ever. The guns are still great. It’s just too messy for my tastes.

Everything great from Doom 2016 seems to be gone.

I'm not sure why they wanted to turn Doom into a lame 3D platform arcade game with a thin veneer of Doom on top of it, but that's what it is.  Platforming in FPS game has always been terrible, so to make it such a crucial part of the gameplay is obnoxious.

The extremely limited ammo pool detracts from the experience as well, requiring the player to spam the chainsaw against lesser enemies.  Even then, bigger enemies will soak up what you have then one-hit you with their overpowered attacks.

I regret buying this.  I love Doom, but this isn't Doom.

I played DOOM 2016. I had fun.
Then I played DOOM Eternal. I did not have fun.
In fact, while a friend of mine walked me through the first few levels, he warned me that the first three levels sucked and were frustrating. I agree.

2016 made me feel like a badass with a tons of weapons designed to kick more ass than Duke Nukem.
Eternal makes me feel like a frightened rabbit running for his life from a pack of hungry wolves. It also makes me feel like I do not stand a chance unless I remember a crapton of key bindings and keep flailing on my keyboard like a madman. I keep having to lift some of my left hand from the movement keys just to switch weapons efficiently, use the flamethrower, switch attachments, you name it.

I tried playing on normal mode. Then I started dying a lot. So I switched to easy mode. I still died a lot. The descriptions of all difficulty modes essentially say "You will die a lot". What, so on DOOM 2016 I had fun on easy mode while still feeling challenged, even completed my game to 100% unlocks, but on Eternal every difficulty must make me feel like I'm not welcome to even try enjoying the game? Gee thanks.

Speaking of dying, one of the MANY resources you collect in the game is extra lives. EXTRA. LIVES. What kind of DOOM game expects you to fail and die and just... enables it??? Like this just felt like an overcomplicated overhealing system with the addition that since using an extra life still means you died, you get to keep playing [i]with the mark of shame that you couldn't handle the battle you're in[/i]. Yeah I really wanted a game to make me feel like I'm too stupid for it then pat my head and be like "It's okay, you suck but since you searched for this arbitrary trinket I'll allow you to suck".

One more thing. On 2016, the most basic enemy on easy mode would have a hard time damaging you in any meaningful way. On Eternal, even the most basic easy-mode schmoe is a threat to your continued existence. Yeah remember when the lore said the Praetor suit was super strong? I think this might've gone lost in translation.

In case you haven't noticed, I don't recommend this game at all. If you wanted something that makes you feel like a badass tearing through armies from hell, play DOOM 2016. If you want to be rewarded for pressing a ton of different buttons, play World Of Warcraft. If you want your computer to fart in your face, play DOOM Eternal.

Now if you excuse me, I'm gonna cleanse my soul on some other game and shelve this one under "too lazy to finish it". Yes this is an actual category in my library.

A disappointing follow up to DOOM (2016). That game got the balance of difficulty, pace, combat flow and atmosphere perfect. Everything about Eternal feels silly and cartoonish by comparison. 

DOOM (2016) encouraged intelligent movement and calculated aggression. Eternal, by contrast, is so frantic and ammo so absurdly scarce that the player is forced into a repetitive pattern of cycling cooldowns while kiting in a circle. Pinging around an arena with underpowered weapons and a useless melee makes you feel less like a badass and more like a mosquito.

The Mario-style jump puzzles and environmental hazards feel out of place. They are dull and unnecessary padding between encounters. 

I really wanted to like this game, but the frustrating combat, annoying platforming and ludicrous lore have made it a real disappointment for me.
its cool

I will start by saying the design of the combat is great. There are some additions and tweaks that may take a moment to adjust to, but rest assured that once you have the combat is still solid. While I would recommend this game, I am primarily writing this to address some of the issues I encountered as a warning to potential buyers. Specifically, the buggy state the game seems to be in. 

My most recent play session consisted of:
-Some walls spawn only to limit combat zones. From a design point this is fine, but I had to reload my checkpoint (and at times replay combat) as these walls did not disappear after winning, completely halting progression. 
-This game puts a higher focus on platforming than Doom 2016. Personally, I found this to be more tedious than fun. Often times the collision detection seemed off. Using a dash into a climbable wall would typically snap me to the wall, but this was inconsistent (perhaps the angles are more particular than I realized) and I was met with a bottomless pit or pool of acid. 
-After acquiring a new weapon I promptly fell through the floor to an area I had already cleared, but the enemies had returned and I had to fight my way out again. At first I believed this to be intentional, until I returned to the checkpoint on a future death and the ground I had previously fallen though was now solid. 

Any of these on their own would classify as minor issues, but given their frequency the overall experience felt more irritating than enjoyable. 

If you are interested in purchasing this, please do so with the knowledge that the experience may be marred by numerous bugs.

There were no errors when launching, even the game screen was not there. What is the problem? God Himself does not know this.

The game is good, but I will not forget the problem described above. I am no longer going to pre-order the game from Bethesda.

When I was buying this hunk of game I was sure what I was about to get. Well I got more than that. A worthy 2016 DOOM's sequel is old-school adrenaline packed shooter, where sprint nor reloading isn't allowed. I was surprised how many things improved and was enhanced from its predicestor. Movement is much more faster and smoother, glory kill are more brutal and Slayer is much more angrier. Arenas are beautiful and platforming fits for the arcadish style of play. Wide range of weapons with its unique mods and combinations fuels the heat of the combat and you will be wondering how you will kill that last demon in the most satisfying way. Additionally there are collectibles such as toys, cheat codes and music discs you can listen to so you won't get bored on the battlefield. I wasn't honestly bothered with new types of enemies nor constantly chainsawing smaller enemies for ammo. Only down fall for me was lack of power ups, which in 2016 DOOM was more than plenty. 

Oh and Mick Gordon shouldn't be left mentioned for making so much heavy and dark riffs. What he made is peak of music soundtracks.

Then the enemy made me reflect more on the gameplay of the game, realizing that parkour, and climbing does not belong in a Doom game, slowing down the stages as you have to solve some jumping puzzles. So DOOM (2016) brought a resurrection/revitalization to this IP, for me that was DOOM as it should be in this day and age. So I was excited for the continuation and expanding universe that is DOOM. DOOM Eternal drops I snag it fast, install, play.

I really wanted to like this game but I just don't. Doom 2016 is one of my favourite games and I was hoping for just more of that. The combat is still pretty good and I'm glad id took a shot at an interesting new type of multiplayer, even if it's not for me. I'll probably still play this game to 100% completion but it feels like a chore. I cringe every time someone in game calls you the "doom guy" or I see a hipster archvile skin in multiplayer. Your character is supposed to be a mysterious force of nature but you see his face, you see his gamer room, and by the end the mystery is gone.

Doom has always been a goofy franchise but this feels like Doom fan fic written in brightly coloured crayon.

Below is my original review, done about halfway through the game.
I'll summarize:
The game is absolutely awesome minus three things, two of which aren't that big of a deal.

The insane amount of pointless lore, and the HUD are weak points.  The 2016 version had a much easier to read HUD - could more readily tell when stuff was ready to use better.  The lore is overkill and doesn't matter much to a Doom game - the game is of course just kill everything you see.

The platforming and climbing adds to the game nicely.  However, the extreme platforming is still horrible.  I'm only really talking about the very few (~15 or so in the game) where you die over and over again doing a jump.  Jump-Dash-Jump-Dash or Jump-Jump-Dash-Dash or whatever.  If they brought those 100% difficulty jumps down to 90% I would be very happy.  After 60 hours of playing and I still die over and over again on jumps is just stupid.

Visuals and world building are awesome.  Combat is awesome.  

9/10 maybe an 8/10 after I quit the game when I die 15 times in a row after some pointless stupid jump.

Just finished last night and will play again tonight.

Original, mid-point review:
This game is stupid and is not a true Doom game.  It is a jumping and puzzle game with some 
shooting added.  You will spend 80% of your time jumping and dying and trying again and again.  

They wasted hour upon hour of making up pointless lore and story telling with made up words that mean nothing to the Doom game play or the franchise.  Doomguy just kills whatever is placed in front of him.  That time should have been spent on explaining portions of the game and what they mean and how they work, e.g., Cheat codes, Challenges, XP, whatever those extra mini-missions are within each level, the things on the HUD (The HUD is awful BTW - the Doom 2016 style is far better to gauge how much fuel you have for the chainsaw - the graphic in Eternal I still don't understand).  

This is a reversion to some other style of game like Doom 2003 was - not genuine.  Graphics are good of course, and the SFX and music are awesome.  The 20% of the game that is fighting is really fun, but too difficult.  Constantly running out of ammo, and also running out of fuel as well.  Again, not Doom.  Even on easiest level you will get wiped out over and over again, and I was successful playing on Ultra-Violence on 2016.  The Doomslayer's main base is stupid as well - excessively large for no reason than to place unused artwork.  

The game is not fun - it is all frustration and confusion as to how to play.  Have turned it off 3 times already trying to make some stupid circus jumps and dying 20 times in a row.

It's ok, but due to the overwhelming positive reviews, I'll give the other side.
It's nowhere near as good as Doom 2016. It's far more arcade feeling and a little sillier. I feel that Doom 2016 balanced ridiculous over the top action with a grounded feeling a bit better.

Ammo changes are weird, but I get that they wanted to try something new, but it doesn't really work in my opinion. Yes you can chainsaw to reload, but it kind of gets repetitive and takes the fun out of chainsawing. It also means there has to be trash enemies in every fight, which gets irritating.

Runs extremely well, optimised brilliantly. Has its fun moments but the combat is very cluttered and feels like just cycling between cooldowns. You spend too much time in the base which I'm not interested in a doom game.

The story is convoluted and told through cutscenes which is a definite step back compared to Doom 2016.

Overall: Wait for a sale.

I looked it up and none of the solutions I found worked.

The combat/gameplay loop of Doom: Eternal will keep you on the edge of your seat on any difficulty, but is best experienced as high as you can crank it. I keep coming back because no other title currently gives me this rush.

The soundtrack is phenomenal and I wish they would release high-fidelity versions of it to the public.

Graphically, there have not been many improvements since 2016, which already felt old, even on max settings. Many textures are too low-res when viewed up close. If you are constantly moving this is not that big of a deal, but if you stop to admire the artwork it falls apart.

Now there are many reviews about this game out there. This one is gonna be specifically geared to people playing on low spec computers. I used to play this game in all its glory +60 FPS and high settings on a 1050 ti. Honestly there is not much difference between low and high settings, but then my gpu died and I had to revert back to my old 750 ti that I had on hand and this game became slightly miserable to play. Luckily due to cheat engine and some help from the community I had access to an unlocked console that allowed me to tweak this game to become playable at 720p (Single Player Only Check out low spec gamer on YouTube for optimizations). The tweaks allowed me to lower the settings beyond what the game allowed me to and I was once again able to play this game at 60+ FPS on a 750 Ti without drops and stuttering! Which is really amazing! Even with those tweaked settings the game looked kinda good. Amazing optimization they've done with this game. Highly recommend it and the new DLC looks extremely promising. DOOM Eternal is an incredible game that has made very many improvements over 2016. A lot of common complaints are that it limits creativity through lack of ammo, and that there is too much platforming. First of all, the lack of ammo forces you to be more creative by making the player utilize weapon switching more. In doom 2016, combat encounters were mostly just "Move around in a circle with the super shotgun until the demons are dead." I still loved that game though. But in Eternal the player is encouraged to use more strategy. Not to mention the chainsaw actually refills in this game, making combat even smoother. And the platforming is very simple. Some people say that they are "puzzles," when in reality an 8 year old could do the platforming sections. The parkour is very short too, and adds some breathing time where you can find some extra health and supplies. Speaking of supplies, Some folks say that flame belch is nothing more than an extra gimmick to further complicate the game. But the flame belch allows you to negate portions of incoming damage, which allows the devs to make smarter ai and stronger demons, which makes the game way more fun. All in all, this game is incredible, and far better than DOOM 2016. When you master the elements of this game you feel like such a badass, and not even the marauders can slow you down.

review: Doom kinda do be eternal

DOOM Eternal is a good game, if you haven't played DOOM (2016) then the rest of this review is irrelevant, however when compared to its predecessor this game is inferior in several ways.  The game is great, better than most out there, if DOOM (2016) didn't exist this would be one of my favourite games.  However DOOM (2016) does exist and that makes this game ultimately disappointing as a successor.

Firstly much of the aesthetic has been changed in ways which just make it worse.  Pickups have been desaturated but the brightness has been increased, creating a cartoonish look that does not blend with the game world.  Weapon pickups in particular are now floaty spinning and glowy things instead of being blended in.  The secrets are now also glowy floaty things instead of being blended into the game world too.  This almost seems like it was a change made later in development seeing as there is a cutscene (shown in the trailer for the game) in which you obtain the plasma cannon.  However at that point you have already obtained the gun as a pickup item (that you would actively have to avoid collecting).  The UI is designed to match this aesthetic which makes the game look even more arcadey.

On top of this further changes to the aesthetic have been made in the sake of fan nostalgia pandering.  The soldier, mancubus and cacodemon have designs based on the original DOOM sprites, which only serves to make them look dated and out of place.

The chainsaw has been changed so that now instead of picking up fuel it has a single charge that recharges overtime.  Additional charges can be picked up as items but you will never have more than 1 charge because you will be using it to get more ammo.  In the previous game ammo was fairly plentiful meaning you could usually save up charges to kill a large enemy when you didn't want to deal with it.  In this game the ammo cap is vastly restricted and you will always be chainsawing fodder and switching weapons to keep you ammo count up.  There is however a new weapon called the crucible that replaces this role, however it is a late game item and the ammo scarcity is more equivalent to the BFG.

DOOM Eternal has added extra mobility options in the form of climbing walls, monkey bars and a dash. These make the combat much more fast paced and facilitate much more creativity with the boss designs.  However this has been used as an excuse include several parkour sections in the levels, which are not challenging and ruin the intense flow of the game that was present in DOOM (2016).

The game frequently suspends the action for tutorials.  Every new piece of equipment/ ability has a disruptive tutorial,  as does almost every large demon.  They are overintrusive and could have been done in a more integrated way.

Many demons now have a weakspot which makes many encounters more gimmicky and repetitive as there is a fixed best weapon and strategy to counter them.  When combined with the fact that the demons seem more tanky now, you are basically forced into using the weakspot to take down the enemies.  This gives the combat a more formal rythm compared to the free flowing structure of the previous game.

One of the new demons added is called the marauder.  The marauder is not a hard enemy if you know how to fight it.  However it is the previous paragraph turned up to 11.  This demon is boring to fight and very gimmicky.  On top of this the game gives straight up incorrect advice (as one of the tutorials) on how to counter this enemy, causing it to be a frustrating learning experience as it is the first demon capable of completely soloing you.  This demon ruins the rythm of the combat as its numerous mechanics force your attention, but require you to slow down the pace while you deal with it.  Not fun 0/10.

The music is good, but in most levels it does not hit as well as in 2016.  It does not seem to be synced as well and often reaches climax right as the fight ends leading to a disappointing fade down to the out of combat track.  This could have something to do with the fall out between Mick Gordan and ID.

I'd recommend it as the story is fun and the more intense fights manage to capture the fun of Doom.  However coming from 2016 it feels overall underwhelming.
a good time had by all.

Fantastic game. Massive improvement over the 2016 installment with great weapon variety and diverse arsenal. Pros:
1- Fluid combat even more than 2016. The addition of dashes, flamethrower, and the tweak of the chainsaw made the combat cycle more fluid than ever before.
2- Level designs are the best in the franchise, both from the mix of combat and exploration, the versatile environments and little dash of parkour added on top. Combat areas have more options for movement with the addition of jump bars.
3- More demons, with weakness points and various patterns. Some are a joy to fight and some are just a pain in the ass (slithering fucks).
4- Combat now focuses more on strategy as you have to keep moving while evaluating your options and choosing your little fights. Smaller enemies serve as resources while bigger ones you need to build up momentum to tackle (in the form of ammo, special attacks, or both). 

Cons: (Spoiler alert)
1- End game levels are not as flushed out as early levels. The last two levels were actually nothing but fight area after the other with little exploration or parkour to add variety. 
2- The end two bosses are just horrible. I don't know how the developers landed on those design choices but man the are complete opposite of the entire game. The last boss is basically a bullet sponge which is really disappointing since the game masterfully avoided bullet sponges among many other typical FPS games gimmicks for adding artificial difficulty. The second to last boss is a repetitive loop where the arena is getting smaller as the boss sets the floor on fire! The concept is extremely poor in practice as it made the fight boring and annoying.

Overall the game is most buy if you are a doom fan. I'd say it is worth ~30 USD or so.

A very good game that could've been better.

Pros: graphics, gameplay, relentless pacing, plethora of unlockables, armor/weapon upgrades, and content in general.

Cons: Marauder is initially a fun challenge, but soon after turns into one of the most annoying and rage-inducing demons to fight against thanks to him showing up multiple times again and again throughout the rest of the game.  He hinders the enjoyment and initial excitement of the game by a ton.  By a certain point he is no longer a fun challenge; he becomes simply irritating to the point where you want to stop playing altogether.  There's also the checkpoint system which I absolutely loathed.  You can get 90% into a boss/horde battle and the minute you die, you restart at the very beginning again.  What a huge turn off.

I love the Doom series, and Eternal is no doubt one of the best installments.  It's just incredibly unfortunate that the gripes I had were big enough to make me go from loving the game to simply liking it.

the good:
More of what you love about doom, the brutality, the madness, the adrenaline pumping stress and anxiety.  They tried to give it a sort of Evil Dead makeover, and I can imagine that could have gone terribly, but I think it works as long as it doesn't go any farther than this. It knows it's cheesy and hokey and plays on it well. It's fun and doesn't take much thought to pick up, play, and kick some ass!

The bad:
Some of the features that got me so pumped in the previous game feel like they've been downgraded. Maybe I'm coming at this having recently played 2016, but it feels a bit slow and easy (I should raise my difficulty level and see how that goes). 
I'm not sure if it was a criticism in the last one about ammo looking too much like the rest of the level in aesthetic so it got lost in the blur of moving through the maps. They decided to design the ammo symbol in a retro game graphics and colours. I'm not really into it, it looks extremely out of place reminds me that I'm playing a remake which I don't like.

I know that I'm in the minority here, but this incarnation of Doom is not enjoyable.  I've played every other version, going back to the very first.  This is super cheesy arcadey, and I do not enjoy this nonsense.  This micromanagement of having to shoot-big-guy while trying to kite, then flame/chainsaw-small-guy, then loop because oh-yeah-I'm-out-of-ammo/health-again is not a fun mechanic for me.  Let's see, we've got weapons with two mods each, grenades, flamer, chainsaw, super-punch, finishing moves for extra health and what else?  It's just too bombastic - there's no real strategy other than run around in a circle and pray you don't get caught on a wall or other element while trying to recursively loop through shooting for five seconds, then collecting more ammo while dodging everything.

I know, I know, 'get gud'.  I'm just not enjoying it enough to invest the time.  I find myself rage-quiting over and over, and I've never had that with Doom before.  Doom 2016 was awesome because they had just touch of the above going on.  This time they took all the fun things from Doom 2016 and dialed each up to 11, which actually is a lot less fun than it sounds.

Get better things to do, and better games to play.

Bought the game thinking the negative reviews were exaggerating. They were not. The game is not horrible but while DOOM 2016 was enjoyable from start to finish Eternal was "meh" in like half of the content. Get it on a steep discount if you really liked DOOM 2016. While playing through it i had many moments where i was disappointed or bored instead of thrilled. Would i have known the following i would not have bought the game.

- The amount of parkour between the battles makes up around 40% of the game. This is way too much and it is just simple jumping making it really boring to do.
- The game is so buggy i would categorise it to be still in beta. Had to do mission 3 more than 4 times since the battle completion bugged out and i did not get the weapon upgrade point. Fell through the floor sometimes. Enemies often don't act and freeze. Sometimes completed mission objectives just get lost later on. 20% of my game time was redoing bugged missions. I don't remember having a single bug in DOOM 2016. Rushed development? 
- The story presentation is simply garbage. You get drowned is notes to read to follow what is happening since they can't be bothered to explain anything elsewhere. DOOM is just not the game to be an epic Opera. This is another victim of their new game development philosophy MORE IS ALWAYS BETTER. 
- Two of the new enemies are just horrible from a design perspective. The Archvile summoning demons is really strong so i one hit kill him with the new weapon. That's the way every single fight against him goes. The other is the Marauder. Putting him into the game was an obvious oversight from the rushed development. I honestly thought we would get a patch removing him.  
- The difficulty is unbalanced. Most fights are so easy even the highest difficulty is not that hard. Then there are some fights i had to change to the easiest difficulty. Having to go to the menu all the time just ruins the game flow. Again, DOOM 2016 in comparison was perfect. I just played it on the highest difficulty and never had to change anything. 
- I totally get what they wanted to do with the severe ammo capping. It's good in theory but the way they implemented it is not finished. I often end a fight with no ammo left at all. Then comes a small challenge fight but with no enemies to refill. So i can't do it and have to return later. Why not just spawn a small refill enemy in every challenge fight?

Edit

Got two other interesting points. 
- The ammo problem is handled right in the master levels. Seems like they know where the problem is but had no time to do it in the campaign so only the two master levels got the right enemy respawn behaviour. Again, the game is simply not finished.
- The marauder fight is the only one not shown in any trailer. They know it's bad but strangely kept him in the game anyway.

review: it's DOOM
One the best sequels I've ever played! Far superior to the first one :)

-	Constant Action?  Yes.
-	Decent Story when you take the time to read it?  Yes.
-	Amazing Graphics at 4K fully maxed?  Yes.
-	Smooth gameplay?  Yes.

Overall, I really enjoyed playing this game.  I was hesitant to buy it at first after so many people were comparing it to Doom 2016 in a not so good light.  While it certainly is a very different feel than Doom 2016, the game stands on it’s own.  I had a TON of fun playing this game and time would fly by because the action was so constant and intense at times.

I would recommend this game to anyone who loves constant and intense action in a twist of an old school shooter with the newer concept of power-ups and attachments.

Favorite weapon…  double barrel shotgun when using the meat hook…  got me through most of the game!  Ha!  ;)
Best non-VR game of 2020.

[h1]Summary[/h1]
One of the best FPS's to date. Smooth gameplay that flows like water. The combat puzzle is wonderfully put together.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
How the game actually plays is Eternal's strongest point. The "combat puzzle" is a joy to work through. Different demons require a different approach. Sure you can [i]try[/i] to Super Shotgun everything, but it won't work out too well for you. For example, if you used the Heavy Cannon's scope mod to shoot off the rocket launchers of the Revenant, he won't be able to shoot at you and be forced to close the distance in melee combat, making him a far easier target. Glory kills replenish health, flame belch replenishes armor, and chainsawing replenishes ammo. Learning when to use those and what demons to use them on can really make your life easier. This is what I mean by the combat puzzle and the game revolves around it.

There are a lot more platforming sections in this game as compared to previous Doom installments. Platforming is implemented well and is used to discover secrets strewn about the levels. Your traversal options are greatly expanded with bars to swing from and walls to cling to. The bars in particular help combat feel as fluid as it does, helping you glide across the battlefield.

[h1]UI and Customization[/h1]
The UI is just incredible and fully customizable. The hud can be changed to a few different colors, made smaller, or removed all together. Hud opacity can also be changed. Almost every facet of the game can be changed to how you like it.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
This is obviously the best looking Doom to date. The Slayer is meticulously detailed, as well as the levels and demons. Up-close glory kills look incredible and taking a screenshot you can see the true work put into the presentation. Weapon models are suitably detailed, which should be the case as they are always in front of you. The level of detail in the levels is truly awesome, especially if you care about the lore of the game.

[h1]Sound[/h1]
The sound is pretty good, although for some reason the soundtrack sounds a little muffled. Weapons all sound great and the chunky hits on demons is wonderful. Punching is also really satisfying and the sound makes you want to keep on punching.

[h1]Online[/h1]
I'm going to be honest here, Online is not the true gem of this game, that lies in the singleplayer. However, Battlemode is pretty fun. It pits a single Slayer vs 2 demons. You can be one of several demons all with different abilities (like summoning other demons or summoning a flame pit). It's quite fun, but there are limited maps and it's the only game mode.
It's DOOM.

OK Reviewing this game is REALLY difficult. 
TLDR: DO NOT think that 'the hardest mode' is for everyone. That's where the bad reviews come from.
No one ever did Ultra Nightmare with less than 200h in this game. No. One. Ever. Will.
It's great, its SHIT, it's amazing... in that order. Let me explain...

This game is set up so that the most casual player to the most highly skilled can all find their own mastery.
DHMD is for people who want to roflstomp, explore the world, read the lore... then leave.
Ultra Violence is for people who have played through, who want a bit extra challenge. You should be able to AltiSwitch your DPS weapons, and have custom Keybinds for each weapons at this point, else go back down a difficulty.
Nightmare is there for those who wish to truely understand the finely nuanced combat and it's high-level quirks. This is for 1/1000 players.
Ultra Nightmare is for those who know where enemies will spawn before they've killed the previous one. The explicit definition of mastery. This is going to be less than 1/10,000 players. This is 'God' tier game play, and I do not say that lightly. 

DO NOT come into this thing thinking you can take on Nightmare without learning the deep inner systems of this game. You'll leave hurt, frustrated, and disillusioned. Thus so many bad reviews for the game. People are idiots.

IF you're a casual, want to play a challenging and highly enjoyable single player experience / campaign, and come form games such as;
-ShadowWarrior 1 or 2
-Titanfall 1 or 2
-Doom 2016 (Caveat)
  Or 
-any other action heavy, content lite shoot shit until it dies game;

then do this:
Buy Game. Play on  Ultra Violence. i think. Maybe the one below that. Yeah, the one under that. I make UV look easy.
spend all your time looking around for secrets, make sure the first Suit upgrades you unlock are 'larger Automap Reveal Radius'. Find every secret and Codex (usually really simple to fine them, they are on the main story path). Read everything, watch every cut scene. Enjoy the game.

Otherwise;
Ultra Violence is for people who have played through once before and understand the game loop.
Shoot/jump/dash/switch/chainsaw/'do it all again'. At this stage I recommend mastery of quick switching weapons.

It's not a glitch, it's an intended 'high level' mechanic. If you're using the MMB or Weapon wheel to switch weapons at this stage; upgrade your skill, or stop playing UV and go back down to Don't Hurt Me.

Nightmare is for those who want to truely master every Nuance and combat system of the game.
DONT watch videos online and think you can do that. You can't, unless you are Shroud Himself... Or Mayo. Trust me. I am a better FPS player than you. This game is going to hurt you. a. lot.

GG>

Buy it and play on easy for a power fantasy.
buy it and play on Hard if you're determined to put 1000h into learning the game's systems.
Else,

Shut up. Fuck Off.
oh, and this review will put all this in perspective in a way I could only dream of doing;

The experience is tarnished by the decision to try to force the player to create a Bethesda account and link it to Steam, even if you have no intention of ever doing anything online with the game. The only way I know of how to bypass it is either disable internet on your computer, through adapter/unplugging ethernet cord, or configure a firewall rule to not allow the game reach out and "phone home". I've had to disable the rule once in order for it to "phone home" and validate itself somewhere halfway through my playtime, as it refused to startup until I did so. Then re-enabling the firewall rule worked still, and I was able to finish the game.

GAMEPLAY, in my subjective opinion, is still good when compared to the predecessor. However for every advancement it makes, it takes a step backwards as well. 

New weapons are fun, but the changes to the chainsaw are incredibly frustrating. You only get 3 units of fuel for it, and it always 1hit kills anything with only 1 fuel. However there is no way in knowing if you can actually use it on an enemy until you try it, and get a "no target" message, or slice it up. As some demons are immune to the chainsaw, and others have to be damaged to an unknown degree before you can do so. 

New melee charge up punch ability is fun when it works, but extremely infuriating when it doesn't... At times I was either mid air and it simply refused to be triggered, or it briefly bugged out and I ended up doing a regular punch and getting my face ripped off instead.

You get much more mobility actions when compared to the previous game, a double jump, and two charges of "dash" which are omni-directional. However, the level design is now much more vertical and platformer puzzle driven now. There's a lot of time spent on weird and unpleasant first person platforming without any sort of action. I felt like I was playing Prince of Persia at times, instead of RIP AND TEAR. The dash also bugged out at times and I ended up getting stuck inside of enemies/terrain for a brief period of time, enough to get turned in to a pink mist on the difficulty I was playing at.

STORY, is mediocre to good.

Exposition occurs primarily through codex entries, and some voice over lines. The developers are attempting to explain and rationalize everything in the setting/events, instead of leaving mystique do the work. While doing an acceptable job, it still leaves minor plot holes and inconsistencies. Especially glaring in many levels where platforming puzzles are so blatantly shoe-horned in without regard to how it would fit in with the setting of the level.

SOUND, absolutely incredible!

Honestly, the sound design carries this game farther that even gameplay. I would like to especially highlight the background ambiance sounds of the levels and the music as really standing out. Top notch work!

Doom Eternal is the true revival of the series. Doom 2016 was missing some elements that made it the epic revival we wanted while still being a good game, doom eternal gives us that stuff we wanted. More gore, more action, and getting to play as the demons. Playing as demons in online is the best thing you can do just spawning in demons while the slayer is crying and suffering.
Rip... And... TEAR!

Doom Eternal is a great game. 

Edit: Since my review the dev's removed Denuvo anti-cheat and reached out to me to let me know, I believe you can see their response to my review. As of now, I will be reverting my negative review. I can safely say that this game is worth getting and playing, you will certainly enjoy it. 

Previous negative review due entirely to Denuvo implementation as follows:

Denuvo's kernal-level anti-cheat is malware trash. The devs expect you to be okay with installing a root-kit program that has been shown to hinder performance.  I've uninstalled the game until this game no longer requires Denuvo to be installed.
developer_response:
Hey there, 

We just wanted to let you know that, with Update 1.1, we have removed the Denuvo Anti-Cheat integration and addressed some other issues. For more information please see: https://beth.games/3gYBFY0

Thank you for taking the time to review our game and we hope that you will give Doom: Eternal another shot. 

Best,
Bethesda Customer Support

review:
Probably the best single-player FPS you can play in terms of pure gameplay, polished to shining.

+ Excellent campaign with neat enemies, arenas, collectables and lore.
+ Unique and fun multiplayer which brings in knowledge of campaign gameplay.
+ Nice selection of weapons with which to slay.
+ Superb enemy variety and utilisation along with integration into the rest of the game mechanics.
+ Refined weapon arsenal where everything is viable, which is needed when the game wants you to constantly weapon switch.
+ You don't die falling off cliffs and such unlike Doom 2016, just spawn with a bit less health, so it's easier to explore.
+ The most optimised while also good looking AAA game I've seen in a while.

= Platforming is fun for downtime but basic, unless you put effort into chaining meathooks, dashes, ballista boosts and the like.
= Marauders are awkward when thrown in with other enemies, though fine eventually the dog is still annoying. Look up Under the Mayo on YouTube explaining how the Marauder is actually an excellent enemy for the game.

- Other multiplayer modes would be nice and snap-map didn't return, so less value for money in some regards compared to Doom 2016.
- Purple slime mostly sucks, especially when you need to fight enemies in it, though is bearable when avoidable with dashes and skill jumps. It's barely in the game to be fair though, so doesn't negate the experience.
Fun Game. 10/10 Would recommend.
Very dynamic game, recommend ;)

Can't believe I am about to say this but Doom Eternal kind of sucks.

They have turned Doom into a fucking RPG. Nothing wrong with upgrades but shooting has been ruined. Demon weak spots, weapons and mods for specific demons (a.k.a shooting order), an endless amount of bullshit and special abilities you have to babysit and chain or face death. Took me quite a while to realize what was wrong during my Nightmare run. I was dying non-stop. And then it hit me - I wasn't pushing the correct buttons in the correct order.

It's a damn shame because the base game underneath is amazing but they've completely ruined it for me with this RPG nonsense. Not felling great about the upcoming expansion either.

A variant of this disease is what was largely responsible for the bitter disappointment that was Shadow Warrior 2. Random generated weapons and enemies! Upgrades! Crafting! Funny lines!!! Dull and forced. It was pure crap.

I don't think I'll be buying any id games from now on if things continue progressing in this direction. Since it got stellar reviews, guess I am out of luck and will have to look elsewhere for AAA non-completely-turned-RPG first person shooters.

This is by far the best entry since the original few, but it still has flaws.

Doom Eternal is all about finding your way out of sticky situations. There is no Doom 2016 ez-mode AI to hold your hand here, and you're likely going to have volleys of projectiles and hordes to fend off from every side. So you can imagine its really annoying when you're playing on Nightmare and suddenly you're automatically swing on a pair of monkeybars(or hit a bounce pad) you didn't know existed, sending you out outside of glory-kill distance or away from ammo/health drops that you need to survive. Sometimes you don't even get the luxury of knowing how the hell you died(a "killed by" message would be nice!)

The movement in this game is a HUGE improvement from 2016 and the light platformer elements are easy, but fun, but one-dimensional. The movement improvements are more for the combat, though, for getting out of aforementioned sticky situations. 

The game gives you a lot to work with, and at its hardest it demands you use all of your options at once. Getting though Nightmare will push even the most dedicated FPS players to the limit, with there being plenty of rage inducing moments. Don't forget that when you sign up for Nightmare you get what the name implies, but it's satisfying to overcome insurmountable odds. 

Finally, the multiplayer is mediocre, the secrets are hardly secretive, the UI kind of sucks(but is great where it needs to be), the rocket launcher lock-on is ass, and if there are two things this game has a lot of its skill trees and bugs. But all in all its a great game, I mean look at how many hours I have in it.

Doom Eternal is a mixed bag. On one hand you have the combat which is exciting and challenging. The game forces you to use strategy against the enemies by using different weapons and abilities. Along with a great soundtrack it can be a lot of fun blasting and killing demons. On the other hand, the game is let down by simple and boring level design and awful jumping puzzle sections.

Between nearly every single "arena" to fight demons, there is always some sort of jumping puzzle. Walls to climb, spinning "Mario" flame poles, monkey bars to swing from, and large pits to cross. These sections really break up the gameplay and consist of about 40% of the actual game time.

The levels are pretty simple, very linear, and always give you waypoints on where you should be going next. It would seem they focused more on visual appeal rather than actual fun or interesting level design. They look great with awesome backdrops but everything is so chunky and static, it feels like you are traversing a fake environment just designed to move you along to the next arena for a demon fight.

Certainly not the best first person shooter to come out, but a decent experience to give you around 10 hours for the main story. Would recommend to get on sale or if you like this style of FPS game.

Don't read this review. Reviews are temporary, DOOM is eternal.

Fast paced and a helluva blast. If you liked DOOM 2016 you're more than likely going to love this. DOOM: Eternal adds more guns and brings back old ones in new ways that really put a breath of fresh air into this sequel. With great controls, badass abilities and an arsenal of weapons that would make the US Marine Corps look small caliber you get to wade through hordes of demons on Hell on Earth with a new emphasis on platforming and exploration that even DOOM (2016) didn't have it really is the ultimate DOOM Slayer experience.

As always, there are a few minor drawbacks. While I mostly got away scotch free, I have heard multiple reports about this game having no small amount of technical issues at launch but I do believe a large portion of them have been resolved with updates and such. The soundtrack, while still amazing, isn't quite what it was in the previous installment having slightly more "wub wub" in it than I would've preferred or even expected from such a Metal focused game like DOOM. Eternal also struggles with it's missions, or rather the transitioning between them. In 2016 you went from room to room and every mission was effectively just a few steps past where you ended the last whereas in Eternal there is no small amount of massive scene changes with little to no explanation short of "lul let's go here now" which can make the game a little jarring in the pacing. While I don't personally share this opnion, there are some that draw issue with the level design combined with the lack of continuity between missions and likened the game to "a DOOM Slayer theme park" as opposed to the more grounded approach taken in 2016.


Even with those issues and shortcomings I do believe that Eternal is overall better than 2016. From the weapon design, to the improved upon abilities to sinking deeper into the DOOM universe's lore. It's a fantastic approach to the game with hours and hours of fun (Including DOOM 1 and 2 from 1993 and 1994 fully playable inside the game) and is absolutely worth your time and your money.

I loved Doom 2016 for so many reasons : a simple but great story, good shootings, you were the Slayer on a base on Mars with guns and heavy metal! 

Here... I just can't get in... This gameplay evolution! I wanted to play Doom 2016 II, not Crash Bandicoot x Quake 3 Arena! 
The fact a game must evolve and try new stuff to sell/being better than its predecessor, sure! But that... I'm genuinely sad. 

This Doom Eternal I was so hyped about became honestly one of my greatest video game disappointments of the last few years, and probably decade... I'm maybe getting too old or something, with adult life / familly and so, but I wanted to continue Doom story through Earth after Mars events, I wanted to love this game as much as the 2016 one... But Jumping around like crazy, always low on ammo "because new gameplay loop / try all the great weapons / all enemy as a particular strat and such", deleting the damage of punches (no damage at all, really??? Did you see the Doom Guy? One punch of this guy would vaporise a grown up dude!) and replace it by some anime-like shock wave?! Eurk... 

And what about his teen room with guitars, magazins and toys?! He is the Doom Slayer, ffs! Not most of his fanbase nowadays!! He doesn't j*** off on his throne thinking he's the best when mommy cooks his meal! Wow... How can you mess up your character so much?! 

I'm sure its a great game and lot of people will enjoy it, but not men not a single moment and I almost never said that before, but I wish I didn't buy this game.

Edit after finishing the campaign :  Even if the story is still under the 2016 one, at least it's pleasant... But the gameplay kills it for me. :/

This game is exactly what it says on the box, and it knows exactly what it is. It's a game.

While that kind of seems like an obvious thing to say, it's kind of also easy to see that a lot of modern games strive for realism over fun. You can't run at mach 10 because that's not realistic. You have to reload every eight shots because that's realistic. You can't just pick up armor in the middle of combat because that's not realistic.

Doom Eternal says, pun intended, to hell with that. You are going to have the most fun in the shortest amount of time possible, and then you are going to repeat that gameplay loop until you're satisfied. The game is difficult, certainly, but it's rarely unfair. You can also tilt the odds in your favor as much or as little as you want, depending on how many of the optional collectibles you get. While getting them all is the way you're "supposed" to play the game, there are achievements for beating the game with as few upgrades as possible.

No matter your playstyle, you're rewarded for that. Whether it's a shiny new gun mod or simply a sense of accomplishment, you're going to have fun.

EDIT: As of writing this edit on August 25th, 2020, I have 81 hours logged in the game. I have played through twice, first on Ultra Violence and then on Nighmare. I am now working on Ultra Nightmare. Something about the arsenal being wide has worked to really captivate me. This game has a surprising amount of depth for a central mechanic of simply shooting things until they die.
Original review below.

Doom Eternal is much more "arcade-y" than Doom 2016. The atmosphere is brightly colored and collectables are shiny floating objects. Personally I dislike that. I greatly preferred the atmosphere of 2016, where, for example, the collectables (save for the toys) were part of the environment.

That being said, the game mechanics are a lot more refined in Eternal over 2016, especially in regards to movement. Among the refinements is a much tighter resource loop. However, there could be an argument to be made about there being [i]too many[/i] weapon mechanics in the loop. There's now a flame thrower and an ice bomb which is swapped to and from the frag grenade. There is also a sword at the end of the game. These special weapons added onto everything from 2016, including two weapon mods per gun. It's just a lot of stuff to remember to utilize in the heat of the moment when there are only fractions of a second to react. I did not get the hang of fully utilizing everything until close to the end of the game.

Gripes about the atmosphere and the at-first unwieldy arsenal aside, I still highly recommend this game.
yup

Literally epic. Definitely the most fun I have had playing an FPS in years. 

First off: prepare to become a one-man killing machine because your arsenal and abilities require you to learn them fast and actually put them to use. The good news is that with every new enemy and encounter, the game pauses and pops up a screen that shows you the exact weak points of your new enemy aka demon fodder. I'd say the funniest weakness is the Cacodemon's vulnerability to swallowing grenades from your shoulder launcher or shotgun; his wide eyed "OH SH!T" face right before detonation is freaking hysterical. 

Secondly, the game is a straight-up rewarding challenge. You will learn to get into a rhythm of combat.. or you will be getting squashed. As a true DOOM scholar I went straight for Ultra-Violence difficulty, beat it, then beat it again on Nightmare. After both, I am pleased to report that I had only a handful of instances where I felt like I had been cheated into a death, or experienced a death didn't really make sense. For all of the other many times I died, I completely understood what I did wrong, and could immediately take a different approach, streamlining the jump back in and preventing my ever feeling "burnt out" from frustration. Every time I got past a section, I felt very satisfied with myself for overcoming the insanity of the onslaught. 

In particular, the Marauders that everyone seems to be obsessed over are indeed a worthy challenge. They give you virtually no room for error, and punish you gravely for taking either of the two typical approaches of "close and in-your-face" or "I'm gonna try to snipe you from the other side of the area." With that in mind, you must maintain a delicate balance of medium distance so that he can't use his close-range shotgun, or super-fast long-range ax blast. But once you defeat one, you WILL feel a rush of accomplishment. PROTIP: Punch the Marauder after you stagger him with a successful shot and he will stagger again, leaving him open for a second shot.  

Third, the story is well-structured, well-paced, and genuinely interesting. The scattered lore pages are fun reads, and do an excellent job of building not just the world, but the mysterious, elusive DOOM Guy as well. In fact, this is the most you can see and hear about DOOM Guy ever, so there is a general sense of many long-time questions finally being answered. At the same time, you also feel like you want to learn even more, and the explosive, exciting ending leaves you with the feeling of "I just can't wait for what's next."

Fourth and final, as to the technical parts, the game has buttery smooth performance for even old systems and seems to have a highly efficient slow-motion effect in place for when your frame-rate drops below a certain level, preventing the action from becoming unfairly stacked against you. Even at the lowest settings, the game looks very beautiful (as much as that word can be used to describe the vile hordes of Hell), and it's actually fun to take a look around and soak in the artwork between the surprising diversity of locations (it's not just burning burning pits of Hell the whole time). Your mother-base and mission jump point, a ship of Maykr origin, is a barrel of fun all by itself, and there is plenty to look at and explore within. 

In a nutshell: this is a mandatory choice for all FPS fans, of all types, and DOOM fans of all ages. If you don't want to single-handedly "RIP AND TEAR" through the armies of Hell like a literal God, then what the Hell do you want to do with your life?

If you're looking for a nice, relaxing game, this is not that. This is a test of how much sh*t you can keep track of at any one time in a FPS. Weapons, weapon attachments, ammo, tools, perks, unlockables, the sheer volume of stuff this game dumps on you in the first two levels is absolutely bonkers. If you manage to wrap your head around the combat system - this is a whole different beast from Doom 2016 - and when everything clicks, Doom Eternal is a stimulation overload. I recommend naps.

DOOM Eternal is a fantastic game, with fun combat, fun platforming, and a pretty alright story.

Combat is by far the best part of the game. While (most) enemies do get shredded by your arsenal, it does take planning and strategy to ensure you survive combat encounters. Becoming overly cocky, even when replaying earlier levels, can lead to taking a lot of unwanted damage. Planning your attacks, glory kills, blood punches, chainsaw uses, and most importantly your movement around the arena are a requirement if you don't want to die. The arenas are designed with your move set entirely in mind, so take advantage of all the ledges, bounce pads and swinging bars. The challenge gates for both secret encounters and slayer gates are a great challenge and super satisfying to beat. Encountering Marauders can be frightening at first but clearing the arena of other enemies and playing safer is not only the best way of fighting him, but also a great change of pace when it comes to the usual "kill everything in sight" combat.

The platforming sections of DOOM Eternal are quite enjoyable and can lead to some very well hidden secrets. Platforming makes full use of the double jump, swing bars, dash and wall climbing, and keen eyed players might spot out of place platforming sections that may lead to a secret of some kind. However, some secrets I feel were very cheaply hidden within levels when compared to how clever some locations are for other secrets.

The story of the game is alright. There really isn't much to touch on as it doesn't try to do anything too special. For what it is, it works in context of what kind of game DOOM Eternal is.

Overall, I highly recommend DOOM Eternal to anyone who enjoys first person shooters and single player games. There is a lot of fun to be had playing and replaying the campaign, and I'm sure that will extend into the first expansion that's releasing soon.

[h1]SINGLEPLAYER: [/h1]
The campaign is one of the best FPS experiences ever, period. Definitely has a couple rough difficulty spikes thanks to Marauders, but otherwise the game is full of intense action, excellent music and sound design, and tastefully excessive violence against the armies of Hell. The platforming is also significantly less garbage and more forgiving than DOOM 2016's, becoming a fluid and mostly seamless part of the Eternal death ballet. 
Ultra-violence is a totally doable and exciting challenge, and Nightmare isn't impossible on a second run. 
The first run is the least fun. The replay value is pretty good, and once it all clicks, the aggressive combat starts to feel natural after a few levels. 
[spoiler]If Marauders kick your ass too often, quickly switch between the super shotty and ballista. Once you fiogure out the timing for a parry, it's mostly over with. [/spoiler]

[h1]MULTIPLAYER: [/h1]
Battlemode is kinda 'meh'. It's not horrible, and thankfully bad games are over with quickly. That said, the Slayer player seems to be either horribly underpowered or overpowered versus the two demon players. Mostly seems to be a product of Slayer mobility and how many fodder enemies demons can lob at the arena. Starting Battlemode for the first time also locks you into the only totally unskippable tutorial in the game, and I think that helps say something about how unnatural the gamemode feels at first. 
Don't rely on text chat for anything worthwhile- it's inaccessible for most of the game, and seems to go by too fast to effectively communicate. Wouldn't be too bothered trying to communicate with other players though, not critical to sweeping the floor with the other team.

Doom Eternal is a first-person shooter. It Blood, guts, and gore from start to finish. DOOM Eternal is a worthy successor of DOOM 2016. This game adds just the right combination of additional features and quality of life changes to keep the formula fresh.
I personally find the multiplayer to be repetitive. I only find myself trying to play it to grind those ridiculous achievements (I’m looking at you 200 multiplayer kills). Regardless the campaign is longer, harder, and has more replayability than DOOM 2016 IMO.
The only issue I have with the game is that you can be having a grand time. Flying all over the map killing a bunch of demons, and then the game grinds to a screeching halt. (I’m looking at you Marauder).

[b] Plot [/b]
Sometime after the events on Mars, Earth has been overrun by demonic forces, wiping out 60% of the planet's population, under the now-corrupted Union Aerospace Corporation. What remains of humanity has either fled Earth or have joined the Armored Response Coalition, a resistance movement formed to stop the invasion, which has gone into hiding after suffering heavy losses. The Doom Slayer, having previously been betrayed and teleported away by Dr. Samuel Hayden, returns with a satellite fortress controlled by the AI VEGA to quell the demonic invasion by killing the Hell Priests: Deags Nilox, Ranak, and Grav. The priests serve an angelic being known as the Khan Maykr who seeks to sacrifice mankind. The Slayer teleports to a destroyed city and kills Deag Nilox, but the Khan Maykr transports the two remaining priests to unknown locations, forcing the Slayer to continue searching.

[b] Accolades [/b]
-Game Critics Awards 2019 (Best PC Game and Best Action Game)

[b] Summary: [/b]
+ Solid campaign with interesting character interactions  
+ Same core gameplay from DOOM 2016
+ Solid worldbuilding
- Bland multiplayer 

PS: Turn off Steam Overlay, you can get more FPS.

[b] Highly recommend! [/b]

review:
This game trudges dangerous territory for me. On one hand, some of the mechanics introduced in Doom 2016 have been refined and polished to near perfection. You will balance abilities in a very satisfying gameplay loop once you get a feel for it. Gun, level, and enemy design are very much on point. On the other hand, I knew this game would make mistakes when it came to some of the lore established in 2016. Of course, this one is very much up its own a** when it comes to the mythos, but at least the cutscenes are skipable. It's not unenjoyable, but things are certainly much more fleshed out than they probably need to be. It comes as extremely juxtaposed by how much the game knows it is a video game. By which I mean, 1-ups, easter eggs, floating guns/powerups and collectables, as well as Doomguy's (sorry, The Doom Slayer's) comedic timing. Also, those expecting to be able to tear through demonic hordes without thinking too hard will be quickly frustrated by how fast guns run out of ammo, or potentially even by the break in pacing granted via the small platforming segments. To me, these certainly don't pose an issue, as they are short and fairly enjoyable and really don't make you think too hard, and I enjoy how the game forces you into utilizing all of the mechanics.

I can't comment on the multiplayer because I didn't play it, but I've heard it's fun. I can't really say.
The exclusion of Snapmaps feels like a missed opportunity.
I can feel the icy Hand of Bethesda clawing at my back when it comes to how hard XP/leveling and participating in community events is thrown at you, especially with all the confetti screens and skins. That isn't to say participating in any of that isn't fun, but this game didn't really need all that. And all the extra fluff around what I consider an already solid game feels pointless, even a bit detracting with the exclusion of snapmaps. At least there's no abusive monetary schemes hidden away in all this.

In the end, I do recommend playing this game. And definitely play on a harder difficulty. Don't get filtered by the Marauder.

I didn't even know games can be this broken in 2020.

First thing I noticed was a 500+ms input delay. Wow. I looked around and Gsync seems to be causing it. Other modern games didn't give me this problem, but ok.

I try to play and... there's no sound? This one is tricky. Turns out that the game sometimes can't be heard on bluetooth headphones. Other games don't care where I get my sound from, but ok.

Back into the game... Now every time I launch it, there's a 50% change that it won't receive input from my mouse and keyboard. I have to terminate the game from the task manager and restart. REALLY?? You make a AAA title for one of the most famous franchises, and you don't know how to read my mouse?!

Update: I managed to finish the campaign. Loved it. What I didn't love was being interrupted by a pop-up 2-3 times per hour, saying that connection to the Bethesda servers has been lost. A connection which, mind you, adds practically nothing to the campaign. About to score a mid-air headshot? Not before accepting a popup about Bethesda's servers being useless again.

The game itself is a solid shooter, but it can't be recommended when it fails in such basic ways.

I have a lot of mixed feelings about DOOM Eternal compared to its predecessor, DOOM.
Pros: DOOM Eternal has a much better movement system and level design. You'll be zooming all over the map in seconds. Additionally, the Super Shotgun chain hook is amazing design.
Cons: DOOM Eternal really restricts your gameplay to how the developer wants you to play. You'll be forced to micromanage multiple resource bars as well as your ammo, and switch between all of your weapons constantly. Additionally, there were some enemies that were designed to be killed a certain way; run out of ammo for that weapon and you'll be stuck trying to fight them inefficiently and getting destroyed for it. In fact, on higher difficulties, the ammo cap is extremely insufficient; you'll spend a larger portion of your time running around looking for a random mook to chainsaw for ammo than actually fighting, and that's simply not a fun experience. In some levels, especially those with minibosses, you'll run out of ammo for all your weapons before killing them about five to six times; this means you have to run around and dodge looking for a mook, chainsaw, shoot, then run around again. The gameplay loop simply isn't fun.
Overall, I wouldn't recommend DOOM Eternal. It just isn't satisfying to play.

I had to wait until after the latest patch in August to write this review since a bug would crash my game upon completion of a Slayer Gate. I finished the last 3 missions and the game, and they felt so much like a chore that writing this review was almost too much.

To keep it short, the team took DOOM 2016 and tried to make it "faster" - cramming you in small environments with too many weapons to use effectively all while zooming around like an asshole. Nothing about this game is polished; attacks often don't activate when they're supposed to (Blood Fist) while the platforming bits will result in you punching the wall instead of grabbing it and then falling to your death. In fact all the platforming bits in this game feel more like a crappy diversion than anything thought out or involving. 

Combat is alright, but having a dozen different weapons with different firing modes means you're switching through weapons as often as you're firing them, trying to find the right weapon for the right enemy. Then about halfway through the game a new enemy type is introduced that completely ruins any "flow" the developers thought they had. Couple tips: upgrade the Super Shotgun all the way first, and farm like 30 extra lives in the first couple levels. Then it wont be as annoying when the enemies box you into a corner and kill you over and over since you're out of ammo and the chainsaw can't kill heavy enemies. Don't worry, that only happened at least once in every single mission. 

All in all buy this when it's half off and don't pay a penny more. I loved DOOM 2016 and consider it one of the best shooters of all time. This is a disappointing sequel, one that feels like the developers sacrificed enjoyable game play and well-thought out levels in order for things to be "faster" - but instead feels cramped, unimaginative and repetitive.

This game starts *rough* but evens out once you get past the Cultist Base.

Basically, this game is wall-to-wall demon smashing.  Chainsaws, laser swords, rocket launchers, four barrelled machine guns, shoulder mounted combination flamethrower/grenade launchers, it has it all.  But it doesn't have it all *right away.*  The early game has you existing on much thinner margins than the late game, and simple mistakes (like putting 4 rounds into an Imp instead of 3) can be the difference between crushing an encounter and having to start over.

All that said, this game is great.  It's a Zdzisław Beksiński painting come to life.  Loud, angry, extremely violent life.  There's a ton more story and setpieces than the 2016 game, and (somehow) way more badassery.  The game is well-written, exciting, and honestly beautiful; Sentinel cities and Urdak are bizarre and gorgeous, while Hell on Earth is a shattered mirror's worth of fascinating ruination.

Also, this game is *metal as hell.*

I'm updating my review, since Bethesda/ID did listen to the community and fixed the game.
I don't personally care for a lot of the multiplayer aspect and the community integration, but this doesn't bear on the game itself. I'm also not a fan of the platforming, at best for me it is just a frustration. All in all, it delivers on it's promise, and is in line with what I expect from a game in the DOOM franchise, though I prefer the mechanics of the older DOOM games. I will certainly come back to playing it, there is simply no better way to to be an unthinking, instinct driven creature of ultraviolence than the DOOM franchise, and Eternal puts that at the forefront of the experience.

review: Yes, THIS IS DOOM!

I gotta say that going from Doom 2016 to Doom Eternal was a less than optimal experience, for the following reasons:

[list]
[*] I hated the menu screens/interface. Not completely sure why, but the horrible, almost unreadable font certainly didn't help.
[*] The parkour and puzzle elements were not welcome. I play Doom to kill demons, not to think - the puzzles in particular introduced a weird pacing into the gameplay.
[*] The Marauder. What a load of bullshit. I get the need to introduce greater variation in the enemies, including tougher enemies, but this is taking it too far. That thing NEEDS to be adjusted somehow, it completely messes with the pacing of the game.
[*] Also way too many progression paths and buttons to press. This should also have been toned down.
[/list]

Despite all this, I had fun playing it. Getting into the game took way longer than it had any rights doing, but it ended up being ok fun and entertaining. Whatever, maybe I'm just an old fart :)

TL:DR, there's too many things going on, but if you can live with that and stick with it, there's a good game underneath.

7/10
