Its been said enough but this is one of the best fps games I'v ever played. lets go over what makes this game so fun.

1.  The combat in this game stays fresh even after 200 hours of game play. The feeling of melting even the strongest of demons with bone crunching combos as you whirl around shoot in every direction is amazing. 

Each of the guns has its own feel: the super shot gun lets you stun bigger demons and shred though fodder like a crucible though a tyrant, the lock on mod for the rocket launcher can kill most heavy demons with only one charge and do massive damage to super heavies, lets not forget the sheer rush we get when sniping a drone from across the map with the ballista or the combat rifle.
 
2. the movement in this game compliments the combat perfectly, this is one of the things that keeps me coming back. Its hard not to fall in love in this game while you're flying though the air raining down bullet and explosive like and angel of death. Its a good thing the movement feels so good because you won't be standing still at all if you're playing the game right. You'll be dodging though claws and fireballs and you launch out your own attacks as the demons hopelessly try to catch you. 

3. The replay value is amazing, even though you'll just be playing the same levels over again each fight feel new. You'll be moving in all different directions learning how to better use your weapons and your skill level keeps rising. another thing is how good it feels when you get good. Its very cathartic when you go from getting killed by the same one mancubus to slaughtering 4 at a time while flying though the air sniping arachnotron turrets. 

Though my one major gripe with this game is the terrible lock on. More often then not when you're going for that one chainsaw, blood punch, or meat hook grapple. there is about a 10% chance the lock on won't trigger. 

Over all a really good game that is very much worth time to play and get good at. Are there bugs in this game and can it cause rage? YES it very much can but what game dose not? Give the game a try and have some fun!

Has everything I loved about the first Doom reboot, only boosted to incomprehensible levels. Everything you loved about campy 90s first person shooters shines in Doom Eternal. It's bloated with a unending and overcomplicated "plot", it's riddled with too many mechanics that you need to keep track of (firethrower to gain armor, glory kill to gain health, chainsaw to gain ammo, blood punch, different types of grenades that you need to switch and use in milliseconds, secondary attack on each gun depending on which weapon enhancement is active, runes that give you some powers (such as preventing death briefly and slowing down time, passively), armor upgrades, skill upgrades, double jump, air dash, air dash + wall climb, gimnast horizontal bars to swing and jump farther, extra lives, plus now enemies have very specific weaknesses that you also need to take care of such as throwing a grenade at the exact millisecond a demon is with its mouth open).

This game is bloated, and convoluted, it's a shame, I really liked the previous one, this is hard to enjoy.

Doom Eternal is a game i struggled to enjoy for a fair bit when starting out. A game that doesn't fully come together until a fair bit in and until that point is an exercise in frustration. Doom Eternal trades in Doom 2016s forward momentum simplicity for complexity and I'm still unsure as to wether or not if it is better or worse. when you are at highs with the game you feel like the unkillable thunderchrist ripping and tearing through the demonic hordes like a hot knife through butter. at its worse its a janky platforming mess that forces you to hunt down fodder for ammo instead of being constant moment to moment fun. With the constant battering the game takes from the bipolar community who cant decide if its love or hate with every decision the developers make post launch, that perfectly reflects the game. sometimes highs sometimes lows. I'd have to say I'm disappointed in Doom Eternal it had a high bar to meet and seemingly fumbled when it came to consistency. but damn if when it comes together it doesn't really come together.

My first few hours in the game brought a lot of frustration. The flow of the game was different than DOOM 2016, melee attacks dealt no damage and a bunch of new mechanics were being thrown in my face. However once I got used to the way things work now, I found myself having a lot of fun. The constant juggling of health,armor and ammunition while trying to stay mobile and slay demons keeps you on your toes and provides immense satisfaction. 

The enemy design is phenomenal both artistic and mechanic-wise. The demons' designs convey their intents and fighting style successfully while also being pleasing to the eye and fitting the game's atmosphere. Returning enemies from DOOM 2016 have been slightly redesigned (can't call this bad or good as it depends on taste but it was a welcome change) and pre-2016 veterans and fresh newcomers make up a seamless opposition ready to be ripped and torn. Contrary to the previous installment, each demon requires a different approach and forces the player to get out of their comfort zone and use their entire arsenal instead of just relying on their favourite weapon.

Again stepping on the predecessors's flaws, DOOM Eternal takes the personal upgrade system and works on it. Weapon mods are now more meaningful as they can change drastically how the weapon plays against certain demons and personal upgrades feel a bit more impactful.

Having the heart of a classic DOOM game, the theatrical evisceration Eternal provides wouldn't be complete without a proper stage to be performed on. The levels feel more grandiose now, taking the slayer to a variety of locations. Design-wise they take advantage of the Slayer's newfound mobility, adding some rather controversial platforming segments and introducing verticality to the arenas. While some can find the parkour segments of the game tedious, I thought they were a welcome break outside of combat and added some extra complexity in the heat of battle.

There seems to be a greater focus on story this time. In addition to the logs you find about the world and the demons, there's also an increase in cutscenes and character dialogue compared to DOOM 2016. Nothing to go crazy about, but a nice addition.

Unfortunately with all the good the game has, some bad things come in its performance. While having the recommended specs, I find myself unable to get to the main menu at times (fortunately restarting the game seems to solve this). There's also the occasional stutter here and the weird demon behaviour there. However, these setbacks are not enough to ruin the experience, although I don't know how it would perform on lower-end PCs.

All in all, while alienating at first, the game forces you to adapt and combines the brutal violence the series is known for with a much needed tactical approach, resulting in a delightful explosion of blood and guts and a satisfactory loop of completing an encounter and preparing for the next one.

P.S.: The Marauder is fine, y'all are just babies.

To preface, I wish I could review this as "Neutral" or "Undecided."
If you enjoyed the first DOOM, you may enjoy this one as well.  I stress: "may."  I don't think I need to sell the positives of this game, all the action and gore of the first game can be found in its sequel, so I'll highlight the differences that could be negatives to some.
The vibe of the game is entirely different to the first game, which I'm not entirely a fan of.  The story of the first game was very driven; you were traversing Mars and Hell to complete concrete goals, and your many fights were simply obstacles to tear through.  In the sequel, you begin after a large time skip, traversing large, disconnected locations to kill priests and stop the invasion of Earth.  This scenario, along with the gameplay changes, make the story feel irrelevant.  I feel completely disconnected from whatever objectives I'm supposed to be completing, I don't feel invested beyond "shoot and collect until the stage ends."

The mentioned gameplay changes are my bigger gripe with the sequel.  In the first game, much in line with the objective-centric story, you collect weapons along the way to aid your progression.  With a wide arsenal, and a weak pistol to fall back on, your weapons were tools; you can largely use what weapons you will, and while some weapons were far more effective versus specific enemies, you could largely neglect some weapons if you didn't care for them.  While you may have run short on ammo near the beginning of the game, as long as you didn't neglect upgrading your ammo count, you probably had a decent amount of breathing room.  None of this is applicable to DOOM Eternal.  The sequel heavy-handedly adopts an arcade-esque playstyle.  While you have an even more versatile kit, the game demands that you use all of it.  You will frequently run short on ammo, forcing you to chainsaw enemies.  The new flame belch weapon allows you to acquire armor from enemies; with more plentiful encounters, and more deadly foes, this too is mandatory.  You earn a dash early on for greater mobility.  Where dash in the first game would have felt very liberating, the enemies in this sequel are far more aggressive, and once again you must use your new tool or die.

Combined, these two factors make DOOM Eternal feel very different from the first game.  In DOOM, I felt like I was exploring proper facilities or messy hellscape, rip-and-tearing whatever tried to oppose me.  I felt powerful, and the story was dense enough to feel meaningful.  In Eternal, the stages are larger, and the space between any story is as well.  Because of the more demanding and limiting combat, I no longer feel accomplished in battle.  With the game demanding you to perform certain functions just in order to survive, even my best of fights don't feel rewarding.  I don't enjoy any feeling of prowess, just an appreciation that I didn't expend too many resources.  Many levels feel like they're just room after room of fights, plus the mandatory collectables.

Again, I didn't include the positives as they are largely the same as the first game, which I am assuming the vast majority would have played prior to Eternal;.  While I favor the first game, DOOM Eternal is still very good, it's just not what I was expecting out of the sequel.  If you have any interest following DOOM, I'd recommend trying Eternal, but if you have not played the first game, you should definitely play DOOM first.

There was sooooo much hype surrounding this game. I'm incredibly disappointed. I wasn't expecting a copy of Doom 2016... But anyone who would even consider comparing this shitty arcade game to that masterpiece should be embarrassed. This would have been mind-blowing... On the original Xbox. Also, it honestly feels like work instead of fun. 0/10 would play again.

2016 was hard from the beginning too... But literally from the first, it was FUN. And I get that it's meant to be played a certain way, blah blah blah - it just feels like they went out of their way to make it impossible to play the game any OTHER way, aside from the specific, narrow, and repetitive one that they have in mind. This should be shameful for modern game developers - and is one of the bigger things that makes the game un-enjoyable. Give me more than one way to play, wtf - and fuck everyone who only ever used the super shotgun in 2016, leading the devs to think this would be a good idea.

Every death in 2016 felt excruciating but fair. Not one ever felt like a cheap death. In Eternal... It's unique NOT to get a "cheap" death, even "playing how it's meant to be played". Apologists will say this is part of the "learning curve", but I've probably been playing Doom since before a lot of them were born, lol. 

After 2016, I wasn't expecting a copy, but I was at LEAST hoping for another immersive experience. This truly and honestly feels like an arcade game, whereas 2016 felt like a legitimate, fully-developed, in-depth modern title. There is no immersion at all, the environments and game itself are cartooney, and nothing happening in front of me feels "natural", if that makes any sense. Also, I don't need to see a f---ing cutscene of a door opening, wtf!

The expanded story just feels forced; 2016 told a better story with seemingly 100% less material. Idk why these guys felt the need to fix what wasn't broken... But in doing so, they somehow turned the f-ing DOOM story into some weird "fantasy tale" and bolted it onto an action game. And the story itself is a huge disappointment, big step down from the how and what of the 2016 story.

I actually 100% agree with how much parkour is in this game; it makes sense considering the scale of the cliche-looking cartoon world pulled from 1998 that we're traversing. But from how much other forced bs I've seen in this game, I won't be surprised to see extra platforming be forced into gameplay later (as other reviews have mentioned). Also, environment objects are inconsistent - when am I gonna be able to ledge-grab, and when am I not? Who knows! More cheap deaths.

Or maybe I'll learn my lesson from these initial few stages and just stay away from the rest of this giant step backwards after the 2016 masterpiece.

If you came right out of DOOM (2016), you wouldn't expect how a shooter can get even more fast-paced. 

DOOM Eternal surpasses fast-paced. It's lightning-paced.

When you begin, you will constantly be starved out of ammo and often times health. They game tries its best to adjust the new pace to the player, yet sometimes it still takes longer than necessary. New mechanics are dropped on you within minutes and it can get overwhelming.

Having been a Doom fan since 1993 I awaited this title with trepidation and concern, wondering if it would live up to Doom (2016) a reboot I thought was an astonishing return to the series roots. I wasn't disappointed.

Graphics

The game is absolutely full of eye candy much like Doom 2016 but better. The environments are glorious. I found myself excited to get into each level to explore them and take it all in. Art direction is top notch and there is a very nice variation of themes in the levels. It's like Doom 2016 but everything looks a little better. Monsters have mostly been redesigned to resemble Doom and Doom 2's designs which as a long time fan I absolutely LOVE. My beloved Plasma Rifle has also had this treatment which I also love. Doom Eternal is wonderfully optimised, I have locked 60fps no matter how much absolute chaos is on screen and there is a LOT of that haha.

Sound

Not too much to say, like Doom 2016 in many ways which is to say brilliant. There's so many different sounds, monsters roaring, all manner of different weapons and explosions happening at once and yet you can discern it all, weapons are very punchy with brilliant bass usage. The music has had criticism from other players but I don't get that at all. I find the soundtrack is fantastic, crunching heavy rock riffs that get my blood pumping and some techno elements, it all fits well making every encounter seem epic. Which they are.

Gameplay

What can I say... I am dumbfounded by the quality of this games gunplay and balancing. Doom 2016 obviously brought us a new take on the classic Doom run and gun. Combat flowed brilliantly with all kinds of synergies between weapons and secondaries that led to some of the most fun combat in FPS history.

Doom Eternal refines this and distils it into what I can describe as chaotic perfection.

The synergy between your abilities, weapons, weapon secondaries, runes etc. work together in perfect harmony if you know what you're doing. Tactically utilising your flamer to get armour (or your upgraded Super Shotgun, what a game changer that is!), glory killing or blood punching for health (or using freeze grenade with right upgrades) and chainsaw for collecting ammo. Whilst your running around getting attacked by huge waves of demons it is extraordinarily satisfying to pull off your different techniques and utilise different weapons as needed. The game makes all of the weapons useful, and due to ammo constraints (which I will say are NOWAY near as bad as people make out, you can always get ammo if you play correctly), you have to switch quite often on the fly, certain enemies require certain guns and it just makes you feel....amazing as you rip and tear using all the arsenal available to you. I am blown away with how well made this game is and just how delightfully fun it is.

Another worthwhile mention is the Doom Fortress. You return here after each mission and you can unlock power ups here as well as practice with your guns, and take a breather before entering the next stage. Important when you've had a heart rate of 200 for the last hour xD

Story

It's good! There's actually a decent amount of exposition and lore for a Doom game, something I have always wanted a bit more of ever since reading the Doom 1993 manual back in the day. It isn't intrusive or slow, but it's enough to heighten your interest in what's happening. The codex is also great.

Overall score 9/10

DOOM 2016 was nothing short of a video gaming masterpiece, allowing you to become the Doomslayer to Rip and Tear like a blood thirsty god. Does Doom Eternal do the same?

Not quite, but that doesn't mean it isn't an incredible game

Short version: The new mechanics and increased difficulty caused by them does damnpen your feeling of being an indestructable god. But if you endure and adapt, you'll find plenty of carnage to unleash in the campaign!

However the servers are simply innexcusably poor; you lose connection constantly even with the numerous workarounds so multiplayer often is impossible.

Long Version:
Looks incredible with detailed and well designed environments

The Maps are fun to explore with plenty of unique battle grounds

The gameplay is where the issue is. The new options in combat add a layer of complexity to the previous games run-n-gun play, which can be very off putting to begin with. They work very well however once you get used to them.

Worst of all is the Marauder, the recurring mini-boss. Unless you cheese it by rockets to the feet or detonated mid air it requires stunning reaction times. It often pops up in the game and ruins perfectly good set pieces and you learn not to treat it as a priority target but instead as a chore.

Worser still is Bethesdas' servers. You will disconnect constantly even with the best internet in the world which means the multiplayer is often just unplayable even with various workarounds including fiddling with your router access.

All in all excusing the server issues and party pooper marauder, I recommend Doom Eternal as a challenging and visceral sequal to Doom 2016 due to plenty of content and great combat.

I originally wrote a positive review for Doom Eternal, having played 18 hours, after which point I had gotten to grips with the new mechanics.

Fast forward a lot more hours, and I am starting to dislike this game more and more.  Here is a short and very brief list of everything that I dislike about the game:

-  The dodge dashing allows for far too much movement, especially when you are in the air.  You can just dodge dash and double jump around the map, essentially kiting the demons behind you (unless the arena is small, and many of them are).  This means you spend more time running than you do gunning, especially on the harder difficulties.

-  The boss fights are trash compared to Doom 2016.  Not a single boss fight is an enjoyable experience.  The only one that is remotely enjoyable is the Doom Hunter, and that becomes a standard mob in the later levels.  The Gladiator is a boring fight, and the final boss, the Icon of Sin, is even worse.

-  The resource management is not necessary in the slightest in the single player mode.  I suspect that the devs were more interested in their PvP Battle Mode for the sake of eSports, that they shoehorned the same mechanics into the single player game (and this also applies to the double dash mechanic).  As a result, Doom 2016 is a far more enjoyable game to play, because you are not forced to lock into Glory Kill/Chainsaw animations as often.

-  The extra life mechanic feels like papering over the cracks.  When you play on Nightmare difficulty, you can die really easily, but what makes it worse, is that you can corner and body block yourself if your dash leaves you stuck in a corner.  This can result in a Hell Knight leaping at you (or a group of Imps), cornering you, and preventing you from escaping until you kill them.  To me, it feels like the devs added extra lives to the game, to compensate for the amount of times you die to their new mechanics, and rather than find a solid solution, they took the easy option, and then tried to sell it to the public as an innovative mechanic.  It isn't, it is just a crutch.

-  The story is very mediocre.  One of the bigger complaints regarding Doom 2016 was the lack of colour, given that it was set on Mars.  So the devs have created more colourful environments, at the expense of a decent plot.  You now have a fortress in space, that you teleport back to at the end of every mission.  This means you often have to visit different planets, and all to service an incredibly boring story (three Hell Priests are leading the invasion of Earth, kill all three and the invasion ends zzzzzzzz).  So you need to find locating devices to find them, and then you need to get a sword to kill a Titan etc, and it is all really boring and just an excuse to push you through a variety of different looking areas.  I liked the first game and the feeling that you start at one end of the facility, and work your way through until the end (with the occasional trip to Hell).  All in all, it just isn't as enjoyable (with the exception of a couple of levels).

-  The PvP mode has potential, but the training mode is extremely limited, and the actual matches leave very little room to actually learn as you play.  My first experience of it, I was playing as the Slayer, and got matched with a pair of Demons who were decent, but not great.  They beat me every match, but I started to improve to the point where I was winning rounds, and giving them a good run.  Sadly though, they left after 4-5 matches.  Then in my next match, despite being green as grass, I was matched against a pair of Demons who were 250+, and incredibly good and co-ordinated.  They wrecked me easily in every match we played (probably around 3), and I eventually quit, because I was dying too quickly to learn anything.  And when I queued again, I got matched against the same guys again.  As it turns out, they are actually very high level/pro players, and I was a complete noob.  So basically, the matchmaking is non-existent, which is probably why so few people are playing the PvP.

So yeah, I am giving this a thumbs down.  It just isn't as enjoyable an FPS as Doom 2016 is.  It feels like a game where the PvP was the priority, and the new mechanics were shoehorned into the single player mode (including the extremely boring platforming elements, to justify the new mobility).  

Ultimately, I would say, if you don't own the game already, buy it on sale.  It isn't worth the full asking price, and Doom 2016 is (in my opinion) a far superior FPS, and you can buy that very cheaply these days.  The PvP in Doom 2016 is better too (assuming people are still playing).

While not as good as Doom 2016, Eternal is still a fun game.

Doom 2016 I was not able to put down once I started playing. Eternal on the other hand takes a while before it starts to pull you in, and for the first two thirds of the game I didn't really feel like playing more than a mission a day. The final couple of missions however were very chaotic and fun, and reminded me more of the 2016 game.

The main problem is that things get a bit too complicated. You have to manage your ammo, certain enemies are only weak to certain weapons, there is more platforming involved, two types of grenades, a fire-thrower to refill armor, a powerful Blood Punch... I prefer the more run and gun style of the Doom 2016 over the more complicated (and harder) playstyle of Doom Eternal.

Some things like the grapple hook felt a bit like a pointless gimmick, however the Blood Punch (which is a powerful punch that one shots weak demons and deals a decent amount of damage to heavy ones) was a nice addition.

I don't think a lot of people play Doom for the multiplayer, which is good, because the Doom Eternal multiplayer is pure garbage. I actually enjoyed the Doom 2016 multiplayer, it just had too few players and too many cheaters. The Eternal multiplayer however, which is 1 Doomslayer vs 2 demons, is not fun. If the demons work well together, they almost always win. If they don't, the Doomslayer almost always wins. So if you plan to play solo then play as the Doomslayer and hope that you don't get matched up against a pair of demons on teamspeak.

Doom Eternal is a fun FPS game - just not as fun as its prequel. However, it's harder and more complicated, which I'm sure a lot of people will see as a good thing.

Either way: Thumbs up.

Amazing game.  Campaign [b]10/10[/b].  Multiplayer [b]7/10[/b].

Doom Eternal does what any great sequel should do; keeps everything great about the original and expands on it further with new content and mechanics.
For context, I played through Doom Eternal on Nightmare difficulty, and I’ll start by saying, the Slayer Gates, and many of the encounters throughout the game, gave me such an adrenaline rush after beating them that my hands would be shaking for 15 minutes afterwards.


[h1]Pros:[/h1]

[b]Movement and Abilities[/b]
The gameplay is fluid and in-depth, it balances platforming and arena FPS mechanics perfectly.  There are a lot of abilities to get the hang of, frag grenades, ice bomb, flame belch, glory kills, blood punching, crucible, weapon mods, weapon upgrades, runes, dashing, double jumping, jump-pads, teleporters, and monkey bar flips, but once you do master it, you feel like a badass.  For a casual gamer, this might be overwhelming, rather than a positive.

[b]Weapons[/b]
[list]
[*]All the weapons are useful and satisfying as well as most of the weapon mods.  I found myself favouring each weapon surprisingly equally.
[*]Weapons are able to be swapped quickly, allowing for some incredibly potent combos.
[*]Glory Kills feel amazing, ripping and tearing from one demon to another, and with the new Blood Punch mechanic, you can now straight up gib several enemies in one punch (Saitama approves).
[/list]

[b]Enemies[/b]
[list]
[*]Returning enemies and the new enemy additions are all fantastic, with each having unique mechanics, models, sound, and movement.
[*]The new weak point mechanic brings a whole new tactical element to disabling certain demons that is satisfying and rewards aim.
[*]Empowered demons are a cool way of bringing a soft multiplayer element.
[*]Every enemy can be defeated in multiple ways.  I never felt locked in to any one strategy, so combat felt very instinctual, doing whatever seemed the best in the moment.
[/list]

[b]Puzzles and Secrets[/b]
Even for someone like myself with limited patience for puzzles I managed to solve nearly all the main progression puzzles quickly and by myself.  As for collectibles and progression items, Doom Eternal incorporates them perfectly into gameplay.  Most only involve a simple puzzle in the same area they’re found (rarely any backtracking).  Best of all, is once you explore close to the area of a collectible it will become visible as a ‘?’ on the handy 3D map.  Lastly, once you near the end of a level you unlock the ability to fast travel to any section of the map.

[b]Graphics[/b]
You get several fleshed out and vastly different environments in Doom Eternal, Sentinel cityscapes, Hell Growth, Mars, Hell, and Makyr environments.  From a design perspective it’s almost unbelievable how many varied, optimised, quality assets they must have created for this game.  Throughout all the environments there are tons of easter eggs as well, and references to other Doom games (like the enemies infighting in the windows of the skyscrapers).

[b]Sound[/b]
The soundtrack is incredible as always and a large source of the adrenaline fuel.  I loved the build-up for the Doom Hunter, and the angelic but dissonant music for Urdak.  Sound effects and voice acting are all AAA quality as well, I never found myself lacking audio cues to understand what was going on during all the action.

[b]Story[/b]
The inclusion of more story and lore was, personally, very welcome, especially the Makyrs.  Doom Eternal kept the stoic, badass nature of the Doom Slayer intact while still fleshing out his backstory and the Doom universe’s backstory.  It has opened the gates for more story driven future Doom games.  It’s worth noting though that a lot of the lore and backstory is introduced through lengthy text, so if you’re not a fan of reading this might be annoying.

[b]Multiplayer[/b]
Battlemode is a 3-player mode with 2 buffed up demons up against a Slayer in a best of 3.  For the most part I've enjoyed the Battlemode multiplayer, when the matches are even it gives me the same adrenaline rushes that I found in the campaign.  To top it off, games have only taken 1-3 minutes to find and I’ve had very few problems with latency (from Australia).


[h1]Cons[/h1]

[b]Gameplay[/b]
[list]
[*]Blood Punching uses the same button as Glory Kills, so it's really easy to waste your Blood Punch on a preempted Glory Kill.  Also, you can still punch as a regular melee attack, but weirdly it does next to no damage at all, I would rather only be able to melee when Blood Punch is full than have Doom Guy feel weak.
[*]I would prefer if Glory Kills slowed time for enemies to prevent them from crowding the player while they're locked in the animation.
[*]The weapon point system is okay, but a lot of the weapon point upgrades (upgrades for the weapon mods) felt insignificant, and others felt more like the weapons were pre-nerfed and the upgrades then make the weapon mods usable rather than feel extra powerful (e.g. Mobile Turret or Arbalest mobility upgrades).  Not to mention this system adds to the already large list of RPG mechanics the player needs to learn.
[/list]

[b]Enemies[/b]
Marauders (despite how cool they are) and Buff Demons (from Buff Totems or Archvile Summons) are too “in your face”, I feel as if they needed to be toned down.

[b]Boss Battles[/b]
The final boss battle, [spoiler]the Icon of Sin[/spoiler], was more tedious than fun with hp sponge mechanics and annoying attacks, which are made harder to keep track of because of the enemy spam.  The [spoiler]Gladiator[/spoiler] boss battle was okay, but some of its attacks were a little strange for a brawler, especially the one where he’s trying to play jump-rope with Doomguy (you’ll understand when you see it).  The non-unique boss battles though were great, especially the Doom Hunter.

[b]Multiplayer[/b]
[list]
[*]With all the mobility, weapons, and combos I have access to as the Slayer the games tend to feel very unfair for the demons.  The demons also have the added complexity of being a duo, which is harder to coordinate than simply being the Slayer.  However, that said, I have run into demons that have completely wrecked me.
[*]The demon resurrection mechanic encourages running and hiding as a strategy after one demon dies, which doesn’t feel very demon-like.
[*]Even though there’s a demon tutorial, there’s still a lot to get the hang of, and those initial games can be rough against Slayers who have had the entire campaign to practice.
[/list]

[b]Bugs[/b] (as of July 2020)
Each bug required a restart from the most recent checkpoint.
[list]
[*][i]Invincible demons[/i]: Sometimes if you fail to outright kill, or glory kill, a staggered demon they will recover and become invincible.  I encountered this 4 times, and that was while trying to kill every staggered enemy to avoid the bug.
[*][i]Slayer Gate crashes[/i]: Can occur after completing a Slayer Gate, which is when you REALLY don’t want a crash to happen.  Happened to me twice, the first time it didn’t auto-save, the second time it did manage to auto-save.
[*][i]Unclearable encounters[/i]: Defeating all enemies in an encounter, yet it won’t be marked as completed.  Happened to me once.
[/list]
Hopefully, in time, these bugs will be patched (Covid may have slowed this process down).


It would be easy to think after reading the cons, “why still give the game 10/10”, and it’s simple, the game is just THAT good.  It’s rare to play a game where even losing feels good and leaves you with a smile, but when everything works (which is 99% of the time), that’s exactly what Doom Eternal does.
This game is amazing.

It's DOOM. I cut my teeth on the 4 3.5" discs in the early nineties, listening to "Black Sunshine" while strafe-rocketing Barons of Hell. This evolution requires a little more thought when it comes to playstyle, and I don't begrudge it at all. No growth means death (also no movement!). Heartily endorse this!

Doom Eternal lacks the mechanical purity that was present in Doom 2016. I just want to shoot demons, not have to cycle my weapons 6 times and be forced to chainsaw on cooldown because there's never enough ammo. Even pinging weak points near perfectly, enemies are still bullet sponges on Nightmare. This wouldn't be so bad if punch actually did damage, but it doesn't unless you have Blood Punch charged up. Punch is incredibly frustrating because of this if you've spent the kind of time in Doom 2016 that I have.

I just want to kill demons. I don't like combat decisions being forced because my resources are so arbitrarily limited.

All in all, Doom Eternal was a frustrating experience that I will not be returning to. After I completed the game, it was promptly uninstalled since there's no further reason to keep the game installed. No custom levels, no mod support, no SnapMap. Meanwhile, after all this time, I still play Doom 2016.

In my opinion, Doom Eternal was a colossal disappointment not worthy of being called Doom. I just want to kill demons without all of the extra fluff they added. It was not needed.

Doom Eternal starts off slow, but the detail and complexity ramps up with your passion for beating the living shit out of every demon put before your omnipresence, flying through the sky only to rip off their limbs and chop off the heads of their superiors for the vitriol of a fired up revenge brought with fury to the doorstep of humanity and eventually for the fall of a seeding sin rampant beneath it. Place your wallet above your restraints and lay waste to those who sought to destroy the final semblance of nature left unfettered, your armada of guns, armor and their respective upgrades as but a fading echo of what all once prospered. 

Cons:
-Denuvo (GONE NOW)
-Performance inconsistencies on the first few levels, staying the same even with dynamic resolution scaling

Future changes that would improve:
-Agnostic Path/Ray tracing that can utilize AMD hardware
-Native Linux Support (Not necessary, but would be a nice gesture)
-Deathmatch normals

Lots of options to tweak in the settings. Some much appreciated quality of life improvements, for example you don't die when you fall off a level. You just take some damage and return to where you fell off. I don't really understand the point of having the basic melee punch. It does next to no damage, so little. I guess you need it for punching walls and such but eh... Could've given it a tad more dmg. This game is a bit more hectic and challenging compared to DOOM (2016). You need to manage your resources. I like the platforming too, I've always liked platformers so it's nice to see some more platforming in an FPS game. Eternal runs very well, it's well optimised. I'm playing at 1080p on Ultra Nightmare gfx (except water quality which is on Nightmare) at 100 FOV. It runs smoothly, 100-170 FPS most of the time with occasional dips down to <100 FPS. I've encountered some crashes which is a shame. Once after completing a slayer gate and once all of a sudden during a level.

Great OST, perhaps even better than DOOM 2016's. I just wish it came to Spotify :/. I hope they add some multiplayer modes as there's only battlemode and they also left out SnapMap which was cool in DOOM 2016. But they did make just about enough improvements and additions to the campaign to make up for the lost features. I love the attention to detail. You can collect vinyl records and spot Doomguy's rabbit "Daisy" in each level, there's lots of references to pop culture (music, literature, etc.). This game is addictive and makes me smile :).

GOTY 2020 contender. 9/10 (rating liable to change as I play the game).

[h1] Innovative gameplay but lacks heart [/h1]

TL:DR It's a fun game for people that like fast paced shooters but they lost a lot of what made Doom 2016 great.

OK, lets starts with pros and cons:

[b] Pros [/b]
[list]
[*]Enemy weak points
[*]Fast paced action sequences
[*]Beautiful scenery and backdrops
[*]Variety of enemies
[*]Skins that showed during gameplay
[*]Expanded story line
[*]They brought back the Tyrant
[*]Sound design
[/list]

[b] Cons [/b]
[list]
[*]Lack of atmosphere
[*]Hand holding (Weak points, Runes, Mastery)
[*]Shoehorned plot points
[*]Platforming
[*]Overwhelming enemies
[*]Extra lives
[*]Overuse of flesh
[/list]

Let me start by saying this review applies just to the campaign and it may change after the DLC is released. 

There was a defining moment in Doom 2016 where I had to stop playing because of a very visceral reaction I had to the environment. I was walking on guts and became nauseous. I knew then they nailed the ambiance of the game. Doom E tries this but there are a couple things that ruin the flow and take the player out of the Hellscape. 

A few things I liked while playing that made me say "that's cool" were the enemy weak points, backround scenery, interactive environments, and skins that showed up during gory kills/cut scenes. The fast paced combat with periods of rest between reminded me of the feels I got playing Halo CE for the first time. All of this made for engaging gameplay that made my palms sweaty. I enjoyed it until I started noticing the little things that broke the aesthetic of the game.

Every time a new enemy appears a pop-up appears telling you its weak points and how to kill it. Early on it breaks the flow (cause it's a pop-up) and later it breaks flow again cause you're focusing on trying to kill something according to developer design. Some may appreciate this but I felt it takes away from the 'jump in and shoot it til it dies' mentality.

Skull switch shrines were metal. in D2016 there was a sense that a body had been destroyed and the skull made to be that switch. The imagery of it being encased in bones means hell didn't waste any part of the body. A metal skull shrine might as well be a light switch.

There's flesh everywhere and it gets boring quick. Its just piles of flesh, not bodies, just mounds of flesh. If there are no human remains there's no sense there was a human population being massacred. The first game nailed this by putting ribcages, femurs, spinal cords, and other body parts in the flesh shrines scattered throughout the UAC. Also in D2016 you had to rib off limbs for fingerprint ID door scans and use a dead guys face for retinal ID. 

I could go on but all these little things take away from the sense of a real catastrophe that the slayer is fighting against. Doom 2016 was up there with the original Bioshock in they both nailed that environment/gameplay/story/lore balance. Both of those games made me not want to put the controller down. I had high hopes that this game would do the same but in the end I was just playing to get through it and not really enjoying the game. 

P.S. You can get a sense of what I mean by simply watching the credits of both Doom games and asking yourself how each one feels.

Doom Eternal is an fantastic example of a perfectly balanced combat system in an fps game where with a little practice you can enter a state of flow being able to mow down demons in a stellar coordinated dance of shooting demons, switching weapons, dashing, punching and jumping. 
If you are an experienced FPS player you WILL absolutely love the way Doom Eternal plays on the highest difficulty. Once you learn how to use each weapon on each demon and understand a few key mechanics such as quickswitching to avoid cooldowns and keeping movement going nothing will be able to stop you.

The game rewards players for taking risks by getting in close with demons to replenish ammo, health and armour. It does this by introducing new combat and movement mechanics to raise the skill-ceiling on top of the already stellar Doom (2016). The dash is a much appreciated mechanic increasing the pacing of the game and allowing players to traverse the arenas in a much more interesting way. Getting in close with the shotgun and dashing out again, flame belching and nading on a group of small fodder replenishing armour etc. It also introduces weak points on enemies rewarding players for using specific weapons against certain demons, decreasing TTK and allowing you to kill more demons faster.

Overall, if you enjoy FPS games and want a challenge I highly recommend Doom Eternal. Once you learn the ropes of the game you will find yourself coming back every now and then to enjoy a true challenge of FPS skill

The "bloat" of a man cave, wothless XP system for unlocking stuff for a multi player I will never touch just irritated me. What also irritated me was the infamous Marauder. A very overtuned enemy I think they designed soley to flirt with the elitist "git gud" minority. Playing on normal (Hurt Me Pently) and had learned the combat somewhat good, still winning some fights by the skin of my teeth, the Marauder just presented me with a wall of death that I did not enjoy in the slightest. 57 times I died before managing to bruteforce my way thru the fight. Did I feel euphoric when I finally beat him? Not in the slightest, I was just annoyed. I do not enjoy sadistic difficlty spikes, even if it fits the theme of batteling hell itself.

But all in all, it's a really good game that's sometimes trying a bit too hard. Still think Doom 2016 is the better game thou.

Probably best singleplayer FPS game of all time

DOOM Eternal has been by far one of the best single-player FPS experiences I had a chance to engage with.
Frantic murder-fest with surprising amount of depth and strategy to it. The game required me to, pardon the phrasing, "git gud" to a degree where I had to shed some of the bad habits that other FPSes allowed me to get away with (like still selecting the weapons from weapon wheel), and yet it never felt unfair - every death was due to my oversight and complacency.

The multi-player part, I can't comment on, as for me it's been completely broken since release - I could not connect to any matches, matchmaking kept hanging indefinitely, and the like.
I should specify here, I use Linux as my main operating system, and I don't dual-boot, thus I can't say how much of that is due to my OS of choice, and how much of that is multi-player being broken. If you're looking at titles to play with others, there are likely better titles out there, but I personally didn't lament it that much; my interest was strictly in single-player portion.

A word of caution:

With Update 1, id Software has snuck an invasive kernel-level anti-cheat into the game, but has done so in such manner that none of the Linux users were able to access the game at all - not just the multiplayer component, but [b]anything[/b].
Update 1.1 has removed the anti-cheat following feedback, but keep in mind it [i]might[/i] happen again, and if you've non-standard machine, or play on Linux, or if you just don't want invasive software with unlimited permissions snooping on your system, you might not be able to play the game any more.

As for now, if you're looking for good single-player shooter experience that will push you and your skills to improve, I can recommend DOOM Eternal wholeheartedly. If you're more of a casual shooter player, or are going for multiplayer scene, you might want to look to other titles.

[h1]Spoiler-free review[/h1]

DOOM Eternal is the best game I've ever played. Period. It's the most fun I've ever had playing a video game. Ever. It's a game that you immediately want to pick up and play again right after you stop playing. Everything is just right. The gameplay is fluid. The graphics are quite possibly the best video game graphics to date. The soundtrack is outstanding. The story is captivating. And then, there's the combat... The combat is brutal, relentless, intense, tough, challenging, and uncompromising, but never unfair. If there's a particular combat encounter you're struggling with, you always know what you're doing wrong, and what you have to do to achieve victory instead.

There's also something deeply satisfying about DOOM Eternal's retro, old-school, and manly presentation. Mick Gordon's heavy metal soundtrack is essential. Sound effects like audio prompts, equipment/chainsaw, powerups, and glory kills, etc. are all top-notch and sound crisp and punchy with a strong sense of machismo. I personally love the "low ammo" prompt sound while firing the rocket launcher, ballista, or super shotgun. The weapons look great and have this satisfying mechanical/manual feel and sound to them. From over the top glory kills, gorgeous hellscapes, a self-aware story that never takes itself too seriously, to collectibles such as toy figurines, floppy disk cheat codes, and vinyl LPs of past id Software soundtracks, this game is an absolute joy to behold and experience.

DOOM Eternal is a game that genuinely respects your skill as a player, but expects it from you in return. It constantly challenges you to become a better player. It is intuitive enough to adapt to your personal playstyle while you master all the mechanics. Basically, DOOM Eternal gives you all the tools to feel like the ultimate badass, but puts you to the test to become one.

id Software went all-in with the DOOM 2016 formula by further improving all aspects of what was an already stellar FPS experience. DOOM 2016 was intense, but DOOM Eternal is on another level of intense. The result is a game that is bigger, better, faster, and stronger than its predecessor, making DOOM Eternal one of the best, if not the best, FPS game. This game is pure gold. It sets a new standard for the FPS genre that few titles may ever dream of reaching. A masterpiece in every sense of the word and a must-play for any gamer.

[h1]Score: 10/10[/h1]

Doom Eternal is one of the great gems of this entire gaming generation. When I got back into PC gaming this game was at the top of my list. In my humble opinion Doom Eternal is so far 2020's game of the year. It is a modern day classic. 

2016 is a fantastic game as well.
You play as a character who is literally too angry to die in a game with almost perfect movement. 10/10

DOOM Eternal is quite literally the best single player FPS to date (coming from a long time Halo fan). It's much faster paced than 2016, and much more challenging (but for the better).

+ The game is best played on nightmare, and many of the new additions spice up the combat enough to make the game highly re-playable.

+ There's no micro-transaction BS, you're getting a complete game. 

+ The game will kick your a** at first, but provided you persevere and master the combat loop, the game becomes much more manageable. There is a high skill ceiling which is often lacking in other shooter campaigns!

+ Level design is great, and there's plenty of hidden secrets to find.

+ Plenty of extra side missions to do, namely the secret encounters and slayer gates. The slayer gates will make your heart pound like crazy!

+ All the weapons are better than ever, and they all have a purpose (which was a key issue in 2016, as once you picked up the bigger guns, there wasn't much incentive to use the starting weapons again.

+ The soundtrack is f***ing amazing! It's a shame Mick Gordon wont be returning as he has composed some of the best tracks for both DOOM 2016 and Eternal. I can't imagine how the next game will cope without Mick as the composer.

+ Battlemode is fun and very intense, although it's not for everyone.

Most of the negativity comes from people who don't want an engaging combat system and are content with just a generic mindless system (as is the case with the COD stories). The complaints about the marauder and some other demons being too hard are baffling, as the game literally tells you how to defeat them!

The reduced ammo count and the enemy weak-points system forces the player to better manage their resources and learn to weapon/ mod switch on the fly. Quick decision making/ reflexes on the higher difficulties is important. Some hate the changes, and prefer to just spam the super shotgun throughout the entire game (like in 2016), however these changes make the game much more engaging, which sets the game apart from others in the genre. Instead of learning to play, some just jump to the typical (this doesn't feel like a DOOM game) train, when in fact they are simply bad and want to blame the game instead of accepting they just need to get better!

- A few minor bugs here and there, but not experienced anything game breaking.

- Blood punch can be inconsistent, which can get you killed quickly as some of the tankier demons punish you in mere milliseconds!


All in all, a must play for serious FPS fans! Cannot wait for DLC and the new master levels...

review:
I've been wondering how to phrase this to properly express my experience with Doom Eternal. On one hand it's basically an okay game, with some great visuals, great soundtrack, fine selection of glory kills and the gory, bloody, pinnicle to the pit atmosphere that we all know and love. The carving out of the revamped Doom univers is also interresting, albeit a bit overly convoluted. Hell is bad, earth is bad and heaven... is also bad? 

However, there are so many details that made my journey through this game more annoying and aggitating than entertaining and enjoyable. Most important of all: WHY AM I STARVING FOR AMMO ALL THE TIME!?
I found myself low or out of ammo on most guns after most encounters of larger groups. I am aware that the chainsaw is there for the low ammo situations but for some reason Doom (2016) balanced the amount of ammo and the need for the chainsaw perfectly, never leaving me with the feeling of truly running out. In Doom Eternal I did actually run out of ammo, several times especially during the early stages, where I would be down to nothing but the chainsaw. Now in theory this is probably how it was meant to be but while the game is ment to be fast paced and you should constantly be moving, it should be because you are actually running away from the demons trying desperately to find a scrap of ammo or some chainsaw fuel. This took a lot of the fun out of the encounters I had enjoyed so very much in Doom (2016). Despite constantly dashing and double jumping I was constantly being hit, dropping my hp and armor so low that it forced me to get into a glory kill to save my life, which did give me some health back but also sent another barrage of hits my way, dropping me low yet again, feeding the vicious cycle. It only add insult to injury that the team that designed the fighting areas do not seem to have communicated with the people designing the monsters and encounters, at all. Once you become fully upgraded, however, things do improve, slightly. 

I played though this game out of sheer spite in the end. I completed my run on the "Hurt me plenty" difficulty as I though it would be challenging enough to be entertaining but doable enough so I would have to waste too much time doing encounters over and over again. I like to game for the story and experience more so than the actually top shelf challenge. But this difficulty proved fitting at times and then just unbalanced at others. During an encounter I found myself boxed into a corner by a Cacodemon and another (think it was a hell knight plus some cannonfodder demons) and I was stuck there getting pounded into a bloody pulp. This happened only a few times but it was still enough to annoy me. I don't remember this happening in Doom (2016). As mentioned before that fact that you get hit all the time just seems weird. In the story they specifically mention that the slayer is faster than demons, so why I can not outrun the damage? I never expected to finish a fight without a scratch but this just seems broken. Especially the Hell Knight and their variants seem perticularly difficult to avoid taking damage from. 

The platforming elements of the game were generally fairly well done, with some minor non-sensical decisions made along the way. Wether this element fits into a Doom game is subjective, but apart from that, the platforming and "base" elements are fairly well done. 

Oh, before I forget: Fu*k the Marauders. These are some of the more challenging enemies in the game, but from my experience, this is more due to some weird design choices than actual difficulty. The range which triggeres the attack didn't seem consistant and most of the time it would shimmer from side to side, making targeting very tricky. The first one you meet is doable, since it's only that one with some feeder demons for health and ammo options, but later on you'll meet these bastards alongside other powerful demons, sometimes reducing your chances of winning the battle to random chance. These guys can corner you as well, so there's that. The Gladiator also seems to have some range anormalities, but maybe that one was just me. 

I should mention that Cyberdemons are a delight to fight in this game. I enjoyed those encounters as they felt more like what the game should have been overall. 

Overall I found myself more frustrated at the above mentioned designs and executions than enjoying myself, which is the bottom line for the negative score. There are so many small annoyances in this game that it simply shatteres the good aspects. If you haven't played Doom (2016) then Doom Eternal will be an okay game, but if you ride on the wave of Doom (2016) you may end up disappointed.

Actually, on further reflection. This is not an okay game. Bethesda, with it's recources and experience, not to mention that all the had to do was build upon Doom (2016), should have done better. This is bad, Bethesda, bad.

And by the way Bethesda, if you are going to make a challenge for "left side" glory kills, how about you make a "left side" glory kill mechanic that actually works?
Fuggin DOOM, play it now.

review:
For me this was meh. I had fun, and appreciate how hard it was, but it never sucked me in the way Doom 2016 did. It wasn't immersive at all, constantly hitting you over the head with the fact that its a video game. The difficulty can be summed up as MOAR DEMONS = HARD, and I didn't really care for the fact that every enemy had a specific weakness that you are more or less forced to exploit to survive on higher difficulties. Some levels were beautiful, and others were over the top, yet somehow cliche and generic all at once. The music was lackluster this time around, and the pacing feels tedious more often than not. The platforming was especially annoying and out of place, further removing you from immersion. 

TLDR  Doom 2016 was Death Metal, Doom Eternal is Metal Mario.   The best part of this game is playing original Doom 1 and 2 on your Doom castle pc. 6/10 for me, and I choose not to recommend it mostly to offset the plethora of fanboys ignoring it's many issues and saying you don't like it because you need to "git gud"

[b]Update:[/b]
I recommend this game to everyone searching for great, fast and challenging single-player shooters. One of the best of the last decades. 
Just make sure that the kernel-level anti-cheat is still removed and never comes back please.. (See my previous review for this)

[b]Before anti-cheat removal:[/b]

First of all, it´s a great Game.. Doom-Slaying at its finest.. 
[i] Now straight for the – I guess recently obvious – “but(t)”: [/i]

I uninstalled right after the new “Update1”-Patch because of the newly introduced [b] Kernel-Level-Anti-Cheat [/b] for a game that is probably mostly enjoyed as a single-player experience. (Preventing Linux-Systems to run this at all) Well OK, maybe the new multi-player modes and experience will be great, but that's not where my personal focus goes to with the Doom-Series.
I will not install a major potential security flaw onto my system – granting kernel-system wide access to anything attached or running on my PC – only for a game (or any entertainment software) to be played – even if the risk could be low. That, in fact, should be a "big no-no" for almost any software out there. Even if it is potentially "only" active while the game is running – unlike RIOT-Games “PC-startup-time always running Spyware”.. There is no guaranty that even software especially made for security purposes is unflawed and completely risk-free. This stuff is already made for cheat detection – hence spying at least into my active processes. Even if this is handled with care, or thoroughly reviewed, the potential harm compared to its use is nothing I'll personally agree to.

This shouldn't be a direction that the games marked should be heading to. A game should never need that deep level of access onto a system. Hopefully this trend will not be continued and picked up by every new game now. One day this will likely fail, resulting in potential complete loss of control and all of your data – traded for a few hours of fun you had playing.

Sadly I wouldn't have bought this game if this would have been clearly stated from the beginning and not introduced as an afterthought.

Sorry for the little rant. Just be aware of the potential risk if you don't have a dedicated “gaming machine” or your network stores reachable private data. Otherwise, like I said in the beginning, it's still a great game. If the “potential risks” are acceptable.. go for it.

developer_response:
Greetings!

We are sorry to hear that your experience with Doom: Eternal was not a positive one. 

If you are struggling to complete objectives in Doom, the best mode to play on is I'm Too Young to Die (Easy mode). You should also take advantage of the chainsaw to ensure you have a steady supply of ammo. Spending weapon points immediately is also a good idea.

Doom is a beloved series and our devs strive to create quality content, including story content, for all our games, Doom especially. We value our player's opinions and encourage you to submit any and all feedback via a feedback ticket at help.bethesda.net/ so that our devs might understand how our game could better match the experience you are looking for.

Thank you for taking the time to review our game in such detail and we hope you will give Doom: Eternal another shot.

Best,
Bethesda Customer Support

review:
If you liked DOOM 2016 because it let you rip and tear however you wanted to, this game isn't what you're looking for.

If all you want is is MORE of everything, maybe this is what you're after. Just be careful what you wish for. 

I can't recommend this game to anyone. The story is incoherent, the game-play loop forces you to play how the devs want you to, and there are entirely too many equipment buttons to manage in combat. 

One of the worst sins of this game is that the BFG and Unmakyr are in the normal scroll/auto-change weapon loop so in late-game you'll frequently find yourself wasting valuable BFG ammo. The devs wanted the Crucible to be the new hotness but honestly its just a reskinned DOOM 2016 chainsaw. At least the D16 chainsaw was fun to use as an oh-shit button occasionally, the Crucible is such a boring tool its not even worth using.

I'm glad I got this game on sale. Consider buying on a DEEP discount.
developer_response:
Greetings!

We're sorry to hear that your experience with Doom: Eternal has not been a positive one.

Our devs strive to create quality story, combat, and game play but we value our player's opinions too. We encourage you to submit any and all feedback at help.bethesda.net so that we can better understand how our games might fit the experience you are looking for.

Thank you for taking the time to review our game and we hope you will give Doom: Eternal another shot.

Best,
Bethesda Customer Support

I waited it out and bought the game when it finally went on sale.  It's just an amazing game that any FPS fan would be thrilled to have in their library.  I am still somewhat early in the game, but there is much more offered in this version than past games.  The fighting is amazing, the music and intensity is out of this world.  Don't be afraid to wait for it to go on sale again before you buy, but when it does, don't hesitate.

By the way, I just read some reviews and saw some complaints about the parkour sections.  Personally, I love them.  I thoroughly enjoy getting some "rest" in between the bloodbaths, and the parkour works nicely for that.  It is fun to use combinations of your double-jump and dash, while jumping from cliffs or on bars.  I can absolutely see why it would be annoying to some though, especially because the ones I've done thus far are not that easy, and I am pretty good at them overall.  But, if you like that stuff as I do, then you will enjoy those parts because they are challenging and test your skills.

Also, I have to mention the improvement to the map.  I just love it and every game should use a map like this for FPS.  You are actually a 3D character on the map, not just a triangle, and they make it extremely easy to see where you are and operate the map smoothly.  It is tremendous to have a map system that is very useful and I have to call it out because they clearly put some time and effort into helping the player have a good sense of where he is and where he needs to get to.  It also helps with finding secrets and special items as well.

DOOM Eternal expanded on what DOOM 2016 (already a great game) brought in 2016.

The story as well as the new lore concerning the Doom Slayer are fascinating.

Combat and movement have noticeably evolved since the last game. Every weapon and its respective mod now has a use; proper use of your grenades is essential. They've developed combat in a way that you never have to leave the fight (for health, ammunition or armour) if you use your tools correctly.

Glory kills are even more brutal & bloody (didn't think it was possible).

Good performance does require a modern computer. I was playing on medium (with some low settings) with my Zotac GTX 970 that I bought 5-6 years ago.

Bethesda did a great job on this one! Especially recommended if you enjoyed DOOM 2016 and you're already familiar with its story and characters.

Doom Eternal review – no-frills, endless thrills.

To start off, this game is definitely not for everyone. Some don't want to be strategic at all in their gameplay. Some just want to go crazy and obliterate every demon in sight with little to no effort.

But for the right people, this game is freaking INCREDIBLE. And I am one of those people.

There isn't any other game where most arguments can mostly just be boiled down to "Get Good" just as much as this one. Because that's just the reality of this game. It's hard. And some people just aren't as dedicated to get better at the game as others. But if you learn to master its systems, like faltering, all the weapons and their mods, resource management, and other tactics, then you'll overcome the demons. And that's probably the most important thing about this game's power fantasy. It doesn't just straight up grant you the power fantasy, because there isn't any satisfaction from that.

You have to earn the power fantasy this time. And that's what I love about DOOM Eternal.
Every mechanic in this game is useful in its own way. Some other reviewer on YouTube said something similar, but think about it this way: A wide variety of ways to kill things in a fps game isn't that great if said ways don't really have their own purpose other than to just kill things in any situation. It'll feel overwhelming.

But in DOOM Eternal's case, every mechanic has its own use. Weapons are damage dealers, and certain weapons are better for certain situations. Like how Hugo Martin said himself, the demons are your problems. Your weapons and other equipment are your tools to solving these problems. You use your chainsaw if you're running low on ammo, or to get invincibility frames so you can catch a breather from all the action. You can also use the moments of downtime from a glory kill or a chainsaw kill to check your resources. The flame belch is used on groups of enemies for armor if you're running low on that. You can stagger demons in order to glory kill them, which drops plenty of health. Grenades are useful for lots of crowd control damage or faltering large targets, which gives you openings to attack them. Ice bombs freeze enemies for moments of downtime if you're cornered or need a quick breather.

Dashing is an amazing mechanic. It allows you to dodge projectiles and just general attacks with more ease. Blood punch is good for a large group of fodder, or to chain into combos on really heavy demons. There's also the weapon mods and their uses. But I don't want to stretch this review to the length of the Bible, so I won't talk about those.

Also, I'm not sure how people are always complaining about the platforming. It's fun and kind of jaw dropping, considering the distances you travel in the platforming sections.

If you don't use the mechanics effectively, stand still, or make tons of mistakes in your gameplay, then the demons will definitely maul you, especially on higher difficulties.

The marauder, while still difficult in his own right, really isn't that bad. And by now, I would think most people would get it. Stand far away from him, dodge his axe throw, let him run towards you. After he swings his axe, dodge the swing and shoot him with a Super Shotgun + Ballista + Super Shotgun combo. Or the other way around. Repeat this, and it'll make it easy to take him out.

Anyway, I don't want to keep stretching out this review, so I'll reiterate: This game isn't for everyone. But if you like fast-paced gameplay with tons of useful mechanics to keep in mind for every situation, tons of secrets and collectibles, fun platforming sections and one of the greatest power fantasies of gaming (which you have to earn, btw), then you'll love DOOM Eternal.

I could call Doom Eternal an enhancement of DOOM 2016, but they're practically different games. Doom Eternal feels very arcadey and has much more diverse locales and enemies than DOOM 2016. Gone is the pee shooter pistol. The Super Shotgun now has a "meathook" grappling attachment. The gause cannon is replaced by a Ballista. The Doom lore is expanded upon. The multiplayer is 2vs1, with two Demons battling one Slayer. Glory kill for health, chainsaw for ammo, and flame for armor. Crap loads of unlockables! I like both DOOM 2016 and Doom Eternal, but for different reasons.

Best game I've played in a damn long time. GOTY. Fuck the multiplayer though, pretend it doesn't exist

[h1]DOOM: Eternal[/h1]

[h1]"Warning: the Slayer has entered the facility."[/h1]

[h1]Introduction:[/h1]
Nah Nah Nah. I'm telling you right now that DOOM: Eternal is by far a sequel done right and pumped up by 1000x notches. You thought DOOM (2016) was great? Well, then you haven't played DOOM: Eternal yet. All these people complaining about how the game is no longer DOOM or how they are forced to play a certain style have literally no idea what they are talking about and are just chatting nonsense. Because Eternal does everything that DOOM (2016) did right and increases it. You get new demons to fight. You get MORE demons to fight. You get new weapons and killing machines to play with. You get a classic DOOM experience in modern gameplay.  

[h1]The Story:[/h1]
DOOM: Eternal is set two years after the events of DOOM. (2016) The armies of Hell had begun their conquest of Earth and are slowly overruning Earth's Military powers. On the first day, 60% of the human population had been wiped out. The UAC from the previous game has now become a technological cult that worships the powers of Hell. (Traitors to mankind) But unknowingly to them. The DOOM Slayer has been watching from his flying fortress in outer space, he is now ready to kill some old and new demons once again. 

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
● Stunning graphics
● Achievements
● Steam trading cards
● Collectibles and Secrets
● Very well optimized [b](By far the best-optimized game since Gears of War 5. Lots of graphical options and impressive performance. Was playing at a mix of high-ultra and was able to keep a framerate of 140-150. Even in big areas with lots of enemies.)[/b]

● Gameplay on crack [b](Gameplay has been improved by a huge margin. You now have a shoulder-mounted grenade launcher, flamethrower, and even an arm blade. You can now dash as well as double jump and trust me. This changes the movement flow so much. You still have your classic weapons from DOOM (2016) but with new functions like the pump shotgun now has a Gatling barrel installed.)[/b]

● New demons [b](Classic demons from older games with new looks as well as totally new demons are here. The remains of the Spider Mastermind had given life to the nimble Arachnotron. The abhorrent Pain Elemental is here to mess up your day. The DOOM Hunter has been designed to hunt you and only you down and my favorite of the bunch. The menacing Arch-Vile is back and bigger/bad-As*er than ever. This is just a small list because there is a ton of more demons for you to kill.)[/b]

● Classic Demon design [b](Existing Demons like the Mancubus, Cyberdemon, and Cacodemon have been given their original design look from the classic DOOM games and if you ask me. They look awesome and more akin to who they were meant to represent. DOOM fans will love it.)[/b]

● More brutal glory kills [b](You think that DOOM (2016) had brutal glory kills? Well, then you haven't played Eternal. I literally witnessed Doomguy pick up a b*tch and throw her in the air and slice her down on the way. Some of them are funny too lol. Like the time when Doomguy pushes the Arachnatron upside down. Or when he kicks the Arch-Vile down on his butt.)[/b]

● Impressive gore [b](You can now see the damage you do to enemies in real-time. Such as skin coming off or bone being exposed. It's a brutal mess and I love it!)[/b]

● Classic weapon design [b](Weapons like the Plasma rifle have been given their classic design look from the original DOOM games. Combined that with the new sound effect and it is so much fun to use!)[/b]

● Plentiful of gameplay options [b](From the ability to play in classic weapon pose to the ability to change your HUD style or even having a simple thing like hitmakers. DOOM: Eternal has it all.)[/b]

● Super Shotgun improvement [b](One might ask. How can you improve the Super Shotgun? How about the addition of a meat hook that allows you to perform a quick trip around an enemy or the ability to get up close and personal?)[/b]

● More chainsaw action [b](Some people will say this is bad because one now has to constantly use the chainsaw in order to get ammo but honestly? I like this change. I almost never saw myself using the chainsaw in DOOM (2016) because there was ammo around every corner. It became really a last-ditch weapon that was a very rare use. But now I tend to use it a lot more since there will always be enough fuel to kill a weakling.)[/b]

● More demons per encounter [b](Remember VEGA Core level in DOOM? (2016) Yea Eternal is like that entire level. The game is no longer scared to throw you harder demons and more of them per encounter. You will face the Cyberdemon, DOOM Hunter, and Marauder multiple times throughout the game. Sometimes even two at once. Beautiful change.)[/b]

● Master levels [b](Only two levels exist but there needs to be more. If you're looking for an even bigger challenge then master levels are it. You will be able to replay an existing level but the demon spawns are completely changed. In a location where you might have founded a Hellknight you will now find a Baron of Hell and so on.)[/b]

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
● Arch-Vile solid spawns [b](Arch-Viles can spawn enemies when they are in the field being the Demon sorcerer and all. I have no problem with that. I have a problem with their spawn outline. You see when they are beginning the spawning of an enemy wherever it is a Mancubus, Pinky, or even a Baron. There is a red outline hologram style of thing to indicate that he is spawning that enemy. Yea that thing is solid meaning that you cannot pass through it. Why the f*ck is that a thing? The demon isn't spawned yet so why can't I pass through it? If he spawns one in front of you and one behind you then you're fu*ked.)[/b]

● Shotgun ammo [b](With all of the upgrades the shotgun can only carry 24 shells. A really dumb decision if you ask me. You should be able to carry 30-50 shells and not a measly 24.)[/b]

● Steam overlay [b](I had to disable the Steam overlay in order to be able to play the game. I got no idea how this went unnoticed. I use the Steam overlay every day and having to turn it off in order to get the game to work was really annoying. It has been 3 weeks and there still isn't a patch to this. Not a good look ID.)[/b]

● Soundtrack [b](The soundtrack was barely active throughout the game. I don't know what it was but it was kind of lame. The only soundtrack during combat that I heard without a problem was "The only thing they fear is you" the rest of the soundtracks there was almost no presence off. It really felt odd, especially since DOOM (2016) had such a beautiful soundtrack. The Eternal soundtrack, on the other hand, is barely memorable or adrenaline pumping.)[/b]

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
If you're looking for an action-packed game that will get your testosterone up and running then this is the game for you. I see a lot of people complaining about how the game forces you to play a certain style but honestly it doesn't. A common complaint was that you need certain weapons to kill certain enemies. The shielded enemy for an example. That was also a thing in DOOM. (2016) You can easily use a single weapon throughout the entire game. You're not forced to use weapons you don't want. The same applies to the glory kills, shoulder-mounted flamethrower, and grenade launcher. They are all optional. People say that the game is slower. I got no idea what they are smoking. Eternal is 10x faster than DOOM (2016) with the addition of all of the new movement fluidity options. Some people will say the game is harder and it might be at first but once you start using everything given to you. You will feel like a God. The DOOM Hunter? More like a waste of metal. The Mauruder? What a p*ssy, he drops faster than the Greek economy. This is a sequel done right by passionate developers. Buy it now and feel what it is like to be the DOOM Slayer!

[h1]Overall rating 10/10[/h1]

DOOM Eternal is a beautiful FPS game that follows up on almost all of the things that DOOM 2016 did so right. This game improves the experience in many ways, such as more diverse locations for the levels (DOOM 2016 only really featured two different locations, as where DOOM Eternal features idk maybe 5-6 different locations that you explore during your demon rampaging).

This game looks and sounds amazing, although the OST did not feel as powerful compared to DOOM 2016. I read somewhere that Mick Gordon didn't perform the music on time so ID Software had to make due in other ways. Which is a shame since the Mick Gordon OST from DOOM 2016 was a big reason so many picked up the DOOM franchise once again. This does not mean that the DOOM Eternal OST is bad in any way. It's not just as good as it might've been,

As mentioned - the game features several locations with different themes ranging from snowy mountains, a green futuristic eutopia and to the deepest layers of burning hell. DOOM Eternal hosts more varying demons and almost everyone feels like they belong in the arenas. The Marauder is a really dope enemy that can send wolfs at you, shoot you with a shotgun, throw an axe at you and BLOCK every fucking attack that you throw at him UNLESS you counter him during one of his attacks which only is available if you stand at a precise distance from him. He was interesting the first time around when you fought him in a boss encounter type of way - but became dull and for me broke the general gameplay loop that DOOM lives upon. Instead of keeping on the move you are forced to more or less stand still in the accurate range and wait for him to do an attack which you can counter. Maybe they should have used the enemy less, and in a more powerful way instead of throwing him in every fucking encounter for the latter part of the game...

All of the models look great and I still can't grasp how ID Software managed to compress it to 42GB, something that otherwise is getting rather ridiculous... Looking at you GTA V, RDR2, COD. I think they are releasing new content for DOOM Eternal, but I live under a rock so I don't really know about that. Anyway that will most probably be rather pricy - which the base game already is when it's on retail. So my recommendation is to pick up DOOM Eternal on sale, as I don't really like the €59.99 meta of AAA games...

Every mistake from the first Doom amplified by ten fold. Sure, its great killing the Demons and figuring out the weaknesses and the weapons but there are so many game pace interruptions.  Platforming brought to an annoyance level. you don't feel any impact upon clearing a highly infested area like before.  The smallest piece of terrain will stop your movements and flow of fighting. They also definitely tried to capitalize on the bright and shiny neon fad that is ruining games right now. All in all about a 5/10.

review:
If you liked Doom (2016), skip this one. Rip & tear is gone, replaced by constantly trying to juggle health, armor, and ammo replenishment, while also trying to master all the fighting combos. Pretty much every other aspect (story, exploration, unlockable extras) is present but made worse in some way.

I got as far as the mid-game boss battle, the Marauder, when after I just barely beat him, the game crashed. I give up.
