review:
Good fun game apart from the awful parkour / jumping puzzles. Absolutely suck balls. Who on earth thought all those stupid jumping puzzles was a good idea? Ruined a good game. This is a FPS shooter not Mario World.

Update after 20 hours play: This game needs a lot of patience to play if you are not used to platformers. It is NOT a straightforward FPS and much harder than Doom 2016. After a LOT of practice the jumping puzzles are do-able but the puzzles towards the end of the game really tested my patience. To make matters worse I'm getting random crash to desktops more frequently on the last mission of the game. 

Now to make matters worse, you need the meat hook ability on your shotgun to defeat the final boss. This never worked during the game which wasn't an issue but the game cannot be completed if this does not work. Doing a bit of googling reveals its a known bug and restarting your game from the beginning is the only fix. Well good job guys. A game I can't finish due to a game breaking bug.

If you suck at platforming games such as Mario (Tomb raider games are much easier than this) I'd stay clear or buy it on budget.
incredible single player game, the price is worth it and if you love destroying things well then this is the game for you

DOOM Eternal makes DOOM 2016 seem like a game for toddlers. It's faster, harder and better. There are however complaints which I find overdramatic and strange: "This is not DOOM 2016", "No ammo for anything" or "Game restricts how you play". There are hints of truth in every complaint of course, but only if you do not look at the whole picture.

PROS

- Story is actually good. While I liked DOOM 2016 because it was straight forward and did not care much about the story, I found myself more engaged in it this time around. This also means there are more cutscenes and dialogue, but most of the story is actually told in codex pages. Basically, for those who do not care, they can skip it all, but lore enthusiasts will be satisfied as well.

- Gameplay could not have been better. I have always hated playing shooters on harder difficulties, because that would warrant abandoning your balls for the sake of taking cover every second. Here, it is more organic with the movement system of dashing, jumping sprinting around the arena. Every weapon matters and moreso after unlocking certain mods.as enemies require you to use specific ones to take advantage of their weak spots. I do not understand why this is a bad thing for some people. Instead of "restricting your playstyle", it is more about using your entire arsenal to achieve victory. This is certainly better than using supershotgun to solve everything.  Grenades are actually useful this time around with the option to switch to freeze grenades as well. I thought freeze grenades would be overpowered, but they are balanced by the high cooldown. The game also encourages you to use gory kills for health and chainsaw enemies to replenish your ammo, which, in fact, trivializes the need of ammo. There are always fodder demon around to chainsaw which allows you to use heavy weapons more frequently. There is also the flame belch for dropping armor. The mixture of all these elements is what makes this game great. I cannot stress enough how fun and satisfying it is to go through a master level on nightmare difficulty.

- Soundtrack is as good as expected. Nothing I can say that has not been said about it

- There are so many meaningful upgrades and collectibles to go through. Weapon mods, suit upgrades, runes, batteries, mastery tokens, and dolls, music albums, cheat codes and even skins. The most important thing is that they are all meaningful. They grant the player something instead of a counter of how many of them you actually have.

- Performance and graphics are fantastic. Levels have way more variety and incredible aesthetic. Especially [spoiler] Urdak [/spoiler]. Levels load incredibly fast is unreal. it takes me 2-3 seconds to respawn after death on an nvme SSD. The game is incredibly optimized and I had no issues with the PC port.

- Master levels which are harder versions of campaign levels, are well designed and do not feel unfair to the player. Granted they are only for those who seek extra challenge. I am only disappointed that there are only two so far, but more of them are on the way.

- Goddamn slayer gates.

MIXED

- Platforming is actually fun but I understand it is not for everyone. I like it but it would be better if it was less gamey and instead, implemented more organically in the level.

- Story, while great, does not give you context unless you read codex pages. Many people prefer the story being told directly, but that would also alienate those who do not give a crap about it. There is also a gap between 2016 and eternal that is not fully explored. I did not mind the way it was told, but it is worth mentioning.

- I could not care less about the multiplayer. I did not even bother launching it.

- Bosses. There aren't that many but, some of them are fun and some of them are frustrating. Your mileage may vary.
 
CONS

- Invisible walls are prevalent, which is odd in a game that encourages platforming and exploration.

- Some levels have narrow corridors of death which do not mesh well with the freedom in the movement system. There is one section in the first level that I am sure everyone found annoying.

- Challenge gates are hit or miss. They are uneven in difficulty and can be frustrating.

- Mission challenges, especially directional glory kills ones, are annoying to do. I had to repeat many sections to just to complete them because an enemy would not stagger or I would not trigger the right one. Luckily there are only a handful of them unlike DOOM 2016.

- The crucible feels floaty and buggy. I am not sure if it is the same for everyone but I died a couple of times because it would not work as expected.

Overall, I highly recommend it for shooter fans. Most of my complaints are really small and do not hurt the incredible gameplay of this highly polished title. I cannot wait to experience the future of this game.

Doom eternal... One of the best games ever made hands down. There are a few blunders that happened early on, however ID were able to quickly deal with the minor inconveniences. I think The game is a straight upgrade to doom 2016 in every way imaginable. Some people don't like the skill that may be required for some parts of the game. I wouldn't let this subtract from the experience as any game that is set-up around high skill play will usually act as a gateway for some of the worse players to help them improve. Team fortress 2 Is another game that requires a decent amount of skill to succeed in and it's also a game I have over 2000 hours in... I bring this up because TF2 is a great example of a game that has a high skill ceiling by focusing on the making the core mechanics of the game revolve around objective skill, (aiming, movement, etc.) And mind-games or Subjective skill which will change depending on what you are against and who you are against. TF2 Uses this as an anchor point to build off of very similarly as to how ID has done with doom eternal. Now what I just stated may seem like it would only apply to battle mode but it applies to the campaign as well. Yes you are up against AI, however the AI can be exploited all be it in different ways than predicting humans. The AI will always be easier to predict than a human, (with modern technology anyway.) Therefore leaving the skill on the mind games part a bit lower for the campaign but that's only because the game is trying to be a gateway game where low skilled players can go to train and hone there skills in things that will assist them not only in doom eternal. This is a great game to use as both movement and aim practice... Now for those of you who will point out the very specific way I have worded things to avoid the controversies (up until this point anyway) I would like to state my stances here and now: The anti-cheat was lazy on ID's part, The marauder is way easier than People make him out to be, (I beet him first try on nightmare difficulty even to my own surprise) and the music being removed from Youtube wasn't ID's doing and I am more or less mildly concerned but I stand with ID on their confusion. I will not be updating this review (at least I have no plans on it) so more information or content/updates may be released that cancel out what I have said. With all of that done good day and good luck for your next endeavour.

It's no DOOM 2016. It's obviously made for a younger generation of DOOM fans, and that's okay. 

It has more mechanics but less depth and doesn't really succeed at sucking you into its world. Levels feel like a greatest hits compilation more than a connected, lived-in world (despite Eternal never really leaning into abstract level design). Overall, it's totally worth a buy but curb your expectations.

Doom Eternal is the Improved version of 2016’s Doom 

Pros

- Improved gameplay
- Great story
- Challenging difficulty
- Decent platforming
- Focused movement ex. Meathook
- A lot of collectibles 
- Fun cheat codes
- Great graphics
- Amazing soundtrack like previous game
- Well-done sound effects
- Decent optimization
- If you pre ordered you get Doom 64 for free

Cons 

- Marauder and Doom Hunter boss fights are overused
- Battlemode is not fun like 2016’s MP
- Game can randomly crash
[b]"You can't just shoot a hole into the surface of Mars." [/b]

Weird and different, almost unique Doom game. You won't be able to just shoot your enemies with your gun in this one. The game isn't a typical shooter at all. There is mandatory melee combat which provides you with resource generation such as health and ammo, such as 'glory kills' melee attack providing health and chainsaw melee attack providing ammo or blood punch charged constantly by glory kills taking down a huge amount of health of bullet sponge enemies and even a sword one shotting any trash mob. Some of those existed in the previous Doom title too but it wasn't mandatory to use them at all, on the other hand this one is a mandatory resource management game and the combat is a lot more fast paced and way more challenging. I totally loved it except that the final boss was a little too hard. If you are ready to a new FPS design you will find it here.
BUY IT !
If you liked 2016 this is better 10x. Action, lore, and death await you in the pits.

It's a good Doom game, a damn good sequel to Doom 1, 2, and 64. It might not be a great sequel to Doom 2016.

Certainly the best aspect of this game is the mechanics. The movement and combat are both superb and satisfying as hell. There hasn't been a Doom game that has pressured me this much since Plutonia on Ultra Violence. There hasn't been a Quake game that's pressured me this much since Quake 3 / Live. Nightmare mode on Doom Eternal is just... awesome. Couldn't praise the gameplay enough.

Doom 2016 felt like industrial metal, there were obvious signs of torture and death everywhere. This game has glimpses of that, but feels more like a heavy metal comic book than a violent graphic novel.

Do I love it? Yes.
Did I want more Doom 2016 and less Doom II: Hell on Earth? Yes.

I guess, as a classic Doom fan, I couldn't ask for a better mainline Doom game than this. Simply making Doom 64 canon was one of the best decisions Id could have made. I love what they've done with the story in terms of the content itself... Still though, there are aspects of Doom 2016's storytelling, music, and atmosphere that are lost with this game. I was more immersed in Doom 2016 because they made a real effort to never take the player out of first person. This game does away with that, for better and for worse depending on which cutscenes you're talking about.

The fact that I feel like I am nitpicking, rather than providing worthwhile criticism, makes this game well above most shooters, and most video games in general.

Doom Eternal is my game of the year unless Cyberpunk 2077 blows it off of that pedestal and spits on it like trash. That is how high I think of Doom Eternal. As the legend Reggie Fils-Aime said "if its not fun, why play it?". 

This game is beyond fun. The gameplay expands on from Doom 2016 in a such a way that makes Doom 2016 feel outdated when I went to go play it back just to see how it feels and it feels archaic with how the movement and gunplay has evolved from one game to another. The glory kill system from the last game is back and more brutal than before, the guns are more dynamic than before, like the plasma gun is actually usable now than before. Everything is just better in this game.

The graphics are beautiful, the environments are detailed and tells a visable story as to what happened to earth and the hellification the planet is going through.

Now the story is what has improved the most from Doom 2016. While Doom 2016 had a story it wasn't mindblowing, it was decent and usable for the game but Doom Eternal blowed that out of the park. The Story expands on everything that was placed in Doom 2016, answering some questions while adding more. The worldbuilding of this game is fantastic, I was hooked reading every codex learning about the world that Doom Guy inhabits.

Overall, this is my game of the year. It blows everything out of the park of what I expected for this game. Id Software has done a great job with this game and cannot wait for the next Doom game and will see how they expand upon the greatness that is Doom eternal

mäh, it is so hard for me to leave a negative review on this game.
I am "doom player" from day one (basically) and enjoyed every title in the whole series.
With DOOM Reboot from 2016 as a definite highlight I was really keen on DOOM Eternal.

And man, the first few seconds feel instant great, super nice gun feedback, swift movement, smashing and slicing the first few lesser beings from hell... and yet, it strted very soon to feel kind of odd what was done to the game.
First thing noticed was this "arena" charakter of the maps where you need to kill a given number of mobs to proceed and then it got even worse with those unholy and super anoying jumping b/s in the maps.

DOOM is not a platformer, was not and will hopefully never ever be again. jump-dash-dash, fall start all over.
Kinde suxx right after the first encounter.
Sorry, maybe I am alone with my massive dislike on this game mechanic, but when I play DOOM, I want to godlike cut-and-slice demons and blow freaking body limbs apart and not "Mario-esk" jump from one floating platform to the next - fail miserably a dozen times and redo all the level from the beginning.

he fighting itself is still DOOM, sure, fast paced and un-forgiving - which I am perfectly fine with.
Also the new Ammo-Management makes it realyl tough sometimes and you fail because in the middle of a fight you end up all empty.... sure, not well enough planed and executed, I love to start over for that purpose.
but falling into lava after miss-timed dash-jump-dash-combo? Ah no, thank you.

review:
Looking for a game with an over powered, angry protagonist in green power armour that isn't halo?
Then this is the game for you.

Oh boy, CAN YOU TELL this is a sequel. [strike] I guess the game is good if you wanted more "refined?" bullet hell than was in the first, but the story from the last game feels like it has nothing to do with this one. The only real hints I have that the games are even related is the occasional mention in a codex (log) entry, aside from that the game looks completely different (daemons ,weapons, and items are 3d Doom2esqu models). There are a lot of codex entries... [/strike]

I've found a little plot twist I forgot from the first game but I still find the dramatic style change from D 2016 to D Eternal odd to say the least.

Edit after playthrough:

I may be a little harsh on this game but please understand that it's out of disappointment, I had no expectations really until I finished D 2016. "Oh boy, there's more, and gritty epic story to boot" followed by "Did... did they piss off the development team?". Perhaps like I said in the comments, my complaints stem from the shock of immediately playing D Eternal after D 2016. In an effort to refine what I mean between the two games I have made a list.

Doom 4:
- Brutal Doomesque
- super intense game
- epic music
- Doom Slayer feels alot slower than Doom Guy
- cool guns n mods
- bit of a power trip
- funky platforming moments but it works
- silly barrels wont stop moving (they don't believe in the law of entropy)
- edgy scifi atmosphere
- rough around the edges mysteriousish story
- cool looking Daemons
- pretty maps
- linear game feel
- little to no enemies sneaking up on you
- why are all weapon slots moved down one, I know the chainsaw is special but god damn why is it G!? (the nerves in my fingers don't understand, it's changeable though)

Doom 5:
- Brutal Doomesque
- super-ultra intense game
- epic music
- Doom Slayer feels even slower because all of Hell wants a hug! Projectiles out pace you
- guns n mods you WILL need to survive
- that power trip is gone, there is only pain
- platforming is a special mechanic required in order to progress
- annoying platforming puzzles, to death metal, right after an adrenaline rush, required in order to progress
- everything feels bright. I don't remember a single shadowy corner, even in hell
- some super brutal moments (don't read codex as you get if you don't want spoilers)
- kinda cool maps, I liked them. Not the platforming that ruined it
- encounters are visible on the map and you are locked in the room the moment fighting starts
- why are the weapon moved down two slots!? The pistol would be silly in this though
- bugs. I found three or so abnormalities that seemed like apart of the game, like a duplicate Doom Slayer mapped to my mouse and being able to unlock cosmetic items with energy cells I had already used (If you open any door with them and restart the Doom Fortress hub level you'll have unlocked the item while not having opened the door or used any cells)
- maps are incredibly linear. You'll never get lost, even in hell, because green lights
- only 3 monsters in total bigger than basic zombies tried to attack without indicators the whole game (nothing is sneaky in the least, the Caco is the quietest I think)
- it feels like a none stop slaughter fest, little to no real pauses, every new fight starts to feel like the same grind even with new enemies to deal with
- secrets don't feel all that secret (alot glow green, have a giant question mark, or they didn't even bother obstructing your path to the secret), because of this upgrades are no problem
- everything feels like it's spoon fed to you. Between the green lights, the cut and pasted interactable environmental platforms (climbing walls, and monkey bars in bizarre places that stick out like sore thumbs), the notifications that you're about to meet a new enemy types (I could have turned it off come to find out) and how to beat it, the game feels babyish. Doom 2016 felt so much more like each corner was unique. In this if you die enough they even ask if you want to use special armor to make things easier.

Now after all that I'm willing to say D Eternal feels like the stronger of the two gameplay (action) wise (not the puzzles, fuck the puzzles). That's hard to say because I haven't beaten it and I'm stuck at the second to last boss and I may not try to finish without help (I'm on Ultra Violent but since 08/08/2020 I found a way to beat the game). I just wont call D Eternal an FPS any more, that's left in the realm of D 2016, this is a bullet hell platformer.

P.s.: I can not however, forgive either game for dumbing down the Lost Souls. They will only attack one at a time...

TLDR and Conclusion:
I guess if you look at "all" the Doom games after Doom 2, ID is playing with the feel of the Doom theme. Doom 3 is all creepy dark and Doom 4/5 are all brutal, back in 1993 Doom was both of these in one package. I wont say lazy (lazy) I'd say an experiment that was catered toward people who require constant input/reward, silly little easy things to complete in order to feel motivated and interested. I don't know who's cute idea it was to make the whole game/the fate of earth about climbing walls, monkey bars, and obnoxious glowing green interactables but I feel they did it thinking anything more complicated looking would scare people away. I understand now, but my heart still felt broken when I started. Other than that, I found I enjoyed the game and the story is okayish kinda i guess. Keep in mind, I got this for $35. I'm glad but I almost wish I could go back to, the Before Time, when I still thought D Eternal was cool and I still had $35...

ps: After some thought, what's impressed me is how the story outright doesn't change anything. ID's original idea of the Doom Guy being something people project onto remains despite the Doom Slayer. review: This game is, impossibly, even better than DOOM 2016. The controls are even tighter, the weapons are more awesome, the demons are updated to be even more insane, and the overall mood of the game is more goofy and over the top. The combat is so fine tuned to perfection that I don't even know how they could top it in the next game. The in between combat gameplay is what really stands out as better, as it is much more engaging. If you played 2016 and said the loop was too repetitive but enjoyed the concept and gameplay, get this because it fixes that, The new mechanics are also really well integrated, like the new dash and the chainsaw. Plus there is an incredible level of content, during the first playthrough and after it. Easily worth the 60$, this is a must have.

review: Sinceramente me encanto el DOOM Eternal, un juegazo

After 28 hours of gameplay, I can without a doubt say that this game is one of, if not, the best FPS games I have ever played. I have a lot of praise, and some complaints as well. I'll start with the soundtrack. Doom Eternal's soundtrack is a step up from Doom 2016's soundtrack, and includes some returning songs. I feel like I am an unstoppable force while listening to the music and slaughtering demons left and right. Mick Gordon was spot-on with these songs, and really hypes me up for more fun. 
     Secondly, visual art and overall style of the game. Doom Eternal looks leagues better than Doom 2016, and I can't get over the level design. It just looks amazing. The levels feel like they are a part of the Doom universe, and I love every inch of it!
     Gameplay is also better than the previous game. The Arenas give you so much more room to move around and use each ability and weapon to their highest potential. Platforming is a great addition to the game and helps add to how each map feels.
     As for complaints, I think the Unmayker is a bit underwhelming. It was originally a gun you could upgrade into a beast of a weapon, but in Eternal it feels weak, and the BFG is just a better option when it comes to the two.
     Overall the game is a 9.5/10 for me, and I would definitely play this game again! Great job ID!

As a fan of Doom in general, this game very much excited me.
I played DOOM 2016 for a little bit but found it very slow paced vs Doom 1993 and other mods for it,
This game was very much appreciated for someone like me who loves fast paced combat and lots of things to micromanage. The goods of this game weigh out the few bad things. Amazing soundtrack, semi interesting story and amazing gunplay. The bad things are when my cloud saves got wiped, I lost my 100% nightmare save, my 1-UP Nightmare run and my Doom Level I earned over 50 hours. The only other bad thing is the game feels SUPER SLOW in the beginning without dashing or weaponry. Losing my saves is sorta why I haven't picked it back up until when The Ancient Gods comes out. Very much recommend this
Great game, concept and drama. The game was fun and hard but not frustratingly hard; it was creatively hard. I am glad I got the season's pass and I am looking forward to the new content.

I'll keep this short:

When there's action DOOM is at it's best. When the action is gone, the game becomes surprisingly boring. Sadly DOOM Eternal get's boring a bit too often.

They upped the Ultra Violence difficulty. That's a good thing. The marauder fights though.. are annoying.. they basically 2 shot you. Are completely untouchable unless they do their special attack which they only engage when you are at the right distance. They are also bullet sponges. All this would be fine.. if the arena's where you fight them give you the space to avoid their near constant barrage of attacks. But half the marauder fights are in dead end narrow lanes making the experience at best frustrating and not fun and challenging. 

So why the recommendation? When DOOM Eternal does it's DOOM thing it's so addictive. And when you beat that room filled with enemies (no more ultra low spawn limit!!) you feel like a god that just did a super human feat. And that makes it worth dealing with the boring platforming and annoying boss fights.

A brutal, lightning-fast FPS that will beat you to a pulp if you don't use absolutely everything you're given, which can feel like a frustrating mess if you're coming from DOOM '16s much more lenient combat & resource management systems, but overcoming that obstacle and learning how to fight turns this into one of the most satisfying & complex FPS games that has ever been made.
The need to constantly manage resources, figure out an attack plan on whatever demons are clawing at you & execute that plan, moving around the arena at a blistering pace is an amazing rush that makes every victory feel earned (whereas '16 was quite simplistic & after a certain point became rather stale with its limited range of tools), & the movement capacity makes the game at its top level feel silky smooth to get around. 
The game could definitely cut back on the unskippable cutscenes for stuff like doors opening, or at least an option to disable it as it makes reruns a little annoying constantly taking the control away, but it's a generally minor complaint. There's also a bunch of story stuff but it's a DOOM game so who cares, it's not a story oriented game we're here to rip up everything in the way.

This game is perfect. Literally. What are you waiting for? buy it and enjoy yourself for hours and hours.

I feel like I grew up with video games - my first system was an Atari in Europe, then I played various games on other systems like Nintendo, SEGA Genesis, etc... until I got my first PC and played everything from Prince of Persia, Commander Keen, Eye of the Beholder, Wolfenstein, and

of course, I played Doom. I remember being so young that I just felt like "beating the game" was the goal. So, I did not feel compelled to replay the game and moved on. I tried playing Doom II and other sequels, but felt like Quake was where it was at with the multiplayer and re-playability, not to mention the 3d graphics. Also, I can't say I was happy with Doom 3 and didn't finish.

Everything changed with Doom 2016. I am so happy I gave it a shot and thought it was the best game at that time. It had everything I was looking for; it was simple (no 50 things to keep track of and man do I dislike "crafting," it's just not for me to learn encyclopedic knowledge of a game for marginal benefit - or grinding). I honestly thought it was the best game.

Then, Doom Eternal came out.

Hands down, the best game I have ever played. 
It is ideal - I can put it down and come back weeks later and not feel like I'm lost in the story. It's fast and beautiful, every little thing is rewarding - and there is lots of humor and Easter Eggs. At this point, I've gone back and gotten every secret, and am only short of finishing at Ultra-Nightmare, having put Nightmare behind me in an epic couple of weeks. 

I feel like Doom Eternal is punishing in how challenging it is, but going back to missions where I had the most trouble after the fact I am surprised at how clean I play. I can't imagine a better system that is fair and balanced, and that's why I love this game. 

Absolutely recommend it, especially if you love First Person Shooters. 

Please make more updates with new levels and more story.
So i started Ripping And Tearing

The "No" here is namely considered against a full AAA price and up against Doom 2016.

Doom Eternal does accomplish, in gameplay, the very specific objectives it set out to achieve: creating a "Doom Dance" of evasion, resource management, and offense that gets ever-more complicated as time goes on. But overall, the combat portion becomes outright repetitive quickly as you are *required* to approach every single fight using nearly every single weapon and trick. Gameplay is reduced to two major modes: combat arenas and platforming sections. Most combat arenas start blurring together as "the same" since the vast majority of enemies are reduced to "exploit weak point/weapon weakness". The only change to this is Marauders and Archviles/runes, which just alter the cadence of the Doom Dance. The combat portion of gameplay tends to rob a player of freer carnage than the predecessor. The platforming bits contribute to convoluted level design aesthetics that feel much more in place with a Metroid Prime game (where an obstacle appears for no other reason than the developer wanted say...a climbing wall health hazard obstacle) as opposed to a Half-Life game (where an obstacle felt like a consequence of the natural environment).

And then there's the story. It's...dull, inconsistent, and much more ham-fisted than its predecessor. You are directed by and exposited to on a near-constant basis. You are told by the opening narration to rip and tear, but the very character who delivered that command tells you to be cautious. Major elements show up with zero introduction, assuming that you collected codex pages or read supplemental material. A major villain goes full Bond Bad Guy with both exposition and manner of attempting to stop you. Just to prove the laziness of story-writing and gameplay design on display, the Phobos/BFG10K level introduction plays out exactly like the trailer released last year. Sounds great. Except the game gave you a plasma rifle a few levels prior...so there's absolutely zero reason for the Slayer to take a plasma rifle from the UAC trooper except because it was part of the demo.

Looking back at developer comments and "crunch time" coupled with release delay, I can deduce that a number of major management failures occurred during development that id and Bethesda really ought to work on before attempting a third title in the Doom revival series.

And this boils down to the thesis: Doom Eternal is not a BAD game, by any means. But it is an inferior game to Doom 2016 and I would recommend waiting for a Steam sale rather than pay full price.

I haven't done multiplayer yet at all, and I don't have many plans to so this review is focused entirely on the single player campaign.

This is a worthy successor to Doom 2016. If you liked that game, you'll like this too. There's more of the same great movement and combat mechanics here, fighting in and navigating through the levels is a joy. Upgrading your armor, weapons and abilities is back as well with a few tweaks, but they work well and the sense of progression you feel here is really well done. There's new movement possibilities compared to Doom 2016, including swinging from bars, and climbing along certain textured walls which both feel really satisfying. The game is just as gory as its predecessor, so be aware of that if you're sensitive to that but if you can get past the gore, it's a lot of fun throughout. I haven't finished yet as of writing this but I'm looking forward to finishing the campaign soon.
One of my favorite games from one of my favorite franchises. Amazing gameplay (imo better than 2016), amazing visuals and good story/lore (some don't like story, but I do).

The first hour of playtime I was really sceptical about the play style change, comparing it to Doom 2016, as Eternal included multiple changes to gameplay, which can no longer lead to plowing through demons with the same favourite weapon. however it has grown on me. Even though there will be people that enjoy more straightforward and classic gameplay as Doom 2016 was, this is a fine addition to Doom games.

The game has bunch of additional game mechanics, involving one's movement as well as available arsenal of weapons. And another change that's been emphasized is variety of enemies, that will force you to think about your offensive as well as defensive approach to any situation (this is especially prominent in higher game difficulties).  I can understand some people wanting more simplistic gameplay (and also less story telling), but for me I feel like Id Software and Hugo Martin did an excelled job in modernizing the series with additional mechanics, as well as bringing back the old enemies to the game, such as the Archville (well, at least for 3 seconds, until you delete it with the crucible)

An absolutely frantic, adrenaline ride of FPS action.  The exploration is good, platforming is fun, and lots of exploration to do once the game is over.  Nightmare difficulty is possibly one of the most difficult things I have ever tried in a game-- but I'm not exactly a Demon Souls player.  

I have played every doom game since they came out.  The original Doom was iconic, Doom II was more of the same fun-- they got more interesting, more realistic, and ventured into different territory over the years, from survival horror in Doom 3 to the Doom (2016) and Eternal playstyles we have now.

SPOILER:
I honestly think that the last boss was... easy; in comparison to random encounters throughout the game, surrounded by mobs that pick you off for the smallest mistakes.  This isn't a bad thing, I think it was sufficiently fun, and kind of an epic fight, but definitely not the hardest thing you have to do in the game, just a long, drawn-out culmination of using your best movement, chainsaw, keep the little guys at bay while you hack way at the boss.

Great fun, would absolutely recommend to anyone not concerned with an OVERT amount of blood and violence.

At first glance a nice game with nice elements. However, there is no catchy storyline and everything is the same from start to finish. Stupid shooting seems like the only goal, but finding hidden rooms and items is challenging! For those who like that and make no further demands, this might be a great game.

Since everything is the same, it gets very boring halfway through so I no longer enjoy the gameplay. As a result, you simply sit down and shoot to finish the game as quickly as possible.

The gameplay also offers a number of options to improve your performance and skins, but given the monotonous nature of the game and the boredom that it causes, it is not a challenge for me to work on it any longer. In short, for me a game that you play once and then never again.

I would say this game is an 8/10, with Doom 2016 being a 9/10 for comparison. I would describe the tone difference from Doom 2016 to Doom Eternal as the difference between Gears of War 1 and Gears of War 3.


What was fantastic:

- Doomguy/Slayer is the single angriest and most brutal character in gaming; Kratos has nothing on this guy. He gets a really fleshed out back story and it is truly epic. They really focused in on his history and craft some truly badass story elements in the collectible texts. This is the ultimate machismo power fantasy.

- The graphics are optimized to perfection. My rig is pretty beefy with a couple aging components at this point, and this game runs smooth as butter with all the bells and whistles on.

- Gorgeous environments and set pieces invoke games like God of War, Halo, and Gears of War. There are things that, when I saw them for the first time, made be think "Wow, what's the story behind that?"

- The Doom Fortress is one of the best, if not the best, hubs in gaming history. Some of my favorites are the Hunter's Dream in Bloodborne, the three hubs in Starcraft 2, and Firelink Shrine of the Souls series. Doom Fortress rivals them all, being large enough to explore but not so large it's a hassle to navigate. The various collectibles you gather are put on display, allowing you to view them and associated models up close, and play music tracks for records you discover. Doomguy has a man-cave with a portrait of him and the only living creature he's ever truly loved. Doom Fortress also contains some skins and powerups you can unlock with energy cells you collect in game.

- The original Doom and Doom 2 are available to play in full after meeting their unlock requirements, with isolated progression saves so you can pick up where you leave off at any point.

- The lore overall is pretty well fleshed-out. Has the occasional inconsistency, but very clearly a lot of time was put into expanding on a lot of aspects of the story.

- The glory kill variety has been increased, and there are some truly satisfying things you can pull off.


What was serviceable:

- The combat is a bit different this time around, I would describe it as the Diablo 3 of FPSes; it's extremely fast paced and you're lambasted and inundated with enemies to chew through -constantly-. Not many true boss fights or slower points for you to appreciate the impact of combat. Your enemies have targeted weak spots that will benefit you greatly if you prioritize over just pumping lead into them. Targeting these areas will weaken them greatly and likely save your skin a few times, as well as expedite killing them. It's combined with a new emphasis on certain enemies being weak to specific weapon types. It's a nifty enough idea, but not one that was probably necessary. I really enjoyed the gun play in Doom 2016, and trying to force specific combat behavior out of the player doesn't really add anything to the game in my opinion. It's enjoyable, but did take a little getting used to initially and became a little monotonous due to the sheer volume of combat by the end.

- There's a much greater emphasis on platforming in Doom Eternal than there was in Doom 2016. It functions well enough I guess, but again, probably isn't providing anything additive to the experience. It's a feature which I would describe as just being okay.

- The music is more of the same from Doom 2016. It gets you amped up to fight with some more orchestral pieces to emphasize the tone of certain moments. 


What was disappointing:

- There's not enough ammo to accommodate the aggressive gameplay the game encourages. As I mentioned earlier, there is more emphasis on strategy here, and part of that is having to ensure you're using your ammo extremely efficiently. It wasn't impossible or difficult to manage, I just felt like I'd been unnecessarily gimped most of the time.

- There are a couple of really cool moments where you get to fire particularly giant guns, but rather than allowing the player to do it, it's just a brief cinematic. It's still cool to see, but really would have benefited from at least letting the player pull the trigger rather than take control away for 15-30 seconds.

- There is a new enemy type, the Marauder. Marauders didn't ruin the game, just the flow (pacing and play style) of combat. They require you to follow sweet-spot-range and perry mechanics while simultaneously being thrown into a clusterfuck of other demons to micromanage. They're designed to take priority during combat or harass you with more aggression than other demons, effectively acting as add-management mini bosses during each encounter after the first. They are manageable once you learn them, but they're the only enemy that complex in the game for some reason. Because if that, they really feel out of place. I think they would have fit better if they weren't the only enemy this demanding, with other enemies requiring specific/skilled strategy to dispatch at that level (sans Soulsbornekiro). Here, the Marauder is in a league of its own, an apex opponent that doesn't have any peers as a point of reference when it is absent. This is to say, it sticks out above the rest of the fodder a little -too- much. I think it would have been better either as an isolated mini boss every time (as in the first encounter), or as one type amongst other similarly advanced enemies.

- The last two boss fights almost ruined the game for me (spoilers). 

+ The Khan Maykr fight requires you to use Blood Punch after chaining up to her, and I frequently found my Blood Punch bugging out and missing her even though I was straight up in her hitbox. 

+ The Icon of Sin... Was just a let down. It's more or less just an add-management fight, in which you blast parts of its body off in between fighting the infinitely spawning demons rushing you. The Icon of Sin just feels like a bullet sponge prop you occasionally shoot at, rather than an interactive boss fight with mechanics to overcome. In the Doom Fortress, there is a giant mecha suit similar to those found throughout the game- I had been hoping/assuming you would actually be able to don that armor to fight the Icon of Sin. Turns out it was just there for show.

- The limited time skins is a really shitty aspect of the game. There are so many skins in the game that you'll never be able to get because you didn't play at a certain time. People like me who didn't buy the game on release and waited, or don't have the time to play but periodically, just don't get various skins. It really doesn't incentivize me to stay tuned into and constantly play the game, just burns me for not being around 3 months ago. This is a live service model that I have never cared for in non-mmo games (mmo's having a constant stream of updated content, not just events, to keep people tuned in).

- The multiplayer is just bad. It's a 1v2 system, where one player is the Doom Slayer against two demon players. I've dabbled in it a bit, and it is comparatively bad even for an asymmetrical multiplayer system. There is no balanced matchmaking system, so very experienced players are constantly matched with very inexperienced players. I've also had the issue of people randomly leaving the middle of a match, with no form of backfilling or bot replacement. Occasionally this just means the match is over outright if the Doom Slayer player leaves.


Overall, this game is definitely worth buying on sale. The campaign is especially robust and really expands on the story. There are some pretty strong negatives, but they are far outweighed by the positives.

Didn't think a sequel could be better than the original. The heavy metal proved me wrong. 11/10.
It's just DOOM 2016 with some steroids, why wouldn't you play it?

[h1]Fan Service[/h1]

Instead of relying solely on slim pickings in a form of an unending chain of leftover references and useless toys, I'd always prefer for all possible homage to be integrated into gameplay and visuals, which is exactly what we have here. From the point of view of an old fan who periodically replays the originals and watches decino daily, Eternal is closer to classic Doom than anything before it. In terms of fan service, this one delivers the goods. Overall, the only thing about the game that I don't feel any reverence for is the pompous plot. He's just a doomguy, a marine, okay? I'll never call him Doomslayer, this is ludicrous! The story is so grotesquely epic that it could as well be a parody. Maybe it is and I missed the point, dunno.

[h1]Graphics and Guns[/h1]

What immediately catches the eye is that they've dropped that brown filter, so the color palette is much more vibrant and authentic than in Doom 2016. As a result, the game is as pretty as a picture and I loved almost all of its fantastic designs. Monsters, levels and most of the weapons look utterly inspired, everything is devilishly well-crafted. Could be slightly less cartoonish though.

The sights are fantastic - who can resist Apocalyptic hellscapes and occasional Akira goodness? The final levels, in particular, Nekravol and Urdak feature, hands down, the most stunningly gorgeous environments that I've ever seen. And I don't make this statement lightly! Besides, all that beauty runs surprisingly smoothly on my mid-tier rig, but I didn't expect anything less from id.

Countless times I had to stop in my tracks not only to absorb the vistas but to examine my arsenal. Even your simple combat shotgun is such an eye-candy! Unfortunately, just like in the previous game, it's only good for sticky bombs. That vintage plasma though, mmmm... The SSG, every connoisseur's weapon of choice, is perfect, too. What I don't understand is why they did the chaingun so dirty, the default skin is too futuristic and indistinct for my liking.

I also can't say that I appreciate the tendency to make some weapons unreasonably wide, it doesn't meet my taste. Anyway, what's more important, when you start shooting these nitpicks seize to matter - the feedback from them guns is superb, you can feel the impact in your balls. Except for the Unmaykr, that over-designed steam mop, from which I expected simply more oomph.

[h1]Monsters[/h1]

Enemies are a pain, so it's very pleasant to observe chunks of flesh tearing off their bodies when they get hit and to hear their bare bones cracking when you break them like twigs. Makes you see why serving in Hell's army is a punishment. Some of the enemies, like Mancubus, Cyberdemons (Tyrants), Pain Elementals, Arachnotrons, Archviles and Cacos, bear strong resemblance to their classical counterparts, making my heart melt. To faithfully replicate the original designs was the best thing they could do without having to send for Romero.

Monsters don't only look good but also have complex behavioral patterns, weak points and even the most basic chainsaw fodder comes in different variations. When you'll get to powerful enough weapons you won't care much about no weak points, so I don't  see why some people oppose them. Or Marauders! They're like fun (okay, this is arguable) mini-bosses, there're less than a dozen of them in the whole game, but people are still angry for some reason. I don't get it.

[h1]Tricks and Traps[/h1]

It happens sparingly, but sometimes a small ambush can be triggered if you pick up an item during an "exploration phase", which somewhat disturbs the whole predictable arena structure of the game. I'm not talking about them special nest encounters right now, although they are a nice novelty, too. Sadly, these events are extremely rare, the game remains a far cry from the original in this regard since the levels are still divided into combat and non-combat areas pretty strictly.

Cards and keys are a nice touch, but It's still the same stop-and-start level design where you're going through alternating phases, which never felt organic to me. The technology is not there yet, I assume, but I'm glad that id tried to do something about it nevertheless. Shows that they're thinking of more ways to meaningfully merge modernity and oldschool. Speaking of oldschool, monster infighting is back! Sort of. Unlike in the originals, I didn't get to use it to my advantage, and I'm not even sure if it works properly (but it's not always scripted, for sure). Yet I'm glad that they've included it.

The one feature I deemed unnecessary was the abundance of platforming, but it's inconsequential since you don't even lose a life after falling into a pit, only a sliver of health. Frankly speaking, "abundance" is an exaggeration and it never gets as frustrating as in, say, The Chasm. Yeah, it can be a bit annoying, it's definitely padding, and I'd prefer to see it only in combat where it really shines.

[h1]Combat[/h1]

Combat is all about dashing all over the place like a monkey, swapping weapons and resource management. I like the fact that the player is given so much control over the latter. With a stricter ammo limit, the chainsaw was reformed, it regenerates and now must be used all the time. Blood Punch is fueled by Glory Kills (that still give you health) and simply obliterates things, Flame Belch (always forgot about it) and SSG's hookshot drop armor, two types of grenades are both useful in different scenarios. Every ability can be enhanced by runes, for example, Ice Bombs can make it rain health when you shoot at monsters while they're frozen, Glory Kills can give you a significant speed boost, etc.

Doesn't sound like much, but try juggling these options in the heat of battle and you'll see that they're more than enough. Making these life-or-death decisions on the fly is what makes the game's combat truly tactical and hard to master. Most of the time, I felt like an old dog learning new tricks - humiliated, confused, but also very excited. Everyone expected that id would just fine-tune and tighten an already perfectly viable combat system, but they've modified and, in my opinion, improved, balanced and sped things up quite a bit. Some appreciate it, some are on the fence, some are just cranky and refuse to relearn.

[h1]Music and Sound[/h1]

Can't pass up the music. Obviously, I'm as huge of a fan of Mick Gordon's masterpiece as the other guy, I can't praise the OST enough - it gets me PUMPED. Too bad that he had some kind of fall out with id over bad mixing and they won't work together anymore, which is pretty damn sad. Now, the sound design... not a fan! You know how in classic games one could immediately tell what monsters were in the room, which of them got damaged or killed just by listening? Here it's all PEW GRRRRAAAAAAAAAAAAH PEW PEW BANG BANG GRRRRRAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAH PEW PEW ROOOAAAAARRRR PEW PEW!!! Eh, even if the sounds were more distinct, to turn down that music would be blasphemous.

[h1]Difficulty[/h1]

This game kicked my ass extremely hard, this is definitely one of the hardest shooters ever made. And I didn't even get a single lousy achievement for beating it on Ultra-Violence! Again. Not that it matters, really, but I was slightly disappointed due to how conditioned I am to expect a cookie for my every fart. At least I felt like I deserved and genuinely needed these sweet rewards after winning them battles, I guess.

But when I'd play the game again, I'd go for Hurt Me Plenty just to have a semblance of power trip instead of experiencing that ludonarrative dissonance after dying like a little bitch during every possible encounter to then watch cutscenes where everyone literally calls me the DOOM itself, a saint, kisses my ass and bends the knee like I didn't just happily suck all of Hell's supply of cocks dry nine times in a row.

BE CAUTIOUS OF ALL REVIEWS BEFORE THE UPDATE OF 5/15/2020!

This honestly feels so wrong to be giving this game a negative review. id Software deserves all the praise in the world for this game. Doom Eternal is a masterpiece of a first-person shooter, completely overhauling the majority of the gameplay elements that were present in 2016. The ENTIRE campaign feels like an all out brawl that forces your foot to be on the gas at all times. Phenomenal work, id. 

But requiring a kernel access driver to even play the SINGLEPLAYER? Are you actually fucking serious? And to hide this behind the fact that you're protecting legitimate players is disgusting. I earned 100% achievements shortly after the game came out, and there were multiple achievements that were in the 0.2% range. And to think that any of this has to do with battlemode is beyond me. I've played at least 15 hours and didn't run into a cheater. I'm on multiple discords, including Eternal + 2016, and I haven't heard a single complaint about cheating. The fact of the matter is, the multiplayer in this game is GARBAGE and no one enjoys playing it. That forces all of us to wonder why this is happening in the first place - and EVEN IF they had decent reasons for it, that doesn't mean that kernel access drivers are okay at all. People who enjoy playing games DO NOT want these invasive additions that deteriorate your machine, ESPECIALLY FOR SINGLE PLAYER GAMES. 

In my opinion, the worst part about this whole situation is the fact that I purchased the Deluxe Edition, because i LOVE DOOM. I was more than excited for the new levels and upcoming DLC. But adding Denuvo without our permission, AFTER we purchased the game is one of the most disappointing publishing choices I've seen in my life. This is the franchise that I have enjoyed dearly since I could remember. But, leave it to the publishers to destroy one of the best games of modern times. 

I will not change this review or install the game again until this kernel access driver is completely removed. Shame on you for ruining a masterpiece, Bethesda.

[b]Doom is Eternal[/b]. I can say that for sure after beating the game for 5 times and spending nearly 100 hours in it. I think the sequel drags bar for arcade FPSes even higher, setting new standard as Titanfall 2 did several years ago. 

	Maybe I could even go as far as to say Eternal is a masterpiece. Almost. Even though the gameplay loop is practically flawless, as game overall it has some places where it falls short in comparison to the DOOM 2016 imo. And before I start praising and kneeling before Eternal, I would like to bring up all these places.

[h1]Where DOOM is not eternal[/h1]

	First of all, DOOM 2016 provides more immersive atmosphere, I would say. The UAC facilities look like real places that had some purpose and meaning before invasion. Having no damage from falling is presented as a separate feature of the Praetor suit. The pick-ups scattered around levels look as subtle as possible, and on top of that, the HUD immerses player in the game even more by being diegetic. Such details make the experience more natural and cinematic. 
	On the contrary, Eternal’s level design often gives some Mario’s vibes and simply contradicts any common sense. Levitating tombstones, monkey bars, dash refills scattered around platforming sections of the game, rotating fire obstacles are literally borrowed from Super Mario Bros. I understand that DOOM was never trying to be associated with realism and whatsoever, but the sequel just constantly reminds you that [i]it is a game[/i]. You are not on the Mars research station invaded hell, you are on the demon-slaying playground. 

	
	The second problem was probably the most unexpected one for me. I could never think that I would have questions to the [b]story[/b] in this franchise. The first part of reboot was as simple as possible, you always had clear objective and understanding of what is going on in the story. In the meantime, however, Eternal confuses you with what’s going on from the start. Having expected the story continue from where it had ended previous game, I suddenly find myself on interstellar fortress (what?), hunt some hellish priests(WHAT?) and encounter interdimenstional god-like creature([b]NANI?[/b]). It is outright confusing and the gap between the first and second parts is never addressed here. Although, eventually, I really enjoyed the lore and the backstory game tells, almost all of it I’ve learned from the Codex pages and other text documents. And they are supposed to be [i]optional[/i]. So if you are not going to bother yourself with them, the story will look like a mess until the very end. 

	The third complaint is multiplayer. I don't know why, but ID Software decided that they do not want classical multiplayer, so they made this strange battlemode with only one type of game where you do not even always play as doomslayer but an ass-boring demon. Well, it is purely subjective of course, however in all reviews I've seen nobody has given this experiment more accomplishing than "meh" reaction. For me it is sad because we could have had a new Quake-like arena shooter platform which would be [b]ACTUALLY ALIVE [/b] (rip Quake Champions).

	The fourth complaint is about certain type of enemy. I want to rant about it a lot, but it is not worth it because breaking pace and making player change their in-game behaviour from proactive to reactive gameplay [b]IN THE FUCKING DOOM[/b] is already enough reason to call him shit. I don't want to spoil it for you, but you will get who I'm talking about as soon as you get to there. 

	Finally it is [i]small things[/i]. Like, you know, having some weapon mods being useless or seemingly worse than alternative is a trifle matter on itself, but when you have a bunch of such problems, it is getting as serious as previous complaints. I have to be short, so I will just list some examples of  [i]small things[/i] I had problem with: (already mentioned) useless weapon mods, magnetic monkey bars, dash refills (lazy design decision really), how are secret challenges made, replaying levels with cheat codes and some other [i]small things[/i]. 

[h1]Where DOOM is eternal[/h1]
	
	Well, everywhere else, I guess… Graphics, soundtrack, art design, and gameplay of course.

	Soundtrack is as fantastic as in the previous DOOM, I would say even better. Each theme has several presets befitting a certain type of situation, and they all do sound perfect. A plenty of times I found myself unintentionally bobbing the head during high-octane battles or calm intermissions. The soundtrack defines what the game wants you to do at the certain part: should you rip and tear, eagerly move towards the next battle arena or even occasionally stop for a moment and enjoy the beauty surrounding you. Well, what else can I say here — [b]damn, our boy Mick is at it again[/b].

	Graphics is decent and that’s pretty much it, game looks good both on low and ultra settings. I would rather like to focus on the art design instead, it’s gorgeous. All locations are saturated through with a theme of gigantism, constantly having something of enormous size around the player: either that be buildings, mechas, bizarre structures or some hellish titans roaming at the background. 

	Heck, even if I ranted about the story just some paragraphs before, all of the cutscenes are gold. If they are not over-the-top badass, they are over-the-top hilarious. The 80s-90s TV shows and blockbusters fit these two traits perfectly as well and serve as a good comparison, and that explains everything pretty much. (I mean, one of the most significant cut scenes in the game is [b]literally[/b] a recreation of scene from "He-man").

	And gameplay... to be honest, I wanted to write a critique on game, analyzing the mechanics and what makes gameplay so engaging and how. However, I discovered that steam reviews have pretty short character limitation, so... can I just paste here a bunch of hearts here to shower it with my pure innocent love and appreciation here? Thanks.  [b]♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥[/b]
	No, I'm serious, it's gorgeous. All newly added mechanics, restructurized demon bestiary and low ammo capacity entangle and create fast-pased hardcore gameplay which actually forces you to think with your head a lot unti your gameplay loop turns into a reflex-perfect consequence of actions. These gamedesign changes might be seen as controversial because they won't really allow players, wanting casual mindless experience of old-school shooter, enjoy the game, but I personally love the gameplay changes they've made. I am against stagnation in industry and I like games with deep gameplay mechanics which allow you to clearly see progress in your skills throughout time. 

[h1]Is DOOM eternal to you?[/h1]
	I am quite sure you will greatly enjoy new DOOM if you [b]do not[/b] expect from it "The same DOOM 2016 [b]BuT mOrE[/b]" and you welcome challenging experiences in games. Eternal gifted me truly new and unique experience in arcade FPS genre and sadly I couldn't get enough of it. Patiently waiting for both of game expansions to come out to download DOOM again and poke out some cute Cacodemon's eyeballs. 

	★★★★☆

Ok, after buying on sale and giving this another try, it's good.  Really good.  Still a little mixed bag, but damn it is worthy and I fully recommend.

No, it's not quite like Doom 2016, but once you get used to the differences, it's still great in its own right.  It's kinda like they took a step back, and a step forward.  Yeah, the limited ammo is just awful, but infinite regenerating chainsaw works just jam dandy when you really get a feel for the juggling of the fuel regeneration.  In fact, that's a big part of this game that was really off-putting at first, but can really grow on you.  You appreciate their presence, and you work to get better and better at juggling them into your combat strategy.  There's now TONS of stuff to upgrade and build over time, which makes you feel more and more badass.

The scenery and atmosphere are really fun and cool, and it's awesome to see new places like a city corrupted and ripped to pieces by a demonic invasion, with behemoth monstrosities in the background carrying literal cathedrals on their backs.  There's new enemies that flesh out the diversity of your victims, and the redesign of the others to better resemble classic Doom designs is superb and welcomed. 

And of course, the cheeky throwbacks and references are great.  And if Funko would actually make figurines with half as much personality as the collectibles in this game, I wouldn't hate Funko Pop with quite so much ferocity.

THAT SAID, there's some bad sides.
Yes, the ammo is extremely limited, and that put me right off the first time I played.  Even with full capacity upgrades, it's still much less than Doom 2016, and of course, a FAR CRY BELOW the grandpappy classics.  Some of the weapon upgrades don't really feel as useful this time, and I miss some of the old ones like how the plasma rifle used to have an upgrade to charge the secondary fire blast without having to fire the gun at all.  There's a few BS encounters where you're suddenly backed into a corner against several super heavy enemies and it's kinda just dumb, and there's some puzzles and level progression that isn't entirely clear.  And still, the thing that makes me MOST angry even though I love this game, is there's no infinite ammo pea shooter, and melee attacks don't inherently do any damage, and monster in-fighting is purely cosmetic.  Womp-womp. 

Flaws and (sometimes unwelcome) changes aside, it's a damn good game, and still retains that frantic bloodlust-fueled violence of Doom 2016, and I think it's a good modern rebirth of what made the classics so amazing in their day.



(KEEPING THE OLD REVIEW FOR POSTERITY)
If you liked 2016, you'll hate this.  The theme and imagery is the only cool part.  You can't kill enemies with melee attacks, your ammo capacity is garbage, leaving you totally unable to fight certain enemies if you didn't know they were coming ahead of time, the game keeps pulling you out for tutorials, and every enemy is a tank, yet feels like a waste of ammo all at the same time.  They took everything right about the first game and fucking obliterated it into eye candy and trash.

The Doom Series does the same thing making Doom 2016 about the horrors of the Mars base while Eternal focuses on a crusade against the demon threat. Doom Eternal is a must buy for anyone who wants an enjoyable first person action game.

review: 9.5/10, probably game of the year.

TLDR: Faster, harder, better. Everything you loved (or hated) about DOOM 2016 is amplified in this sequel. I enjoyed it and can only recommend it. I bought the game on release day and didn't regret a penny. 

[b]Story[/b]
The story takes us back to the Earth as demon forces have begun the invasion. From your space headquarters with help from VEGA AI from the first game, you are on the hunt for demons to stop them and save the Earth. With time you encounter new species and learn about the history of Earth, your Slayer Guild and these new species. The story is told via cutscenes and Codex pages found in each level. Most of the history can be accessed and read via the Codex menu anytime in the game, which is in my opinion, a great way of separating the story from the "Rip and Tear" gameplay. Thanks to that you are not overwhelmed with a ton of story throughout the game and can read it when you want it if you are interested in it.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
Doom Eternal is even faster and more aggressive then it's predecessor, making it a little bit of an (Ultra) nightmare for people not used to the fast pace of the previous game. Thankfully, you are given new ways of dealing with the demons and means of increasing your survivability throughout the game. New mechanics involve flamethrower to get armor, glory kills now replenish HP only, grenades for damage, freezing grenades for crowd control and a good old chainsaw for ammo. Levels got more platforming so it's also as much about vertical movement as about horizontal. All of these new features made the game, at least for me, more pumped with content and enjoyable in a long run.

[b]Enemies[/b]
Old enemies from the previous game are present, but you will encounter new enemies that are more aggressive and require a specific approach when dealing with them. For example, Arch-vile which summons new demons on the battlefield, so he becomes your main objective in fight. Some old demons got upgraded like Cyberdemon or Baron of Hell, being more aggressive and durable. What felt a little underwhelming were last two bossfight, penultimate boss was honestly, insultingly easy and that was rather disappointing to me. The last bossfight, for the amount of hype throughout the game, felt extremely monotonous. Second phase was just a first phase  in a "new cloak" (or should I said without the cloak?).  It was too long and too much of the same thing. Otherwise I enjoyed other encounters. Some of the bosses become regular enemies after you defeated them for the first time but they didn't lose their strength and remain a serious threat in subsequent battles.

[b]Headquarters (base)[/b]
Between each level you return to your base in space where you can unlock either skins for Doom Guy, or upgrade points for your suit and weapons. You can train in special arena in lower part of the base or check your unlocked weapons and collectibles. Over all it created this unique place where you always return and plan ahead with help of VEGA who's in control of everything. I liked this a lot.

[b]Upgrades[/b]
Weapons are upgraded the same way as before, but now you can also upgrade your suit, giving you  advantages in certain enviroments or boost your grenade launcher and flamethrower. You can also get special traits, after every upgrade of your maximum health/armor/ammo. Same as before you also acquire runes, of which you can have 3 active at the same time. There's a lot of upgrade and progress and I find it well balanced.

[b]Levels[/b]
There's a lot variety to locations, each having completely different style and design of platforming elements, perfectly fitting for the area. Secrets are in every level like before and most of them are easier to find thanks to the map showing you a lot of information, for someone this might be downside but I felt more comfortable about it. There were a few secrets that, in my opinion, needed more thorough searching but otherwise, collectables are pretty straight forward. At the end of almost every level you can teleport around several checkpoints on the map and look for things you missed. I liked this feature a lot.

[b]Multiplayer[/b]
I tried multiplayer only for like 2 or 3 games, it's format is different than classic DM. It's 2-3 player controlled demons vs 1 player controlled demon slayer. I don't think it's evenly balanced and wasn't very enjoyable on either side for me.

In the end, for singleplayer alone this game is worth it. If you are not a DOOM franchise fan, just wait for some, for you, acceptable sale and buy it. It's a great game. 9/10

Fidel to it's roots and innovative at the same time. Think about it, after Doom 2016 this could have been so many things but a success like this one. I think we are a lot to be surprised and that's something for a franchise that popular. In overall comparison what strikes me the most is that sometimes in Doom 2016 clearing rooms after rooms you tend to forget where you are fighting, not in Doom Eternal where each step on the map feels like a steps through the story. Everything looks so good, plays so well, runs so perfectly, bleeds so plentyfully...just wow and wow again.

Edit: I spent hours trying to finish an achievement that just never updated, so I have to restart the mission from zero, that's annoying especially considereing ow much time it took me to realize it was a glitch. All is excused Doom Eternal, that's the only problem I got, it is still the best.

If you're used to Doom 2016, when the game starts you'll wonder how anyone thinks this game is an improvement. You start off very weak with few options for combat in a game with more demanding systems and it's not very fun.

But stick with it... as you gain more weapons and learn that you now have to be even more active than the first game in maintaining your resources you come to realize what a masterpiece Doom Eternal is in game design. It's a game that demands your attention as you dance between enemies, constantly swapping weapons and keeping your ammo topped off with strategically timed chainsaws swipes. Added mobility options like dashing and grappling around the arenas takes the destructive ballet of the first game and one-ups it to a point where it will be difficult go back to the old gameplay ever again.

Doom Eternal is a true sequel. It shouldn't be played without first playing the original, and it builds upon that original in so many meaningful ways. Despite an introduction that will turn some people off at first, it quickly grows into one of the best FPS experiences to date.

review:
Well the game used to be the textbook definition of "fine"

Then they added spyware. Oh well!

Maybe they'll see the light and remove it down the line, though Bethesda gotta be Bethesda.

-Edit!-

Before getting started, let's be clear I'm not trying to blister the individual from Bethesda who left the very diplomatic response to my original review. I'm sure they're a lovely individual just trying to put dinner on their table.

Now, I will not be giving the game another try. I got most of the way through the story when I dropped it so I'm pretty sure I'm not missing anything life changing. Plus I cannot trust that there isn't something else that's been added that's similar to the "anti-cheat" they tried in the first place and I can't trust a corporation to not do what they do.

I also will not be changing my original review (other than this long winded diatribe) as it represents the opinion I still hold. The game was, indeed, fine. Want to know how fine? Read the review from literally anyone else, they'll tell you. I probably would have finished the story if the above rigmarole hadn't occurred. In addition, Bethesda did still add what is widely considered to be little more than a virus and there's no amount of updates that will erase that event from the timeline. Finally, I'll reiterate I don't trust that they haven't tried to sneak something else into the code that is just as damaging.

To close out, I'd like to pose the following question: why does Bethesda care now? Why have they hired someone with infinite patience to contact some random dork who said he didn't like their game. It's not like I hold any sort of clout when it comes to opinions on the internet. Plus I've already bought the game, right? I've already given them my money so why care if I said I'm not playing it again, right? No real reason to try to get as many people as possible habitually playing, Right? Probably not going to try to add in a bunch of microtransactions to the multiplayer in an attempt to milk people for all their worth, right? Right?

Bethesda gotta be Bethesda.

review: Very enjoyable. reminded me of playing Doom on DOS

Graphically it looks pretty amazing and very well optimised, music is hardly noticeable as gun/enemy sounds overpower it.
I would quickly compare it to previous Doom game with a bit less shooting, nearly all shooting happens on arena battles with some platforming on top.
Story's pretty interesting but does not explain much, loose continuation of previous game story.

You need to keep switching weapons quickly depending on enemies you're facing as game throws tens of them at you.
If not, you will often face issues with ammo efficiency (pretty poor for arcade/fast-paced shooting).
Single player campaign will take you around 20 hours, completing + achievements (single player) should take below 30h.

There are some parts of the game that feel unfinished (ie. big statue/robot-like inside you base, below the main deck that feels you should be able to use/control). 

Where the game shines for me and brings most fun is re-running levels with built in-game cheats, that makes battles more bloody, faster/dynamic and you don't care about either dying too fast or running out of ammo. 
Certainly feels that some default game balance/mechanics are not as well designed as they could be.

Overall it does feel weaker than the previous Doom (2016).
Full price is hard to recommend but 50% sale seems better.

The story is engaging without being too complicated. I have had a lot of fun with this game and highly recommend it. There's no need for me to score the graphics or soundtrack honestly ( YouTube has surely shown you already ).
hard to recommend, definitely get on sale, mostly fun but sometimes makes me want to strangle the people who made this

[h1] DOOM Eternal - 9/10 [/h1]

[i] Rip & Tear [/i]

[h1] Introduction [/h1]

If you are looking for an arcade-style first-person shooter, then this game is for you. It is a direct sequel of the Doom 2016 game, and it improves and adds so much from its predecessor in almost every way, such as the movement, weapons, perks, and more. Note: For this review, I will not talk about the story - only pure gameplay.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

The shooting is much more satisfying now; the way the guns sound and bullet splashing through demons feels awesome. In this game, ammo is more scarce than the previous game. This forces you into utilizing all of your weapons as much as possible. Especially considering each individual demon now has a weakness from certain weapons or abilities, it adds more variety in gunplay rather than just use the most powerful weapon in your arsenal. I didn't find any gun to be overpowered. I thought they were all perfectly balanced and fun to use, as opposed to the previous game where I used about only 2-3 out of 8 guns only.

What makes this game so intense is how improved and much more intelligent the AI is. They will track you like it is their last day on Earth. In that, the demons are much more brutal now and all they want to do is kill the mighty DOOM SLAYER.

This game adds new movement variety. You can use monkey bars to swing to certain places for better positioning. You can jetpack dash to avoid demon's projectiles. Also, you can stick to specific walls to navigate through certain areas.

Levels are way more fun in this game than D2016. This is mainly due to the levels being longer, and the overall aesthetic of the game. D2016 had a darker. grittier style, while DOOM Eternal returns to its classic roots with the art design like the loot items and the main Doom Slayer skin. Moreover, this game has more variety in collectibles. You can collect toys of different demons, soundtracks of different classic Doom or Quake games, cheat codes that you can later use to have fun with when backtracking. Additionally, once you are done with a level, you go back to the Fortress of Doom, which is essentially the Doom Slayer's base that you can explore and find your collectibles shelf. guns on your gun rack, etc. It is also where you can mission select and activate a portal to travel through.

One thing I want to say about the story is that the game is more lore-focused than D2016, so I recommend you read the codex's to understand what is going on.

[h1] Audio [/h1]

DOOM always had amazing soundtracks. In this game, you can feel the intensity of the action through the crazy metal music that will keep your adrenaline pumping. You can also collect soundtracks from various classic DOOM games and other id Software games as collectibles.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

I was hesitant of getting this game at first because I didn't expect this game to be worth $60. I thought it was gonna be a short 13 hour game like the previous one with fun repetitiveness. But, boy, was i wrong. It is worth every penny. So much content for a simple FPS game. If there is one negative thing I could say about this game is the Multiplayer achievements. Yes, for someone who enjoys achievement hunting, I think this is a pathetic way of forcing you to play their multiplayer. Apart from that minor complaint, this game is a must get for someone who wants to simply turn their brain off and just rely on reflexes and aim like old school games. Therefore, I recommend this game!

Having the audio cutting in and out every 30-60seconds is very off putting. I tried all the fixes from the developer, but nothing worked. I even did a fresh install of windows and that didn't solve it. This is the only game to have this audio hiccup. And I have seen I am not the only one. Hopefully they can get it patched, but it ruined it for me. I requested a refund, after only mustering 6 hours of "game time' which were really just troubleshooting time..

Doom Eternal is like Doom 2016, but amplified to 11.
Combat is faster, weapons are better, the glory kills are more brutal.

While the story may be harder to understand, long time Doom fans will definitely enjoy the extra lore that is sprinkled throughout the levels.

If you enjoyed Doom 2016, you'll enjoy this. Taking on the hordes of Hell has never felt better.

Doom 2016 was an amazing game. A fast paced twitch-fest that evoked the original Doom in the best possible way. But Doom Eternal is not that game. The game play is needless complicated (I mean, its DOOM ffs, it is not supposed to be complex) by the ammo system and the attempt to rock, paper, scissors the combat. Want to use the shotgun all the time? bad luck.
Doom 2016 once i finished I immediately restarted on a higher difficulty. Doom Eternal I doubt I'll finish, it's a slog. Which is unfortunate because the graphics are top notch, the levels extremely pretty and the sound effects chunky and solid. It isn't a bad game, but it is disappointing after the 2016 variant.

If you have played neither, buy Doom 2016. If you enjoyed Doom 2016 and want more of the same, don't expect that here. If it's on sale, sure, pick it up, its a decent shooter with great graphics.
