review: qe pasa larba
Heavy metal music, guns, gore and protagonist who actively reminds you he doesn't care about the plot. Rip and Tear.

After finishing my third play through of Doom 2016, I thought it was the right time to check out Doom Eternal. The game had glowing reviews and the consensus being that it's one of the best shooters of the year. I slapped down £25 when the game went on sale and got stuck in. 

My first initial reaction is at just how good the game looks and performs. It has a similar visual style as Doom 2016 and runs much smoother. The graphic style has a lot of colour and a lot of cool grotesque designs. I didn't have a singles stutter or slow down at all throughout my 20 hrs with the game. I found the controls very easy to handle. Doom Guy moved very smooth and the default control layout worked just fine. The music by Mick Gordon is just as good as it was for Doom 2016. The mix of pounding metal music and industrial beats under the weapon fire etc is very well done. 

After playing a few hours, I found myself a bit concerned in regards to my thoughts on the game. I didn't find myself enjoying it nearly as much as I thought I would. I found the extra long level design to be very tedious. They all looked fantastic but whoever designed them failed to capture the tight pacing that Doom 2016 had. A majority of the levels could literally be cut in half and you wouldn't miss anything in terms of content. It's the same thing over and over for a good hour at a time. Take the last three levels for example, (ignore the fact that the final two bosses are absolutely awful design) you spent your time going from one large fight to another by huge jumping platforms. If it was trimmed down considerably, it would be okay. But the tedium just goes through the roof. It left me wishing the level was done, instead of dying to slaughter more demons.

The biggest problem is the fact that the game is basically an open area of puzzles, a battle arena and then some platform jumping. It repeats this process several times over in each level without anything new or interesting to do. When you compare Doom Eternal to Doom 2016, you can see the big problem I had with the levels by a mile. The first game looked and felt like an actual Mars colony. You wondered your way through different sections, seeing all sorts of different sights and felt like you were actually making progress. Doom Eternal's levels on the other just feel considerably more gamey. The platform puzzles look so out of place in the environment. Large spinning flame columns, oddly placed flaming chains, breakable platforms etc. It honestly looked like some idiot was playing Super Mario Bros and decided to take the exact same platforming sections and place them in Doom. They don't fit at all.

You also have to look at how the enemies spawn in these levels. They spawned with just enough time to give you a breather in Doom 2016. In Eternal however, they just sort of come at you all in one large group. It gives you very little time to react. The later levels are especially bad for this. It's constant hordes of bad guys coming at you and it's very over whelming. Some people might like that experience but I felt it was a bit too much. 

Combat is generally okay throughout. I mean, it's basically the same thing as Doom 2016 for the most. You run around an arena and swap through weapons as you tear demons a new hole. The change in how you acquire armour and chainsaw is where the combat grew tedious for me. In Doom 2016, you were a legit bad ass who could demolish a group of demons without hesitation. In Doom Eternal, well... it's clear that he's been drinking too much soy or something. Doom Guy's health drains much quicker and his ammo pool is embarrassingly small. This means that you have to use the flamethrower, chainsaw and quick kills considerably more to top up your health, armour and ammo. It's fun to begin with but the bigger the battles get, the more you do it and the resource management just does not feel fun. Especially by the end game.

The enemy design is (for the most part) okay. You get your traditional Doom bad guys, all of which are easy enough for any Doom Slayer to disperse. The newer enemies on the other hand, they're clearly there to give you a bit of challenge. Each one of the new opponents are fast, powerful and incredibly hard to dodge. They always pop up when you've got a good rhythm with all the classic enemies and ruin the fun. The worst of the bunch is by far the Marauder. He's faster than you. Get too close and he shoots you with a shotgun. Get too far and he flings laser beams at you. Fire at him and he whips out a shield. You have only one time to hit him and that's when his eyes glow green (for some reason). He's okay enough to deal with by himself. But when he summons his stupid dog and chases you through a group of 10 demons, it gets annoying. He'd be fine as a big boss fight (which he was to begin with) but when he shows up more frequently, I hated it. 

I could go into more detail about what I didn't like about this game but it's just pointless. Everyone's of the same opinion that it's some modern classic. If that's you, I'm happy you think so. But as someone who has been playing these Doom games for nearly 30 yrs, I couldn't get into it at all. It's a well made game technically but the game play is just too hit or miss for me. I would recommend it at discount at most. The price of £49.99 is a joke.

Huge thumbs up to the developer for listening to the community about removing Denuvo Anti-Cheat! Cheaters suck and need to be prevented but the Denuvo approach is to intrusive. Especially for a single player game. The game by itself is AMAZING and I am very happy I can jump back in without concern of Denuvo admin access to my computer. Thank you again for listening (and acting!)

review: Really enjoyed this game tons of replayability really pressures the player to make use of alot of the weapons. The arm launcher for the frag gernade which enables the player to launch a gernade while still shooting with a gun was genius.

This is the Doom you've been waiting for. 

Games just don't give that destructive power fantasy like Doom does. You need to experience it for yourself. Slash, burn, and decimate the armies of demons with an arsenal that requires you to use the right tool for the right foe. You won't just be able to rocket launch or SSG+Ballista your way through it all, but you can sure try if you really are a superfan of those weapons.

Play it on Ultra-Violence for a fair but firm challenge. It's honestly not that difficult compared to the modes above or below it. It just forces you to use the systems somewhat or you'll die quickly. Don't use the Weapon Wheel at all, too slow for this mode, you gonna need to bind weapons and quick switch if you wanna be smooth. 

I haven't played Multiplayer and enjoyed it like this since the days of Halo. It's active, fun, and great casual or competitive.

review:
Thanks to Doom Eternal I've lost interest in the Doom series. The game was somewhat fun to play, but after playing through I've lost interest in the game. During the last levels I just thought "Let's get over with it now...". 

With all the Easter eggs, the remixed music from Doom 1 and 2 and the designs resembling the weapons and monsters from the original games from the 90s, I thought this must be the best Doom game ever. But I was disappointed.

Pros:
Good graphics, constantly 60 FPS
Short loading times
Lot's of achievements, some of them resulting in new skins etc.
The story is rather short and finally explains how the Doom guy got his strength.

Cons:
Level design: Nearly all levels are completely linear. You start in a passage with some platforming elements. You enter some kind of arena where wave after wave of enemies spawns. You are locked inside this small arena and have to parkour your way around enemies until the last wave is defeated. Then you continue to the next passage. 

Game play: You constantly run out of ammo. So you have to use the special attack with the chainsaw to get new ammo drops. All enemies deal a lot of damage. One constantly has to replenish it via glory kills. As a result the game felt more like resource management than shooting. 

Enemies: Most of them were quite fun to fight and kill, except for the marauder: This enemy was just utterly annoying. 


I've played the other Doom games multiple times. I've probably spent more time in Doom 1 and 2 than in any other game. But Doom Eternal, well, I've played it through once and uninstalled it.
play to release the anger of hearing your step dad go to town on your mom

The only negative is the fact that Battlemode doesn't live up to DOOM(2016)'s multiplayer and not adding it to this game is a huge missed opportunity. Battlemode is not a bad gamemode, it's ok but it's just not as good as the multiplayer

9/10, an AMAZING game
i n t e n s e
Super fun and creative combat. The best FPS I've ever played

Cluttered gameplay.  Combat was redesigned to focus primarily on using the chainsaw, glory kills, and flame belcher to get supplies, and all of these abilities have cool down time.  Carrying capacity is low and pickups are limited, so ammo and health have to be obtained with extensive use of every ability.  The shooting is a lot of fun, but it gets constantly interrupted by the need use a chainsaw with regenerating fuel to trigger several scripted animations over and over again to get ammo.  That, or it gets interrupted by the need to use a glory kill to trigger several scripted animations over and over again to get health.  Or you use the flame belcher to get armor tiles.  It´s all the same, because all three of these resources have an identical impact on the gameplay: they make the player stop dealing damage so that they can hit a key binding that will let them get back to doing damage (the chainsaw requires pick ups of fuel to kill anything that can defend itself).  They basically just added more stuff you have to do in addition to running around and picking up the stuff you need.

There's also the platforming.  It's tedious to figure out where the game wants you to go, and dying three times in a row by falling to your death when you can't find a ledge, in the dark, is irritating in a game that sold itself exclusively on combat.  I've spent almost as much time in this game doing platforming as I have in combat, and it'll be like that on every difficulty setting.  There really is a lot of platforming.  Most combat encounters have some kind of jumping and climbing in between them.  It's gotta be about a third of the game.

Doom Eternal feels bad as a shooter because the direction they took is moving away from shooting.  More fixed animations, more running around the map looking for stuff or waiting for stuff, it´s all more screen time that is not gun-play.  They don't really let the guns be the center of attention in this installment.

I really wanted to like it. I was a huge fan of Doom 2016 but I didn't enjoy this game at all. I don't feel like the gameplay is very well tuned at all. Its not that the game is too difficult, its that the difficulty seems to come from poorly balanced enemies with too much health, poorly telegraphed moves, and indistinguishable models. For example, is that a normal imp or some elevated enemy that takes 4 times as much damage, and can only be chainsawed with 3 fuel bars? Its very difficult to tell by looking at him and takes a lot of trial an error. Then there are enemies which are easy to fight but take so much damage you have to wail on them for what feels like forever. Then you are constantly bum rushed by crowds, forced to fight big mobile enemies in tight hallways and on and on... 
its all focused on using attacks to refill your vitals (health, ammo, armor) using the appropriate attacks (glory kills, chainsaw, fire). This means that there are rarely any pickups for these things. I think they wanted to be able to eliminate the pickups for these things to keep you fighting, but the result is you are always running out. The strategy then is to kind of ignore the big demons and focus on the fodder. You essentially have to do this because every enemy can cheese your heath to zero in just a couple hits. So you are just jumping from zombie to zombie and occasionally firing at something bigger.   

Many people see this as part of a challenge to enjoy and I guess I'm happy for them, but to me this just poorly engineered gameplay hidden behind a lot of spectacle and riding the previous game's coattails. It feels like they had some other game in the works and rebranded it as a Doom sequel. 

Again, to preempt the obvious criticism, I didn't feel that this game was too difficult for me (I had no issue with the notorious Marauder for example, just more dancing from zombie to zombie like every other fight), I just don't find it engaging. Once you realize the game loop is designed to keep you almost dying and then refilling just in time, the emotional tension disappears and you're just playing the clock until the demons die.

Anyway, again, many people seem to enjoy this game. Maybe you will too? I hope so. But if you aren't having any fun after the first two hours return it while you still can. Don't do what I did and keep giving it more chances until its too late.

yeah it was fun and all but have you played hdoom?

Doom Eternal is a fantastic game. It's so much fun and a wild ride from start to finish. Though, while it is a phenomenal additon to the Doom series, it does have it fallbacks in certain areas and ultimately, it doesn't quite reach the same greatness Doom 2016 achieved.

Gameplay in Doom Eternal can be summed up as a strategic ballet of running, jumping, dashing, and killing. It's this strange yet addictive formula that makes up 90% of the game. Though it strays from 2016's "shoot everything until it's pulp" which focused more on a berserker-style action, Eternal forces you to plan out your onslaught and strategically use every single weapon at your disposal to drag through each arena. 

Weapons feel and sound phenomenal, they have a much heavier sound to them which makes you feel like you're tearing up demons with heavy-ass weaponry. Mods have much better variety to them as well as being much more useful like the Heavy Assault Rifle's Scope turning it into a sniper or the Combat Shotgun's burstfire being replaced with a revolving barrel. The only downside is that the weapon design's themselves feel strangely foreign compared to the last game, their design seems much more whimsical like the Hell-inspired rocket launcher which is a shame because despite their relative mundane appearance, I really liked the more mechanical and UAC inspired weapons of 2016.

Atmosphere is where Eternal inherently falls short though. While textures look much better and much less muddled than 2016's, the demon-invaded earth just doesn't really compare to the desolate feeling of abandoned corridors of the UAC facility on Mars or the gore strewn landscape of Hell itself. None of the arenas or environments of Eternal are really that memorable which I find incredibly disappointing especially when you had Hell, Earth, and Urdak yet none of them were especially fantastic in their presentation. 

Lastly is the narrative of Eternal which in all honesty, is a god forsaken trainwreck. You're thrown like halfway through the major conflict of earth with the demons and so many things are thrown at you like you're supposed to be aware of what's happening. You'll have people mindlessly tell you to read the lore collectibles but that can only do so much with an incredibly fragmented story. Hayden is no longer a human as he was portrayed in 2016. The Betrayer is suddenly a major key into the story. Sentinels now have a strangely huge connection to the game because of Slayer's "mysterious" past. Everything is horribly disjointed that even though it "makes sense" in terms of lore, it really doesn't because of how it's unraveled to you. Even Slayer himself, previously he was this faceless angry avatar of death and suffering for the demons but now with all these flashbacks Eternal introduces, he's displayed as this superhuman fixated on killing demons which while ok, seems like a downgrade from his more mysterious origins. Oh Fortress of Doom is cool and all but where the hell did it come from? One major thing I will note is that 2016's story was very minimal but it portrayed the idea that Doom didn't need a story very well.
(why does the Icon of Sin seem so comical in it's portrayal in Eternal than it's ominous appearance in 2016?)

Oh, also Mick Gordon does a fantastic job once again with his soundtrack in Eternal. It might not be quite as memorable as soundtracks from previous titles but it's still pretty damn good. It's hard to top BFG Division or E1M1 Hangar.

TLDR: Doom Eternal is a fantastic game when it's firing on all cylinders for it's main component, gameplay. If you focus outside of that too much, you'll start to notice the muddled material baked around it. Just don't think too much about it. While Eternal may not take the crown from Doom 2016, it sure as hell proves itself as a worthy successor to the Doom series.

Like, I don't really know what to say. Look at my hours played. This is GOTY, hands down. Give your money to this game.

review: Alongside Half-Life Alyx, this is the best game of 2020.
very good and short

I loved Doom 2016 but this game is just oof 
I will basically compare this game to doom 2016 now, to keep it short 16 = Doom 2016

Story:
16 had a simple story and interesting lore in the codecs.
Eternal tries to be more story focussed but half of the time i'm like "Who the fuck are they?" because the game doesnt introduce them, it seems like i'm supposed to know them.
Another thing is the start of the game. Suddendly hes just there and has some space ship, this feels so lazy, they arent even trying to explain what happend between this time. They're like "We know that Doom Guy will return so we just skip to the end of it".

Gameplay:
16 was a simple shooter with a few nice jump&run moments. 
Eternal adds a bunch of weaknesses to the enemies and you now use the chainsaw for ammo and stuff like that. It isnt as simple anymore. This can be something that you might like but the fact that you often have to run through the same glory kill and chainsaw animations because ammo is a rarity now is just annoying. Another problem is that you cant save Ammo with the punches, the punch is almost useless, except its one of these power punches
Another problem are the jump & run sections. Sometimes they're fine and often you dont even know what the hell youre supposed to do and how to get access to the waypoint. You gotta look around and try to find places on which you can wallclimb or anything similar.
If I want to play Doom I dont want to search 5mins for some wallclimb wall. I want to kill demons.

Soundtrack is good in both of these btw.

Now you might see my problem with Eternal.
16 was simple, fun and understandable
Eternal tries to mix things up, tries to add a better story, tries to add deep gameplay but that just isnt what atleast i've wanted. 
Eternal fails to explain a story by not even trying to introduce characters correctly.
Eternal fails to keep it simple but fun
It tries to add things not many people asked for.

Youre better off with Doom 2016

This new Doom game is great, they really did make a game different to any other out there. 
I enjoyed doom 2016 more then Eternal.
Being a fan from the original Doom & Doom 2 i was expecting a lot of old memorys being replayed in much better graphics and game style, sadly the only memory that made me happy playing the game was the fact the guns looked kinda the same and they brought back the original demons e.g the spiders. No demons fighting themselfs this time..... so its not Doom then?
Making some boss fights amazing just to find out its going to be a standard demon to kill within the rest of the game, making it very annoying in battles and ruining the hype down the line. Every single demon has the same dash, jump and auto lock projectiles apart from maybe 3....no personality, they brought this mini version of the cyber demon with a sword which was very cool but wasnt even hard to kill just some other demon shooting rockets when ever it sees a little glimps of you. The demons are like having a ham and pineapple pizza its nice so lets add some more toppings yes thats even better now, finally lets add some grapes, skittles and peanut butter, wow slow down your over doing it now. 
Traps....oh yeah there is none. Jumping and grabbing was a really nice feel to the new doom but on this one its like you have to, if you dont theres no other way around fights or the story.

I liked:
Music
The different worlds
The feelings of each level
Bringing back classic items and so on
Video cuts
Story


I disliked:
Cant be arsed to write them all down....
Enjoy the game content and throw back to the game history.
this will push your fps skills to their limits on higher difficulties. But when you finally win the feeling is great.

This review only covers the single player portion-multiplayer isnt for me and thus will not be covered

For bad players: As a player who isnt very good a video games, playing this game for the first time was very fun. I played it on hurt me plenty but soon turned the difficulty down to easy. On easy mode the game still isnt a walk in the park but it gives you the doom guy power fantasy of riping and tearing demons left and right. You will want more and want to play the game again on higher difficulties. The arenas are really fun and the platforming is actually fun. The puzzles arent hard unless you are a 5 iq person like me.

For experienced players: You already own this game why are you even reading the reviews
This game is amazing, The combat is refined and the soundtrack is incredible. I would say buy this game as soon as you can.

I don't like Eternal. It doubles down on some aspects that I disliked about 2016 (poor level design, platforming) while adding on more bloat with its combat system. Combat in 2016 was fast paced, and you weighed options between glory killing for health, using the chainsaw for ammo, and using your more high powered weapons to get through the encounter faster. You had options to weigh per encounter. That has not changed in Eternal, but now it feels bloated. There are a lot more things to keep track of, between enemy specific weaknesses, your different grenades, your blood punch, so on and so forth. 

I'm in favor of more depth in games, but this honestly feels like less depth and more "if you don't play by these rules, you are going to be loading up a checkpoint". This is more frustrating than fun most of the time, because your ability to freestyle is actively limited by what enemies you are fighting and the game will painfully remind you of this every time you have to reload a checkpoint with a primer on how to deal with the enemy that ended your life. A lot of people talk about the Maruader, but he's easy.. its enemies like the Doom Hunter that make this game feel like a bore.
Absolutely love this! a great mix of classic doom with modern updates to graphics and weapons.
fun
really cool
Thrilling, beautiful and extremely engaging gameplay!
metalheads will cream playing this

Yes yes yes. If you want an even better DOOM 2016 or just a good game look no further than DOOM Eternal. When you get it running it might kick your ass. However if you master the combat and the mechanics and use your whole arsenal than get ready for a fun ride.

Incredible. The best shooter I've played in years. The gameplay from DOOM 2016 has been improved in virtually every aspect. Fun as hell (get it?) and a non-stop adrenalin rush from start to finish.

Absolutely worth the hype.

Linux gaming has arrived!  After getting it to work with my 5 year old Nvidia GTX 760 card (Ubuntu 20.04) I switched over to an AMD RX 5600 XT and it works out of the box, just like they said it would.  And what an amazing difference in graphics from 5 years ago.

To say nothing of the game, which is a masterpiece.  It's fluid and fun with ridiculously cool monsters and weapons amid cleverly designed levels and puzzles.  And if you've ever enjoyed the original DOOM you'll love it even more!

I really liked the game when I first played it, but before I got too far they suddenly required an unsafe program for anti-cheat.  It was a pretty shitty thing to do considering it came out after many people had bought it.  At the time I stopped playing and recommended against anyone buying the game.

Since then, they have removed the requirement, so I am updating this review.  The game's a blast and I'm really looking forward to playing it again.

However, I will still be weary of buying games from Bethesda for the first few months of release.  It's great that they listened to the backlash about Denuvo, but there's nothing stopping this from happening in the future.

review:
Not Finished the game yet but its a 10/10 

i mean its a doom game, take everything good about DOOM 2016 and amplify it by 100 the music is godly it kicks in at just the right moments and gets you into the mood needed to fully enjoy this game, im not gonna spoil the game but fuckin hell the missions are insane, you do one and when you finish it you think 'it cant get anymore intense' well your wrong each mission is better than the last, glory kills are as brutal as ever the story is interesting it provides lore if you want to read up on it the game looks great it runs great OH AND THE MUSIC, the range of demons is great (fuck the marauder tho) its kinda fun to learn all their weaknesses, like at first you spam everything you got at a hell knight then you learn how to take them down, also all the boss fights i've played are fun they are challenging but still enjoyable and fuckin absurd, the character designs are great, did i mention the music? in case you couldnt tell i fuckin love this game if it doesnt win game of the year i'll be quite annoyed and finally this is the most important thing to remember about this game it will help you tremendously, Cacodemon best demon

Edit: Finished the game twice now about half way through my Nightmare run this game still is great the replayability is outstanding its fun all through the game everytime the harder difficulties are a fun challenge Nightmare well is as the name suggests. i've tried Ultra Nightmare a couple of times and it takes lots of skill and you cant cheese it (as far as i know) which is good and makes sure the difficulty can only be beat by the best, even though its hard its is really fun and makes you want to try again, not played on im too young to die(easy) cause its DOOM and easy would be boring, the ending is satisfying and a fun fight aswell as a good wrap up to the campaign and with DLC 1 coming soon (hopefully) i've never been more excited about this game, so still i give DOOM ETERNAL a 10/10

review: Playing Doom Eternal is the best way to protect yourself from Coronavirus.
Makes you feel like an unstoppable force. Graphics are insanely detailed and the settings are impeccable.

It doesn't feel as free-form or flexible as DOOM 2016. It REALLY wants you to engage in the cycle of shoot, glory kill, shoot, chainsaw, so it keeps you low on ammo so you frequently are put in situations where you must chainsaw. If you get stuck in a spot where you don't have gas, and you've run out of ammo, it's difficult (and frustrating) to proceed. Even on easier difficulties, you can punch the basic zombie enemy 10 times and it won't even start flashing, while 1 shotgun shell will completely destroy it. Being forced into such a specific cycle of actions with many enemies that have one weakness, with little flexibility on what you do, isn't fun in a game where you are supposed to go wild and wreak havoc.

Only three hours in and I already absolutely love it. They have managed to build upon the 2016 Doom and somehow make it even more entertaining. The gore is absolutely amazing and the combat feels a lot more smooth and fleshed out than the original game, the sense of progression compared to the 2016 Doom is a lot more fulfilling and actually feels like you are accomplishing something. I can already tell that this game will be very repeatable as there is so many collectables to find!
It's probably not right that this game is just relaxing awesome fun.

review:
One of if not the best first person shooter I've ever played.

Doom eternal is one of those games where you pay it, and then realize it's 4:00 AM and you've been playing it for 5 hours straight.

It's like a symphony of just gore and violence and satisfaction in coming out of an encounter unscathed, the grapple hook on the super shotgun is very fun and a phenomenal utility tool allowing an upgrade to be earned that allows you to get armour pickups from grappling on to enemies.

IDs approach differs from the previous entry, having ammo be more scarce but also allowing your chainsaw to have essentially unlimited uses with a cool-down, this drives the player to diversify their loadout because they cannot rely on a singular weapon as they'll run out of ammo mid-encounter.

Pick this game up, it's extremely good, and worth a 60 dollar price tag

review: One of the previous updates came with a kernel-level Denuvo anticheat. The game was completely unplayable on Linux, but was also malicious on Windows, as kernel-level anticheats are extremely vile and leave a massive security hole in your system. This has already been proven with Valorant, which soft bricks PCs and locks input and changes BIOS settings from time to time. The publisher cannot be trusted, be cautious.

review: Yes.
Beautifully made game !

Before this starts, understand that I only review games I like. The fact that I've bought this on Steam, again on Xbox and finished the campaign multiple times should show an unhealthy obsession with the game. It's just awesome, good job id. I honestly can't wait for the DLC additions. Don't let me down!

Now, the complaints (of which there are only 2 but one's big).
1) The Music - Without getting into the cluster**** of Mick Gordon's departure, the combat music seems much slower paced than that of the 2016 predecessor. This could be easily overlooked as tracks from previous DOOM titles are hidden all over the game BUT you're only able to listen to these while in the Fortress of Doom and not while actually Ripping and Tearing. A playlist feature would be a nice addition to the in-game menu and would make multiple plays more fun.
2) The Multiplayer - Good god this is where the game falls apart. In an attempt to break away from traditional deathmatch modes, they built a well designed 2v1 game mode. That's it though. I like Battlemode, don't get me wrong, it's well balanced and fun when you can keep 3 players in a game. But it relies too much on all 3 people being in the same skill bracket, AND willing to stay for the whole match, AND do a rematch so everyone gets a turn as the slayer. In the 70+ hours I've put in, hardly any of it is multiplayer and that's a shame. I spend more time waiting in a lobby for an ultimately disappointing match and there's no variance. There's no different game modes to switch between like TDM or CTF. So when you get tired of Battlemode, or if it's not your style of game play, that's it. We're still promised the campaign invasion mode (where it's still only 2v1) but there's no news on when we'll actually get it. Adding one or two more game modes kind of seems like an easy addition considering you already have balanced slayers, demons, abilities, and maps. I sound super salty here, but the same old deathmatch in the new DOOM is one of the things I was expecting from it and the game didn't deliver.

You should still get this game. Just prep for a LOT of lobby waits.

worst version of 2016,overdone.souped up trash. gameplay is too fast paced. cant even enjoy killing demons before 7 more take their place. everything except fodder has a ranged ability and rush you from every angle. upgrade system is terrible and useless. too many abilities,you have binds for weapons,dash,double jump,flamecannon,swapping between ice a frag grenades,grenade,your crucible and swapping your weapon mod.if that isnt enough you have to the very very very very annoying marauder.you cant express negative opinions about this game because the Doom fanbase will try to shout you down. fuck this game for being almost good. fuck bethesda for ruining it and fuck ID for letting rape their baby. and they fucked with the soundtrack

... Someone forced the OST's for DOOM (2016) and DOOM Eternal to be removed from Youtube. 




Someone just signed their figurative death warrant.






What else is there to say about DOOM Eternal, except RIP AND TEAR!!!

Well, there's also lots of lore, SOOOO many easter eggs (one that makes me question if the devs for the game and story writing have ever seen a certain fanfiction crossover), new faster combat with new mechanics, music that gives me a RAGE *****.

I am slightly disappointed that certain important pieces of lore didn't turn out as I expected, but that's ok. A lot of the history and lore behind the DOOM franchise has been lots of speculation, and the stories that have resulted from nothing being set in stone has been amazing. I dare say that it's part of what captivates some of the audience of DOOM (it sort of is for me). 
Of course, there comes a time and place where concrete details and lore have to be laid. Perhaps that time is now, perhaps not. For me, only hindsight will tell. 
I'm fairly certain that whatever the lore turns out to be, I'll be very satisfied with it. 

[CAMPAIGN COMPLETED]

Edit 3/23/20: When it comes to key cards and such, it feels like those were just thrown into the story line. They don't really need to have lore or anything, and they're not that important, just a noteworthy difference I noticed from the last game. 
To be honest, I was expecting a short dialogue line from VEGA a couple of times in the first level, like if you approached a locked door, he'd say something like "Scanners detect a keycard nearby, but you'll need to find it." Eh, whatever.

Also, seems like the Sun was already devoured. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2033335526


Edit: 4/17/20: I went back to DOOM 2016 for a little bit to get another feel for it's story. I believe that DOOM Eternal's campaign feels a bit more sporadic then DOOM 2016, at least when it comes to 'cohesive story telling'. 
I wish the story did more to connect certain things together. 
For example, I wish I didn't get a head's up about the betrayer through a NOTIFICATION on the hud. I'd prefer if A: the information about the betrayer was subtly laid out there for me to want to discover and figure out; or B: the story itself had the information in it through dialogue.
It just felt like this story was more random then DOOM 2016, at first though. 

That first impression of the story is crucial to grabbing the attention of the audience, and it turned me off at first.


[CHARACTERS]

King Novik... Why is he in the game if he has like one line? I wanted him to be an antagonist SOOOO BADLY!!! Just listen to him in the first story trailer of DOOM Eternal! 

Khan Makyr: She played her role as an antagonist well I think, so no additional criticism needed. 

Marauder: Kind of wish he had a bigger role in the story beyond being another demon. What I mean is that I wish he had more personal significance to the Doomslayer, beyond what the lore describes about the Marauder. 

Deag Grav: I was anticipating for the Doomslayer to also be the betrayer, or to have some sort of deeper connection to the betrayer, so that the conflict between Deag Grav and the Doomslayer was that much more intense. 
I also wasn't expecting Deag Grav to be so wimpy, but my expectations probably stem from something I was reading online before DOOM Eternal was released.

[Multiplayer]

It's pretty fun. It's different from playing gunplay with other people, but it's pretty fun. I hope that more multiplayer games are added though, to add more variety.

[Weapons]
 
The only thing that could be better with the Super Shotgun's meathook is that it could acquire targets instantly. The reticle for the meathook should instantly snap to the target within range, as fast as an aimbot would. And it should be able to grab target's heads when they're exposed, so that if you fall down an edge, and a demon's head is still visible, you can grapple it with the hook to get back up.

Definitely a step up from DOOM 2016. Keeps you on your toes as you dash around and kill your enemies. Now with having less ammo than before, the chainsaw can recharge to one slot after using it all up, so finding ammo is no longer a problem, just saw right through them! With the new demons and old ones returning, it's a great game if you want to relive DOOM 2!
In my opinion Doom Eternal is better than Doom 2016. More fun combat, more fun exploration, insane graphics. I am really loving Doom Eternal.

Buy it.

Play it.

Enjoy it.

It's Fucking DOOM, no need for words.

Huge improvement from DOOM 2016. i can't go back to that awful game now.

Initially I refunded this game at the two hour point because it just felt like Doom 2016 all over again, not a bad thing but not something I was ready to pay $60 for.

When it went on sale for half off I picked it up only to once again regret my purchase and wonder if I could refund it again. 

As you get further in the game it does differ from Doom 2016, plenty of fun elements but it's overshadowed by far more annoying introductions of enemies and mechanics. 

There's more emphasis on the parkour element they had from the prior game, double jumps, air control, dashes, climbing, pole swinging and so on. The problem is that more often than not the climbing will be unresponsive. Plenty of times I've accidentally punched walls when I intended to climb them or smashed my face on a pole when I went to swing, plenty of times I went to grab an edge and instead of grabbing it I just slid down into the pit below me.

While it can make the combat seem more alive and dynamic, it doesn't do much since you're trying to avoid demons already because almost all of the arenas are claustrophobic sizes of small and they drop more and larger demons in on a regular basis, leaving you practically shoulder to shoulder with everything. This gets added onto with new demon types that have been added and make the experience even worse.

The new demons in question are primarily one that exists for the sole purpose of placing shields in your face to block your shots. There has been a time or two where I've blown myself up because he suddenly existed and stopped it. He can be easily countered if you switch to the Plasma rifle but to need to go out of your way and reach for a particular weapon to stop an enemy from stopping you from targeting others is obnoxious. Another is generally thin, very fast, and despite having the former two capabilities it does have a generous health pool, fast melee attacks, and very good tracking ranged attacks with equally substantial size.. And with little to no space to move at times it feels unavoidable at times.

  Lastly they introduced a lives mechanic to this game by default with no way of turning it off. Nothing feels more insulting than to be playing on the second hardest difficulty and proving your worth only to finally die and... Not even be remotely punished for doing so. You lose one life when you have a reserve of nineteen more and can power through the fight without a care in the world. The problem is you don't get to choose if you want to spend it, there are a couple of times where a fight is genuinely difficult and I want to use a life but I may have accidentally burned a couple on a fluke that got me killed (Or the terrible platforming) and I don't have as much or any.

  I can't and won't recommend this game. I highly suggest getting 2016 and avoiding this mess.

Not as fun as Doom 2016, as they took that and added in a Dark Souls component because we need to make every game like Dark Souls. I enjoyed how powerful I felt in Doom 2016, and do not enjoy how this makes me feel like a weak monkey solving puzzles for food scraps.

They informed me they removed the campaign anti-cheat so I am modifying my review. It's always good to see the developers active and willing to listen to the community.

review: I played this game on xbox one and decided to buy a PC just so I could experience this masterpiece the way ID intended.

EDIT: 8/12/2020
I've been informed that the previously mentioned Denuvo Anti-Cheat has been removed from the game as of patch 1.1. Based on this, I absolutely have to recommend this game; it builds upon the predecessor in a multitude of ways, improving enemy weaknesses, ammunition types, enemy variety, customization, new abilities like the flame spitter and rechargeable grenades, ice grenades, and the complete adjustment to combat itself. Doom 2016 felt fast on release, but compared to this monster, it's like you're stuck in Atlanta traffic. Combat flows through multiple parts, each vital to not dying and slaughtering demonic hordes, utilizing movement options to reposition and close gaps, identifying enemy weaknesses and using the proper weapons to exploit them, and capitalizing on your abilities to keep your health and armor at max. It feels like a perfected version of Doom 2016, like a beautiful bloody waterfall. 10/10, buy this shit.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

At release, it was a fantastic game, and it still is today. However, Bethesda and id pushed an updating implementing Denuvo Anti-Cheat on the 14th of May, a few weeks after release. Being primarily a single player game with what feels like a tacked on game mode, this feels extremely anti-consumer. There's multiple problems with the anti-cheat as well, lowered performance, no way of disabling it for strictly single player modes, some players having issues with UPnP and of course, it running at Ring-0 while the game is running. While this isn't uncommon for anti-cheat programs, the fact is, they do bring along security concerns (See SecuROM and Sony's XCP Rootkit scandal), and the anti-cheat runs even when playing strictly SP. This removes the ability to experiment and mod using cheat engine, a program that should have no problems in a SP game. Until the developers remove this, I can't recommend the game anymore, and I hope Valve starts allowing users to refund their purchases, as this feels like an extreme bait and switch.

review:
Edit - the invasive anti-cheat has been removed and I can now recommend this game again with some caveats. Result!

As it is, Doom Eternal is a fast paced shooter with a much greater focus on movement and navigation than previous entries in the series. It's basically a game about moving as fast as possible and shooting things as much as possible. If you like those things, you will almost certainly enjoy this. It also feels like it doesn't quite know what kind of game it wants to be.

Max ammo count has been reduced across the board to try to make you use a variety of weapons in each combat engagement. There's a hub level full of interesting nooks and crannies, with upgrade collectables and shoutouts to various other id/Bethesda games. Levels are nice and varied in both visual design and in the different movement/navigation gimmicks they use. These are generally good things and they're all integrated with each other so they work well in combination.

Music and sound are also excellent. Provided you don't have an overwhelming hatred for dubstep and the like, you'll find plenty here to enjoy.

I think what works less is a suite of abilities on cooldowns, weakpoints on some of the enemies, and an even heavier emphasis on the "glory kill" mechanic from 2016's DOOM. These aspects of the game don't feel very "Doom" to me and I feel like they detract from the essence of what the series is about - move fast, shoot the things with your gun, don't get shot. That's what I'm looking for out of a Doom game, and those mechanics feel like they belong in other games and were added solve problems that didn't really exist.

I also have some issues with the tone of the writing because I'm not quite sure what it's trying to go for. DOOM (2016) takes a quite silly idea and runs it with a completely straight face; there's comedy but it's in spite of the tone, and it comes across as classy and understated. Eternal acts as a direct sequel so you'd think it would try and strike a similar balance, but it ends up trying too hard to be funny, often overshooting to the point you laugh at the game, not with it. When it happens, this is distracting.

In summary - shooting things as fast as possible is great fun. More of that sort of thing please.

review: dude holy fuck i love this game

Played first game on Nightmare like previous DOOM:

Positive things that delivered top notch game experience:
+Art, music and landscapes were amazing
+Improved movement mechanics like dash were fun
+Intense fight scenes were difficult and enjoyable

Negative things that frustrated or disappointed in the game:
-Too much jump puzzles to my taste
-Too few Slayer-gate type of intense fight scenes in the first half of the game, in later stages there was plenty of intense action.
-Biggest issue in the beginning were some of the combat mechanics. Very limited ammo feels awkward especially in the beginning of the game, overemphasis on weak points and chainsaw ammo limiting your options what monsters you are able to kill for ammo. Escaping fights altogether due to lack of ammo made me sad. Later on with ammo upgrades in the game this is no longer an issue.

Overall game experience is a bit of mixed feelings. Starting levels were not really keeping me interested and almost stopped and uninstalled. If I would have rated previous DOOM 10/10, this is 8/10. Not bad, but some annoyances struct a cord. Replayability through master levels is nice. Slayer-gate gauntlet with increasing difficulty until death would be a fun custom game mode for future patches.

Say no to kernel level anti-cheat software. It completely bogs down the game performance wise and it's ideally not a good idea to install Bethesda/ID spyware.

Edit: They have removed the Denuvo Anti-Cheat software and it greatly improved the games performance. It is a great game however, I will not remove my original post to remind people of what shady practices Bethesda does and what happens when we ban together with one voice.

review:
Invasive anti-cheat software in the game weeks after launch. It requires kernel level access to my system and it's a security risk I'm not willing to take. Hopefully Steam will allow refunds for people who played more than 2 hours. This is unacceptable.

EDIT: The anti-cheat has been removed for a while now, so I'm updating my review.

I'm giving it a thumbs up because there's no "mixed" or "more or less" recommendation. I'm saying this because while the game is good and fun to some extent, it's not what I expected. DOOM 2016 was great because it was pure, mindless "rip and tear" action. Doom Eternal? Not exactly. The way the gameplay was designed pretty much forces you to use all the different weapons and attacks otherwise you're gonna die fast and run out of ammo. You can't do it like 2016, which you could stick to your favorite weapons and roll with them as much as you liked. Some say it's a nice change of pace but to me is a strong negative. Doom Eternal is, in a way, more tactical than 2016 and pretty much all the previous Doom games, and it's not exactly my jam.

TL;DR: I acknowledge the game's quality (hence the thumbs up) but I'm not 100% the target audience for it.

review: i love to rip and fart and i'm all out of farts :(

Update 1.1 removed Denuvo Anti Cheat from the game so I am editing this review to recommend the game once again (although I have refunded it in the interim I will probably pick it up again next time there's a sale). Just be aware that previously Denuvo Anti Cheat was added without warning so if you do install the game, keep a close eye on what updates it receives.



===


As of the most recent update (Friday 15th of May, 2020), the game has a kernel level anti-cheat driver which launches with the game and runs alongside it, which is made apparent only in the patch notes (and not on the pre-game splash screen or the store page as of this time).

If you've installed the update, you need to go manually uninstall "Denuvo Anti Cheat" from your list of programs and check your windows services (open the start menu, type run and "services.msc" and look for Denuvo Anti Cheat in the list of services and make sure it's not running).

I would not recommend buying this game (or reinstalling it if you already own it) while this is an outstanding issue.

review:
Update: 
Given Update 1.1 has removed Denuvo Anti-Cheat, I can again recommend this game. The single-player campaign was brutal and exhilarating, and I would love to go back and try to complete the last couple challenges I have left now that I don't need to rootkit my computer to play it

Old Review:

Up until yesterday, I would have wholeheartedly recommended this game. I enjoyed playing the campaign (and ignoring the multiplayer), and had fun ripping and tearing. But everything changed when Bethesda decided to try and sneak a kernel driver anti-cheat into my single-player game. There is literally no reason why an anti-cheat needs to a kernel driver to function. They are ineffective against cheating, as cheaters in Valorant (famously using a kernel-mode anticheat "Vanguard") show on a daily basis, and do little more than open my computer to security problems.

I have uninstalled this game, and already been denied a refund despite Bethesda changing the terms of purchase out from under my feet. Had this been in place on launch, I would have never bought the game. I need to trust the security profile of my PC, and I can no longer play DOOM Eternal and still trust my PC to be able to guard my data.

review:
Love it.  Way harder than DOOM 2016 but in the best way possible.
The added movement mechanics  make DOOM 2016 feel slow.
The hard counter style combat does take some getting used to, but once you find the rhythm and  internalize how it all works you'll feel like a GOD. 
Everything is so perfectly balanced and tuned that when I die I know exactly WHY and how to prevent it next time.
Lots of cosmetic unlocks that you get just by playing, and a bunch of super interesting lore, if you're into that stuff (I definitely am!)
The Marauders are definitely a frustration until you really learn how to deal with them, and even still, they can get you raging pretty hard. That said, I do actually like them as enemies. 
I can't say enough about how much I really dig this game. Lookin' forward to the DLC!
ONE OF THE BEST GAMES I HAVE EVER PLAYED

EDIT: Denuvo Anti-Cheat has been removed and I can now recommend this game. 

As stated before, it's a lovely gameplay loop. Intense, challenging and brutal. It's just a better Doom 2016, less repetitive as 2016, better visuals, better sound, better music. 

While hard, it's fair. You never feel cheated or like you don't know what you did wrong when you die, except for some instances. One of those is the level design in some areas, I kept getting stuck on things on the ground that I didn't expect to. This doesn't happen that often, but often enough for me to get frustrated by it. 

The game has tutorials that can be turned off, however, I'd prefer if you can set the amount of tutorials for the first playthrough, because they tell you way to much. Like how to defeat a boss.. I wanna figure that out my self. But if turn of the tutorials, you risk missing some critical information about new weapons and gear.

But overall, I loved the game. If you loved Doom 2016, you'll love Eternal. 
Sorry for the negative review, Id Software. 
Keep up the good work, can't wait for the DLC:s!



----BEFORE DENUVO WAS REMOVED----
Well, I hate to jump onto this review bombing train, but this time it's really necessary..

I love this game. They took the gameplay loop from 2016 and made it even more intense and awesome.

But this low-level, anti-cheat driver from Denuvo is just awful. I was excited to go back, getting 100%, trying the master levels and maybe dive into the multiplayer. But when the game requires some shady software to run at kernel level... naa man, I'll go back to this game if and when they fix this. 

At this point in time, I do not recommend anyone playing this game on their personal PC.

In the first age, in the first battle, when the shadows first lengthened, one stood. Burned by the embers of Armageddon, his soul blistered by the fires of Hell and tainted beyond ascension, he chose the path of perpetual torment. In his ravenous hatred he found no peace; and with boiling blood he scoured the Umbral Plains seeking vengeance against the dark lords who had wronged him. He wore the crown of the Night Sentinels, and those that tasted the bite of his sword named him... the Doom Slayer.

Tempered by the fires of Hell, his iron will remained steadfast through the passage that preys upon the weak. For he alone was the Hell Walker, the Unchained Predator, who sought retribution in all quarters, dark and light, fire and ice, in the beginning and the end, and he hunted the slaves of Doom with barbarous cruelty; for he passed through the divide as none but demon had before.

And in his conquest against the blackened souls of the doomed, his prowess was shown. In his crusade, the seraphim bestowed upon him terrible power and speed, and with his might he crushed the obsidian pillars of the Blood Temples. He set forth without pity upon the beasts of the nine circles. Unbreakable, incorruptible, unyielding, the Doom Slayer sought to end the dominion of the dark realm.

The age of his reckoning was uncounted. The scribes carved his name deep in the tablets of Hell across eons, and each battle etched terror in the hearts of the demons. They knew he would come, as he always had, as he always will, to feast on the blood of the wicked. For he alone could draw strength from his fallen foes, and ever his power grew, swift and unrelenting.

None could stand before the horde but the Doom Slayer. Despair spread before him like a plague, striking fear into the shadow-dwellers, driving them to deeper and darker pits. But from the depths of the abyss rose The Great One, a champion mightier than all who had come before. The Titan, of immeasurable power and ferocity. He strode upon the plain and faced the Doom Slayer, and a mighty battle was fought on the desolate plains. The Titan fought with the fury of the countless that had fallen at the Doom Slayer's hand, but there fell the Titan, and in his defeat the shadow horde were routed.

And in his terrible rancor between worlds and through time, the Hell Walker found the wretch who shall not be named, but in his heresy was loyal to his evil cause. The wretch adorned the Doom Slayer in a mighty armor, wrought in the forges of Hell, impenetrable and unyielding. With sword and shield of adamantine strength, the Doom Slayer set to banishing all that were left unbroken by his savagery to the void. Yet as the mighty Titan fell and dread engulfed the armies of Doom, the demon priests of the Blood Temples laid a trap to capture this scourge of Hell. Insatiable, even by the vanquishing of the Great One, the Hell Walker sought prey in the tombs of the Blood Keep. And blinded by his fervor, the lure drew him in. The priests brought down the temple upon the Doom Slayer, and in his defeat entombed him in the cursed sarcophagus. The mark of the Doom Slayer was burned upon his crypt, a warning to all of Hell that the terror within must never be freed. There he lies still, and ever more, in silent suffering.

review:
Mechanically, this is the best shooter ever made.

A bold claim, but one that I stand behind. Except... it's not really a shooter. At least not in the way DOOM 2016 was. Try to play Eternal like a normal FPS, and you'll die. Almost instantly.

Eternal overloads you with different mechanics very quickly, and mastering each one is key to surviving. You restore health by damaging enemies enough that you can move in close and finish them with a melee kill. You get armor by setting enemies on fire. You get ammo by chainsawing them. Each gun has multiple alt-fire options that act very differently, and you'll have to master all of them too. Combat is what this game is all about, and the bulk of the game is spent in the midst of large combat encounters that take place in very open, very vertical arenas. They're designed to keep you moving constantly - if you stop, even for a second, you're most likely dead. Combat encounters become a bloody ballet of moving around these arenas at Mach 10, constantly assessing threats, switching weapons, managing resources and cooldowns, and dodging projectiles flying in from every direction.

I can see why many people bounced off Eternal. They were expecting a similar experience to DOOM 2016, but DOOM Eternal has more in common with the likes of Bloodborne and Sekiro. It's not enough to be good at shooters; you NEED to learn enemy weaknesses and every nuance of every weapon and ability to survive.

As for the other aspects of the game, well, there's a story. Far more of a story than in DOOM 2016. It's extremely cheesy, and you'll either love it, hate it, or, like me, just not care about it in the slightest. There is far less exploration than in DOOM 2016, but that doesn't really matter - Eternal is not about exploration. The music is still amazing, and the graphics are still gorgeous. But this is a game that's all about combat, and that's where it shines. It's mechanically dense, has a very steep learning curve, is extremely unforgiving, requires 100% of your attention all the time, and I wouldn't have it any other way.

Also, the Marauder fights are great. Ignore the naysayers!

review:
Fast paced action, new mechanics for survival and great attention to detail. 

The soundtrack makes the scenes come alive. One moment you're running and fragging, the other you're hunting for treasure and sometimes to progress it becomes a bit of a platformer having you make jumps and dashes to advance.

Find bots to unlock weapon mods.  Earn weapon points and spend them to upgrade mods.  Upgrade all the mods on each weapon to unlock masteries.

Find slayer keys to unlock slayer challenges.  Beat slayer challenges for empyrean keys.  Collect all the empyrean keys to unlock a new weapon.

Unlock your chainsaw, frag grenade, flamethrower, ice grenade, blood punch, dash, grappling hook, and crucible sword.  Find crystals to upgrade your health, armor, ammo, flamethrower, and punch.  Find praetor tokens to upgrade your suit.  Find batteries to upgrade your ship.  Find runes and create a loadout to unlock new powers.  Collect albums, "cheat codes", extra lives, toys, secret encounters, codexes, and mastery tokens hidden across every level.

Complete weekly challenges and missions for XP (do all 8 challenges in a week for extra XP!).  Play with friends for an XP booster.  Level up to unlock skins and cosmetic goodies.  Get different rewards every week.  Join the Bethesda Slayers Club.  Earn points to increase your rank.  Each rank unlocks skins, cosmetics, and merch discounts.

Oh and also it's a shooter sometimes.

MAYBE buy this! (just don't install it on an SSD)

Noticed it had Denuvo. Ok, I thought they'd remove it after a few weeks, like with Rage 2.
(I didn't want to start it up as I have it on my SSD, and Denuvo has a reputation for shredding SSDs)
They didn't.

DO NOT BUY THIS UNTIL THEY HAVE REMOVED ALL TRACES OF DENUVO!

Edit, Response to developer's comment:
Still. Has. Denuvo. Anti-Piracy.
Will BethSoft replace my SSD when Denuvo shreds it? I think not.
Will BethSoft pay for an upgrade for my rig because Denuvo tanks performance? I think not!

Until Denuvo has been removed, ALL OF IT, I cannot in good conscience recommend this game.

Doom is back and the thrilling and fast paced gameplay is also back, more so than the 2016 I would say. In Eternal you don't really find anything that will hinder your pace and there are no navigational challenges or puzzles to keep you in the same spot for any amount of time (I mean there are some but they are like finding the door knob to open a door so I'm not calling them puzzles).
You run through the level balls to the wall and the game is constantly throwing demons at you to mow down so you really do feel like the unstoppable force of anger issues, given the fact that this is mostly the reason we play Doom I would say it was successful on that front. 
I see some people complaining about the amount of ammo in the game and yes there are a lot less resources and you will run out if you don't mind the amount and the way you are using the ammo. But I didn't actually find this as a negative, quite the opposite: it gave me a reason to constantly switch between my weapons and actually use clever combos to shred the poor things to sticky mush in the most optimal way which was quite satisfying actually. The only qualms with the gameplay I have is that I never found much power ups, just a handful here and there (I think I used berserker powerup only once ONCE !) after some time I forgot to even look for them.
Lastly if I were to compare Eternal to 2016 (If I don't I can't say this game has any cons) the music and the ending was better in the 2016, honestly the blandness of the ending surprised me. But the entire gameplay wise I don't think Eternal would lose to 2016 also the story was quite a lot more engaging too. You get a lot of clarifications and backstory so everything in the Doom timeline starts to click into place.
Yes

Compared to Doom 2016 this game adds weapons, enemies and mechanics. Enemies can take body part damage and the game encourages this to lower enemy threat. Encounters require using more ammo than can be carried across all weapons and then replenishing ammo throughout. The game emphasizes awareness and reflexes.

After completing everything the game has to offer in its current state, I can say without a doubt one of the greatest FPS's, and most definitely the best DOOM game. If you're thinking about getting this game, just get it, it's too good to pass up. I've played through the single player campaign several times and it gets better every time; you know how to deal with certain enemies better, and you're just overall better at the game. The multiplayer is not as bad as some people say, although it does need a lot of balancing work. You more often than not queue with someone on the enemy team who is much higher level and skill than you and the game ends in three minutes, but those games where you do find someone of equal skill, it is very fun. If this game doesn't get best soundtrack of the year, we are gonna have a problem.

review:
I loved DOOM2016 but varied reviews kept me from getting Eternal on launch. After getting it on sale, I can only say that I made the right choice waiting for a price drop. Eternal is very different from 2016. The story, atmosphere and weapons are quite similar but the gameplay is very different.

First of all, this is a very platform heavy FPS. You will spend a large portion of the game jumping around. You got a double jump and a double dash which makes you very flexible. I mostly enjoyed the platforming, but at times it could be very hard to get where you need to go. I sometimes spent minutes looking around before noticing a tiny climb-wall in the very distance. Besides that there are many 'puzzles' in the game that have you looking for switches and draining water from pits and such. It's frankly very dull and it can definitely hurt the pacing of the game. It doesn't have to be 100% action but the puzzles felt boring and forced instead of actually fun. 

Most Enemies in Eternal have a certain weakness and this is very pronounced this time. You can still kill most of them just by pumping their body weight in lead into them, but it's not the best stategy. This does mean that the game can get a little chaotic. You're running around with a crazy amount of enemies attacking you from all sides and you're constantly switching weapons and trying to take out weak spots. 

Ammo is very very scarce especially in the beginning of the game before upgrades. You have to chainsaw demons to get ammo but sometimes the game doesn't spawn enough fodder. There were plenty of times where I was just dashing around with literally zero ammo in all my guns waiting for more chainsaw-fodder to spawn. I understand the idea behind the ammo scarcity, but I feel like they overdid it slightly. It's not that much fun, honestly.

The weapons are great. They all have good punch and good sounds and most of them have fun alternative fire modes. You can upgrade them in different ways. You can also upgrade your suit and find ruins, which are basically perks. It was surprisingly easy to upgrade everything fully, especially since you can replay missions with cheats on and get everything easily. 

I found upgrading everything very much needed for the last two missions which are ridiculous with the amount of enemies. I played on normal ("Hurt me Plenty") and usually had no trouble dying but I rushed through all my 13 extra lives in the second to last mission. Overall level design is amazing but some parts are too cramped for the amount of enemies that spawns, getting you stunlocked in a corner eating through your lives. 

Most enemies are fun to fight but I hated the marauder. This guy was fine as a boss but afterwards the game keeps throwing it at you combined with dozens of other enemies and it's just not fun as it requires constant focus. The re-use of bosses gets old quickly and I found myself annoyed instead of excited each time they spawned. The final boss was decent. The game is decently lengthy and worth the sales price for sure (I spent 15 hours but I replayed most levels to get secrets. Base game is probably around 8 to 10).

Overall I very much enjoyed Eternal but I must say I still prefer DOOM2016. It's way less in-depth, but honestly I liked that. I will definitely be playing through Eternal again with the cheat codes on, enjoying infinite ammo and just having mindless fun again instead of the regular gameplay which can get quite stressful at times.

If you're looking for a really polished and chaotic action game, behold, I recommend this masterpiece to you. 

My experience of the game was based on the ultra violence difficulty but my words will remain true throughout the review.

I like it how they have really limited ammo and you would actually have to plan strategically with your ammo.  There are a lot of things that have been added to the gameplay like the shoulder flamethrower and new demons that pose more as a challenge. This game also made it feel satisfying with all of the glory kills and with the realistic tear down of a demon as you quickly shoot away its (Quoting doom guy here) "big guts" . As of writing this review I haven't completed the single player and rage quit the game in frustration of not being able to clear out a certain section to at least get this review down. The game can have the casualness and action mixed together with lower difficulties and at least paying attention. Speaking of attention, I absolutely love that this game will make sure you aren't gunning down demons just by just shooting that shotgun at anything, they'll always make sure there's some big factor like the spiderdemon exist, it MAKES you pay attention which basically makes the game less boring. Lets switch over to performance terms. I ran this game on a:

I7 8700k
GTX 1060 3GB

Summarizing, it still has fun aspects but should not be a continuation of Doom 2016 and that's why I don't like it. Where Doom 2016 was a labor of love through and through, this really doesn't feel like it. I don't mind the difficulty, but your grand opening act is a bunch of burnt grey buildings? Weird Contra-style wall cannons that shoot on proximity? Monsters constantly fighting each other as you arrive on scene? Besides that, the tougher enemies are clearly presented with "this is how you kill them" pop-ups. Sometimes the camera is hijacked to show you the opening of a demon barrier. Not to mention plain grey room tutorial areas to take you right out of the game and the flow. Enemies seem to have a clear-cut singular way to kill them, otherwise they become bullet sponges. I learned that as the game throws more variations of enemy groups, your fun is in solving the weapon-monster matchup puzzle and doing it the same every time. In Doom 2016 you tended to go in head-first, kick ass as you see fit, and get glorious complex dynamic music as the soundtrack. Not to mention the high level of gameplay/level polish and immersion that this game seems to lack. The soundtrack dynamics are pretty much removed in Eternal and they just recycled the main theme for menu. When you look over the edge of your map some of the scenery in the distance just looks plain awful and I maxed the settings on a 1660super. I am wholly unimpressed, but like I said the gameplay still felt cool and fast. Reminds me of things like Unreal Tournament and other 90s shooters. Fast paced, never stop moving, you die quick, they die quick. That's the one aspect I liked, but as I read more user impressions this flow is later broken up by frustrating platforming. The game felt like: keep pulling that trigger, cheese the tough enemies with the right gun, don't stop moving, repeat. I figured I'd have more fun playing 2016 and refunded this.

Not for this price. Doom 2016 was glorious, the right balance of everything and gave us back hope in reboots done right.

While this is not awful, it's not at the same level, they tried to cram too much in it and made the fluidity and ambience of the previous game disappear, also the Quake3 Sauce UI/Pickups are an abomination.

The "strategic" way to use different weapons and skills on specific enemies get in the way of fast action and would've been way better as suggestions rather than super punitive obligations. To me, Doom should be "pick up your favourite weapons and destroy everything" now I feel myself stopping, having to hide and snipe little canons on mobs' heads.... it just doesn't work for me. The fact that melee is now seemingly only effective for glory kills is also disappointing.

I remember starting 2016 thinking... platforming? Oh hell no! Only to be surprised on how fluid it was and how it served gameplay well. Now? I seriously have no patience for your little bland jumping puzzles which just slow down my slaughter.

The music and sound design are also nowhere as powerful and serving the game as in 2016.

Writing this makes me wonder if I am an old fogey. I grew up on the classics DOOM and DOOM 2 and was thrilled by DOOM 2016' interpretation that brought the franchise into the modern era but without frills. DOOM Eternal still has those fast-paced, up-close, bloody firefights but complications have been added to the combat and most irksome of all they are spaced out by parkour sessions more at home in an Assassin's Creed title.

DOOM 2016 has a pretty simple combat system. You shoot the demons until they are almost dead and then you Glory Kill for a bloody finale. Mix in alternate fire and a grenade or two for spice and double jump to move around the battlefield. You won't often be low on Ammo but if you are, Chainsaw a demon or two.
DOOM Eternal adds:
- A flamethrower (on cooldown) which gives you Armor
- A double dash (on cooldown) which can be used on ground or air
- Blood Punch, a powerful punch which must be charged by getting Glory Kills
- Critical damage spots to aim for on certain demons
- Meat Hook to fly toward enemies
- Chainsaw being much more necessary since you will be frequently low on ammo
So there is a lot more for you think about during a fight. But I came here to shoot demons until they are dead. These extra mechanics add complexity and complication.

So I came here to shoot demons until they are dead. I definitely didn't come here to platform, climb up walls, and spin around poles. In between nearly every major combat there will be parkour areas you need to traverse. Exploration has always been a part of the franchise. But the timing component of platforming along with the new mobility mechanics, like air dashing and the Meat Hook, means you can get stumped by a jumping puzzle. And even just slowing me down is too much. Because jumping isn't what I came here for.

All in all, DOOM Eternal has occasionally given me the same rush that DOOM 2016 consistently did. Since it's a sequel the developers needed to add on. This undercut the strength of DOOM 2016, it's mechanical purity, and the add-ons have weakened Eternal. Maybe I am an old fogey for wanting simpler combat and exploration. But that's what DOOM 2016 delivered so I was hoping the thrill would still be there.

I'm really picky on FPS games, because alot of them feel extremely "cookie-cutter" as of late (i.e. COD, Battlefield)

Doom Eternal is the furthest thing from cookie-cutter. While the game itself isnt particularly hard, the fights are challenging and can be made even more difficult with increased difficulty scaling. I can easily say, its is the most fun FPS I've ever played, and I enjoy seeing how extreme things get with each progression in the game.

Also - the game runs fantastic on my system (running GTX 1070 and i7-6700 CPU at 2k resolution). One weird hiccup in the hours of playing, otherwise entirely smooth, and the computer isn't struggling and overheating like some other games (looking at you Borderlands 3)

Some small cons-
1) I do prefer the "style" of Doom 2016 over Eternal. Eternals graphics are better, but Doom felt darker/scarier.
2) Battlemode multiplayer is kinda hit or miss. I personally dont love it, but its interesting. Looking forward to Invasion mode when that comes out
3) Replayability sounds like it would be fun, but i can see it getting old quick. Granted, I haven't beaten the game yet, so ill come back and edit this after.

Some small cons

This game has exploding barrels!
It is the most feature rich barrel explosion simulator I've come across, which is significant considering I've never played a game that does not feature exploding barrels.  Notable examples:
Forge an alliance with the barrels so they only hurt your enemies, not you.
Bestow the barrels with ammo drops that you can pickup to use exploding MORE barrels.
Exploding barrel respawn!  There is an endless supply of exploding barrels in Hell somewhere, that helpfully teleport to the location of an exploded exploding barrel so you can explode it again and again.
A good attitude will always take you further than a bad habit

Having passed twice DOOM (2016) I took up Eternal. The same basic rules but the difference is in the details. To do this, compare between them:
- DOOM's reminiscent of Doom 3 with its style and decor. In Eternal, the atmosphere is more relegated to the background focusing on Doom 2 with its certain cartoonishness. You can get used to it.
- DOOM was quite dynamic requiring the use of at least a few weapons. Eternal also expanded this by adding weak points and footprints(which allow you to evaluate the health of opponents). At the same time, there is a restriction of cartridges for filling which you need to use a chainsaw more often. Due to the lack of ammunition, the game forces you to use the entire Arsenal.
P. s the First missions initially create a sense of discomfort due to the lack of Arsenal until we get most of it.

The most difficult thing is to "retrain" when you have to do it to achieve high efficiency in combat.

Interestingly, Eternal differs from DOOM, which is not like Doom 3 exactly like Doom 1&2&Final (There is also Doom 64). All of them... Different.

Is it worth playing? If you can quickly adapt to the new mechanics, you will get a lot of joy.

CAN be tons of fun, but even without dying, it just feels so messy all the way through. If Doom 2016 was like writing a story, Doom Eternal is like filing your taxes. Under time constraints. The fact that refilling armor and extra lives is a new mechanic just goes to show that this game is not about avoiding damage, because regarding the sheer amount of demons you are facing, this is utterly impossible, this game is about refilling your continously shrinking health and armor bars while coincidentally killing all enemies in the arena. That's not fun, that's not even strategical, it's just stressful and boring at the same time and not at all in line with the weapon-based focus of its predecessor. To win, press the buttons of all four abilities as soon as they have recharged like you're playing Overwatch. Weapons? We tell you what you may use against whom, and if you're out of ammo, well you didn't hammer the ability button enough like we told you. When I saw a group of enemies in Doom 2016, it was like a dish that made me rejoice in anticipation as I debated how I would take them out the slickest. When I see a group of enemies in Eternal, I look at my resource meters, spot the largest demon I currently see, and plan a route through the waves of trash to ensure that I'm not dead before I've killed my target, and then spend 50% of the time with my eyes on my abilties and resources to decide what I do in every given situation. Combat feels sloppy and chaotic instead of elegant, and it's not at all what I expected from a sequel. I can see that a lot of effort went into this and I am happy for everyone who thinks this is the best FPS ever made. I simply do not share that opinion at all. I bought this to play Doom, not Supermarioverwatch.
