Before i start, i love this game, and i recommend everyone playing this game as it has very good gameplay.

THIS REVIEW IS FOR SINGLE PLAYER ONLY

PROS:
Every mechanic has it's role, nothing is useless literally every tool that you have at your disposal you will use.
The biggest change from it's predecessor Doom (2016) it has reduced the amount ammo you have which gives the chainsaw a much more important role in the overall gameplay.

Low health and armor can be dealt with easier with the flame belch and the glory kill system, although the glory kill system hasn't changed one bit, the flame belch is something that you are entitled to when in combat.

The meat hook is a new addition to doom, you lock onto enemies with a massive hook that is under the super shotgun and grabs and pulls you towards enemies. This can be used to manoeuvre around the arena and figure out a plan.

Dashing is also a new mechanic which lets you move around much faster than usual.

The Maruder is a enemy introduced as a boss but becomes a rare enemy that will probably go down in the list of the fucking greatest enemies i have fought in a video game. There is plenty of different ways to fight him and i love that.

Scenery is beautiful it is astonishing how the world just blends in with the action. There isn't many games i just stop playing to look at the beautiful scenery.

Doom Eternal has a lot of action that lasts very long and is fun. Because of these long action parts of the game it should give you some relaxation, and it does. Platforming, doing puzzles and secrets is the pause from action which I personally like.

The also big but good change is the melee. Melee attack does next to nothing, but if you get enough glory kills it can contribute to a blood punch almost one hit killing a Hell Knight

More bosses would be great. This game takes much inspiration from old games and old games had bosses at almost every level.

Cons:
The purple goo is a slime which slows you down and limits you from jumping and holds you to the ground. There isn't many parts of the game which has Purple Goo but still takes the game down a step. I liked some parts of the purple goo but most of it is really just tedious. The thoughts behind purple goo isn't bad, believe me I didn't have a problem with it at start. But now playing it again and seeing how the purple goo limits you from exploring and playing the game differently isn't good because playing the game different is the hugest and greatest part of Doom Eternal in my opinion.

The Archvile and Cyber Demon is not how they was expected to be. The Archvile used to be a very hard enemy in Doom 2 which when you look at him your player would burn. Now he is a spawner. That is very disappointing. The Cyber demon used to be this big demon that would beat your ass and punish you for mistakes you made when fighting him. Now he is like a big tower in the middle of the arena that is easy as hell to kill. I think I have died more to a fodder than this fucking tower.

Additions:
A horde survival mode where you are in an arena fighting demons as long as you can. Because the game has 13 long levels and a multiplayer which is barely fun. To keep up the replay value this addition would be great.

It may be only me wanting this, but a coop campaign (which is also Lan supported) would be so fun. Exploring the game with your friends would be pretty sick.


Thank you for your time of reading my review! I hope you have a great day

Mood, controls, degrees of freedom, challenge, and pacing; these are crucial elements of video games. 

The mood is overwhelming. A ceaseless attention to detail and current, hypnotic riffs bolster the cruel reality described by the lore. The controls are fluid and grant the player near limitless creativity. Each battle is a thoughtfully crafted theater of blood. The level of freedom seen by the player is very high. The upgrade/leveling system allows for childlike experimentation. Choices are rarely punished, and the "meta" is nowhere to be seen. Whether FPS, arena shooter god or still getting used to that whole "feet move one way, head moves the other" thing, there is a difficulty setting available, and each are finely tuned for challenging,   but not punishing, play. Finally, the tempo is decided by the audience. Make haste and brutally dominate all in one's way, or take a bit of time to do some item hunting. In this dynamic symphony of death, you are the conductor. 

10/10 would DOOM again.

I truly loved my time playing this game. I would, however, like to leave some areas where I think it could improve (as well as leave some minor personal nitpicks).

Nitpick: I do not like the introduction of fantasy elements. It is not a huge deal, and I can get over this, but I much prefer the pure satanic sci-fi aesthetic of Doom 2016.

I do not like the abandonment of of the doom 2016's style of storytelling. It was great that the slayer had a "I don't give a f*ck" attitude in that game, but that is almost nowhere to be seen in this game. I don't like that they take themselves seriously in Eternal (Minor SPOILER  [spoiler]especially in the scene where the slayer talks, ugh... [/spoiler]). There are too many cut-scenes that don't really add anything at all. These pointless cut-scenes (the lore/world-building cut-scenes) should be optional and out of the way, like codex entries. Don't  get me wrong, there ARE important scenes (chiefly the ones that highlight the villain) that I do feel appropriate for the games' story, but more often than not the scenes are just... tedious. 

The new platforming element in level design didn't add anything for me. I did enjoy these new movement options in combat, though. Even though I wasn't excited by the platforming, I do think that the grappling hook having no use outside of combat is a missed opportunity in level design. 

I really and truly hated the return of the pop-up tutorials that were first introduced in Rage 2. Just let the player learn the guns and the demons on their own (or read up on them), don't force 'em by pausing the damn game every time.

SPOILER: [spoiler] I am disappointed I can't fight/kill Samuel Hayden. The bastard... [/spoiler]

Another minor nit-pick: I miss the summoner demon from Doom 2016. I think it could fill a niche that the Archvile does not.

Minor Boss SPOILER: [spoiler] I did not enjoy the gladiator boss battle. Arena is too small and restrictive, which is the opposite of modern Doom combat. [/spoiler]

The marauder is not very fun, and it just wastes my time. There was no sense of accomplishment after killing him. One can use certain use spammy tactics against him (so they will), but that is  a symptom, not the problem. The problem is that his design is too linear, it tries to force the player too much. Let me be a resource sink as well as his current design.

Over-all, the game is great and has amazing fluid combat that can make you feel like a god. I easily can recommend it despite the issues have brought up here. You just can't get this type of game-play anywhere else.

review:
Doom is truly eternal. The series laid dormant after Doom 3 attempted to turn it into a slow-paced horror shooter; whether you liked D3 or not, Doom took a long slumber for over a decade. In 2016, it returned as DOOM, the annoyingly-titled soft reboot that had a ton to prove, and still managed to exceed expectations; it wasn't just an excellent shooter that proved old-school arcadey shooters are still relevant, but it proved to the world that iD is still a legendary team. After Doom 3 and RAGE, iD had a lot to prove, to themselves and to everyone.

So, here we are now; DOOM Eternal in 2020. How do I put this game simply?

Well...if DOOM 2016 was iD showing the world that they're still relevant, DOOM Eternal is telling [i]the universe[/i] that iD is once again a legendary studio. Despite their ups and downs and RAGE and---God forbid---RAGE 2, iD has put together nothing short of the best shooter of the generation. Forget grey-brown military shooters, forget The Order, forget all of that nonsense, because DOOM Eternal is THE shooter.

The game is an unabashed celebration of the FPSes of yore; if Doom and Quake had a baby, then that baby was given a BFG-9000, you'd probably get something like this game.

The story is actually pretty great this time around. iD took the feedback from DOOM 2016 (unskippable long cutscenes where someone just talks to you for 10-15 minutes) and embraced it; the story is much tighter, has better pacing, there's more and better-written lore (all optional and not really required to understand the plot), and the best part: YOU CAN SKIP CUTSCENES. ALL OF THEM. If you wanna just RIP AND TEAR through the game, and damn the plot, just hold R during a cutscene and it'll skip it, even if it's your first time watching the scene.

The gameplay is pure brutality and mayhem, as you tear through Hell's hordes! I'm not gonna spoil any of your arsenal, because 90% of the fun is playing with the guns in this game. Try everything out; you'll need them all!

The platforming is much better than it was in DOOM 2016. No more instant-death traps, no more "Welp, I messed up the jump but I'm just too floaty to control myself, guess I'll die", none of that. You have two charges of a dash to navigate levels and battlefields, a double-jump right out the gate, and a lot more control over the DOOM Slayer in general. Moving about the level has a kind of hypnotic satisfaction, just double-jumping, dashing, grabbing ledges and swinging on monkey bars; it all feels good.

Honestly, I don't even have anything to really complain about with this game. Even after getting thrashed by the Marauders over and over (and BODY-BLOCKED BY THEIR WOLF AGAIN), once I take 10-15 minutes to calm down or even just take a second attempt at the fight, my vitriol gets drained immediately because clearing each fight, finding the secrets, it's all just so satisfying that I can't complain about when the game hits a little road bump.

Absolutely worth $60, and if you can get it at a discount, it's a must-buy.

review: This game taught me whenever I see a crack in the wall to punch it..

I like this game and I recommend it, however I'd say it's more of a 7/10 than a 9/10 as a lot of other people seem to think. I still think Doom (2016) was better overall but Doom Eternal is still a pretty dang good successor if I'm being honest.

What I like:

The gunplay of Doom is unmatched by any other game. For over 27 years Doom has been the gold standard for the FPS genre, in fact for a while any FPS game released was just called a "Doom Clone" and Doom Eternal takes the formula established by the other games and injects it with cocaine and steroids. The gameplay is so smooth and fluid in [i]most[/i] places that it honestly feels more like a souped up version of old school Quake than a Doom game. my words don't do the gameplay justice. Seriously try it out.

The story is also pretty good but it's pretty much optional, if you're just looking for a game to where you can turn your brain off and have fun, you can do that here [i]for the most part[/i].

What I hate:

Doom Eternal has one of the most finely tuned movement systems of any FPS game I have ever played and it's a lot of fun to mess around with. My problem is that it's held back by the level design. There are invisible walls, everywhere. Like you gave me this really neat kit and expect me to not try and use it? The level designs are super linear and samey because of this and they don't have to be. It's a lot of fun grabbing a cacodemon with the Super Shotgun and flinging yourself to another enemy. But you'd be hard pressed if you wanted to grab the cacodemon expecting to move around the level. I guess I'm super used to other games offering multiple solutions to a singular problem, in DE however all the puzzles have one solution and one solution only, meaning there isn't a ton of replay value unfortunately. 

Then there is probably (from what I can tell) the most polarizing enemy in all of Doom, i.e, you think it's really easy, or really overpowered. (spoilers ahead) [spoiler] The Marauder. Now I can see the purpose of the Marauder from a game design standpoint, it's a way to get the player to slow down and use their head a bit and pay more attention to what's going on in the battlefield. This sounds good in theory but in reality it feels kind of out of place in a doom game. For 27 years the Doom series has rewarded players for taking initiative. "Go get in a fight! Be proactive!". In reality the Marauder forces the player to be [i]reactive[/i], if this were a reactive game like say, Dark Souls or Super Smash Bros. this would be fine. But it really disrupts the flow of gameplay and is quite annoying to deal with when you see one. If it were a one off boss fight it would have been fine, but there are at least 2 per level and it gets old quick. [/spoiler]

TL;DR:

Doom Eternal is an amazing game that's held back by some rather poor and out of place game design decisions. Nevertheless I think the precedent established by this game will help inspire ID and other studios to further innovate game design disciplines and techniques. This game makes me super excited for what games in the future will be like.

This game was a lot of fun, a big improvement from DOOM (2016). The movement additions, the new weapons, and even finding the collectibles was fun. One common criticism of the game is the parkour, which I didn't think was bad at all. Most people say that it's boring or unintuitive but I have to disagree. The parkour was really easy, and but it still felt satisfying to pull off. It only really added to my enjoyment of the game. When it comes to being unintuitive, that can be a fair point. The only criticism I could really give to it, is that grabbing onto a wall should be automatic all the time instead of just dashing into it. The game tells you to press E next to mountable walls, but if you dash into a wall you hop on automatically. This should be the default, and it'd make these sections more fluid. The guns were pretty fantastic, a big improvement from the last game. It does suffer from a similar issue from the last game, which is that some mods are just better the alternatives. Some examples:

Combat Shotgun: The sticky bombs don't use any more ammo then a normal shot, and they're great for crowd control early on.

Heavy Machine Gun: This weapon is one of my favorites for it's scope alone, getting rid of weak points is super satisfying. Honestly if it was a sniper rifle i'd enjoy it just as much, if not more since there could be interesting mods for it.

Plasma Gun: The stun from the beam cannon saved my life from some of the larger enemies a couple of times throughout my playthrough. Whenever I ran out of ammo for my standard shotgun it was also very useful for crowd control.

Ballista: The hell wave was immensely satisfying whenever I got a chance to use it. Clearing out every single enemy infront of me and seeing everything cut in half was always a blast.

Super Shotgun: The meat hook was perfectly executed. Grabbing onto a Tyrant and running circles around him, or latching onto an Arch Vile right before he finishes summoning were some of the highlights that made my day.

The Chain Gun: The pure destructive power of this gun is great on it's own but once you remove the cooling it's probably my favorite gun in the game.

BFG: Classic, near the end of the game you have to fight two Doom Hunters at the same time and throwing them into the second phase instantly is just one of the times this gun has saved my ass.

Unmaker: Really disappointing, I was only able to use it during the Icon of Sin fight. It was hyped up the entire game and I don't know what I was expecting but it sure as hell wasn't this. It's not bad, and the slayer gates were amazing so it wasn't a chore to get but I really wish it was something more exiting.

The best part of the game for me was the weak points that specific enemies had. I mentioned this before but the sound for sniping those off made the game a lot more exiting for me, especially in the slayer gates on higher difficulties. The only thing I thought was genuinely bad was the Marauder enemy. Sometimes he'd telegraph an attack and then pull out his shield, or whenever I had shot him when I was supposed to he wouldn't become stunned so i'd still take damage. The worst thing he did was run up to me and then do his shotgun move, which is supposed to punish players that get too close to him so it doesn't give you an opportunity to shoot at all. There were a lot of times where I just had to get hit because I couldn't avoid it. Another thing is that the BFG and Unmaker have no effect on him whatsoever, which was really annoying because I had such a problem with him. The only thing I could do was spam grenades on his dog and keep out the super shotgun anytime I saw him, because it was the most consistent weapon to fight him with. Overall: 8/10

[h1]First-person Darksiders with more guns?[/h1]

I'll get this out of the way immediately: this game is fun but does not feel like a DOOM game. 

You know what I want and expect out of a DOOM game? Speed and violence, a few secrets, and one or two puzzles to progress areas. You know what totally kills the idea that you're this unstoppable killing machine? Pausing to read walls of text to figure out what this heck has happened because the lore is now suddenly existent, horribly long platforming sections (which felt more frequent and longer than combat...), and this weird rotation of abilities that is more reminiscent of playing WoW than any previous DOOM game. 

Slayer Gates were what I expected out of the main game's big arena fights, not optional content that is intentionally harder. During the main campaign these [i]six[/i] encounters were where I had the most fun. Replaying missions with infinite ammo on to avoid the ammo famine loop let me focus on approaching encounters how I wanted to rather than how I was forced to which made the underwhelming encounters significantly more exciting. The platforming should have been gutted.

I can't begin to explain how bad the last two boss fights were. 

The game's design does work smoothly and I didn't have a single performance issue (never dropped below 144 fps on highest settings). If this game had been a different franchise (rather than one which has existed for 27 years without God of War platforming or Darksiders lore and is still celebrated for its simplicity) I'd probably have nothing but praise. Instead I'm reminded of how disappointing DOOM 3 was too.

It's a rock paper scissors version of doom that removes all the pick up and play fun of hte orginal. Too many buttons, to many quick time events, too many gun alternatives. How many fucking buttons do we need to throw a grenade?

I just want to mow down shit with a machine gun, not parkour through an overly complex 3d maze with annoying ammo restraints.

From the get go the mouse lags in the menu, everything feels clunky and over developed. I can't even put my finger on it, but the last doom was a total masterpiece from start to finish.

Would not recommend, unless you enjoy memorizing bland rock paper scissor counters and endless jump puzzles and gimmicky progression. It's a non stop little mini game of saving up just enough amo to kill the next few enemies before you have to pilfer more in some bizzare half assed clone of the original. On paper all these changes sound like they're good, but you never have the feeling of having a large ammount of ammo to mow thrrough hordes of enemies with amazing powerful weapons. It's a non stop swap fest quick time event ad nausium from the very start.

This isn't doom. The reviews are terribly overblown.

If you liked Doom 2016, this is a more refined version of that, If you didn't like Doom 2016 give this a try. It feels a bit closer to the classic dooms with a lot more mobility thrown in. 

Always remember, your chainsaw is your source of ammo! If there's a low ammo warning popping up a lot that means you forgot about your chainsaw. Make chainsawing small fries a habit and you'll never be out of ammo!

I was hesitant to get it because I was told I would need a Bethesda launcher. That was apparently only true if you don't buy the game on Steam. After you boot up the game you can either log into or create a Bethesda account. That's all you need to play. No launcher is needed. I wish I had known this sooner.

Overall a damned fine Doom experience!

Had fun with Doom, Doom Eternal not so much.

[Overall] Just feels like a slog thru so much muck and confusion that we never stop and say, "that was fun." Way too much stuff happening. Too many buttons. Too many attacks. A couple extra jump features.
Aside from the main weapon line, they throw everything else at you in the first few maps.
No chance to learn. Poorly designed campaign for all but the most avid speed-FPS gamers.

[Game-play] is so overly intense as to cross the line into just plain sloppy. We then either play at ridiculous challenge levels or nerf the difficulty and play with horrendous slop (demons literally on top of you with others shooting you and still you just don't die.)

[Visuals] Graphics are AAA. Cool giant monsters and mechs litter the landscape. Better scenery than the last game; slightly worse unit skins. Strangely, they've done something with the creature "looks". Don't know what it is, but something's just off a little bit; weird since it was far less noticeable in the last game.



8 weapons, each with a couple of useful mods
3 melee attacks, each requires (health/armor/ammo) regular use
2 grenades (each cycling independently; both required to use since there's never enough ammo)
We're looking at 13-18 useful attacks. Not to be varied using one load-out per map or situation, but all 18 need to be fully incorporated into each level.

I'm 7 hours and a few levels (and 1 restart) in and considering calling it quits.

review:
The Good: 
The environments look better, and there are more of them.
It’s nice to see more enemies.
There is like one more boss fight, which was nice.
Movement is a lot faster, which gives the player more options to kill.
There is a sense of a larger universe, which they can expand on. 
There is a story (if you want to get the most out of it, you have to read the codex)  
More weapon attachments.
Enemy AI is a lot more intelligent than in Doom 2016.

The Bad: 
For some reason the boss fights are are not as hard as some of the Heavy enemies you encounter.
The Marauder is a massive piece of s**t (You will see)
The 2nd final and the final boss are almost the same, you shoot armor, and then you kill them. 
You can get stuck on terrain and other objects.
The climbing could be better.
In order to get the most out of the story, you must read all of the codex entries, which is a bit lazy by Id software. 
Demons which look like you would require no more than 2 chainsaw ammo might require a lot more.

Its a very good game. The ammo capacity makes it better as it forces you to stop spamming your favourite gun and differ your playstyle. There is a story if you want it but it still makes somewhat sense if you have no intent of reading the data logs. It is more challenging then 2016 and in my opinion that makes it better. 2016 was somewhat easy. Spam gause cannon and chaingun. Spam hologram and rocket. Cycle and repeat. Eternal makes you move and dance and really makes sure you use your environment correctly. Weakpoints are also a good addition. This is an amazing fast paced FPS game that scraps most of the annoying features of new FPS games to make a pure fun experience, is it the most competitively viable game, no, is it really fun, yeah. This game really makes you FEEL like Doomguy. 10/10 - IGN

Jokes aside, there are several pros and cons when comparing this game to the 2016 version.

Pros:
- Feel and flow of combat has been cranked up past 11 all the way to 666
- The polish of this game is damn near perfect
- Music is just as badass if not more badass than the original OST in some cases
- The sound design of weapons and abilities is somehow even meatier and punchier than before
- Enemy variety has been more than doubled
- Chainsaw now activates the same way as a melee
- Upgrades are more plentiful and more meaningful 
- Chasing collectibles is actually fun now
- Weapon skins and Doomguy skins pogchamp

Cons: 
- Weapon ammo has been reduced across the board (however, in favor of being able to counter enemies with different weapons)
- Story feels kinda corny... but you're not here for the story
- Marauder kinda ruins the flow of combat most of the time
- Final Boss fight is a trainwreck 
- No arcade mode, but there are "cheat codes" now I guess

All in all, it's just more DOOM. If you loved the first game and you don't already own this one, I don't really know what you're doing with your life.

I've only played a couple minutes of Doom here and there before.  I vaguely recall playing Doom 64 possibly.  I picked this up after a friend recommended it.

On Normal difficulty it's fun.  Good challenge.  Neat power ups.  The glory kills are a great time.  Love the animations for those.

Despite being linear, the levels give lots to explore, which is nice.  A level will take me about an hour or two to beat.    I've played for 9 hours, and I just finished level 5, not sure how much more there is in the game.

I'm not a fan of the multiplayer.  Two demons vs one slayer.  Neat concept, but there's no even matchmaking.   As a new player I got my but handed to me by a level 58.

I picked this up for $30 when it was on sale, I would say it's a solid purchase for that price.

(Updated post Denuvo (HISS))
Probably the best FPS I have ever experienced. As someone who has been into the occult shooter for a long ass time, a lover of the original Doom games, the mods, Doom 3, DOOM, and so many other shooters that I cannot possibly name right now... this was an absolute treasure. 

I must admit, I was cocky and thought I could just throw on the second highest difficulty and I'd be okay. The game KICKED MY ASS every level and I LOVED IT. I've never been beaten so entirely by a game and enjoyed breaking through it's challenges.

Yes. Marauders are massive bullshit, but they are an interesting addition and not a staple. 
Yes, the final boss engagement was lack luster. Yes, the outro was meh, but more is coming, is it not?

Also if you want a guide on how NOT to play DE, go watch Upper Echelon Gamers' review on it. If anything, it's a good laugh.

After playing this game 3 times on console, and starting my 4th playthrough on PC, I think I have some qualifications to review this game.
DOOM Eternal is the best shooter this generation, and quite possibly THE best shooter on the market, period. id Software have outdone themselves once again, raising the bar for quality in the shooter genre and the video game industry as a whole like its the '90s all over again. The gameplay is so refined and excellently crafted, every part of it is done deliberately and with purpose and care and it shows so much. DOOM Eternal takes everything DOOM 2016 did and blows it out of the goddamn water. It takes 2016s speed, intensity and pure ferocity and amplifies it a thousandfold, making 2016 look like a slowpoke baby game. Musically, I think this is Mick Gordon's best work, usurping Killer Instincts' spot as my favorite of his. The more electronic sound of 2016 is put in the backseat a bit, and the heavy metal sound that 2016 was seemingly afraid to show off is put front and center with Eternal. Honestly, I can't even poorly describe how I feel about it like I did with the gameplay, you'll just have to play the game yourself to find out(or listen to the soundtrack on SoundCloud since its not officially released yet).

Review over 10/10 buy the game you fool.

If you're a fan of the original Doom, Doom2 and then the GZDOOM, Brutal Doom and Project Brutality mods, then this is kind of a "mish mash" of all of those with a lot of "hand holding" thrown in. As in "Go here" and "do this" Add in a little bit of Quake style gameplay, add in some really unnecessary pixel perfect platforming jumps - in order to progress - and you have?  pretty much what this is.. A "mish mash" that I'm not really sure quite what to think of.

But my biggest BIGGEST Bugbear by a long way - is the checkpoint system which forces you to repeat a level over and over again should you misjudge some jump or not spot something. Granted you're given another chance (albeit with diminished health) but seriously? Let me save the damn game. WHERE I WANT TO. Seriously FUCK checkpoints.

Graphics wise? It's fabulous. Pace wise it's about right. It's not a walking-flash-light-simulator-new-engine-show-off like the gawd awful Doom3. which Carmack left to his own devices, created. There IS a pleasant fast fluidity of movement and the controls (mouse + keyboard -what else would you use?) feels "right"

Would I recommend it?

If you love GZDOOM, Brutal Doom / Project Brutality. You'll likely be disappointed. So  I'd give it a "No" Those mods offer FAR better and challenging gameplay (imho) with a vibrant and lively community behind them. 

If you're new to the Genre. Go ahead & buy it! It#s currently on sale at the time of writing  and at 50% off,  it's a buy.

As is. I'll reluctantly give it a "thumbs up"  but it's more of an overall "hmmmmm" ? Not sure

DOOM Eternal plays out as a great sequel to the 2016 DOOM, featuring fast-paced combat, djent synthetic metal and unforgiving enemies to fight. The combat in this game plays similar to DOOM, but with small changes to keep the movement system fresh but similar to fans of the predecessor. Whilst the weapon system can seem overbearing, the ability to easily use the chainsaw over time allows you to use preferred weapons easily, and feel like a badass doing so. As introduced in the DOOM 2016, glory kills are reanimated, new and epic, giving the player the feeling of actually ripping out a Cacodemon's eye. Sound design is awesome, to the weaponry, demons or even the environment around you, this game keeps you immersed with the various realms of hell and the seemingly innocent plain of Urdak. Also, lore in this game is extremely in-depth, as entries into the codex allow the option for the player to explore more into the backstory of the Doomguy, Hell's presence on Earth, or just the various demons that you encounter on your rampage through the story. On the other hand, music in this game is extraordinary, as the predecessor, DOOM 2016, has proven before that Mick Gordon's brilliance on the mixture of different metal genres, gives you the badass feeling when playing this game, making it a core part of the experience overall. Lastly, the game includes a 3v1 multiplayer for you to play against your friends, or other randoms around the world. While it can be confusing to play, some find it fun, but the core value of DOOM Eternal is it's driving story. With the first expansion coming soon to the game, The Ancient Gods: Part 1, this game sure has the ability for a sequel, and is waiting for more content.

Doom Eternal is a fantastic game! I only wish there were more levels to play. I'm currently replaying the missions on Ultra-Violence, since I have all the upgrades now. I definitely recommend upgrading your slayer before trying the harder difficulties. 

This fast-paced FPS is definitely challenging, but I like that about it. You can't just mindlessly mow down your enemies. You have to be strategic about your ammo consumption and which abilities/guns you use.

IMO they improved upon the 2016 version in every way. They introduced some exciting new enemies and throw them at you more and more as you progress through the game. The final boss fight is just ridiculous, but they give you a way to beat it if you have trouble. 

The Marauder is by-far the most brutal addition to the game. The super-shotgun is your best friend to take him down. Though, it will take some practice to get proficient at killing him. I will say I managed to kill one in under 30 seconds with some practice and some luck lol. 

I see some folks aren't a fan of the 'parkour' they introduced. I really did not mind this addition. I think it helped break up the intense fight sections. Sure, I definitely died quite a few times from falling, but it just resets you pretty close and you lose some health. You need to do it to find all the secrets and level up your slayer. Once you know what you're doing, you can breeze through these parkour sections on subsequent playthroughs. 

A must-buy for any fans of fast-paced shooters. I grabbed it on sale, but I think its worth the full price.

Ok so i'd like to revise my previous review about this game, previously I complained about denuvo, since then, that has been removed, however, the game now suffers from frequent crashes after slayer gates, its unstable, with i'd say one random crash every 3 hrs of gametime.

However, the combat is really good, and i really mean that it's really good. I got no other reason to play this game other than its combat, cause it sucks in many other regards.

The music has also proven quite dissapointing compared to doom 2016, with a weak sense of escalation, the music has suffered alot. Its way too much in your face, and that becomes repetitive quite soon.

In 2016, the music only "kicked in" for about 15 seconds during each fight, and those 15 seconds were the shit, however, in eternal its in your face, all the time.

This game was a faster, better, and more difficult version of DOOM 2016. Between the two games, this one took everything its prequel did right and make it bigger and better, and took what it did wrong and learned from it. I was especially happy with the automap/exploration features (being a completionist), which I felt allowed for more actual exploration, instead of looking at "collectible walkthroughs" like I did in the prequel. I would argue this game is worth full price if you're interested in the multiplayer, but if you're buying for the campaign (undoubtedly the best part) like me, I'd buy it on sale.

It definitely has the right vibe for an Id Software game.  My only negative feedback is I'm not a fan of all the platforming and Spider Man jumping you have to do to navigate some of the levels. At the time of this writing, I'm about 11 hours in and have made it through 2 or 3 Single Player Missions in the Campaign.  

For me:
Pros 
- Excellent graphics (RTX2060 Super 8GB)
- Phenomenal  Music
- Fast-Paced Play
- Moderately Difficult Even on the Easiest Settings (Waves of random spawning enemies really bring back the nostalgia for me)
- Cut-scenes are really well done and look great

Cons:
- Not a fan of the platforming (Parkour) or however you want to refer to it.
- Some of the climbing walls are not obvious and you can get stuck or lost in a level quick if you don't look around
- Chainsaw requires fuel so you can't use it at will unless you keep finding fuel for it
- (My own opinion) A little too much focus on melee combat.  I've personally always considered Doom to be first and foremost a shooter with some chainsaw thrown in for flavor.  

Overall, I do like the game and will be playing it completely through the single-player campaign as well as going back for the completionist in me to get all the rewards and achievements available for non-PVP/non-multiplayer modes.  I've been a huge fan of Id Software from the very beginning back in the 1990's and after playing through roughly 1/3 to 1/2 of this iteration of Doom, I'm still a fan of Id Software.  I'd really like to see more from you guys in the future.

Hell yeah for insane optimization, runs like silk on my 3 y.o laptop and looks stunning. Everything else in the game is as hell of game as optimization. id Software know what their doing. 

The the coolest thing are all those small game mechanics innovations, which I won't go into detail here, cause it's fun discovering it.

Doom Eternal is best singleplayer game I have ever played (OK, tied best with Amid Evil). I love games where every  moment, you are on a knife edge between life and death and careless mistakes get you killed fast and I also love fast paced games that throw you in large levels filled with enemies where you have to rely on skill and nothing else to survive. Doom Eternal caters to my needs perfectly.

The game is very difficult, but that may have something to do with me playing on Nightmare difficulty for my first playthrough, but so far, I haven't died for something that wasn't my fault and its never taken more than a dozen attempts to beat an arena.

There have been a lot of complaints about this game comparing it to Doom '16 and how its not more of the same, but I found that game very easy filled with slow, easy to kill enemies and while it was fun while it lasted, it wasn't a memorable experience for me. In Eternal, all the parts of '16 that I liked have been greatly expanded and improved on and the parts I didn't have been improved or cut out entirely. the new platforming is fine I guess, I dont mind it, but I dont much care for it either. I would prefer some light corridor combat against low level enemies to act as a "breather" between the large arena battles. I would say thats the only point '16 has over Eternal.

With this game currently half off for the Quakecon sale, theres no better time to pick this up.

This game is fantastic. It is everything you want from a shooter. You can't however say it's mindless violence as in the higher difficulty levels every fight requires you to be fully present - mastering the combos and your resources is incredibly challenging, yet also immensely satisfying.
great fast paced 1st person shooter great for the classic series

Absolutely different to Doom 2016, doesn't catch at all. Don't feel any story behind. Just primitive "run, jump, shoot". It's strange there is no some mushrooms that you need to hit by your head to knock out extra ammo
This game is fantastic and makes you feel like unstoppable killing machine the whole way through. Also has a secretly really deep story if you read all of the logs.
Since the spyware was removed, I'm once again very happy with this game.

It's been a bit since I updated my review of Doom Eternal.  I gave it a thumbs down when the Denuvo Anti-Cheat software was added.  With the update, that was removed.  

Doom Eternal is a great game.  I cannot deny that fact.  What I also cannot deny is the drop in quality with each successive update, for me at least. 

In the beginning, Doom Eternal stood on solid ground.  It was fun; it was fast paced; it was awesome to behold the Doom Slayer in all his adrenaline fueled, monstrous rage, ripping and tearing through hordes of enemies.  There was one or two little issues, but those were beyond negligible.  

What has happened, as others have pointed out, seems to be a steady decline into uncertainty.  First issue that came to light was the freezing whenever I tried to take a screen shot.  It spooked the crap out of me when the game went dark.  When I tried to re-load the game, it kept going to black screen.  I tried to fix it by uninstalling then reinstalling the game.  It still didn't work.  What fixed it was right-clicking on the Doom Eternal game, going to properties, local files, and directly loading Doom Eternal via the application.  

The more research I did, the more I found out this was due to a conflict with Steam Overlay where you can't use F12 or [insert key bind of your preference] to take screen shots.  No big deal, it doesn't ruin the game.  I'd like to take some screen shots, but, again, no big deal. 

On the otherhand, what has caused Doom Eternal to degrade for me in terms of enjoyment and replay value (replayability) are the new bugs that seemed to crop up with each new update.  One example is during the ARC facility when I go to exit the garage and into the main area before proceeding to the ARC HQ.  On two, near three separate occasions the game has booted me back to desktop.  This is one major gripe, and it's not the only instance of this happening.    

Another issue happened during the first portion of Taras Nabad.  The gates opened.  The Marauder came out.  I was victorious and stabbed him through his eye socket! The problem? Combat music was still on.  Why is it still on? Well, I look up to see a dang Pinkie stuck in the wall near the gate doing ****ing ballet, almost laughing at me that it's untouchable.  (It seems this issue might have been fixed where demons will die if they are stuck in wall or out of bounds for X amount of time.) 

What I'm getting at is the sheer disappointment I have for a game such as Doom Eternal.  It started of grand, almost untouchable.  Now it seems like a former shell of itself with the bugs, glitches, and general plague of nuances.  Other games I have run fine.  

Overall, I'd be cautious about Doom Eternal.  It has typical Bethesda issues/bugs.  However, the core game is rock solid.  

I'd recommend the game despite the current issues.  And though I recommend the game, I give that recommendation with caution.  Expect bugs, don't use Steam Overlay to take screenshots as it will cause issues/crashes.  

Grade Wise, it has gone down from a solid 10, but it's still good. (8.5/10) 

TL;DR
Decent game, updates caused more issues than fixed some, imho.  Requires the most up-to-date graphics card drivers for Nvidia (no big deal).  Since it is on sale right now during the Quake Con event (writing this 8/8/2020), I'd say get it or wait till it is on sale the next time around during Halloween, Xmas, or whatever.      



Computer Specs for those curious: 
Intel core i9-7900x CPU stock 3.30GHZ cooled with 360mm fan (10xcore with Hyper Thread)
W10 OS 64bit 
Nvidia GeForce GTX 1080 graphics card, updated drivers (PCI Express 16x)
Memory: (32gb) (Would need to pull info on latency/etc...) 
Running SSD for Steam with M.2 installed in EVGA X299 dark MB for OS

Doom 2016 was one of the best fps games of the last decade, and an excellent re-invention of the franchise. It was fast, fluid, looked beautiful, had great combat and a near perfect balance between corridor shooting and arena encounters. It also had a decent, unobtrusive story that was well presented. Doom Eternal has almost none of that. Yes it's fast, but just about everything else about it is significantly worse. The combat has been significantly changed - there's now virtually no corridor shooting, with almost every encounter being a succession of arena combats. Furthermore, the difficulty level has been ramped up to almost comical levels. The Doom Slayer has gone from being a demon killing badass into a one hit kill mobile punching bag. The number of enemies on screen at once has been significantly increased, but so has the level of demon. Rather than facing a gradually increasing hierarchy of demons over the course of the game, almost from the get go you'll be swamped by imps, arachnotrons, cacodemons, mancubi, hell knights and god knows what else - all in the same fight, often with more than one of each and several at the same time. To top this off, your ammo levels have been drastically reduced (in the first game you start off with 20 shotgun shells, and each upgrade gives 10 more. Here you start off with 16 and each upgrade gives you TWO(!) more), and armour and health disappear almost immediately. This means every fight becomes a desperate encounter for survival in which you're constantly running out of ammo and down to 1 health with no armour, and the only way to survive is to use the correct take downs to add just enough to keep going for a few shots more. On top of the stressful and frustrating combat, level design is generally greatly simplified save for the completely weird addition of endless environmental puzzles and platforming. These feel completely out of place in an fps and again it's difficult to understand why anyone at ID thought this was a good idea. Other letdowns include the graphics and general design - for some reason textures are significantly worse than in 2016, and several graphics options have been removed. Furthermore, the cool immersive storytelling from the first game (e.g. physically ripping the shotgun out of someone's dead hands,) has gone, with all items and power-ups now looking like poorly modelled icons. I kid you not, secret items are now just large, yellow floating question marks - I genuinely thought someone had left placeholder art in the game by mistake the first time I saw one. The levels themselves look for the most part like large, empty rooms. You start off coming to Earth and fighting through a ruined city. This amounts to a few simple, remarkably clean and tidy office buildings. Where is all the blood? Where are the dead bodies that littered the floor like in the first one? Finally, the story. 2016 had a fairly straightforward story with a limited number of characters, and some interesting back story hidden in codexes if you wanted to seek it out and learn more.  Eternal doesn't pick up directly after the first game, instead seeming to skip ahead an unspecified amount of time. Earth has now been almost entirely overrun by hell when the Doom Slayer suddenly arrives in orbit in some kind of weird flying castle. Where did this come from? Why does it have Vega on board?  Other than this strange disconnect, the game hamfistedly introduces a huge amount of back story - apparently the Doom Slayer is now part of some ancient group, serves a ghost King of some kind (and yet completely ignores a direct command from him), is part of a prophecy, plus there are now multiple alien/godlike groups introduced all with different aims and interconnected relationships. To have any idea as to what is going on you have to read pages and pages of codex entries. Oh, and I haven't even mentioned the god-awful tutorials which keep popping up every five minutes, either covering over most of the game screen with windows of text or worse, literally transporting you to some kind of test room to explain how to use whatever you've just picked up. 

Overall, for me, if it wasn't obvious from the above, the game has been a massive disappointment. I know a lot of people absolutely love it and consider it one of the best FPS's around, and that's fine, but for me, there are just too many changes to the first game and almost none of them are for the better. I'm trying to persevere to finish it as I've spent the money on it and can't refund it, but at this point I'm not sure I'll ever get that far. I've already re-installed 2016 and re-started playing it from the beginning, and frankly it's a lot more enjoyable.
This game is a disgrace to first person shooters and an insult to the legacy of gaming.

I love the DOOM series of games. In-fact, I thought DOOM 2016 was the true modern-day version of DOOM. I was worried about that game forcing Glory Kills on you, because DOOM was always about guns not Melee. 

I have 27 minutes on this game and I immediately asked for a refund. Don't let the mindless monkies tell you the lies of the Game "Magazines" saying this game is a 8/10 at the lowest. 

This game is balls compared to the original. 


Remember the badass music? Not there. 

Remember how the original game opened up with like 30 seconds of a cutscene with no dialogue and the cutscene blended into the game play so you actually wake up and feel in the game immediately. Well, what did they do with this game? 5 minutes of Dialogue. During these 5 minutes they show Doom Slayer without his helmet (back of head) which is something I don't agree with. 

Remember how much personality Doom Slayer had, even though we were controlling him? That's gone. 

Remember how fun it was going around shooting enemies? NOT ANYMORE! The Ammo capacities on the weapons are insanely low. It FORCES you to use the Chainsaw and Glory kills. I was playing on Nightmare and I got the REALLY shitty assault file (or Heavy Rifle) and it took two shots to the head on the zombie enemies to get a headshot. IN DOOM 2016, that would have been 1 shot in Ultra-Nightmare. 

DOOM 2016's design made you feel you were in a place that potentially existed. Not Eternal! The literal title screen looks like a Toy-Playset for DOOM. The Doom Slayer toy is standing on the playset and is shiney in the way that plastic is. The enemies in the game all have that characteristic plastic sheen. The worlds LOOK like you're playing with toys in a playset. It's fucking crazy bad. 

You also know how it was a goal in 2016 to not interrupt gameplay with dialogue heavy cut scenes. In the 30 minutes I played it interrupted me twice for dialogue. 

It's like they fired the whole team from the original game and hired a fucking EA staff or something. 

I *DO NOT* recommend this game. I LOVE DOOM 2016. Easily shot to being in my top 5 games of all time. DOOM Eternal just falls so fucking flat.... it's insanely different game despite having a lot of similarities.

Being serious, it's a bit tough to recommend this game to just anyone. It's not as easy as just saying "If you liked the previous Doom games, you'll enjoy Eternal." It is fairly different from previous entries in a lot of regards. These changes, such as the extremely fast and aggressive ai, the low ammo capacities, and the new suit gimmicks are going to feel awkward at first. After a few hours of dedicated playing, the game should eventually click for you and will start to get really, really good.

That being said, it's still not a game for everyone. If the sound of combat that is so hopelessly chaotic at first that you can hardly keep up sounds repulsive to you, perhaps Eternal just isn't for you. There's no shame in that, in the same way you shouldn't feel ashamed for not liking turn based combat for being too slow.

Actually like this game. And now they've removed the Denuvo Anticheat again, I can recommend it.

It's still not as good as Doom 2016 in my eyes... the ammunition management in here bugs me... if I had twice as much ammo for each gun, I wouldn't complain... I like being able to run out of ammo... but you can shoot a gun dry in mere seconds... 

And the climbling sessions... what are they there for?

The pace of the combat and general feel of the game is better than Doom 2016, but those things bug me enough to still think 2016 is better.

Then there's the fact they turned Doom Slayer into The Predator, with shoulder cannon and wristblade........ why? I LOVE Predator, but Doom Slayer shouldn't be him/it.
The amazing thing with Doom Slayer was the fact that he litterally ripped big demons apart with his bare hands... that's why the demons fear him, using a wristblade makes it less brutal and "scary".

Remember that old saying, "if it ain't broke, don't fix it?" That quote is this game in a nutshell.

The game has good graphics, cool weaponry and super fluid combat. The many platforming sections are not what you expect in a shooter but are okay once you are acquainted with the mechanic. Still misjumps were the main reason of fatality.

The player is put on an ammo diet. So it's chainsawing all the time or swap weaponry which I dislike. I play other Doom games primarily with the SSG but that's discouraged now and you have to do it their way. Pity since that gun is superb and the meat hook attachment is one of the best inventions since sliced bread.

The combat can be enjoying when they offer a decent amount of enemies. In every level though they crank up the difficulty with those high octane arena battles where a dozen of super heavy enemies are thrown at you in a confined space. It becomes more survival and running headless around instead of dodging attacks deliberately.

I also didn't like the lengthy multiple phase boss fights in which they throw anything at you.

Overall I didn't enjoy it too much. It has too many mechanics in it and too many aspects I don't like in a shooter.

Finally I wasn't fond of creating yet another (Bethesda.net) account. These companies can just use my Steam account.

Edit: adjusted a bit after replay in UV mode.

What a f****ing trip this game is. It is absolutely perfect.

It's fast, it's epic, it looks great, it's got a music score that makes your ears bleed (in a good way), it's everything you ever wanted it to be and more. It runs buttery smooth, the combat is incredibly fast-paced without it being completely chaotic, the enemies are diverse and challenging (and some of them really make you [i]want[/i] to rip them apart - and you can!). It makes you feel like a complete badass the entire time.

Best of all, it doesn't punish you if you're not an elite gamer. You can complete everything in the game even when using cheats, and if you die at the same spot multiple times you can choose to get a buffed armor to make it easier. Without belittling you or preventing progress. This little addition is [i]such[/i] a huge quality of life improvement that all games should have.

11/10 [b]RIP AND TEAR, UNTIL IT IS DONE[/b]

You are too busy swapping weapons to use the alt fire of one gun type, or swapping to a gun that actually hurts another demon type. Meanwhile you are dance around doing parkour because you have so little ammo you need to wait for your chainsaw to recharge.  Nothing is Metal about that. My gun should be glowing red because it NEVER STOP FIRING. In Doom you F-up any demon with whatever you happen to have in your hands at the time.  And if you punch a demon, that demon knows it just got punched in the face.  In this game your fist is replaced by a wet sponge. Oh but they did build a sword into your suit now, too bad you cant use it unless you a doing a glory kill, that also feels way less Metal than the 2016 reboot. At least in 2016 I didn't have to glory kill every enemy as I HAD AMMO.  I could afford to use that extra slug if I wanted to.  Everything feels so forced now.

This game forces the new game mechanics on you so hard, that its just not nearly as fun anymore.  When I hear Doom, I am expecting to run and gun. You just don’t get that in Eternal. Too much effort, and I do mean effort. Energy is spent manipulating these new game mechanics.  Sure they might be fine in some FPS, but NO ONE ASKED FOR THEM IN DOOM. It changes the game far too much to be called a DOOM game.

I will slowly finish this game I think as I did pay for it.   But I am not glued to my seat.   Its actually more of a choir to finish than anything.  
Game play so far 4/10 thus this game gets my thumbs down.
If you are looking to play a Doom game, skip this one.   Even on sale its not worth the money.
IT'S FUCKING AWESOME

First and foremost, I would like to express my filthiest and nastiest insults to Bethesda, they deserve every one of them.
Why do you want me, worst, force me to create an online account to play a solo game ? I don't care about online gaming, so just let me opt out of it, instead I have to put steam offline to trick my way in. Why do I have to ruse to play a game I F**KING PAID FOR ??? Just why ? To milk me more ? That's why Steam shows 5 min of playtime but believe me I've played it.

About the game, beautiful technically & artistically speaking, badass music, and for me that's it.

Too much gameplay mechanics : Flamethrower, Ice Bomb, Chainsaw, Blood Punch, Weapons Mod + Weapons point, Praetor suit + Praetor points, Sentinel crystals (increase health and co), Runes,  Double jump + Dash, grappling hook, Climbing on wall (oh god...), monkey bars ( Look how they massacred my boy ). It's more Darksiders than it's Doom.

Too much platform : I've read in the forum "Previous Doom were about platforming". Sure and Hidden objects games are Static first person object shooter...  For the love of god, NO, Doom has never been a platformer and if there was some precise movement moments in previous opus like in "Chasm" it was pure skill not this "press the button at the right timing Assassin's Creedy smelly brown substance coming from the intestines".

Too much cutscenes, too much npc : I witnessed a cutscene in a game calling itself Doom, nuff said... I witnessed an NPC in a game calling itself Doom (Not counting Doom 3, didn't play it, don't want to), Doom guy is alone in the middle of monsters that's it. No npc, no chat between battles.

Too much Hub: WTF ??? Fortress of Doom ??? Where 2016 succeded to have a marvelous continuity between levels, Eternal fails by giving nice and cosy apartment to the Doom guy. And more, knowing nothing about the character was part of the character, here to kill, period, and that's fine.

So to sum up, not a bad FPS, a good one if I may say, but failed as a Doom entry where 2016 succeeded by keeping it simple. Doom was always about running and gunning, Eternal feels bloated and too mainstreamed.

Take this critic with a grain of salt, it's just gaming, I don't care... And Thumb down because of the forced account creation.

Bethesda you morons, do not dare imposing an account for Wolfenstein 3, let me at least opt-out.

Review Update I bought a RTX 2070 Super for $530. There is a known bug where you can't run Doom Eternal at Ultra Nightmare on RTX series cards. This is Doom Eternal in a nutshell -> broken to the point of hostility towards the player, like Dommthousand and One, A Space Odyssey?). It also failed during both the Steam and Bethesda outages because of modern anti-gamer licensing. Original review below.

Doom used to set the course for the video game industry; Doom now follows the course set by the Little Sisters.

This is generic AAA game and a terrible Doom sequel. It's obvious Doom's synthesizer Zenimax owns all the FPS IP because this game is now interchangable with every other AAA game - there is even a flamethrower. Yeah, this game is so dumb that you use a flamethrower to stop demons from a classical, burning hell. Imagine if you used the squirting water in Super Mario Sunshine to fight the water - that's how stupid Doom has become. Call this Far Doom, or Assassin's Creed: Doom, Call of Doom, or Doom Wick - Doomguy even has a stupid dog now. Even the battle driven weapon upgrade path from last game is gone, replaced with something dumber that seems to give you more virtual stickers than weapon upgrades (Minecraft Doomgeons?).

Okay, we can ignore the feature creep that means the Doomguy now does rapid wall climbs after double air dashes launched from stripper poles (Doom Nukem 3d). These are the game mechanics the lowest common denominator wants, so let the braying paypigs have it. At least I have a gloomy, Doomy story about humanities irresponsible resource management... Nope. The story is moronic, incomplete and starts in media res retarded. Characters who were heroically self-sacrificed last game are just here, chillin, not even referring to their magical reincarnation (Doom Souls), where you got a brand new space station (Doom Space 4), or why all of a sudden the Doomslayer can't stop mugging for the camera like the Rock (Doomangi).

Don't believe me that Doom just took two huge airdashes backward yet? The UI is trash, as if made by George Romero on a G3 (Doomkaitana). It is genuinely hard to read text on the screen in 1080p. To read the oceans of lore you have to press one button to make the graphic go away, then another to scroll, and so on - things are so cluttered it genuinely feels like no on at Id knows how to put a graphic and a lot of text on a computer screen anymore so they force you to hide the graphic (Zork: Eternal Doom). Doom3's lore roledex was way more usable than this one. I'll admit the style and story are up for debate, but the illegibility of which button you have to push to make a dialog modal go away is either what you get when a megacorp can be sure their game will sell or is a wry meta-commentary on the state of the video game industry (Fallout Eternal: Doom Vegas).

Point blank: the sound sucks. The shotgun in Doom2 sounds way better. Every game in the series, including the Doom RPG port for Nokia phones, sounded better than this (Doomgry Birds Eternal). Constant UI blips and bloops drown out the oddly quiet phut phut of the assault rifle; a great example of the sound's quality is me googling to see if I accidentally equipped a silencer on the assault rifle. Imagine someone else was playing Doom and Id recorded the sound leaking from their headphones for Doom Eternal. It has a uniquely uncommitted, flat sound for any video game - let alone the heir to Doom 2.

That's where I want to leave it - Doom Eternal is a uniquely uncommitted, flat heir to hell on earth (Doomald Trump Jr).

review:
Positives
The intense combat makes Doom 2016 look like a babies game in comparison and forces you to think at the same time or else you die. 
The details in the worlds and the demons really make it look next gen but you don't have to worry about performance because the id tech 7 engine is really optimized and can run really well. 
Although the story is weak in some places, the lore is still amazing and worth diving into.
Doom Eternal is absolutely worth it for the amazing singleplayer campaign which is a blast from start to finish.

Negatives:
The confusing story is one of the weaker aspects which requires you to read the codex to fully understand and there are some absolutely stupid pointless cutscenes that show things like doors opening and the doom slayer being unable to jam a power core into a machine.
The battlemode also isn't perfect and is the only multiplayer gamemode so the singleplayer really is the only thing that is worth playing with battlemode being a tiny little bonus on the side.
Personally, I don't have a problem with the skins, but they can be a little too much for some people and can get in the way of what is a very good game.

Writing this review is a really though decision for me to make. Usually I do not write reviews (mostly because
I am too lazy to do so), but in this case I feel as if I have to.

First of all: 
DOOM ETERNAL, as in the core experience, is an amazing experience, worth every buck. The core 
gameplay is tight, the flow between fighting and exploring is seemless. The changes to the weapon system 
from the first game gives every weapon a reason to be used whilst streamlining the ammo system at the same.
Performancewise DOOM ETERNAL is a technical marvel and a treat to enjoy due to the great implementation of
the Vulcan API. The graphical fidelity is quite higher than in Doom 2016 yet keeping the demand in hardware quite
moderate. Good Job! The game puts you in the same trance/rampage state just like Doom 2016 empowering you 
and making you feel as if you ARE the Slayer. This immersiveness combined with the general gameplay loop and flow
is so much fun if you are into this rather old school "run-and-gun" Shooter type of game that puts gameplay above
all else. 

For this I would recommend the game to anyone who enjoys these kind of games. No second thought here.

HOWEVER, 
as of now, May 16th, 2020, Bethesda released an update which includes Denuvo's implementation of an Anti-Cheat
that uses kernel-level drivers to enforce that purpose. The reason for this is supposedly to stop cheating in the MP 
portion of this game. I will not indulge into the details on what a kernel-level driver is, as this can be easily done with 
a couple of searches in a search engine. 

My biggest issue with this is: 
- This impacts the performance, tanking the FPS on many system including mine. (RTX2070S + i7-9700k)
- This breaks the support Linux/Proton, making it impossible to play this game on my laptop running Ubuntu
- Having access to the kernel, is like having the keys to the castle. You have to put faith into some company 
   somewhere in the world that they will do you no harm with this kind of access or keep their services save 
   from any third party access that could the enduser by proxy. 
- The inclusion of such an invasive software after the release and people spending their money on this, without 
   any kind of prior notice except for a simple remark in the patchnotes is just bad practice. On top of that a lazy 
   solution to a problem in MP that also impacts SP. Which is, in my opinion, the core focus of the game. Not the MP.

Simply put: I came here to buy a Game that has a great Single Player experience. I don't care or buy DLC. I don't care or 
play Multi Player. I can, just barely, stand with Denuvo Anti-Tamper. KNOWING this I dropped 60€ for this on release just to have some simple SINGLE PLAYER fun. And now, after just a month, I have an update forced upon me that includes a software driver, that never was part of the the deal and I refuse to install, for a mode I don't even play. And because of that, I am unable to access the Single Player Mode since the driver needs to be installed to boot the game. 

In conclusion:
Would I have known, that this lazy "Anti-Cheat" would be part of the game in the first place. I would not have bought this game at all. Despite it being so great...
I urge everyone to not purchase this game unless this issue is addressed. The game is broken at this point on a technical standpoint. People are locked out of the game because they are hustled to submit access to their whole PC which wasn't even part of the deal in the first place. Business practices to include such invasive measures well AFTER launch (possibly to avoid press backlash) is yet again a slap to the face to paying customers and overall a very shady and unacceptable business.

Thank goodness I didn't buy this on the stupid Bethesda Launcher and can at least hope to get a refund.

I'll say this, this is peak doom. Never have I once found DOOM to be this fun, the campaign is great, it's looks really nice etc. Ripping and tearing is extremely satisfying.

However, I can't with a good conscience recommend this game in its current state. Because of an anti cheat present that's named Denuvo.

You might be asking: What's so bad about an anti cheat?
Well, denuvo has level 0 access on your computer, which means that it has high priority to the files on your computer. This poses quite a security risk since the software can gain access to hardware an important files. For an anti cheat(which is always running in the background btw) this is completely unacceptable.

If Bethesda for some reason listens to the consumer and removes denuvo, this game is well worth it, but otherwise I do not recommend it.

If you want to educate yourself on this go check the wikipedia page on protection rings: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Protection_ring

edit: Murcielago, a developer informed me that they removed the denuvo anti cheat integration in update 1.1, this game is now well worth it. The fact that they actually removed denuvo is actually fucking sick.

This game is not forgiving.

All in all Doom Eternal is a great action packed game that greatly expands on the mechanics of Doom 2016 and really challenges the player to use all the weapons and mods throughout the game and to adapt to the rapid interchanging of them throughout an encounter. It's a highly tactical game, yet extremely fast-paced at the same time. It requires you to really build skills up and punishes you for settling into a "comfort zone." Don't get too comfortable with two guns and one mod each, or you will find yourself Eternally frustrated. Even a single heavy demon often cannot be feasibly or reasonably destroyed with a single weapon or mod, forcing you to have to go through stages of attack against a particular foe, each stage requiring a different weapon or mod and requiring you to change up your tactics, all while constantly moving to avoid being bombarded by a barrage of incoming enemy attacks. This installment of the franchise is far more challenging than the 2016 installment and the world and maps are, over all, far more fun to play through. The length of the game is rather short, but I see it as an episodic installment onto the 2016 release more so than an independent franchise installment, so I can easily forgive the brevity of the story. Regardless of the length of the story/game, there is great replay value and tons of features to unlock with exploration and additional playthroughs, as well as lots of Challenges to achieve and in each difficulty mode. Additionally, the game is so challenging on Nightmare that you will not notice how brief the story is because you will be too preoccupied retrying maps and encounters.

The game also features a very ambitious new style of 1v2 multiplayer mode, where one player plays the Doom Slayer and the other two play demons in a Support/Offense role, which greatly shakes up everything we know about multiplayer FPS and introduces something that not even Overwatch has covered.

As for the downsides, they did not include any kind of Death Match style PVP or co-op in this game and, according to the powers that be, they won't be adding this feature and they think that it's too "old hat" for us. That's really too bad. With the kind of game play mechanics this game has, I get that it would be awkward to fit it with a DM style scenario, but that doesn't change the fact that the world still loves DM games and Doom is the founder of this play style. I think the double dash and double jump game mechanics would make for a very interesting way of playing a DM game. Plus the game already has many arenas in it that would work well for 2 to 4 player death matches and co-op.
Cool

Definitely grab it on 50% sale, but it's worth it even at full price.
The tactics are so much more in-depth than Doom 2016; you'll find yourself switching constantly between different weapons and mods to take down specific demons, managing resources HP/Armour/Ammo, and moving around constantly. Play on Nightmare difficulty and it's challenging but not impossible.

Overall the game is fun but it definetly has a number of flaws.

The game takes around 16 hours to complete with all of the secrets found. At some points you just want to skip the battles as they aren't challenging even at higher difficulty making those 16 hours more like 14 hours of worthwhile gameplay. 

During the early stages of the game you get bombarded with weapons and around 5 different ways to upgrade your player and weapons through abilitys. This is not nececeraly overwelming but it is pointless as you will most likely stick to the same 2 guns and your first 3 skills for the rest of the game. This is because you can pick anything at anytime and these are your preferred / by far the best abilities. Weapon abilities also have the problem that by the end of the game you can get all of them. Fundamentally this is not bad but because there are so many upgrades you end up with a large amount of upgrade points you dont use becouse you dont want or need the other upgrades. At the end of the game I upgraded over 10 weapon abilities at once just to see if there was an achievement (there isent) and not for the ability itself as all of the abilities I wanted or looked interesting I already had unlocked.


Although the story is fine besides the ending which is a bit basic and boring most of the levels of the campaign have bad flow with certain areas often taking to long and becoming stale.

The main reason I don't recommend the game is because of the price tag. I havent played multiplayer yet but the rest of the game is not worth 60 euros. Its more like 20 to 30.

Edit: The multiplayer is just boring. It's a 2v1 monster vs slayer gamemode. The idea of playing the demons is cool but the execution is a bit stale. It plays in a very small arena where the only goal is to kill the slayer or the demons depending on wich side your on. Its basically a arena mode where there are 2 dumbed down but overall stronger demons controlled by players that have special abilities that allow them to spawn a small amount of normal demons and heal themselves.





[i][b] TLDR: The overall game is fun but to short. You will only play the campaign once, you will propably not like the multiplayer, the pacing of levels is too slow making levels get stale, There are to many abilities and weapon upgrades that you will never use because the others are clearly better or more fun. Don't buy unless it's on sale for around 20 to 30 euros unless +- 16 hours of gameplay is worth 60 euros to you. [/b][/i]

One of my favorite FPS' since 1993 just keeps getting better and better.  Doom Eternal is easily the best in the franchise to-date. I didn't think they could outdo 2016, but they did, especially with the new gameplay mechanics. The single player campaign had me grinning - it's magnificent, violent, gory terror and glory. The game's electronic/industrial/heavy metal-inspired music hits, and the game is both an entirely awesome experience and brutally challenging if you like it to be, which makes me a very happy fan. 

Unfortunately, Battlemode falls a bit flat, in my opinion. It's got some balancing issues which they've been working on, but it's fun and is a cool idea. However, there's very little multiplayer content and the playerbase is very small. There is a high learning curve to playing the Slayer and winning games.  Old-school Doom/FPS fans like myself have been calling for Deathmatch - hopefully it gets added with an update.

Nonetheless, if you like to play FPS this should be amongst the top on your list.

I have mixed feelings about this game.
It's good, but I found the previous Doom (2016) better.
They went a bit too far with doing the glory kills for health, fire thing for armor and chainsawing for ammo. You don't have a lot of health, armor and ammo so you find yourself constantly gathering this.
Combine this with the combat system where you essentially go from little arena to little arena where they throw waves of enemies at you, you find yourself constantly gathering resources (is the game Doom or is it Age of Empires?).
It made combat feel like a chore sometimes, and not really fun anymore. I found myself quitting the game sometimes after one of those long combat sequences with lots of waves of enemies, I felt kind of exhausted after some of them.
Which is a shame because the combat / gunplay itself is real fun.
This wasn't the case for the previous Doom, I had more pure fun with it.

They are so unfun to play against it isn't even funny and at times has caused me to stop playing the game for days at a time. Yeet

Previous Doom was awesome.

This one is somehow boring, and the platforming is lame.

Doom: Youngblood is extremely disappointing, especially so if you played the far superior prequel. Although that's kind of the point, this sequel is so significantly different in so many ways I don't think you can genuinely call it a sequel to Doom 2016. I'd almost go so far as to say calling this a sequel to Doom 2016 is deceptive marketing.

First thing I noticed was how "wrong" the music sounds, even on the main menu. It all sounds like something someone made in their bedroom using only half of the tools available in a music editor because they don't know how to use the other half, just the same 4 second clip repeated over and over, with a few stings, changing in pitch and tone maybe, but so constant and boring I couldn't stand it after 20 minutes and just muted the in-game music altogether. They might as well not have bothered with music at all. I turned on the OST from Doom 2016 and it was like the difference between night and day. 

Even on the highest graphics settings this game looks... weird. I don't really care about graphics, but it stood out to me anyway. Some items in the game have ridiculously low-res textures, they look like something from 2002. The textures also wrap around and overlap at odd angles like this was someone's first custom map in an editor. The game genuinely feels like a significant dip in quality in this regard to Doom 2016. It doesn't look bad, but it definitely doesn't look good. 

The game controls weird. It feels similar enough to Doom 2016, enough that having replayed it recently I could feel the similarities, but it definitely feels different. The glory kill button and the melee button being the same button is a big mistake. Often I want to melee an enemy, but I'll be spun around to execute another enemy instead, getting disoriented and killed. That never happened to me in Doom 2016.

The jumping is just bad. I bounce off things, bounce off invisible walls, bounce off walls I can supposedly climb, it's a roll of the dice as to whether you will actually wind up where you want to be. Do not put platforming in your game if the platforming controls dont work. Know your limits.

Guns just don't have enough ammo, and I tried dropping it all the way to the lowest difficulty, it's still a problem there. Nothing more fun than having to stop every 10 seconds to go hunting for ammo. Definitely doesn't kill the pace of the combat at all. Also, even on the lowest difficulty, you cannot kill enemies with melee. I tried. No one tells you this, though, and it is ANOTHER big change from Doom 2016. I died in the first room because I thought "surely the doom marine can punch these little zombies to death", but no, turns out those raggedy zombies are tougher than the Doom marine. Great immersion there. That was what immediately told me they had done something wrong. 

The new mechanics of the grenade launcher shoulder weapon and other wacky stuff is neat, but it feels like too many cooks in the kitchen. It's hard to remember you have all these tools to hand when you're desperately trying to kill things. 

The game's art style and violence feel way more cartoony. Enemies look almost cartoonish. This is a real disappointment. Pretty much the entire tone of the original is dead. It almost looks like a saturday morning cartoon at times, and I mean that in the worst way possible.

Also, first level, giant robots everywhere that have been destroyed which look much more fun to play with than the game itself. Remember the old rule of writing? Your story should be about the most intersting part of the story. This feels like Star Wars Episode 2 where they keep talking about stuff that sounds way more interesting than what you're actually seeing. I'd much rather play with those than this crap.

The ironic thing is that many of these complaints are the same complaints people had about Wolfenstein Youngblood. Too many changes and none of them good. Tone and mechanics warped to a degree of unrecognizability. Hence why I say this is almost deceptive marketing to advertise this as a Doom game in the same line as Doom 2016. They really should have gone out of their way to say "guys this is a very different experience it's not like Doom 2016 at all", but obviously if they did that, they'd make way less, so no surprises.

It's just not a very good sequel to a very good game. It's "okay" as a game on it's own, 6/10 you tried, but extremely disappointing if you compare it to the game that came before it. I feel like a lot of the people who like this game are people who didn't play Doom 2016, but maybe that's just me. It is definitely suffering from all the same problems as Wolfenstein Youngblood. Who knows, maybe a future title will be able to win back some of the magic of the original, but for now this is just disappointing. They obviously could have done a much better job, but rushed this out (at least I hope this was rushed, otherwise that's just sad and there's no excuse). Do not recommend, play Doom 2016 instead.
