DOOM Eternal is a good game. I will most likely never finish DOOM Eternal. Eternal did a good job balancing the game for the most hardcore of players who enjoy switching weapons and preforming combos to play in the most optional fashion. They did not extrapolate this well into easier difficulties. The ammo pools have been nerfed across the board from DOOM 2016 which is just frustrating to be in the middle of an encounter and then need to search for a zombie or imp to chainsaw. The Marauder is far too difficult to be a common enemy and brings the game to a screeching halt. A personal annoyance of mine is that if a game has levels then they shouldn't be overly long. Many of Eternal's levels could have easily been split in two. It does not feel like the developers really cared about the players who wanted to just shoot demons without thinking and increased the difficulty to a frustratingly hard level, even when playing on the easiest difficulty.

As of patch 6/25/2020 they have officially ruined the single player campaign (for hardcore players) all for the sake of their lackluster gamemode "Battlemode", if you enjoy Battlemode fine, cool, whatever i don't care. Absolute beast of a game, I had it day one and am still playing it.  There's so much to gush over, the graphics, the gameplay, the soundtrack, the gore.  Everything is just balanced so well it's incredible.  The master levels add another layer of challenge after you beat the game, and the mauraders are really not that bad once you get good (anyone can get good).  You don't need to be anything more than mediocre for ultra-violence and below, but if you try nightmare, you better be ready for it cause it'll kick your ass.  Basically you need to weapon switch... a LOT.  You either need to be the most agile player ever or adopt the weapon switching for it.  But weapon switching is pretty easy to learn after you reassign some key bindings.  I personally used the keys:
1 - shotgun
2- super shotgun
3 - ballista 
4 - rocket launcher
5 - heavy rifle
z - chain gun
x - plasma rifle
t - BFG

It worked wonders for me.  As for battlemode its ok ig but can get old kind of quick.  I might do more of it later but I'll definitely be playing the campaign and master levels until the next one comes out often lol.
Tits is temporary, DOOM is ETERNAL

Ah DOOM. What a game. Shame that it has console sickness and should be quarantined.

"Easy" isn't easy. First of many, many weak points. The sound is not as consistent as in DOOM 2016, but good. The gunplay is weaker. Impact and handling feel much to soft. It crashed once, with no apparent reason. Not much new (in the first few hours) on the enemy front. Nice levels.
What do I mean by console sickness? It was clearly developed for consoles. A lot of convoluted upgrade systems. A lot of collectible stuff. A mandatory Bethesda account, even for single players like myself. WHY?
The campaign is a bit awkward storywise. But that is just because I am unused to the new direction. What I don't like about the campaign is the level design. Fighting arena --> platforming level --> fighting arena and so on, with a kind of menue world in between. WHY? I am talking Prince of Persia or Tomb Raider platforming, and I just can't see the DOOMGUY swinging around a pole to double jumb - double dash into a climbable wall. That doesn't feel right. I could do without those parts. Challenges, Weeklies, Time Trials, anything to pad out the game. At this point I wouldn't be surprised about side fetch quests. On many occations, I thought to myself, if they really had a meeting about what "the modern gamer" awaits in a AAA game these days, and just threw it in for no rhyme or reason, without thinking about its place in DOOM.
Good thing is, that they don't do the "you lost all your powers, again" shit. They throw the shotgun, the chainsaw and the first few upgrades in your face at the very beginning, so you feel like DOOMGUY right from the start. But when I saw arachnobots as one of the first enemies, I doubted the game. When they threw three at me in hour 4, I thought about what they will have left at the end. 
I will finish this, of course. But right now, I am just mildly motivated to go on. Nothing, really nothing compared to the euphoric rush of DOOM 2016.
PS: I don't want or need a menue that tells me, what cosmetic dumb pics or stickers I could grind for. I want to play the campaign. I don't need to customize DOOMGUY. I don't want my levels to be interrupted by this information waste, that doesn't add anything to my single player experience. Obviously, I cannot tell you now or ever anything about the multiplayer. 
The recommendation is a cautious one.

EDIT: I will NOT finish this. In fact, I already deinstalled it. DOOM Eternal didn't manage to motivate me to continue. Over the last week, I always found myself thinkung "I should finish DOOM Eternal ... well I'll just play X instead" with X being Witcher 3, Satisfactory, Hypnospace or random VNs. DOOM 2016 had me gripped from the beginning, and I played through in two sittings, collecting stuff and grinding some runes afterwards, with 4 playthroughs total. Eternal already bores me after 5h.

[h1]DOOM Eternal Review[/h1]
Rip & Tear... Until it is Done...

[h1]Pros[/h1]
+Addicting fast-paced gameplay
+Great solo campaign with tons of unlockables and secrets to find
+Great graphics with pretty good sound design
+Very well optimized for PC

[h1]Cons[/h1]
-MP is a bit underwhelming compared to its predecessor
-Weird glitch that tanks performance if you use the Steam FPS counter

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Doom Eternal is a fantastic single player game with Non-Stop adrenaline pumping action. Its core gameplay Loop is addicting and will have you playing for hours on end trying to beat its story and finding all the collectibles hidden in its world, and even though I find its MP a bit lackluster, there's no doubt that Doom Eternal is still worth every cent of its purchase price for its single player alone. I highly recommend it!

review:
I loved Doom 2016 but I found it hard to feel the same way about this one. I mean it looks great, solid controls etc. but there's just too much crap going on for my liking. All of your skills work on a recharge basis so you have to remember to constantly go through the loop: dash -> flamethrower -> chainsaw -> grenade -> blood punch, there's like 3 (?) types of upgrade tokens everywhere, bars filling up, the levels are divided into little arenas, shit constantly spawning on top of you - it honestly feels like a free-to-play rhythm game more than a Doom game sometimes. Ammo is bafflingly scarce (played on Nightmare), so you have to constantly switch to crappier guns you don't like, melee basically ineffective outside of blood punch.

Maybe I'm just getting old but, not for me.

Shooters tend to be about reflexes and sneaking or using tactics.
This game does require reflexes. Sneaking is non-existent. Tactics...
Tactics is knowing that when you're low on ammo you find something to chainsaw in half.
And to constantly move. And to memorize every available weapon and remember to use it.
If you die, it's because you forgot to use every piece of equipment or you stopped for some reason.

The story is actually surprisingly interesting. It's sorta vague. But like Metal Gear you can figure it out with dialog or reading a lore guide. It's kinda like ancient aliens but darker. It mixes spirituality with science fiction and it's really cool but harsh.

I didn't really even enjoy playing. It was like a robotic mindset to survive. But I had to kill the demons. They had to be atopped. I had to finish the game.

I have no desire to play the game anymore. But i highly recommend it. It may cause PTSD.

I hate to give this a 'No', but it feels like too much of a departure from the feel of Doom. I loved Doom 2016, I wanted a sequel to Doom 2016. This is something that uses Doom 2016 as a reference only. There is less feel of sci-fi horror. The art style is too bright, too comic bookish/cartoony. The fights are not about raw brutality. Extra lives are a thing to collect and fight difficulty even at Hurt Me Plenty is tuned to make you use them, Glory Kills are now something you must do if you want to keep your health up, chainsaw kills are required to gain ammo due to extreme ammo scarcity for even the basic weapons, switching weapon types to match monster 'weaknesses' is required to not run out of ammo trying to just gun them down, and worst of all (imo) is the introduction of a monster type that requires fighting at a specific range and timing your attacks as counter attacks. I'm sure some people will enjoy the new feel of the fights and the new art style, but it isn't for me. As I approach the end of the single player game I find the fights more frustrating than fun. If another Doom sequel is made in this same style I'll definitely pass on it.

8/4/2020 UPDATE:
Great news - they removed the DAC integration, so I'll gladly recant my review to be solely based on the game.

Doom Eternal takes the Doom 2016 formula and changes it up to be a much faster beast. All weapons now have a purpose (or specifically, enemies are weak to a specific weapon) forcing you to change up your weaponry on the fly, making liberal use of dashes and glory kills on feeder demons (example: zombies), and some neat platforming too.

Here's the nitty gritty though: this is not Doom 2016. I liked the direction that Doom 2016 was going into. It seemed darker and much more gritty, but Doom Eternal adds a splash of awkward color into the world that is a little bit out of place.

If you're expecting more of Doom 2016, like I was, I do not recommend this at full price.
If you're wanting a highly-mobile shooting game that rewards you for playing on the fly, then I recommend this.

Unfortunately, I feel like I'll be going back to Doom 2016 more than Doom Eternal. There is just something missing from this game that made 2016 special, and I'm afraid that any future entries in the series will share the same fate.

ORIGINAL REVIEW:
Game is much different from Doom 2016 but still a blast. HOWEVER: the Denuvo Anti-Cheat program that was forced through the latest patch is an invasive program that I find unacceptable in 2020. Who the hell thinks it is okay to force a program onto users that gives Kernel-level access to their PC, just to play a goddamn game?

Terrible, and I STRONGLY SUGGEST you do not even purchase this game or install it until they remove DAC.

This game isn't worth more than 20$.  They're doing some weird platformer/puzzle/shooter thing and while this normally wouldn't bother me, in a game about "slaying demons" you do two or three times more not slaying demons. Most of the game is either getting stuck in a cutscene, or wandering around while either your trusty AI sidekick explains objectives, or a brain in a jar rattles at you about your epic backstory.

The platforming, is mediocre. While some of the new mobility additions are interesting and fun in their own respect, the platforming itself isn't challenging beyond clunky controls and buggy terrain. There are usually no demons in sight, and you can't even see your feet. You're also not typically slaying demons while platforming.  They're usually not even present in any capacity.

The "puzzles" might be challenging for a 4 year old, or game reviewer. The game is basically long hallway, the rooms are small and the puzzles are too simplistic and obvious to feel rewarding to solve and are just more time spent not actually slaying any demons. 

The "secrets" are actually pretty insulting. They're pretty much just laid out in the open but every time you collect one the game goes "secret found!" as if there's some amazing achievement to be had in collecting objects that catch in your field of vision as you hold down the W key en route to the next cutscene in the cleverly designed linear hallway. It reminds me of collecting riddler trophies in batman games, just 100 times easier.

The "shooting" has a few high points, and definitely picks up speed in the later levels despite being sprinkled in between momentum and immersion killing puzzles and platforming, but for some reason there are forced immobility cutscenes and i'm not talking about the "press e to melee cutscene" tier stuff that's in combat, but forced cinematic cutscenes where combat stops and you're forced to watch a door opening or something which completely kills whatever momentum you were feeling and pulls you out of the immersion of being the "doom slayer." this is usually accompanied by some epic force fed lore over comms about how great you are or how epic your backstory is or how badass your enemies are, which totally kills the mood because they've made sure that nothing noisy happens while you're being talked at (no demon killing.) This is partially solvable by setting voice to 0 but there is no option to disable the forced cutscenes, or an option to add more demons to the completely demon barren segments. 

There are a few points in the final level where the boss is lumbering around in the background which looks really good but at one point you're forced to stop what you're doing and watch him walk through a skywalk. Why not have it be an ambient environment hazard that you have to look out for? It would have been much more satisfying if that was a point at which you could be killed by environmental hazard (the icon of sin) if you werent paying attention and went into the crosswalk. Instead it's "look! look! see! here he is the icon of sin! woww he's crashing through this skywalk! epic!" and it completely kills the momentum you just picked up from the previous demon slaying segment. If there's a benefit to all the cutscening it's that you are immune to damage when doing a "glory kill" which could be used to tank certain attacks.


Also, there's the gadgets. This is a very worrying development that doomguy gets a batcave and gadgets and there's a section in his batcave that has crafting benches and an armor stand. While at present they do nothing, but as your base comes with a 3d printer (that produces a gun after a few levels,) you get cryo grenades as alternative to regular grenade, and you get narrative updates via radio, I fully expect the next game to feature picking through rubble for trash to craft a plasma rifle. Along with questing, factions, faction warfare, base building, base defense, You know, some kinda Doomout 76. I fully expect it. We've basically had VATS melee since doom 2016 but it's far more developed now and with the rest of the additions in doom eternal I feel comfortable saying we're going to get an elder scrolls style doom game, or doom fortnite.

My biggest pet peeve is the forced cutscenes on everything. press e c or v to melee cutscene, cant move, interact with something cant move for 3-8 seconds, get on elevator can't move.  Not being able to move on a game elevator as someone who has a lot of energy, i like to bounce around while i wait to help relieve stress or anxiety because i have to wait until i can continue playing game, but in this game you're forced to stand perfectly still in the middle or you're forced to watch some lore cutscene (which are thankfully skippable most of the time.) It feels claustrophobic and makes me anxious. In the middle of the game there are one or two elevators that let you move freely and when i encountered them It felt so relieving. This is also the case with both a train and a cart segment. Forced to stand perfectly still, cant shoot, demons are flying around but cant shoot, you just have to stand there and look around while you get talked at until the ride is over.  I can go on but it's all just so tiresome.

It really feels like the people who made this game were more interested with hyping doomguy than making a fun demon slaying game. 5/10 worth maybe 20$ don't buy it full price.

Doom Eternal gets lands in that awkward box of games that I love, but can't recommend to anyone else. Believe the hype, this is one of the most hyper-kinetic, ferocious FPS experiences you will ever have. What also sets Doom Eternal apart is how incredibly smart (or dumb) it makes you feel.

Unfortunately, that drive to demand that the player juggle eighteen different things at high speed is also what makes this game so hard to recommend. Like any good, high-skill game, Doom Eternal demands that the player play in a certain, resource/kit-minded way. However, Doom Eternal is also just downright pushy. 

Doom Eternal: "Okay, here's a horde demons, and two shotgun shells. Make it work. NOOOO!!! NO NO NO, YOU'RE DOING IT WRONG! YOU'RE... UGH... YOU'RE.... ARGH... YOU'RE SUPPOSED TO.... OH, LOOK, YOU'RE DEAD NOW!!! HAPPY!?!?"

I get what the devs were going for, but they didn't have to be this rigid on the combat loop.

Doom Eternal is fine, I suppose. I bought it on sale for half off, and hats off to Bethesda for that. It's on sale right now too, and it probably doesn't have to be, so thanks. That being said, I think I prefer 2016 to this. It was more 'grungy' and I liked the music much better. Doom Eternal is a bit too ostentatious, a bit too flamboyant overall, even if it has lots of cool stuff to look at. [i]I like the UAC holo-woman's bum.[/i]

I don't mind the ammo/chainsaw system, and you get used to the combat dance relatively quickly and it's pretty enjoyable. I played the thing on nightmare, but those fucking marauders man, they kinda ruined the game for me. I would turn the difficulty down to 0 whenever one of them showed up on the screen. Boss fights kinda suck in general, but to have a standard enemy that is ten times harder show up around a dozen times in the game just deflated the experience for me, and I was soon eyeing the exit for an uninstall. I'm sorry to say I did not try the multiplayer, and wanted to get that sketchy DRM off my system.  For 30 bucks and only 40 gigs it's more or less a steal though. I realize that Bethesda has a bad reputation and there were more than a few issues with the initial release of this game, but I figured that if I waited for the dust to settle then what was left would at least be playable. I paid money for this.
yes

Doom 2016 was a very successful game that was very well received both from critics and users alike. A sequel to it was to be expected and to be looked forward to. I was very excited to see what they would do next with the story and gameplay, and what did they do? They added parkour….

[h1]What I like:[/h1]

+ The gameplay, though not without its flaws, feels like a massive step up from its predecessor. The intensity and high-power action are increased tenfold, especially on higher difficulties.

+ The new mechanics such as blood punch and the flame thrower are welcome additions that successfully make the combat feel more satisfying and rewarding. 

+ The levels are fantastic to look at. Seeing Earth in an apocalyptic state in the opening hours of the game is a brilliant first impression. Each location is iconic and unique in its design and feel. 

+ The story is pretty decent.  I can’t say I always knew what was going on, but that never really mattered too much to me since I had a general idea. It is a Doom game after all.

+ The increased emphasis on exploration is something that I wasn’t expecting, and in my opinion, it’s done very well. Not only does exploring provide you with various collectables that appear in your ship, it also provides you with an increase in your effectiveness in combat.

+ The weapons in this game are great. They all bring something new to the table, especially when modified. Returning weapons from the previous game are better than ever, and the new ones all feel like they belong.

+ The boss fights in this game are excellent. The last two in particular are some of the best boss fights I’ve ever experienced in gaming. The game’s build up to these fights really pays off. 

+ The voice acting is something that I feel is worth mentioning, especially with the main antagonist. Although there isn’t a vast variety of characters, the ones that are present all have very talented voice work behind them. 

+ The optimisation is surprisingly very good. I didn’t think I’d be able to run the game on max graphics, but alas I was. Never went below 60 frames. (I have a Nvidia GeForce GTX 1070).

[h1]What I don’t like:[/h1]

- The parkour. Why does it exist? I didn’t mind the basic traversal sections and how its applied in combat, but whenever I went around a corner only to see tonnes of obstacles such as flamethrowers, spinning lasers, crushing doors, falling platforms etc., I wasn’t exactly filled with excitement. 

- The Marauders. I don’t know who thought they were a good idea. It’s not only that they are insanely annoying, they’re not fun to play against. Their gameplay loop consists of “Go around them in circles and shoot them when their eyes glow green, but don’t go too far away or too close to them.” I’m just glad they weren’t in the boss fights.

- Parts of the combat feel clunky. Unless your blood punch is fully charged, melee attacks do no damage. Enemy weak spots are an okay addition, but sometimes they just felt like they were getting in the way. 

- There are too many sections that take control away from the player. One scene literally consists of the main character walking through a long room with people being shocked by him. The player could’ve done that themselves.

- This is a rather small complaint, but it annoyed me nevertheless. The game encourages you to use the BFG way too much. When you run out of ammo on a weapon, you automatically switch to the next one. Sometimes you switch to the BFG, so when you’re firing away, you may accidentally waste it. It happened too many times.

[h1]My Overall Thoughts:[/h1]

It took me some time to get used to Doom Eternal. Right off the bat it felt very different to the 2016 version. The more I played it however, the more I got used to it, and the more enjoyable it became. 

The combat feels very satisfying, and the new additions only improve the experience. The game feels a lot more intense and fast paced compared to its predecessor. The levels are horrifically gorgeous to look at, and the benefits of exploring these levels make side-tracking worthwhile.

Is it better than Doom 2016? Personally, I don’t think it is. What made the 2016 version so good was its simplistic yet highly addicting gameplay. It’s the things such as the over-used parkour, the marauders and various other clunky aspects of the game that let it down. They get in the way and interfere with the fun.  

Despite these flaws, Doom Eternal is still a really good game, and I had a blast playing it. I can’t comment on the multiplayer since I haven’t tried it out. If you’re more interested in the single player part of the game, I can tell you that it’s great fun, just not without its flaws. 

[h1]Final Rating:[/h1]
8/10.

Doom Eternal makes it clear from the get go that it does NOT want to do DOOM '16 over again. It wants to do its own thing and I think it succeeds on almost every level, but I also think the game has turned into marmite in pursuing its new direction.
By marmite I mean this is a game that you will either love as your new favourite shooter of all time, or hate with a fiery passion. I’m not sure about there being an in between simply because one of the things this game does well is have all of its mechanics and level design congeal with each other. They all work in tandem to make the player feel like they are an unstoppable killing machine when the game is played right.
The controversy comes from just that though. If you are playing the game the way it wants you to, which is very different from ’16.
You either grok the new play style and love it. Or don’t and hate the game for it. And I can absolutely see where you would be coming from by hating the game. It is a matter of taste. Doom Eternal is not Doom ’16. So do NOT go into this game expecting it to be.
If you go into this game with an open mind and take it on its own terms. You’ll either find one of your favourite games of all time. Or a frustrating game you’ll never play again. 

Worth the gamble imo.

If you liked DOOM 2016, this should honestly blow your mind.

This game is full of action from the start to the very end, which might not appeal to everyone. For those who are looking for an adrenaline rush and some mindless fun it's highly recommended, though. At times the game can be very frustrating, but when you finally succeed in surviving a battle against a large horde of demons, you're filled with a sense of accomplishment and pride. 

At the beginning of the game I felt ill prepared and started to wonder if age really had numbed my reflexes as I got my ass handed to me so easily. Repeatedly. However, I soon learned the ways of the Slayer and after some hours and several upgrades later, I felt like a beast; someone the demons should fear. Maybe that's how it's supposed to be? I don't know, but it's a special feeling nontheless.

I thoroughly enjoyed my time with Doom Eternal and the developers deserve high praise for what they've produced here. I felt the length of the game was just right too; in fact I was surprised at the scope of this game as I had expected it to be shorter and less varied!

I guess I'll begin by saying I'm not the biggest fan of FPS games because of how one-dimensional they tend to be. However, this game is just exceptional; the best FPS I've played to date, and a lot of that is because it's so much more than a shooter. A nice mixture of shooting and platforming with intense firefights and great mobility controls. There's no one way to get through this game; it suits many different playstyles well. Personally, I like to be elusive in shooters. I enjoy how this game really makes you pay for standing around for even a second too long, and you have to be mindful of which resource you're going to use in any given situation. You control your own destiny when it comes to health and armor; rather than always having to rely on health packs and armor shards, you can basically beat it all out of the demons you face. As usual, you have to be smart about it. The music is what you'd come to expect from a DOOM game. There's also plenty of collectibles for the completionists out there. A masterful game that I'd recommend to anyone, especially those who are on the fence about FPS games. 10/10

Doom Eternal is a fantastic upgrade from the 2016 reboot. It is fleshed out, has some additional weapons and the story is actually enjoyable if you are into lore. There are also a couple of new demons to face. Overall the game took around 30 hours for me to complete on "Hurt me plenty". Dying was not common and the lives you pickup mean restarting from a checkpoint is scarce. That brings me to the topic of "secrets", some will be obvious along the main path, and by no means do you need them to complete the game. However, life will be easier if you do go out of your way to find them as I did. At the same time, the game does give you tokens to upgrade your amour and mastery tokens to get the bonus masteries on weapons. Though you will get more of these, and you will get them earlier on if you find all the secrets and complete all the challenges per level. Overall I think it is a great FPS and has a nice balance of fast-paced combat and exploring moments to give you a breather.

A complete 180 from DOOM 2016, this game features piss-poor level design where the way forward is often obscured behind a doorway or path marked nearly identically to all others, or around some hidden hallway with zero effort put into even getting you to notice it. The added platforming mechanics are unnecessary and infuriating when you just want to move onto the next combat scenario, and in spite of god-awful level layout, the game still feels like it's patronising you with pop-up instructions long monologues from the enemy.

It feels like the Eternal team took everything they learned from DOOM 2016's development and threw it out the fucking window. While the combat remains fun, they've complicated everything to an unnecessary degree and made answering the simple question of "ok, where do I go next?" into a journey of backtracking, jumping into pits trying to reach platforms that seem reachable to someone desperate, etc. before being forced to google the name of the current mission to watch someone else figure out where the hell to go. I've never had issues navigating in video games before, but this game simply makes NONE of the affordances other games make to ensure the user is set in the right direction.

Summary: If you want a good DOOM experience look for the previous ones especially DOOM 2016.
This doesn't feel like AAA game, rather it feels like you are killing enemies in arenas that are procedurally generated; like an indie fps game.

Pros 
- Lore ( If you enjoy the franchise)
- Visuals 
- Musics 
- Performance ( It has a better performance than Doom 2016)

Cons 
- Game constantly punishes you with low ammo; even for lower level difficulties. 
- You end up trailing a low level demon with a chainsaw in order to get ammo rather than focusing combat. 
- This always blocks the flow of the game.
- Every Stage consists several arenas that you need to circle 1000 times to get ammo, health. 
- This is much more like a survival FPS rather than action FPS.
- Because of focusing too much to generate ammo/health/armor by punching,flaming, chainsawing enemies; you end up not using any weapon mods of your guns (except main weapons; shotgun, machine gun...).
- Because of the controversial anti-cheat none of my friends as well as me haven't installed the multiplayer. 
 
Extra Comments
-I have just finished 6th stage of the main campaign.  (I will update this review when I finish the game)
-It got really boring and levels feel same. 
-I will finish the game by playing time to time just to grasp the whole story. 
-It is now 2020 and there are lots of good examples of FPS games. 
-It is now 2020 and there are lots of good indie clones of DOOM. 
-I hope next time developers come up with a better Doom experience we all enjoy.

I played Doom 2016 and Doom Eternal back-to-back. Many of the negative reviews and complaints that I read have to do with Doom Eternal deviating away from Doom 2016 in terms of an arbitrary "feeling" to the game. This is in fact, true; however, that does not mean Doom Eternal is a bad game, and in my opinion the difference in feel between the two games is negligible and downright overblown.

Doom Eternal is Doom 2016, but much more challenging and consequently satisfying. If you liked Doom 2016 there is a very high chance you will like Doom Eternal as well.

Updated Review 02Aug2020: 
After a kind nudge from a Bethesda rep, I've had time to take a look at the game following the update to remove the Denuvo Anti Cheat system. I'm pleased to confirm this has been removed and the game is great again - but I say it with caution. id have mentioned they'll re-evaluate, so I expect another system to appear eventually, and I hope that implementation will not affect the ability of paying customers to play the game in a normal way and without compromising their system.

The single player game is fantastic. It seems more difficult in a good way. The additions and skills certainly at first seem an odd choice for doom, but I genuinely think these work brilliantly for the game, adding to it's fast paced and aggressive nature. There is a surprising amount of tactical play in here as you try to control the various battles. The multiplayer is a nice addition that I hope they build upon, but not what I'd consider the core of this game.
There are also a good amount of additional challenges to keep you busy and new content is apparently on route too.

I certainly recommend the game for those of you keen on single player Doom experience and are ready to test a fresh way of playing. To me this game is better in every way over 2016, but it does seem like this is hit and miss for others.

review:
First impression: There's too much shit going on and this game is asking a lot of the player between all the weapons, weapon mods, two types of grenades, blood punch, flamethrower, chainsaw fuel, and insta-kill sword. It's gilding the lily.

Simultaneously, they made aiming with the mods stupidly easy. There's a magnetic aim assist to most of the game's weapons that it feels like there's this massive disconnect between the large number of things it wants you to do, and the baby-town-frolics of the shooting mechanics.

Then the story. What are you doing game? Why is the doom marine a magic space knight as well? I could not give a fuck about that, and you don't seem to either with how sarcastic you are with the subject matter so I don't know why you're trotting this stuff out you can't be bothered to be sincere about. 

Doom2016 was about waking up from a coffin and killing everything in sight. This is about globetrotting demon invasion stopping nonsense while pumping me up as some kind of chosen one who doesn't give a fuck? Why do the extra work to try to get me to give a fuck then also not give a fuck? It's like it was afraid to do something sincere so it cloaked itself in irony.

Honestly everything about this game is grating on me now and I think it started with the fact that I loved the starting shotgun in Doom2016. I was a fucking sniper-surgeon with that weapon, getting direct hit cluster-bounces with that shotgun that it was my go-to throughout the entire game. They made it anemic  while giving the new 'sticky' mechanic this garbage magnetism that makes me feel like the game isn't letting me win by my own skill. From there it just got more and more AAA nonsense of everything sanded off and over designed, from the tutorials that shove themselves into my face to the autowin weapons that I barely have to aim to use well. 

I can't believe I was BORED at the end of this game. :|

Game is limited to two gamemodes: Campaign and Battlemode. Campaign is fun and kinda of replayable, but gets stale. Battlemode is a fun gamemode with 2 demons and 1 slayer, but its the ONLY multiplayer gamemode and some like me, dont like it. So there isnt shit to do in this game anymore. 
The game has been out for almost 5 months now and they have added 1 thing, that should have been there at launch. 

No new gamemodes, No new campaigns. Not even any new master levels (Campaign levels with new enemy placements and harder enemies). A DLC has yet to even release.

This game feels like a bit of scam sometimes.


Also that deluxe skin looks nowhere near what they showed on the steam storepage, so thats also super dissapointing.

Doom Eternal can start out feeling daunting or overwhelming with all the abilities and weapon swapping, movement and upgrades. Once you get used to it all, man oh man. It is like a symphony coming together of quick, visually stunning, satisfying game play. Having to actually think about what you are trying to kill, the best way to kill it (weak points), while avoiding other demons and managing your armor, health pool, ammo, and being aware of your surroundings makes this Doom even better than the last in my opinion. It can be very difficult on the hardest setting at times but it gives that old fashion game feeling of beating something that is truly difficult with the ability to master it, or at least become better. I will probably finish the game but I am really, really disappointed and frustrated with how it  feels so far.

Doom 2016 right? Somehow you always felt how to play it. After a short while, you joined this dance of death with the demons, it was fluid, challenging, but natural. 
At a point you entered this trance like state where defeating impossible odds, dodging lighting swift attacks was just your nature. 
The only bad thing about it is how good it felt, all the time. After a longer play, too much of the good thing left you kind of overstimulated.

[Spoilers about game mechanics and gameplay ahead]

Doom Eternal? You need to learn how to play it, you no longer feel how to do it right. They introduced low ammo simulator mechanics, so you need to think about ammo. All tougher enemies became mini-bosses, with weak points you have to think about. Stay in motion to - stay alive principle doesn't work anymore, the game introduces a new mechanics, that only make sense if you get hurt often, you have to use them to stay alive. You would like to choose how to defeat an enemy? Nope, prepare for rock-paper-scissors gameplay, again you need to think ahead, what kind of ammo you want to keep, in case you end up with scissors against a rock.

You don't even have any means to keep the momentum up, as platforming became the secondary gameplay mechanic.  You would like to just enter the next arena and quickly use what you learned ? Nope. Platforming, parkour, falling.
You are bombarded with new content, new mechanics, new equipment, runes and all other AAA nonsense, to a point that it's distracting and feels like swarm of buzzing flies.
On top of it, it doesn't feel like the game is giving anything new, instead the true gameplay is taken away in the beginning, and you have to chip away the content padding to get it.
I know this is how content is usually delivered, but if it's executed well, you won't ever notice it.

And finally, even Mick Gordon's music feels pretty weak.

I will try to finish this game, and do my best to like it, with hope I can change this review, but so far it's not looking so good.

review:
A beautifully fast paced and chaotic shooter that will leave you wanting to play it again and again at higher difficulties.

Pros:

1) The mechanics of the game are buttery smooth. You can really create your own rhythm within the carnage once you are well versed with the different mechanics.
2) The ammo/health/armour replenishment mechanic in the game is a fresh take on the tired fps resource scavenging model.
3) The grappling hook allows for interesting and fun movement within the game.

Cons:

1) The final boss battle was a bit disappointing to me. Without revealing too much, I was hoping for something grander and more direct in interaction and involvement with the final boss.
2) The wall scaling parts can feel a little tedious at times.

Doom Eternal is by far the greatest game in the franchise. Single player has improved immensely, combat has become more advanced and the multiplayer is fantastic. 

10/10

Bigger, bolder, badder in every way possible, and I've only played the first four hours. I was ready to get into this game and believe I knew everything there was to know, but god damn, this game will kick you in the ass hard. The game definitely holds you responsible for success, and won't hold back to punish you for even minor mistakes. It's faster, and tougher than Doom 2016 by a considerable margin, but once you find your way through Doomguy's incredible arsenal, you'll start wiping the floor in demon blood in no time.

This game is very aware of its predecessors legacies, and I love it. The hub area you're given is filled to the brim with easter eggs, callbacks, and numerous collectables scattered around that you gain from finding secrets in the main missions. Collectable toys, player skins, songs from classic iD Software games with their own personalized album art, and I bet plenty more considering I'm not even halfway through the game.

While Doom Eternal has a heavier emphasis on story telling, thankfully it still stays mostly unintrusive. Like its predecessor, most of everything is still told through data logs and other means. What really makes this game's setting and presentation however is the world building. You will visit places and dimensions you've never seen in a Doom game, let alone a first person shooter. Each of these worlds ooze with creativity and care, and both minor and major details open up a universe of history and lore to delve into, all neatly documented in a codex for you to read at any time you wish.

Also, it would be a sin if I didn't talk about the performance of this game. I have to give kudos to the development team for their incredible optimisation. This game runs as smooth as butter, and is highly configurable. It's requirements may seem heavy, but with the numerous graphical settings to the inclusion of a dynamic resolution, most folks should have next to no trouble playing this game. From a technical standpoint, Doom Eternal is a marvel to look at, as well as take part in.

Doom Eternal is the best possible sequel we could've got from Doom 2016. This is by far one of the best shooters I've ever played, and with the amount of replayability on hand, I can see myself playing it for a long time.

This game is phenomenal. Everything that I loved from DOOM 2016 is here, plus new weapons and mechanics to make the combat fresh. If they'd released the same DOOM 2016 but with more levels, guns, and enemies alone it'd be one thing. But this feels like the natural progression of the game. It runs wonderfully and the combat remains as frenetic as ever, but new approaches to specific enemy types make for a more strategic set of encounters. You're not just "RATATATATATATAT KILL THE DEMONS" because they're stronger and more complicated in many ways; instead, you're making split-second decisions in combat to turn the tide on the demons, and it makes a lot more sense. Doomguy is, essentially, still a human. A human built like a gorilla on steroids with limitless stamina and infinite malice, but a human at the core. So it stands to reason using mobility and tactics to overpower these existential alien/demon things rather than pure force of concerted fisticuffs is a neat way of keeping combat challenging without needing to change the rules on the player every other level. Instead, it builds on itself, new enemies alongside old, forcing the player to adapt and not forget old strategies. This game also doesn't hold your hand with puzzles, and most of the secrets are accessed via these same strategies, making them feel more like discoveries rather than secret doors requiring wall-humping.

However, and I know it's a controversial opinion... I miss DOOM 2016's PvP system. I know it went over in the community about as well as a birthday cake with toenail filling, but I liked the gunplay enough and I feel that this game's mechanics would make for interesting Slayer v. Slayer combat.

Overall, a 9.7/10. Worth every penny.

Doom Eternal - 2020 - Play Time: 17 hours

[h1]Overview[/h1]
A blood soaked action packed adrenaline rushed sequel to Doom (2016) and it delivers and all aspects. Combat feels more intense and punishing if you stop moving. A constant game of chaining together kills, switching weapons to hit specific weak points on demons, and using your chunk machine chainsaw to replenish ammo. The ability for this game to give you a power rush but at the same time make you feel helpless is a outstanding piece of work. Hats off to the team behind this game and all the effort they poured into it. 
My single compliant with the game lies with the story. Yes, why nick pick when the game is such a hit? Because if you have a story, it has to be fluid. Regardless of how polished and excellent everything else is. The game fails to explain how we got from Doom 2016 to Doom Eternal. At first I thought maybe I perhaps missed it in one of the lore books (After collecting them all and reading them), So I went to the internet. Nothing. No explanation as to the time skip, how we managed to snag a badass ship fortress? Some say it will be addressed in  a future DLC but I think that is vile practice for game development. 

[u]Positives:[/u]
+Boss Fights
+Tough yet fun combat
+Mods for Weapons

[u]Negatives:[/u]
-Lack of story between games

[h1]Scoring[/h1]
[u]Story:[/u] 9 / 10
[u]Gameplay:[/u] 10 / 10
[u]Visual/Audio:[/u] 10 / 10
[u]Entertainment:[/u] 10 / 10
[u]Controls:[/u] 10 / 10

[b]Final Grade:[/b] A
[b]Replay Value:[/b][i]None[/i]

[b]TLDR:[/b] Doom Eternal is a good game that I don't like. 

After 28 hours of the campaign, a little Battlemode, and a Master Level I'm ready to never play DOOM Eternal again. This game pushed me to improve; to move faster, aim more accurately, hesitate less. But after every session my fingers were cramped and I felt tired. There were fights that I finally won after a dozen deaths that made me feel accomplished, and there were those that I breezed through like a killing machine. The power fantasy is strong here... but I realized as I played through that I've changed as a gamer.

I played 2016's DOOM reboot on Mouse and Keyboard, eventually beating it on the highest difficulty. I relished maxing out weapons and pushing my skill. These days my gaming has transitioned to the couch and a controller because I want to spend time with my wife and dog rather than remain cloistered in my office, which has become a literal office due to the pandemic. I'm in it for the story now. I'm in it for the fun. DOOM Eternal traded interesting voice acting and narrative for text logs. I enjoyed that lore, but it was largely detached from the gameplay unlike its predecessor. 

Look. I'm old now. I don't want my hands to hurt after playing a video game. I want to chill on the couch and feel invested in a story that makes me feel whisked away to another world where I'm powerful and skilled. DOOM Eternal isn't that. If you're a gamer like me, pass on this one.

Doom Eternal Review
By Sandewr_Pally
Score: 10/10
Played On: PC
Hours Played: 15
Mode: Normal

Right away the atmosphere of the game hits you. Earth is under attack and you, the Doom Slayer, are its only hope. Demons are on earth and you are their death. With a superb soundtrack to kick off the violence you jump headlong into the carnage, filling out your arsenal and becoming the Slayer that Earth needs.

Taking much of what made Doom 2016 a true reboot of one of the most popular shooters of gaming Doom Eternal goes further in making you the perennial slayer. Familiar weapons are back, with more mods and styles of play for experimenting. The addition of mechanics that help restore health with glory kills, a function taken from the 2016 Doom, to a flame turret that finally gives Doom its answer to reliable armor restore. Each Weapon comes off as unique and needed, for only utilizing each weapon to its fullest extent can the player hope to prevail. Especially in the endgame when many of the toughest demon combinations come into play. 

Speaking of the Demons themselves the AI that makes up your enemies are even more dangerous, a promise that Doom Eternal Developers have delivered on. The horde feels like a proper enemy that works together, yet sometimes to their detriment as much as benefit. Old, new and returning enemies have all gone through new changes to make them even more dangerous. Getting close a gamble that more often than not got me killed, especially against one of the late game enemies.

The classic Doom exploration is upped to eleven, with secrets galore and challenges awaiting those that take the time for them. The challenges themselves (One series that is required for a locked secret) puts players in some of the more intense combat sequences, challenging each of the players skills. Most of the Powerups that you get come from exploration making it well worth it to find a way to that powerup that you see through a grate in the wall.

For lore buffs the history of Doom and its titular character lay bare to all, making an interesting story in a shooter that to most is just tear through demons it is nice to take a moment to read through a piece of lore. Even the bestiary, that gives you tips on how to defeat the minions of hell, is enjoyable to stroll through in the downtime, or when you really need some tips on how to kill them.

Doom Eternal Takes what made the reboot of Doom great and made another masterpiece from it. I would Wholly recommend this game to old and new Doom Players, for it is just that good.

Doom reboot was amazing, for reference id give that game 9 or 10/10, but what did they do with this....It's like they decided to take out the single player game and just make it like playing a deathmatch interspaced with some walking and/or jumping puzzles.

I should say everything is still amazing other than the gameplay itself, but its such a bad experience from my perspective that i have been playing 1 level per day before i get bored and quit. Compared to the previous Doom game in which I finished over the first two days i owned it.

So the combat, firstly you are given bare minimum ammunition to force you to utilize the chainsaw = ammo mechanic.
Next you have a high cooldown grenade which doesn't really do much as you rarely get enemies grouped up.
Then you have the flamethrower, again when you are given so little ammo and then have to spam bullets into enemies on fire to get armor it just doesn't really make sense.

Finally pretty much anything will hit you for 20% minimum of you total heath, and you have literally be jumping or dodging 100% of the time as things you cant see will always be a split second away from hitting you. Even doing that you will always be taking some chip damage and have to glory kill for health every 10-15s in a arena fight.

Long story short, instead of being fun like the last Doom, the combat in eternal is a CHORE. Which is a real shame because the rest of the game is great.

Game of the year 2020

The story of this game is convoluted and makes no sense for a newcomer to the series. The exposition is also rather heavy-handed, with frequent cutscenes on some levels. A more descriptive name for the game would have perhaps been Doom (2016): Chapter 2, since the scenario of Doom Eternal is illegible without the lore and additional context it provides. The constant teleporting of the player character in the campaign and within the levels further adds to the disorientation and the feeling of detachment from the game world.

The ability to hit the weak spots of enemies to remove their parts and change their behavior is interesting, but it's only really applied to early game enemies. Most of the demons introduced later do not seem make much use of the system. The enemies are surprisingly generic and uninspired. The floating and colorful Cacodemon, with it's funny grenade-swallowing behavior, is perhaps the coolest type of enemy in the game. The Marauder is another distinctive type of enemy. The game has a system of demon skins that could add flavor to the game, but it cannot be applied to singleplayer.

My interest in the game was initially captured by footage where the player made use of switching between weapons in combat to create "weapon combos". It seemed like if you could master switching between different weapon types, such as from a shotgun to a sniper rifle to a rocket launcher, you could greatly improve your efficiency and speed up the pace of combat by avoiding reload and cooldown periods of the different weapons. In actuality, these weapon combos have been partially eliminated by the developers. There is now a typical significant delay when switching weapons, making the gameplay seen in most videos of this game impossible.

The system for staggers and finishing blows is also a bit underutilized and disappointing. Since the more elite demons tend to have longer finishing blow animations, provide no additional incentives aside from a couple of one-time challenges on specific levels, and because staggered demons tend to die rather easily of damage from any source, you mostly want to avoid using the finishing blows on high-end enemies in favor of fighting from afar. The game has plenty of epic animations for the chainsaw and the finishing blows, but they are mostly not utilized, since the vast majority of the time they are only used on the same low-level fodder demons. It seems that only in the early game, and only on specific enemies, you really want to make use of the finishing blow opportunities on larger demons.

In a nutshell, many of the more unique and original systems in this game are not used as well as they could have. Some of the core dynamics of the game you might see in gameplay videos, such as weapon switching for combos, are actually not very prominent in-game. The story is surprisingly jarring, complex and heavily present for a game series that some might have the impression of not being strongly story-driven.

Update (with minor changes):
Finally the minimap is no longer pitch-black in HDR. 
So at least it can function as it supposed to be, sort of.  
But the game still keeps popping out warning and errors and eventually it crashes my machine.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Venturing further into the campaign only generates more frustration.  
Every gimmick that supposed to work fails when the game try to trap the player in a small playground and flush it with waves of mini bosses. 
It fails spectacularly at higher difficulties.

But since I don't get paid for writing this, I won't go into any technical details.

The most obvious symptom that most player should be able to notice is, instead of coming up with a solution to make the game "fairly-unbalanced" on higher difficulties, they went with the old-school Quake style approach. And clearly that didn't work because they have to put in a "buff yourself up after died for couple of times at the same place" option as a workaround. 

And once you turn off the music, those seems-to-be-exiting-boss-fights starts to pale off, and you can get bored even before finishing the game.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

For most casual players. I think the most common issue would be, the minimap doesn't work in HDR.
And if you don't turn HDR on, the graphics looks like crap. 
And to be honest some scenes still looks like crap with HDR turned on, it seems like some designers messed up the PBS properties of certain assets.
Graphics aside, whether the gameplay is good or not is debatable.  
It feels like the game is specifically tweaked for playing on lower difficulties with a controller and multiplayer mode. Playing on higher difficulties like ultra-violent and nightmare with mouse and keyboard exposes a lot of problems.  


Case in point, enemies could attack the player across the map with pin-point accuracy; 
sometimes the projectiles would fly through walls and makes you think you get damage by just walking.
enemies would attack the player from positions where player can't reach;
enemies could constantly getting stuck in corners and sometimes in mid air;
there could be "wrong" decisions about selecting weapon mods during first play-through, in other words, selecting one mod over another can make the upcoming arena or challenge more difficult to beat;
enemies sometimes could dodge attacks in an "only possible for bots" fashion and end up breaking the animation sequences;
certain enemy type, especially mini bosses' behavior and stats are clearly tweaked for playing with a controller, makes maneuvering in circle is always more effective then hit and run;
gameplay rely too heavily on QTE (glory kills);

there're a lot of problems like the ones listed above, but these are results of more serious problems.
The game, other then how the weapons and enemies are animated,  doesn't feel like Doom. Instead it feels like a mix of other popular games in recent years with a Doom coating.  

But, at least it's not boring.

I came into Doom Eternal expecting a solid shooter that would be worth the 30$ I spent for it on the summer sale. I skipped Doom 2016 because it seemed like another bland and brown 7th gen tier shooter and it didnt pull me in. The gameplay for this game seemed faster, more complex, and I liked the aesthetic better. In the end, I decided to give it a shot.


I started the game on ultra violence (Hard) and I got my face kicked in. (You are underpowered at the start) I thought I lowered the difficulty to medium, but I wouldnt find out until 2 levels later that I actually didn't. I thank god I didn't actually lower the difficulty because it forced me to learn the ropes of the game, By forcing me to learn the loop of the game as the devs intended it, I was having so much fun that this may be one of my favorite shooters of all time if not my favorite shooter outright. The Slayer moves very fast and the dashes and double jump help encourage this mobility. There is platforming to help break up the intense action encounters, and I believe this to be a positive aspect of the game. Not only does it allow fun breathers between intense action sections, but it reinforces that this game is really about mobility.

Weapon Switching is another fun aspect of this game too. There are some demons that are hard countered by some weapons, and some weapons just work better on certain demons. This encourages weapon switching which can be satisfying later in the playthrough. This encourages you to use more weapons other than the SSG, and you will find that almost all of these weapons are not only just useful, but really fun as well.

The slayer has the flamethrower (flame belch) to use on enemies if you want armor, glory kills for health, and chainsawing enemies for ammo. Since this game has pretty low ammo, (at least at the start) you will need to become accustomed to using the chainsaw, along with all these other things. This bothered me at first in this game, but as I got better at the loop, (and got more weapons so also more usable ammo), I found myself enjoying an exhilirating gameplay loop. This really surprised me, because needing to use scripted glory kills in 2016 somewhat turned me off from buying that game. But I swear if that is your reservation, this game will convert you. The glory kills and chainsaw not only keeps you in the blood pumping action zone, but gives you a second to check all your cooldowns and plan your next move after scripted kill. This is really useful on higher difficulties. And thats another thing... If you arent looking for a pure casual experience, I encourage you to start your first playthrough on ultra violence and try to fight through it. It will force and teach you into the gameplay loop that is unrivaled in the FPS genre.

The secrets in this game are pretty cool as well. You get records you can listen to in your hub, toys you can look at in your hub, and cheat codes that are fun to use when replaying levels. I find the hub to be a very nice addition, and its fun to screw around the hub. There are also alternate skins you can unlock in the hub like the classic Doom Marine Skin. The weapon mods also allow you to use your weapons in unique ways, and you can choose weapon mods that cater to your playstyle,

Some nitpicks with the game, I found the purple goo segments to run against the gameplay philosophy of this game and were very unfun. I wasnt a fan of the tentacle enemies, and I disliked the final boss of the game.  Although I apparently didnt have the one weapon mod that works well on the boss, so maybe that was my problem. The suit enhancements feel useless except for the exploration ones, because those help you find secrets easier. I also found the grenades tacked on, but maybe thats just due to my own playstyle.

I initially had a problem with the Marauder, but I found out the main issue with him is that the tutorial misleads you. His gimmick is that you can only attack him when he decides to attack you at mid range. It tells you that you need to be in mid range and if he shoots you with his shotgun, he is too close and if he shoots his axe at you you are too far. But what you need to do is stand at the inner range of his axe range. What he will then do is run up to you and attack you. Then you can SSG him and combo that into a ballista shot. Once you figure this out, it becomes much easier, and a fun fight.

Battlemode is also fun for a few rounds, but not something I would keep playing. Playing Slayer in MP feels like a downgrade from SP. 

The story is also fine as helps builds Doom Slayer up as this really cool dude, but that is just a backdrop to the gameplay tbqh. It's good you can skip most of the cutscenes if you want.

Overall, I find the Singleplayer Campaign in Doom Eternal to be one of the greatest shooter campaigns of all time. Its hard to think of another FPS game that compares. As a reasult, I have to give this game a 98/100. I highly recommend people to buy this game and I 100% would have payed full price for it. I can't wait for the DLC. Rarely does a game come out that impresses me this much.
Now that devs have removed the anti cheat, I fully recommend this game. Tons of fun, quality hours ripping and tearing through hell.

	[td]Mechanics[/td]
	[td]9[/td]
	[td]
+ Movement greatly improved with not only double jump but also the addition of dash. With that comes new platforming sections, which I quite enjoyed.
+ Ammo capacity for weapons almost halved, leading to more resource management. I enjoyed this change which doesn’t allow you to just kill mindlessly.
+ Combat is the tense and adrenaline pumping experience from Doom turned up to 11, dashing across the level and blasting demons from whatever distance you deem fit. The more open environment complements this very well.
+ Pistol is completely removed, which I think is a good thing since it’s rarely useful.
+ Chainsaw is now an essential part in combat. Glory kills no longer provides ammo, and you will need the chainsaw to get ammo, which now recharges one pit automatically.
-	Fortress of Doom don't really add much to the game, other than providing a safe haven for practicing combat but even that is counter-intuitive because it is so far away from where you usually are in the fortress.
-	The fucking purple goo is the worst thing introduced, disabling your dash and jump, in a fast paced game.
-	The toxic water and tentacles combo are the worst because the toxic water wants you to move fast or you will take damage but the tentacles wants you to stay slow or risk getting jabbed. It’s just ?????
-	Demon customizations don’t apply in the campaign.
-	Mission Replay and Master Level progresses don’t save.
[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td][/td]
	[td]Content[/td]
	[td]10[/td]
	[td]+ Tons of content within each campaign level.
+ Outside of the main campaign, there are Master Levels, which are harder versions of existing levels.
+ Progression system ranges from suit improvements to weapon modifications and attachments to health, ammo and armor capacity increases, all these while adding new demons to the mix.
-	Another case of developers wasting time to work on multiplayer mode that most people don’t play Doom for.
-	You can only equip 3 runes making the rest of the runes redundant.
- For the amount of work you put in for the Unmaykr, it is next to useless.
[/td]

	[td][/td]
	[td]9[/td]
	[td]This is a very good Doom game, and a better one than 2016's Doom. The game retains its fast paced action while introducing new movement abilities like dashing and swinging and new demons, greatly reducing ammo capacity to encourage weapons switching, glory kill no longer providing ammo thus mandating the use of chainsaw. which I really welcome. That being said, there are some mechanics that I very much detest such as the purple goo and the tentacles which luckily only exists in the first half of the game. The game’s unstability also diminished my enjoyability a bit, which is the main reason why this game couldn’t get a 10. While I loved this new concept of tighter combat, you probably won’t like this game if you just want an action game with mindless killing associated with 2016's Doom. In a nutshell, if you like to think while playing and be challenged, then I strongly suggest playing Doom Eternal, on Nightmare, and you will get an experience no other games will provide. Life is limited, but Doom is eternal. [/td]

review:
DOOM Eternal is an action packed first person shooter that has you killing demons left and right! It differs from DOOM 2016 when it comes to difficulty. You need to be more tactical in this game. For example, you can't just spray and pray. If you do this you will die. Instead you should prioritize each enemy and know what their weaknesses are (which all of them have). The only gripe I have is the ammo issue. You simply run out of ammo too fast. You can use the chainsaw to get more ammo but this happens way too often to be a fun game mechanic. The plus side to this is that you are going to be using your abilities all the time compared to DOOM 2016 where you can just beat the game with the shotgun.

Apart from that, the secrets in this game are a blast to discover and the rewards you get for finding them make it worth it to do a second play through of the game.

As of now, I am still stuck on the last level because it is really hard for me but I will finish it at some point.

All in all, the game does not take itself too seriously at some points but all around it is a great game and a worthy followup of DOOM 2016.
A getting gas simulator with diabolically good level design.

Simply amazing. 
If your are not used to the weapon and ammo management system from playing Doom (2016) this may seem a little annoying at first. But give it same time to get used to it, learn to use the weapon mods most efficiently (almost every enemy has a weak point which can be exploited using the fitting weapon mod - read the codes pages) and you will feel like it says in the trailer - an unstoppable force. And from that point on palying the game is just pure fun.
Difficulty as you would expect from a Doom title: Even on "just" Hurt me plenty it's not a walk in the park. 
Looks and feels great. Music is awesame. Some may argue that there is that story gap from Doom (2016). That is true, but personally I don't care. It's Doom, I just want to kill monsters.
Also tried out Battlemode: Not that bad. You get a taste of it during the campaign too while getting the shotgun.
All in all: Highly recommended!

The game started off fun, but it got old and frustrating pretty early on.

I guess the developers think a good challenge is to spawn mid to high tier enemies all over you so when trying to focus on what's in front of you, you get spawn fucked from behind. The boss battles in this game aren't enjoyable, and the Khan one was the dumbest thing ever. The ground turns into fire while you have enemies shooting at you and the main boss firing crap at you. You die quickly and it makes the whole experience awful. The last level of the game was the most ridiculous ever. It's literally a mess of enemies surrounding you while you run away and glory kill for health. You'll be doing a lot of that in this game.

Not to mention the platforming in this game is beyond despicable. Especially in the last few levels.

A note to the developer: JUST BECAUSE YOU HAVE 100 ENEMIES ATTACKING YOU AT ONCE DOESN'T MAKE YOUR SHOOTER "CHALLENGING". It makes it frustrating and repetitive. I actually enjoyed the game more when there wasn't any combat. That's not what you want from a FPS..

Also this game is a weapon switching simulator. You'll be mashing buttons to switch through your weapons to fit enemy weaknesses, especially when you have 5-10 different enemy types at any given time..

I wish I could have realized I didn't like this game sooner to get a refund.

This is long
TL;DR the game has a lot of good ideas but more worse ones, and ones that weigh the game down beyond mediocrity, turning the game into a incredibly frustrated slog halfway through

Man oh man, this is a huge conflict in my head but ima go with this aint worth it. This game has an issue, and its rooted in it trying to be so much more than DOOM 2016. All of the new enemies are wild and new and do well, the most possible annoying things. The game has a momentum issue, in a game where you are encouraged to jump and fly around the map and switch between all your weapons to get tons of awesome kills on the demon populace of earth, it sucks that there is SO MUCH that absolutely HALTS the momentum. The scraps of ammo forcing you to constantly empty whole guns on tougher enemies and scramble to chainsaw a smaller zombie or imp, enemies with tons of attacks that forcibly move you and stop you on top of reducing your look speed, enemies requiring specific weapons to combat reducing the amount you use your whole arsenal, and most notably the marauders. 

here is where I will gripe about the marauders and how they actually ruin the game for the rest of this review
The marauders are a major major issue in the game, each fight halts the gameplay and FORCES you to focus on only them, if you dont you will be killed by them almost immediately even on lower difficulties. Worst of all if you even attempt to play outside of the EXTREMELY specific and incredibly vaguely defined parameters the marauder allows you to fight in, you are heavily punished. Hell the fucker can even juggle you around with his attacks as they all reduce your movement and push you around. On top of all that, he blocks ALL quick kills in the game. The instant kill crucible? he blocks it. The extremely deadly unmakyr players have to work incredibly hard to get? he blocks it. The legendary BFG9000, one of the deadliest weapons in DOOM history? he blocks it. Once again FORCING you to play by HIS rules. The only real effective weapons against him are the railgun and super shotty, weapons that have EXTREMELY limited ammo, so you either make every shot count or try to chainsaw an enemy while he bullies you. On top of all that is the ways he punishes you. If you shoot his shield at all: he sends out a wolf that you cannot dodge that does 40 to 60 damage, if you aren't looking at him, he darts as close as possible to shoot you with the shotgun, reducing your movement and look speed on top of taking a hefty chunk of health. If you're too close he shoots the shotgun, if you're too far he shoots tracking projectiles at you, if you're in range he will dart around in and out of range of his ONLY attack that allows you to retaliate making it incredibly difficult to even keep track of.

This blows, i hate it so much, cause the game has so much good shit in it, the equipment is all fantastic, the actual weapons sound and feel so much chunkier, the new weapons are great additions, the weakpoint system is really satisfying albeit a little too important, and the old enemies brought back to this game are super fun to fight and look fantastic. It sucks that it gets bogged down by a myriad of horrible ideas in the quest of trying to make new enemies and ways to fight.

The good:
+ Soundtrack
+ Adrenaline-filled blasting action
+ Engaging in the beginning

The bad:
- Instead of focusing on ripping & tearing, the game wants you to focus on managing skill cooldowns and ammo supply, and switching to the "right" gun at the right time
- The game feels repetitive after unlocking all weapons
- Marauders ruin the flow of the game
- The story is mediocre (compared to Doom 2016)

Over all, fun for a while, but finishing the game felt like a chore.

Really tried to enjoy the game, but can't.
Therefore no recommendation from me.

review:
What an amazing combination of lore, combat mechanics, and pounding metal, this is such an incredible evolution of Doom 2016, as the Doom Slayer, you feel absolutely unstoppable, the entire experience is geared to let you roam free and murder away. The game also requires tactics and an incredible amount of resource managing and gun switching, I've already seen comments of people who don't like the low ammo counts, it's for that exact reason to nudge you into the aggressive, switching playstyle they want you to be in. The enemies are brutal and unforgiving especially on higher difficulties (and in the slayer gates, which are some of the most challenging gunfights I've had in gaming) and the weapons are a blast to use (That super shotgun <3) there's a great self aware sense of humour carrying through the game and plenty of easter eggs and references to find. The soundtrack is downright incredible, I will rip and tear anyone who says otherwise to pieces.
Downsides? The codex is a bit uninspired and dry, especially compared to 2016 which was genuinely funny sometimes, some collectables feel a bit, placeholdery(?) and half baked. These are pretty much the only two things I can actually hold against the game.
As an experience, this is absolutely worth paying full price for. Kar En Tuk.

Doom Eternal is a great game that takes the mobility of Doom to a new level. The devs have made some major changes, such as limiting ammo, and buffing enemies greatly. However, this is offset by your new tools. 

This time all  enemies are projectile or melee based. This encourages a high-octane style of play with the Slayer dodging enemy projectiles while using weapon combos to devastate them. Think of Doom 2016 on Nightmare. However this time they have given you a double dash, regenerating chainsaw, a freeze grenade, and a more reliable way to get armor (flame belch). It originally seems much harder than Doom 2016, but once you realize what you have to do, Doom Eternal plays a lot like a Doom 2016 with more enemies and a faster Slayer. 

The areas of this game are much more diverse than 2016. There  is the mangled cityscape, the hellified Super Gore Nest, the beautiful vistas of Exultia combined with more hellish elements, an arctic Cultist Base, Ancient Sentinel cities, and more. There are also an abundant amount of secrets as would befit a Doom game. This time they have more clearly marked these areas with enticing question marks where these collectibles are. 

You can view these collectibles in the Fortress of Doom, where you can purchase upgrades with Sentinel Batteries hidden all over the various locations, unlock skins with said batteries, look at your weapons and collectibles, listen to music you've collected, and even play Doom 1 and Doom II. There's also a practice arena where you can test your weapons, practice your movement and combos, and get better if you're struggling. There's even some more secrets inside the Fortress of Doom. 

Some dislikes about the game:
Runes are just given instead of through Rune Trials which was much more fun. If you replay a level for fun and spend BFG or Crucible ammo it doesn't get replenished. Inversely you can also run through levels when you have spent all of these just collecting BFG rounds (such as in BFG division). I would just prefer having everything replenished in the middle of levels instead of everything BUT BFG and Crucible rounds (which you can farm through level replays anyway). I also highly dislike Battlemode. Either the demons are put against someone who is sh*t or they go up against Slayers that completely destroy. Just give us back Deathmatch :(

Overall Doom Eternal is a pinnacle of shooter design that is worthy of bearing the name Doom.

I think that DOOM 2016 is superior of the two, but DOOM Eternal is still an awesome good time!  DOOM 2016 was a bit simpler of a shooter which made slaying demons an enjoyable pass-time.  Plus, who can forget memorable tracks such as Rip & Tear and BFG Division?  In DOOM Eternal, there is an increased emphasis on movement while shooting, as well as some challenging platforming elements.  The moving and shooting feels incredibly smooth once mastered, but the platforming continues to be a bit clunky.  The soundtrack is in no way bad, but there has yet to be any stand-out tracks.  There is a return of BFG Division in one of the challenges, and that was quit a nice surprise!  The graphics and visuals are incredible to say the least.  Props to the art team for designing a truly hellish Earth and some VERY beastly demons!

Overall, I recommend DOOM Eternal to fans of the franchise.  The shooting is smooth, the graphics beautiful, and the story compelling.  The movement can be clunky and glitchy, but nothing game-breaking.  Pick it up!

I finally got around to playing and completing this thing and as someone who has been playing id software games since the 90's the whole thing comes off as a polished love letter to their fans. This is everything that a shooter should be. I've got a long way to go before I can say I've mastered it. I just completed the campaign on Hurt Me Plenty and while I felt like latter parts of the game we're tough to the point I even let out a few WTFs at the screen, I never thought it was unfair. They give you the tools to carve your way through it. Its just about re-training yourself to use it all in the right place and at the right time. Keep momentum going, don't get hemmed up in corners, etc. I mean I've just finished and I'm already anticipating doing additional playthroughs on harder settings. If you love classic shooters, and you dig their idea of using enemies as chess pieces on a battlefield then you'll love this. Added bonus this is the only modern game I can think of that sets up cheat codes as a reward item. So like the Doom games of old if you want to just play god and mindlessly blow up deamons, hey. That's here too!

The easiest way to describe Doom Eternal is it's the Sonic Mania of Doom: riddled with fanservice, trying to find a happy medium between classic design and modern game dev sensibilities, and it turned out quite alright for what it's worth. Maps are more interesting to navigate over those in 2016's Doom, combat is made more engaging with the aid of elements like The Marauder and the cryo grenade, and the soundtrack is much more in line with my expectations for modern Doom, though it never really gets as enjoyably experimental as Doom II's soundtrack, which feels only like a bit of a missed opportunity. Definitely up there with The Ultimate Doom as a fundamentally solid, enjoyable Doom, though not without its snags and burrs.

You already know what DOOM Eternal is.

I would like to preface my thoughts by addressing the fact that I loathe Bethesda Softworks, and its parent company, Zenimax. My disdain for their practices, lack of integrity, intelligence, creativity, and end-user-friendly policies is widely known. While I acknowledge the fact that Bethesda is a publisher and ID are the actual developers, it is difficult at times to differentiate the two with decisions I find to be in poor taste at the management and game design level.

With that said: This is, without a doubt, one of the most impressive and fun FPS games I've ever played, and I've played an unhealthy amount of them. I'm late to the party with my review, given the hotbed of unending Bethesda controversy at the time of release, along with the growing crisis that was the Covid-19 pandemic. I find myself to be somewhat disappointed that I waited as long to actually play it as I am. It's more than likely you already know enough about DOOM Eternal to make your own judgement call aside from my review, but I'd like to throw my hat in there regardless.

I have a lot I could say about this game, but this is the most important: It is very, very much worth your time and money at full price. You won't be disappointed.
