[Note: The multiplayer aspect hasn’t interested me nor do I have anyone to play it with, so that’s why it won’t be covered in this review.]

For as much as I dislike relying on comparisons, it’s hard for 2016’s Doom (I’ll call it Doom 4 for the sake of ease) to not be stacked against Doom Eternal. It’s more of that heavy, crunching combat I enjoyed back in 2016 (which in itself is worth it at price of admission), and while there hasn’t been drastic changes in terms of the gameplay loop of explore, fight, hunt for secrets and repeat, it does just enough to keep it from feeling like a glorified expansion pack. Tight gameplay, plenty of options to fight with based on the situation, exploration that’s a bit more than industrial parkour, new fantastic hellscapes… If only the boss fights weren’t gimmicky and bloated.

Where 4’s story was essentially ‘Oops, All Demons’, Eternal’s story is… It’s still ‘Oops, All Demons’, except this time Earth is under threat of demonic consumption with the Doom Slayer using a floating fortress as his base of operations to plan out and stop the incursion. There’s plenty of collectible lore to discover and read into for greater context and information, but admittedly that was low on my to-do list. What I did read into was well-structured, written and considered, so even though I went through the full game barely looking into the lore, it’s there for anyone interested and I can appreciate the effort from the writers. The plot can still be followed since it’s rather open and shut on who the bad guys are and what needs to be done to stop them - It’s Doom, after all.

Anyone coming from 4 to Eternal should feel right at home, but for those unfamiliar, Eternal’s gameplay is fast, arsenal and equipment based first-person-shooter combat frequently taking place in arenas with multiple terrain and movement options for better positioning and evasion. While there are some options for being precise, a tactical shooter this ain’t; standing still typically means game over, so mobility and target priority is a must. I can’t help but feel like the AI in Eternal got an upgrade in terms of their aggression, as there were far fewer instances I could duck behind a corner and catch my breath; if there’s enemies, they’re either in constant pursuit or bombarding you from range. Add to that encounters having more enemies to begin or spawning as the fight goes on, and you have a campaign that requires good usage of all your tools and ammo management even on normal difficulty. The flamethrower being so reliable does hurt the game somewhat, as having a tool that lets you set enemies ablaze for more armor increases your survivability, but lets the game get away with more, angry enemies. During regular encounters this is fine since it’s less time scrambling for pickups and more time in the fray, but this turns boss battles into a drawn out survival challenge instead of feeling like a major bout. With pickups being limited and enemies being used as ammunition and armor caches, cannon fodder regularly appear to serve that purpose - While still retaining their aggression amidst the boss’ own attacks. The previous game was just the boss versus the player which made the set piece feel all the more grand; in Eternal, bosses feel like a colossal gimmick with resource pinatas running around instead of this nefarious big bad to take down, especially with them having a tell to watch out for before damage can be inflicted - Often having a break in between to wait for the next opening.


This being my only real complaint of Doom Eternal, at least bosses are spread apart which means the majority of your time in the game is spent going from regular encounter to encounter and exploring the level for secrets. There’s standard secrets for upgrades, power ups and weapon modifiers to aid in combat (as was the case in 4), but there are also collectibles that are displayed and usable back at the Doom Fortress (level hub). There’s even items to find at the fortress, making it another place to explore for prizes but also to unwind in and maybe find an easter egg or two. Platforming has more going for it with some segments making use of swing bars, climbing walls and boosters to cover great distances with. Some of these elements also appear in arenas for greater mobility and vantage points, and when combined with an upgrade to allow greater air control, other than jump height there’s not a terrible lot keeping you from repositioning anywhere you want during fights - So long as it’s a valid surface and there’s no ten foot demon ready to clap you out of midair. When fast travel gets awarded, backtracking being a chore to find missed secrets is avoided and lets you pace out how to progress the level, either by heading right for the end then retracing your steps or snooping around after encounters or platforming segments.

My expectations for Doom Eternal were middle of the road mostly because I wasn’t sure where else they could take the game when I went into it. Its campaign expanded upon why the Doom Slayer is power incarnate and certainly ensures you get to wield that power with the games’ combat, but even with only a few peppered in the boss battles slaughter the fun and are the only reason I haven’t started a new playthrough yet. When I say the final boss is exhausting, it’s due to the length and incessant additional enemies spawning, not due to difficulty. That said, whether on higher difficulties to test if your Doom 4 or mobile shooting skills are sharp or lower difficulties to go for that sheer power trip, Doom Eternal is still a great, fun and worthwhile campaign.

This is a massive improvement on the already impressive DOOM 2016. DOOM Eternal introduces several new combat mechanics that really takes the game to the next level. Health, armor, ammo, melee, chainsaw, and the "flame-belch" all form a self sustaining economy that allows you to have the maximum carnage possible. Next to challenging new demons, more impressive music, and an ever evolving lore, the game doesn't stop offering you new quality content. Some have  complained that it isn't similar enough to the originals, but I assure you this is a natural, and logical evolution of the mechanics in the original DOOM. This is one of the best shooters recently developed, if for nothing else but the uniqueness alone.
Possibly even better than the first one. I'm just getting started but I'm hooked.

The story is also overdone and doesn't flow naturally. Seems to have been written by a 12 yr old, but the gameplay generally makes up for it.

I will not be playing this game until they add a singleplayer-only option and an opt-out for the kernel level MALWARE they are shipping with this game. Please do research on the potential  security risks and potential system stability problems before you install this software.

[h1]Game Title: Doom Eternal [/h1]
[h1]Date of Review: 27/07/2020 [/h1]

[b]Story: [/b] [h1] 4/5 [/h1]
Story when playing Doom in never something I would normally pay attention to, but this one caught my attention. Whilst it may not be the most structurally sound story it definitely gives you a sense of direction and accomplishment rather than just “KILL EVERYTHING!”. But...... y’know, still “KILL EVERYTHING!”

[b]Gameplay: [/b] [h1] 4.5/5 [/h1]
Fast paced, action packed, gore and more. Single Player is exactly this with the previously mentioned story as well as collectibles and an array of guns, upgrades and challenges. As for Multiplayer; it is a 2v1 system where 1 person plays the slayer and 2 people play demons that can also spawn lesser demons. Demons have to kill the slayer once to win a round and the doom slayer has to kill both demons within a 20 second window to win a round. Whilst I enjoyed the multiplayer, it quickly reached its lifespan for me, but during the time I did play, the community seemed decent and friendly for the best part.

[b]Graphics: [/b] [h1] 4/5 [/h1]
Visually this game is awesome, blood and guts everywhere, chunks getting blown off of demons and some of the kill animations are just pure art. 

[b]Sound: [/b] [h1] 4.5/5 [/h1]
The soundtrack is fantastic, not quite as good as the first one (2016) but that may be due to how it was mixed. Sound FX are on point and combined the game is made to be very atmospheric.

[b]Value for Money: [/b] [h1] 4.5/5 [/h1]
I got just under 70 hours out of this, around 50 in single player and 20 in multiplayer. Multiple difficulties made for plenty of replays in single player as well as collectibles, challenges and other cool Easter eggs and unlocks.

[b]Conclusion: [/b][h1] Final Score: 86% [/h1]
I really enjoyed this game and definitely recommend it if you are a fan of pretty much anything by Bethesda, faced paced action games or if you are just a fan of Doom in general. 

At full price I still consider this game good value for money, but to get the most out of your money, wait for a sale. I got it in the summer sale at 50% off which massively increased the value for money.
Best single player shooter campaign in a long time. Plays very different than 2016 will take some getting used to for new players, but its totally worth it once you learn how to play it.
Excellent game.
Rip and tearing so smooth it doesn't have wrinkles on its admittedly large ball-sack.

review:
This game does not live up to Doom 2016. There are too many buttons to press to use the various gadgets. The button layout is now different so you're constantly pressing wrong buttons. This would be fine if the game allowed you to play how you want to play but this game forces you to play the game in a specific way. You have to exploit enemy weaknesses to progress or you have to turn down the difficulty. For a fast paced game, the game has surprisingly poor movement. You're gonna be constantly getting stuck on edges and in enemy hit boxes. On top of this, the game wants you to do platforming puzzles. If you miss a single platform jump, you often have to do the whole thing again. I just want to fight demons, I don't want to solve any puzzles. 

I had to force myself to play the game multiple sessions and I haven't enjoyed the game at any moment. The Doom slayer feels really weak. The guns don't seem to have any impact. I wish I skipped this game and I wish the online reviewers had been more honest about this game's shortcomings.

Poor DOOM Eternal, attacked on release for being different, and having bethesdas grubby hands all over it during major updates has really messed with this games reputation. If you ignore the admin stuff and focus on the game only one words comes to mind.

Fun.

This game is fun. It's objectively a better game than the 2016 version, you feel less of a badass but the amount of raw enjoyment you can get is insane, levels are long and full of secrets, but each are visually distinct, unlike the 2016 version. DOOM 2016 often felt like a sprint, bullrushing your way through enemies using weapons to get get a slight advantage whereas Eternal is more like a dance, choosing the right tool for the job and annihilating the competition. It's harder but much more rewarding when you clear that one hard arena. 

Fun is the name of the game here, in every aspect of this games development - fun came first, and it shows.

The game is good, I had a really enjoyable time playing it. Just visited it recently and have discovered my average FPS is half the usual + as many have pointed out, realized that Denuvo was also added. As many others have said Denuvo is a extremely dodgey anti-cheating software that has complete access to your pc. When I say complete access I mean complete access, and as always there are methods to use it as a backdoor to your system potentially if Denuvo is ever compromised (which is not a rare thing nowadays) Like said the game is fun, but this is a complete and utter over step by Bethesda in terms of breaching privacy+Security compromises, and for what? Stopping some asshole from cheating in a multiplayer mode that is already generally deemed to be extremely unbalanced because of the OP Doom Slayer? So we're supposed to put our privacy and pc safety on the line by installing a rootkit just to play? No thanks. While I'll continue fighting for the game in general (it's really really fun) and the dev's deserve praise, whoever thought this recent update was smart is a complete fool and because of this decision I refuse to support such a game. 

UPDATE: Denuvo was removed, Back to recommending the game. I appreciate Bethesda's response, and it's nice to see a company respond to the fan's backlash regarding Denuvo (Even if it was due to an overwhelming outrage) At the very least this is a more positive response than say Fallout 76 lol.

Brutally beautiful shooter that feels like a violent Arkham Asylum in Hell; you will be surrounded by a whole bestiary requiring strategic execution. You will have to use your reflexes, speed, aggression and your entire arsenal to survive. Of course, that all looks and plays great. A ballet of blood, fire, guts and high-flying maneuvers. The only criticism I got is regarding the multiplayer; it was better in Doom 2016 whereas here, it feels like an afterthought. However, where it counts; the single-player, Doom Eternal is fun. Makes me happy I pre-purchased this as I did Doom 2016 before. At this point, Im 89% sure that I will pre-purchase the next Doom if it comes. Finally, you will DIE! So, you can't just half-ass your way through. That and if you play on anything lower than Ultra-Violence; you are screwing yourself out of a rewarding, stimulating shooter experience. P.S Big ups to whoever created the Marauder; genuinely fun to fight him. Unpopular opinion I know.
Insane action, intense and full of suspense. Hunting for secrets is also fun. The story is told out in a fun and well choreographed way. Lots of visual detail...great game!

This game is the pinnacle of action in first person shooters, i highly recommend it. The graphics are great, the size is astonishingly small(only 39 gb). The main campaign lasts for about 20 hours with tons of replayability and it has solid mechanics which encourage creativity. You cant go wrong with this game.
Be warned though, the multiplayer is an okay asymmetric mode without conventional modes and you should at the very least know a bit more about the kind of game this is, since this is very far removed from any other shooters in the industry.

Updating this review since I have finished the game now. I again find it difficult to adhere to Steam's binary review system, but I have to barely end up on the recommend side.  But, I recommend you buy this only on sale, I do not think it was worth the glowing review it has gotten or the full price I paid.  If you liked the last Doom, you will love this one.  If you have not played one of the modern ones, I would definitely pass over the last one for this one.  Here is my summary:

Graphics - 9/10 - They are top notch, but I think the conceptualization is too comic-book like and wish it had been more gritty.

SFx/Music - 10/10 - Man did they hit the nail on the head with this. You just have to listen for yourself.

Plot/Story - 4/10 - They made a bunch of convoluted lore to serve as background and narrative. It is boring and worst of all, serves no purpose since no one ever needed a reason to play Doom. But what is painfully obvious as you progress through the game is that someone spent tons of time writing all of the schlock when it could have better spent ironing out some of the gameplay issues.  This is a game where less is more when it comes to plot.

Control - 9/10 - Your default speed is too slow in my opinion. Other than this, everything is great. It feels very responsive and natural. All keys are can be rebound to your liking.

Gameplay - 7/10 - Oh man, they were so close to perfection.  The fighting mechanics themselves are brilliant.  But they made a few  huge mistakes. First, they kept the game linear as it was in the last version, and even worse, in this game they do not even hide it and most of the time you know you are going into combat before you even get there.  Once you are in an encounter you are locked into that are and cannot move until you have finished the encounter.  Second, the maps are ENORMOUS and working your way through them is incredibly tedious and kills the replay value for me. You can never backtrack through a level. Completely the opposite of Doom's original brilliant gameplay. There are also some very bad decisions that were made about enemy behavior/design that really decrease the level of fun. First, there are two things in the game that can 'boost' the enemies, boost totems and another enemy called the Archevile. While an interesting idea, it is ultimately pointless because the what simply happens is that as soon as you are aware one of these things exists you immediately do nothing else but find that so you can destroy it because there will be no way to win without doing so. Often you simply cannot find them so you just die repeatedly trying to find it.  Another problem is the marauder, but others have written about that, just google it.  There are other things, too.  Trust me, there are issues with the gameplay!

Side note:  I have to remark that this is the most stable games I have played in ages.  Not only does it never crash, there is never even a hiccup or stutters when playing. 

So, 39/40, as I said, buy on sale.

I want to love this game, I really do.  For the things I love, this game is hands down beautiful.  The scenes portrayed feel like something horrifying and crazy is happening, yet are painstakingly beautiful.  You can see that much work went into the graphics system and they knocked it straight out of the park.  The game engine runs smoothly and I did not have any types of stuttering or lag while playing where other games, even including Doom 2016, I had stutter in places that could kill you in game.  The music feels truly appropriate for each location you hear and it can make what would be a small uninteresting place enjoyable just from it alone.  The creativity of the creatures and scenarios you find yourself in also enhances this game in amazing ways.  Hell, even the multiplayer is a fun experience that even with the Demons being the more likely ones to win, playing as the Slayer is still enjoyable.  However, the actual combat mechanics, and to a much lesser extent, the story KILL all these experiences.  

Let’s start with the combat as they’ll probably be some spoilers in the story line of this.  If you enjoy Doom 2016 and are coming straight from it, your experience of the game will almost certainly be harsh at best.  I understand that many people enjoy hard games and even I have enjoyed harder games such as Dark Souls on my consoles.  But I can say this coming from Doom 2016 myself and that is the difficulty spike between the two is absolutely absurd.  

This is a game in which you are the Doom Guy, but within a life-based system around a large damage income and low health and shield recovery.  It ultimately will leave you feeling like some random guy who put on the Doom Guy armor and it’s the only reason you are even surviving rather then being the full-on Doom Guy who the demons of Hell fear so much.  You are expected to use every single alternate ability to it’s fullest and if you are not fast enough or familiar enough with these abilities, you will die quickly even on the lower difficulties.  This incentivizes you to have some of the highest reflexes I have ever seen required for a video game and can be very harsh on someone who is not quick on the draw.  

Weapons of the game feel a bit down trodden.  The punch mechanic of the game is nerfed to be almost completely useless taking 10-20 punches to kill even a basic zombie that a single gunshot could remove unless you have a blood punch charged up.  In addition, there is no pistol so the two fall back weapons of previous Doom games are completely removed by these actions.  Your selections of weapons come back to some well-known Doom weapons, but their ammo reserves are so incredibly low that after a few shots you will find yourself running on empty and being unable to fight.  For best example, if you fully max out the ammo increase in this game your Shotgun ammo still does not even reach the first ammo upgrade in Doom 2016 for the shotgun.  In order to combat this, you are expected to make full use the chainsaw on small enemies which will then drop ammo.  It quickly becomes apparent that this is a painfully bad game technique as you are required to quickly kill the larger enemies while leaving the small ones alone. Any enemy in this game can deal serious damage to you so if you leave too many of the small ones around you will be over run as they keep spawning until the large enemies are dead.  However, if you kill too many you will find yourself out of ammo and most likely dying to larger enemies while hoping a small one spawns for a new ammo cache.  

Enemies are enjoyable for the most part.  Some of the new additions such as Whiplash and Gargoyles are annoying as Hell itself, but they feel like good additions and fit well into the system.  Marauders though DO NOT and they ruin the experience of the enemies.  This here is a creature that does not fit into any rhyme or reason within the gameplay.  If you are too close, it shoots you with a super shotgun.  If you are two far it blasts you with energy.  If you are standing the perfect distance from it, it will attack you with an energy axe.  If this was all the Marauder did, it would be a strong enemy and a unique one to the game.  Nope, they decided to give it a shield that it can bring up and negate all damage at any time.  Think you’ll one hit kill it with a BFG or Crucible attack, nope it’s immune to both of these one hit kills.  So you have a very attack driven and defensible enemy now.  What more to give it?  How about a large amount of health requiring several shots to kill when you are able to hit it?  How about a summoned dog that spawns and attacks if too much damage is dealt to the Marauders shield by you or by other enemies.  This enemy felt like it should have been a boss fight and for one of the stages it is, but then they just throw it in as a casual enemy in locations with several others in a wave spawn.  There was no reason for this other than to artificially create a difficulty that could have been obtained without this enemy and still felt fair and normal in the game.  

At last, the story.  If you do not want any potential spoilers, please end your reading here.  TLDR of this, the story went off the rails like a freight train having a head on collision with another train.  



Starting this game, I loved the story.  It seemed as though it was following up from Doom 2016.  There were a lot of questions such as who really are these priests, who are the Makyrs, what exactly are the sentinels, etc.  This game started explaining and answer these questions, you got to see how the Priests behaved, what had happened to the Sentinels homelands, even explained the downfall of the Sentinels.  The story was going great.  Then you get towards the end of the game and you have to rescue Hayden.  Here, the story shifts from an interesting story to “wtf, you threw out everything you just setup”.  Hayden seems to know everything that happened to Doom Guy.  He knows the machine that was used to give him incredible powers, he stole Father to make Vega, he knows the prophecies of the Makyrs from all I can see and find in game were never wrote down or shared with the Sentinels or Demons.  Everything in this game points to him being the rogue Makyr that created Doom Guy, but yet we know from everything in Doom 2016, Hayden was born a human, made the robot suit which others helped work on, and transferred himself into it so he could be a deadly disease.  How is in Doom Eternal this robot is now something that no one has ever seen the technology for and they cannot access it? There are so many questions here that I can’t even begin listing them all as it makes so many contradictions to the Doom 2016 and most of the Doom Eternal storyline when it gets to the end.  Maybe if there was something more clean to this I wouldn’t have issues as I do with the story and all problems would be solely with the combat.

Doom Eternal is not a bad game but it is a bad sequel to Doom (2016). The game seems to misunderstand what made Doom fun in 2016 and adds a lot of features which mostly make the game worse. The welcome additions are the weak points, new demons (NOT MARADUR) and there destroyable models. The ammo economy, glory kills drops, stage hazards, and cut scenes  all worsen the experience for me. The dash is fun at first but quickly makes your normal running speed seem slow by context. In Doom (2016) you always moved at max speed so you always felt fast. The puzzles and platforming is not complicated enough to be engaging and not simple enough to zone out for. Not sure what they do but pad the run time. 

The marauder is the least fun thing to play against in Doom Eternal. So many times I stopped playing once a marauder showed up. The fact you cannot use any super weapons to instakill them or even just damage them means you must engage with them in the very specific way the game wants you to. This the major problem with Doom Eternal is the railroading. You can only play Doom Eternal one way, exactly as the developer intended. Doom (2016) had a intended playstyle but playing a different way was still viable.

DOOM Eternal is a terrific game made by incredibly talented developers, marred by an out-of-touch publisher (Bethesda) its parent company (zenimax). I was lucky enough to have purchased this game at launch and played through the campaign on nightmare difficulty. I had a lot of fun with it and was looking forward to playing it again on the highest difficulty and discovering all of its secrets. The latest update that installs the Denuvo anti-cheat driver has forced me to uninstall the game. I don't intend to play the game until Bethesda allows consumers like me to opt out of installing the kernal-level driver. I refuse to install drivers that make my PC vulnerable to malicious attacks by third-parties.

UPDATE: Id updated the game to remove the Denuvo anti-cheat driver. I can recommend this game again. I still don't like that the driver was installed in the first place, but I commend Id for listening to feedback and taking necessary action

DOOM is a game I have always seen but never thought it would be anything that ever appealed to me. It looked too fast paced and gorey for my personal taste, or so I thought. I had decided to pick it up during summer sale 2020 and ended up starting it up about a week ago. I was pleasantly surprised.
Not only did the game have an incredible soundtrack to which I wanted to listen to just on its own, the gameplay, while incredibly visceral, makes you feel like a force of nature to be reckoned with. You feel unstoppable. As you jump through the levels and almost seem to laugh at the enemies trying to inflict damage on you, you are able to inflict double to triple right back at them. The game is enjoyable, to say the least. It has a subtle humor to it that cracked me up from time to time, and has a decent story that appears to go back all the way to the original game in 1993 (a game I have never played). 

In my honest opinion, being a demon killing John Wick is 100% worth $60. There's more than enough game play and I'm eager for DLC that's supposed to come out later this year. I haven't touched the multiplayer yet, but I enjoyed to campaign enough I am debating playing it again on a harder difficulty. 
Plus, it's... great for taking your anger out with.

[EDIT]: I'm more than thrilled to have this game back, now that the kernel-privileged Denuvo AC was removed. Since I took the time to give feedback about the DAC, the least I can do is provide an actual review now that it's gone:

  The red v blue team mutliplayer is a pretty cool take; definitely more on the creative side considering how cut and paste many FPS games are with PVP; but what's far more interesting to me is the campaign:

  The action is fast paced, in your face, punchy-blasty carnal goodness. It feels amazing to flash through swarms of enemies, swapping through truly various weapons while adapting to a shallower pool of health and ammo than traditional; presenting the player with a masterful balance between your abilities and the strength and volume of the enemies. 

  Continual movement is critical, making a few moments in the campaign heart-poundingly tense. I can't remember the last time, when going through a campaign the first time, that I stopped after taking down what felt like a sea of enemies, stopped and paused for a sec, and said out loud "that was f****ng AWESOME."

  I absolutely recommend this game to anyone who loves quick draw horde-slicing action; for those who love the old DOOM games and will appreciate the myriad Easter eggs and fuller story line, and those who will have this as their first time ripping and tearing.

review: They took out the Denuvo, so this has been edited to a positive review again. Good game.

Doom Eternal in my opinion is much better than its predecessor (Doom 2016).  The gameplay is good, however, I'm not a huge fan of the platforming/parkour of this game.  It feels a bit clumsy and not well designed in my opinion. 

Other than that playing through the game is such a thrill and enjoyment.  I enjoyed collecting all the collectibles there was to offer, all the toys, codex pages, albums, cheat codes, etc.  However I was unable to take many screenshots to upload due to the game crashing every single time I tried. I've always liked the campaign better than MP.  UN is very difficult (as it should be) and is taking me longer than I anticipated. But this game so much much to offer than I think I will focus a lot more time into MP for this game.

review:
This game is everything I wished some of the later Unreal games would have been as a kid. Didn't have access to a PC to play the original Unreal games, or Quake. Doom Eternal isn't bringing us back to what makes FPS games great; Doom Eternal takes us to the next level of the FPS genre. 

If you were a fan of Quake or Unreal, you are going to love Doom Eternal. Even if you aren't a fan of those games, this is one of the best FPS games I've ever played--give it a shot. 

What are you waiting for!? The mortally challenged aren't going to slay themselves!
Sick gameplay, sick graphics, sick music! Absolute blast of a game!
Very fun, holds up as one of the best shooters in my opinion

(Originally posted as positive on 3 Apr @ 5:01pm, revised to negative on 19 May @ 10:12am after the Denuvo issue, now revised back to positive.)

Doom Eternal is a solid 8.5/10 imo. It has an excellent single-player campaign, an incredible soundtrack, and the developers do seem to care about player feedback as after the questionable decision to add kernel-level "anticheat" software to the game, it was removed following backlash.

However, while Eternal is at its best when you go *pew pew* against hoards of demons, unfortunately inbetween the action there is more of a focus on narrative and also an ungodly amount of aggravating platforming that takes away from the experience imo.

[h3]The good[/h3]
[list]
[*] Another poggers soundtrack from Mick Gordon. Even the menu theme is a banger.
[*] Combat is really, really fun. Very challenging and fast-paced, the game really peaks when you're just up against hoards of demons and going wild. There's definitely a certain flow you have to get used to, but once you get it it's pretty sick.
[*] Visual direction and graphics. Compared to the last game, Eternal is a lot more vibrant and colourful. Demons have been redesigned, with some going from a very edgy look in 2016 to a more stylised, almost cartoony look in Eternal (cacodemons in particular come to mind). The environments are also a lot more creative and varied, and some like Urdak actually look absolutely gorgeous.
[*] Performance. My PC isn't the most modern, but I could still run it on high at 60 FPS for the majority of the game.
[/list]

[h3]The bad[/h3]
[list]
[*] The platforming, and level design in general. There's a lot of Xen-tier floating platform shite, in addition to wall climbing and swinging from monkey bars. There's also underwater sections?? I don't know why they went this direction, but I did not enjoy it.
[*] The story and writing. While I'm not against story in a Doom game, they just didn't do a good job for how much they emphasised it. Important and relevant information that gives context to what's going on is kept to collectible codex pages (meaning you have to read walls of text), or is simply not provided at all. They certainly tried, but I still had way more questions than answers by the end.
[/list]

[h3]The ???[/h3]
[list]
[*] The abundance of cutscenes. While the last game was pretty sparse with them, they really went ham here. Cutscenes aren't inherently bad, but I feel the excessive use of them really took away from the experience. You've got door opening cutscenes, riding the elevator cutscenes, talking to people cutscenes, you name it. Some of them are cool, but a lot of them just feel pointless. I'd rather press E to kill a demon than watch a cutscene of it being killed from a third-person perspective. 
[*] Linearity. This time around levels are SUPER linear and straightforward -- while this isn't necessarily a bad thing, it's certainly different. As a result though, it's a lot less time-consuming to hunt for collectibles and progress through levels.
[/list]

TLDR: shooting good, platforming bad
Amazing game. Even better then 2016.

Wow I get to own a product that I buy? What a revolutionary concept. Thanks, ID.

As for the actual game, it's only slightly worse than DOOM 2016. The combat is faster and more complicated, and there's a ton of enemy variation, but it feels significantly less cohesive than DOOM 2016. For every cool new idea there's a regression in either art design or story and it just doesn't mesh together in the same seamless way the previous game did. The more fantastical elements of the story always seemed to take me out of the game, rather than the kind of "mysterious and unexplained" approach the last game took to integrating its supernatural elements.

If you're only here for a mechanical challenge, this game has significantly better AI than the previous game, and will take serious consideration to get through fights on nightmare.

9/10 a slight step backwards from near perfection, but you'd be hard pressed to find a singleplayer shooter that will give you more bang for your buck in these dark times for gaming.

Also, there seem to be more of the old original monsters, revamped and beautifully created in today's graphics.

But overall, to my mind, it is spoilt by the platform type areas - wide jumps / climbs that must be passed in order to progress through the game. If you get stuck on one, you have to keep repeat, repeat, repeating till you succeed, and that quickly wears a bit thin.
So the game mainly seems to be either a repeat-till-you-succeed platform, or a frantic kill-fest.
Doom 2016 was a more progressive journey through the levels, with a consistent level of monsters and ripping and tearing. But I suppose it's down to personal preference.

I have played Doom 2016 through twice, and will definitely play it again, but the platform sections might put me off doing the same with Doom Eternal. Still, as usual with Bethesda / Id games, the quality is always there, & ripping those monsters apart is definitely great fun. It's certainly good value if picked up in a sale.

I feel I need to thumb this up solely for the quality of the product. It just runs super well, the environments are gorgeous, and the sound is excellent. You will get your moneys worth and this is just quite simply a good game. However, it has a long list of issues, and seemed to do nothing but deviate from the quality of the first game.

1. Bugs. Yes, unlike the first game you will actually encounter quite a lot of bugs in this game, from crashes to getting stuck inside walls, to the camera doing weird things with some of the set pieces and going inside objects. It really took away from the experience, and is sad to see given I encountered none of this in the last game.

2. Level/world design. While everything looks great, many of the platform and puzzle sections are just outright bad and unintuitive. There were several places where I wondered around for sometimes minutes trying to figure out what I supposed to do, only to find some wall climb or jump I was supposed to do, but it was so obscure that it took forever to find. Really just a lot of these sections were poorly crafted.

3. Hard enemy counters. This game encouraged you to use all available tools by giving enemies unique counters, which seems like a good idea on paper. It actually works very well in the later stages of the game when you have a full arsenal of tools, you get into a rhythm and everything flows together well. The problem is that before you have all these tools, the game is incredibly one dimensionsal and boring. The first 40% of the game is just not fun. By the time things are put together and the game starts getting fun, you are already about done with it.

4. Ammo. Related to number 3, this game gives you virtually no ammo to work with, forcing you to swap weapons. The intention is that you use the chainsaw to replenish ammo, but the problem is what happens when there are no good chainsaw targets. There were several times where I simply just didn't have ammo or anyone I could chainsaw, so I just had to stand there and let enemies kill me. Really flawed design there, even something as simple as throwing out some weaker enemies would have solved this, but nonetheless there were several times where this happened and it was just frustrating.

5. Leveling up. Why there were so many resources and leveling systems baffled me. They all felt out of place. It felt less like I had a "build" and more that qol things that your character should just have were locked behind these weird systems. I don't get it, and I didn't get it in Doom 2016 either, but apparently modern gaming = skill trees in everything, even in genres where it doesn't belong.

6. The Marauder. This point has been made by everyone already, but the Marauder is just simply an enemy in the wrong game. Every time you encounter one the gameplay becomes degenerate, and you just gotta run, kill everything else, and follow the stupid pattern waiting for him to glow green. You get used to it pretty quick, and it's really not that hard, just really boring. I don't see how this even made it out of testing stages, but here it is and it sucks.

Again, I'd say the environments, the sound/music, and the super shotgun make this a quality game worthy of a thumbs up, but it really was just worse in every way than Doom 2016, a bit disappointing really.

Oh sweet 8lb baby jesus chugging a Monster while riding shotgun in a Redneck jacked up truck. I was HOOKED. Like this game is gore to feed gore to just be gore. Like it's over the top, it's ridiculiously awesome. Also I'm not a fan of it... Like I'm more of a COD kind of guy and even though I played on "I'm to Young to Die" I still suck and it's just not as much fun as the Borderlands fights with bullet sponge demons that you're hunting. IDK, I feel like the game is too different that what I'm used to or what I'm good at but I can tell why this game was big to begin with and on the easier, easy levels.... man slaying was FUN, but there are just to many puzzles and tricks in the game than straight blasting my way through stuff. All in all I'd give it a solid 8/10 for sure. Everything plays fine the graphics are great the everything is awesome... Doesn't feel like a doom game at all, this is a ''modernized'' fps with the gimmicks of this era; hand-holding, clear counters to everything so you don't have to be creative in finding how to overcome obstacles, UI designed for console (the UI is awful on pc) and a myriad of gimmicks influenced by hero shooters to appeal to 12 years old overwatch players.

awesome modern take on a classic FPS. Doom eternal takes everything good from Doom (2016) and cranks it up to eleven, the gameplay is completely frenetic and action packed to the brim. A true must play for any FPS fans out there.

It's so weird to see a sequel completely obliterate an already good first game, but this is exactly what DOOM Eternal has done. Amp up the gore, the music is better than ever, and the story is actually incredibly engaging and a wonderful tribute to DOOM's past. This is what a sequel should be: an improvement in every regard. I haven't even touched the multiplayer yet, but I can safely say that you should buy this game at full price, right now. It is arguably the best shooter of this generation.

Absolute Banger
ITS THE BEST

A great fast-paced shooter with plenty replayability. Lots of mobility! 

The gameplay loop reminds me of character action games a bit, but without the scoring system. The AI is much more aggressive and brutal than the previous entry, so don't just load it up on Ultraviolence if it's your first time playing (I did that but I just powered through it.) Haven't played the multi-player much since I have bad internet, but I hear it's decent. 

The soundtrack is amazing. Even if you don't own the game yet, look up "Doom Hunter", "BFG10K", "Cultist Base", "Phobos Base" and "Meathook" on YouTube. It's actually hard to recommend just one or two songs because the soundtrack is that good. Lots of aggressive industrial synths and percussion. Djent guitars, too. Mick Gordon used a chainsaw run through a homemade compressor for one of these tracks.

The story might be seen as a step back to some when compared to the last game, but I personally had fun with the He-Man saturday morning cartoon vibe they went with in this game. There's space vikings, screaming skeleton gods, mad scientists who rant about their finest creations, and a whole level dedicated to crafting a new magic/futuristic sword for the protagonist (after you broke off the last one into a demon the size of a house.) Definitely tons of fun if you like over-the-top storylines that don't take themselves too seriously. Some of the running gags will get annoying after a while, though. The "mortally challenged" joke might've been funny the first 20 times, and I've heard that joke since that one pre-release trailer, but the game keeps. making. the same. joke. over and over again. There are even some characters that make the joke despite it not making sense for them to call demons mortally challenged, like the ARC broadcast lady.

The art design is fantastic. It's trivial to tell, in a split second, what enemies are of what type based on their design, even from far away. The environments look great as well. Every set-piece in Hell looks like a death metal album cover. It's great. The argent and mayk'r worlds look cool too. The weapons look and feel amazing, my favorite being the machine gun. It's like firing a 50. Cal, but you're running around with it. 

There was some drama over id putting kernel-level cheat protection into the game, but I think they removed it in an update a while ago.

Overall, I would totally recommend this game! If you're really not sure whether or not this game is for you, try it out at a friend's captain's quarters. Just be sure to buy a copy if you like it so you can support the devs!

review:
Dont waste $120 and under on this game. Preordering was a big mistake.

Save your time and money. 
Get the 2016 DOOM. 
That's what you want. 
Not this. This is bad. 
I feel so scammed out of time and money. 


Between the crap RNG for online (Pitting a lvl 3 player against 2 level 100-200 demon players, or two lvl 2-5 demons against a lvl 100+ Slayer, I mean what the actual heck devs?) 
And the abundant cheaters (Slayer stood there, shooting us, didn't move, he was swarmed by 2 live demons and our little minions. He didn't die. We died. All rounds. Same MO. Not enjoyable at all) 
It's nearly impossible to play PVP unless you too are sporting all the finest aimbots and wall hacks the internet has to offer. 

Wish I'd known it was this bad before playing 2 hours in SINGLE PLAYER MODE so yanno, I can't refund it or anything.

It doesn't pick up from where you last left off in 2016, the maps are still trash level design wise, look forward to spending 45 minutes trying to solve a puzzle spot, only to lurch yourself forward enough as you die, that the game presumes you did it right and saves you on the other side of a pit you cannot get back across so anything you didn't do back there (secrets etc) you'll never get on this play through. The story is disjointed, and that's if there's story at all I'm nearly 20 hrs in and I STILL have no idea whats happening or why I'm doing what I'm doing... It's clunky, and awkward and feels overly inflated for the sake of inflation.   

I just wanted a DOOM 2016 continuation, Pick up from the crap hitting the fan and headed for earth.  Instead we get a floating mecha cathedral in space which serves as far as I can tell, mostly to house your collection of collectables... Which are oddly easier to find than last game. And a teleporter to zip you down to random spots to fight demons, turn on turrets and fight more demons with cartoony sounds and colours. Long gone are the actual terrifying demons, enjoy your neon glows and farting giggles they call Demonic SFX..

The soundtrack is nice, the first 20 times. I was excited to hear it.  It's great. Do yourself a favor, listen to it on youtube. 
But theres no variation to the music, I feel it's the same song with the same rift and I hear that damn guitar in my most unenjoyable of nightmares now. At least 2016 switched it up every few maps. 

The skins and events and items and stands gestures etc... There's little to no information on HOW to get them. 
Do you HAVE to play online mode?
Are they timed events?
Can you still get them after events?
If you're halfway through a level of items, are you SOL once the next set comes out?

And when you DO get them, they show up... eventually. This problem has been ongoing since launch. the Pre-order items came in at random. if at all for some players.

Overall highly dissatisfied with this game :(

*Update*
+6hrs
I keep trying to like the game.. But I can't, and I don't. Ughhhh so sad I really wanted to love this game ;__; Sadly I still play DOOM 2016 SINGLE PLAYER more than I play this. Trudging through the levels is an effort to say the least. 
Platforming tools get in the way, so many times I've been looking to get away from a demon only to find out I've accidentally backed into a swing bar and WHOOP off I go, nowhere I wanted to be, and usually into a swarm of demons BOOM dead.  This game is work. I don't like to mix work with what is supposed to be an enjoyable exciting thrilling game. 
But no. It's work. And whats worse is its work I paid to do. Jokes on me. 

*Update*

I finished it.
All I can say is Meh. 
The story just kind of.. Ends. Theres no pay off. At all. 
Oh wow we killed the giant moo cow of sin. Whoopeefuckwhocares.

I feel so ripped off. Ugh. Waste of time and money and hype..
so good.

9.5 out of 10. -0.5 for battlemode.

The game is an absolute adrenaline overload. So many things happen at any engagement that may seem overwhelming at the start, but once you get the rhythm of the game, Doom eternal will look like an elegant dance of violence. 

Personally I like the aesthetics of Doom 2016 more. But Doom eternal's gameplay leaves 2016 in the dust. In 2016, weapon switching was merely suggested and the chainsaw was just another weapon. In DE, weapon switching is a must and chainsaw  (along with your flamebelcher and grenade launcher)  is required to be mastered to fully play the game. To that end, you must rebind your keys,  so that you can instantly react  to an ever chaotic situation. The weapon wheel can help for some players but it's a lot better to rebind your weapons directly to keys.


Every heavy / super heavy demons have weaknesses you exploit with the proper tools/weapons.The following is what I usually do against certain demons
Cacodemons (buffed as compared to Doom 2016) are agile and spam ranged attacks) - grenade in mouth for glory kill status
Arachnotrons (very deadly at the initial levels) - heavy cannon snipe off the cannon on top, aim rocket while its stunned, ballista / ssg thenafter
Mancubus (deadly at close range with their flamers) - one heavy cannon snipe for one cannon, one ballista at the other cannon, a rocket at center mass, meathook for up close SSG shot
Cybermancubus - same as mancubus but cannons can't be shot off, best tactic is to  freeze grenade, meathook, blood punch, SSG / balista
Revenant (rockets deal respectable damage) - heavy cannon snipe one of its launcher, ballista the other, meathook for either SSG or bloodpunch 
Whiplash (massive pain in the ass with their ranged / stunlock)- Lock on triple rockets for insta kill, no discernible weakness other than high burst damage
Stalkers - meathook pointblank ssg (kills) or ballista (glory kill state)
Pinkies - bloodpunch instakills them
Hellknight / Dreadnight - theoretically can be staggered endlessly by chaingun, but a properly placed grenade can help you stunlock them with typical switches (rocket, ballista, meathook > ssg)
Pain elemental - rocket lock-on > ballista > meathook SSG
Doom hunter - microwave mod for plasma rifle can remove their shielding after 3 sesconds, before the last second, shoot a grenade near its  "feet" to stagger again, then do your usual cycle. Once removed from its ride, pretty standard high burst cycle can insta kill it
Marauder - always kill the wolf when it spawns, stay away from close range, when eyes flash green shoot your SSG, immediately shoot a grenade at its feet, ballista, SSG, ballista. Marauder hp is down to around 40 percent. Wait for another opening then do again. Marauder dead in less than 6 seconds.
Baron of hell - Eh. Just a big hellknight/dreadknight
Tyrant - quite easy to kill tbh. just a large lifepool. Ballista seems to stagger it pretty consistently. So basically cycle rocket > ballista  > meathook SSG > grenade at feet, fly away, repeat.

Battlemode while an interesting idea is poorly executed. Latency issues will have you getting shot at (either as a demon or as the slayer) when you're already in cover. When I play as a demon, I fall into the ground at the start of the match around 20% of the time. There is no rank match making, so sometimes new players get paired with high level players making the match seem severely unbalanced for either side. Then you hear from dev's that they are  focused more on battlemode rather than beefing up single player more. Snap maps (from 2016) is a lot more interesting. Master levels are interesting. A horde mode / co-op mode is interesting. Battlemode is  meh.
yes
Hope you like spam, because this game has nothing else to offer.

One word: A W E S O M E

Hellish FPS lovers, this will be your pit stop for quite a while.
bruh

TLDR; It's like DOOM 2016 but faster, with more demons, more challenging, with a deeper lore and a good variety on the environment. Definitely a good game.

The combat system has greatly improved, you finally have to use more than two weapons, and resources management has a huge impact on the outcome of a fight (well, given that you are playing on at least UV, below that anything works really), and countrary to what a lot of people say, you will hardly run out of ammo, since your chainsaw automatically refill one charge overtime.
Battlemode is...there I guess. It's not great, after a while it gets really repetitive, but it's still fun to do some matches between an UN run and the other. At least they got rid of the ugly loadout system of 2016 and got back to a more "FPS Arena" style, which is definitely good (bring back Doom 3 multiplayer pl0x).
The OST is superb as usual (really sad to know that Mick and id will not work together anymore), it mixes really well with what's happening on screen and you'll never get a "quiet" moment. The exploration is faster than its predecessor, and especially the collectibles are less tedious to get on the first playthrough.

I very much like the re-imagining of Doom, fast paced, no shortage of daemons to slay. Eternal goes even further by bringing back a lot of the original Doom visuals, which put a huge grin on my face. Yes, I still think that the infamous Marauder should have been a boss fight only and not a regular addition to the rooster. Platforming is confusing or even annoying at times, but with accommodating  level design like on Mars or Earth it give a lot more mobility and interesting level traversing options. Overall, this is both thumbs up and a recommendation to everyone looking for fast paced, arcade combat where you'll get to rip and tear the Hell a new one. 

Also, thanks to devs for acting on feedback and removing Denuvo that was patched in after release. Especially for the single player portion of the game it made no sense.

Played it on nightmare difficulty. I was a bit skeptical of this game at first because it comes off as a little more 'game-y' than Doom 2016: tutorial rooms to teach you guns, specific ways to force HP/Armor drops in addition to chainsaw ammo, etc. To my surprise the game is incredibly well balanced compared to its predecessor due to these decisions. You need to use all of your guns because ammo/chainsaw is limited, no longer can you just stick with the Super Shotgun of 2016. The game feels incredible when you master the dash, the fast weapon swaps, the meat hook, and the other mechanics needed to succeed on Nightmare and Ultra-Nightmare difficulties. The mobility in this game blows all previous entries out of the water with how fast it plays and I really get a Quake CPMA feeling between movement and fast weapon swaps.

My biggest fault is some of the assistance features that are turned on by default. Tips that pop-up telling you how to defeat a new enemy before they even appear on your screen, special armor if you die on a boss a few too many times, etc. These can be toggled off in the menu but I'm not a fan and don't understand why they aren't disabled on Nightmare difficulty. I did appreciate how loading screen tips changed bind keys based on my configured keybind, nice touch.

The only other downside is that exploration isn't as exciting as older 90's Doom games. You never really find anything exciting in secret rooms but sometimes the puzzles are satisfying.

The music is still amazing in this game with both new and old songs.

This is probably the greatest Doom game ever.

review:
OMG. This game is so much like the first, but so much better in every way. The only thing I can think of that this one doesn't have are the retro levels. However, it makes up for that in droves with outstanding gameplay mechanics, diverse environments across every level, interesting engagements with enemies, and fun puzzle bits. I seriously loved this game so much more than I thought I would. I am impressed in every way.

Final note... this game is REALLY hard. I played on the second lowest difficulty and almost moved down to the lowest. If you're really struggling, don't hesitate to move down the difficulty. This game is a serious test of skill and patience. Good luck!

I'll flesh this review out later.

For now, just know that Doom2016 is far far better in the vast majority of ways.

Narrative: 4/5  -Doom Slayer must save Earth from invasion of Hell's Demons
Mechanics: 5/5 -Expanded weapon upgrades and utility provide creative gameplay
Visuals/Art Style: 5/5 -Hyper-realistic state of the art graphics
Audio/Soundtrack: 5/5 -Hype sound track
Replayability: 3/5 -Retry missions for collectables or try multiplayer battle mode
Performance: 3/5 -Multiple game crashes for unknown reasons
Overall: 25/30

Doom Eternal is a masterpiece and a must-play title.
HAHAHAHAHHAAHAH KILLLLLLLLL REPEATEDLTY but video games dont cause violence

Alright, so there is a lot to say about this game, so I will summarize now. I think this game is worth $30 - $50 I would pay $40 and be happy with the purchase. This game is like DOOM 2016 and Wolfenstein: The New Order, two good games.

         Now that that is done, I paid $60 for this game and I will be mostly discussing the bad of this game, so before I start saying all of the bad things I noticed, I do like this game, and I believe any fan of Bethesda's FPS games should give it a try. I'll name a few objectively good things first: it is DOOM, this needs no explanation if you are familiar with the series. It has great graphics. The game is optimized very well. There are less glitches than other Bethesda games (no obvious ones to me after playing 18 hours of the campaign.

          Alright, so now time for my problems with the game; the campaign in this game is pretty short considering the $60 price tag, this is something that I need to talk about, because in recent Bethesda games there has been an increase in online content, and DOOM Eternal is in an awkward stage in between a Quake and a DOOM. What I mean by that is, every DOOM game up until now has been solely focused on the single player experience, yes DOOM 2016 did have multiplayer, but DOOM 2016's multiplayer was an afterthought, the whole thing was kind of thrown in there and completely unbalanced which is bad. But DOOM 2016's multiplayer was not PVP focused like DOOM Eternal, it was coop based, and PVP is much harder to account for. I believe that DOOM Eternal's development was closer to a 50/50 split for multiplayer and singleplayer making them both suffer. Unlike other reviews I will not take offence to their map design, I have seen much worse from Bethesda (I come from playing Oblivion). A big thing that I take issue with this game is how the developers added so much new stuff, I think every installment of a series should be very distinct and they did that, but I think if they took all of the enemies and weapons from DOOM 2016, set it on earth, and updated the graphics; it would be distinct enough. The amount of things they did to DOOM in this installment I believe is too much, they added a flame thrower, multiple grenade slots, dashing, button things, climbable walls, etc. and in DOOM 2016 I don't think anyone even used the grenades, I sure didn't. The point is for me to bring light to how hard they tried to make this not just another DOOM game, but, is it crazy to say that that is what all of us wanted? Even if it was basically the same DOOM 2016 we all loved with new levels it would still be good. DOOM 2016 felt like a splash and a real revival to the DOOM games, it felt like the same Doomguy we liked in the original games, updated for a modern audience. And all it needed to say on the box was DOOM and nothing else, it was awesome, then DOOM Eternal comes out and it is good, but it isn't another splash, it felt like Wolfenstein: The New Order, a good game, but not DOOM. That is another thing, Wolfenstein 1 (as I will call it) was a usually slow paced shooter that felt great to sneak around people, but DOOM has none of that, DOOM is supposed to be in your face and loud shooting. But because of the game having all of these mechanics that you are forced to use if you don't go around to find every collectible known to man you are, one or two times a stage, in a courthouse battle scenario without all of the tight controls, speed, and lean mechanics in Wolfenstein, it is not as hard as the courthouse battle but it might take you a few tries. The bottom line of this is that DOOM has always been loose and limber, you run around and shoot hoards of demons, but DOOM Eternal feels tighter and more technical, like Wolfenstein, this is a change no one should like, because this has always been the difference between Wolfenstein and DOOM and this difference seems to blur the further we go on. 

Over all, this is a DOOM game, and a good one at that, but I fear for the future of the franchise. Bethesda has done this in 2 different ways with, now, 4 of their series. Oblivion came out dumbing the intelegence of the story and puzzles for better gameplay, Wolfenstein's reboot sacrifices it's more DOOM-esque features to form it's own identity as a more technical game, Fallout 4 came out as dumber and more technically focused than any other Fallout game, and now DOOM? I don't think so yet, but if I could ask Bethesda one question about the future of the DOOM series it would be: If you take away dumb fun from DOOM to add more technical features, then I ask you. What is left?
If you like Doom, this is a fun game. It's going to be lots of shooting monsters. Feels a little like Halo with gore.
Takes a while to get used to the new combat flow compared to the old game where it's no longer just glory kill city, but i have enjoyed the challenge. Start on nightmare if you've played the first.
Doom may be eternal, but Halo is infinite.

I absolutely loved the previous iteration of this franchise, unfortunately this one is just not as fun due to the constant break in the flow of the game. They made it way more story centric than it should be; unlike the original 2016 Doom, where there were no specific cutscene that damaged the flow of the game; this gameplay is constantly being broken up by random cutscenes of doors opening when you are done with a bloody massacre fight, and just a dumb storyline to follow... Remember when Doom was about a random Marine fighting demons on Mars? Well now he has a floating castle in space; and he apparently had been sent to Mars to fight demons by some bullshit fantasy kingdom in some other dimension bla bla bla; granted in Doom 2016 they made it clear he wasn't just a marine, but they didn't really make a big deal out of it, and it was great that way. If it wasn’t for this I would be enjoying the game 100%, the visuals are great, music pumps you up, and the gameplay is as good and violent as the original. I won't not recommend it since it is still a pretty solid game, but I would not spend full asking price on this one, wait for a sale.
It's Doom. Everyone can find enjoyment in it

I am disappointed with Doom Eternal and Bethesda. The game feels spammy and spastic. It almost feels like they took Doom (2016) and increased the playback speed to 150% except for the player so it almost always this deluge of blitzed attacks and enemies jumping around the screen. Also, I could do without all the parkour, wall climb, hoop jumping antics. That got very old, very quickly. The constant scarcity of ammo is highly annoying. I feel like I spent more time trying to line up health/ammo/armor kills then just playing the game. The Marauder is not difficult to deal with on his own. It really feels cheesy difficult. The only time he becomes a problem is when other enemies are there, because they are sure to be spamming their attacks.
unplayable, not the doom guy i was expecting. and who the Freasuskvfcking genius thought of armor/ammo drop from flamethrowers and chainsaw? that shieat makes me wanna toast all ur genitals.

EDIT: Anti-Cheat was later removed. My point about the gameplay still stands.

Heads-up, this game no longer works with Linux thanks to the anti-cheat. Furthermore, the anti-cheat implemented by Bethesda and Id is far too invasive to your home PC. It also can cause game instability. You have to use this system even if you never plan to play online. 

Bethesda's stance on this anti-cheat is confusing. They don't seem to understand why the players are upset. To be fair, in the last nine years the company has become too detached from their fan base. Most of what comes down from Pete Hines is either contrived BS or conceded half-truths. 

On the gameplay note, I feel Doom 2016 is a bit more fun. Eternal has a great score and some fun instances of combat, but the game pushes you to swap weapons constantly. This becomes a little too much in some fights where you're less focused on the enemy and more focused on how many shots you have left. You're no longer swapping weapons because specific guns are more powerful against specific enemies, you're swapping out guns because they're all constantly empty. There are perks to increase the amount of ammunition you can carry, but they do not add nearly enough. This system feels like it was designed for a higher difficulty setting. 

Some of you may enjoy this mechanic. If you're not a diehard Doom fan, then perhaps this isn't for you.

review:
Doom eternal is a glorious game that builds a multilayered pie of skill-based gameplay loops into an addictive whole while running better than most other large releases this year (with a fraction of the HDD space too).

Every part of this thing was designed with clear purpose and a role in the elaborate, free-form combat system that is as much about tactics as it is strategy. Even the much maligned marauder has a valuable role in meaningfully changing how you have to approach combat (I think the hate comes from the fact that people assume he is a pressure unit to be taken out quickly rather than a kind of 'chaser' that should be taken out last, this is the sort of thing that people will get used to in time).

all in all a great game and one of the best, most punishing combat systems ever made. Pro tip: play on ultra-violence (unless your gamer rage is too sensitive), the high damage really encourages you to make the most of the games systems and feels like a constant fight to survive, its exhilarating.
KAR EN TUK!

It took me a while to figure out why I didn't like this game but I got it. this game has a SINGLE SPECIFIC way it wants you to play it, does it very well, but has eliminated all other options. It is not like the other doom games (classic and 2016) where you can approach a battle from a number of ways with a number of weapons.

In eternal you more or less have to play the games way and will do that the entire game. I heard it gets better but also have seen footage and been told that you handle the final boss the same way. it is not a game of strategy and being fast enough to survive. you just need to follow the flowchart and as long as you can do it well enough you will win.

White man rage simulator
it's fuckin great

i've talked with a fairly diverse amount of people that both enjoyed and disliked this game, and i'll try to relay unbiased opinion before giving my own

Issues Other People Have With Game:
-platforming - can be a little bit imprecise at times, unsticking from things etc. (FPS platforming can be clunky when done wrong and i feel like many people have difficulty precisely platforming when they can't see their character on the screen, i.e. 3rd person games or side scrollers)
-marauder - an enemy almost everyone unanimously hates at first, possibly forever, and without the proper strategy feels like the game is throwing a boss at you from a souls game
-difficulty - sometimes the game is just brutally hard and a lot of people will be quickly overwhelmed in certain arenas by the large variety of demons

What I Think About Those Issues:
platforming - every once in a while i won't latch to something i should have latched to, but other than that, i have personally loved the platforming throughout the entire game, and i think it's really well-designed in that it doesn't slow down the pace of the game (unless you mess up). also, the mantling, double-jump, dash ability and meathook really make navigating basically every space in the game easier. 
marauder - hated him until i learned how to weapon swap. now i don't find him to be a huge issue (occasionally wackiness where he doesn't get staggered by a point-blank ballista shot aside). 
difficulty - most people i find who complain about this are often getting caught by demons on the ground. you should always be airborne in this game. it gives you a lot of tools to do this, some of which are the most fun mobility mechanics i've ever used in an FPS.

okay, now the biased opinion. this is my favorite shooter to be released in a decade or so. it may be my favorite of all time.

Graphics/art design: 10/10 - if you liked original DOOM color schemes and level designs you may feel the same. demons will lose chunks of body as you shoot them to display how much damage they've sustained. i love little details like that.

Sound design: 10/10 - pretty easy to tell where everything is by sound alone, guns sound really good

Music: 10/10 - the dynamic music in DOOM (2016) and Eternal are one of the reasons they are so popular from what i've been able to tell. never played a game that does such a good job with this. i'm pretty uneducated musically, so take this opinion with a grain of salt, but i think this soundtrack is better than 2016's. BFG division will always hold a place in my heart, but this one's really good. hoping that they find someone equally as talented as mick for future games.

Gameplay: 10/10 - it's just so fast, and so aggressive, and there are a lot of buttons to press. the same amount from 2016, plus some extras. they are not necessary to press - my first nightmare playthrough, i barely used flame belch, for instance. however, you will feel much more unstoppable when you've mastered all of the various abilities. this is good, because demons are accurate, fast, and numerous. every demon has a weak spot that can be exploited for more damage or to reduce their battle effectiveness, and even in their handicapped state, a lot of them are still pretty strong (fucking arachnotron bombs).
movement tech in this game is just so rewarding and fun. the meathook feels so unrealistic but who cares, because soaring across an arena at 200mph after swinging yourself around a zombie feels so good. once you've mastered the game's mechanics, you will feel EXTREMELY powerful. 

Story: 9/10 - i liked it even when it was cheesy. big difference from 2016. i won't say much more.

oh yeah, Multiplayer: 7/10 - needs better netcode (like really bad), would be nice if it was slayers v slayers as opposed to the asymmetrical experience they went for, BUT i really enjoy the multiplayer. my experience with it has been: laggy as shit, almost completely nontoxic (either no communication or nice, friendly chats with other players), with a surprisingly high skill ceiling for demons. however, the pace of the game is set entirely by the doomslayer. certain people are able to weapon swap and hit with weapons so accurately and quickly that you, as the demon, can die in about 2-3 seconds, sometimes unable to properly react because the slayer is behind a wall on your screen due to the aforementioned shit netcode. i have had some games where it is literally just impossible to beat the slayer unless you are coordinating with your teammate on voice chat, and have some experience playing together. even in this situation, certain players will almost never lose, which can be discouraging to new players

if you are interested in this game and you like arena-style shooters with a really high skill ceiling, some of the best mobility options in an FPS, and it's also DOOM, you should probably just buy it, on sale or whenever you can afford it.
Not very fun regret buying this game and i have loved this series since i was 5
amazing graphics and even better glory kills. also very faithful to original

I still only got 20 hours out of the singleplayer (same as last game). Get it if you want more doom, it's still worth maybe 30 bucks, max.

As incredibly fun and riveting as the combat can be when you get into the right flow, the gameplay is often more frustrating when you get knocked out of that groove — which is nearly every combat encounter. It is definitely every encounter with The Marauder which intentionally breaks the flow of Eternal combat. The feeling of frustration is compounded on levels that often take over an hour to complete. 

The nail in the coffin is the total lack of irreverent humour that made DOOM 2016 such a joy to play. Instead, you're overloaded with self-serious and verbose lore so ham fisted that was a complete chore to slog through reading.

Despite fleeting moments of sweaty, heart-pounding, action, I find myself completely unwilling to play it again. I'd love to try the multiplayer but my friends have the Bethesda Launcher version which, for some absolutely stupid and infuriatingly unknown reason, doesn't allow us to play together on PC. Needless to say, we've all given up and uninstalled the game.

I can't recommend Eternal unless you find a copy for $20.

At least the music f***ing slaps.

This game is really fun with a fantastic combat loop, and really pretty levels.

However, outside of that, it's sub-par or outright disappointing. The game feels like a total parody of itself.

Everything that made Doom 2016 great was turned into nostalgia-bait gimmicks and parodic fan service.

SPOILERS:

The video-gamey approach, such as floating weapons/items, extra lives, floating question marks for secrets, are extremely cheesy and make it hard to take anything other than the gameplay seriously. It feels like it's one step away from being a meme game. It feels like a bunch of nostalgia bait was crammed into it, and it feels really arcadey.

The portrayals of doom guy where he talks is cringe-worthy at best. I like that they tied the slayer to the classic doom guy, but the approach was just all wrong.

And last but not least, fighting the Khan Maykr and the Icon of Sin were the most disappointing fights I've ever encountered. They don't feel like a test of skill, but more of an endurance test. Fighting them was more of a chore than anything else.

Not to mention the Icon of Sin's design is fucking awful. Let's just put this ancient eldritch goat head onto the body of a raging bodybuilder, and put really hideous armor on it. Then you get to relive Doom 2's icon of sin fight by shooting at a wall, only this one requires less skill and frustration because the weak spots are out in the open.

Doom Eternal had so much potential and failed in many areas. While I do enjoy playing this game, I can't recommend it because it's such a letdown in all the ways I've listed. It's a gimmicky, borderline meme game with fun combat.

Also the menu sounds are ear-splitting. Why did id want to fucking destroy our ear drums for just using the MENU?!

id software, if you ever decide to remake Quake 1, please do not fuck it up.

Overall great game, love it so much, took whatever was in the original DOOM 2016 and made it even better. Only ONE major flaw, and it doesn't have to do with the game design. My laptop is more than capable and is only a year old (so no way it's an issue from my end), the game freezes TOO MANY TIMES. It always happens in the middle of the action and you cannot close it, except via task manager. I've actually lost count how man times it happened, and it seriously takes me out of the immersion. You know what is also associated with glitches? Bethesda. Great game but seriously the freezing was too much. Bethesda gets zero credit for this game IMO, great job ID software and Mick Gordon OF COURSE <3. The game would have been nothing without the music.

GOOD GAME

Well at least I had an opportunity to play it once before Failthesda ruined the game with invasive malware.

Update:
In the light of Bethesda staff leaving a comment on my review, I've decided to update it.

Doom Eternal is a fine game... However, I didn't like it nearly as much as Doom 2016.
I understand the idea behind "combat puzzle", but I don't like being forced in a particular play style, instead of improvising on the go as I want to. The further into the game, the more combat feels like a chore instead of a fun activity it supposed to be.
And don't even get me started on Marauders! I have no idea why they exist. The only purpose they serve is being fun police. As soon as Marauder shows up, combat slows down to a crawl, and any semblance of game flow is getting thrown out of the window.
All in all, Doom Eternal is.. alright. I wish it was more like Doom 2016 though.
