review: Best game in 2020. Not one of the best. This is THE BEST game!

I didn't like it at first honestly. It felt too complicated compared to the other DOOM. After putting a significant number of hours into it though, every tool at your disposal has a purpose and I really enjoy how the devs tied everything together. You stop worrying about your 6 different cooldowns and just flow. Die, live, die again. Once you learn how to play you stop fearing the demons and simply RIP AND TEAR.
yes yes yes yes YES

One-liner: RIP AND TEAR for all the achievements

Pros:
+ fast-paced crazy guts action
+ plenty of secrets to hunt for
+ variety of weapons is top-notch, while still being balanced
+ story and lore are quite well-written 

Cons:
- rather short
- can still feel a bit repetitive after some time

This is probably a good game, but I came in expecting more of Doom (2016). It isn't.
Gone are the carefully crafted maps, the carefully crafted music, the carefully crafted mechanics. It feels like a shell of the previous doom.
The most annoying things so far: 
* Melee does no damage. What?
* Weapons and keycards and upgrades no longer feel part of the world.. they just float there. 
* Same for lore and secrets. No pads or secret levers, just floating pages and floating giant question marks. It's no longer an immersive world.
* Running out of ammo. Constantly. Having to use the chainsaw every 5 enemies to get ammo. It's stupid. Edit: even after upgrading to maximum ammo, it's still not enough. The shotgun only holds 12 shots, for example. There is some strategy involved in when to use which weapon, but with only 4 ammo types (5 if you count bfg), once you run out on one weapon, you'll also run out on the other. Final edit: ok, the chainsaw refills itself. Ammo is never an issue anymore, because you can just keep chainsawing forever. This gets very tedious, however.
* Platforming. A little bit is okay, but you're supposed to jump from ledge to ledge and if you miss, you're dead. Also, jumping from wall to wall is almost a puzzle as it's barely visible which walls you can jump and which you can't. edit: I'm a bit further in the game now and it has progressed to double jump to double dash to recharge dash in mid air to dash some more to jump to horizontal bar to jump to dropping platform through fire and electric barricades. I wish I was kidding.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2168900703


I'll continue to play to finish the campaign, but I wanted to throw this out there for people thinking about buying it in the summer sale: this is not the greatness of the previous doom. Wait till it's at least 75% off.

Final edit: Ok I have now finished the game. My points all remain the same. I'll give the game one thing: it is very pretty. The environments are amazing to look at.
But it's just not as fun to play as the previous doom. The music never goes to 11, I never got the "this is awesome!" feeling, the entire game feels like a chore. The story is.. whatever. They retconned Samuel Hayden's character and some other stuff. Half of the story is just loads of text that you have to read in a crappy interface (tip: read the codices on the wiki instead of ingame).

Maybe it's me.

This is a great game from an amazing team of developers mixed with another amazing team of developers and publishers. This game makes me forget every other game, which is a feeling Ive had after a longgg time. The single player campaign is so addictive. Doom Eternal is basically a 3D Action Puzzle Game and if you're coming from DOOM 2016, you're gonna have a much different experience. The graphics are very much improved over DOOM 2016 as well. This really isn't how the like DOOM 2016 like DOOM 1, 2, and 64 were to each other, this is a much more realized version of what a 3D Demon Shooter can be.

review:
since denuvo has been removed i will edit this review.  
Doom Eternal is honestly one of the best games made in recent years and is an amazing continuation of a beloved series.  the combat is fluid and fast paced while the weapons have incredible precision which amps up every aspect of combat to new levels.  replay value is amazing as is the incredibly innovative way the camera shifts from 1st to 3rd person in many cutscenes.  as for me personally, i absolutely adore the insane level of mobility they have given to the Doom Slayer allowing for true free movement during and after combat in all areas.   the art work on this game is beyond masterpiece levels, a real treat for the eyes and imagination, building an amazingly living world out of dead corpses and destruction.

i will be leaving my old review in place under this as history must be acknowledged as should their (the developers) work to right historical wrongs should be acknowledged as well.

___________________________________________________________________
OLD REVIEW - PRE DENUVO REMOVAL




Doom Eternal was an amazing game until denuvo kernel level drivers were crammed in with the first update.  no userlevel program needs kernal level access especially anti-cheat systems that are known to and are currently screwing up save files, degrading performance, and making the product you paid for utterly unable to be used.

will not recommend this game to anyone until denuvo kernel level is removed.   
i am a QA Engineer with 20+ years experience as well as a Network Engineer with 20 years experience, kernel level drivers for something like anti-cheat are 100% a security risk and should NEVER be used and absolutely should NEVER be forced on players AFTER they have already paid for a game.  telling us beforehand at least lets us make an informed decision however bethesda took away that consumer right when they forced their crap through to people who already bough DE.

review:
Over past few years, I thought I had lost the taste for games, as I had difficulty getting immersed by the games I played. The only game that had managed to immerse me was Dark Souls and that was thanks to its atmosphere, lore and narrative.

Then, I played DOOM 2016, which I had an absolute blast but was not really immersive for me. (that's not to say the game is bad in any way).

Then I got DOOM Eternal from steam summer sale and boy oh boy. During intense fights, I could FEEL my brain getting 100% stimulated by dashing, double jumping, shooting and switching weapons at the same time. Some say that the decreased ammo capacity is a downside, I say that it is indeed an upside, as it introduces strategic thinking into the game. 

Once I got a hang of the game mechanics and managed to incorporate ammo-, armor- and health management into my play style, it felt amazing. I was chewing through demons with speed and FUN.

10/10 - you are literally to angry to die.
Great game (as long as no-one forces anti-cheat backdoors on my system... looking at you Bethesda...), well designed and beautiful (in a gory way).

review:
Fun and challenging for the most part, some horrible enemy/battlefield designs though. Once you are introduced to Marauders you will learn to hate this game. Every time you encounter one of these fucks, the arena is tiny and quite tedious to maneuver to avoid the Marauder. With that, they spam spawn an enemy that constantly punts you around, throwing off your aim. If that wasn't bad enough, the Marauder itself constantly spams ranged/melee attacks and is only damageable for a fraction of a second as it is attacking you. After that, it gains the ability to deflect any damage you throw at it. There are several other enemies in the game that follow this same poor arena design/enemy difficulty scheme that ultimately leads to more frustration than fun. It seems like many of the maps/arenas were designed more with a focus on looking cool rather than pairing well with the enemies they contain, limiting the fun aspect of gameplay and only giving challenge.

With all of that being said, it has some fun gunplay with all of the different weapons/mods you can find in the world, not that they'll ever really help. Every gun still feels like a pea shooter against most enemies besides the fodder. The collectibles/lore are just about the only enjoyment I get from the game, many of them are hidden behind fun/challenging puzzles that promote a desire to explore the different maps. The story and lore are very engaging, and I find them to be vastly improved when compared to Doom 2016.

review: swag
it's awesome
Hard, but fair

As a disclaimer, I had completed the entirety of the game on a challenging but non-ass clenching level difficulty known as Ultra-Violence. I loved every second of the gameplay, music, and story. After completing the game, I read online that there would be updates and DLC in the future and left to play other games until those were in the making. After a couple of weeks, I hear from Youtube, including many of the people who had praised the game earlier, that the once perfect, Doom Eternal had implemented a faulty driver anti-cheat software. I don't know who's idea it was to add Denuvo but can the whoever came up with the idea to remove it only speak at the next tech meeting for Bethesda. Either way, I loved every moment of the game and saw it as a befitting sequel to the fantastic Doom 2016. I Just hope that more poor design decisions don't turn a 10 into a 0...

Narrative: 4
Mechanics: 4
Visuals/Art Style: 5
Audio/Soundtrack: 5
Replayability: 3
Performance: 5
Overall: 26/30

I beat this game on Nightmare difficulty ( it was a nightmare!). Nonetheless, Doom Eternal was a great and rewarding fps experience. The action is fast paced, it's mixed with stunning visuals and bad ass music. The story will keep you hooked, along with all the various weapons and mods. There are tons of collectibles in every level, an online multiplayer but nothing further to keep you coming back after completing the campaign. Incredibly optimized, had no performance issues on maxed settings. I picked this up on a sale and it was a steal. Definitely recommend.

review: I haven't played much yet but the Kills are Very Satisfying.

I really enjoyed the game at launch.
While IMO not as good as Doom 2016, I liked the fast paced gunplay and the amazing soundtrack.
I did not really liked the platforming as it slowed the game way down.

However with the recent update, the game now includes Denovo anti-cheat which uses a kernel-mode driver to detect cheating. If a vulnerability in the driver is exploited, it will be able to affect the most basic functions of your pc.

I do not recommend purchasing, installing or running this game (or any other game with this level of access to your OS) while Denovo anti cheat is installed with it.

Edit (07/23): With update 1.1 Denuvo Anti Cheat integration is supposedly removed.
However you will still need to manually uninstall Denuvo from your system using Programs and Features in the Control panel of windows. 

I will NOT recommend this game until Denuvo is no longer included in the install of the game and is automatically removed from existing installs.

review:
In a word- a tad disappointing. We loved Doom 2016's reboot because it was fresh, it was *different*. It was wild and crazy, and atmospheric. Your exploration felt like it had impact with good story telling to back it up. Doom Eternal is an arcade game. It lacks all the charm of the original, but with 3x the action. The action itself is wild and fun, but it's *massively* overloaded. It's less an 'adrenaline rush' and more a 'meth-addict rampage' that makes NO sense story-wise. Good for getting your FPS rocks off, not so great for a relaxing gaming experience.

EDIT: Original review had some very scathing remarks regarding the Denuvo Anti Cheat kernel-level driver. My understanding is the driver is gone now- good on you for listening to the community Bethesda. It takes guts to admit you made a mistake and worked to change things for the better. Thanks.

review:
They caved.  No more Ring 0 DRM.

The game is fast paced and brutal.

==========================

It's a great game but the game portion is not the problem.  Bethesda has seen fit to add an anti-cheat service that operates at the kernal level on your computer.  This will cause performance hits but the real problem is it creates a gaping security risk. 
 That's completely unacceptable.  While the patch notes (linked here: https://slayersclub.bethesda.net/en/article/2zHgbzsIV8gTzFUZ75ADGx/update-1) claim that it will not be used for any spying or nefarious purpose we've been lied to before.  

More importantly if Denuvo is ever cracked it would be possible for this to become a gaping back door for any black hat who wants access to your system.  Bethesda: You do NOT get to do this.  You do NOT get to alter a product into unsability by anyone sane and informed.  The fact that you did this in the first update tells me you had this shady BS planned from the start.  You know that many people wouldn't have bought the game if had this from the start so you waited a bit didn't you?  This is lawsuit territory.

Kernal level drivers. For an offline single player game. Ring 0 access for a malicious spyware bundle of software. Why would you damage system performance with this crap. A tiny symptom of a much larger problem: Why didn't steam let me opt out of this update and just not connect to the bethesda server. I want to play this offline. With no internet connection. 

How is it [Current Year] and Steam doesn't have the option: "Do not download or install updates"

An Edit: 

Thank you Lazida, I shall note in my review, the reason for my negative review is no longer that Doom Eternal contains Denuvo Malware, my negative review is now for the reason that Id Software and their parent company Bethesda both somehow deemed it acceptable to introduce Denuvo Malware post-launch, and only decided to remove it after outcry.

How did the staff at these companies become so out of touch with their consumers. How did the staff in charge of this decision not have the advisers they needed to forecast that such a stupid choice would receive push back from the people who loved their otherwise perfect game.

Stop requiring an internet connection for single player offline games. 
Stop making me jump through hoops to sandbox my programs. 

Why is this still a discussion in [Current Year].

review:
Alright, now that Denuvo has been partially removed in the 1.1 update, I'm tweaking my review a bit. As a fan of the original Doom as well as the recent remake, I can say it is a solid continuation of the first. The campaign is good, and there's a few neat new mechanics that are quite fun. I can't speak for the multiplayer since I don't use it, but the single player is very enjoyable.

Now, onto the disclaimer. If you're getting the game for the singleplayer experience, I 100% recommend it. Very fun. If you're planning on doing multiplayer, however, you'll need Denuvo installed.

For those who don't know, Denuvo is an incredibly invasive anti-cheat and DRM. It literally installs itself into your PC at a kernel level, meaning that it literally builds itself in as a system process for Windows. It is known to ACTIVELY weaken your PC's security, do plenty of data harvesting and selling, and to top it all off, degrades your PC's performance while the game is running AND while it isn't. So yeah. having Denuvo on your system won't only make DOOM run like crap, but all your other games too! Not to mention that Denuvo frequently causes FPS loss of 30 frames or more on MOST systems.

In conclusion, don't pick this game if you want to play with other humans. If you want a good, immersive, fun campaign, definitely recommend. If you're looking for multiplayer though, find another game like Destiny 2 or Remnant: From the Ashes. Denuvo is too high a cost to play with other humans.

review:
There is no real reason to buy this game

1) This is more a first-person platformer with occasional battles in the latter half of the game. There are even the fire sticks from the original Super Mario Bros. as aerial obstacles with no explanation, they just float in mid-air unconnected to anything.
2) Ammo caps are so low you can't take different approaches to fighting, there's only 1 way to play. Figuring out the "right way" cuts the difficulty by 75%
3) The game's story elements are completely disconnected from 2016. We don't get an answer as to why the Slayer saved Vega, why Hayden teleported the Slayer away at the end of 2016, anything about Hayden.
4) The game's control scheme is overloaded. There are 7 different weapon controls outside of the actual primary and secondary-fire weapons and they're poorly designed. There's a button to switch between 2 grenades instead of just two buttons to fire two grenades. There're still two buttons, but firing the second grenade requires an extra keystroke.
5) It doesn't feel like a DOOM game. The end of the game plays like Xen from Half-Life.
6) A lot of the enemies in the later half of the game have CC. There aren't any stuns, but there are several enemies (like the Whiplash) which have nothing *but* knockback. This is really frustrating, since the game requires a close-in brawling combat style.
7) The weapons aren't satisfying. There is no pistol, and the shotgun doesn't feel like it has any weight behind it. The machine gun ("Heavy Cannon") shoots a large, slow-moving that's slower than the Plasma Gun, and I think this Plasma Gun has the lowest DPS of any Doom game.
8) The weak points on monsters are gimmicks, only a few monsters have them, and the game largely switches away from those monsters to the newly-introduced, weak-point-free damage sponges the new dev has created.
9) There is no casual fighting, i.e.: no fighting as you move from one point to another. Every fight is marked, in advance, on the map, AND only happens in obvious arenas. 
10) If this game wasn't the sequel to DOOM it would a 6/10 and a 2/5. It's coasting on the success of 2016 while rejecting all of it's design principles. 2016 had a simple, clean design, and even in the menus, Eternal is a noisy mess.
Updated to Yes.

This Denuvo stuff is ridiculous - I'm not playing the game again until it's removed...

*EDIT*

It was fixed.

review:
Doom Eternal offers a very solid FPS experience with fun and challenging enemy gauntlets and awesome hard core boss fights. the game performs great on many machines as well offering a smooth experience on good graphical settings for even medium tier setups. The developers took what Doom 2016 and went all in building upon it hard.

The only missteps the games has are the time limited unlockable skins and sometimes it really feels like its trying to egg you on to do the versus mode part of the game (which isnt terrible, some people though are only in it for the single player aspect) 

Either way the game is a absolute must have for any FPS genre player who just wants to dive in and have fun. RIP AND TEAR!

review:
So I love this game, But with the latest update, there are serious issues I have noticed in the backend of the game, I beleive due to Denuvo, ring 0 kernel anti cheat patch. It pulls 13% more cpu in the backend on my test system , and crashes linux systems. Again I love Doom, I love what ID has built in the last 4 years, but I feel unless there is a fix made quickly to this issue, I will unfortunately not play this game  anymore. To clarify I only do the campaign, and I understand the need for an anti-cheat patch in multi, but there are better ways to implement a fix like this.


As of update 1.1 I again feel comfortable playing this game. Thank you to the devs at ID for listening to the community.

review:
UPDATE (7/22/2020: Forgot to do this when the news was originally announced, but, with update 1.1, Denuvo was removed as a requirement from the game. So, the game won't hold you at ransom (at least not with Denuvo, but still with bethesda.net) anymore. They did say that it would return one day, but in a less intrusive way, and only in multiplayer. That still sucks, but hopefully it won't be kernel level then. I can now safely recommend this game as it is still a very good game (though I do prefer Doom 4 a bit more). 

Original for historical purposes: 

Fuck Denuvo. Stop ruining games after release with shitty updates that add anti-consumer things. Didn't you guys see the shit that happened with Riot, and that shitty CS:GO + Overwatch Offspring thing that nobody asked for? When you install a fucking rootkit into the game, PEOPLE AREN'T GOING TO JUST BEND OVER, AND TAKE IT! 

Do not pay for this game. What I have played of it so far is fun (single player only, haven't touched the multiplayer), but it is not worth having a shitty piece of software on my computer that adds a potential backdoor all for the sake of a multiplayer mode almost nobody knows even exists. 

On top of that, why the HELL do I not only have to have a Bethesda account, but also have to sign in to even get to the main menu? It's fucking unnecessary, especially in a single player game!

I don't fucking understand what it is with you guys, and ruining games. This game is great, but in its current state, I cannot recommend paying for it. Play it the way you should play any game that goes Epic exclusive. You know what I mean.

review: one of my top games of the year tbh. one of my favorites too.

Incredible game, ID hit it out of the park...

Until the latest update. Anti-cheat software should NOT have kernel level access to my machine under any circumstances. It introduces a huge security vulnerability if Denuvo anti-cheat becomes compromised in any way. Not to mention the hit in performance that others have reported. I am not updating until Denuvo anti-cheat gets removed.

Update: it appears that in recent updates Denuvo anti-cheat has been removed. Changing my recommendation to yes.

review:
Ah yes, avoid this shit like the plague. 

it installs a sector 0 rootkit, this means that the rootkit itself (Denuvo Anticheat), can access any information on your PC, everything from unmoddable system files to the the keys you press at any time. This all, in theory, can be used or sold to do questionable things. Denuvo says this isn't going to be exploited, but why the fucking fuck would you believe them ever? Lmao

Paid for the deluxe edition, refunding asap.

EDIT: Apparently Denuvo was removed, but at this point I don't see a reason to even consider it, if you're going to decide, as a group of technically minded developers who all know what a rootkit is, that a SECTOR ZERO ROOTKIT is acceptable for anticheat in a DOOM game, a game in which such a low percentage of the playerbase even wants cheats that devs barely even care to make them, than I don't trust your intentions in the least. I'm a dev, this was a gross abuse of my trust because I understand on a fundamental level what happened.

review:
After playing 200 hours of DOOM Eternal. I can proudly say that DOOM Eternal is much. MUCH better then DOOM 2016.

I was really happy when DOOM 2016 was announced, i was waiting and getting money for a new PC.
I played it. I was glad that i did. I was satisfied with what i had to play. But when i wanted to replay it... It felt boring. Dunno. The game felt really boring. The repeative levels. Gritty level's. Same thing everytime.
Then comes DOOM Eternal. And oh lord, Jesus Christ, how HAPPY i was just replaying the same level over and over, hundred times, thousands, and never getting bored whatsoever, i didn't thought that i'll replay it this much honestly. And master levels on Nightmare? Just... A cherry on the cake.

Battlemode? Meh... Haven't played it. Not really interested in it honestly.

But overall, if you feel Christian enough, DOOM Eternal is for you. (DOOM 2016, is just a bottom of the cake, while current one is everything on top of it.)
(i bet there is gonna be a lot of DOOM 2016 fans sending death treats tbh)

oh and don't forget that the longer icon of sin is on earth the stronger it will become.

I have been playing the Doom series since 1993, and this game is everything I love about the series and then some. It is technically and visually very impressive, as Doom games always have been - I am running it at 4K60 on my 5700XT. The adaptive resolution scaling is nice since you can just set and forget, the lowest I have seen it drop to is 85% of 4K, which is very impressive considering how good it looks.  The texture work, animations and set pieces are some of the best this generation. 

Gameplay wise, this is much more difficult than Doom 2016 was on Hurt me Plenty. There are more enemies, and they hit harder.  In Doom 2016 you could pretty much spam super shotgun and do fine, in this game you have to constantly be moving, and use the right tool for the job. Once you get the combat loop down though it is almost zen to play. This also expands on the Doom lore quite a bit, which I also liked being a huge fan of the series. Very happy with the purchase - this is one of the best shooters this gen, and for sure the best Doom game.
i had fun
Rip and tear until it is done!

Denuvo Anti-Cheat. (EDIT IS IMPORTANT!)

Edit: So since a developer has decided to respond to this I need to also point out that the removal of Denuvo Anti-Cheat is not permanent, and that they have stated they plan to re-add it at a later date. DO NOT BUY THIS PRODUCT!!!

review:
Amazing successor of DOOM 2016, this game makes every weapon and ability have purpose now rather than just being used once for certain areas like in the first game. Up until the final level, you will always be receiving more weapons and utilities.

Also, the biggest advancement over the first game are the loading times, they are so much faster and put you right back into the game immediately.

This should be a FPS game.. but all the challenge is only to be able to jump at the right moment... this is a platform game, no a DOOM game, very disappointed (you need to try, fall, die, try, fall, die... always).
DOOM Eternal reminds us that games are supposed to be fun.

Doom Slayer : The man who burns demons and maykrs in the hell
Khan Maykr :    :/
All Demons : Oh mort we all going to die again >:(((
kick a s s
They got rid of the drm and it's now a fine game. 10/10 a little over the top tho

Doom Eternal is a proper sequel of Doom (2016). The game gives the player a lot of excitement and thrill. A very good FPS game. To beat the campaign, you need around 30 hours, depending on the level of difficulty and additional battles. The Battle mode is a huge asset for those who want to test their skill.

Let's hunt some demons!

This review concerns only the single player game (campaign) and I've tried to make it as spoiler-free as possible. Below are major properties to which I mostly paid attention. Despite the minor cons that I brought up, this game has become one my favourites. Can't wait for the upcoming installements. 

[b] Story [/b] 

The Doom universe has been expanded drastically in Doom Eternal introducing new characters, environment and answering to some of the questions that have been concerned the players throughout the franchise. It is well executed in a sense that it does not get on the way of the gameplay itself, which is the core of this game. The number of cutscenes are kept minimal and most of the story can be read from the codex. In other words, the players can dig into the story whenever they want and don't need get frustrated by cutscenes, although, the cutscenes can be skipped. The downside of the story are the plot holes.   

[b] Gameplay [/b]

Simply amazing. Controlled chaos as its best. I have beaten the game on "Ultra-violence" and "Nightmare" difficulties and have to say it is challenging. Doom Eternal is more difficult compared to Doom 2016. 
The constant movement and jumps remind a bit of arena shooters i.e. Quake or Unreal. Special thanks to dashing and all the tricks that can be done with super Shotguns meathook. 

The game gives you a lot of room for creativity on how to kill your enemies. Using only one weapon won't work and you have to think for different strategies on how to defeat the enemies in different situations, which is heavily relied on resource management.  
In addition to that, you have to constantly use your utilities and those are grenade/ice bomb and flame belch. The game is difficult in the beginning, but you'll eventually master it. 
The point is to learn and learning brings enjoyment. PS. I played Doom 2016 and it wasn't easy to go back to it after playing Doom Eternal. 

A minor downside is that there is no ammo for super weapons or the Crucible in early levels, if you want to play those levels after beating the game. It would be good for example to get energy for the Crucible by killing a certain amount of demons in the manner as regenerating the Blood punch, instead of picking "Crucible ammo". 

[b] Level design and platforming [/b]

The levels are much larger and have a lot to explore, which motivates even more to search for secrets most of which give you rewards for upgrades.
New places, while stunning, are a great refreshment to the UAC facilities, thanks to the great graphics and art design.  
 
Platforming for most parts felt unnecessary. For example, in levels "Hell on Earth", "Super Gore Nest" or "ARC Complex" it made sense since the level was destroyed urban environment, where you have to jump over or climb rubles. 
However, in others such as "Urdak", "Cultis Base", "Doomhunter base" or end of "Excultia" it felt annoying and dull. Teleportation or different kind of route would have made much more sense. Swimming was kinda weird.  

[b] Soundtrack[/b]

Mick Gordon's soundtrack fits Doom like Ennio Morricone's soundtrack to Sergio Leone's Dollar trilogy.

Denuvo Anti-Cheat is mandatory for single player? Really!?

Update: it's optional now (as of 1.1) so I'm giving it a thumbs up, because the game is awesome!

review: I have played and loved all previous Doom games and unfortunately this one is not for me. There is just too many jumping puzzle sections in a game that the platforming is not done well.
I don't know if this game is good or bad or hard or easy or if the graphics are crazy awesome or just plain terrible because the game won't launch.

I am typically the type of person that enjoys RPGs and puzzle games more than single player FPS titles. I wasn't particularly interested in DOOM 2016, but the combination of dashes and grappling hook in this game caught my eye. 

What I think makes this game so great is the fact that it sets you up as this unstoppable demon killer with an arsenal of amazing weapons and abilities. It then introduces you to waves upon waves of demons, with each level typically introducing multiple new types. The challenge is to balance ammo, shields, and health while flying around absolutely obliterating everything. On top of that there is some basic exploration elements and some optional challenges.

The game play is pure fun, the graphics are gorgeous, the music is heart-poundingly epic. Every second of this campaign was worth playing; not once did I feel a lull or a slowdown in terms of pacing. ID Software has mastered the art of the FPS, and this game so far is their magnum opus. 

I bought the game on sale, but it is 100% worth full price. RIP AND TEAR UNTIL IT IS DONE!
I dont get it. sorry

It's good to see a response to the denuvo issue coming in, even if it took a while.  I can't forgive that kind of underhanded move.

That being said.  The game is good.  I appreciate the response from the developer.  I wasn't a fan of the multiplayer but that's not why most people want DOOM.  if you want bloody rip and tear, then you'll get that in spades.

Doom Eternal is the best game I hate. Despite the fact that this is the least fun I've had with the franchise, I can't dispute the fact that an incredible amount of attention and craftsmanship went into the game. It's just too bad that it feels more like Bop It than a classic FPS, in my opinion.

The game relies on a weakness system. Enemies have a weak point, or are susceptible to certain attacks. And it isn't a straight up buff to damage either: entire move sets can change. In theory, this is cool. In practice, the game limits your options down to one or two weapons per enemy. You simply [i]have to[/i] use the sticky grenade on the arachnotrons in the later levels. If you don't, you'll be hit scanned to death by the three that spawn, rushed down by the hellknights and plinked by the 100 imps.

The sticky grenade is a prime example of why I hate this system. The super shotgun is a straight upgrade in every way, but you have to constantly switch to the pump just so you can avoid the insanely high health pool of even a lowly cacodemon on normal. You can't just save up shotgun or plasma gun ammo and go ham -- the game knows you want to do this, and caps the ammo to a downright anemic limit. You have to have the appropriate amount of fun in the heavily regulated methods. I bet you that the higher difficulties make it virtually impossible to ignore this system.

One thing all the big demons have in common is a stupid huge health pool. Another is that they can't be chainsawed for more ammo. This means you have to constantly keep around the little dingleberry demons to restock mid-fight. Don't accidentally shoot them one extra time, or let them get stuck in the crossfire, or else it's all for nothing. It feels oddly like a survival horror system. Again: good in theory. In practice, why am I not killing all the demons in Doom?

There's a bunch of new enemies, bosses, as well as important redesigns, but most of them are just plain annoying. Most of the bosses are the kind where you have to wait until they do the one move that leaves them open and then you shoot them. Many of the new enemies are just stupidly fast like the whiplash. Some enemies are both fast and force you to wait around to hurt them like the marauders. Archviles are even worse in this game than usual: they teleport around, summoning [i]new[/i] demons, with a simply monolithic health pool. Save the BFG or crucible for them and pretend they're not in the game.

Meanwhile, the doomguy is the slowest he's ever been. Sure, he's got some dashes and a rune that makes you speed up for a bit, but it feels like anything --[i]anything[/i]-- can outrun you. Even mancubi, even [i]imps[/i]. Every arena starts the same: jog around looking for power ups, take out the weak points you can, target the high priority or rush down enemies, and then pick the little circle you're going to run laps around while you clean up the trash. You just don't move fast enough, you [i]must[/i] abuse things like monkey bars and jump pads.

There's also a puzzling focus on cinematic cut scenes and story. Remember that time in Doom 2016 where the bad guy is trying to tell you what's going on, and doomguy doesn't care so he shoves the computer out of the way? I wish [i]that[/i] doomguy was back. Prepare to be lead by the nose and talked at by VEGA, the AI from 2016 that I forgot existed, and Samuel Hayden, the AI from 2016 that is now mysteriously not an antagonist anymore despite the post credits teaser from the last game. Maybe it talks about it in the million codex entries you can read through instead of playing the fucking game. You can also find out about the Sentinels and Makyrs and all this other shit no one asked for or cared about. Wise man once said "Story in a game is like a story in a porn movie. It's expected to be there, but it's not that important." This isn't Gone Home, it's Doom for Christ's sake.

The graphics are stunning and colorful, and there's loads of set pieces chock full of collectibles. There's too many invisible walls, even for what is essentially a corridor shooter, but I can't complain about it too much. The music is less Trent Reznor circa Quake if all he had to work with was Cryptopsy samples, and more generic djent and butt metal. In a word, it's overproduced. Nothing comes close to the raw energy and experimentation of BFG Division. I'd call the tracks in the Makyr world downright bad and annoying to listen to.

But again, most of this is by design. It's done exactly what it set out to do, and done so expertly, but I disagree with all of it. It's well made by talented people. But from the start, I think the direction they were heading was the wrong one. This is most likely the beginning of the end for the new Doom. The next one will most likely tout itself as a return to classic form, while basically being a stripped down version of the Bop It Doom in this game. It was fun while it lasted, Doom. Hopefully I won't have to wait for the next reboot series to enjoy it again.

review:
The game at launch was fantastic. 

EDIT: Everything below was before the removal of Denuvo Anti-Cheat. After removal of  this anti-cheat, I've changed my review. The game is fantastic, and I'm glad that they walked back on this.

The game with update 1 introduced an anti-cheat rootkit that must run even if you want to play single player. Anti-cheat engines are, essentially, rootkits. Adding an invasive anti-cheat like this just for playing Doom multiplier makes no sense - it's not a competitive multiplier scene like CS:GO or League, nobody is playing Doom Eternal professionally, there are no ESports teams maining it. Requiring this rootkit to run even to play the single player game is a spit in the face to everyone else. 

Your game is not important enough to warrant a rootkit anti-cheat for the multiplayer, let alone the single player.

I have played many doom games though the years and own almost all of them, this one is a ton of fun, wow! Highly recommend, cant believe it took me this long to play this one. Have not tried the multiplayer yet, but the campaign is amazing.

It's freakin' AWESOME!

It's far better than Doom 2016 IMO, It's bigger, faster, and much more brutal, you'll hate the previous game once you start playing this.

The levels are bigger and the missions are longer than before. The encounters are INSANE. Fast ,brutal and hugely satisfying.

Some of boss fights are really good, the timing plays an important role in most them, some of the bosses are really interesting.

The platforming is a good idea.. but it's easy a bit, there is no challenging in it! that's what makes it less interesting.. at least for me. but overall it's good.

The mobility is fu♥king fantastic! The Dash and the Meat Hook are among the best features they've added to the game! It makes the player movement smooth and fast and very useful to evade demons' attacks.

id Software managed to force you smartly to play the way that you supposed to play as Doom Slayer, no longer possible to stick with one or two weapons throughout the game as some do in the previous game, every weapon and every mod is great and functional, some of them are effective against specific types of demons but they're almost useless against the others, so you have to switch madly between weapons and mods to choose the most effective things against demons and their weak points.

The story is good and the lore is great, even If you not interested in Doom's Lore, in this game, you'll love to read some interesting paragraphs in the codex about Doomguy and Doom universe.

it's bugged, unbalanced and it has latency issues, just forget it and enjoy the campaign.
Love is temporary, but DOOM... DOOM is eternal.

After beating the game several times on both PS4 and PC, I can say I thoroughly recommend it... if you don't mind having your ass rammed for a good few hours until you harden to the game's difficulty enough to ram it back. It really hammers in the combat loop and won't let up even when you've mastered it. The game does not give training wheels (often) and does not give leeway once you know and have everything you need to beat it. It's one hell of a ride and it was fun being able to conquer it. (My Ultra-Nightmare runs are probably going to be a shitshow though.)
Battlemode's unique and can be fun as both Slayer and Demon. Unfortunately, I don't have anyone to play it with privately so that hinders my own experience but I had fun just playing in public lobbies. The skins and stuff you unlock are pretty cool too.
Overall, damn good experience. I wait in anticipation for the campaign DLC to come out but in the meantime, I won't mind slaying demons from time to time in this game.

review:
I fucking adore Doom 2016. Everything in that game clicked so well for me, the combat was satisfying, the music was amazing, the world design felt tailor made for the slayer's momentum, it's so good. So, naturally, I was hyped for Doom Eternal. There's a couple things that I felt could be refined and tweaked from the original, mainly the combat could be expanded a little so it doesn't become stale, but other than that I just wanted more.

Doom Eternal is a very different game to its predecessor. It feels like a soft reboot in a lot of ways, a reboot of a reboot. A 'hell' of a lot of stuff has been changed, arguably too much. The combat has been deepened, with enemy weak points and new abilities, which is really cool, but way too much has been introduced. There's a wider array of settings, but they feel way less deliberate than the original. There's now a far more complex parkour system, which is fun and breaks up the battles, but arguably too much. There's now like 5 different skill trees. There are way more collectables. There's now a hub world for no reason whatsoever seriously why is this here. The story (which was admitedly kind of boring in Doom but at least it was something) has done a complete 180, swapping from the kinda serious, kinda sarcastic style to the most boring plot in a video game ever made. There's no drive to do anything because I don't even know what I'm doing half the time.

It's nice to see a AAA studio give the developers a lot of creative freedom with how they approach a sequel, but I think there was a missed opportunity here. Doom left so much room to expand and develop what had been created, and while this sequel does do that in some aspects, it feels like an entirely different game in others. I'm not saying it's not good, because there's a lot here that a lot of people I'm sure will love. For me though, it just doesn't work.

The soundtrack's fucking great though holy shit

Well, I'm editing my review for the second time.

Although there were few disappointments with that anti-cheat even for single-player experience, this game holds up.

I don't much into these community events for new skins so don't care much for them - all I need is already in the game - I can replay any mission as I want, thanks to builtin cheats system so I don't need to worry about ammo.

This game differs from doom 2016 but not in bad way - it has it's charm, so I'll play both of these games.

Unless developers will include anti-cheat to single-player mode, no, thanks.

Overall - I can recommend this.

[h1]This is a masterpiece[/h1]
[b]TLDR[/b]: I think we'll look back in 20 years and be like "remember Doom Eternal? I hope a FPS as good as that will come out someday soon". It's an Instant Classic. Building upon Doom 2016 with more mobility, more diversity, resource management, rewarding challenge, which all result in a perfect fast arena FPS gameplay. Also, there is a freaking lore bible because.. why not?

So, Doom 2016 was cool, nobody argued on that. But Eternal is a big improvement. So much that I don't think I can really have fun on Doom 2016 anymore. [b]Doom 2016 made you feel like a badass, Doom Eternal makes you one.[/b]
Eternal builds upon 2016's ideas, the chest pieces arenas with micro decisions each second, pushing for contact. They were good ideas, and now it works so well!
First, [b]You can move much faster[/b], making you able to evade encounters, dodge attacks, seek melee and resources. Dashing, jumping, grappling, climbing... You are moving in the environment like a lightning bolt.
[b]Resources are key[/b]. They evaporate in a heart beat, especially ammunition. It's a resource management game where if you don't have health, ammo or armor, you are f*cked and need to go after those immediately. You have all the tools to do so, at any time (chainsaw's first charge recharges after a while, zombies piñatas spawn regularly...).
[b]Diversity[/b]. More enemies and weapons means that the game is much more diverse but also more complicated, it could have been impossible to remember all those. But the game made it easy thanks to clear and logical strategies. When you see a new enemy, a tutorial pops up with its weakness. They give us a solution, but in an arena there is tons of different enemies with their own weakness, ideal weapon to kill them with. So it is in the execution of those strategies that the challenge reside. Also, with stronger weapons unlocked, you find better, quicker strategies.
[b]Hard to master[/b]. This is the one that divides players. To put it simply: it's really hard. I beat it in hard mode the first playthrough and even though I sometime struggled, I learned, got better. The maurauder is a pain, but by getting your *ss kicked you start to understand how to manage him. The same for doom hunters, archviles... The game made me really master it compared to Doom 2016, I feel like I know almost every gameplay details and techniques now.
[b]Pacing[/b]. The game is very fast paced. Still, you can slow down with plateforming, puzzles, secret hunting, lore reading. It's all there to rest a little between fights if you desire. (secrets are much more fun than in 2016, you can fast travel at the end to pick them up, it's smarter that those levers you hated).
[b]Huge campaign[/b]. 30 hours for 100% in hard. More than twice the length of the last Doom and it doesn't become boring at any point. Every environment is a new, beautiful surprise. The story never stalls, it's rich but optional. So if you don't care about the lore and all, don't worry the game doesn't force it. And if you care... there is an entire huge Bible covering each world, characters, enemies. And it's a well written sci-fi take on biblical themes with bits inspired from Berserk. They even contain some legit tension and plot twist, which is the first time a codex gave me that.

The only negative critics I have: [spoiler]That one hidden toy in the well at level 9... seriously?[/spoiler], the music's dynamic range (the original composer didn't deliver in time so the devs improvised with the unmastered bits) a shame but it's still beautiful.

[b]To finish this long *ss review[/b]: if your heart can take fast paced gameplay, if you like FPS in general, [b]PLAY IT[/b].

Doom eternal does a lot of things right but gets a lot of things wrong overall an enjoyable experience. What it does right is builds off the original game with new game mechanics and demons in a consistent and pleasurable manner. What does right it's easily overshadowed by the errors in game design and story. A simple example is the new "Buff totem" mechanic which as an objective to find a small totem in a Sea of Monsters and demons are overpowered at the moment that can be simply neutered by destroying the totem, which makes the totem the high priority and now you are on an egg hunt to find this one totem which usually results in dying, respawning looking dying again and repeat until you find the totem and then you can start the engagement with the demons. The new game mechanics like the flame breath, grenade launcher, suit upgrades, ice grenades are at first overbearing and cumbersome but as the game goes on and you adapt to the new equipment the game will become more enjoyable in spite of the additional complexity. 

I would recommend Doom eternal but the first half of the game is more of a 6 out of 10 and the following half more like an 8 out of 10.

If you enjoyed DOOM (2016) and were hoping to see a game that would keep the same tone, or something built around that formula, this game might not be for you. If it wasn't a sequel, and was judged entirely outside of the perspective that the prior game inescapably brings into the conversation, it would be easier to justify all the questionable decisions that were made in DOOM Eternal. It would've been an okay game, maybe not the best one to represent the franchise, let alone the genre it once shaped, but it would've been somewhat appealing to a certain type of gamer, as is. That said, IT IS a sequel, and for a game, that one would think builds upon something that wasn't entirely broken, it sure tries to fix right about everything, except the things, that actually needed fixing.
DOOM Eternal doesn't really address the biggest criticisms of the previous game. It isn't any less repetitive, and, in fact, puts even more effort and production into the sequences that are focused only on delivering plot (yes, there is a story going on somewhere there, apparently). Why they couldn't have been written into the gameplay more naturally without breaking its natural flow, is beyond me.
This is not the biggest thing, that breaks the flow, however. Between constantly searching for ammo or armor, by trying to pull off one of way too many special attacks, and platforming back and forth from one hazardous area to another, only to realize you're not using the optimal weapon for a certain enemy type, there is sometimes a momentary window of good ol' monster slaying, while jumping around them oldschool style. And frankly, when there is so little flow going on, it may seem that it's the fun parts, that occasionally break the grind.
Another incredibly frustrating thing is that I always kept relying on ALL of the special weapons - and there are way too many of those - while barely using (or needing) three of the eight main weapons. Also, there are only two types of grenades in the game, and two buttons to use them - but instead of binding each button to each grenade, one is used to switch between them. This is just sheer stupidity. Your arsenal is outright unbalanced in this game, even outside of the comparison with the previous title. Certain types of particularly bullet-spongy enemies don't exactly rectify that.
Platforming on its own, as far as game mechanics go, is not half as bad as some of the hysteria on the internet would let you believe. But it is inexplicable, that the player movement was redesigned specifically for this game, and yet the levels look like they were designed for something completely different. Is there a single aspect of this game, that wasn't corrupted by its identity crisis?
Unless you're very inexperienced with the genre, I suggest to turn off the tutorials, because the number of game pausing textual hints is INFURIATING. They show up all the time, sometimes one right after another, and don't stop until the very final boss battle. Do they not know what the point or definition of a tutorial is? Multiplayer tutorials are also utterly annoying, and are on by default.
Speaking of the final boss battle, I am truly amazed that in the year 2020, in one of the biggest Bethesda titles we are still getting the most generic, dull and unoriginal, worst possible kind of a mainstream final boss in a game with "DOOM" in its title. And that is really the ultimate problem with this game - remove the name, swap the characters and the monsters, and you got yourself a salvable title. But this whole thing with "DOOM" in the name? Nope. There are just too many things you have to keep in mind in order to do well, and there are games that benefit from having somewhat convoluted mechanics, but when you're given a bunch of giant kickass weapons with a bunch of demons to kill, all you should wanna do is to have some fun killing them. Yet all these things end up getting in the way of having fun.

By far the worst DOOM game to date.
I regret buying this and I have shitloads of games that I don't play but only DOOM Eternal I regret buying.
This isn't an FPS, its a hyperactive platformer with a DOOM skin.

Pros:
-graphics: looks great;
-performance: never crashed, no stuttering etc...;
-Dev team: cares about having updated content, patches;

Cons:
-New mechanics: new doesn't always mean better. 
In past DOOM games there was an advised way to play the game but you could do your own thing and still get through it. 
In this game you're forced to follow a certain cycle; 
"non stop double jump-chainsaw-shoot-switch weapon-double jump-flamethrower-double jump-shoot-switch weapon-grenade-double jump-chainsaw......."
It isn't fun or exciting, it's frustrating.
When you don't know the cycle and expect a DOOM/FPS experience you're gonna have a significantly hard time.
When you get the cycle you're gonna get a terribly boring time of constantly jumping/chainsawing/switching weapons.
And I mean constantly, if you're not flying/jumping, you're dead.

Enemies/combat:
When you're getting bored with the cycle grind, they throw the marauder at you...
I fought him once, died and quit, never starting up the game again.
The marauder can only be fought with a certain cycle, stay close but not too close or he'll shotgun you... don't go too far or he'll throw his axe at you... he has a indestructible shield and blocks any attack you'll throw at him... he even is immune to all superweapons... so you can only kill him if you stay within the non instant death range and attack him within a fraction of a second when he's about to attack you and if you don't attack him on that fraction of a second, you're dead.
And the cherry on top of the cake is that he has a minion that constantly bugs you, together with the standard cannonfodder so you're constantly getting fucked by either the marauder or the cannonfodder.

Tldr:
Overrated platformer with crippled gameplay.
DOOM 2016 is the best and last FPS DOOM game, so if you're looking for a good fps, go for that or wolfenstein(NO, OB or NC).
Buy it on a steap sale if you're into platformers, 20$ is what I would recommend.

Difficulties played: Nightmare
Actual difficulty: Easy

[h1] Picked this up in the Steam Summer Sale of 2020 and was very excited to play, being a huge fan of the Doom franchise and with how DOOM (2016) turned out. It only took an hour for DOOM Eternal to rip and tear through any excitement I had and I am honestly left unsure how to feel. I don't think I have ever played a title that was so different in how it actually plays from the information given in so many reviews out there - I feel like I played a completely different DOOM Eternal from what I have read out in the wild.

Everything about it feels off from DOOM 2016; the mechanics, weapon handling, the bugs, animations, damage distribution, level design, the overall tone, the new cartoonish aesthetic....everything feels slippery and slowed down. I don't feel like I'm really in control of how I play anymore and that I'm more a slave to the mechanics than having a fun time. DOOM Eternal is wanting to be a 'pedal to the metal' FPS but keeps hitting the brakes every few seconds with its mechanics to constantly interrupt the carnage for some resource management.[/h1]

There is a lot to discuss when it comes to DOOM Eternal and I will be breaking it down into sections for easier consumption as well as making comparisons to DOOM (2016). 

[b][u]Movement and Control[/u]

In Doom Eternal a new 'dash' mechanic has been added in as your primary mode of movement. This 'dash' is on a timed charge and comes in a pack of two, with options for upgrades with Praetor Suit tokens. Combined with your ponderous walk pace this is an element in introducing a 'stop and go' effect into DOOM Eternal - movement is no longer smooth and fluid. This becomes more of a problem as movement feels slippery in general; with ledges and corners being the worst offenders, the former attempting to pull you off if you get anywhere near.

Glory / Chainsaw / Crucible kills are now wildly inconsistent in terms of locking on to a target when compared to DOOM (2016). This can be frustrating since enemies are now in higher numbers, respawn and performing these animation based kills are now tied to a new resource management mechanic the whole game is built around. 

Controls really feel like they were designed for console players - or at the very least a controller - with how weapon selection is laid out, juggling resource mechanics and the nature of how dash feels and functions.

[b][u]Weapon Handling, Enemies & Level Design [/u]

DOOM Eternal introduces new body damage to enemy models which ends up making weapon damage noticeably inconsistent - especially when combined with the new resource management mechanics. This ends up making weapon damage variable when it comes to both staggering a foe for a glory kill or simply attempting to finish off an opponent. Enemies with mechanical system placements (Arachnotron/Mancubus/Maykr Drone/Revenant/Doom Hunter) can have them sniped off with the Heavy Cannon or Ballista, forcing them into melee, to drop ammo/HP or disable that system entirely. As you might have guessed, weapon specific weaknesses have been introduced even more so into DOOM Eternal limiting your options for carnage even further. 

Something to note is the stolen designs for enemies, specifically from the Games Workshop IP 'Warhammer 40,000'. The three biggest offenders are the Khan Maykr (Eldari), Marauder (Chaos Marauder) and the Doom Hunter (Necron Destroyer Lord) - with the latter being the most direct and obvious design that was stolen of the three. How the Doom Hunter breaks apart into its second phase shows just how much they were paying attention to Warhammer 40,000 when designing these enemies - it is almost a copy with a slight aesthetic change to cover the deed.

A word of warning is that enemies are now incredibly fast compared to your much slower self and will often spawn in the same space as yourself - leading to instant death. You can also be pinned into corners much easier due to the higher number of enemies and more box'd design of the levels.

Resource management is the system to which you will now be slaved throughout your time with DOOM Eternal. Levels are no longer well designed but feel even more like boxed arenas than previously experienced in DOOM (2016). This is due to the game revolving around resource management mechanics that are requiring juggling and your constant attention in a fast-paced situation. Glory kills are still your bread and butter for health, chainsawing your opponents your source of ammo and now requiring to burn your enemies with the 'Flame Belch' for much needed armour. This gives combat a frantic 'stop and go' feeling that sacrifices the fluidity of previous Doom titles - all the while making the game feel less like it was about skill and more about random luck. 

A final note, many glory kill animations are very similar and lacking in variety, with player death animation variety being gone entirely from DOOM Eternal. 

[b][u] Bugs, Secrets and Crashes [/u]

Throughout my time with DOOM Eternal I was subjected to a number of odd experiences, crashes and bugs. 

[list]
[*] Controllers must be disabled in options or you will be trapped forever in a loading screen
[*] Crashes at cutscene loading - both to desktop and full PC reboot
[*] Crashes taking screenshots during cutscenes and gameplay
[*] Player will randomly fall through floor
[*] Enemies can become stuck under floor and in walls - still able to attack player
[*] Super shotgun has fired plasma
[*] Crashes at beginning and end of cutscenes
[*] Crashes upon Slayer Gate completion
[*] Black screen bug from Sentinel Prime onward - game must be played in admin mode from then on via .exe
[*] Combat Encounters not counting as cleared - requires complete replay of section and still may not count
[/list]

Just to name a few, with some of these requiring areas to be replayed due to crashes or bugs which is frustrating. 

Secrets are now much easier to find in comparison to previous titles, making the platforming and exploration portions of DOOM Eternal lackluster and almost unnecessary in regards to the former.

[b][u]Final Thoughts[/u]

DOOM Eternal has easily been one of my greatest gaming disappointments of 2020, possibly even my entire gaming career. I wish I had refunded it while I still had the chance and not listened to reviewers and other gamers assuring me it improved past the two hour mark, when all it does is double and then triple down on the problems present. DOOM Eternal feels like it should have been released as a $30 expansion instead of a full blown release at $79.99. 

I no longer feel like a badass Doom Slayer in DOOM Eternal - which is probably the biggest disappointment of it all.

I hit the 10 hour mark with Doom Eternal and boom, a pop-up emerges asking me to give Doom Eternal a thumbs up or thumbs down review.  In short, I give it a thumbs up but here our a few things to keep in mind:

I am a Doom fan - I have liked Doom since the 90's and thought the version in 2016 (?) was nothing short of great.  However, this game just doesn't measure up to it and in my opinion, here is why:

1. Nothing new here to see.  Same everything with lack of originality.
2. Levels have annoying "jump" puzzles that don't really add to any type of "story" - jump on this wall to go to another wall and eventually punch a skull to level through.
3. Levels are the same to me.  The only reason I know I am about to finish a "chapter" is when there is enough baddies on the screen to indicate this isn't a normal firefight.  I slaughter them and next chapter loads.

In closing, fun game so far but I wouldn't spend more then $30 on it and don't expect anything different than a run-and-gun, monster slaughter-fest.  Not that there is anything wrong with that but there are other games out there that accomplish the same and cheaper.

Have fun!

Let me be very clear, Doom Eternal in concept is a very good game. The ability of running and gunning continuously is such a good thing to have. The action is non stop and you really get sucked into it. However, there are some real flaws that prevent you from enjoying the game: 

1) Frequent Crashes - no one knows why but the latest patch seems to crash...a lot. Normally, I would just restart and go along my merry way. But if you happen to be in middle of ultra nigthmare run, you are hosed. I have seen numerous streams in which the game crashes in middle of such runs and the host has no choice but to restart. There were no crashes before the patch, so more to do with game than PC specs. 

2) Bugs - In addition to crashes, latest patch doesn't register key strokes. You could have something flashing for a glory kill and on pressing the glory kill button...nothing happens. Same thing for chain saw as well. Very frustrating when you are close to finishing something and because of these bugs, you die. 

3) Master levels - The ARC complex master level is actually good. The cultist one...not so much. The idea of ramping up difficulty is shoving tyrants in small spaces. If they were in different waves, that would be fun. Having too many demons together makes it pretty annoying and not fun. IF you know spawn locations of the demons, you will get through. Otherwise not....seems more like a "do you know where they spawn" rather than a test of your skill. 

4) Broken promises - this one is the most heart breaking. The devs promised plenty of master levels and other content. Yet to live up to their promise. 

I cannot recommend this game in the current state. Maybe when things improve in future, sure. 

TLDR: Brilliant on concept, short on execution.

not a good DOOM game. as a game, its not the worst thing ever made. its just not a good Doom game. not only did they sneak in pay-to-win features in the form of "boosters" but turned Doom into basically, a shooting platformer with a couple of references to Doom. 
the combat itself is fine... the graphics look decent enough for this day and age and its really not too terribly hard to run on alot of different hardware. the controls are responsive and fast enough to do what you want to do.

..that being said, i have a few issues with the game itself. first off, "pay-to-win" in the "multiplayer" mode(s) is a huge deal breaker for me. i should have known better, considering its a bethesda game, but i was hoping that maybe theyd let this one slide, but of course not.... it doesnt feel like a Doom game. it just doesnt. it plays more like a shooter-platformer more than anything, with a few cutscenes in the game. that isnt what Doom is supposed to be, but whatever, times change, i guess....  the music. look, im a HUGE metalhead and i LOVE metal, but this soundtrack is trash. everyone talks about how good it is, but its just not. i had to turn the music volume all the way down because it sucks. good thing i have second monitor so i can just play my own choice in music instead. ugh. there are so many options they could have gone with that would have made it SO much better, but i guess they didnt want to pay royalties to a band that actually knows what theyre doing....

Doom Eternal is the sequel to 2016’s Doom, and the story continues with Earth having been overrun by the minions of Hell. Unfortunately Eternal doesn’t live up to the hype. If Steam allowed average / sideways thumb reviews, that’s what I would have picked.

[h1]The Good[/h1]

•	Fast paced FPS combat.
•	Weapon variety including all the old Doom favourites, shotgun, super shotgun, assault rifle, chaingun, plasma rifle, rocket launcher, BFG.
•	Enemy variety including familiar foes such as imp, pinky, cacodemon, revenant, mancubus, and also several new enemy types.
•	No framerate issues or crashes.
•	Controls are fully rebindable and feel great on mouse and keyboard.

[h1]The Bad[/h1]

•	Level design is the worst I’ve ever seen in a modern FPS, where the pacing and rhythm of combat is broken up several times on every level with annoying jumping puzzles. Jump, double jump, dash, double dash, and wall climb over bottomless pits and falling platforms that will cause instant death if you make a slight mistake. Jump, double jump, dash, double dash, and wall climb to find switches hidden on high ledges to open doors. These sections just don’t feel like “Doom” and sadly there are *so many* of them.
•	Sometimes if you die on the jumping puzzles you have to replay the previous combat encounter because the placement of checkpoints is dumb.
•	£50 for a 17 hour campaign (played on the third difficulty, Ultra-Violence) is overpriced.
•	If your internet connection drops for a second, the game will pause and throw up an error message, which is extremely annoying. I must have seen the below message a dozen times, usually when in the middle of combat. And yeah, okay, obviously my internet sucks. But it shouldn’t matter when I’m playing the singleplayer campaign. (Note: I disabled the option to have special demons who killed other players invading my game before I even started playing because I don’t care about that kind of thing, so that’s not an excuse for needing to be permanently online while playing singleplayer).

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2172098952

[h1]The Recommendation[/h1]

While Doom 2016 is probably the best FPS ever made, Doom Eternal is ... fine, I guess. The combat is fun but those negatives spoiled the experience too many times. Wait for a deep sale.

This game is a masterpiece, plain and simple.  There are numerous other reviews explaining why the singleplayer campaign is amazing, and all of them are valid.  What I want to review here is the game's unique multiplayer experience, "Battlemode" (or BM for short).

BM is an asymmetric 2v1 game mode that pits one player who takes on the role of the Doomslayer against two players (and their NPC minions) who take on the role of playable demon characters (as of the time of writing this, 5 demon characters were playable).  There have been many players who most likely tried this mode a few times and didn't enjoy it.  I'm not here to say anyone is wrong for having an opinion, and certainly everyone who plays this mode competitively knows that there are some problems that need to be fixed.  But I'm here to tell you that BM is absolutely amazing and is by far the most fun I've had with any multiplayer game released in the past 10 years.  

One of the core design principles that the developers used to guide their development of this game was the concept of a "fun zone," which is to say that they have a vision of what "good gameplay" looks like, and they design the game to reward habits and behaviors in line with that vision and punish those outside of that vision.  It is my opinion that a majority of the players who view BM in an overall negative light are those who have most likely not yet experienced the "fun zone" of this game mode.  It needs to be stated that playing BM requires all of the singleplayer campaign skills as just a fundamental baseline - to really play successfully and against truly skilled opponents, you need to elevate your skills beyond just the level needed to play the game in singleplayer.  In fact, playing BM at a high level is the most challenging thing this game has to offer.  As such, players who want to push the limits of skill and creativity and who have a competitive mindset will naturally be able to find an extreme amount of satisfaction from playing and mastering this game mode, but ONLY if they give it enough time to realize that they need to learn more advanced skills than what works in singleplayer.  And that's only talking about playing the game as the Slayer; when you play a demon character, you have a whole new skillset to learn and master that is different from anything you've ever seen in a Doom game.

Now a word on some of the current flaws in BM.  The biggest one is lag/latency issues.  It's impossible to know how much is due to the game's netcode itself versus the natural latency that occurs based on the geographic regions of the players connecting (i.e., if you live farther away from a server, your ping is higher which means lag affects you more).  There is simply nothing that can be done to fix geographic latency and it is not the game's fault that this exists.  But due to the fact that this game allows for some very fast actions, when a player's screen doesn't accurately reflect every action, it can be frustrating.  Luckily, the developers have been quite open and engaging with the BM community and have stated that they are working to fix these issues.  We also know that they are working to add a ranked mode (presumably after the lag issues are fixed) and additional demon characters.  Given the current situation with COVID-19, I see these as positive steps and am willing to accept that implementing these things may take more time than what we impatient gamers might normally expect (or demand) from the developer who took our money and promised us greatness.  You are entitled to your own judgments about this.  There are also still some balancing issues, though the devs also release hotfixes every so often to try to address community concerns (the bigger problem is that the community in general is the same as all other gaming communities and tends to overreact to everything, but that's just gamer logic).  Overall, I am pleased with the effort the devs have shown in addressing the flaws of BM and am willing to be patient as they work to implement changes over time.

But even with the flaws considered, my experience with BM has been exceptionally fun.  I play this game almost entirely for it's multiplayer content now, as I enjoy it even more than I enjoy the singleplayer campaign (though do still replay the singleplayer, because it is indeed very awesome and well worth the price).  I encourage everyone to give BM a try with an open mind, realizing that it requires different skills than what you may have acquired from just singleplayer or from prior FPS titles.  All of the top tier BM players are very welcoming to new players and many of them stream BM content, making them good resources if you want to ask questions and get a better understanding of the "fun zone" of this game.  You don't have to become a godlike player to find the fun in this game's multiplayer, and once you do, you'll realize that there is nothing else like it on the market today.  In that respect, I personally am grateful that id Software made the decision to create this game mode rather than rehash the classic deathmatch that has been done over and over again over the past 30 years.  Battlemode is unique and it stands out, but because of that you will have to put in more effort to master it because not all of your prior skills will translate over to it.  To me, this is a strength and makes it worth wanting to play and master.  If you share my opinion, give it a try (especially if you have a friend to play with), and you might also come to realize just how much fun the Doom Eternal multiplayer really is.

Endless platforming and monkey bars - die more from falls because you missed swinging high enough than from enemies. 

Forced ammo scarcity to  make you use the weapons the devs want you to use on certain maps - you don't get a chance to use your full arsenal, only what they allow you to use. 

New enemy types where you have to shoot them in specific ways to do any damage.

New weapon combos, like the flamethrower, that you're forced to use, even when they don't work well.

Too many attack combos requiring too many different buttons to play smoothly with a keyboard - clearly designed only for game controllers, not mouse and keyboard players.

Tiny maps swarming with respawning enemies from every direction, so there are no tactics you can use anymore. There's no way to use terrain to your advantage because you can't stand still for a second - just jump and shoot and spin like crazy and mash every button and hope you kill them before they kill you. So, none of the differences in the maps actually matter. They look different, but every one plays the same: a tiny area that you sprint around without stopping for a split second, just mashing buttons, until the entire board is clear.

In total - more grind, less choice, less flow, less fun.  A real step backwards from Doom 2016. What a shame.

It's more of what made 2016's DOOM so good, but with various new twists on the gameplay and a very improved story. Some might be surprised at how the combat flowhas changed compared to DOOM (2016), but it makes this feel like a totally different game, which is great. 

I initially wanted to play on a higher difficulty but found that the new combat flow made this a more frustrating experience than I was willing to tolerate, so my recommendation is to set the difficulty to what you find challenging but not frustrating.

Note: The following review was written after a bout of frustration at Taras Nabad. One friend read it it and told me "heh. I think I know what happened. I decided to go back to the game, replay everything so far up to a certain "PONR", and my current oppinion is a bit different right now
------------------------------------------------------------------
"Ammo not included" 

Run out of ammo. Get trolled about not using the chainsaw. The chainsaw is either out of fuel, or there are not weak demons available. And speaking of fooder demons, you reach a point where they are practically being guarded by heavies, so going to them in a hurry is suicide.

This game takes all the fun out of Doom 2016 and turns it into pure frustation at points. For all the cool graphics, the godly vulkan performance, the collectibles, the "poorly mixed soundtrack", you are stuck with an absurd unfair difficulty at points where any  public complain will get you trolled by "git gud" shitbags. You git gud? The game cranks up the fudgery to the point you wish you bought this in physical to shove it up the exhaust pipe of the designers.

The jumping is ok. The marauder is ok. Or it would if it was a true one on one honor battle instead of thousands of mobs. Because by this game they don't even know how to make a boss. A different slightly bigger enemy and more mobs to generate artificial challenge and difficulty.
-----------------------------------------------------

7 hours of gameplay later...
Nothing like getting up and reading your own words 24 hours later. I really was pissed off at that point. I decided to go back to the previous levels and do the collect-a-ton. And damn, I'm actually hooked for real now. The joy of obtaining everything on each level was insane. And this time, things played a bit differently. There's something like "git gud" here. Las week I was complaining about it being too hard. Now I am feeling weird about not dying enough and thinking I should increase the difficulty.

You need to keep playing until certain things become second nature or an habit. Customize the keyboard bindings to have the most important wepons close to your left hand fingers (number keys are good in original Doom, but here there's no break for reaching the ones on the right side of the alphanumeric keyboard), remember to alternate the two types of grenades, set ablaze your enemies from time to time, and have a defined rotation of weapons inside your rip and tearing routine. Oh, and try every weapon mod. By the end of my second week I have been surviving slayer gates without even needing extra lives. I end dying and needing them when trying to get the challenges.

Still, even if you get good enough so that you can automate inside your head all the small tasks, there's still a chance of ending in a guaranteed failure situation. Namely, having zero amunnition, and no chainsaw ammo at all. this is the worse that can happen,  and you will running an arena like a dumbass praying it refills and you can find a fooder demon that is not next to that superheavy while low health, no armor, no ammo, no fuel. This is happening less, though. Most of the time I run in this situation is when trying to do a challenge that requires using a specific weapon, or conserving the gas.

The solution would be some decent melee. For so much doomslayer god of men, his melee is more like cuddling demons if they are not staller. For Richard Stallman sake's, you have two fists. You should be able to pummel an enemy , or kick their demonic ball sack. What, that's what Dork Nokem would do? bleh.

Anyways, the game has a lot of great stuff, and also bad stuff, but less. It's missing balance. I don't need cheat codes, lowering the difficulty or the sentinel armor. I just want an opportunity to come back, instead of being stuck like in a Sierra adventure game.

To be continued. I need to do Taras Nabad again, 100% everything and get to that final leg of the journey
