Notes: No comment on Battlemode will be made because I have not played it. All of my comments will be based solely on the single-player on Nightmare difficulty, since it is the main difficulty I have played.

What I like: 
1. The gameplay. Fast-paced and hectic, forces you to think on your feet. Limited ammo forces you to be a better player. Contrary to popular belief among the loudest detractors of this game, this game is actually not particularly limiting on playstyle, certainly not more than 2016.
2. Weapons are well-balanced, I managed to find legitimate uses for most of the weapons and their mods.
3. Suit upgrades also allow for more flexibility compared to Doom 2016.
4. Roster of enemies has been expanded and they have more ways of hindering you besides just shooting fireballs at you. I especially love the Marauder because the Marauder forces you to rely on your competence regarding game fundamentals rather than using cheese strats.
5. The goddamn Slayer Gates!
6. The game runs pretty decently even on my GTX 1060 Max-Q GPU.
7. The master levels!

What I don't like so much:
1. I can honestly do with less narration, Dr Hayden really could shut up at times. In terms of narration, 2016 is better in this regard, it is less in the way.
2. Sentinel Battery insertion cutscenes can't be skipped. Just why? It gets grating having to see the same animation over and over again with no option to skip it.
3. Crashes and bugs happen at a noticeably higher rate compared to 2016. Also there are more weird invisible barriers that I can do without. Doesn't really take away from the experience very much though.
4. The purple goo needs to die in a fire with the heat of a thousand suns. Thankfully purple goo is not a common sight.
5. We could do with more master levels, although I understand id Software is planning to release more along the way.
6. Writing is honestly nothing to write home about.

Things I'm ambivalent towards:
1. The flashier UI and overall more "video game" feel. I understand why id Software made the changes they did. I wouldn't say I like it so much that its basically the best thing in the world for me, but I will say its something I don't really mind.
2. For the most part I didn't feel anything much about the platforming, I don't think its the absolute best thing in the world, however I'm also perplexed by some of the complaints regarding the platforming. It's honestly not that hard and frustrating and the game doesn't even kill you if you screw up the platforming sections. Have the people who claimed the platforming is hard played the advanced test chambers in Portal 1? That shit can have you tearing out your hair in frustration at times.

Overall, the negatives should be noted, but not enough for me to outweigh the positives. For that, I give the game 9/10, I would highly recommend that people buy this game, especially people who like more gameplay-driven games. However, if you're looking for a more immersive game, more relaxing game and more story driven game... you may want to look somewhere else.

But If I was to nit-pick (and I always do) I think the previous game's campaign level design was better.  

Nitpicking follows:

In DOOM (2016), There were subtle choices to most open areas, allowing you to approach a fight from different angles from the outset. There were also scattered enemies between each set piece. 

In Doom Eternal, your path doesn't branch as much.  It loops and crosses over itself, but there's actually less choice; you're herded into a ambush zone, you fight, then you navigate a jump puzzle (or a series of them) before you reach the next fight. Enemies are scarce between these encounters. 

The scenery is visually much more impressive this time around, but there's more platforming in the main campaign path than the previous DOOM.  

People who love platformers will cheer for that, but I find jump puzzles annoying when they're this frequent, challenging and so visibly contrived; for example I felt that the spinning fire chains (in the early hell level) were not particularly organic in the scene, they looked comical.   

Having said that, there is a more irreverent tone in this latest installment; crushing zombie heads down into their torsos, the cork-pop sound effect when you score a headshot, and the cheesy audio broadcasts from Earth.  It's taking itself a little less seriously these days.

I'm enjoying the playthrough so far.  Savouring it.  I'm just hoping that level exploration opens up in the midgame.

DOOM Eternal improves upon the DOOM (2016) in almost every way. The combat is even more kinetic due to environmental additions such as swing bars, powers that makes  you fast right after a glory kill and a grappling hook. There are new weapons and mods which complement the combat really well. The game is noticeably harder than the previous entry. One key change they did was to make ammo much more lower than before. The idea is so people don't stick to one gun all the time and instead switch up. This might make some people to get adjust to it, but personally I loved this change as I always switched guns constantly until the fight is over. The addition of grenades and fire adds even more tactical depth to the player's consideration as damaging or killing enemies on fire yields armor. When you combine everything, it blends perfectly with the combat style setup by DOOM - 2016 and improves upon it.

The game environments are bigger and more complex than ever before. You will be travelling across  different worlds this time and every world has a very unique aesthetic when compared to Mars and Hell from the first game. You even have a hub world from where the DOOM Slayer can launch missions from, I love hub worlds and this is implemented wonderfully in the game. The game looks even more gorgeous yet it runs just as fast. Their id tech engine is amazing.

Mick Gordan's amazing music is back and is better than ever before and when combined with the gun sounds and screaming of demons, it almost feels like a badass metal concert, like it should. Terrific audio design.

The only issue I had was the game's platforming sections. Most of them were fine, however, some of them were annoying as you really couldn't see where to go until it was too late. Luckily it wasn't as bad as it could have been.

The game is an asymmetrical mp mode got battlemode which I haven't tried yet to give any opinion of. But I am really glad it is a unique mode instead of a standard death match from the past game.

Finally the game is designed to be played multiple times with lots of meaningful unlockables which unlocks music, skins, collectibles like plush toys, etc. After finishing the game I feel like I need to keep it installed on my SSD so I can come back to it very soon.

After all this hype, the game is completely broken. You enter the very first room and the demons fail to spawn, trapping you. Even if this garbage is patched, I'm leaving the negative review up. Making this through Bethesda was a mistake on every level. If this isn't fixed, I'll be forced to refund the game I was hyped about for months and bought a new gaming PC just to experience in its full glory. edit: The oddly specific workaround required starting the save file using my xbox controller of all things. But I still encountered crashing and other disastrous bugs the whole way through so as much as I loved the campaign unfortunately the review stays negative. I can't even get the Unmakyr because finishing a slayer gate causes a crash. Fix your game!!!!

I was super hyped for this game based off how amazing Doom 2016 was. Unfortunately, I was very disappointed. Doom Eternal simply tries too hard to be unique, and as a result feels like a disjointed mess.

First, the combat - while some may enjoy the new pace of combat, I think the need to constantly micro manage your ammo breaks the immersion of just being a badass demon killer. The weapons are obviously cool, but at times using them feels too much like rock-paper-scissors. "Oh, there's a Cacodemon, better take out my shotgun with explosive charges for the 1000th time". And don't get me started about the Marauder. Second, the platforming. Doom is not a platforming game, why add out of place platforming sections that border on either trivial or frustrating? They feel tacked on. Third, the atmosphere/story - Doom Eternal sprinkles attempts at world-building and story-telling throughout the missions, but just like the platforming they feel like an afterthought. Of course you don't expect a strong story from a Doom game - that's not what it's about. But Doom Eternal tries a little too hard to make you take it seriously, and it detracts from the overall atmosphere.
Nah... just nah.

The only problem with doom eternal is that story and atmosphere wise, it's less consistent and more poorly written than 2016.

Gameplay wise it cranks itself to 11 and demands mastery from the player so they can climb a perfectly angled difficulty curve, which is not so steep as to be domineering, but not so flat that it's boring to climb. Doom 2016 makes you feel like a badass, Doom Eternal forces you to be one. It truly is built for nightmare difficulty, so if you're decent at shooters, start from there.

The parkour/platforming (which everyone seems to think is a massive deal for doom for some reasson) is easy as hell. The puzzles are incredibly simple, and honestly quite difficult to fail. I only started to have a little trouble with them towards very late-game.

Overall the improvements in gameplay are so significant that in my opinon they crush the downside of a poorly written story with bad continuity to the last game. I mean how often is it that a sequel improves gameplay so much that you feel like it's impressive antecedent just won't cut it anymore? 

There is one more downside though. Bethesda.net integration is more cancerous than helpful, and sometimes messes with your saves/ has online issues. One of my saves even got deleted at some point, but luckily it was one of my abandoned half-finished playthroughs. 

Side note: I doubt you're buying this game for the multiplayer battle mode, but if you are, some advice: Don't. It's really not that great a gamemode, and feels slow and lethargic (terrible for a doom title). I really appreciate that they tried something new, but they should have leaned more on asymmetric arena shooter and less on first person moba (as far as the demons are concerned).

I am finding it hard to recommend this game. I've been playing for about half a dozen hours now, and up until very recently the game kept introducing new concepts and techniques to me as if I was still playing the tutorial. 

Bethesda, why? Why did you ruin a perfectly good game? Doom 2016 was perfect: it was tight, it was fast, it had an amazing sound-track, and honestly if you'd given me the exact same game but with a different story I would have loved it. Instead you gave us this bloated mess. More is not always better. In this case, it is so, so much worse.

Let's start with the abilities: at any given moment in the fight you have approximately 6 different cool-downs to worry about: there's your flame belch, grenade, chainsaw, weapon-mod, blood fist and dash, good luck keeping track of them all in the middle of a hectic fight. Then you need to keep an eye on your health, your ammo and armor, all of which you must constantly replenish throughout the fight through one of the aforementioned cool-downs. Then you need to remember what equipment works against what enemy: does your chainsaw work on any enemy? Like hell it does! But if you run out of ammo and there are no small fry to kill, well, you done buggered up son, go straight to hell and you do not collect your mini-figurines. 

Take even just the chainsaw: it used to be a get-out-of-jail free card, to be used sparingly. It worked, it was good, and it made sense that you needed more fuel for bigger enemies. Now it's essentially a "can-only-kill-imps" weapon, which you MUST use all the time to keep your ammo up, and the NEW get-out-of-jail-free card is the blood punch. Except the only way to know whether blood punch is available is through a tiny little icon next to six other tiny little icons. And it's the same button as your glory-kill button, so if you accidentally mis-targeted a demon for a glory kill, well, there goes your blood-punch. 

It's a mess. No, Bethesda, this does not give us more "options". It rigidly locks us into a single play-style because there is only one possible way to play now. And it's just.. not fun? 

Frankly, you've ruined it for me. I consider Doom 2016 one of, if not the best games of the past decade. It's right up there with the original Half Life for me. But Doom Eternal just plays like a crappy shooter that tries to make everything way more complex, shoe-horning in stuff just to bloat itself. Take the wall-jumping: we had perfectly good platforming in Doom 2016 without it. It does not make combat faster, it does not make the platforming more challenging. It serves no purpose. Blood punch? Again, no purpose. 

And don't even get me started on the gazillion ways of upgrading weapons, the suit, the ship, the weapon mods, all with practically no purpose other than to make it more RPG-like. Yes, Doom 2016 had this to some extent, and it was mostly pointless there too. 

I almost could not stop playing Doom 2016. It was just so much fun! Every time I hit a new arena, I said to myself: "heck yeah let's go!". With this bore? I'm dreading every encounter, barely a few hours in and they already feel like pre-ordained boring grindfests. 

Literally the only thing that Doom Eternal does better are the environments. I am seeing some of the most amazing landscapes and diverse arenas ever, they are absolutely stunning. Shame the gameplay has been utterly ruined.

Doom Eternal is a modern masterpiece. It perfectly translates a 2D Arcade game into a 3D open world. The shooting mechanics are easy to learn and fun to master, which makes each encounter a rewarding experience. You can make the game your own by customizing your loadout to fit your playstyle. All in all, I would recommend this game to anyone and everyone.
lots of fun and great graphics!

Even though I haven't been playing first person shooters until a few years ago, DOOM Eternal is very enjoyable. The campaign is awesome, with unique level design and great challenges to overcome. I loved how the guys at id wanted to frustrate you as long as they had something to teach you, like how Hugo Martin (the creative director for the game) has said. In the beginning, you will have problems with some of the heavy enemy types, and towards the end of the campaign, you will be ripping and tearing through them without breaking a sweat. The campaign is around 20 hours, but there is still so much more to do, with the existence of the Fortress of Doom as a hub filled with easter eggs. There are collectibles to find and secrets to uncover (which are actually quite worth finding and enjoyable unlike other games where they are throwaway quests essentially). 

There is also the multiplayer experience, where currently the only mode is Battlemode (Invasion has not come out as of this review). I will be honest, I have yet to play more of it but it is really enjoyable so far. It is quite unique mode with 2 demons vs one Slayer, and strategy versus skill really matters. If the demons do not plan out their acts, the Slayer will easily kill you and win. Meanwhile, the reward system from multiplayer is through a Battle Pass kind of system, but as far as I am aware there are minimum or no micro-transitions. Yes, people have complained of the absence of traditional multiplayer modes like Team Deathmatch, but I am okay with id's decision to try new things instead of the same old regular multiplayer that every other game has. 

Overall, I loved playing DOOM Eternal so far, and will continue to play it and enjoy it. If you get a chance, go buy it and have fun!

Great sequel to an excellent game.

There are a few annoyances in the sequel - ammo is a lot rarer, there is a particularly annoying enemy that requires playing in an artificial way to beat, and there are still some stability issues (July 2020) but it's definitely worth it.

Tip: Play it on Ultraviolence or Nightmare. This is a game that pairs well with high difficulty, and when you're in the zone it's like a dance of death.

The environments are all very different to 2016, which is nice because it never feels like you are repeating things you have already done before.

Doom Eternal takes what Doom (2016) did, and makes it so much better (even though I loved 2016 already). The mobility this game adds with the dashes, monkey bars, the meathook and double jump from the start really gives you a whole other feel when running around the encounters, ripping and tearing everything in your path.

The game makes a point showing how much the player is respected, feared and worshipped. That's you. You, on your own, are so much of a threat to all hell, that humanity looks to you as if you were a god, and the demons are warned of your presence when you enter a new area. Id Software really creates that feel you look for in a Doom game, that YOU are the most powerful being in the universe. 

And of course, it's all accompanied by Mick Gordons incredible soundtrack. There were people who complained about the metal in Doom (2016)? Well, Id Software basically told those people to go fuck themselves, and shoves even more down your throat. It's absolutely fucking amazing. Now, to be fair, I preferred the soundtrack in 2016. It matched the flow and progession of the game better. That's not to say the music is bad in Eternal, it definetly slaps just as hard, if not harder, it's just doesn't match the game quite as well as 2016 did.

Now let's get to the lore. While Doom (2016) was more or less testing the waters with their new(-ish) concept for a modern Doom, and focused a lot less on story than on the gameplay, Doom Eternal has a solid story which is easy to follow, and if you're actually interested in the lore, there's a lot to read in the game. This is done perfectly in my opinion. Doom was never created to be a story-driven game. The focus was always on the gameplay. It was all about running around at high speeds, slaughtering demons. For the people that only want that, it's relatively easy to gloss over any story elements, as you aren't really forced to learn that much about it throughout the game. Most of it is written on pages you pick up during the game, allowing the people who are interested to read, and those who don't give a fuck to not give a fuck.

I personally enjoy learning about the lore, especially in this case. Without spoiling anything, Id Software managed to connect the old Doom games to the new ones in a very interesting way. It actively makes me want to know more about the lore, which isn't something I ever thought I would say about a Doom game.

All in all, Doom Eternal is fucking incredible. From a gameplay perspective it's probably one of my favorite games of all time. It's definetly the best Doom game to date (in my opinion), and I can't wait for what's to come.

This game is pure, unadulterated and raw fun. The levels are longer and packed with more collectibles of more types, yet the game somehow only takes up about half the disk space of DOOM 2016. The inclusion of an arena mode in the game's hub room (called the prison) is a very welcome addition for when you just want to experience the detailed, gruesome combat without worrying about other surrounding aspects. The soundtrack certainly delivers in this game, even allowing you to pick up some music from other id software games as collectibles.

You no longer die when you fall off a level, but instead respawn at a nearby location approximately where you fell. The movement is also greatly expanded and improved, allowing you to swim, climb walls, dash (upgrade this quickly), fling off of monkey bars and break certain cracked walls.

The chainsaw plays a much larger role in DOOM Eternal compared to it's predecessor, acting as a way to quickly gather the in this game much scarcer ammo from lower tier enemies, rather than quickly eliminating the tougher guys (which you rarely have fuel for). For this purpose, one bip of fuel recharges quickly over time, and the game features a plethora of ways of executing the bigger demons in your way. Take for example the BFG or it's rapid fire counterpart which you can unlock, or an immensly powerful sword for one hit KO:s on basically any enemy.  

DOOM Eternal is much harder than DOOM 2016, and will feature encounters where you almost laugh at how ridiculously many enemies the game throws at you. However, on normal difficulty I had no problems getting through it without getting frustrated, especially because this game gives you multiple lives and only resets you to a checkpoint when they run out (which never happened for me) as well as multiple ways of regenerating ammo, health and armor.

Some levels have cheat codes as collectibles, which can be activated when replaying any level. The ability to progress, collect items and such still function mostly as it would during a normal playthrough, allowing you to master a level while having infinite ammo, all runes, infinite beserker mode and much, much more. 

If you go for all the secrets, expect a 13 hour long game (as seen by my playtime).

This isn't a Doom game. It's a bullet hell knockoff where the designers thought spamming damage sponge enemies that take 25 bazooka rounds to the face to kill (I'm not even joking) was a good idea. Game play basically consists of areas of Super Mario platforming (which gets old after the second stage) followed by a giant fight where you will essentially run in circles over and over. The mobs spam heat seeking projectiles at such a high rate you can barely tell what's going on. 

Doom Eternal is hard, very hard. So hard the Devs really really want this to be some FPS Dark Souls or something. You will die, not because of clever and challenging game design but because you'll get stuck on one of the many walls placed by someone that apparently went to the Salvidor Dali school of architecture.  Standing in one place for more than a second is is a death sentence due to the constant cheese spamming of literally every mob in the game. Apparently, the designers think that running in a circle for an hour makes compelling game play. Their foil for this profoundly innovative combat design is to have Prowler mobs that can teleport clear across a map at will right behind you so you get blocked for that split second needed for the 293284023802384023840923890 perfectly aimed projectiles the other mobs are throwing at you to hit you for a zillion damage. It's the video game version of throwing sh*t at a wall and making your insides stick when you explode for the 70th attempt.

I expected more.

TL;DR: If you like lots of platforming between each fight and constant ammo mgt, this game is for you.  As for me, I'll replay Doom 2016,

Where Doom 2016 was a FPS that had occasional jumping puzzles, Doom Eternal is a platformer with occasional combat.  The jumps usually require 2 jumps, 2 dashes, a few yellow poles you have to hit during these jumps, and then wall climbing and each level is full of them.  Sometimes, to mix it up, the platforms or walls disappear a few seconds after you land on them or there are targets you have to shoot while jumping.  There's probably 10 minutes of trying to figure out where to jump and then doing it for each 2 minutes of combat.  Even when your fingers start becoming trained to do this and it becomes easier, even fluid, it breaks up the flow of the game; you feel more like Super Mario with a shotgun than a rough tough demon slayer.  And unlike Doom 2016, you can't just turn off your brain, pick up a shotgun, and kill some demons.  This game requires thinking.. where to jump, how to jump to the next area, etc.  There are a lot of other design choices that I dislike immensely (low ammo count so you basically have to use the chainsaw every minute and can't save it for bosses, and you still have to change weapons constantly, for instance),

To be fair, there is a way to change the difficulty, but it doesn't actually change the required jumping so it doesn't actually make a big difference.  Enemies die faster, and the ratio of platforming to combat just gets worse because of it while it doesn't actually help with any of the jump puzzles or double jumps.

To an extent Doom 2016 was an arena shooter where you are forced into small areas to fight and can't backtrack or retreat. Doom Eternal turns this up to 11. The fights still lock you in so you can't backtrack. But now you get so many resources from glory kills/chainsaw that nothing has consequence. 

The original Doom was tense because even if you cleared a room you might have used up so much ammo and health that you were screwed. The new one might as well not have levels, if you beat a fight you can just chainsaw and glory kill to be at full health/ammo. Each fight is disconnected. 

It would still be a good but not great game even with that. But because the devs decided you need to rely on fodder to keep your health and ammo up all of the bosses and hard fights are infested with infinitely respawning trash mobs. You don't get to decide to clear trash first or focus the boss like in the original series. You're constantly shot in the side by imps that have to be there because without them you wouldn't have enough ammo or health.

The original games were amazing, there was a tight limit on health and ammo per level and it was up to you to overcome. Yes that meant backtracking to pick up health or ammo, but thats okay it added to the feel of the level being a real place. Doom Eternal has a very modern hyper polished feel. The devs wanted to remove backtracking. They wanted to make sure you couldn't screw a level up by getting to the last fight without enough resources to finish. 

The design choices to create that polished modern feel have made the game fun in each micro segment and vastly worse overall. It has chopped the game into lots of little disconnected pieces that added together is less than the sum of its parts. In summary, Doom Eternal embodies late 2010's design trends and is less because of it.

An otherwise excellent game ruined by one unit--the Marauder. Seriously, in a game that has dropped all pretense of serious storytelling or world building, combat flow is *everything*. Doom Eternal has the best combat flow of any FPS to date hands down--until the Marauder shows up. Every other enemy in the game gives you plenty of latitude in how you choose to engage them, allowing you to twist and weave your strengths/enjoyment--except the Marauder. Remove the timing mechanic of this Souls-inspired, argent dumpster fire and the game is a 10/10. Until then it's broke.

I thought Doom 2016 was the perfect FPS when I first played it 3 years ago on my PS4. It was fast paced, action packed, heavy hitting, and all the other buzzwords people like to throw at a Good Game.

Then Doom Eternal came along and made Doom16 look like babby's first schuter.

Everything about Doom Eternal is a step up from its predecessor. It isn't content to let you stand back and kill every enemy with your favorite weapon, as it challenges you to come up with weapon and item combinations to kill faster and harder with the least damage taken. I played through the game on HMP for my first go and even then i found the game to be decently challenging. Going from that to Ultra-Violence feels like removing the training wheels, as the game is more content to punish you for small mistakes.

Don't get the wrong idea, the game isn't unfair. It's not punishing you for the sake of it. It's not trial & error. It respects the player and expects the same in return. If you go into every encounter relying entirely on your SSG, you're going to die. If you rely on one weapon you will die. If you don't move, and use the available items like grenades and flame blech, you will die. The game demands you get better at it to achieve the feeling of being a true slayer.

If you're looking for a game to really master, look no further.

DOOM Eternal is, for now, one of the best games of 2020. It took everything that DOOM (2016) did and just made it better. It even got rid of some of the problems of the first game. If your interested in a new game to play and you like shooters and an adrenaline rush, this is a must-play title.

This is DOOM 2016, but more. More demon types, more patterns to learn, more things to keep track of in a fight, etc... Ammunition can feel scarce, but despite what some players believe, this is less to make you to use your chainsaw, and more to force you to rapidly swap between weapons with different ammo types to get through a fight. Combat centers around rapid movement, combining jumps, bar swings, mid air dashes, and grapples to enemies. Whereas you can mostly dodge everything coming at you in 2016, here, the volume of incoming attacks almost forces you to take hits. This leads into the game play loop of constantly topping off armor, health, and ammo with fire kills, glory kills, and chainsaw kills.  You are required to learn how to use all your gear, mobility, and weapons in a way you don't have to in 2016, which I think is the source of many players' frustrations. Additionally the mobility centered puzzle elements and arena additions (bars, jump pads) bother some people, but they're hardly out of place for an arena shooter by ID. Its like complaining about no waist-high-walls to take cover behind in a Quake game.  I notice that people's complaints about the game fall into these categories:

The fighting is too difficult / too much of it
The platforming and exploration sections are too difficult
Their is too much lore compared to 2016
Their is too little lore compared to 2016

Make of that what you will.

Doom 2016 was a fantastic experience that felt great to play, and gave you the tools to achieve your maximum potential. The difficulty felt appropriate for each level and the campaign was a lot of fun. And then there was Doom Eternal. Holy shit, what an upgrade. If you played Doom 2016, I feel like you'd be hard-pressed to dislike this addition into the franchise. The mechanics are pretty different in this game, but I feel like all the changes were to its benefit. To be perfectly honest, I never really bothered with the chainsaw in Doom 2016, but in Doom Eternal, the limited ammo capacity requires that you use it throughout, and it's more forgiving when it comes to fuel as a result. Weak points on demons makes you really plan out your attack, and it means that almost every weapon will serve a purpose. In Doom 2016, once you got the super shotgun, there was very little need to use anything else, unless you ran out of ammo. The story in this game definitely got turned up to 11 and feels more narrative, whereas the story in Doom 2016 was rather lacking. There's much more dialogue, lore, and cutscenes in this entry in the series. Also, if you thought Doom 2016 was difficult, this game makes it look like a joke. Nightmare on Doom Eternal is infinitely more difficult than Nightmare on Doom 2016. If you're a fan of Doom, I think you'd be insane not to pick this one up. It's made even better by the fact that it goes for as low as $29.99 on sale. Highly recommend this.

This is one of the most complicated shooters I have ever played. It's got a strong learning curve with a many new progression lines and controls that become more and more necessary as the game progresses, even on the lower difficulties. Exploration is a must and you are rewarded purely for covering the map green as well as finding secrets such as praetor tokens, suit and weapon upgrades, batteries, dolls etc.
It took me about 4-5 hours before I learned the rythm of the game. It takes a good amount of time to figure out when the best time to use your chainsaw or flame belch are so don't give up too quick. 
Once you master the weapon wheel, mods, powers and aiming it feels SOOOOO good. It's a blast to get in and really feel like the DOOM Slayer for the first time!

This isn't your Daddy's DOOM by any means. You will be tested and you will fail MANY times, but it's so good. If you have the cajones to play on Hardcore or Nightmare or even Ultra Nightmare, may satan have mercy on your soul, and your sanity! You will be tested!

Good luck and play on friends! I HIGHLY recommend this game!~

Finished the game yesterday and I just have to say that I wasn't really happy with the game over all. It can be fun and really feel like an improved Doom experience, but the game tends to quickly take away the fun by drowning the player in tutorials and new mechanics all the way until the end of the game. It can be frustrating at times because I've always seen Doom to be a simple fps. 

I know it sounds like a broken record, but the marauder really sucks. Like he reallllly sucks to fight. I was always curing under my breath every time he would show up and it totally took the wind out of my sails. Eventually you get used to fighting him and it becomes easier, but with how may new demons we have in this new game, on top of all the new mechanics, it feels like the game is too much over time. 

But on the positive side, I would still recommend this game to anyone who has been a fan of the series. The fact that they are able to pack so many demons into the arenas feels so chaotic and I've never been happier to see all chaos on my screen. I also love that they tried to give more lore to the universe and I also love the detailed environments we traverse. The series has come a long way and it's really amazing to see how much has changed over the years. 

I personally don't think this is my favorite game in the Doom franchise, but I feel it is welcome and am excited to see what ID does next.
Well worth the buy, super fun if you want to try and find secrets or just enjoy killing demons with some awesome sound to boot!

Daym good game

So here's a summary of my review

Spoilers aplenty

Story beginning/premise
The game skips 8 months between the stories of 16' and Eternal. ||Sam got split down the middle whilst fighting the demons on earth after warping you to parts still unknown and got stuffed on life support back in his ARC resistance HQ (probably in Los Angeles or Austin Texas)|| You start in the fortress of DOOM, Slayer's/player's hub area, get a request for help on the radio from civilians calling for any aid. Slayer cocks his shotgun then drops right into the hell barge with ||One of the three priests leading the demonic invasion|| and from there is roughly 15-20 hours of mayhem.

Gameplay basics: The demons have been balanced on a tightrope of three factors
Size, Damage output, and numbers. Everyone comes back for more when you first meet them. You have fodder such as imps, zombies, and soldiers. They do enough damage to be a constant threat but exist to be farmed for resources (the chainsaw regenerates one pip of fuel so chop em like beef on a grill) You have the heavies like DOOT, Mancubus, Pain elementals, whiplash and cacos. There be four super heavies that'll drive you to blood lust, as the devs intended (Archviles, the Marauder, the DOOM Hunters, and our old pal the Tyrant. Be sure to humiliate him by not using the BFG or ||Unmakyr|| when you do.

Chainsaw for ammo, glory kill for HP, and Flame Belch + attacking burning enemy = armor. Runes make a return, but there's no Rich get Richer rune. They made that one into a cheat you can find.

To upgrade guns you have to complete combat encounters, secret encounters (timed combat skirmishes) and the Slayer Gates. 1 point per encounter and secret encounter, and three for a Slayer Gate (you can't access the Gates when using cheats tho) up to 10 points per mission max. Also bosses give various amounts, but i'll leave those out completely... also ||GIANT SWORD||

Every not-key-8 weapon has an alt fire mode and upgrades for them. Take full advantage of the arsenal, because they all have good uses (except for maybe the Microwave beam for me personally). You collect praetor tokens to upgrade your suit, and Sentinel batteries to access useful stuff at HQ, and some cool skins. Lastly there are crystals that upgrade health/armor/ammo stats. Fill in a dual set of upgrades for a perk like Loot Magnet. Max those out and become a death god.

As you progress you'll eventually unlock skins for Doomguy, battlemode demons and your guns (Yes, even the BFG-9K).

The cutscenes are relatively short and all skippable. They are simultaneously 5/10 and an 8/10 for me. Whilst they do pad out the game a bit (and are easily ignored) you still get great animations and stellar character development for our boy. They fit well and don't interrupt the flow of the game, because they all lead to you slaying the armies of darkness.

You can collect cheats, album covers, toy figures, have a display for weapons, go to the ripatorium for some casual BFG Division slaying. There is plenty of things to do while you DOOM. They even added a new multiplayer mode I've yet to try for myself.

In short, DOOM Eternal is a genuine labor of love from the folks at iD. Worth my $60. 9/10 GOTY 2020

Playing this makes you feel more like a badass than Doom 2016, the inclusion of the dash and meat-hook makes arenas more fun as you move from enemy to enemy blasting bits of their flesh off; the game is much more fast paced and it makes it exciting and thrilling to play.

F the snakes

Combat is visceral, engaging, and rewarding. Enemies approach from all directions. Broadly speaking, they come in 3 priority tiers, but across 2 of those tiers you'll still have to weigh your options depending on available ammo, positioning, and heat zones in the combat arena. All the while, you have to keep yourself moving. Standing still is like backing yourself into a corner -- you will die. Fast.

You're left so overwhelmed with the barrage of stimuli that you'll even welcome the brief story cutscenes. You probably won't care about what's happening, but that 20 - 30 second reprieve clears the fog of your bloodlust. Over time, the cutscenes become longer, though (thankfully) less frequent. I wish they'd stuck with this "take a breather" format, though...

Every 4 - 5 missions, gameplay design takes a back seat and you're left with long stretches of exploration between combat encounters. While this may be reminiscent of missions in the original Doom games, it doesn't mean it's fun. The illusion of 3D geometry was still a novelty in 1992, and players were happy to bask in the atmosphere while jamming to MIDI guitar riffs.

Eternal's designers seem to know that simply moving around won't cut it any longer, so they try to break it up with alternate traversal mechanics, such as dashing, double-jumping, air-dashing, and vaulting onto nearby ledges. These mechanics do keep things fresh for a while (especially during combat), but they're extremely forgiving -- to the point of presenting no challenge in puzzle sections. The designers didn't take the player's learning curve into account, so traversal became boring again.

I'd be willing to forgive the complaints above, but the worst part is the introduction of the Marauder enemy. He's such a threat that he immediately takes highest priority, but he also has such a demanding combat loop that you really need to wipe out the other high-priority targets to prevent yourself from dying because some demon sucker-punched you. After you manage to whittle down the playing field, you're left with a tedious fight.

The Marauder deals high damage if you're too close. He also deals high damage if you're too far. You have to stay in his Goldilocks zone, but he can dash and quickly closes the gap. He has a shield that deflects all damage, and he only lowers it long enough to dash in for the kill. You're left dashing away on the defensive and it's disorienting. You'll probably miss with the right weapon. Hold the wrong weapon and it may have too much spin-up time to even land a shot before his shield is back up -- or worse, damage yourself with splash damage. Try to use a super weapon and you've just wasted your ammo. Oh, did I mention he has a flame elemental guard dog that will attack you if you move too far away? Since it's incorporeal, you can't chainsaw it for ammo, which is inevitably the reason you moved too far away from him in the first place. If you need more ammo, you're going to trade health for it.

The Marauder has appeared 3 times in the game. I'm about 2/3 of the way through. Maybe I'll revisit Eternal some day, but I think I'm just done for now. If you're looking for 10 - 15 hours of solid gameplay, I'd recommend Doom Eternal. Just cut your losses when this guy shows up.

First off, I want to say that this game is an absolute masterpiece and is definitely on the list of best games of all time.

That said, there are a few things I want to nitpick:

1. The upgrade system in general is not as great as it was in Doom 2016. The whole thing with the sentinel crystals was kind of lame and a lot of the upgrades seemed to go toward systems I never actually used. I didn't use the grenade launcher once through my entire playthrough. Additionally, there were extra suit upgrade tokens and sentinel batteries that I didn't know what to do with at the end of the game.

2. This game is also quite lore heavy and delves more into the world of Doom that has been in construction since Doom 2016. I did enjoy learning about the lore itself--I know there are those that have their own reservations about it, but I really liked the lore in the game. My problem with it is that I wasn't able to actually read the codex entries until finishing up the game. I couldn't read them as I picked them up in the game just because it was hard to transition from battle to reading. It's a small nitpick, but something I felt others should be aware of.

3. I also felt that the developers went a little overboard trying to amp up the graphics in this one. You really can't get much better than Doom 2016, but in trying to I feel like they tried a little too hard and ended up making it just a bit too colorful. It's not bad by any means, just not as good as its predecessor. Doesn't distract too much from gameplay.

I will also say that the game itself is definitely harder than Doom 2016 was, to the point that I had to set it to the lowest difficulty level to actually have fun--however, I should also note that I'm not a big first-person shooter player in general (I'm just not very good at them) and I only just got into the Doom series. If you need to play on the lowest difficulty setting, don't be afraid to. Not every game is Dark Souls and you should be able to play however you want without judgement from others. Games are meant to be fun, and goddamn this one was fantastic.

So ive been excited to make a review for this game. Since I played Doom 2016 last year, ive been really excited to play Doom Eternal. After reading some of the reviews, I wasn’t so sure how the game was actually going to be. I, along with a majority of others, were comparing it to its predecessor, Doom 2016, which had many accolades and was highly praised. This one had a lot to live up to, and in my eyes, it did a pretty good job. Im going to go through and review certain aspects of the game and address some of the other points I saw in other reviews. For the sake of myself and time, imma just refer to Doom 2016 as Doom. 

[h1] To begin with, lets discuss the basic gameplay. [/h1]
      Its very similiar to Doom 2016. The maps are very linear, you go from point A to point B, stopping every now and then with a demonic encounter, and you clear the room, and move on. Simple and straight to the point. Nothing too bad or complicated here. The minimap is so much easier to read and be able to make out locations than it was in Doom. This game falls short in the same way as Doom did. Well, it only falls short based on your playstyle in this regard. The collectibles. There are so many dam collectibles. That’s not a bad thing, but if you were like me and wanted to find them all in one playthrough, you would spend 80% of a level just looking around at the minimap trying to find how to get it. As mentioned earlier, the collectibles are much easier to find, most of the hidden ones are hidden by a giant breakable crack that’s easy to spot. In Doom, a lot of the hidden ones were hidden by a lever that blended in like it was Susan Storm from Fantastic 4. But honestly, the collectibles are found throughout Doom Guys lair, Fortress of Doom, so that’s a pretty cool little difference. Doom Guys “Rec room” consists of many Easter eggs and collectibles that act as a gateway for character models like in Doom, but instead in a room that you can admire them in. But getting back on topic, looking back, Doom eternal added a nice little feature where you can fast travel to certain points on the map after you complete, but NOT EXIT OUT of, the level. Meaning, you can actually go through the entire level without stopping the combat to hunt for items, and then go back after killing all of the hell spawn to look for items. I didn’t do that and ending up having many slow times in the game, where I was just looking for collectibles. And there are about 10- 15 items per map.  So kudos to them for improving that. 

[h2] Lets move on to basic Gameplay mechanics. [/h2]
 Most of the weapons are similar, nothing new. Don’t fix what aint broke. The Ballista and Gatling gun got a few new upgrades, but that’s about it. One new thing that’s introduced near the end of the game are a few weapon token used to bypass the mastery. In my opinion, that kinda defeats the entire purpose of mastering the weapons by yourself. But you don’t have to use them, so its up to you. If you like grinding, you still can, and if you don’t, you don’t have to. Theres about 7 or so I think, idk. By the time they were introduced, I already had a couple of the guns I liked mastered. Oh, and the super shotgun is amazing. The little hook that comes out of it is amazing and later becomes essential for armor and just for looking and feeling like a badass. The biggest game play mechanic that I saw in the comments but wasn’t sure what it was was the “Parkour” element to the game. Basically monkey bars and climbable walls. At first it seems kinda cool, then it just feels like they are in there just to prolong the game and just to have them in. Its Doom Guy, killer of demons and gods, yet he cant bust down a wooden door to get to Point B, and instead has to swing from conveniently placed monkey bars, sometimes spread apart so far that you have to time the jumps just right or else its game over for poor Doom Guy. This isn’t a huge problem, it just kinds becomes pointless after having swung from a few hundred bars already. Wall climbing seems like a more appropriate choice. This game also has a lot more “Puzzles” in it, meaning you have to hit buttons and levers in the correct order, not hard btw, its just a couple. These just seem kinda pointless, as why the hell would these demons build their fortress, decked out with traps and gates and such, just to have a button that can be shot to unlock a door that will let Doom Guy just waltz on in and kill them. Seems kinda like the Deathstar, but you know, whatever, story line. 
Another issue that players had was how the ammo looked, that it looked too colorful and cartoony. The UI in the game is great, and totally customizable. You can change the brightness of the drops, and even change the color of the UI, which is neat. There are more options, I just didn’t mess with them. So yeah, if you don’t like how the drops look, you can change them.
 
[h3] Then there's the ammo problem. [/h3]
 After a while, ammo isn’t as bad when its fully upgraded, but you still need to use the chainsaw. The other reviews made it seem kinda difficult, but its not. There are literally a class of demons called Fodder. Your chainsaw always refuels one fuel, making those fodder demons your main source of ammo. Kinda annoying, but its manageable. So in my opinion, not that big of an issue. 
Now, the game feels a lot harder than Doom. Which is a good thing, as Doom began to feel a little too easy near the end of the game. In this game, you die a lot more often. They do have extra lives scattered throughout the level, but its useless. They saved my ass maybe a total of 4 times, the rest of the time id die to an imp or something, wasting my life. You cant just restart a checkpoint to get that life back, those lives are gone for good. The extra life rune is more important than any of those anyway, imo. So they are good and all, but honestly, except for the Extra life mode, a perma death mode, where you have to rack up those extra lives, its useless. You can survive almost any encounter by yourself after a few attempts. 

Im not one that’s big for story line, but this one was good I guess. I really forget whats happening after I spend almost an hour on a level hunting for little toys and other hidden items, but you get the gist. Demons bad, Doom guy good. You get a little backstory of Doom Guy and his race, which is cool. (Hopefully the DLCs will expand on some things) 

[h4] Multiplayer. [/h4]
So I wanted to 100% this game, but that’s really hard due to one thing. The multiplayer. And most of the reviews are pretty accurate when they say its dead. It’s a cool concept, Doom Guy vs 2 demons, but holy hell is it dead. It takes maybe a minute or so to find a match, another half minute to get ready, and depending on the enemy, may be over in 2o seconds. The first match I played, I hadn’t quiet finished the game and was like a lv 12 or so, I got matched with a both opponents at lv 150+. Next match was a dude 200+. But the point is, rarely will you find a match with people your skill level. Its sad that an achievement, play 25 battlemode matches is such a rare achievement. I mean only 2.6 % of people on steam have played 25 matches?? Unlike in Doom 2016, it had sooooo many customization options, and as this one does have some, it so much different than Doom. Its fun seeing your character in the campaign though. 

Overall, really fun game. Demons are harder, cooler looking, and that Super shotgun is looking sexier than ever with its ability. Worth the money. Its just a shame that a cool concept like battlemode was executed so poorly. The devs tried, but it just doesn’t work out in its current state. Theres a lot of fun to be had in the campaign though. I was also hoping for a little somthin somthin for players that sat through the entire credits, and it did not disappoint. Its pure perfection. 
So overall, 9/10.

 I am currently on my second playthrough, this time on a harder difficulty, and I can say I am nowhere NEAR done with DOOM Eternal. There is a high skill ceiling, and in order to complete the game on the harder modes, you MUST master the movement and weapons. It's a tough game. Especially compared to 2016's DOOM, but unlike 2016, the utilization of all your equipment and weapons is vital to success in Eternal. This means that the gameplay is incredibly rewarding, and that "cheesing" your way through the game is a less viable option.

I love DOOM Eternal. I am looking forward to the extra content that is coming later this year, and in the meantime there's enough to do in the game to keep me VERY busy until then.

The game feels and plays absolutely amazing. The pacing of the game is very well done and i've had a lot of fun playing the game.
The last level of the game however is completely insane. They just pump enemies after enemies in the same location upping the difficulty to a point where you get stunlocked by enemy attacks if you stop walking for a single second.
This is an artificial way of difficulty i don't agree with seeing as it's still the same enemies you fight with no real mechanical changes.

It was not a bad game but I would not recommend it at full price, or perhaps even 50% off.

Unlike many other negative reviews I didn't struggle with ammo or the gameplay. I played it on Ultra Violence (second hardest) and finished the game with ~23 extra lives left and 100% collectibles. So the problem was not that I struggled, the problem was that I didn't have that fun playing it. This is mainly because how the game was designed to be played:

CONS:
The levels, while visually nice, are far too linear for my taste. In very crude terms it basically boils down to corridors that lead to big arenas where you fight a lot of demons that spawn in. The arenas definitely feels like shooter arenas with jump-pads e.t.c. all over the place. Personally not a fan of singleplayer arena-styled shooters.

Exploration is mostly looking at the map instead of actually exploring the environment.

Fighting demons feels more Unreal Tournament as opposed to Doom. Lot of double jumping, jump-pads and dashing around while constantly switching weapons.

The levels are disjointed to each other. Where am I now? Mars? Earth? Hell? Somewhere else? It feels random.

Timed challenges sucks. You can find them on levels and after activating them you have to beat X amount of demons in Y amount of time. If you fail you can retry but your lives, health and ammo is NOT replenished. Not fun at all.

Press 'C' to ammo. Also known as the quick-key for the chainsaw which replenishes almost all your ammo. While it works, it makes it completely pointless to manage and search for ammo between demon waves. For example, you don't need to search for secrets and store up a supply of rockets which you can use on a hard level like in the old Doom. All you need to do is press 'C'. The only exception is the BFG which the Chainsaw does not replenish.

The multiplayer sucks. It's only 2vs1 and expect to only be matched with players with 100+ levels. Levels don't make you stronger but it does mean you have played the game a LOT. No deathmatch or team deathmatch.

PROS:
I liked the platforming.

They tried to flesh out the lore.

As expected, a masterpiece shooter from Bethesda. Gameplay mechanics are just superb. Loved every aspect of the game, how they have improved over the doom series to the point where this game feels absolutely perfect. You have a solution for everything, it's purely skill based now, rather than collecting ammo and armor you make your own. Low health? Glory kill. Low armour? Burn the demons. Low ammo? Just rim em through the chaingun. And the meathook... loved it. Absolutely recommend this game.  RIP AND TEAR !!

I loved Doom 2016 and got Doom Eternal hoping for more of the same.  In some ways Doom Eternal delivered, but in others it fell short.

The levels in Doom Eternal look every bit as pretty as those in Doom 2016, but they are not as well designed mechanically.  Even in just the first few levels there have been multiple occasions where I have been standing there thinking 'where do I go now?'  Puzzling out how to get to a secret is fine, but if it is completely unclear where I am supposed to go to progress the main game that is just bad level design.

Doom 2016 had a mechanic that if you used the chainsaw on a daemon it would spit out a bunch of ammunition, which was a neat little extra.  Doom Eternal has changed that to a core mechanic as ammunition is much more scarce, and not only that but the chainsaw attack doesn't seems to produce as much ammunition.  Combined with glory kills to replenish health and the flamer to replenish armour this gives you three different things to juggle, forcing you into using specific attacks and making what was a neat little extra into a chore, and I at least find that I keep running out of ammunition.  In addition, whereas in Doom 2016 all of the ammunition icons produced by the chainsaw attack were a fairly dull orange, now they are fluorescent green, purple, red.  In the words of the Girlfriend Reviews youtube channel, 'diarrhea christmas lights'.  It just looks obnoxious and distracting.

The final thing that is a negative for me, but might be more of a positive thing for some people, is that there is a lot more platforming than in Doom 2016.  I really dislike platforming.  If you are also a person who dislikes platforming and found the minor platforming sections in Doom 2016 a chore rather than enjoyable then this is also likely to be a negative for you.

It's a fast paced first-person shooter that takes your heart rate to the max. There's a difficulty for everyone and slaying demons in DOOM Eternal has never felt better. DOOM Eternal utilizes all of the revolutionary gameplay mechanics from DOOM 2016 while simultaneously adding more demons, more weapons, and a longer campaign. The chainsaw and improved glory kills make you feel as though you are literally a Dragonborn shouting apart your enemies with via a Thu'um. However, the main part of DOOM Eternal that makes it so great is how smooth the game feels. Any game can implement weapons, abilities, and interesting demons to eviscerate. But, DOOM Eternal feels so incredibly smooth the only way to describe would be like a lightsaber sliding through a block of cheese. DOOM Eternal makes the Slayer feel weightless, swift, and free. No more slow and heavy characters like in Escape from Tarkov of PUBG; DOOM Eternal is the KING of fast-paced first-person shooters.

Buuuuuuuuuuut... Doom Eternal leaves me wondering if this game is really worth it. Don't get me wrong, this game is absolutely wonderful... when it works. 

The amount of Bethesda that peaks out is overwhelming and honestly is just upsetting when it shows. Frustrating glitches and bugs are rather apparent at times such as the weapon mastery bug or just simply clipping through the floor and falling forever. I was lucky enough to beat the game once through without any major bugs occurring, but on the Extra-life play-through, I just didn't have the patience to deal with it. 

All in all, if you're a Doom fan, go ahead and get the game, if it's on sale like when I bought it. I wouldn't pay full price for this. Maybe if the bugs ever get fixed, I could recommend this game to others, but as of now, I cannot.

Playing this on the second highest difficulty. Compared to the 2016 DOOM, you have quite a few different buttons to push here in the middle of combat, but it's just enough that it doesn't become a frustration. In many fights I find myself unable to think ahead in the time before another demon takes a swing at me, meaning I ultimately end up having to rely on my reflexes in those rather common situations. And that is a GOOD thing. This game rewards fast decision making heavily, as you must pick out the appropriate tool of your arsenal for any given moment. Your resources (health, ammo, armor) will likely bounce between near-empty to full within moments, which feels highly rewarding, and they can drop just as fast, which keeps the adrenaline running. 

The game makes you feel powerful while leaving you on the razor's edge, and it's amazing.

It's ironic that this one is called Doom Eternal, because its design decisions make it look like its heading to Final Doom territory. People like to bitch about Doom 3, because it was memorably different, but forget how forgettably shit Final Doom was. 

This game has been horribly, and unnecessarily overcomplicated for such a throwback shooter. There are so many systems in the game, its near impossible to pick up a play session after a week or two of playing other games. I had my controller break, and switched to keyboard and mouse, which wasn't a problem for me in 2016 Doom, but this one was just too many control combinations, and since non of them are standard shooter fare, muscle memory couldn't guide me through new controls, I had to just stop playing until a new controller could be bought. This is the first shooter I COULDN'T play with a keyboard and mouse. 

The game is so complicated, it feels the need to stop the game with a popup box every time a new enemy appears to explain why just shooting it... in... a... shooter... doesn't kill it. That's a design decision that raises a red flag. 

The most worrying aspect of this game, though is the Maurader. For a game this large and complicated, dozens of design meetings are required. The Maurader made it through all of them without anyone saying, "Maybe this is shit and shouldn't go in the game, maybe." Instead they said things like "Let's make you fight it at an arbitrarily defined 'Medium' range", and "Lets give him that 'everything proof shield' that every kid you hated in school had. Lets make it immune to the BFG too, because this is apparently a Doom game, lol". This is a massive second red flag. This enemy is entirely antithetical to literally every other enemy in the game. If it was simply on boss fight it wouldn't be a problem. But their lead designer, Kaitlyn Bennett (or I assume because of their affinity of shitting themselves) decided to put at least one in every conflict for the last HALF of the game. They recognized Denuvo was a bad idea and patched that out, but somehow the least Doom idea every put in a Doom game stays in. 

The third red flag was the handling of the soundtrack, suffice it to say that Mick Gordon did pull a fireable offense, but Id and Bethesda should probably mop the floor where they were standing, because they totally shit themselves in that debacle, no one came out well. Third red flag. 

This game has more red flags than a flag pole at Beijing Olympics. In the end I would recommend this game, but this could very well be the last good, but not great, Doom game. I don't see enough involvement in design decisions from anyone who made 2016 Doom fun. This one seems focused on design decisions executives want, like Always Online functionalities and season pass sales. *Bethesda executives looking at next Doom 3* They were sloppy, but you, you will be worse. A 90's shooter done from a modern perspective. Better than Doom 2016, but some may not like the added emphasis on story this time around.

Would I recommend ... well yes but actually no. 

If you want a Doom sequel, where, as that guy from the old ID documentary said (something to the effect of) being a guy taking on the forces of hell, look elsewhere... 

If you want an introduction to the world of Warhammer 40k then this is the best thing ever!!! It has it all!!! All us can rejoice we finally got a sequel, in the form of a prequel, to Spacemarine 40k. Here you can play as a Neophyte (Spacemarine candidate) as he takes on the Chaos forces in the hopes you impress some primarch or the other and get the all mighty gene-seed (called all cheats in game).  

Do you want:
Heretics..............................................check
The corrupted force of Chaos.....check
Space marines / Space wolves....check
Battle Titans......................................check
And...
Dead Royal Guy on a throne.......check

Sure, its easy to point out the similarities, but that is very problem. Doom never needed to be fleshed out story-wise. At it's heart was the story of a lone HUMAN survivor who decided to take on the forces of hell, that's it. It was relatable, to a small degree, who hasn't wanted to fight evil with such abandoned... but this doom guy is now a member in some cosmic brotherhood of space knights, blah blah blah... leaving you with this feeling of watching a dull rehashed space opera. I haven't once so far said that's interesting, rather it has me thinking back to Call of Duty where I can at least get behind the men and women of the story. 

If you want to know about the game play, it's okay. You get into fighting the hordes only to have it end seconds after... It blows its load (of bullets) and then rolls over leaving you dissatisfied and wandering around looking for secrets.... but at least it's fun to look at. 

Bottom line, Bethesda has made their money... my review is beyond late...but at least I didn't pay full price.

Imagine everything you loved about Doom (2016), and then brace yourself for something better. Something more engaging. Something [i]new.[/i] This game embraces wholeheartedly the incredibly fast paced shooter that it is, but also the fun loving spirit that most gamers have in droves. The combat has been revamped to force you to think on your feet, use your entire arsenal, and rip and tear like never before. In Doom (2016), you could get away with using only two weapons, That was fun enough, but the devs really worked to make sure you don't do that this time around. They've made enemies more aggressive and strategic while also lowering your available ammo per weapon. To counter this though, and make sure you're more engaged than ever, you've been given far, FAR more tools to use. You can now dash, have a flamethrower that drops shields when you burn enemies, have a freezing grenade, and your chainsaw regens to make sure you can always get more ammo if you play your hand right! I was a little unsure when I heard about these changes from the devs, but after playing, I'm absolutely astounded. 

Doom Eternal feels like the type of game that just isn't real. It feels like it shouldn't and can't exist. It juggles intense combat with a fun sense of love and care through both the quality of the game itself, and the fun easter eggs you can find in droves. I feel as though, when I wake, this incredible experience will have just been a dream. I can barely fathom the idea of owning something so deeply fun. 

Now, all this praise being said, it's currently a bit buggy. I'm very pleased that they pushed back the date, because it seems to have really needed it. Currently, you'll find yourself getting stuck on a lot of the objects around the map, sometimes you'll be stuck on an enemy (Not grappled, just stuck), and sometimes the Monkey Bar grab is...iffy. All in all though, these are so negligible with just how fantastic this game is. There hasn't been a single moment in my first 5 hours of playing where I thought to myself "This part sucks." Not once has that thought crossed my mind. 

The location of secrets seems far, far smarter this time around too. In the first game, one gripe I had was how frequently out of the way they would tend to be. My first time playing, I didn't mind too much, but with the nature of the game, I really didn't like having to stay out of combat for so long with how fun it was. This time around, however, most of the secrets are streamlined into the routes you'll be taking anyways, so if you keep an eye out, you'll find 'most' of them. Some are pretty sneaky though, which isn't a complaint. The locations for them just feel better this time around! 

I'm yearning to play more of this game right now, but I also don't want to finish it all right away because of just how grand of an experience it is. All in all, I highly recommend this game, and also recommend supporting the developers. They really out did themselves, and deserve to be acknowledged for it!

Absolutely fantastic. 

I'll caveat at first that this game is not flawless technically, it looks great, but there is a not insignificant amount of bugs. It's not something that majorly disrupted my experience, but there are a number of bugs that range from mildly amusing to requiring a reboot of the game (rebooted or crashed about~5 times in 150+ hours of play time). Like I said though, relatively small issues. 

Despite these issues, almost everything is improved on from Doom 2016 in terms of pacing and options the player has. Most importantly for a game about being a one man army, you feel powerful, like "I'm not trapped in here with you, you're trapped in here with me" levels of powerful. It's not just that feeling of power either, Eternal walks a thin line of you being a godlike killer of demons while the demons themselves are a horde ready to wash over you. The game constantly introduces new enemies, weapons, mods, and abilities to keep you and your enemies interesting. The weapons feel impactful, unique, and useful, and those weapons fit perfectly with the enemies. The demons are fast, brutal, and numerous, each fight is a constantly shifting balance of weighing the combat options available with the enemies presented to you. The game shines in huge, hectic arena fights where you can force the battle to be on your terms, but is a bit less entertaining during boss fights. There are 4 real "boss battles" in the campaign, and while decently entertaining on the first playthrough, after completing the campaign once or twice they can be more like a chore in between you and the next arena. The soundtrack is still great of course, it speaks for itself. 

The only thing that was not better than Doom 2016 in my opinion was the story, which is to say, there's a story in this one. I get what Id was trying to do to set up more games after this one, and I didn't hate it like some people do, but a lot of the overall self aware tone is gone from this game. You still find bits of funny voice lines or codex entries poking fun at the game itself, but the overall story is more serious, it wasn't too bad, it just felt a bit odd after Doom 2016's complete lack of regard for any narrative resembling more than a 6 year old's crayon drawing.

TLDR: If you like shooting, punching, ripping, tearing, exploding, and chainsawing through demons like an unstoppable force of nature, play this, there will be a bit of a learning curve since it plays a bit differently then most shooters out there, but totally worth it

With it's visual spectacle, visceral soundtrack, a wide-variety of over 25 demons, and an explosively adrenaline pumping gameplay experience DOOM Eternal can impress even the most avid game enthusiasts.  DOOM Eternal takes the existing groundwork of DOOM (2016) and offers a multitude of additions that improves the formula and stays true to the focus of constant action/violence and fast movement that calls back to but stays unique from the original 1990s games.  For brevity's sake I'll refer to DOOM (2016) as '2016 and DOOM Eternal as Eternal, please refer to the invader zim DOOM song if you feel any DOOM withdrawal.

I played the campaign on Ultra-violence difficulty and found that it required my complete concentration on each enemy and my resources while staying balanced throughout the experience.  During each fight (save for the "parry" demons) there is little to no downtime as you swap between ammo / weapon types to take out each demon.  While you're well-equipped to handle another demon infestation with dashing and many weapons to deal massive damage, enemies are much faster and heavier demons are tankier.  Like in '2016, there's great fun in swapping weapons quickly with the numerical keys where each one applies to each demon type.  You also have two swappable modifications to each weapon (excluding the super shotgun) to fit your playstyle, in my experience I only swapped in the beginning where you lack weapons.  Performance, controls, and pacing all worked flawlessly and I hadn't noticed any areas of dropped framerate / inputs, or too few encounters / too many encounters. 

Ammo is more scarce and limited unlike in '2016 where you have a chance to gain ammo on kills.  I noticed in my playthrough that I burnt through and ran out of ammo several times on each level which heavily incentivizes the use of the chainsaw. In the previous game where I'd use the chainsaw to both clear heavy demons and get ammo back only once, rarely twice each fight I'd use the chainsaw more often in Eternal and only on smaller demons for the ammo.  You can hold a max of 6 fuel pips in '2016, in Eternal you can only hold a max of 3 but can slowly recover a single fuel pip automatically if you have none.  It's up to your discretion on which game did it better but in my opinion I preferred how '2016 incentivized you to use it both for the ammo and cleaving through large demons whereas Eternal punishes you for using it.  If used against a large demon the player is obligated to wait until they get their free fuel pip before picking up any other fuel canisters, in this regard you lose a significant amount of potential ammo to only kill a single enemy and it oftentimes takes you a significant amount of time before you find another canister as there are far fewer fuel/ammo pickups in Eternal (I spent most of my time on one fuel pip).  In addition Eternal lacks the dramatic death animations from '2016, I'd speculate this was removed in order to retain the focus on the power of the DOOM slayer and constant flow of gameplay provided by the extra lives pickups.  

As-of launch the game's multiplayer "Battlemode" feels lacking in both balance and gameplay depth.  It's a 1v2 with a slayer versus two player-controlled demons with 5 to choose from.  I quickly learned that using lock-on burst in conjunction with the super shotgun quickly kills demons with little to no counterplay on the receiving end. I hope to see better balance of the rocket launcher in the game's future.  With the current lack of gamemodes '2016s base multiplayer experience was much more appealing and balanced in my opinion.

[b]5/27/2020 EDIT:[/b]  ID software has done a good job with some of the recent patches which nerfs the slayers effectiveness but still retains a balance for both sides.  However there are several fundamental strategies that the slayer can use with no counterplay options from the demons. 

Slayers can spend most of the match in the air with jump pads that have no cooldown and offer no counterplay.  The majority of demons are at a disadvantage when a slayer uses a jump pad as the slayer is too high to receive damage from most high-damaging attacks which can be abused indefinitely since jump-pads do not de-activate.  (some maps have jump pads that lead directly onto another jump pad) 

The Chaingun shield can solo a mancubus at point blank range and the only counter is using hazard zone whose cooldown is far greater than the shield (7/13/2020 EDIT: The chaingun shield now properly doesn't shield the player from behind in battlemode and while it no longer de-activates the shield when the slayer is in a hazard zone it still deals damage as it did before leaving some room for counter-play)

The speed of quick-swapping weapons could use some tweaking, slayers can kill player-controlled demons in only 5 seconds.

Overall, the fun I had GREATLY outweighed some of the missteps in this incredible game, can't wait to see what new content ID software has in-mind for the game.  RIP AND TEAR!

For the Doom fans out there, this game is for you. For the fast pace shooter crowd, this game is for you. For the faint of heart, this game will challenge you and push you to the limit of your first person shooter skills.

Graphically the game is breathe taking, a significant improvement of details on the enemies compared to Doom 2016. Overall scenery is just flat out incredible. The "arena-style" battles are similar to Doom 2016, but more intense. The upgrade system is there, yet ammo is more scarce. Not to worry though as there are many other balances that help you out along the way.

Part of me felt the game was an overkill, so many new monsters, many of the puzzles were just plain insanity. But the new monsters, and weapons, are amazing and are some of the hardest I have ever faced. I've been gaming for 25 years mind you. 

The plot seemed to take a bit to get started, but was definitely there and overall was great. The boss battles were extreme and usually resulted in low health on my part. Standing still was not an option, the enemies will always find you.

I recommend this game strongly to any Doom fan out there, to any first person shooter fan out there. System resource usage seemed to be quite high, with everything maxxed I was running 7.6 GB of Video RAM. But again, it is beautiful!

The gameplay in this game is fastpased and fun and makes you feel like you are always your on your feet. As you progress through the game I would advise to start on Hurt me Plenty then to change it to Ultra Violence so that you can master the basics before moving up the difficulty. The only things I disliked about the game is occasionally getting Gang banged to the corner by a couple of demons and how it takes a little bit to understand whats going on in the story. I thing the game will improve and I cant wait for a dlc. I would give it 9.5/10 highly recommend.

Doom 2016 is an amazing game, i've completed it 3 and a half times, which is amazing for me because I very rarely play games more than once.

WHAT I LIKED

The levels look beautiful.
The chain hook on the super shotgun is amazing.
Having a dash makes so much sense.
The freeze grenade is super useful in most combat encounters.

WHAT I DON'T LIKE

The levels are boring. Seriously they look amazing but all you do is go from battle arena to battle arena. Remember Doom 2016 when you had mini encounters in the lava factory level, or being on top of that massive crane, jumping and shooting imps, moments like that are gone. You go into a battle arena, fight, go to next battle arena, fight, rinse repeat. It's so uninspired.

Why are weapon, keys, health, armour etc so cartoony? I get they were going for a retro feel, but it just doesn't mesh with the level design being semi-realistic. In Doom 2016 it was so exciting physically picking up the weapons and keys you get.

The combat system. On paper a chess battle sounds good but in practice its so boring. Oh look, the floaty eye monster, swap to shotgun, fire grenade in mouth, execute. Oh look, spider enemy, snipe turret off, freeze, mini gun, execute. Why have they strong armed people to play this way? It's like they're bothered that people like to use a certain amount of weapons that they like.

Going on from the last point, the ammo system is terrible. Every gun has so little ammo you spend 90% of the game looking for squishy enemies to chainsaw, otherwise the combat becomes almost impossible. 

The mini bosses, they fucking suck. The doom slayer, you stand there with a super shotgun, wait for him to flash green, shoot, run out of ammo, search for spawned squishy enemy, chainsaw, rinse repeat. Doom robot thingy, shoot with plasma rifle until shield goes down, then shoot with everything else until you run out of ammo and have to search for squishy enemy to chainsaw.

Why when a game is about constantly moving did they introduce a purple slime that slows you down and makes you unable to jump. It doesn't add anything to the gameplay, it just makes it frustrating.

Why is there a battlepass? It's a game that the majority of people are coming for the single player, it seems like such a bizzare addition. Why do I want a custom skin when the game is played in first person?

LAST THOUGHTS

The game feels like what happened with Shadow Warrior to Shadow Warrior 2, or Wolfenstein The New Order to Wolfenstein The New Colossus. It's like the devs don't realise what made the first games loved.

If you want a game that Doom Eternal should have been like look at Ultrakill demo on steam. It's everything this piece of shit should have been.

I don't normally do reviews like this, but it's such a let down I had to let people know, don't waste your money.

TL:DR: They don't know what made Doom 2016 so good, give it a miss.
