This is not a review, just a personal opinion.

Doom Eternal is amazing, graphically and gameplay-wise. Glad they bumped up the AI, they actually pose a threat now, not just target practice, even the fodder if they managed to gang up on you (freaking totems xD). 

The only thing that disappoints me is that you don't really have much to do after you finish the story, found all the secrets and collectibles (and if you're like me, you probably did all of this by the time you finished the game); besides waiting for the expansions. Sure you can try higher difficulties if you're a masochist, that's fun too.

Sadly they took out what was fun in the multiplayer, like the different modes you could play, now there's just 1 v 2 mode, 1 Slayer vs 2 Demons, which is.. meh, not that I managed to get in a lobby, for me at least, it was empty, barely managed to find one guy who was like 100 levels over me (don't know if levels count in multiplayer - besides what cosmetics you unlocked). 9/10, A Bloody Masterpiece

I was really skeptical of Doom Eternal when it first came out, especially as I watched Byte, the world record holder of Doom 2016 100% speedrun spending hours struggling to adjust to Eternal's new combat system. At that time, it seemed to me that this game overwhelms players with mechanics: dash, flame belch, bloodpunch, two kinds of grenades, and crucible. Players not only have to keep track of these cooldowns and resources, but also manage demon weakpoints at the same time. On top of the seemingly over-complicated combat system, Eternal's cartoonish color, UI design, bugs (such as swimming in air, weird Marauder behavior and BFG crash), retcons, and cutscenes tailored for weak systems make me dislike the game more and more. Before buying and playing the game, I thought Eternal is simply made up of unnecessary additions that force a playstyle upon players and take the depth, freedom and creativity of its 2016 predecessor away.

I couldn't be more wrong.

A few hours in after purchase, I was thoroughly hooked and invested in this sequel. While some of the criticisms above do hold up, and it is kind of a shame that you cannot beat the game in your own way(for example, with only super shotgun), the incredible experience Eternal creates outweighs the downsides by a mile. First, the graphics and animations are fantastic. Demons are extremely lively and expressive, not to mention their decaying flesh as you pump damage into them. Weapon mods are also very well balanced; they all have their distinctive purposes that serve different situations. And just like 2016, the little details and secrets really show the effort, passion and care the devs put into their work. Lastly, it turns out that the new combat system isn't all that overwhelming. Once you get the hang of the timing and usage, everything starts to fall into place, like a perfect, metallic symphony of chaos, rage, and blood. Doom 2016 might be a more polished and contained experience, but Doom Eternal is in no doubt a cathartic mayhem that challenges you to embody the Slayer. 

TLDR: Don't be a cloud player like me, play games to actually experience for yourself.
Absolute masterpiece and props to the team for creating a flawless game <3

DOOM Eternal is a very difficult game to review. First and foremost I want to say that it is worth your money, no doubt about that. I sincerely recommend the game to anyone who likes fast pace action and never-ending sheer brutality (against demons that is :] ). The game takes the concept of weapon modifications from DOOM 2016 and expands it to a point where you can build intricate combos to desimate enemies quickly and effectively. The game also gives you the same opportunities to upgrade health, armour, and ammo. I will talk about ammo later...
The level designs I think is where the game excels. Many players critisized Eternal for having too much platforming, when I see this as a way to show the amazingly designed atmospheric levels. As an artist, every moment in eternal is like a hyper-realistic painting. The art direction and 3D modeling team has my eternal respect for achieving this monumental task. (pun intended >:] ). This being said, I have to mention mobility. The games controls are fantastic for combat... and that's it. Platforming does have an element of rage to it in the later stages in the game where I wasted many minutes trying to nail a few jumps, totally breaking the constant adrenaline the game has you on during fights. This extra difficulty is due to the fact that the controls work poorly outside of combat scenarios. This being said, the fights are very well structured, with enemies appearing in waves from easiest to hardest, and sometimes a mixture of both which results in the danger on the demons being similar to that of an opponent in chess. You can't just prioritze the big strong demons over all the lesser ones because those will slowly chip away at your health. This is a virtue rather than a curse because it keeps combat engaging throughout the whole game. This being said, it is time to discuss the games biggest flaw... the Marauder. I hate the marauder, I also love it. To elaborate; the marauder is the best mini-boss enemy in the whole doom saga, but it is the worst enemy in Eternal. He gets introduced to you in a magnificent 1v1 duel at the midpoint of the game, and in a few small encounters afterwards. BUT... then he gets thrown into big fights. This is awful. The marauder is an enemy that spins the DOOM concept on its head, having you actually care for timing your shots and keep a strategic distance from him at all times. You can NOT use your trump cards like the BFG or the Crucible, you are forced to fight him properly and if you do not wait for him to lower his guard it is impossible to make ANY damage at all. Like I said, this works well on individual encounters, but as you can imagine works absolutely horribly in big fights. You have to wilfully shift your focus on him and try your best to ignore all the other enemies at the same time. It totally breaks the DOOM "dance" as some call it, and makes fights tediously challenging rather than entretainingly challenging. I think the lategame would be a million times better if they removed the marauder from big fights completely. This problem also combines with the games second biggest flaw: ammo scarcity. Now I know that the game has less ammo to force you to use the chainsaw in the way that it is intended, but they went so overkill with this concept that you eventually run out of fuel too. You can imagine how bad it is to fight the marauder with almost no ammo. You either land every shot perfectly, or you die again. Then you will spawn a few moments earlier with the same amount of ammo as last time and the cycle repeats until you manage to beat him under these poor conditions. This happened to me multiple times during my playthroughs and it was enfuriating. Of course, you could just say "you are bad at the game", and if it were a fair fight i'd agree. But this scenario make fights significantly skewed against the player.
Now that I've gotten the problems out of the way, i'd like to end this review by stating that DOOM eternal is nothing short of a masterpiece of modern shooters. The combat design and freedom given to the player is unmatched by any other game I've ever played. Despite its numerous flaws, I know that nothing in this world is perfect... and thus I still urge you to try Eternal out.

DOOM Eternal gets a 9/10 from me.
Thank you for reading! ;]

[i]Would give this a mixed review if possible[/i]
TL:DR - Not as fun a game anymore, a lot of annoyances and downgrades from Doom 2016. Only buy at -50% off or more.

- Glory kills are terrible and so much worse than 2016
- Ammo is shared between some guns and is sparse
- Enemies can CC and stunlock you
- Game is harder than it needs to be on the earlier levels
- So. much. parkour. It doesn't belong here and is just an annoyance
- Too many upgrade currencies and menus get overwhelming
- Bad UI makes knowing when things are off cooldown harder than it needs to be
- Forced to use weapons you don't want to on a lot of enemies, like a rock paper scissors
- No more normal multiplayer or snapmap from 2016, replaced by a mediocre battlemode
- Has a battlepass system

Although I do have a lot of complaints for the game, I do enjoy parts of it and they got some things right:

- Good soundtrack as always
- Really well optimised, can run on almost ultra at 144 fps which a lot of games can't really do. No fps stutters or crashes
- Graphics look pretty good
- They added a more prevalent story into this one, although no one plays this for the story
- When in combat and I actually have ammo, it's really fun most of the time
- The game has some customization with skins and such, if you are into that (although they're not serious at all)

The narrative isn't great, but it's fun with some cool moments.  The music is not to be missed.  One of the most well matched OSTs I've seen in a game.  The way the score matches the pace and feel of the gameplay is uncanny.  Also the set-pieces feel like you're wandering about in various metal album covers.  If you liked Doom 2016's gameplay, Eternal makes some very engaging developments on those mechanics.  More punishment for standing still, more rewards for moving, and a lot of sweet new mechanics that are fun to practice and rewarding to master.  They also really make you switch weapons constantly.  As a result you really learn which weapon is best against which enemies, which you need to know for higher difficulty levels.   There's some event-based content you can play for new skins that's pretty good too.  The textures and animation are stunning.  I did prefer the mood and tone of 2016 over Eternal.  All things considered, its a ton of fun and a worthy addition to the franchise.

Doom Eternal makes Doom 2016 look like a student project.  Everything is far more polished - controls are tighter, soundtrack is surprisingly good, graphics and environments are breathtaking, and the story is nicely fleshed out.  You will die a lot.  Keep slaying - with 60% strategy and 40% luck you'll make it.

Ammo and other resources are far less plentiful than the previous game, requiring a dependency on the chainsaw and the new flamethrower in order to survive.  You ditched your infinite ammo pistol too, for some unknown reason (seriously, if something had infinite ammo, why wouldn't you keep it?).

One mind-blowing aspect of this game is: you can destroy some furniture just by touching it, but you can't break any glass with the exception of one glass door.  That's right, the Doom Slayer can punch through a wall but can't break glass. (MEME time?)  I would have thought, with Red Faction setting the bar for destructible environments, that other games would have gotten the hint - especially games like this where it would make complete sense. Sadly that just isn't the case.  Seriously if the demons had walled themselves up in a glass fortress, there wouldn't even be a game - the slayer would never be able to get in.

Imps.  Get used to clearing out a room and concentrating on anything (or the last remaining demon) and having an imp attacking from behind.  They seemingly just pop right behind you just to irritate you.

The game is also a bit more hokey than Doom 2016.  Adding 1-Ups and a comically animated wall climbing mechanism that makes you feel like the devs played a lot of Darksiders when they were creating this.  Some of this stuff sadly takes away from the immersion aspect of things.

There are also some balancing issues, namely with the Marauder.  This demon is final-boss-of-any-video-game-ever level.  Pure god-tier.  It's never alone, it constantly spawns these golden wolf-dog spirit things that munch on you, and it blocks everything that you do.  There's a little video showing you how to take it out - problem is that the marauder never moves slow enough for that video to mean anything at all.  Oh, and it's resistant to things like the BFG.  The only chance that you have to kill it is to throw everything explosive that you have at it repeatedly and hope the splash-damage ends up killing it.  Strategy simply does not work, speed simply does not work, skill simply does not work.

Minus these shortcomings - this is an amazing game and one that you absolutely need to play if you're a fan of the run-and-gun genre.

Doom: Eternal is an improvement over it's already solid, predecessor, in every way. Even though Doom (2016) had some of the best gunplay of any FPS game, my biggest critique of the game was its bland level design. Doom: Eternal took this issue, and created something amazing. The level designs in Doom: Eternal are a breath of fresh air. No longer are you confined to the generic space stations of Mars, or the two-tone colored hell levels. Doom: Eternal brings you to colorful locations of a hell-raised earth, Gothic castles, arctic fortresses, and the list goes on. 

Along with some incredible new locations you'll get to visit, the gunplay in this game has improved upon the already perfect gunplay from Doom (2016). You have more weapons and abilities at your disposal, your chainsaw has a refresh rate, so you'll always have the opportunity to rush in and rip some enemies apart for ammo when you find yourself running short, and the combat feels more fluid than ever.

The final cherry on top is the lore you'll find in this game if you take the time to read all the data logs. There's some very interesting story and details that you won't want to miss out on if you care about the story of Doom: Eternal. The developers have put a lot of heart into creating this game into a living, breathing world. A world that you, as the Doom Slayer, will liberate from this damned hell invasion. 

Doom: Eternal is one of the best FPS games I've ever played, and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a top-tier shooter with unique locations, an interesting story, and solid gunplay.

I bought this game because of all the hype and the ratings. My experience with this game has now led me to believe the hype and ratings are misleading. They're just another type of stealthy marketing in a now fully capitalistic world that includes "reporters" and "influencers" as paid and willing actors. Anyways, here's why I don't like this game.

This game has so many puzzles that it ruins all of the action. Doom's history indicates that the original creator didn't want to slow down the game by making the players read lore. This latest version slows the players down with puzzles instead of lore. 

Imagine this: You're tearing through demons, building up skill, listening to rocking music. You're on a roll and you're loving the fast pace. Suddenly, after you've defeated all the enemies in the area, you don't know where to go. You look at the map and it looks like you need to execute a complicated series of air jump maneuvers in a perfect sequence. If you fail any part of the jump sequence, you die and have to start all over again. You're now stuck in a Groundhog Day type loop until you successfully complete the entire sequence. All the health benefits, extra lives you accumulated are lost. Ok, it happens. Some players hold on to health and extra lives until the end of the game anyways and don't enjoy the game as the developers intended. I get it. But, look at the other side: all of that rush you got from tearing through the demons while listening to metal is now gone. Your eyes are tired, your fingers and wrist are overworked. The only reward for all of that "enforced grinding" is that you crossed the artificial hurdle put in place by developers who want to make you play the game in a certain enforced way. 

Ok, anyways, you start playing again and it gets good again. You're defeating enemies and rocking out to music, again. And, suddenly, one more platforming puzzle for you to do. The platforming puzzle is a part of the main game. It's not for an extra mission or for some hidden trophy for the completionists. This whole FPS, puzzle, FPS, puzzle, ... business is repeated for as long as I played the game.

I have encountered enough of these to give up on this game. I have spent many hours spread out over weeks trying to finish one puzzle. I spent more hours solving the puzzle that actually playing the FPS part. These puzzles don't become easy with practice or with more command of the keys. While puzzles do improve your jumping skills a tiny bit, the puzzles become harder too. 

Don't get me wrong. Puzzle games have their place and people love them. But Doom doesn't market itself as a puzzle game, it markets itself as an FPS game. But, this Doom game is 50% puzzle and 50% FPS. All the glowing reviews conveniently skip this key detail, which is why I feel the reviews are all fake/paid. Any solid FPS reviewer who has actually played the game for a decent amount of time would at least mention this very important aspect of gameplay. 

If you want to play an FPS game that's frequently punctuated by puzzle-grinding, this is the game for you. If you don't like the puzzles in an FPS game, I think you'll end up abandoning this game midway.

A fantastic continuation of DOOM 2016, DOOM Eternal is a fast paced first person shooter that is all about mobility, ammo management, and killing demons in a gory and brutal fashion. The story and campaign is linear although there is a good amount of exploration in terms of finding secrets and collectibles, which admittedly is very easy especially if you upgrade your suit to mark them on your map. There is plenty of combat to be had, and the game relies a lot on the arena style combat of DOOM 2016, but has also added a sprinkling of enemies through out the level so you have some things to shoot on the way to the next arena battle. The gun play and weapons of DOOM Eternal are much the same as DOOM 2016, although many of the weapons that were useless in 2016 have been buffed, as well as mods that weren't used that much in 2016. However you'll quickly fall into preferring certain mods and certain weapons over others, especially since weapons in this game still share ammo with other guns. For instance once I got the chaingun I quickly stopped using the heavy cannon unless it was for situational things.

As for the story itself its fairly enjoyable, they did a fair bit more world building in this game than they have in the other DOOM games and has confirmed some fan theories related to the Doom Slayer, and a lot of the environmental design lays into this, the design that is quite phenomenal, as I often stopped just to observe the world that id has crafted, with areas such as hell being more hellish than the prior games. The graphics are also fairly good, although I wasn't running them at the highest settings, with effects and sound design being on point. The game is also fairly lengthy, taking me 15 hours to complete with me going after all of the secrets and most of the challenges.

The game also definitely tries to be the DOOM 2 to DOOM 1 of the newest iterations of DOOM, in that it ups the ante, especially in terms of number of enemies and difficulty. I've played both this game and DOOM 2016 on ultra violence and felt that I was dying more often and struggling more in Eternal than 2016. This is both because of there being more enemies, being more enemy variety, and most importantly, because the AI of the demons in this game is much more aggressive than 2016. They actively will try to swarm you, jump up and down ledges to come after you, and many will try to get into melee range with you while others stay in the back shooting you with projectiles. This is overall good and gives a great challenge but it does often feel a bit overwhelming.

My only concerns with the game is how they implemented ammo management, particularly in the fact that weapons in this game have very small ammo capacity, and the only ways to get ammo is to either pick it up off the ground, blow up barrels with the right armor upgrade, and, the most common way, using the chainsaw. In DOOM Eternal you'll always regenerate at least one fuel for the chainsaw meaning you can use it fairly regularly on weak enemies to get a steady stream of ammo, and because weak enemies such as zombies will keep spawning in arenas while the stronger demons are still alive, you'll usually have a steady stream of ammunition. While this isn't too much of an issue, this does get rather tedious, and I feel as though they want you to use the chainsaw too much and a high ammo capacity would've been more appreciated to keep the flow of combat going. Another issue I personally have is that the default punch does 0 damage unless you charge it up to be a blood punch, and my final issue with the game is the Marauder enemy, who I always groaned at when I saw him appear, as they are very time consuming to kill.

Overall though, if you love DOOM games, Eternal is an excellent addition to the franchise and a wonderful challenge to get through if you love fast paced FPS games.

[h1]Doom: Eternal is easily the best game in the entire series.[/h1] 

Especially if you're already a big fan. I myself, have been playing these games since the release of Doom 3. Which got me heavily into the series, and simultaneously into survival horror. However, if it wasn't already obvious, these modern games go back to their roots. Non-stop demon slaying action, hidden collectibles, power ups, and secrets. Intense battles and a somewhat interesting plot.

If I truly had to nitpick on some things it would be the following:
- [b]Marauders, one of the new enemies introduced in the game, are easily the most out of place and annoying baddies to have to battle.[/b] As they block all of your attacks and won't let you hit them until they open themselves up for attack. In a game where you're constantly moving around managing other monsters with different behaviors, its a real huge annoyance to have a virtually invincible enemiy harass you at the same time. The only defense is to keep moving away from him, while you manage the other enemies. Whats worse is that one of the timed challenges in the later maps features a Marauder that was insanely frustrating to beat. Since the monsters attack pattern is inconsistent, and the games only advice is to keep him at "medium range". Eventually after some luck and determination, I beat the challenge. Some people might not have the patience for this. However, IMO the game was too fun to not push through and beat every challenge I faced.
- [b]The game seems pretty buggy, and has crashed on me several times after beating crucial story points.[/b] That said upon restarting the game again, I started exactly where I left off. Or at least the closest possible checkpoint. So no progress was lost any time this happened. The games cheat codes that you unlock as you progress through the story, also seem to cause weird bugs. If you turn them on, you won't be able to get the Empyrean key from the Slayer Rooms after you beat them. I had to do the same challenge at least twice, restart the game, and then turn the cheats on then back off again. After another reload of the game, I was able to get the key just fine.
-[b]I found the ending to be kinda underwhelming[/b] [spoiler]After you defeat the Icon of Sin, it just kinda ends on a corny line and thats it. No real resolution, especially when everything implies that Dr. Hayden might be up to something. And that VEGA might actually be assosciated with the Makyrs somehow. Who's to say Hayden isn't the Makyr that gave Doomguy his speed and strength. All kinds of questions unanswered, but maybe that's the point?[/spoiler]

Overall the gameplay is fun, intuitive, and downright addicting. The replayability is pretty high, especially on higher difficulties if you like that sort of challenge. I might even consider giving it a try after writing this review.

And lets not forget Mick Gordon and the heavy metal symphony that is the soundtrack. I can't stop listening to it I'm obsessed with tracks like 'Meathook', 'The Only Thing They Fear Is You', and 'Super Gore Nest'. Check them all out, plenty of good quality releases out on YouTube. At least until they officially release the soundtrack.

During the summer sale, I bought Doom 2016 at an extremely good rate, played through it, and loved it.  Before the sale was up, I decided that I would check out Doom Eternal while it was also on sale.  So, I started it up to play it, but having played Doom 2016 and Eternal back to back really highlighted some of the annoying changes.  

With Doom 2016 as my baseline, there was a noticeable decrease in quality nigh across the board:
- The animations seemed lazier
- The glory kills had less variation
- The user interface was overly simplified and unhelpful
- The texture quality was greatly reduced
- Rune trials just turned into touchable runes
- Default keymapping is annoying and unintuitive
- Monster AI appears to be diminished, but more aggressive
- Gauss cannon removed from the game in lieu of Ballista
- Equipment animations dropped in lieu of shoulder fired grenade launcher/flame squirt gun.
- Emphasis on rechargeable chainsaw kills due to ammo scarcity.
- Ammo drops themselves are 2D color coded squares on the ground.
- Story driven single player was revised to mindless robot speaking in my ear.

These are the things I noticed in the first hour and a half of the game that I didn't like about it and I wasn't about to spend another 15 hours growing this list.  It's possible that the game improves given my extremely limited time playing it.  But, from what I saw, it wasn't fun and I've no desire to continue.  Maybe it isn't fair to compare it with such a good game released in the past.  But it exacerbated the annoyance I had with it when playing them back to back.

Plus, this bad review doesn't even include all the crazy business decisions Bethesda has made over the last couple years.
Better than DOOM 2016 in every way and probably the best single player FPS to date!

DOOM Eternal Review

Four years after the release of the awesome Doom 2016 comes the next chapter in the saga called Doom Eternal. How does it compare to the previous game? Let’s find out.

The story, which is kind of a remake of Doom 2’s plot, is simple: Doomguy/Doom Slayer has returned to lay waste to Hell’s armies who have invaded Earth. In other words, this is id Software’s version of the Book of Revelations.

Gameplay remains as great as ever with some new abilities to help you rip and tear through your enemies such as ice grenades that freezes enemies, flamethrowers that’ll get you more armor from burning enemies, and a badass laser sword (which sadly you won’t get until the end of the game) that takes out even powerful enemies in one slice. You also get the ability to climb walls and even dash, both on the ground and in the air.

As with the past Doom games, there are numerous collectibles to find such as floppy disks that enable cheat codes, toys, and albums each containing one song from id Software’s past titles like Doom II, Quake and surprisingly even Commander Keen. There are also upgrades to find such as Sentinel Crystals which expands your health, armor and ammo, Sentinel Batteries that unlock items in your Doom Fortress, Mods for your weapons and Praetor Tokens to upgrade your gear, abilities and maps. Finding these collectibles and upgrades feels a lot easier in Doom Eternal than its predecessor as I always had difficulty locating all the secrets.

The game’s difficulty is more challenging than ever, even on normal difficulty. As you progress, you will be up against super tough demons that will make it difficult for you to focus while you dodge attacks from nearby enemies. So you'd better know what you're doing or you'll be so filled with rage, that you’ll wind up playing Rage. (Little id Software humour for y’all)

Mick Gordon who composed the music for Doom 2016 (as well as one my favourite fighting games Killer Instinct 2013) returns with another badass soundtrack. The music gives off vibes of hopelessness, dread and makes you feel like you’re in a hellish nightmare. Good job, Mr. Gordon!

Of course the game isn’t without its faults. Weak points. Why? Where’s the honour of that? When I played Doom 2016, slaying demons was fun. In Doom Eternal? Well, to get rid of the Mancubus quickly, you should take out their arm cannons. Cacodemons? A sticky bomb into their mouth for a quick glory kill. Revenants? Take out its rocket launchers. I can go on, but I find it difficult to focus on enemy weak spots while a horde of demons are trying to gang up on me.

And there’s the inclusion of extra lives. I don’t know how I feel about extra lives since I always liked the challenge of trying to fend off again a huge wave of demons with one life no matter how frustrating the experience can be. On one hand, they seems like an attempt to cater to casuals IMO. On the other, they do come in handy if you’re trying to get past each level, especially, with those pesky Marauders and the final two bosses. Less said about my experience with them, the better.

And finally, there’s one big gripe I have with this game and I’m sure this isn’t the only Bethesda game that’s having this issue. You can’t play access the game unless you sign up for a Bethesda dot net account or bypass the login screen by briefly unplugging your internet. Ugh... Why? No seriously, Bethesda. You're blocking me from playing this awesome game just because I have absolutely no interest in signing up for what should be an optional account? What’s even worse is you can’t even play online multiplayer unless you sign up for one. Which is nonsense, especially with games like Fallout 76 and even Wolfenstein Youngblood. Also, I bought the deluxe edition of this game and so far, I haven’t be able to access the exclusive demon slayer skin or the classic weapon sounds. Do I have to sign up for said account to access these items and the upcoming Year One Pass DLC? That said, this is Bethesda’s online & offline pass. Fix this, Bethesda.

**UPDATE 7/12/2020** I finally caved in and got a Bethesda dot net account and I can confirm that you need one in order to access the Deluxe Edition goodies. I have Wolfenstein Youngblood and it's the same deal. A bad business practice if you ask me because we should be able to get them without creating an account.

That said, as of this writing, I have not played the Battlemode. So I cannot give my thoughts on the online multiplayer modes. But if playing as a Revenant in single player is any indication, it sounds fun.

Oh, and spoiler alert for everyone, Doomguy actually speaks in this game. Not much, but still. Out of character for him if you ask me.

Final thoughts:

Once again, the folks at id Software have hit it out of the park with yet another awesome Doom game that improves from its predecessor. Sure, the game can be tough and you need a Bethesda account to play online & offline (again, unless you briefly unplug your internet). But if you can get pass these issues, Doom Eternal is a great game and a worthy successor to Doom 2016. Buy it.

Now please make a new Doom 2016-style Quake game already, id Software! Or a new Commander Keen game perhaps?

8/10

Pros:

Amazing game with tons of glory violent kills, rage, gore, and heavy metal music, which accompanies it perfectly. :) About 40% of players finished the game, which is a very good indicator by comparison with other games. Took me 25 hours to finish the game. Game is polished and graphics is amazing. Developers created unique scenery from the start to finish. Game tries to tell an interesting story, but not in a way for you to focus attention on it.

Cons:

Difficulty is badly balanced. This is one of those game where you have no time to perfect your skills and attacks with your favourite weapon. You just get bigger guns and bigger monsters. I’ve started game on “Ultra-Violence” (Experienced) difficulty and completed about 75% of game on it. Then game just started to pile more big demons and added Marauder – out of place demon, which I could not kill even with BFG or Crucible and had to counter its attacks in 100-350 millisecond range, which is beyond physical capabilities of some older players (my future in 20 years :), therefore failure of QA team. Usually I would deal with Marauder after wiping other monsters, but developers decided that it is a good idea to spawn other range damage monster when you have to focus on Marauder (mixing requirement to run and stay in place and focus). I lowered difficulty to “Hurt Me Plenty” (Normal). Last boss fight was visually impressive, but poorly done i.e. no strategy just mindless slaughter and more demons. Lowered to “I’AM TOO YOUNG TO DIE” (Easy) difficulty for it, because I could not be bothered. Game would drop you into challenges without refilling the ammo, which could be “resolved” by you choosing to die on purpose.  I think there must be an easier difficulty option, which would allow bigger reaction times and further jump distances, which would allow me to play such games when I will get very old.

[h1]DOOM Eternal[/h1]

[b]Narrative:[/b] 4
[b]Mechanics:[/b] 4
[b]Visuals/Art Style:[/b] 5
[b]Audio/Soundtrack:[/b] 5
[b]Replayability:[/b] 2
[b]Performance:[/b] 5
[b]Overall:[/b] 25/30

[i]DOOM Eternal[/i] is an incredible game that improves on every aspect from its predecessor [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/379720/]DOOM (2016)[/url]. Take control of the Doom Slayer once again and save mankind from the powers of hell as they try to take over Earth. [i]DOOM: Eternal[/i] goes further in depth about the origin of the slayer, the history of the conflict with hell, and more to sink your lore loving teeth into.

The same basic formula from [i]DOOM (2016)[/i] returns: execute glory kills for health, use your chainsaw for ammo, and burn enemies with your flamethrower for armor; but the ability to climb, swing, and dash are all new mobility options to help you survive...and you're going to need it! [i]DOOM Eternal[/i] is HARD. I felt that the entire game was challenging but doable up until the final boss. After failing a boss fight several times in a row, the game does offer you the option to use "Sentinel Armor" which reduces the amount of damage you take, and I had to use it for the finale.

The visuals and audio for [i]DOOM Eternal[/i] are incredible. The graphics and art style are fantastic. The death metal soundtrack alongside the very distinct audio cues in game that help you know when your abilities have refreshed, or which enemies are near you, are a huge help when trying to survive. Plus there are many classic DOOM references, easter eggs, and re-mixed soundtracks to enjoy!

I played the game on Nightmare difficulty and was able to collect all the toys, gun mods, weapon upgrades, etc in a single playthrough. After completing the game, there are additional activities to do such as "Master Levels", which are re-mixed and harder versions of the game's missions, and various multiplayer modes. Personally I felt no desire to try these Master Levels or the multiplayer modes.

[h1]Summary and Target Price Point[/h1]

All of the above, paired with butter smooth and fully optimized performance come together as one of the best games released in 2020. I highly recommend [i]DOOM Eternal[/i] to any fans of first person shooters and single player experiences! Pick this one up at $30 or less and rip and tear through this 25 hour masterpiece.

Check out [url=https://isthereanydeal.com/game/doometernal/info/]this link[/url] to compare price and price history of [i]DOOM Eternal[/i] from your favorite retailers.
This game is incredible, buy it now

There is a very good FPS here somewhere. Unfortunately, it is buried under layer upon layer of useless upgrades and skill trees, forced platforming, and worst of all, the ever-present resource management: ammo, health, and armor are intentionally scarce, and you are forced to use special attacks to refill. To some that may be fun, to me it just makes the whole experience feel incredibly clunky and unnatural, interrupting the flow of the game rather than adding to it. While we are on the subject, the number of special attacks is excessive: chainsaw, flamethrower, glory kills, blood punch... keep it simple will you? It's a Doom game, I came here to blast demons away with a double barreled shotgun, I don't want to have to memorize half a dozen key bindings. Then there's the platforming: I like the idea of double jumps, climbing, dashing, somersaulting. Those are all things which, in moderation, would have been a great addition to the game, but sadly they got carried away, and often you find yourself spending more time jumping than shooting - again, this is a Doom game, I came here to fry hordes of demons with a BFG, not to re-enact Nadia Comaneci's perfect 10 at the Montreal Olympics. Probably as a consequence of this forced platforming, the levels also feel very linear.

The story is also a significant let down: they turned the tech-occult theme of previous Doom games into a sort of dark fantasy mishmash with kings, priests, gothic churches, and similar elements which might have been great in another game, but which simply do not blend at all with the Doom lore. The main character himself is disappointing: in Doom 2016, through some excellent use of environmental storytelling and brief cutscenes of the Slayer punching and smashing his surroundings, you felt like fury incarnate. Here... meh. The storytelling is also subpar: in 2016 you knew who the main villain was within minutes of starting the game, here, I've played the game for seven hours and I'm still not sure who or what I'm trying to find - something to do with some priests?

Overall, Doom Eternal feels bloated and clunky. That said, it is not a terrible game. It is a major step back in the series, and it is also a major disappointment, given how much potential was wasted due to poor game mechanics, but it is definitely not all bad. There are some enjoyable moments here and there: when the fighting picks up and you don't immediately run out of ammo, it can be entertaining. Just don't buy it at full price.

---

Addendum: I forced myself to finish the game. I only did the campaign because I don't care for multiplayer. I stand by what I wrote: when you are in the thick of the fight it can be entertaining, and once you get the hang of it you even stop running out of ammo (protip: dash, dash, chainsaw), but the glaring issues I saw in my first hours of play only got worse.

The platforming and puzzles became so annoying I almost quit several times. I do not know how much time overall I spent jumping around like a frog, or frustratedly looking in every direction, searching for a climbing wall or a horizontal bar that might get me to the next cluster of demons, but it definitely felt like hours, and it probably was. All that time spent not shooting anything and engaged in activities which would have been better suited to a Mario game, was time in which Doom Eternal was failing utterly at its main purpose: being a first person [b] shooter [/b].

Then there's the whole "you must only play the way we want" attitude. This was already evident in the forced chainsaw-flamethrower-ice bomb mechanics, but it became even more annoying with the marauders: they're really not that difficult to kill, they're just... boring: there is a certain distance you have to keep, and there is only a specific time window during which they are vulnerable to your attacks. There is absolutely no room for doing things any way other than what the developers decided. And don't even get me started on the Khan Maykr. Once again, the experience feels incredibly mechanical and artificial.

The story and the atmosphere... eh. More priests, more fantasy environments, some clichés about [spoiler] angels being just as bad as demons [/spoiler]. It's all a convoluted mess. Where Doom 2016 was almost lovecraftian in hinting at the unseen and the unspeakable ("They promised me so much"), this was in-your-face and comic book-ish, and I cringed every time the UAC hologram talked. Even the "evil priests" sound petulant rather than scary, definitely not something you would expect from literal Hell. All this nonsense is canon in the same way that midichlorians are canon: it simply does not fit with the rest of the story, it severely hinders suspension of disbelief, and I hope it will be quietly ignored in future games. Speaking of disbelief: what's with "empowered demons" who "killed another player"? This is a single player game, I don't want to know about other players, this has to be the most immersion-killing thing I've seen in a game! What were they thinking?

To conclude: several times while playing Doom Eternal I had the distinct feeling that, in some posh executive's office at id/Bethesda, some of the suits decided that rather than improving upon the previous game, the surest way to sell more copies would be to expand the target market by including gameplay elements which may attract people new to the franchise or even to the genre. Unfortunately, the end result is a Frankenstein monster of a game which tries to be too many things at once, and fails to deliver the kind of experience a lot of older fans have come to expect. There are still moments of absolute brilliance, namely when you are given lots of guns and lots of very angry, very mobile targets, but that just adds to my disappointment, because if this game had just tried to be Doom, instead of Doom Raider or Assassin's Doom, it could have been really good.

Good game when it works. However, I've crashed to desktop at least 8 times already. Listening to voice logs at the ARC Campus is a guaranteed crash to desk top. Additionally, I went to replay a mission to complete the slayer gate, but the game crashed as soon as I beat the gate. No progress was saved. This happened on the Super Gore Nest level which means in order to get the key for the gate, I need to play almost the entire mission again. The threat of the game crashing again saps any fun from the experience. Combine this with glitched invincible enemies, and I struggle to justify the $60 price tag. This is of course without going into any issues I may have with the design of the game itself. Wait for a sale or until the serious bugs or worked out, maybe both.
 
P.S.  I went back and did the Gore Nest mission slayer gate again and it crashed exactly the same. Erasing my progress again. This feels like Deadly Premonition, not a $60 AAA game. Definitely wait for a sale and for the major glitches to be worked out. I would request a refund if I didn't happen to get the game on sale.

I don't understand the allure of this game as an shooter, and I'm genuinely sad that this did not live up to the amount of hype it's received since the pandemic began. I tried for over a dozen hours to like this game, but honestly I hate it.

The shooting reminds me of playing with a bow and arrow back in the Elder Scrolls Oblivion. There's no weight to the shots and no sense of feedback to the bullets registering on enemies. The graphics are pretty, if you like that sort of thing I guess. It's gratifying to see chunks of the enemy's flesh being blown off, but that doesn't really amount to jack shit if they aren't being affected by what I am doing to them. When I empty a mag into a generic human enemy that's literally reduced to a skeleton from my attack but he still somehow manages to close the gap and soul-punch me into a wall before mugging me, that doesn't encourage me to try harder next time. 

I read a lot about how this game implements 'strategy' and that 'you have to think your way through each fight' or some rubbish like that.

No, it appears that the 'strategy' touted in all of the reviews and blurbs seem to boil down to "When you see X enemy use Y weapon. If you don't have Y weapon ammo then strafe like a kit in a hurricane until you pick up or earn ammo resources and then cheese the enemy".  When I first read this I was excited because I thought from the sound of that, that this game would encourage you to experiment and explore different approaches. But alas, it's more like The Arkham Series' melee combat but with extra steps and you routinely just run out of the tools you need to deal with something in front of you that otherwise would be a cakewalk if you somehow knew that the enemy was going to show up at that part of the mission- oh wait, when you replay the mission that's exactly the case...

Which leads me to the worst part of the game that made me realize I don't want to play it anymore. It's repetitive to the point of boredom in a way I haven't experienced since the previous console generation.

And I get it. I doubt anyone will read this. The developers are millionaires. They have my money and I am in the minority on this take, but I am just very disappointed with how much of a letdown this game was. When the 'strategy' of each gunfight boils down to very predictable 'rock paper scissors' equations that punish you when you don't play by their rules, it takes away a lot of the experimentation from a game like this. Combine that with the fact that the missions are soooo long and it just feels like I'm doing chores to get to the end of a mission for the chance to replay said mission over again in such a way that I know exactly what to expect. So I can do exactly the same sequence of weapon rationing. So I can fight the same order of enemies.... Etc, Etc.

I don't know what else I could say without repeating myself. As a shooter this game blows, you either kill things instantly by exploiting their weakness or you get biffed by their damage sponge haymakers. The replayability is there maybe once or twice but after you know what to expect the formula is impossible not to see. Also, maybe I'm the only one who thinks this, but can we have one "dash mechanic" shooter where instead of just hitting shift and then WASD you can just double-tap one of the WASD inputs to juke in the direction you double tap. I don't know if I'm getting too old for this or what but I felt like I playing piano while trying to juke in mid air, switch to the insta-gib weapon, and also freeze another enemy in place with my shoulder mounted grenade launcher. On paper that sounds like a fun sequence, in practice though I had at least two other different enemy types that were also trying to brute force me at once and it just felt more frustrating than intense.

Changing this review after the Denuvo Anti Cheat debacle. ID/Bethesda actually listened to peoples' feedback and removed the DAC requirement. Good on them!

Doom Eternal is a great follow-up to Doom 2016. It's faster and has more action. The gunplay is satisfying and cannon fodder is plenty. It's got the grandiose, over-the-top weapons, battles and monsters and it's all amazing.

It has a bit of a lighter atmosphere compared to 2016, with some moments being comical (cacodemon grenade animation, zombie glory kill head bash, etc.). While I myself prefer the more grim and dark appearance of 2016, Doom Eternal's look is far from being a deal breaker. It's a beautifully crafted game.

There's three things I'd rather not have in the Doom Eternal: Parkour sections, very limited ammo (you have to use the chainsaw to replenish it constantly) and marauders. All three slow down the game's pace. Other than that, it's a solid entry to the franchise.

THE GOOD:

-Music is great but not 2016 great (just my ""taste"")

-There is a track from Andrew Hulshult ("Goroth" -Quake Champions) hidden as a secret
-Blood Punch is gonna make you nut

-Hell looks ***king amazing

The *kinda* BAD:

-No doom 64 or doom 3 skin
-No Kar En Tuk song with just the vocals :(

After 200 hours I completely recommend people to buy this game only if they have the 60 bucks and want to try something fun as frick and "fast".
Great game!!!

This game is amazing! For all the gents out there playing this, it'll put hair on your balls! It's that good. For anyone who played DOOM 2016, this one is, in my opinion, better. The combat is more thought provoking and you have a greater variety in weapons and enemy types. There is some light platforming which I enjoyed and it doesn't detract from the greatness of the combat system. The music is fucking awesome much like the original's. The graphics are gorgeous and the game is very well optimized. The controls are also pretty good. There isn't much I can say that's bad about this game. The much talked about Marauders are not that big of a deal once you realize how to fight them. Overall, to me this game is way better than the one from 2016 and a must play for any DOOM fan or FPS fan. Definitely give this one a shot.

As someone who has never been a DOOM fan, only played DOOM 2016 through once and never felt the need to touch it again... This game is amazing. DOOM Eternal is ten times faster paced and has combat so satisfying it just keeps drawing me back for more. The real edge this game has is the fact that the better you get and the more you master the systems (of which there are a lot more than in 2016) the more fun it gets. Playing it through once wasn't enough, I then had to test my mastery by beating it on Nightmare difficulty, which then wasn't enough as even though I was slightly bored of some of the levels (mostly early game), I loved the combat so much I still kept getting the itch to play more and this has led me to attempting Ultra-Nightmare which I have yet to complete.

Simply put, the game runs smoothly, has an awesome combat system, extremely tight and responsive controls, and will make you keep coming back for more DOOM.

The main negative reviews I remember from around release were by game 'journalists' who had the main complaints of 'the marauder is too hard' (of course they didn't say that but by looking at their gameplay you can tell that's what the problem for them was) and 'why does it have platforming?'
My response to these is as follows, the marauder is punishing sure, especially on Nightmare, but he is definitely balanced, he can be countered effectively using skill and the right tactics (I mean speedrunners beat him in less than 5 seconds legitimately so he's clearly not too hard) and personally I never died to him even on my first playthrough, you just have to use the right strategies.
In terms of the platforming, is it amazing? No, is it terrible? Also no, as it is responsive and works well. Given this, it's more about what it adds to the game, which is the opportunity for the developers to add large, open and amazing level design which they otherwise wouldn't have been able to put in the game, so I think it overall ends up being a positive, and to really seal the deal, would anyone really rather ride a 30 second elevator or train where you can't control your character to get to a new area than just do a section of platforming which can be mastered and done in far less time? This is not the only example of how it betters the game either, areas can have little wasted space, as in the third level for example after an arena fight you do a 5 second part of platforming and you head back over the top of the arena to drop into the next arena fight quickly, instead of having two far away and totally separate areas that need to be accessed by some kind of walkway if there weren't any platforming elements. The main point is this: it's not the best thing about the game, but it allows the game itself to be so much better than it would have been otherwise, so don't believe the hate, and honestly some sections can be quite fun, especially doing your own parkour by using the meat-hook in combat!

All in all, this game is just great, I haven't bought a 'full price' game in a long time, and even this I got on half price sale, but it was worth every penny and after having played it, I would have paid the real full price for it, and I absolutely intend to get the DLC. So if you love fast combat that has a lot to master in it as well as many ways to improve and feel like more of a badass, grab this game.

In every aspect, this game is a masterpiece. You press start, heavy metal starts blasting, you're given a shotgun, and your only instructions are to push forward into a game that's combat, level design, and music production are well above any modern game's standards.

I've beaten the game since writing this review and the only thing I have to say is step outside of your comfort zone when you choose your difficulty. You can change the difficulty at any point in the game without penalty. My first playthrough was on Ultra-Violence (hard) and I felt that it was the perfect difficulty. I never felt that the game was too easy and I always felt like I needed to be aware of my surroundings and really keep the heavy demons in mind when moving around each arena.

So for me this was Bethesda's last chance to prove themselves. DOOM 2016 is a timeless masterpiece with amazing gameplay that is easy to follow and for the most part makes sense. Eternal is not that.

The game drops you off in the middle of a completely different story line (as if the G-man had you on an interdimensional monorail for 10 years). 
The gameplay is a cheap recreation of the first entry. 
Graphically there is little to no improvement. The addition of HDR actually breaks the game. All Maps and menus become illegible.
The story is all over the place. You feel like you missed an entire game from the first to this one. There are huge story gaps.  The story is also extremely short. If you are not a completionist like me you can probably complete the campaign in less than 5 hours.
Most all boss battles are repetitive and unrewarding. 
Ammo is not plentiful whatsoever. There are many areas where you will become stuck and unable to continue without restarting.
The soundtrack is atrocious compared to the first game. Its basically the same guitar riff the whole game. Plus it doesn't go along with the action.
This whole game is pretty much just $60+ DLC. 

Bethesda completely lost my respect after this one. Fallout is dead to me now, Wolfenstein is completely ruined and now DOOM feels like just another one of their franchises they squeezed all the life out of.

Overall just disappointed. This could have been a good one.
Just buy it

I started my first playthrough about a week ago, i have a fulltime job in an office and this is a great way to release that pent up anger built up by lazy colleagues and annoying customers that ask too many questions. Normally i play games just for the story and it's respective setting, Doom Eternal however, is a different case. Once you start getting used to all the many weapons given to you and the new and improved movement mechanics, you'll understand why this game is worth every penny you pay for it, regardless the price you paid. Unlike every other game with secret rooms, collectibles and extra challenges, i thoroughly enjoyed every last bit of exploration, extra challenge and all of the other side activities presented to you in this game.
Now i'm just speaking from my own point of view of course, but i'm 100% certain in saying that people who will not enjoy this game fall into three categories: 1, highly religious people. 2, parents who are afraid their kids might shoot up a school. 3, pussies.

TL;DR:

BUY THIS GAME. RIP AND TEAR, UNTIL IT IS DONE.

I don't think I've ever done a complete 180 on a game like I have with Doom Eternal. I was so disappointed with my initial experience with Doom Eternal that I returned the game after two hours. I had just replayed Doom 2016, and Eternal was such a poor sequel to that game both in tone and gameplay that I perhaps overreacted. The game seemed needlessly complex and over-designed. The perfect combat loop of Doom 2016 was replaced by extraneous button-pushes and old-school platforming. Fortunately, Doom Eternal went on sale for thirty bucks a couple weeks later, and for that price I decided to give it a try. Once I got over the fact that Doom Eternal was not just more Doom 2016, I started to embrace the game on its own terms and appreciate what it was trying to do.

This is a difficult shooter that expects the player to keep track of many things at once. You have your flame belch, a flame thrower that immolates enemies who then drop armor as you damage them. The chainsaw is your main method of ammo replenishment, rather than the optional tool it was in Doom, and if you don't want to constantly run out of ammo, you have to chainsaw fodder enemies regularly. Glory kills function just like in Doom, but perform two of them and you'll have the option of performing a Blood Punch, a devastating melee attack that can severely weaken powerful monsters. You also have a recharging grenade launcher that can shoot ice grenades, which really comes in handy for crowd control when you're juggling twenty-plus enemies at once. Finally, you have enhanced movement options--in addition to your double jump from Doom, you can now perform two quick dashes as well as grab on to horizontal poles in order to swing from them like Tarzan. Add in the fact that most powerful monsters have damageable parts--you can shoot the rocket launchers off the revenant and the gun hands off the mancubus, for example--you have a game that expects quite a bit from you during a firefight. Initially, it's a little much to handle--the beginning levels throw several tutorials at you, introducing most of your new abilities in a few seconds, and then send you on your merry way to deal with arachnotrons and hell knights--but around the midgame point, you finally start to get into the combat rhythm that Doom Eternal requires of you. This is due to level design improving, as well as your arsenal, while your fingers have finally figured out which buttons to hit during what moment. The supergore nest level was when I finally mastered Doom Eternal, and it's also a wild ride through a hell and guts infested earth city.

Tonally, Eternal is a departure from Doom 2016. Whereas that game seemed to be a mishmash of Doom 3's realistic spaces and horror aesthetic with the more frantic gameplay of Doom 1 and 2, Eternal goes full nostalgia. The enemies possess none of Doom 2016's grindhouse design--they look like updated renders of the original game's cartoons. The whole art style screams Heavy Metal (by which I mean the influential magazine as well as the music genre), and one of Eternal's best gags is that the Doom Slayer can find and collect records from the soundtracks of id's classic games. I don't know if I prefer the tonal changes to the style of Doom 2016, but I like what Eternal does.

So what does Eternal flub? The platforming, mainly. There are many platforming sections which serve as breathers between the combat and little else. Some require decent timing, but I can't think of a decent reason for their inclusion other than old school shooters used to have lots of platforming. Also, the new combat loop works when you are given a big enough arena in which to do battle. Several of the early levels have you in little spaces. When you get stuck in a corner, the Doom Slayer is sort of screwed, since he doesn't have the durability of previous games till later. As far as difficulty is concerned, there is a huge jump from Doom 2016 to Eternal. I played Doom on Ultra-Violence (hard), and that's what I started Eternal on, and I was getting my ass handed to me until I figured out how to play. That difficulty stems from the aforementioned weaker Doom Slayer, as well as the sheer volume of heavy hitting enemies the game thrusts on you. I got used to it, but I don't know if I prefer Eternal's combat to that of Doom's.

If you're a fan of hardcore older shooters, then you'll probably love Eternal, with the caveat that it's not Doom 2016, which was a classic. I don't know if it is a better game that Doom 2016 (I greatly preferred Doom's wink and nod approach to story as opposed to Eternal's obsession with its boring lore), but it's already occupied 18 hours of my time, and I have several levels to go. It also caused me to abandon my playthrough of Titanfall 2, which was pretty good, so I think that speaks to Eternal's quality. So get it if you'd like to indulge in a little ultra violence.

So, I gave in and started playing Doom Eternal yesterday. I bought it on the summer sale even though I waited and wanted to buy it for Switch.

I'm a big fan of Doom 2016, which in my opinion is close to a perfect shooter with its tight game design, shooting, action, movement, level design, visual style and world building. 

So starting Doom Eternal, I am immediately thrown off by how the game does not take it self serious. Characters and enemies act like an Adult Swim comedy cartoon and the sound design only add to that with overly used wet gurgling noises and comedic plops. Visual design is just the hell and demons theme on steroids, and all pickups and the UI are super colorful and arcady. None of the more realistic horror sci-fi stylished mix from previous game.

ALL that being said. I already LOVE the game. I can tell their focus was to make a fun and tight game.
Enemies are more aggressive and you have to move around even more than the previous installment. You have so much movement options with dashes, swinging from handles and the hook.. The weapons feels AMAZING. A great sense of 
power, in not just how much damage they do, but visually with how you see bits of flesh fall of your enemy and the audio feedback from the weapon and the hits. Just wow...

I can't hold a grudge towards this game even though it's not what I hoped for, in terms of what I liked about the 2016 game, but it's just so much fun to play!

What the heck happened? 

The original Doom reboot wasn't necessarily a deep game but the dark story itself was told REALLY well in a wonderfully engaging way that's brilliantly interwoven throughout. Doom Eternal throws all that completely out the window and you're thrown into a... space castle? WHAT? How in the heck did I get in a space castle? WHY am I killing these priests? What are these GIANT FREAKING ROBOTS I AM PUTTING BATTERIES IN. Who is this "Betrayer" and why am I suddenly giving him things I just risked my life to obtain? 

WHO KNOWS, they never really tell you.

There is a MASSIVE gap between the two games that isn't ever really filled and none of it makes any sense or gives you any motivation for what you're doing and that's honestly really disappointing considering how wonderful the first game was. There are clearly components and other narrative pieces within the game that seem part of a larger story but they are not connected in any way almost like it's all been gutted for no apparent reason like a 24-episode season of a tv show where they only show you episodes 13, 18, and 23.

What's even worse is that the game-play itself has some really fun new mechanics and the new parkour and dash functions add some fun variability and paths to get away during encounters. However, these new mechanics are thin candy coating in a hollow shell of very brightly lit linear puzzles. 

For a game that was delayed multiple times they really dropped the ball for no real obvious gain. Absolutely do not buy this game for full price if you are buying it to continue the story.

Virtually every negative problem and critique about DOOM 2016 has been addressed, or is going to be addressed in the future, in this game.

[b]Snapmap has been removed from the game[/b], leaving Eternal to focus on the single-player and the multiplayer components. This was a negative from DOOM 2016 as that game never planned to have mod support, and this was a "replacement" of sorts, containing level blocks that the player could arrange into a makeshift level. It was generally underused and there were only a few bright gems towards the end of the game's life-cycle.

[b]Story DLC has been confirmed and is in the works right now[/b]. The original game had three planned multiplayer DLC packs, the component and the expansion packs were à la Call of Duty. To mitigate fracturing the player-base for multiplayer, they eventually overhauled the progression system and gave you the choice of unlocking the maps and equipment purchased, or making you earn them all over again. Overall, it was not well received in comparison to its single-player component, where fans wanted more from.

[b]Multiplayer has been completely reworked[/b] into an asymmetrical 1v2 multiplayer component where one player controls a fully kitted-out Slayer from the campaign and their objective is to kill the other two demons in the arena before they kill you. The mode requires you to be strategic regardless of the role that you're playing. The Slayer needs to be incredibly skillful, understand the weapons' various strengths and weaknesses, and the map structure and entities in order to succeed. The demons need to cooperate and work together in order to successfully trap the Slayer and overwhelm them The demons have access to various buffs and powerups throughout the match such as spawning heavy demons like the Tyrant (i.e. a cyberdemon), a Doom Hunter, a Baron of Hell etc. At the end of each round, the Slayer and the demons get to choose a powerful buff to use in the next round.

[b]More demons, more Djent, more of everything[/b]. This game has a much bigger scope and allows for more replayability of campaign missions with seasonal content for completing challenges. You can also unlock these emblems, skins, stands, and animations by participating in Eternal's multiplayer component, Battle Mode (1 Slayer vs. 2 demons), as well. Generally, the levels are much longer in length, the campaign itself is longer, there's more in-your-face music, there's a LOT more demons, and a bunch of new weapons and mechanics for the Slayer to traverse the environment with. There are more boss fights in the game which last much longer than DOOM 2016 and later in the game, those bosses show up as regular enemies (although slightly nerfed with regards to health). Also as someone whose purchasing decisions can either be made or swayed by the game's soundtrack, this game includes a best slice of every id Software game's soundtrack such as Quad Machine from Quake 2, Commander Keen, Wolfenstein 3D, and the classic Doom games (even DOOM 64!) 

[b]This is a much more difficult game than DOOM 2016[/b], and honestly it benefits a lot from it. In 2016, you could literally go through the entire game with a super shotgun or a Gauss cannon from start to finish and not encounter many problems while doing so; this was even possible on a relatively difficult setting such as ultraviolence. In Eternal, there are demons with bigger weaknesses to certain weapons in your arsenal. For example, it would probably take you 10 seconds to kill a Cacodemon with a Super Shotgun (generally more powerful), but it would take you less than 3 seconds to kill a Cacodemon with an ordinary shotgun's grenade launcher attachment while its mouth is open. It's little weaknesses like that which require you to think strategically about which demons are more susceptible to being killed first in combat. 

I'll admit that I'm not entirely a big fan of the extra lives system. I understand it's an accessibility setting, and by no means am I a 'git gud' sort of player, but I would prefer if we had the option to disable that mechanic entirely alongside all of the extra life power-ups in the game. I'm also slightly worried about the future of the game's DLC given that Mick Gordon has been taken off the project due to internal conflicts and project scheduling. 

If you loved DOOM 2016, this is more of the same but better and more fine-tuned.

It's Doom.  You think I'm not gonna recommend this?  In all seriousness however:  I love the combat in this game, way more fluid than 2016 (not that 2016 Doom was bad), final act of the game still has a lot to offer, enemies are wonderful, weapons really feel powerful, and everything just flows for the most part.  The only part I didn't like was all the platforming.  I feel that, while it does engage the player (obviously), it just feels a tad too much at times.  I play Doom to murder demons, not jump around on platforms.  However, for every frustrating platforming area, there are 4-5 fight areas, and you never know what the "arena" is going to look like till you get there.  Visuals are simply stunning as well.  All in all, great game, and if you like FPS's there is no other like this.

After playing Doom Eternal, this game shows us what the future of the franchise will be.
* huge levels
* arena-corridor-arena game play, which isn't that bad
* more platforming, which is fine but I hate blind corners and blind leaps
* beefier weapons
* beefier enemies (even the "feeder" enemies are tough)

This is all all right but I don't like way they've implemented fast travel in the game. I feel once you've completed a level you should be able to go back to it and have fast travel immediately and forever unlocked for that level. The levels are huge and it's a PITA if you're looking for something in particular. Also I encountered a bug that marred my progression (completed a slayer gate but did not get an empyrean key--making it unlikely I will be able to unlock the unmakyr).

PROS:
+ I like the more movement options, I didn't think I would, but I do, double jumps, dashing, monkey bars, all of it
+ I like the beefy weapons
+ I do not mind the feeder enemies/chainsaw ammo resource management, it's ok, but meh
+ chainsawing enemies is fun but the timed recharge can really interrupt the flow of the game (at least for me)
+ the platforming is fun after you've done it a bit, it can take some getting used to
+ I like being able to upgrade your weapons and stuff
+ it's nice having all the old Doom II enemies back
+ the belcher/armor mechanic is fun--it encouraged me to use the belcher often
+ there's a story to doom now, it's not just mindless "kill everything"
+ I like exploring the levels
+ I like that the levels have fast travel now

CONS:
- I do not like getting swarmed by the enemy AI especially when I'm trying to reach an enemy to chainsaw or glory kill
- the AI in dewm eternal seems dumber in some ways, in dewm you could always get to your enemies, now there's traffic jams all the time
- I'd like fewer, more obvious weapon upgrades
- I do not like most of the newer enemies, the viper/whiplash, the gargoyle but the doom hunter and marauder seem OK
- I do not care one iota about the "progression" system to add customizations to your game/UI/whatever, it just seems like a distraction
- the frag grenade seems pointless if you can shoot a bomb with your shotgun, just give us more shotgun ammo and drop the frag grenade
- I thought I would like the meathook more than I did, with the dashing, it seems redundant; you get the double dash way before the meathook--although the burning meathook is a nice option (since it drops armor for you)
- DRM: denuvo anti-cheat (which was later removed) and dunuvo DRM haunt this title
- the story, as it stands, it's just bafflingly stupid (IMO)--it's worse than Dewm's story; it's nice it has a story, but they could do better
- fast travel should be always available once you complete a level

After thinking about it some there are 3 "eras" of Doom so far... canonically, they're all a single timeline but to me, that timeline doesn't make a lick of sense, and they are all very different game play wise. So I tend to think of them as separate, but similar, realities.

Era 1: Doom/Doom II/Doom 64
Era 2: Doom 3
Era 3: Doom (2016)/Doom Eternal (or as I call them now, Dewm and Dewm Eternal)

"Not your little brothers shooter"
And so this game has been out for a couple of months now and I finally came round to reviewing it. I mean you have seen the reviews and scores, THIS GAME IS BLOODY BRILLIANT. As a long time DOOM fan since i was a wee child it makes me so happy to see the series doing so well in this day and age, But lets get into the actual game. I came into this one with high expectations for many reasons. One this was the sequel to DOOM 2016 of which I adore. Two the DOOM series rarely disappoints. Lastly this is a game I have been itching to get my hands on since the reveal at quakecon all the way back in 2018. I tend not to get excited over games mainly because I have been let down by many games I got hyped for in the past, *cough cough* Star wars battlefront, But even I admit this game had me hyped to play and this is the one game I have been looking forward to since DUSK. Lets get presentation out of the way. ID Tech 7 looks awesome and the high detail in weapons, character models and environments shine in some breath taking levels, But what I love is the fact that even though this looks as good as it does its disk size is at least 15gb smaller than DOOM 2016, I dont know what Black magic they are playing with at ID but I love it. Also the game is really well optimised I only had one crash and its when I took a screenshot during a cutscene. Story has had a huge involvement in this game, I wont be that guy to ruin the best moments as some parts of this game left my jaw hanging, but my only issue is there seems to be a huge gap in time between DOOM 2016 and DOOM Eternal which kind of annoys me as I wouldve loved to see Doomslayers Journey between games, but with confirmation of two story DLC'S maybe we might get to see this story told. To the thing that matters. Gameplay. Core gameplay is a lot like DOOM 2016 I mean if its not broke dont fix it but a lot of new factors have been implemented into the combat that makes this combat a lot more challenging than the previous game. I think the biggest one that had all the game journalists butthurt was the lower ammo count which yes could get annoying as power weapons like the Rocket launcher and Ballista have bugger all ammo, but you can upgrade your total capacity and the game has made the chainsaw automatically refill its fuel to allow you to constantly be chainsawing the fodder demons for ammo. To further this point even more the game gets to the point where it will infinitely spawn fodders like zombies, zombiemen and imps in an arena until you defeat the bigger demons so if you are actually half decent at shooters this shouldnt be a problem. I believe this game to be an evolution of the FPS genre it quite literally has changed the game and other big budget shooters are going to be hard-pressed to even come close to this beauty of a game. Also I did not try the battlemode as I am not really a big online guy, but my friend says its fun if you can get on it with friends so I will take his word for it,

9/10 
"Not for snowflakes, DOOM is Eternally Great"

I think it's a good FPS and a very good iteration on Doom 2016 but not particularly a "Doom game" nor some kind of masterpiece. Graphically very nice and much improved from '16 in terms of visual clarity (uses all colors instead of just red). Every stage looks unique and extremely pretty although it's all very concept arty and motionless. 

Similar sort of gameplay to '16. It doesn't feel like you can really "avoid" attacks, like there's no weaving in and out of fireballs and rockets as in classic Doom. It's more about moving constantly while managing your ammo counts and "super ammo" counts and four cooldowns and one meter. Levels flow much better than '16. Progression feels worse than I remember. Suit, weapon, rune, crystal.. too many types of leveling up, nothing feels substantial or interesting beyond like 2.5 of the runes.

Not much to do after the campaign; I do not enjoy Battlemode even 1%. "Master Levels" and Lives Mode poorly conceived, half-baked. Takes itself stone cold seriously in terms of lore and tone, in contrast to '16.

It's "great" but it's not like top 100 of all time.
