The main campaign is alright, super repetitive gameplay involving focusing the 'heavy demons' first and fodder for health and ammo. I won't lie, this was my first DOOM game and I am just not impressed beyond the glory kills and carnage. Multiplayer is alright, but won't keep you playing.

[i]Let me preface by saying I have never played any other DOOM game, or read any novels. However at the time of writing I have sunk 82 hours into the game to give you an accurate representation instead of something cheesy and surface level like most one liner reviews. I hope this guide helps your final decision on whether or not to get this game.[/i]

[h1] Doomblade into the Campaign [/h1]
[b]NO Spoilers![/b]

Visually speaking, the game has moments of feeling really fucking ferocious. It's a weird thing to admit but the carnage is just something of an addicting stimulant to keep you going. You can glory kill anything at any angle and fall in love with wiping out hordes of fodder with a mega-mc-double-pummel of your gauntlet. The problem is... well, beyond that..? Not much else is very engaging or enjoyable. I really loved the beginning of the game, I played through this on ultra-violence and had a blast for the first maybe 6-10 hours; but got so fucking bored afterwards. To begin with, I really couldn't get into the story very much, it just felt like a pretty average revenge tale.  You will learn in the first 10 minutes that your objective is to kill 3 Hell Priests that made Earth go a bit wild. Let me just say, that is essentially the whole story.

In terms of the game play, from what I hear this variant of DOOM is quite different from the 2016 release; which I have yet to play. For this reason I don't feel comfortable making comments on the comparisons which can be made (unless someone thought it right to gift it to me lmao) but I will tell you this much... You will learn rapidly the ideal strategies to eradicate each small arena-like room of demons. As I said earlier, this process is pretty fun at first because of the carnage but later on it's literally

"Do I have enough ammo to kill this big bastard?"
if yes, use either everything you've got or something it is weak to
if no, chainsaw an enemy. Then ask yourself question one again

This same analogy would work with your health and armor, simply switch out ammo for health lmfao

Anyways, unless additional information is needed. This is about as brief as it will get when talking about the campaign. The reason I didn't like it is because you repeat these targeting systems for hours and hours and eventually the game comes to a close. Boring as the hell our demons came from my guy.

[h1]Ballista Beams, another word for Multiplayer[/h1]
[i]Can you guess what's coming?[/i]

The multiplayer, or 'battle mode' as it is called in DOOM Eternal. When the game first came out it actually was pretty damn good because of all the lads playing and everyone being relatively bad.Even if it was a 1v1 you had a chance of winning. Now adays it's more akin to prestige 3 playing your level 50 and below lookin' ass. Not only has matchmaking become so irrelevant, but damn... It's just a never changing meta.

If you're playing a slayer, use the super shotty and ballista.

If you're the demon, spawn your garbage mobs and run lmao

Despite being a two demon one slayer system it feels like in any match a slayer that knows what they're doing will win. If you focus the demons and don't miss your shots (which is easy with the eccentric 'freeze frame' lag). You will kill them and the slayer gets a massive health and ammo drop which [b]can't[/b] be blocked. So, then they just need to focus you with a relentless chase and the round will end pretty quickly from there.

If you [b]EVER[/b] get stuck in a 1v1, and the slayer knows what they're doing just throw the fucking match it is so easy to stomp the demons balls into their throat and turn their dick into a banana smoothie like FUCK my guy it's too easy and I can't stress this enough!

Also, I will admit something I do agree with off the bat is that having an option between battlemode and slayers vs slayers would have been so much better. I can just tell a majority of players finished the campaign. Played an hour of battlemode and left the game to rot on their hard drive.

[h1]Cheat Codes[/h1]

So, with all that being said. I would have to say that there are just a couple of other things I would want to speak on. First, I am running a beefy krabby patty of a computer and the graphics maxed out simply did not impress me at all. There is some weird effect in place that makes looking at objects or rooms kind of... bad. I can't quite place it, but if you need examples I will gladly take screenshots and post them in the comments. Along with my notes as to why it looks weird. However, this can't be said for the demons or gore. All of that looks absolutely fantastic! It's simply the environment that looks strange throughout the whole game.

The events are average at best. Like I said, you have a pretty boring/repetitive campaign and a fairly dead/sweaty multiplayer. So, these events will reward you cosmetics for completing challenges and ranking up in the 'battle pass' if you will. However, the problem I had with this is that the challenges just aren't very fun. This is [b]not[/b] the devs fault. It's just that this system really couldn't be utilized well when you place it with everything you have to work with. It's like the challenges are just "Kill 40 frozen fodder demons", "Kill a pinky with a doom punch", "Jump off a cliff but pull of a 360 no scope". Like uhh... I will tell you a secret right now... You can re-run the level Mars Core and [i]always[/i] complete 70% in a run or two, if not the whole thing.

The multiplayer seems to get challenges as well each season, these challenges are really simple; but like I said they can't really be different because the core game is just the way it is. You play 3 matches as a demon or 3 as a slayer and boom. Challenges done.

[h1]The End[/h1]

With all this in mind, I can only recommend you this game if you pick it up on sale for $20 or less. Truly it fucking blows to say this because I was ready to get into DOOM. This is my first exposure to the series, and I even went so far as to preorder the game. I didn't come in with high expectations, because truthfully I couldn't. It was my first game, no impressions or anything. Yet still, I was let down. I am sad to say all this about the game because it's got an appeal which I can understand. However, I'm also not blinded by what this game is. Just barely above average.

So, I would like to thank you for reading. If you have thoughts, questions, or anything of the sort please leave a comment or rating on this review to help others see it and understand. I'm glad to have been a part of this games review process, and keep in mind... Rip and tear lads!

I am by no means a game critic, so bear with me.

[b]This only goes over the campaign, as I, and probably many others, didn't buy a DOOM title for online PVP.[/b]

Starting off with performance/optimization, max settings ran surprisingly well with no frame drops, at a solid 144fps, despite this I did have a few crashes but none made me lose progress.

For gameplay, overall it was good, but could sometimes be clunky, particularly with the wallclimbs and pipes. Another thing I disliked was having my dash get blocked by an enemy when it looks like I should've made it past, getting me stuck and losing a lot of health. Meathook felt great once I got familiar with it, and is a really nice tool for hit & runs and getting in the face of something over a gap. There's lots of on-the-fly ammo management, which can be quite annoying sometimes.

The first few levels have this odd immersion break where it teleports you out of the level into a small tutorial room, which is completely blank and looks like it was made in 30 seconds. Needless to say this is highly unnecessary, the tools at your disposal are relatively simple and can be learnt faster in combat than in a small gray space. Other tutorials such as weak spots showcases for new enemies, are also done in a similar room, but without you actually being there. It's just a video.

Regarding the story/lore, it's about what you'd expect for a DOOM game. Earth is infested with demons, angry man goes to Earth and kills the demons and their sources.
It's obviously not that linear, but I want to keep the review spoiler free.

In summary, is it as good as DOOM 2016? It's hard to say as I love both games, Eternal is much faster paced, with more movement mechanics, while 2016 is slower, simpler, and has a better story.

This is a solid game that only improves Doom 2016 in every way. The gameplay is top notch where it takes Doom 2016 gun play ramps up the speed and incorporate a ton of aerial combat. The devs added significantly more collectibles then the previous game but I found that they more much easier to find then before. The damage window when he has his shield down is way to small. The fact that he can dash, summons a dog, has a shotgun and shoots an energy blast at long range is just way to much in my opinion). All in all I recommend it   with an overall score of an 8/10. If the game had more content I would give it a higher rating.

Meh.  The Doom franchise IMO "jumped the shark" with Doom Eternal.  Just after finishing all current content in Borderlands 3,  I saw DE om sale for half price, and a further coupon discount.  Given I am a fan of all the previous versions of Doom, and the strongly positive reviews, I was majorly disappointed.  Compared to Borderlands 3, or any Borderlands game DE is a incredibly boring. Worse yet, it's nauseatingly cheesy.  I still feel like I paid more for the game than it is worth.

Sure, it has great graphics.  But I can't play the higher quality settings on my QHD monitor, because I have a 6GB GTX 2060 card?  The required memory for the higher levels is just 0.2 GB more than 6GB?  Seriously?  I would think 6GB graphics cards make up the largest portion of cards in use today.  It seems incredibly sloppy and lazy that Bethesda basically decided "oh well what can we do" when a tiny 3% further optimization would have made the highest quality settings playable on 6GB cards.  My card runs  the game at 130 FPS+ at native 2560x1440 resolution at the highest usable graphics settings allowed.  Clearly the card could easily handle great frame rates at higher quality settings. What  waste.

That said the graphics are pretty.  Not ground breaking, but good.  Previous Doom games were more of a shut up and shoot affair, with only infrequent comments from your "commander". The demonic characters that talk in DE are just nauseating,.  It's like they are trying too hard to make the story engaging.  Its not.  The result is so cheesy and annoying its like a B movie, or the worst movie sequel you can imagine.  The talking demonic characters are so bad, that they are almost funny.... almost... they're just irritatingly bad.

It's not that this is a bad game, its just not a great game.  Especially having just played a game like Borderlands, where the story telling is just as incredible as the graphics.  I spent about 130 hours on BD3, finished everything.  I have spent less than 2 hours with DE and am already thinking of just deleting it.  Life is too short to play cheesy mediocre games, even if they have nice graphics.

DE is an excellent example of why any game that you have played for less than 1 or 2 hours should be fully refundable.  Buyer beware.  You may like this game, or like me, despite the many positive reviews may find the game tarnishes the overall doom franchise. Doom 3 was a good game, not an amazing game, but at least wasn't so cheesy.

Beware that just because you have liked all previous versions of Doom does not mean you will like DE.

I went into this fairly excited as Doom 2016 was a great game with some flaws, my first game I played was the first Doom on PC so naturally I looked forward to getting this one day and I've just been disappointed in it.

It's not a terrible game but it doesn't feel it took the improvements from 2016, the management is just downright stupid, I've done raids in an MMO that doesn't feel as suffocating as this, Ammo management is just completely absurd and it just makes me want to stop playing seeing that all my weapons are low ammo constantly, yes I can use the chainsaw to remedy this but it doesn't feel as flowing as 2016, in fact it feels like the brakes are slammed here constantly to deal with some annoyance that threatens to slow the rampage down.

So, i've been playing Doom since the first one, somewhere in 2000-2001 when i had my first PC, i've been a die-hard fan of the franchise ever since.
When Doom 2016 was released it blew my mind, everything was perfect in that game, i was hoping to be as pleased with Doom Eternal as i was with the 2016 reboot.

Eternal fell a bit short to my expectations personally, but it's still a great game nonetheless.

It feels like the developers wanted to do something a bit different this time. Some of these things were cool, some not so much.

What i am totally unhappy about this game is that it steered a bit from the classical type of "corridor shooter" as some might call them, meaning that it has too many characteristics of an adventure game, for my tastes at least.

Some puzzles were overdid, you can't afford to be very trigger happy and just blast everything because you usually have somewhat a small ammo available.
Typically Doom was the kind of game that always had tons of ammo everywhere, and you could just don't care, shoot, blast, explode, so i wasn't happy about this change.
Most of the times i died were because i was totally out of ammo for any gun, and the melee punch wasn't strong enough to kill even a fly, so i had to adapt a bit, and be more cautious with the firepower.

The puzzles weren't hard (and i say that as someone that is very dumb when it comes to puzzles, the last few years at least), it's just it feels like there could've been a better balance between Action and Adventure.

What i loved most about this game on the other hand, it gives you a more humanly perspective of the hell, it gives it some more rationalization i suppose,

[h1]Music[/h1]
Oh well, i am not a fan of this soundtrack, I don't know exactly how to describe it. it's just very vanilla, too soft. 
DOOM 2016 had one of the greatest soundtracks i ever heard in games, with music that would give you that adrenaline rush and pump you so hard you were feeling like you were actually, indeed, inside the game.

It does contain the song "BFG Division" which is a pure masterpiece, but you don't get to hear it often.

Personally, i am a simple guy, if i could have a song switcher, i would've listen to it the entire game.
I don't like this genre of Alt-Nu, or however ti can be called, and i get the feeling i am not alone in it.

Menu theme was pretty cool, it was chill, but it also had some dark and unnerving vibes, totally loved it.

[h1]Maps, Levels, Demons, W/E[/h1]
I liked the level design, of course, as usual you get to have secret locations where you can find cool collectibles such as Vinyls and dolls.
Towards the end, however, it's where the level design actually shines at its brightest, they were so beautiful i wished i could take a trip to hell for some hours.

Some enemies are annoying as hell (no pun intended), for example the Marauder but luckily they don't appear often.
A cool thing i encountered was that, some times a demon would appear that had previously killed another player, and he was a bit stronger, but also dropped more loot.

Weapons, you have plenty of them, the ammo isn't great as mentioned earlier. I wish [spoiler]you'd get the BFG a bit earlier though[/spoiler]

I think Doom is the only game that made a classic, non-fancy double barrel shotgun look and feel so bad ass.

[h1]Performance[/h1]

The game is very well optimized, i played it on a PC that hasn't seen a fresh OS install since 2018, with a GTX 1060 that needs new thermal paste, and an i5-4440. 
While my GPU is far from being old or outdated, i was still a bit surprised to see the game set things to almost maximum at the launch of the game. 

I did encounter some bugs, some i could reproduce, some i couldn't, this area is mostly for the devs if they are reading reviews and want to fix them:

- Sometimes when launching the game, i was having two cursors, the game window was somehow not in focus, as i couldn't do anything, keyboard didn't work, neither did my mouse. I couldn't alt-tab. My workaround was using an android app on my phone that i use to control my PC, to bring focus back to the game window. 
Not sure what causes it but i had it most of the times i launched the game

- Screenshots while the Doom guy was picking up collectibles was causing memory leaks, might have something to do with Steam itself.

That's about it, i mean, the game did crash few times on me out of sudden, and i had 2-3 more random memory leaks but those i blame on my PC itself.

[h1]In the end[/h1]
If i had the chance, i wouldn't pay again 20$ for it, that sum of money is not that small where i am from.
With good and bad, i loved the game, it's a good and new addition to one of my favorite franchises.
I think a big factor on why Eternal didn't tick for me as amazing as DOOM 2016 was in fact, the music, it's a really big important factor.

If you are not a fan of the franchise, i think it would be better if you got DOOM 2016 instead (assuming you don't have either, and want to choose between them)

I give it a 7/10.

Hope you took this review with a grain of salt.

For a game this hyped,I thought it was going to be absolute garbage. It was not. If you played the original DOOM franchise, the callbacks will be amazing and very enjoyable. If You haven't, then the experience will still be amazing and enjoyable, although I would play DOOM(2016) so you have moderate feel of whats going on, though its not that necessary. Compared to every modern AAA shooter, this game is a priceless gem that outshines all the rest, and unlike every other bethesda game, the DOOM games actually work (Thank you id software)

I think DOOM Eternal is pretty good. It may not start especially strong, but after the first third of the game you've got a bunch of new abilities, weapons and movement options that makes the 2016 reboot seem threadbare in comparison. The levels start fairly linear, but open up as you progress through the game. The combat this time around is definitely harder, and there's one enemy in particular that's probably the toughest in the [i]entire[/i] series, but oh man is it ever satisfying. Plenty of ripping and tearing to do!

You're forced to use almost every tool in your arsenal in a sort of rhythmic dance of death, especially since your primary source of ammo is from demons, not pickups. It's not like in other Doom games where there's enough ammo lying around for you to use just a couple of guns - you don't hold that much ammo, but your chainsaw that you use to kill demons for ammo automatically fills with gas now. Thankfully the rhythm is fun; cutting fodder demons open like a demented pinata is always great, and the weapons are very punchy feeling. Movement is if anything even more important this time around, given how deadlier your enemies are. I don't even mind the arcadey floating pickup icons, because most of them are secrets and there's more than collectible dolls this time. The hub area is neat, with places for your collectible items, bonus upgrades you can unlock, and other things besides.

The only thing I didn't like so much was the occasional patch of purple goo that slows you down and prevents you from jumping. Since movement is a very important aspect to the game, being stuck in the goo is not only less fun than free movement, but dangerous in combat. Tutorial pop-ups tell you how to defeat most non-fodder enemies just before you face them for the first time, and apart from a couple of bosses where the advice is welcome (including the aforementioned toughest enemy in the series) I found it a bit egregious. Fortunately you can turn those pop-ups off. There's noticeably more platforming than in the 2016 game, and while I didn't mind it too much, there were bits that I ended up falling off like 2 or 3 times before getting through them.

For those of you who care about Doom's story, there's a lot more lore this time around. The backstory that was alluded to in Doom 2016 is essentially revealed, as is the Doom Slayer's background. Between that and where the campaign takes you, it's an interesting ride...with an okay end. I honestly expected more of a denouement after the final boss. Multiplayer's different now: it's a 2v1 arena where two demons gang up on the Doom Slayer. It can be fun, but the biggest problem is a lack of matchmaking skill balance.

Ultimately Doom Eternal changes up the formula enough to be more than just "the last game with different scenery", and while that might displease some people, I thought it was done well. Throw in another patented Mick Gordon soundtrack (unfortunately he's stopped working with ID Software and won't be scoring the DLCs) and plenty of callbacks to the classic games for older fans and you've got yourself a great time.

IMPORTANT: Do NOT try to run this on a laptop. DOOM 2016 worked on mine (slow but functional), but this refused to run. I ended up buying a gaming desktop from a friend for a very good price just to play this (though that was long overdue).

For those of you picking this up after playing DOOM 2016, this is a very different experience. The enemies are more powerful, but so are you. Many times, I would find myself wondering why I was having trouble, then I would remember that I had way more tricks up my sleeve than my guns. It has an Overwatch-like plethora of abilities with cooldowns and other ways to replenish them, and some of the enemies have Dark-Souls-like attack-timing and weak spots. There are several sections of platforming, and they're usually kinda puzzle-y. Imagine DOOM 2016 but with all that thrown in there. If that doesn't sound like fun, then this might not be for you.

As for me, I enjoyed this a bit more than 2016. I say that because while it was more frustrating at times, it was also more satisfying to succeed in. Before, when I got through a hard section, I would think, "Well, I shot my gun, and they died. Cool," but after getting through Eternal's hard sections, it felt more like, "Wow, I actually managed to pull that off by using all my abilities and the enemies' mechanics as best as I could. Awesome." It makes you feel a lot more apart of the fray and less like a mobile tank just clicking on everything. It also makes you feel more mortal in that if you screw up or fail to use your the mechanics properly, you're toast. Some people like that, some people don't. That's mostly what you'll see in the reviews here, but there's the truth. Both games are very fun and have their own things going for them, mechanically. 

I didn't bother to get too deep into the lore myself (I got both games almost 2 weeks ago and beat them; I'm new to the DOOM franchise), but this game is far more rich and explicit with it than the previous games. And, like the other aspects of the game, your enjoyment of it is based on your preference. For those who disliked how deep it got into the Doom Slayer's backstory, I mean, come on. They probably weren't thinking too deeply about lore in the earlier games, and in order to tie it all together here, they really had to stretch. Some of it felt kind of odd and vague, but I thought it was overall pretty cool (with some suspended disbelief). Some of it felt a bit lacking, but hey, it's DOOM, you play it to saw demons in half, not read books (though I spent a good amount of time admiring the fortress's bookshelves), so it's kind of a petty thing to get hung-up over.

And the platforming is fun. It sometimes gets challenging, but that just gives you a chance to prove your skills. There was only one section (I think it's in the Cultist Base) that I was REALLY frustrated with and ended up having to use some very unconventional methods to solve (Make sure you get the air-control perk early!). But besides that, I had fun with it. 

While I don't necessarily think this is a game I will be coming back to frequently, the 16 hours I spent on the campaign in normal mode were a blast. I wouldn't say it's worth $60 (I got it half off), but if it's on sale, and my above description sounds appealing to you, then absolutely pick this up. If you like big guns, powerful abilities, daunting enemies, and Christian values, this is the game for you.

PS: 2016's soundtrack was better, though

Doom 2016 was a pretty damn killer game. It was also an extremely simple game. The combat required a lot of skill, but 95% of that skill was just moving around the level and dodging attacks. It didn't really matter what weapon you used, all of them would work against almost any demon. You still had some strategy, but for the most part you could make it through the mid-to-late game picking completely random weapons for each encounter and you would still make it out on top. Thinking back, that was one of my only real gripes with the game: When in a firefight, I would swap weapons on a complete whim with no real rhyme or reason as the player is given an overwhelming amount of firepower, so many different types of attacks that a few of them would always go completely unused or would be useless compared to other attacks. This "no-brainer" simplicity of combat was reflected in my middle-school era three word review of the game: "PUNCH FUCKING EVERYTHING".

Doom Eternal is like being pulled by the neck out of the mindless, comfy W+M1 combat of the previous game, shoved into a cold steel chair, and having a gallon of frigid water dumped onto you. This game's combat is like 2016's in appearance only, and whilst that turned a [i]hell of a lot of people[/i] off of the game I can't get enough of it.

Whereas Doom 2016 gave you the feeling of being a legendary warrior, Doom Eternal makes you fight for it. Eternal is the [i]Hypermagic Mountain[/i] of Doom games. Combat is an absolute knife's edge - right off the bat, you're given less than half the ammo pool you had in Doom 2016, and even basic enemy attacks damage for an immense amount. Any enemy past the basic fodder demons are tough to kill unless you use weapons that they specifically are weak to. You could chip away at that Revenant with your pulse rifle, sure, but that wastes precious time and ammo. Instead you could focus fire on disabling its rocket launchers with the combat shotgun's sticky grenades or the heavy cannon's charged bolt, then get in close with the super shotty and have it dispatched in just ten seconds. In this way combat becomes a puzzle in and of itself. You have weapons dedicated to replenishing your three resources: Shred demons with the chainsaw and they will drop ammo, Glory kill them with your Doomblade and they will drop health, Light them on fire with the flamethrower and they will drop armor. You will constantly be running out of these resources, so it becomes a challenge upon figuring out the very best time to use these. (Maybe not the chainsaw though)

Every weapon and ability has a specific usage as well: The dash ability that seems like it's just for platforming at first is mandatory to dodge attacks that in previous games you could simply strafe around. The rocket launcher's detonate mod which was completely useless in the previous game now has a very distinct purpose - getting behind the front-armored Pinky demon. It was used for this in Doom 2016, but now it's required; this game's Pinky has a MUCH TIGHTER turning radius and deals a LOT MORE DAMAGE. Use the heavy cannon's charged bolt (think sniper rifle shot) to snipe mounted weapons off of demons, forcing them to become melee only combatants. The plasma rifle's microwave beam may force you to slow down, but it stunlocks an enemy and guarantees a kill, making it perfect for cleaning up larger enemies after you've dealt with the smaller ones. But if you don't have the time to switch to a specific weapon or mod, don't fret- the frag grenade (a rarely-used weapon from the previous game) and the new ice bomb are always available no matter what weapon you have selected and are an [b]absolute godsend[/b] when you need some space to think up your next move. 

Doom 2016 may have had simple combat, but its levels were unforgiving. Secrets were so hard to find that I needed to look up the locations for half of them. The game had an obsession with locking you out of all previous parts of a level as soon as you entered a new room, so if you noticed an item you missed on the game's map you'd have to restart the entire 35+ minute mission to get it. With Doom Eternal this is rarely an issue. The levels are boxier and more clearly laid out. The secret items are more numerous and easier to find: you'll know when a secret is nearby and for almost every secret you just need to find the breakable wall that leads you to it (only needed a video tutorial for one item in the whole game, lol). The game has a more cartoonish and bright art style making enemies and pickups pop out, and inbetween fights there are platforming segments that give the levels a bit more variety, as well as allowing more interesting placement of secrets. Apparently many people hate the platforming segments. I couldn't disagree more, they're one of my favorite parts of the game - it's very clearly (with a... few exceptions) marked where and when you need to jump.

It's obvious this game will not click at all with specific types of people. You may have seen negative reviews complaining that the game forces you into a very specific playstyle with almost no room for deviation- use these specific weapon for this specific demon type, all other weapons won't be as effective. Let me tell you with complete certainty that this is [i]absolutely, undeniably, positively [b]TRUE.[/b][/i] And personally, I love it. I enjoy the game's super run-n'-gun puzzle combat gameplay, and the game is completely structured around stuff like "jump and dash and lock-on burst that mancubus then quickly switch to your super shotgun and meathook that gargoyle to get across the arena so you can barely dodge the hell knight about to pounce on you then flame-belch the zombies around him, glory kill one of them for health and blow up the others with a frag for the armor they'll drop, then duck behind cover, charge up a destroyer blade shot, and shoot it down that hallway with those two carcasses and the half-health pinky I stuck a couple sticky bombs to thirty seconds ago, and all of this while running away from the marauder because the marauder kicks my ass every time and i want to save him for last because he SUCKS". That was an overly detailed description of about twenty seconds of gameplay. Every single weapon I used in that wall of text I used for a very specific purpose. If I hadn't used each weapon for its given specific purpose it would not have been as effective. If this sounds like something you would enjoy or you loved Doom 2016 but thought its combat was too simplistic buy this game right now.

But all and all what I like the most about this game is that (as previously said) where Doom 2016 simply gave you the feeling of being a legendary warrior, Doom Eternal makes you fight for it. You will likely stagger at the start from the unforgiving nature of the combat (I was playing on Ultra-Violence first playthrough if you were wondering), but when you figure out what the hell you're doing and you get REALLY good at the combat loop, you really [i]feel[/i] like the god damn Doom Slayer. Seriously- the final boss fight is one of biblical proportions and by the end I sure as hell felt like a legendary warrior for the shit I just trudged through. Basically, it's a good game. Even with the Marauders. Fuck those guys.

A worthy successor to DOOM 2016 that made the reboot possible.
Doom slayer is back with a never ending thirst for vengeance against those unlucky enough to deserve it. 

Hell wasn't just on Mars it was also waging a full scale takeover of Earth, luckily you won't let them have it. Between games the Slayer has been busy building up his own resources for when he will have to stop the demons once again. You now own the fortress of doom, a relic of a long lost era when the Knight Sentinels once ruled. Strike out from your base against those who would want to see humanity fall. However your actions aren't going unnoticed... 

For those that smugly said DOOM 2016 was too easy well id listened and you're going to regret it. Combat against the forces of hell is more brutal and bloodier than before and you will need every advantage you have to make it out on top. Retaining your movement options from the last game, you unlock even more ways to traverse the arenas. The dash ability at first seeming to be an optional move is quickly learned to be necessary. Quickly engaging and just as quickly moving back to relative safety is a skill you will need to hone. Doom Slayer now makes use of monkey bars as well to launch himself to higher areas of arenas and to get a drop on his foes. However none seem to compare to the "meathook" the grappling hook launched from the underside of your trusty super shotgun allows you to do both, move quickly like your dash and gain elevation like the monkey bars. All the while you can still dispense brutality to the unfortunate demon at the end of your hook. 

The demons of hell are back and more fearsome than ever. They're faster, stronger and much smarter this time around. Instead of seemingly running around doing their own thing they will work in tandem to try and bring you down. Hell knights are much more aggressive than last time, able to run you down if you simply try to back pedal. Even mancubi have new tricks up their guns with more movement options at their disposal with faster firing cannons that deal out hefty damage. New enemies like the prowler will phase in and out of reality to do hit and run attacks on unwary Slayers. 

This comes with an all new damage mesh system. As you face them down with equal brutality, demons will begin falling apart. Large open wounds and exposed flesh, bones, and blood will appear on them as they sustain more and more damage. 
We also can't forget about the new glory kills. Along with those we've seen, there are also a lot of knew ones involving the Slayers new arm mounted blade that let you pull off quick yet brutally efficient glory kills.

Now let's talk about music. Mick Gordon has outdone himself and has been allowed to fully embrace the heavy metal riffs and guitar that those were so wary of in the first game. The combat music soundscape for each level inspires a feeling of visceral need to keep going against all odds like "rip and tear" did when we first heard it.

In short the game is harder, stronger, faster and better than ever. To see what id could possibly create to top this seems impossible.

DOOM Eternal managed to be everything I feared Doom 2016 would have been. As a disclaimer, I've been playing on Ultra-Violence; I understand some of the problems with the game aren't quite as bad on lower difficulties. The combat lacks all the satisfaction of its predecessor; the game seems to be taking itself too seriously, even the music (which as a standalone is as awesome as in 2016) just doesn't fit the ambiance properly. The sceneries are gorgeous, but they feel like they don't make any sense. The glory kills feel like exactly the kind of annoyance we expected 2016's to be; somehow, 2016 avoided that, but something about Eternal's breaks that. You no longer have a fallback weapon; instead of an interesting tactical option, the chainsaw becomes your last resort of getting any damage at all. The melee attack is completely worthless against anything but staggered opponents - even the most basic zombies can shrug of dozens of hits (I gave up after twenty hits or so).

Level design seems to be a bit schizophrenic. Wide open spaces with lots of pickups and no monsters (maybe a few zombies); tight spaces with no/few pickups and lots of monsters, making you backtrack once in a while to get ammo (except when a magical barrier appears to stop you from backtracking). A lot of jump and dash action, but it kind of fell flat; and is further hindered by many invisible walls to boot.

The worst thing is, when you add it all together... in my two and a half hours of gameplay, I never once felt the rush or joy of playing Doom 2016. It all felt like a tedious slog. For bonus points, often interrupted with annoying popups trying to tell you how to play the game. It's obvious a lot of hard work went into the game. It even feels like another month of work with someone who really gets how 2016 works would be enough to fix everything that's broken with the game. A damn shame.
They really out did themselves with this game. Play on Nightmare and thank me later.

I've put almost 3 hours into the game so far. My only other experience with the franchise is Doom 2016, but my first impressions of the game is that it's like someone had this great idea for a post apocalyptic shooter and then they decided to turn it into Doom Eternal.

 - Since when is Doom a 3D platformer? The swing bars, wall climbing, and jumps you can easily fail- why? Doom 2016 had its platforming moments, but not in the first hour of game play, and not as what appears to be a continuing theme.

 - Run out of ammo? Well that's ok cause demons have an unlimited supply! Whip out the chainsaw, cut up a demon, and you're good to go. Just something about this really breaks the immersion for me. I think making it a primary mechanic was a mistake. The veritable confetti of ammo spewing out of your latest victim used to have a sort of satisfaction to it. Now it just kind of empty. Seems to me like the easy way out to actually plotting out where ammo dumps should be. Also, I just miss the pistol.

 - *** spoilers *** Story Progression: 2016 was really great at telling its story, and if things were left unsaid it was done in such a way that it made sense. Now we're just dropped in a part of the moon orbiting earth, and we're just supposed to accept that he made it out of hell without any explanation? Also, Vega is alive, online, or whatever? It's a very jarring transition from the end of 2016 in my opinion, and it makes the other elements introduced at the end of the first mission even more confusing, which, again, breaks the immersion.

 - Enemy Progression: I took the note about low health being common in the early stages of "Hurt me plenty" with a grain of salt, but was not prepared to be facing enemies akin to what you'd see probably halfway through 2016 in the first hour of the game. I also don't like the fact that you end up having to get an upgrade to punch your way through the waves of the weakest enemies.

I'll keep at it, and maybe I'll change my tune farther down the line, but those are my thoughts.

TL;DR Not what I expected, and a very abrupt change from Doom 2016. It feels like something that would have been brilliant as its own standalone game.

WARNING! THIS POST CONTAINS SPOILERS SO IF YOU DON'T WANT TO BE SPOILED ABOUT THE GAME AND THE STORY THEN PLEASE STOP READING HERE.

What is DOOM Eternal?:

DOOM Eternal is an arena FPS Game which was originally created in 1993. DOOM Eternal is the recreation of the original series and it holds itself extremely good. In this game you have to kill Demons throughou the way to get into the finish line. It sounds like it's a basic combat game but no. It's more then that.

The Combat:

In DOOM Eternal there are multiple Demons which you can encounter with. At first the game introduces you to the simple and basic Demons like the Possessed. The Combat gets harder when you meet the Arachnotron. The tutorial tells you everything about the Demons and it's weaknesses and it's useful. the Arachnotron has it's turret and it deals some major damage. At first you can ignore the tips from the Tutorial but after a while you realise that the Arachnotron's turret is annoying as hell and it has to be gone! So you use the sticky bomb launcher or the scope on the Heavy cannon and destroy it. I've never seen such a game teaching you even after the tutorial and it feels awesome. this game and it's Demons are frustrating but in a good way because it's frustarting you but after you die you keep want to try again and again until you ripped them apart. This feeling is awesome and not much game has this feeling. The Combat mechanics change everytime you meet a new Demon and after you receive a new gun. With every new gun you create new strategies to kill the enemy easier and easier but everything changes after you meet the Heavier and stronger Demons like the DOOM Hunter, Marauder and the Baron of Hell. You realise that you have to CATEGORIES the enemy. Which one should you kill at first. Which one should you leave for the last and more.  This well built up combat gives an extremely hyped push into the Combat. Analysing the Battle is one of the most important things to do because you have to understand what you're about to encounter with. The small Demons are good for ammo supplies and the bigger ones are the threat to you. This means that you have to aim for the bigger Demons first and if you're running out of ammo then you simply have to use your chainsaw to kill one of the smaller Demon. You can also save your chainsaw fuel to kill a bigger Demon but there for you have to be more experienced in the game. If you really want to kill a bigger Demon then you have to create strategies to save your ammo. The different Demons with different strategies require the categorisation in order to finish them all. Simply running into the horde will only kill you and it won't do much however, if you analyse the horde first then hunt it down then it means that you understand what the game wants you to do. Personally my favourite Demon is the Marauder because of it's combat style. It may look simple but it's complicated and hard. You have to understand the thinking of the Marauder in order to beat him. You have to analyse when he's about to come at you and attack and when he's about to put out his shield. I've seen and heared that a lot of people are complaining about him because he's imune the BGF, he's blocking every shot and that he's slowing down the combat. I don't hate these people. Everyone has it's opinion but I think that they're wrong. For example they're complaining about the dog he's sending out. Well the problem is that he only sends it out when you hit his shield or when you miss him. The dog is a punishment for your failure and I think it's a great punishment for the player. It makes the player constantly learn to be more careful about his/her combat style. It can be brutal but at the same time you should be more careful. This gives DOOM Eternal a meaning that you can't just shoot everything until it dies. You have to think about a strategy to encounter your enemy with and it makes the game so much greater. All of the combat encounters have it's hype to give you the feeling that you're the real DOOM Slayer and you want to RIP AND TEAR UNTIL IT'S DONE. No matter how much time you die, after the Combat you'll still going to feel like a god.

The Story:

DOOM Eternal has a rich story. The Game tells us a continued version of the original ark when the Slayer sacrificed himself by going to hell to save earth. DOOM Eternal tells us what happened to the Slayer after that, How did he meet the Sentinals, How did he become a Sentinal and how did he become a Demi God. The Slayer fought against Hell's forces  to save earth but after a while he was worn off and he was found by the Sentinals. He was sent into an arena where the Sentinals realized that he has an extremely big potential in him as a fighter so he became on of their soldiers. He was trained by the Sentinals for a while but in the mean time the Sentinals (Khan Maykr side) made a deal with Hell to create a new energy. They combined Hell and Sentinal energy and creater Argent Energy. This kind of energy opened new opportunites in front of the Khan Maykr to save her world. In exchange for she destroyed and killed other planets and civilizations. This time a Sentinal didn't like this this idea and granted the Slayer a gift. He gave him power to fight the Hell's and the Sentinals forces in order to save the worlds and that's where our story begins in DOOM (2016) and continues with DOOM Eternal. Overall I love the story of DOOM and the new DLC will answer new questions and probably will create new questions aswell.

The Scenery, Graphics and coloring:

DOOM Eternal has some BEAUTIFUL Graphics. The details and the maps are extremely detailed and great that sometimes you have to stop for a second and look around how it looks. The Scenery is one of the best part of this game because they're so beautiful and awesome that you have to experience it for yourself to really agree with this. Nekravol and Taras Nabad it's Scenery are just so great. I can't describe this category with more words, it speaks fot itself.

The Multiplayer:

The Battlemode is a gamemode which I don't know a lot about. I mostly played DOOM Eternal in singleplayer mode and I didn't really play in mutliplayer. All I have to say that it's completely different than the Campaign mode. New Rules, new Strategies, new Maps. Everything changes drastically. I recommend to watch tutorial videos about the multiplayer because it's so different from the Campaign that you may even think that it's not the same game. It's hard. It's hard if you don't know anything about it. The tutorial teaches you the controls and the powers of the Demon but not much about the Strategies. In the multiplayer you can choose from two sides. The Slayer or the Demons. The Slayer has to encounter two heavy Demons in an arena. As the Slayer, you have to use ALL of your experiences of the game in order to have a little chance. For the people who are relying on they're Super Shotgun. You'll loose. You will definitly loose if you'll only rely on close combat. In the Battlemode you have to work from the range. You have to use your advances in Range combat to have a bigger chance. A lot of Demons underestimate the Slayer because they're not thinking about the Slayers Range possibilities. This may give you a bigger chance of winning. On the Demon side I recommend to play with a friend. You should use the Voice chat in order to stay informed with your teammate and to understand each other better.

Last words:

Overall I love this game. It's a MASTERPIECE and it deserves more attention. If you don't like it it's okay. It's simply not your style. It's not wrong or bad to not liking something. It's completely okay but you can't change my mind. DOOM Eternal is the greatest game of 2020 and I won't stop playing it for a while.

I thank everyone who read my review about the Masterpiece, DOOM Eternal. I hope you enjoyed it or you found it helpful. Have a nice day. :)

Doom 2016 was truly a return to formula, and for me Eternal went away from that formula a bit

I don't really like any of the combat mechanics they added. I feel like the protagonist was weakened in order to push them. I'm certain that they especially increased enemy damage in order to support the new "extra life" mechanic. I mean I'm supposed to be a badass slayer yet death can become a regular part of combat, I only actually died a couple times on the normal difficulty and finished the game with over 20 of them, but still they should have just omitted it entirely and had the player focus on health and armor Instead of nerfing the protagonist to add it. I think the contributing factors to this is all of the other combat options they give you. The flame belch, the ice bomb the crucible, everything probably contributed to a overall feeling of being weaker, and they didin't all gel together in combat for me at all - especially considering that 2016 Doom stood out on simplicity. Ammo also just felt horribly nerfed. I get that I needed to upgrade it but I felt like did this to really push the chainsaw. In 2016 Doom, I was using it so I could get back to the weapons I liked the most, rather than desperately going around looking for an enemy that requires one fuel bar so I could continue fighting - even in a ton of boss fights which was super immersion breaking. I felt like I[i] needed [/i]to upgrade whereas before I felt like it just made me even stronger - mind you, playing on the same difficult across both games.

Boss fights took a huge hit as well for me. I've never seen a game give you nothing but a boss, a giant health bar, yourself and say "good luck", which is what 2016 Doom did. In this game, every boss and even new enemy came with a tutorial which took me away from the gameplay big time. Some of the bosses had a huge "wait to attack" base, which is something I never thought they would add, and it's not what I looked forward to.

All of my complaints stem from comparison with the 2016 Doom though. This is a fantastic game and the soundtrack is 10/10, it is easily worth the $30 I paid for it.

id Software cracks it out of the park again with this sequel. Chaotic fast paced combat forces players to keep up their apm lest they be slaughtered by the hordes of demons. DOOM Eternal accelerates the pace of DOOM (2016) by giving the player more movement affecting tools to traverse the battlefield more quickly. In addition to more movement options, the customization introduced in DOOM (2016) has been further expanded upon to reward combat prowess and exploration to earn character advancements. The new platforming added in DOOM Eternal feels a bit clunky, but it is a step in the right direction in expanding the complexity of level design. Most platforming portions of the game are straightforward, but I'd recommend turning up the brightness on some darker levels because it can be difficult to see where the next jump is. Overall, id has given us an amazing game and I'm glad I get to enjoy it.

As a fan of Doom 2016, I was extremely disappointed in this game. That game was great due to it's fantastic sandbox of weapons, most importantly the ability to use whatever weapon you want whenever you want. That freedom of gameplay was incredible. 

Well that's completely out the window with this game. You are basically forced to use certain weapons and attachments for certain situations, which completely takes the fun out of it. Also add the fact the you are constantly running out of ammo and the only way to replenish it is to use the chainsaw. The player shouldn't be forced to play the game in the hyper-specific way the way the developers want them to. For example, tossing a grenade down a Cacodemon's throat is by far the most efficient way of killing it, and there isn't any reason to not do it that way. It's pretty cool the first few times, but it gets old really fast when it's the only way to do it. There's layer upon layer of annoying gameplay mechanics, which is completely opposite it's predecessor's relatively pure FPS experience.  

There are a lot of goofy and totally out of place platforming segments that look straight out of Super Mario Bros., spinning fireball traps and all. I actually laughed out loud when I first came across one. The artstyle has been changed as well, to a more bright and cartoony style instead of the more gritty style of the previous game. Enemies look silly and unimposing.

Doom 2016 is one of my favorite FPS campaigns of all time alongside TItanfall 2, but this one just ain't it, chief. I totally get what they were trying to do, and I can understand why some people may like it, but it's just not what I come to Doom for. This is the perfect example for why more isn't always necessarily better.

Preface - [b]IN MY OPINION[/b]

Christ on a cream cracker is this game incredible.

This is a perfect sequel because it builds on what was good about the last game. The blood-soaked no-nonsense Doomguy is back again with a simple goal: stop demons doing demon-related things to Earth. In a world filled with games trying to have the most complex story ever, it's nice to return to simpler times.

Like I said, Doom Eternal builds on the best parts of the last game; the weapons have more grunt, the glory kills are even more gloriously violent and there are now twice as many enemy types to blow the brains out of. The rune system has also been streamlined, shooting is as tight as ever, even bigger levels means there are hundreds of collectables and the suit upgrade system has also had a bit of a revamp.

One thing this game does better than its predecessor is being utterly bonkers and bananas. Not in a wacky LOL RANDOM sort of way, more because sometimes there will be so many things going on at once you will have no clue what you're shooting at. In many games this would be extremely frustrating, but because of the perfect balance between getting a bit beaten up and health-drops from enemies you never feel like you're going to die; it's more like you've entered a red mist in which you don't know what you're shooting at, only that it needs to be shot at until it stops existing. It's exceptionally fun.

Of course, no DOOM game would be complete without a killer soundtrack, and the bassy metal perfectly encapsulates the atmosphere. Every so often you'll perform a glory kill perfectly in time with a power chord and those are the moments you'll truly understand what bliss feels like.

[h1] Hell of a good time [/h1]

NOTE: This review was originally negative due to the implementation of Denuvo software which has since been removed, I have kept my original review at the bottom of this for anyone who sees this review in later months and wonders why my opinion changed on it.

DOOM Eternal is a fantastic game. The core gameplay mechanic is simple: Kill demons. But this simplicity is not a bad thing. The mechanic is not only cathartic, but extremely well polished. With abilities such as the double jump and dash, the player is able to navigate the arenas with ease, gliding around and decimating hordes of enemies. I have seen comparisons (both positive and negative) with this feature to DOOM 2016 - I haven't played that game but am looking to do so, and I'll update this section once I have played it enough to be able to make a comparison.

This gunplay alone is not what makes playing this game the experience that it is though. Full credit has to go to Mick Gordon and the sound team on Eternal, as the pulsating soundtrack drives the player forward through each encounter, so that - even if you are as terrible at the game as I am, wildly misfiring every gun at any enemy in sight, not noticing the summoner demons - you feel like you are good at the game.

The only major drawback to this game is, in my opinion, the tutorials. The issue for me was that they broke the pace of the gameplay up a little too much, such as at the start of boss fights, when the bosses weakness is given to you. Looking back at this having just plugged 80 or so hours into Dark Souls III, this feels like the wrong way of approaching boss fights for me. Even though the DOOM Slayer is a powerful being, having the bosses weaknesses laid bare before a shot was fired made the game seem a little too simple for me. That said, it is possible to turn this off in the options, a setting which I personally found has made the boss fights a little more challenging (which I prefer), and has retained the pace of the game far better than with the tutorials on.

In conclusion? DOOM Eternal is a very good game. In a year where everything seems to be spiralling out of control globally, it's nice to play a good quality game with a great sense of catharsis. As weird as it sounds, DOOM Eternal is one of the most calming games I have played.

Please don't put Denuvo back into the game though, writing this positive review took a while.


My original review:
It genuinely saddens me that I have to leave a negative review for this game, because it is very well put together. It's incredibly satisfying, the combat is fun, it looks beautiful, and the music is still top notch.

So why am I leaving a negative review?

As many of the other recent reviews explain, in the past week a new anti-cheat software has been shoehorned into the game post-launch, after many players (including myself) have played past the 2 hour limit Steam sets for a refund. This anti-cheat software has access to a very secure level of a computer, and is touted by its own company for its invisibility when running. This software is [b] required [/b] to play DOOM. This means that at the moment, the game remains uninstalled in my library, until I can either get a refund, Bethesda/id Software changes their policy, or I remove the game from my account at my own cost to hide the shame of being mugged off to the value of £37.

What a shame.

We appreciate you taking the time to provide your review, and we hope you will give DOOM Eternal another chance.

Best regards,
Bethesda Customer Support

Great game overall. The crucible really sold me, plus the slayer gates are awesome and so are all the secrets.

Before tallying positives and negatives I want to say I wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys action games and/or fps games. It’s a joy to play and I’m really grateful for the development team's hard work! They really made something to be proud of, my hat is off to all of them! I’m still playing the game after 60 hours and that’s very special. I love it to bits basically. 🥰

+ absolutely gorgeous all the way through, great animations for enemies, runs very well on a 1070 in 1080p
+ great, pounding (sometimes a bit too pounding) soundtrack that provides momentum to the action
+ a fun take on the very dorky doom story with few (often humorous), skippable cutscenes with LOTS of lore if you’re into that
+ the fights are an absolute thrill, I came out literally sweating and cursing from some of them and shouting when I finally achieved victory
+ lots of fun weapons and movement skills to play around with
+ it’s actually difficult at times! Reminded me of Sekiro (but you have more possibilities to cheese in this game, but game can be played without the crutches BFG/Crucible, and to me that was more fun)
+ lots of item/suit/weapon upgrades and secrets give a fun sense of progression and add a break from the action
+ lots of fun enemy types that really become a challenge when bundled together
+ the slayer gates – really thrilling curated battle encounters locked behind secret keys
+ generally great, simple platforming that provides a fun break from the head-stomping
+ master levels
+ the promise of more master levels and story DLC, looking forward to all of it!

these are mostly small niggles, but some could be annoying:

- sometimes the music doesn’t let up even when you don’t have a battle encounter going, which made me stressed out and annoyed. I think this has been affecting other people as well who say they ‘feel exhausted’ after playing. I sometimes changed to other music because the came is really more chill than it wants to show 😊
- there are some bugs regarding achievements (some not popping, some popping without reason), I played this during launch so I hope they will be ironed out in time
- the controls for the few swimming portions are odd and Doomguy can’t keep his head above water. He needs swimming lessons asap, and he is very bad at exiting the water as well 😅
- some platforming moments are maybe not the most intuitive?
- some geometry issues with cragged ledges being unclimbable (except some are climbable or from some angles?), so sometimes you try climbing one and a demon gets your back 😆
- I do not enjoy the final boss. Your mileage may vary.

Much love to the developers. Going to go read some of that lore now 😘

Take strength from the hanging yellow stick to reach another area, I mean seriously, what are developers thinking really? It very sucks. Plus climbing the walls also tedious, the story is meh either. Demons invade the world and we follow their traces to kill three hell priests. It's not a deep, immersive narrative. Doom 2016 wasn't good too but at least it had presents much better gameplay.

I would have never thought I'd say it about a DOOM game... but the story is actually very good and everything is gorgeous. DOOM Eternal knows when to tell, when to show, when to let you act, feel and that's what makes it so interesting. There's a tremendous amount of effort put into the story and I like how the game encourages the player to collect all the extra info and read into it. Shooters were essentially the first games I got into when I was younger and I've played a lot of them. I still remember all the boring shooter games I've played in which everyone knows that the story is bad but the game still forces you to sit through it until you get to the action... DOOM is nothing like that. It is constant adrenaline that never feels the same.

The gameplay got upgraded. There's now actual platforming in the game and it's fairly challenging at times. In addition to that, there's upgrades for everything, collectibles, little easter eggs hidden across the map, secret encounters, upgrades in the base... a lot. I honestly can't think of anything that could have been added to this game - all you can think of is here and it creates fantastic balance between the action, exploration and extra things. The action itself is great, very fast-paced. 

DOOM Eternal is a fantastic addition to the list of modern classics by Bethesda!

As a guy with little money and a crummy rig, it seemed irresponsible of me to buy Doom Eternal the second it arrived on Steam. Since purchasing the sequel to the excellent 2016 Doom reboot of the franchise, I have had nothing but a big, sinister, blood-drenched smile on my face. I can safely say that this purchase, as quick as it was, was not a waste of my money. Doom Eternal has earned a spot in my heart as one of the best games I've played this year. For all those stuck inside during these uncertain and trying times, consider this an adrenaline coated release for all your woes and strife.

Doom Eternal takes place some time after the events of Doom 2016. The Doom Guy has reappeared after the demons that plagued Mars last time have now invaded the Earth, nearly destroying the planet. With the human race on the brink of extinction and no one seemingly capable of stopping them, it's up to you to take the fight to the horde. You have only one strategy: Rip and Tear!

Game play, like in the previous instalment, is the core of the experience. One of the main complaints about Doom 2016 was that, once you had the Super Shotgun, you could almost ignore the other weapons. In Doom Eternal, it's made clear that to survive this slaughter house, you need to use EVERYTHING. All guns have unique effects on demons and their weak points. New tools allow new benefits during game play. The chain saw gives you ammo, the glory kills give you health, and the flame belch is the latest addition that gives you armour, rounding out the survival trifecta. All of the weapons are satisfying and useful, no longer relegating the responsibility of damage to just one weapon of carnage. I was gleefully swapping from the Rocket Launcher to the Machine gun to the Shotgun the whole way through. And believe me when I say the carnage was oh so satisfactory. It was fast paced but also strategic, allowing me to feel like a crafty gun man, and not just a tanky one. Like a metal version of John Wick.

The story is another matter. By no means bad, not by video game standards at least, it is a lurch for the franchise from 2016. Before, 2016 kept its story simple with hints of greater ambitions. Here, the story absolutely drowns you in a cinematic universe's worth of lore and history. The Makers of Urdak, the Khan Maykr, the Night Sentinels; I was lost on a lot of these places and people and had to check the glossary a lot. It's not a bad thing to have a story with lots of lore, but Doom Eternal still tries to hug the tight rope between a story buffet, with elaborate cut scenes and narrative-based levels, while still trying to keep it vague and "unobtrusive to the game play." In the end, it just comes off as bloated fluff that doesn't add to the game's experience. It does have moments of pure cheesy, metal, He Man-esque joviality and carefree humour which makes it a joy to sit through. Surprisingly, the best character is often the man who never says a word.

Consumer-level complaints: Some things that members outside of gaming news and the Doom community should know. 1: The Marauder and the Tentacle enemies are considered pretty controversial. The Marauder is often called  one of the worst enemies in the game because he interrupts the flow of combat by constantly blocking the player. The tentacle is a jump scare enemy that surprises you and is often too quick. The slimy critter will take some health from you before you kill it by poking you. 2: Bethesda recently added the Denuvo anti-cheat system to the game. This particular system interfered with the performance of the game and is also highly intrusive to player systems due to its kernel-level driver. It has since been removed, due to player backlash. However, I advise people be aware of Bethesda's actions because the company might try to do something like this again.

But don't waste time. Get this game if you can. Raise hell in the best way possible! And afterwards, get Animal Crossing next.

I am not generally a fan of single player campaigns.  I am generally more of an online competitive shooter type player.  But DOOM Eternal completely swept me away.  The combat is amazing, one of the most fun systems I have experienced in a game.  Literally everything that is introduced to you is important, every enemy has a specific weakness that can be best exploited with a different weapon in your arsenal.  I was constantly thinking on my feet to choose the best option for tackling a fight.  The movement might actually be the fundamental component of game-play that made this the most pure FUN single player shooter I have played.  You feel so fast, when you get a glory kill the graphics are incredible and you feel like an absolute unstoppable force.  I picked the game up on sale just to try it out and I am now hooked on the game-play and am incredibly excited to play the next game in the series.  If you can afford it and you're looking for a game that is just purely fun and doesn't necessarily take itself 100% seriously, do yourself a favor and pick up DOOM Eternal its fantastic.

Quite possibly the best single-player FPS I've ever played.

It's not for the faint of heart; this is a very challenging game with extremely fast paced and intense combat, and it keeps you on the edge of your seat with this constant sense that you're just *barely* scraping by. The entire experience is this insane, adrenaline-pumping, high octane action game that forces you to think on your feet and put actual effort into combat. If you're a relatively casual player, this game might not be for you. If you want a game that will put you in the shoes of a badass and let you run wild in your ultimate power fantasy, this game might not be for you.

If you want a game that makes you *play* like a badass, that makes you master its systems and thrills you in ways you didn't realize a game even could, a game where you earn every victory and through your failures and experience you *become* the Doom Slayer, then this game is for you.

Excellent game.

Takes the original game and refines it to near perfection. I found the game hard for the first couple of levels as I was playing it with the original game mindset and getting killed A LOT. You need to keep moving, keep topping up ammo, health and armour constantly, and I mean constantly. If you get carried away and let one of the 3 drop too low you're in a world of hurt.

The atmospherics of the game are different to the original too; I found the last game dark and brooding (and violent) whereas Eternal is more varied (and violent).

The weapons are well balanced and the mods are interesting and varied. The lower order weapons like the shotgun get relegated pretty quickly though and you find yourself using them primarily for the secondary mode which is OK I guess.

There is an overwhelming number of mods, suit upgrades, runes etc in this game which can be a bit too much to start with but eventually I loved it as you can really fine tune the Doom Slayer the way you want - obviously you want to max that out of course.

The storyline is about as compelling as the original - ie not much to get excited about - it doesn't get in the way of the game.

Graphically it's super slick, there are probably better looking games but everything is moving at 200mph so who cares. Maxed out graphics on a 3440x1440 ultra widescreen @ rock solid 60FPS. On a Nvidia GTX 1080 / Core i7-8700 laptop (last gen hardware). Cannot complain!

Once you get into the flow with this game it's just ace - it will take a few hours of frustration on the harder modes but worth the challenge and hella satisfying to wipe the floor with demons that were kicking your ass yesterday!

Doom Eternal is a shooter unlike many others. Compared to 2016, 2016 is much, much tamer as a game. Eternal's movement is more refined, with dashes, double jumps, and more options in the slayer's arsenal. The blood punch, flame belch, frag and frost grenades. Weapons with mods to be unlocked, upgraded, and mastered. Runes to refine the art of combat, and Praetor Suit upgrades, to make things easier on yourself. Sentinel Crystals, increasing armor, health, and ammo, and upgrading certain aspects of the suit the regular upgrades miss. And a ton of collectibles, cosmetic armor, toys, albums, and even cheat codes. This game is a masterpiece in brutal, arena shooters, (except for the occasional crash), and should be played by anyone, with a PC of sufficient power. Rip and Tear, until it is done.

I enjoyed my time with Doom Eternal a lot. I experienced countless moments when I win a battle by the skin of my teeth and, with just a few health points left, breathe a sigh of relief, let the adrenaline settle a bit and get ready for the next arena. Killing demons is a great fun and surprisingly never gets old or stale, due to huge variety of enemies and your arsenal. 
However, Doom Eternal is quite a different experience than Doom 2016. The new mechanics change the feel of the game rather drastically and not everybody might like it. I personally really enjoyed the fact that you get all your resources by killing enemies, even if some portions of your arsenal are a bit fiddly to use. Being able to recover from the brink of death during a fight really helps to keep the pace up, and you will never face a situation when after a fight you're low on health and ammo and have to backtrack to regain some before the next encounter.
I do however have several nitpicks. The way you get ammo and health now means that boss fight are no longer duels of equals. Instead, now bosses have their own entourage, which is fine if they are some lower demons but becomes problematic later on, when bosses fill half a screen and their minions include barons of hell and cybermancubuses. It really turns fights into a clusterfuck that is less of a desperate fight for survival and more a chore. If authors wanted to have a story, they should have told all the important parts in the cut scenes and not in the codex entries. The pick ups need rebalancing, as by the end I was able to unlock everything and still have weapon points and suit points available. The design of pick ups in general is not great, as bright, colorful icons don't fit with overall aesthetics of the game.
This are however just a small issues of a very solid game. I wouldn't buy it for 60 bucks but if you can get it during sale you definitely should.
It's like Doom, but with more Doom.

I hate to give this a 'No', but it feels like too much of a departure from the feel of Doom. I loved Doom 2016, I wanted a sequel to Doom 2016. This is something that uses Doom 2016 as a reference only. There is less feel of sci-fi horror. The art style is too bright, too comic bookish/cartoony. The fights are not about raw brutality. Extra lives are a thing to collect and fight difficulty even at Hurt Me Plenty is tuned to make you use them, Glory Kills are now something you must do if you want to keep your health up, chainsaw kills are required to gain ammo due to extreme ammo scarcity for even the basic weapons, switching weapon types to match monster 'weaknesses' is required to not run out of ammo trying to just gun them down, and worst of all (imo) is the introduction of a monster type that requires fighting at a specific range and timing your attacks as counter attacks. I'm sure some people will enjoy the new feel of the fights and the new art style, but it isn't for me. As I approach the end of the single player game I find the fights more frustrating than fun. If another Doom sequel is made in this same style I'll definitely pass on it.

On the plus side, the technical execution of things has been fantastic. I've run into no major bugs or crashes.

review: Took a little bit to fully come-round, but I think this game might even be better than the first (if that's possible). They kept much of the original structure while adding marked improvements to your arsenal and mobility options. If you liked the 2016 DOOM, this game is definitely for you.

so much gore so much lore very nice

I wouldn't say I loved it more than Doom 2016 but it is an incredibly fast paced game with great mechanics.  In terms of story it's incredibly metal but the story feels less immersive and more arcade-like than it's predecessor.  

The in your face grind to a halt tutorials all the time are annoying, mostly unnecessary and just bad in the way they are done.

The game shines in the gameplay.  It's fast and it's incredibly intense.  

The levels are broken into transition areas full of somewhat mediocre platforming though great looking areas and demon full arenas that are balls to the wall crazy fun.

The most vicious enemy in the game is the limited amount of ammo you can carry.  It forces you to swap guns and use the wide, maybe to wide a variety of skills for the pace, to gain back health, armor, and ammo.  

Overall the game performs incredibly well and is a blast to play even if it seems a bit silly Metalocalypse at times instead of the more serious Doom 2016.

Overall in spite of my criticisms it's a hell of a lot of fun to play.  If you want action and metal then this is for you if you want engaging story then I'm sorry Rip and Tear is the plot.

Ok I have some mixed feelings about this game. On the one hand general gameplay is maybe the best I've ever played. It's smooth and responsive, fun as hell. But sometimes there's just TOO much going on. Like you want to chainsaw but you accidentally waste something useful, or you want one gun and you grab another and die. And the 2 final bosses are absolutely dreadful, the antithesis of doom. But overall I had a great time, until the last 2 encounters. I do recommend this game to practically anyone, however. It's a blast also, that slime stuff is truly awful

The game-play is a masterpiece. On Ultra-nightmare, you have to be constantly alert, there is not down time during fights. You have so many weapons and pieces of equipment, and they all keep you alive in some manner or another, so you have to learn to use them! The story is not as good as the first game, but is is serviceable. They make some classic "putting something on stage that never gets used" errors. Another Bethesda game. Crashes frequently, glitches are rampant. The story was good and the new mechanics were a good idea, but they are horribly implemented. Unique combonations of enemies get replaced with just throwing in a few of the hard hitters to make it "difficult". The stages just become reskins of previous stages. yea

It's DOOM, but you have to have a brain to play it (some what). Gone are the days of running around mindlessly killing demons. Now you have to think on your feet and swap up your play-style on the fly to accommodate the ever changing battle around you. Some sleight ammo management thrown in also. The movement system is pretty damn good too. Pretty easy to pick up, and lets you become a real monster when you get it down a bit. The graphics are pretty insane on PC. Everything loads quickly and runs smooth at Ultra on a 2k 120hz monitor pushing around 140 fps (dunno why it's not syncing up with my monitors refresh rate tho. Haven't bothered to look) Nice they added more things to unlock also. (skins for MP & Campaign, gun skins, loading pedestals, etc) You can obtain mostly everything it seems just by playing the campaign if you want. All in all, it's a very solid game so far. Story seems decent also. A good bit more fleshed out than DOOM 2016.

This game is a complete and total improvement over the last game (Doom 2016) which was already a great game

More mechanics such as: The Crucible, Flame Belch, frag and ice grenades with each adding more strategy to the overall game flow for example: flame belch making enemies explode armor when killed while on fire.

Final boss: Actually difficult this time same with the other bosses.

More difficult: adding to the fact that the Slayer gets stronger and stronger the more demons he kills, you fight way more demons at once and most are heavies or medium demons. By the end game you're decimating several powerful demons at once. (beautiful game design here)

And finally my overall favorite new aspect: Visible damage. As you rip and tear the demons you take parts of their flesh and bone off making super powerful demons have exposed guts and bones by the time you're shoving their snapped forearm into their face in a glory kill.

What a game! The new movement abilities (dash, meathook), allow you to move around the well-designed arenas fluidly and with great control. Runs well and performs like a Triple-A title. A worthy sequel to Doom (2016) and an awesome addition to the Doom family.
