[h1]Score: 8/10[/h1] 


While the graphics, animations, and gameplay are amazing, technical problems and some game design issues hold [i]DOOM Eternal[/i] back from achieving its full potential.


[h1]Pros[/h1] 
[list]
[*]Incredible action that is a test of your reflexes and simultaneous knowledge of the game's weapons, enemies, and environments. These elements are balanced nearly perfectly, creating a mix that is dynamic, challenging, and rewarding.
[*]Great production values. It's made with love and seemingly infinite appreciation for its source material. At the same time, it never takes itself too seriously.
[*]Graphically superior and very well optimized in terms of graphical performance for the PC.
[*]Actually a pretty decent multiplayer mode that gets the jitters and adrenaline pumping, partly on account of the high skill gap. You're going to get pwned *a lot* in this mode, but don't give up!
[/list]
[h1]Cons[/h1] 
[list]
[*]Several bugs, design oversights, and crashes remain. I had crashes while taking screenshots in some areas: "Application has been blocked from accessing graphics hardware" error. I've even had a bug where the final enemy in a room was indestructible. The worst of them all is a common bug on both PC and console versions that causes the game to crash after completing Slayer Gates in Mission Select mode, causing you to lose all level progress and preventing you from obtaining the Empyrean Keys needed for the game's secret weapon. In this vein, if you crash at any point while in Mission Select mode, you will have to restart from the beginning of the level. Also, the Battlemode tutorials are unskippable. If you initiate one by accident, you'll be forced to play through it, or force quit the game!
[/list]
[h1]Summary[/h1] 

This cheesy arena shooter is keenly self-aware and builds on practically all aspects of the series while introducing a gamut of its own ideas. The single-player campaign is especially strong, but the well balanced and nuanced gameplay overall kept me wanting to improve my skills and take on other aspects of the game beyond the campaign. Some poor design and technical problems make the game feel slightly unfinished, as though it needed just a bit more time in the cooker to bring everything together. This is unfortunate because in many ways [i]DOOM Eternal[/i] is something special. It's just not quite as a good as it could have been.

[table]
    [tr]
        [td][b]Story[/b][/td]
	[td]4/10[/td]
	[td]One of the silliest stories I've experienced in recent memory, but at least they make an effort to own up to the source material and do what they can. It must be hard making a narative out of something with such an absurd plot to begin with! The lore does a decent enough job for players interested in learning more about the game world, although I felt that the setting of earth was way underutilized.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
        [td][b]Gameplay[/b][/td]
	[td]9/10[/td]
	[td]Top notch and masterfully balanced action with a high skill gap. It's easy to learn, difficult to master, and rewarding the whole way, but it can be frustrating. The platforming is only good when it is woven into the fighting sequences. The pure platforming sequences are tedious and hurt the game's pace overall. The scripted cinematic sequences that take place duiring the campaign while manning turrets and vehicles, using certain objects, etc., are entertaining to watch, but I would have preferred to have control of the input in these cases.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
        [td][b]Graphics[/b][/td]
	[td]9/10[/td]
	[td]Amazing enemy models, animations, gore, glory kills, weapons, loot effects, etc. Great customization options. It's really state of the art in this regard. The environments are beautiful, but I wish they were more interactive in some cases. The wonderfully macabre environments would come to life even more if they were destructible![/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
        [td][b]Sound production[/b][/td]
	[td]9/10[/td]
	[td]Incredible sound quality, effects, and OST in so many ways. Great customizability too.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
        [td][b]Difficulty[/b][/td]
	[td]8/10[/td]
	[td]The fights can be extremely challenging, especially while you're getting used to all the different tools at your disposal and the intricacies of the various enemies you'll encounter. The game has a hardcore permadeath mode if you're up for it. In other areas, the game is quite forgiving though. Having all collectibles and most secrets detailed in the dossier/map seems to defeat the purpose of a treasure hunt, making this aspect of the game feel more like a compulsive chore than an actual accomplishment.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
        [td][b]Multiplayer[/b][/td]
	[td]6/10[/td]
	[td]The multiplayer takes some getting used to, but I came to enjoy it quite a bit. Matches can be super intense, and there is a high skill gap. It's brought down by a clunky UI, both during matches and in menus. It also takes far too long to get into matches by modern standards, and the map rotation is almost always interrupted because someone leaves the lobby, and if someone leaves during a match, it's game over essentially--couldn't they have figured something out to avoid these issues?[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
        [td][b]Replay value[/b][/td]
	[td]8/10[/td]
	[td]There are so many ways you can add variety to this game, whether it's playing through the campaign on harder difficulty levels, finding collectibles, applying one of the many cheat codes that create fun modifiers, or delving into the multiplayer. The home base is a nice addition but it feels a bit bland, not to mention slightly out of place for the single-player campaign. It would be nice if there were some NPCs and/or more things to do there. Why isn't this a place I'm able to hang out and explore while looking for a multiplayer match?[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
        [td][b]Overall value for asking price ($60)[/b][/td]
	[td]8/10[/td]
	[td]This a state of the art game in many ways and is probably the best one in the arena shooter genre right now. There is a lot of high quality content.[/td]
[/tr]

I'm exhausted -- seriously. This feels like less like mindless carnage and more like dance-dance-revolution with guns. Disappointed that Id is taking this game in a different direction, but I think this was more of a passing the torch kinda game for me -- kinda like the new Star Wars series for the younger generation.

I don't recommend this game for die-hard doom fans that are all about the freedom to wreak carnage the way you want. This game literally tells you the EXACT way to kill a demon, which seems like a step backwards in this game brand's philosophy.

That being said, this game is for a lot of people! A lot of people with a lot more, focus, mental-wit, and patience than me! I guess I just have a bit of buyer's remorse because in the 30 years that I've played DOOM games on a vary degree of difficulties, this has never been what it's about.

Doom Eternal is a true evolution that builds upon everything from Doom 2016. This game is all killer no filler: levels are more interesting both aesthetically and layout-wise; lame weapons like the pistol and frag grenades are dropped in favor of more inspired weaponry like a Ballista and a shoulder-mounted grenade launcher/flame thrower; the battle chess is more strategic with various resources to manage and enemy prioritization to think about; the generic multiplayer is dropped in favor of a demons vs slayer 2v1 mode that actually plays to the game's strengths; even the story is better, providing a deeper, more interesting lore-rich narrative while still making it almost completely optional/avoidable if that's your thing.

I'm about halfway through at this point and my biggest gripe so far is the Marauder. Criticism around this enemy is all over the internet and while I see id's philosophy of wanting to make an enemy that would act as the Doom Slayer's equal - someone to really stress you out and give it your all - the inability to inflict damage on the enemy until he provides you with a window to counter, I believe, goes against all design pillars of this game, forcing you to essentially corner him and dance around him just *waiting* on HIM to make a move so you can hit him a couple times. I think the Marauder worked best in his first encounter as a sort of mini boss, perhaps one that should have returned throughout the campaign and acted as a rival for the Doom Slayer getting stronger with each encounter, instead of being a almost regular occurrence in the arenas.

Aside from my gripe with the Marauder, I definitely recommend this game as it stands. If you liked Doom 2016, you're going to like Doom Eternal; if you like the new Wolfenstein games, you're going to like Doom Eternal; and if you like meaty single-player first person shooters, then you're going to like Doom Eternal. I picked this up for $30 during the Summer Sale and I'm honestly bummed that I didn't pony up $60 at launch because I would not have been disappointed.

I don't get it. I loved the original dooms. I thought doom 2016 was incredible (minus the lame boss battles). There are only certain ways to kill each enemy in doom eternal, otherwise they are tedious bullet sponges. There is never enough ammo. Switching weapons and weapon mods is the whole game. The weapon wheel takes up 90% of gameplay. The enemies are practically hit scanners because the arenas are all just a bowl full of monsters and the fact you need to use (spam) the invincibility of the glory kills to even survive is boring and feels broken. In doom 2016 it wasn't required to live and you were okay to just shoot demons until they die. Now it's shoot exactly as many times as needed and then zoom into the enemy and be invincible for a second. It is very stuttery gameplay. Doom 2016 you felt like part of the game, this you feel so removed. All the intensity is sucked out by the formulaic approach you must play. It feels like it is using the terrible mid nineties elaborate combo systems games like killer instinct had where you need to spend so much trial and error to figure anything out. FPS games, doom especially, should be run and shoot, not analyze the enemies, select correct weapon, hit specific weak spot without using too much ammo, spam glory kill, switch weapon, select mod, flame thrower on this enemy type for shield. It's just a mess that's not fun.

review:
Man where do I even start, imo this game is just bloody amazing.

Once again, Mick Gordon hands out eargasms with his headbangin' compositions. 11/10 OST.

Eternal's very different from Doom 2016 in many ways, with some negative but mostly positive. 
You can easily tell that this game was meant to be friendly to people new to the Doom franchise, from the sometimes jarring tutorial popups to the bright visuals. Doom Eternal is visually much more colorful, vs. the dark horror vibes of 2016. I personally preferred 2016's vibe much more though. This is also reflected in the UI, which was glaringly off-putting if you were to compare it to 2016.

The designs of the weapons, enemies, and levels were excellent. I found myself stopping and admiring certain areas of levels, the side of the ballista blade mod, and even tiny sections of a floor, sometimes for minutes at a time (Maybe due to my artistic disposition. I'll definitely be using some elements of this game as future references and inspiration).
The weapons are beautifully complex in terms of design, revamped from the previous Doom game. 
The already humanoid demons have been made to look much more "human", particularly their faces, which also added to the more colorful look of Eternal. The Baron does look much more badass though, now being infused with fire, revealed by the new gory gibbing system. You can remove massive chunks of your enemies flesh as you damage them. 
Now onto the levels themselves. Here you fight from the depths of Hell, the ravaged surface of Earth, the sci-fi facilities of Phobos, and to even the beautiful ruins of forgotten cities. The level designs are extremely diverse and just so impressive.
The world of Urdak was so awesome. Urdak's architecture reminds me of the orokin from Warframe, which is super cool. In some cases, it literally looked like I [i]was[/i] playing warframe, and inside of a Clan Dojo. 

The gameplay is what seems to have garnered the most complaints from other players. For a variety of reasons, I don't share the same opinions. 
Ammo is more scarce in Eternal. Your chainsaw, the main ammo source, needs to be used more often. Some people consider this a chore, but another change is that your chainsaw fuel regenerates, in addition to having many small fry to saw up. So I didn't mind this new ammo system at all. 
Another common complaint is about the marauder. Combat-wise he's a bit clunky but I don't understand the hate for him, he's not deathly hard nor is he extremely disruptive. Lore-wise he's super cool. Demonized sentinels man, super badass. 
Eternal also introduces a new climbing and dashing system, giving rise to more vertical level designs with many "puzzles", platforming, and parkour which I LOVE to death. Some people hated this but I say to hell with them. 
The relative difficulty of Eternal has increased considerably compared to 2016's due to the presence of more ranged enemies. This is where the dashing comes in, which also increases the already fast-pace of Doom. 
Not much to say about the glory kills. As visceral and violent as ever. Rip and Tear.

Finally, the story. I L O V E T H E L O R E. I couldn't wait to find each new codex page and finding out more about the Doom world. I'm just a casual so I can't really judge how well written the story is, but I can say that I enjoyed it way too much. The cut-scenes are now occasionally third-person to help push the narrative, which some people disliked because it took them away from the feeling of being the Slayer himself. Previously the Doom guy didn't really have a real established identity so it helped people immersive themselves as the Slayer. I was never one for self-insert so I didn't mind in the least. In fact, I prefer it this way because now I can admire the epic design of the praetor suit(s) during the cut-scenes lol.

To sum it up, I [i]love love love[/i] this game. I exclusively buy games at 50% off or more, but this was an exception. I bought at full price, no regrets.

10/10

I played Doom Eternal on day 1 and loved it to death. However in the coming weeks Bethesda made the questionable decision to patch in Denuvo. This choice has thankfully been reversed, removing the terrible cloud floating above an otherwise excellent game. No offense to the dev team, the community would not respond so strongly about these things if we didn't care about your game. It's a real work of art and we want it to be the best it can be as well.

Okay so Doom Eternal is another fast paced game in the Doom series that has made a lot of changes to the Doom 2016 for better or worse. This game now has many new mechanics that increase Doom Guy's mobility including a dash and ability to stick to and jump off of climbable walls. These mechanics are fairly fun to execute in combat, and are also used in platforming sections that break up the action (These are fairly short and simple). 

Also introduced is a flame thrower to make enemies drop armor, a new melee attack that does high damage to enemies in front of the doom guy, 2 grenade types to aid in crowd control, and the chainsaw is now less of a weapon and more of an ability. The Gameplay loop is simple but the execution is fast paced and complex. Certain weapons hard counter certain enemies forcing weapon swapping. Ammo pools are at an all time low meaning that players much remember to take time to chainsaw enemies for ammo. Typically how things work: You shoot demons, chainsaw when available (unless you are saving 3 charges for a big boy) for ammo, flamethrower on cooldown for armor refills, and weave in grenades and blood punches when needed. If that sounds like a lot... It is... This game is fast paced and almost overwhelming with the amount of options you can and must take advantage of to succeed. Doom Eternal features many many upgrades for the Doom Guy, his suit, and most substantially his weapons that can greatly change how you tackle the demon hordes.

 You might be thinking... "This sounds like a lot of fast paced thinking compared to Doom 2016", you'd be correct. This is Doom Eternal's strength but also it's weakness. Making a fun fast and vicious game that also kind of loses some of the brutal simplicity of 2016. Make no mistake that Doom Eternal is a great game, but it has a lot of differences compared to 2016 and it is not everybody's cup of tea.

Okay now that the important gameplay stuff is out of the way... The visuals are top notch, everything looks and feels great, the world designers are masters of their craft, the audio folks are equally impressive, and the soundtrack is bangin. The story is somewhat crap, but it seems to accept and run with that fact, which sometimes works and sometimes doesn't, I appreciate the effort, but it's not why we are here.

tl:dr: One of the Best Action FPS in long time, it does have a different approach to combat than Doom 2016 though and this might turn a few people off.

Denuvo Anti-Cheat was removed making my initial skepticism invalid. I'll probably rebuy the game and play through it. Keep Bethesda's behavior in mind though; they only removed Denuvo because of the massive outcry.


Original review:
I'll probably return this game as it uses a very dodgy rootkit for "anti-cheat" known as Denuvo anti-cheat. 
Denuvo anti-tamper, which the game launched with is general okay, though still DRM-bullshit. 
Denuvo anti-cheat on the other hand is unacceptable. It requires the highest level access on your system and can pretty much do ANYTHING if they want it to. It also stays in your system even if you uninstall the game. This is a MASSIVE security problem especially coming from a unethical company such as Denuvo. 
The fact that Bethesda or ID soft put this in months after release is incredibly sketchy and downright insidious. I can honestly say I'll not buy any future titles from either unless they are completely DRM-Free so I wont have to deal with forced updates like this.

review: Randomly runs from 200+ to 5FPS. Glory kills cut the rythms of fights, low amount of ammos forcing to use the chainsaw, boring game design.

A lot of people seem to really like this game. I liked Doom 2016 despite having a lot of issues with it. It was a really worthy entry in the franchise once I got past the admittedly big issues I had with the game. Did Doom Eternal work on these issues and turn out to be better than 2016?

Uhhhh I don't know?

This is like the most mixed bag fucking sequel I've played in awhile. I don't think I've ever had to think this hard about whether a game was worth experiencing or not. I'm going to start with the issues I have since you can probably find a whole bunch of the positives below.

The early game is hot GARBAGE. In 2016 it was slow and boring. In Eternal its aggressively bad to the point where this is actually one of my biggest issues with the game. Jesus fuck is it not only slow, but the early game features some of the most questionable game design I've seen in awhile where they took everything that made early 2016 slow and...made it worse? The maximum starting ammo feels and probably is lower. I played on Nightmare and I don't pretend to be an expert player, of course I wasted shots here and there so I was near constantly running out of ammo. Which lead to looking for pickups or waiting for my chainsaw to recharge. And when I was mostly relying on the chainsaw this means seeing the same chainsaw animations. Over. And. Over. And. Over. again while fighting Imps, Possessed, and Cacodemons. Ah yes, Doom, the series I want to play for its deep ammo conservation mechanics.
Ah well, no big deal though running out of ammo for the shotgun! My infinite ammo, charged shot, backup pistol exists to headshot those pesky fodder! Uh, what do you mean they removed the pistol for the early game? Okay, not a problem, not a big deal. I'll just conserve ammo on those mindless zombies by punching them into a glory ki- oh it takes upwards of 5 melee hits to get a zombie into glory kill mode? Well uh, chainsaw and ammo pickups it is then. Well the enhanced mobility I've heard so much about should come in han- oh the dash is unlocked beyond this mission. How the FUCK did the first few missions get playtested and get approved?
I mean luckily this is a game that you can tell is going to get better. Chainsawing will become less frequent as you gain weapons, ammo upgrades exist, the dash is going to eventually come, grenades will eventually come too, mods will become available, enemies become more varied. Still though, ANY game's early game being this infuriatingly bad is inexcusable and could have been improved SIGNIFICANTLY with a pistol or actual fucking melee damage or the dash being present or the heavy machine gun/grenades being available earlier or removing the pointless praetor suit and sentinel crystal upgrade shit and letting me have NORMAL (please note, not a broken amount, a fucking NORMAL) amount of health/armor/ammo? That leads into another of my gripes.

Yeah the upgrade system. Why does it exist? Just to make me engage in unfun exploration and platforming just to find "upgrades" to things that...shouldn't actually need upgrading? Ah great a normal amount of armor and ammo, just the kinds of upgrades I really like. Oh I have respectable weapon swap speeds now and my frag grenades are no longer shit? Great. It's like the design team literally went "Okay here's what the norm should be. Let's just remove some armor, ammo, and general features from the player and mix them with actual upgrades to flesh out our upgrade system so we can justify having an upgrade system." I had this same fucking problem with 2016. The only reasonable upgrade systems are for the weapons and runes.

And here's a whole bunch of minor gripes that add up. The platforming is boring as shit and takes up too much game time. Exploration isn't that great. Buff Totems are pointless additions that literally pause combat to encourage exploration in combat zones(the fuck?). Goo that slows you down, removes your ability to effectively dash, and removes your ability to jump (in a sequel that added enhanced mobility?). Tentacles are pointless trap monsters that just exist to fuck with you during exploration for some reason. Marauder, despite being easy to fight once you got his gimmick down, isn't FUN to fight at all. Art changes from 2016 to Eternal are mixed bag. I think the Praetor Suit and some demons look worse (Wtf did they do to the Revenant and why?), but some enemies look dope as hell (The old school Cyberdemon design is much better than 2016's design). The change from first person only during cinematic moments to mix between first and third SUCKS and the game lacks a lot of those charming expressive moments in the first person that 2016 had. Doom Slayer death animations literally lack all of the charm they had in 2016. Most of the boss encounters are just not that fun. Those cutscenes where Doomguy talks weren't nearly as cool as the writers probably thought they were. Glory kill challenges are still not enjoyable at all. I don't think the Crucible is that enjoyable of an addition.

Okay...now the good. General combat arena shit has been greatly improved with the enhanced mobility for the most part. Mid to late game fights in both games are basically the highlights of the game. Its fast, frantic, and has a very good pace to it. Enemy weakpoints implementation is pretty good. Weapons feel good, mods are generally fun and useful. The combat arena design is overall about the same in terms of quality as it was in 2016. Slayer Gates are the best parts of the campaign. The Unmaker is in this game. Fuck yes. The music is pretty great and atmospheric. Environmental design can be pretty cool at times (dead giant mechs posed over dead giant demons). The Fortress of Doom has some neat easter eggs in it.

That's it for the positives to be honest. It may not seem like a lot, but those positives were enough to drag me to the end of the game. I'm at the final level of the game right now and while I don't regret my purchase, I would say overall I don't feel the experience has been entirely worth the negatives. Obviously different people will feel differently, but there are so many issues in this game that I actually consider to be straight up bad game design, I'm really wondering why people praise it so highly.

review:
TL:DR: A ton of fun.  Single player campaign is great, but short.  Multiplayer and story are lacking.  
Get it on sale, and enjoy the ride while it lasts.  3/5
-----------------------------------------
I bought this as my first real FPS game as a way to generally get better at gaming.  (They never have been my forte). It's definitely a thrill ride.  I appreciated intuitive controls and appropriately scaled difficulties.  The enemies each have their own weakness, which seemed balanced.  My main gripe is that I got ~50 hrs total out of it before I'd maxed out every stat, upgraded every weapon, found every secret, and beaten ever boss 2 times over. Then I was left with a "now what" moment where I'd felt I'd completed everything the game had to offer.  

Pros: graphics, intuitive controls, soundtrack is sweet and matches the game well, varying difficulties scale well

Cons: Story is lacking and has a lot of backstory holes (but it's DOOM, so what did you expect?), and the multiplayer is just not enjoyable in my opinion.  You'd sit forever in a lobby to wait through more player animations, to a quick fight, then back to more loading screens.  The single player campaign is very fun, but too short.

The whole game was satisfying. The lore, the gameplay, the soundtrack and weapons. The new added gameplay mechanics make it way more fun to play. A little off compare to the previous game due to the design differences. Overall, this is still a doom game we all hope for. They didn't let us down.

Rip and tear. Amazing game, longer then i expected. Game style is a bit different then 2016, but it's hell of a lot  of fun to play. Would highly recommend to pick up, if you love the Doom series. Got on sale for over 60% off well worth it.

The bottom line is that this game is a masterpiece and an example of a series reboot gone right.  While most modern shooters incorporate a rewarding cover system and other mechanics such as peaking that reward staying in one safe area, the motto of the Doom franchise remains the same: keep moving or die.  Doom Eternal takes the classic DOOM mechanics and cranks everything up to 11.  The slayer is as agile as ever and has abilities that are seldom seen in the FPS genre, such as glory kills (cinematic finishers), dashing, and much more!  Doom Eternal is a fast-paced chess game and learning to master everything takes time, but is oh so rewarding.

[h1] [i] RIP AND TEAR [/i] [/h1]

Game of the year and probably one of the best first-person shooters ever created!

There are certain things I preferred about the tone of Doom 2016, but this is an overall improvement with the gameplay cranked up to 11. As a fan of classic Doom, I really appreciated all of the monster designs and callbacks that were included.

At first, it feels like there are a lot of superfluous systems in-play here, but once you get acclimated to the "Doom dance," this is probably some of the most-fun I've had with a video game in years. Mick Gordon's incredible soundtrack is the icing on this fiery cake of damnation - just AMAZING.

Buy, buy, BUY this game!!

The most enjoyable singleplayer game I have ever played. My hearth starts racing, I start to feel the blood pumping through my veins. The soundtrack just hits different. The timing on the music is impeccable. Just a great game!

[h1] TLDR: This really ain't it chief. [/h1]

Starting with the opening mission you are dumped into the new hub zone (I will return to this shortly) and a bunch of plot threads are thrust in your face without proper introduction. I genuinely wondered if I had missed a game between 2016 and this one to explain why the fuck you suddenly have a space station and what the makyrs were cause the opening story beats were incredibly jarring. The story would be fine, just like the first games, if they properly set the new story beats up rather than smacking you around the face with them.

After each mission you return back to a hub which is one of the worst implementations of a hub in any game. It slows the story pacing to a crawl and serves no purpose besides being a place to get a few unlockables and see some of the stuff you collect during missions. That is it.

I think the most weird change they made to this game is the changes to level exploration. For the love of god stop making this a platformer. The swing bars and bounce pads are actually nice additions to combat letting you get some good verticality in combat but going full spiderman on a wall in first person just looks dumb. As I said, Doom isn't a platforming game so it's just confusing why they fill the breaks in combat with tedious platforming sections.

Finally the combat....they had basically perfected the formula in 2016 all id had to do was not change to much and add in a few new enemies and guns. That was it. But they decided to change things, the guns feel and sound as good as ever but the ammo economy is a total mess and the glory kill system from 2016 got broken up for no reason other than forcing you to engage with new systems. This is a pure case of justifying feature creep. The flamethrower is simply there to turn enemies into armour vending machines instead of acting like a flamethrower should. And I've legitimately never had to use the ice grenade. The game also pauses just before you go to face a new type of demon so it can tell you all about it's weak spot which in my opinion totally devalues being able to exploit weaknesses as you never get that moment of discovery.  

For the most part the new enemies the game introduces are pretty good, Archvile is kinda annoying but nothing the bfg can't handle, however the Marauder is a problem. A serious problem. People meme on marauder shields in mass effect but in doom they take the piss. The game teaches you early on that you can use the plasma rifle to destroy energy shields but not the case here. The dudes energy shield is impervious to everything and the marauder pops it up the instant you start firing not letting you take advantage of the windows where he has it down so he can snipe at you. The marauder continually summons a wolf that harasses you and causes staggers, you can't just kill it and move on cause it'll just be back a few seconds later unless you sit in the nebulous "mid-range" the helpful tool tip mentioned. Then you just have to wait for the marauder to attack you for a bit while invulnerable and then open itself up for a stagger by it flashing green where you get a very short window to shoot it so god forbid you be trying to shoot the dog or anything else. Then it sits there for a second to let you damage it then it's back to being immune to all damage until it feels like making itself staggerable. This enemy feels so out of place in a doom game and forces the combat pace to slow to a crawl until its dispatched. id needs to rework this enemy to stop it being such an annoyance. Letting you kill the shield with the plasma rifle would be a nice start and allowing you to damage it when it puts its shield down to snipe would be great starts.

Finally, a more personal problem, this game crashes a lot and the frame rate is really unstable. Legitimately after every slayer gate my game will ctd, half the time it won't even save my completion so I have to do it again and hope it saves this time. Eventually I just gave up on doing them because it got so irritating that this recurring issue continued to happen. The same ctd would occur during level traversal, particularly the arc facility mission.

Overall this is a highly disappointing sequel to an extremely beloved game. The game's director seems to have lost the magic behind the first game and seems to be adding new features and enemies not caring whether they help or hinder the game. The game is hard carried by the visuals, music and weapon feel. I hope id revert the changes to the glory kill system, curb the platforming, remove the hub and rework problematic enemy types like the marauder. Because if they don't I very much doubt I will be buying the next doom game should they choose to make it.

[b] 4/10 (only because the soundtrack is so fire) [/b]

No room for being creative.  Anyway,  I'm sure there are a lot of people who disagree and love the game.  Again, not saying the game is bad, it's just not in my lane.  Played for 7.9 hours.

One of the best FPS ever made, awesome rewarding exploration, upgrades after upgrades, and it truly deserves a spot at the table of legendary FPS like Halo 3, and the likes. Just 100% my save slot for story mode and it was the most fun I've had 100% a game in a awhile, cheat codes are fun when you picking up the collectibles and stuff on your 2nd time thru missions.

Just my opinion: it feels like an expansion of the previous game in the series. With less ammo. But it's a must-play for the fans of the franchise.

PROS:
- Pretty good graphics
- Interesting terrain and maps
- Ideal for the fans of the classic shooter
- Interesting weaponry upgrades
- The game becomes better on its second half
- Some of the boss fights are great
- Once you get access to the higher-tier weapons you can feel the power
- Full Ultrawide support

CONS:
- The story could have been better
- You never have enough ammo, no matter how much you jump, run, kill and use the chainsaw
- Some cinematics feel like bits of a cheap CGI content
- On higher difficulties the game is way too hard (don't try Nightmare, you will get frustrated)
- It takes quite a lot of time and effort to get new weapons
- Too many jumping "puzzles"
- Some parts of the design look very similar to the Warhammer franchise design
ID/Beth removed the invasive virus protection and fixed a lot of the bugs. Been having fun lately, esp with the Master sets. Hopefully they continue to provide content.

review:
Game so good I got it on PC when I upgraded just so I could experience it with M+KB. Worth it.
Possibly the best shooter I've played, as it focuses on making the game fun without forcing all that "cover mechanics" and "reloading" crap on you. Which makes for a much better game than pretty much any other shooter I have played. You are the god damn Doomslayer, and it makes it clear how you are the badass who kills demons from the start, instead of most games have you be a generic soldier or something who just kills endless enemies cos protagonist.
Soundtrack is really good, and I don't even like metal. Played once with the soundtrack on, but gone back through levels for collectables with the mamma mia soundtrack and some river dancing tunes, that works too.
Story isn't the crown jewel here, but it provides the lore that you can read into while back at your space castle, and the story presented serves it's purpose for getting the Doomslayer from spine-tearing at location A to ass-tearing at location B. It's fun tho. Never bored me, as custscenes were short and normally contained some sweet sweet murder.
Multiplayer is pretty fun for a while, but nothing to get too excited about, but the campaign makes up for it.
Basically, if you are looking for a great single-player shooter with the most fluid and fun-focused attitude to game design, this is your game. It is simple, but not boring.
If you prefer a more realistic approach to shooters, but want to play a game with monsters and stuff, there are plenty of games out there for you, but this ain't it, kiddo. Hunt: Showdown is pretty good and heard good things about GTFO.
Oh shit, also there may be some slight, itty bitty amounts of blood here and there.
It's a very fun game.
Best arcade fps ever!!!

Super Mario Bros. Doom Edition

You know how hollywood takes a great doom game and turns it into a big budget pile of crap movie?  Well imagine for a moment that the same guys who make those horrible doom films decided instead to make a Doom game, and voilà you get Doom Eternal.

First, IGNORE the positive reviews.  10/10, 9.5, 5/5, 94/100  I don't know what game those people were playing but they weren't playing Doom Eternal, and if they were they obviously never played Doom 2016 or they are paid fakenews media. 

Describe the game in one word:  Lazy.

Describe the story in one word: Nonexistent.

Describe the combat in one word: predictable and repedative. Gore kills are fun when they are rare, having to do it every 30 seconds to refill ammo or armor makes it tedious and unenjoyable. 

Describe the level design in one word: incoherent/disjointed with Platforming EVERYWHERE!. 

Describe the challenge in one word: minimal:  
All but maybe 2 demons offer little challenge. I beat them game just below nightmare using the basic shotgun and grenade launcher mod the whole way through save for the very last boss which was a tedious bullet sponge and not challenge or difficult compared to similar bosses in doom 2016.  
 
Rate the game - 1/5 
(and that’s a generous 1 as what was good here was all taken from doom 2016) and the bar should  always be higher for sequels. 

Should you Buy this game? No. 
I'd suggest waiting for a steam sale and then only purchase if its under $15.00 anything more and you’re rewarding them for this garbage.

Developer Cash grab: ID was so desperate to turn this into COD with a season pass.  There is nothing here worth paying for any kind season pass. skins and backgrounds for loading screens, icons for your avatar? these are not things gamers should be expected to pay money for in a game like this.

Multiplayer: is almost non existent.  They tried to do something new here and its failed enormously. There are few players and if you do find a match, enjoy the 20 mins of loading screens so they can showcase the swag backgrounds or avatar poses they want you to pay for in the season pass.   How are Devs doing this in 2020 on a premium AAA Title?

DOOM Eternal might just be game of the year 2020, it's damn near perfect, a 9.5/10.

However, I cannot recommend the game in its current state. Bethesda and Id Patched a little thing called "Denuvo Anti-Cheat" into the game, and my anti-virus rightfully flags it as malware.

As I've said before, this is currently my game of the year. If they remove this awful anti-cheat/anti-piracy measure, you should definitely play it and I'll even change my review for a full-blown essay praising the game and its intricate mechanics. But not before Denuvo is gone.

I already knew this game nailed fast paced combat from every review I heard about it before buying, but after finally playing it myself I was pleased to find out it also nails the gameplay in between the high intensity battles. You will often be exploring the map, finding secrets or solving puzzles in this downtime, and without such time, it would be too much constant high intensity battle. It is perfectly balanced, and each type of gameplay compliments the other. 

In the beginning I had trouble learning all of the gameplay mechanics, I feel like it was throwing new shit at me left and right and I still often forget to utilize all my abilities in a fight, for example I often forget about the flamethrower and grenades. Lots of different ability upgrade currencies and different attachments for different weapons, some weapons are kind of similar to others, and you have a combat system that is kinda difficult to get the hang of, but definitely makes battles very open for whatever you want to do, and doesn't get stale.

The last thing I want to mention is the music, possibly some of my favorite game music of all time, it all flows together really well, the high intensity battle music makes me grit my teeth, lean forward in my chair and feel like a god while executing my enemies, and the downtime music can be so eerie and builds tension for the next battle so well. Some of the most fun I've had playing a singleplayer campaign in a very long time, but even that said, $100 is definitely pricey for me, I'm glad I got it half price.

DOOM Eternal expands on everything that made DOOM (2016) an incredibly well done reboot of a classic series. 

[b]Pros:[/b]

+ Movement and aiming feels better than ever - blending speed and movement fidelity perfectly
+ By extension of movement improvements, the platforming elements of the game, which are numerous, do not feel tacked on, and blend nicely into regular gameplay (whether during arena fights with the swinging pipes, or during map exploration with the climbing walls)
+ Gunplay is fantastic, with each weapon having their clear pros and cons, and a roster of diverse enemies that encourage you to experiment/switch through the arsenal to defeat them 
+ Most weapons have two modification options, some of which are expanded on from DOOM (2016) which compliment their default firing modes (the short range Combat Shotgun can take the sticky-bombs option for long range, precision firing)
+ Weapons and their modifications can be further improved through Weapon Points earned through killing demons and completing optional challenges
+ The Slayer's armour can also be improved through Praetor Suit Tokens, much like in DOOM 2016, with some new equipment options
+ Similar to Suit Tokens, you can find crystals throughout the game that improve your health, armour or ammo capacities, which can have further bonuses when paired together strategically 
+ There is ample opportunity for players to unlock these improvement points; through mission-based challenges (Glory-Kill an enemy in a particular fashion, or find a particular collectable), timed Secret Encounters (kill a series of enemies in a short period of time), or through the Slayer Gate challenges (Six increasing difficult arena encounters that can be found throughout the game, leading to an unlockable super-weapon
+ The new equipment options (shoulder-mounted grenade launcher/flamethrower and wrist blade/Blood Punch) do not detract from other combat options, but complement them
+ Map and environmental design is phenomenal - you can almost hear the artists/writers giggling as they make the world as crazy as possible
+ The same as above can also be applied to the expanded lore, which has been used to make an interesting narrative for the game that carries you from Hell-torn Earth, to Hell and beyond
+ The lineup of Demons return from 2016, along with some familiar faces from Doom 2 (such as the Arch-Vile, Pain Elemental and Arachnotrons), and some brand-new Demons for you to slay
+ Each Demon has its own abilities, strengths and weaknesses, much like your weapons, and in time you'll learn how to exploit and prioritise their presence to maximise your slaying effectiveness ('Fodder' demons like Zombies can be farmed for ammunition and so on)
+ Some Demons have strategic 'weak-points' that can be disabled, like the Mancubuses' Flame-Throwers, providing you with an edge during an arena-fight 
+ From a technical standpoint, the game runs smooth as silk, and has a huge range of optimisation options and unique video rendering settings (such as film grain, colour filters, the 'classic' centered-weapon pose from Doom)
+ The game looks and sounds fantastic, and Mick Gordon once again hit it out of the park with the soundtrack
+ Battlemode, a co-operative PVP Slayer vs. Demons mode is an interesting addition, that can be avoided completely
+ Extra lives are a handy bonus for those having trouble against particularly difficult arenas
+ Good range of difficulty options, and 'cheat codes' - unlockable modifiers that can be enabled to customise your experience during the campaign (very similar to the Skulls in Halo)
+ Huge range of collectables and easter eggs that encourage you to explore the stages of the game in detail, and also help encourage multiple playthroughs of individual missions, or the campaign in large

[b]Mixed:[/b]

+ Most of the reviews I read prior to actually playing the game frequently mentioned that you are incredibly hard-pressed for ammunition and health throughout the game. This was, at least in my experience, most recognisable during the first act of the game, and the necessary resource management becomes second-nature once you are well experienced in the campaign, and the mechanics required (frequent glory, chainsaw and flamethrower kills) to keep stocked. 

[b]Cons:[/b]

[i]I really, really enjoyed this title, and most of the cons are going to be nit-picks[/i]

- The movement-slowing slime sections can slow down the pace of the game, and can be more of a nuisance than a complementary experience
- Similar to the slime, the demonic tentacles in some stages don't really add too much to the game, besides making you slow down and be cautious 
[spoiler]- There is one particular level of the game that feels completely out of place, even though it is crucial to the narrative of the game, and almost cheapens what the Hell/Earth levels are trying to establish - in short, it's almost [i]too[/i] whacky[/spoiler]

[b]Summary:[/b]

If you enjoyed DOOM 2016, or any other entry in series (besides Doom 3), then you owe it to yourself to pick this up. Even if you're unfamiliar with Doom, and just enjoy arena-based shooters, like Quake or Unreal Tournament, you'll enjoy this. I would encourage one to play through DOOM 2016 first, in order to appreciate this to its fullest extent.

Wow, Doom Eternal Delivers!   I rarely ever pay full price for a single player game and pre-ordering the deluxe package was 100% worth it.  This was the perfect pandemic launch game

Pros

- Graphics and Art Design that will blow you away.   I kept stopping to take screenshots
- Perfect Ultra-wide 21:9 support at 3840x1600
- Vulcan powered engine that ran 120 FPS 100% stable
- Great new variety added to the Doom Slayer's attacks - Grenades, Fire, & Sword
- Great level design, sound / music, and a servicable story
- Played about 25 hours and eagerly awaiting the expansions.  I played in small chunks of time

Cons

- The gameplay isnt revolutionary.   Walk around map look for the secret locations enter a room full of monsters and move on....
- Not much interaction or phsyics interaction with the environments

Doom Eternal is what you get when you release the perfect shooter and try to improve it.
TL:DR - if you like platformers, retro gaming and want a challenge, it'll probably be up your alley. If you loved doom 2016, consider skipping.

Generally if a game is well made but not to my liking I'll still give it a thumbs up however I can't help but view this one in the context of its predecessor and Eternal just made me really unhappy while playing it.

For every interesting new idea there's something new that I hated, for every returning positive feature there's a returning feature that's all messed up. 

[h1] Doom is a shooter, this is 50% platformer [/h1]
This is probably the biggest single reason I had a bad time and I shouldn't bring it up as a complaint if it weren't for the lack of presentation clarity. Admittedly I didn't research this game a ton before buying but everything I saw gave me the impression that it's a shooter like Doom 2016 but instead you'll be swinging around monkeybars and climbing walls like lara croft as much as you'll be shooting. And well I really don't enjoy platforming. the platforming even invades the shooting sections as your traversal of the combat arenas are more jumpy and climbey than ever.

[h1] Objectively good, relatively worse [/h1]
The core of the game should be how the shooting feels, right? Well it feels good. But Doom 2016 felt somehow more fluid and smoother. There are a lot of new tools and systems but for me personally all it does is make the experience more convoluted. Until you've unlocked all the upgrades, guns manage to feel weaker and in a power fantasy game that's bad, even on the easiest difficulty some of them are disappointing. Eternal is generally harder, which would be fine if there was one even easier difficulty setting that would just let me have fun shooting demons without all the other nonsense going on (Yeah there are "cheat code" unlocks but that's not the same). I actually went and re-downloaded Doom 2016 to make sure I wasn't just misinterpreting things and the only thing it did was to highlight how much better, more pure the previous game was in almost every way. I didn't feel any particular desire to return to Eternal after playing a few levels in Doom.
Bosses are hit or miss, the big ones towards the end are luckily very good but the game flirts with invulnerability (again making you feel weaker and more gamey). The Marauder is easily the worst enemy in the game and I can't remember an equally bad-feeling enemy in any game in recent time because you're allowed only to hit him at certain openings and that'd be fine but even outside those opening, visually he's open to getting shot, just when you shoot him he immediately pulls up a shield and it's an unrealistic feeling animation, it's ridiculously fast, it feels like the game saying "NO" every time it happens making things incredibly annoying. Every demon (except maybe one with a giant shield up ALL THE TIME) should take some damage even on badly timed hits and against poor weapon choices.
Oh and another minor frustration to add to the list is how melee punches seem to do nothing. Even as I punch a "trash" demon, I can't kill it with just punches. So why even let me punch out of glory kills and blood punching? Another bit that makes me feel weaker and not stronger as the doom slayer.

[h1] Cool, but covered in ugly [/h1]
I love shiny visuals in my games and whilst not every game has to be up to the same visual standards, sequels should look better than their predecessors. What's frustrating about this aspect of Doom Eternal is that the assets and style of the world are fantastic but most of the time the lighting, colours and textures make it feel more flat or cartoonish than Doom 2016. Additionally I hate games that are... well, gamey and the areas of Doom Eternal are filled with gamey objects like blockers (barriers and gates), monkey bars (god I hate monkey bars) and climbable walls that all have green "notification" lights next to them so you can find them easily. Demons, again, look better in terms of models and animation but the colours tend to go in the retro rather than immersive direction which I dislike. The UI, despite customization options, is one of the worst looking I've seen in recent times.
Cutscenes are weird, inconsistent and intrusive. Doom 2016 did an amazing job at making you feel in control and above everything else going on but 3rd person pop-out cutscenes add nothing to the experience and make you feel less like the doom slayer and more like in an rpg. Some of the cutscenes are like the good, old ones but why the other half are more traditional, lame ones I can't fathom.
In a vacuum it'd be an amazing looking game but how can I not complain if the game ID made 4 years before this one looks better.
I should note here though that the render modes are pretty cool to mess around with.

[h1] Narratively confusing with memes on top [/h1]
Doom 2016 had a very clear, simple mission statement throughout the game. It made you feel like a matter-of-factual force of nature but in Eternal you start aboard a spaceship in the middle of a story for which you lack the introduction to. I really wanted some more explanation to connect the two games better. With all the character interaction and 3rd person perspective cutscenes it feels like you're trying to make doom guy an rpg hero. That said the story is great as long as you read the codex to understand it.
A particularly annoying little detail I noticed is the humorous announcer jokes referring to you as "doom guy" (yeah he's called that but very counter-immersive when used inside of the game) and all this "mortally challenged" nonsense, giving orders to demons as if they were coorporate workers. Doom has always thrown some jabs at the ridiculous, evil and greedy attitudes that have lead to the disasters you find yourself playing in but this kind of humour just breaks immersion and the wall between doom fandom and the game world.
Codex entries seem to be more down-to-earth and boring. Somewhat behind Doom 2016's progression of codex tiers with each consecutive one being more outlandish and cool.

[h1] There are good things but just too many frustrations [/h1]
Eternal certainly brings some new improvements to the table that feel good like the soundtrack is fantastic. Some levels manage to look amazing despite the earlier complaints, like the late hell levels are the best doom has ever had. The dash and meathook feel good (though I never felt the desire to use the latter). The collectable system is great, as you don't have to look stuff up or wander the same circle for an hour to find all the items though even here some things have been made worse, for example (and this is minor but frustrating) you can't move once you activate the collectable toy animation and you gotta wait there for it to finish. Plenty of systems are fine and similar to the old ones (like runes, armor and weapons mods) but clearly the game has gone in a direction I don't want to follow. I enjoy the shooting enough to play the game but around every corner is something that drives me up the wall (pun intended, I hate wall climbing), makes me bored or disappointed.

It's a technically savvy,stable project and if the features it has are something you like it'll be a great experience. Not for me though.
Great combat, great sound, acceptable story. Shame it force on me some mechanics, but overall great game.

DOOM Eternal is probably one the best games I have played by far. It has face paced interactive combat and extremely well constructed arenas. It has difficult and sometimes frustrating enemies, but that's a reason why the game is so good. The hate you have for the enemies makes it so much better when you rip them apart. A lot of people say the Marauder breaks the pace of the game, and that's a good thing. DOOM Eternal is a game where you have to adapt to your situation and play around what's happening. Knowing the arena, enemies, weapons you have, equipment, etc. So the Marauder is more to really test your skills in those areas. He isn't there to break the pace, he's here to test if you can keep it. Besides the point, the game has great levels and fights, broken up quite well with a few enemies here and there between arenas, and just looks great even on low settings. Older computers can have issues running it, though. So check your specs and see if you can run at least 60 fps, if you can't, in game performance can be affected pretty poorly, e.g, missing a shot, etc. Other than that, it's an incredible game. 9/10.

DOOM Eternal is a truly amazing experience, living up to the hype in my opinion. It's just as good as it's predecessor. The gameplay is even faster, and almost ruins 2016's gameplay. You haven't lived until you feel the rush of dashing around, blasting demons apart, before chainsawing one and slicing the head off another at 90mph. The game has tons of unique and fun weapons, ranging from your typical double barrel shotgun, to the awesome Crucible. 

There are tons of collectibles, like toy versions of the demons you fight, and cheat codes. My personal favorites are the record vinyls, that let you play music in the Fortress of Doom. The lore pages are also interesting reads too, expanding on the interesting lore and backstory of the Makyrs and Sentinels.

The boss fights in this game are amazing, and each one is unique. My personal favorite is a demon taking inspiration from the Classic Doom Hell Knight design. Tons have spoken their disdain for the Marauder, but I personally love fighting him. It's a fun change up of pace, and you have to play smart and be patient. He's your equal in every way.

I haven't tried the multiplayer yet, but I have heard both good and bad. But it's there for those interested. 

My only negative for the game as of right now, is the lack of Master Levels, with there only being ONE with the base game, and TWO if you own the Digital Deluxe Edition. I can't really blame ID though, due to the current events transpiring, being forced to work at home. My fingers are crossed for more Master Levels soon.

This is a must play for FPS fans of all kinds. This is game is a masterpiece.

Doom is probably the best shooter of all time.  It was the first and is still the first in class.  A lot happens very quickly.  Even the normal difficulty is very challenging.  You're always balanced at the cusp of death.  You have to make a lot of decisions very quickly.  To compensate for the difficulty the game controls very well.  I get a lot of pleasure from simply flicking the screen.  It's so fast and so tight.  

If you've played Doom 2016 there are some difference.  The BFG is scaled down but it's made up for with a new addition.  Chainsaw recharges but ammo depletes faster.   Armor is a renewable resource.  There are a lot more keys to press.  All of this makes subtle but large changes to how the game plays.  Subtle because it's still feels very much like 2016, but large because instead of glory kills being the main focus you're now focused on many different tactics to balance health, armor, and munitions. 

There are a couple of negatives which come close to ruining the game.  In 2016 a lot of focus was placed on preventing you from being caught in geometry.  This game lacked that focus.  You will get caught in shit.  There are invisible walls in this game.  In the chaos of conflict you will leap for a clearing you should be able to reach and an invisible wall will block you then you will die.   You will get caught in some geometry on the floor for just a second and then you'll be dog piled.  You'll try to escape but you can't shove pass.

The next complaint is even greater.  There is one enemy in the game that is in complete contrast to the entire game.  The Marauder that you cannot attack.  You have to wait to counter it.  It will always be on top of you.  It summons a ghost dog that respawns as soon as you kill it.  You have to sit and watch this fucker while staying in the perfect range while everything else the normally happens in Doom is still happening.  

Overall It's beautiful, it's challenging, it's metal, it's one of kind.  Doom eternal is a ledge above all other fps's.  Most of the changes made from 2016 make the game feel new and improved.   A couple of those changes jeopardize everything.

DOOM Eternal is the perfect sequel to DOOM (2016). Everything from the previous game is expanded upon and made better. The weapon mods, the upgrades, everything. There are so many new and interesting enemies and environments to fight in. I love the inclusion of more platforming, the climbing walls are a great addition along with the bars to swing on. One small problem I had with this game is that it's significantly harder than DOOM (2016). This made it somewhat a chore to play early on, but, it got easier with time. The only thing that persisted throughout the entire game that I didn't like, was the Marauders. Literally the most annoying enemy to fight in the game. Other than that, I highly enjoyed this game and loved how the story was expanded upon.

Its very good but a bit different. Instead of fighting on the ground you are more in the air 50% of the time. This version of Doom forces you to constantly be dashing or double jumping. I'm not sure i'm a huge fan of that part but its still Doom. Ripping and chunking demons is the name of the game.

Builds upon everything that DOOM (2016) did so well. The increased mobility and new abilities make this game even more fun and challenging to play and the gunplay is as satisfying as ever. Meanwhile, the humour is absolutely still prevalent in regards to the absurdity of what you do on your missions, so a couple of chuckles amidst the hellish chaos is almost guaranteed. 
At the time of writing, I haven't finished it yet, but I can only recommend you try this game out - especially if you played DOOM (2016) and are looking for more!
veri good ejs

This game easily has the best fps gameplay I've ever experienced. At first I found the game pretty intimidating, there is so much you need to keep track of; your multiple different ability cool downs, your ammo, health and armor, and the number/types/positions of all the enemies. As I mastered the doomslayer's abilities and got more accustomed to the maps and enemies though I found that the complexity is exactly what allows the action to get as chaotic and exhilarating as it does. I have now played this game through 3 times, first on "hurt me plenty", then "ultra-violence", and now finally nightmare, and I found each play through to be a real challenge. The constant challenge forces you to learn the gameplay, and that is really when the game gets fun. When everything clicks, when you remember all your weapons and abilities and are switching between them seamlessly as you fly around the arenas dodging demons and projectiles while at the same time managing your resources and rapidly slaying demons, well it really puts you in a trance. I've never played a shooter that requires so much of you or is as rewarding. I also am a fan of the platforming areas, the platforming is really all relatively easy and its a great way to split up the constant action of the gameplay. If you are someone who liked playing games about shooting and killing things I really could not recommend this game enough.

Unlockables and other rubbish in the game that just didn't need to be there (the whole base system) that could have been offered in a much more organic way (and most of the game's progression - UNICORN SLAYER? what the hell (pun intended) happened to this game.

Let me start by summing up this review: buy it, you're not gonna regret it.
Now, for my opinions on the game. If you've played DOOM 2016, the basics will feel pretty familiar to you, but not just the movement but your mobility in general has been amped up from the first game. The devs really tried to make the gameplay a lot more frenetic than the prequel, and it shows. You're gonna be zooming through any area killing demons without much time to stop. But this also comes at the trade-off that, since you're so much more mobile, fights are also more packed and harder in my opinion (though I only have completed it in the Hurt me Plenty difficulty as of writing this), so expect a bigger challenge than before. The guns also received some overhauls in the upgrade section, making them more distinct than in the previous game and each one having a different feel to them. All of this, with the lower ammo max and new tools (Flame Belch and Blood Punch especially) create the most action packed DOOM until now.
As for the looks of the game, in the graphics section, it's not gonna win any awards, but it doesnt defer from the experience either, and it allows the game to run smootly at all times. But the art direction, oh man, it's amazing. Compared to the previous entry, it took a lot more inspiration from the classic DOOM's, both in the levels, and especially in the enemy and gun design, and I gotta say, I really dig it, it feels pretty unique to me.
As for the music, you just can't find a bad track in this game, Mick Gordon did an amazing job again, not only is the soundtrack awesome on it's own, but it really improves the experience of this game. Definitely one of my favorite soundtracks in games.
Now, for the multiplayer. Let me start by saying that, although the 2016 multiplayer was a bit generic, I actually really liked it, for me it had a very good blend of mobility and quick action, it still was friendly enough that you could still play it perfectly casually and improve over time without getting stomped all the time. For Eternal's multiplayer, although I can certainly say it's more unique than it's predecessor, I don't think it's as much fun. I haven't played much, but for my first impressions on the Slayer's side it was chaotic as hell (hehe) and for the demon's side it was very do or die. In all of my games, most were favored to one side, be it the Slayer's or the demon's, haven't found much in between, but there's also a lot of factors that may have contributed to this, such as skill gap and lack of cooperation.

Builds on everything DOOM:2016 had, including the difficulty. 

Customization menus are a bit of a pain but they don't take up too much of your time at least. You really have to narrow down and focus what you're doing to even stand a chance - which is draining over time, so it's a game that really requires breaks between play-sessions. The Save + Exit option after each level + Exit to Desktop are welcome to that effect.

You'll use the chainsaw a lot, which is why knowing what you can or can't chainsaw counts and there's no indicator this time. Unlike the predecessor, "No target" sign appears when u just swing. There's a DOOM Level Up which pops up occasionally with no direct info on what it means. A lot of info pops up fast and this time u must press TAB immediately or you have to browse to the codex entry by hand. The font is cumbersome to read and the buttons for the codex and the UI in general could've been streamlined. A nice plus is that you have hotkeys to browse through every menu at least.

Similar to 2016 you have arenas you fight in to open a door but you have double or triple the usual enemy count.

Biggest problem? "Bethesda.net connection." You are taken out of the game and into a menu and during the worst fights it's really annoying. Why would you ask the player to manually refresh your connection instead of automatically doing it silently? For a game that is built around "high tension during fights" and "release nerves after fight", it really severs the game flow.

Graphics are gorgeous, especially when you're not in the wrecked cities.
Customization options are very generous. 

Sound design is great, really captures the gamey but still brutal feel of the experience: enemies sometimes "pop" like a corked bottle, ammo gets sucked up like candy while your chainsaw hacks flesh and enemies rage like wild beasts.

Music is a little bit too metallic for the game-play and could've used more musicality against the noise. Turning it off and putting your favorite R&B tracks actually improves skill and lowers cortisol levels dramatically after a couple of hours of play.

TLDR: DOOM Eternal is first-person shooter perfection.

I'm a fan of DOOM and Quake. I'm a fan of arena shooters in general (Quake Live, Overwatch etc).
I've thoroughly enjoyed DOOM 2016 and found it to be the best revival of an IP that I've seen.
I expected DOOM Eternal to be more of the same, maybe with a few tweaks here and there.

[b]But, holy cow, nothing could have prepared me for this.[/b]

DOOM Eternal upgraded on every single aspect of its predecessor. It's everything I wanted in a DOOM game, and then some.

The combat is unrelenting and fast-paced, yet cerebral at the same time. If you are not constantly thinking and making decisions, you are dead, especially on higher difficulties.

The arenas feature a lot of verticality and perfectly complement the weapons and movement options at your disposal. There is a huge variety in environments and you will not find yourself getting bored with the looks of the game. As soon as you've had your fill of one environment, DOOM Eternal makes sure to teleport you into something completely new.

The demons are well-varied, extremely aggressive and smart. They all behave differently from each other and you will quickly learn to distinguish between even the weenies. And you will have to if you want to survive - the weenies, while being made of paper, can still dish out significant damage.
Some of the demons have weak points and destroying those weak points is oh-so-satisfying.

Between fights there are short platforming sections, none of which are terribly hard. They give you a chance to play around with the movement and take a breather before the next arena-slaughter. They are also when you will explore and find various upgrades and collectibles. 100%-ing the game isn't terribly hard, but it's very rewarding nonetheless.

The sound design is superb.
First off, you get Mick Gordon's brutal metal soundtrack. It's not just a soundtrack though, it flows between each combat encounter, reaching it's peak during peak slaughter and lightly riffing in between fights. Every map has its own soundtrack with multiple plays on the main theme of the soundtrack.
The sounds themselves are excellently created with each action having its own easily recognizable sound. This allows you to focus on the action and simply hear when something in your arsenal is ready, or if that off-screen grenade has succesfully removed an enemy weak point.

There's a lot of fan service in DOOM Eternal - from the monster designs looking like DOOM II/64 sprites, the skins and collectible figures and albums. But this doesn't in the least detract from the experience of the game. It's a love letter to the older gamers who grew up on this, and it's a way for newer generations to be able to appreciate DOOM's roots.

In the end, a word of advice:
You will want to play this game on Nightmare. 
You don't need to do it in your first play-through, but do yourself a favor and try it out once you're familiar with the game.
I promise, you won't be able to play it on any other difficulty afterwards.

I've thoroughly enjoyed DOOM Eternal and I'm still playing it as of writing this review.
It's my choice for Game of the Year 2020, and I feel that it will last me a while longer than that.

Amazing game. Fast and exciting arena shooter gameplay on this smooth as butter game. Highly recommend if you are looking for a good single player FPS experience. Online is a bit of fun as well but definitely not the main focus of this gem.

WARNING!!!

This game is a First-Person Platformer (FPP).

If you buy this game expecting a FPS experience, it may take you more than the 2hrs Steam currently allows, for you to realize just how much FPP you'll have to endure to get the shooter experience you thought you were paying for.

This lesson cost me $50+ (purchased the deluxe edition during a steam sale), and because it took me 14hrs of play to realize the early platforming wasn't just to teach you techniques to use in the shooting portions of the game, but instead make-up at least 50% of the time you'll spend slogging through the campaign, Steam has refused my refund request.

Learn from my mistake... unless you enjoy platforming, DO NOT PURCHASE THIS GAME!


BTW, Steam... instead of an arbitrary limit of 2hrs, how about setting the threshold to be a percentage of how long the developer says the game should take to complete?

Usually when I see a trailer saying something like: "You are felling unstoppable!" or "This game is absolute blast!", it's usually just some bullsgit made by the review site to make the review more entertaining to read, but this... ohhhhh yeeeaaa!

I am playing this game on Linux in Proton without any issues at all and I have to say that every dollar spend on that game was worth it. I have been playing only few hours, but its awesome! That game starts really slowly teaching you every possible button press (little bit annoying), then it throws you right into the combat which forced me to switch into easy mode since I was not able to beat the level, but after playing some time, I really got into it and now I feel like a killing machine! 

This game is exactly what I imagine a good FPS should be. Having a crazy back story when you hear how people think you are literally a god brutally killing the demones and of course the killing itself. Also the music fits perfectly. 

If I could, I would have played the entire game at once, but sadly I don't have that much time. That's how good it is. 

Only thing that I just want to note (it may be caused by me using Linux, but trying it on other machine with Windows seems to be exactly the same) is that in some levels the game just drops the FPS to really low like around 20 for few seconds until all the newly spawned enemies are loaded. It would be really nice if that was not happening, because sometimes in combat it cost me lot of health. 

Anyway definitely would recommended. 10/10. Rated as masterpiece. Like all the doom games basically.

[H1] General [/h1]

DOOM Eternal may just be one of the greatest games I have ever played. Knowing that it is a sequel but just because it is a sequel,  does not mean it needs to be a carbon copy of the previous game. DE succeeds in that a lot.
Also id pls give 2018 gameplay reveal hud.
[h1] Story [/h1]
I don't understand the entire plot but the gist of it is "man too angry to die kicks out demons from Earth that were sent there because Heaven wants to exploit humanity for energy".

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]
(note: dont go in expecting the same gameplay as 2016)
[b]Speed is important. [/b]If you stop moving, then say hello to the  "reload checkpoint" button! You  have a bunch of weapons, [b]all situational[/b], that is. SSG won't always save you this time, bucko. Ammo is also handled differently this time, you need to chainsaw them mfs or you wont have jack. It makes it a bit more balanced because as mentioned before, it makes weapons not be your go to. In 2016, you had a hella(no pun intended) large amount of ammo, basically making the only decent weapons SSG and Gauss. Not here.
Ammo though can be upgraded up to 4 times. Some enemies also have weaknesses to certain weapons, so that's cool, I guess. 
[b]Upgrades, people, upgrades![/b] They are important in your demon slaying quest. Immune to barrel explosions? Yep. Switch weapons faster? Also here. Remote Detonaton rockets having flares? [b] Y E S [/b] .Other stuff aswell. There are also collectibles, such as cheat codes, toys and [b]Empyrean Keys, which give you something if you collect them all...[/b]
[i]Also you can play DOOM 1 and 2 on a PC in your fortress but you might aswell yeet them into a source port.[/i]

[h1] Graphics [/h1]
The graphics are pretty nice, even on low. The graphics are so optimised, in fact, that cranking up the settings does minimal stuff. In the recent update, there were some extra added decals to some things so yeah.(EDIT: Apparently these were always in game, but people with lower specs could not see them

[h1] Multiplayer [/h1]
Currently there is BATTLEMODE(caps because the devs said so dont @me), a 2v1 mode where a Slayer fights against 2 demons. No anti cheat and probably wont be for some time after the entire fiasco some time ago, so expect rapid fire BFG.  There will be the upcoming [b] Invasion mode [/b], where you can raid someones Campaign as a demon. If there is no AI friendly fire I ain't interested in the slightest.

[h1] Rating [/h1]

I hereby give DOOM Eternal, a 9/10, not enough Earth levels.

I'll play some more but i think I enjoyed DOOM (2016) more than Doom Eternal and here's a quick summary as to why. I feel the game added a bunch of junk i don't really want nor care about, i like the simplicity of just running and gunning of doom, why change it? Also there is apparently a time gap between the end of DOOM (2016) and Eternal, I was actually enjoying the story of DOOM (2016) but it looks like they threw the story out for a new one. All of this is based off of two hours and I'll probably beat the game and make a better review, but so far, I'm really not liking it.

I was hesitant from buying the game because of the reviews stating the gameplay is vastly different and more complex than Doom 2016.  I loved Doom 2016.  So I dragged my feet pulling the trigger on this game and due to the sale I pulled it.

45 minutes in to the game I was annoyed and bored.  I turned the game off.  The controls were complex.  Game play was complex.  I played on a harder difficulty than I usual do for Doom which is my fault but still the game was frustrating.  I turned the game off.  Strongly disliked it.

Fast forward to today and I decided to try again.  30 more minutes in to the game I was starting to catch the hang of it and the game began being fun.  I kept on it and kept working the controls and practicing in zones where I killed all the monsters to train my brain how to switch weapons, modes, and glory kills.  The more I practiced the more natural weapon and mode switching became and it became even more fun.  I have to admit though that all the weapon modes still make the game play frustrating...each weapon has different modes and has different modes on those modes plus you have to learn how to use flame, chainsawm and grenades.... which add to more complexity.  I have not learned those new weapons yet... but so far game is an absolute blast but I still am reserved on the overkill/complexity of weapons and fighting.  Parkour is not doing it for me either, and the dash/double dash is killing me.  Every game the shift key is sprint but this keeps throwing me in a dash.  I was using the shift key in this game without the shift key doing anything because that is so natural for me.  I was better off without the dash and hitting the useless shift key then hitting the shift key and dashing off a cliff.  More training on my brain required.

Regarldess I do recommend this game.  Sounds and looks great and I am sure the more I learn the game the better it will get.

Update:
Weapon switching still very difficult to learn.  I rarely run out of ammo which is a complaint many have said but I learned the chainsaw quite well.  I still get spanked because switching weapons is hard with a wide array of enemies in a spot, and they chase you so fast, much faster than Doom 2016.  I used to be able to run and buy time but this game very little chance.

Parkour, I really do dislike it.  So far I can get past every difficult parkour section, though I die a lot, but it adds no value to my enjoyment.  I know I will solve all the parkours to advance in the campaign but no sense of accomplishment, just eye rolls and *sighs.

Update 2:
I still hate the parkour.  But game is getting even better.  Their is a real sense of accomplishment as I progress.  This game is not like the reviewers say, you can kill all the monsters with all the weapons, it is just easier to kill with certain weapons.  This game is not entirely what the reviewers made it seem like.  I really enjoy this game.  it is really testing my old man reflexes...pushing them to the max.

DE adds too much on top of that and it shows.

The beauty of Doom is that it always kept it simple.
