I’ll mostly be comparing this to doom 2016.
This is a good game don't get me wrong. but I don't get some of the design decisions compared to the first game. 
cons
•	This game is much more linear than the first one which is sad. I liked back tracking and exploring secrets hidden in those big levels.
•	This game still only has 4/5 ammo types and not one ammo type for each weapon. I find that annoying and baffling since the reason why you cant carry that much ammo  with you is that the devs want you to use and switch between all the different weapons in your arsenal, which would be fine if using one weapon didn’t deplete the other weapons ammo too. the regular shot gun uses the double barrels ammo, the regular assault rifle uses the gatling guns ammo etc… so you’re stuck again switching between the same 4 guns that the game switches in your hands when you run out of one weapon type to another. So, you barely get to use guns like the double barrel shot gun, pulse rifle, and gatling gun.
•	The platforming is fun but overused.
•	Same guns and abilities mostly.
•	The marauder is just not fun, it would have been fine if he just had a lot of health and no shield. 
•	Mostly the same gameplay as before, little innovation.
•	I know that we don’t play doom for the story, but I just kinda felt lost the whole way through not knowing who’s really the bad guy. (why was sam only introduced half way through the story? Did they forget him?)
•	The unlockables for your suit mostly don’t do anything substantial. (ex: grenades stun a bit longer, stay frozen a bit longer, big whoop)
•	Still only like 2 real bosses which is just sad.

Pros
•	Lots of new and fun enemies!
•	Soundtrack is still pretty good.

TLDR: great game, but doom 2016 is much better.

DOOM Eternal (DE) looks great and runs really well, and its gunplay and weapon feel is incredibly tight. Sound effects have appropriate oomph, and the typical ensemble of roars, blasts, and squelchy dismemberment is pretty much what you'd expect. The game's not lying about the whole "rip and tear" thing. Props for the amazing automap, too; I wish more games would adopt something similar.

DE took the "glory kill" mechanic from 2016's DOOM reboot, added several more synergistic resource-on-hit/kill mechanics, and made them all super important to survival. Doomguy is faster, too, and once you get used to it all -- really, you can't hide behind cover or "take it slow" at all now -- the sprawling battle arenas are mostly a fun and chaotic romp. It's much harder than 2016, although increasing your mastery of the game's many new systems really amplifies your own damage and survivability in ways that more than make up for it. Enemies have "weak spots" now too, which make them much easier to kill and create more complex rock-paper-scissor elements for each engagement. My only wish is that they had dialed down their importance somewhat. It would be once thing if these optimal attack patterns were just encouraged for bigger and tougher fights, but in reality you need to be mindful of them for every mid-tier baddie and above. Larger demons especially are such ridiculous bullet sponges that you almost have to go after their weak points to have a chance.

I played it on easy and found that to be an enjoyable challenge. I doubt I could make it on anything higher than normal, so anyone looking for a Serious FPS Challenge(tm) will find it here -- and particularly anyone that thought DOOM 2016 was too easy or that it lacked the larger-scale battles of the originals. DE makes up for that and then some. I was less excited about all the platforming elements, though. Once you've figured out the handful of jump puzzle variations that game can pose, you've mostly seen it all, and I was always eager to get to the next battle but rarely excited about all the jumps, air-dashes, and wall climbs required to get there. At least the game is pretty forgiving about reloading you near the jump puzzle without taking away your extra lives.

Then there's the story and world/lore stuff. I remain skeptical of the need for the Doom franchise to have a story like this, and particularly since DE just drops you right in a year (I think) after the events of DOOM 2016 in a needlessly confusing and info-dumping fashion. You're on a quest to liberate Earth, which is already something of a hellscape, and you've picked up a "Doom Fortress" spaceship/station hub from which to launch your earthly incursions. There's more -- you're entrusted with the task of killing Really Important(tm) Hell Priests, a bunch of McGuffin-chasing on the road to killing some corrupted angel-types, and other forgettable C-grade nonsense -- but it doesn't really matter. It's just serves as a weirdly convoluted and largely unnecessary reason to shepherd you from one awesome battle arena to the next.

I honestly don't mind some context or story-lite in a game like this, but I'd rather it be more akin to 2016's reboot; instead, there's just so much here that it's hard not to get distracted, and although production values are great, B-movie schlock with high production values is still B-movie schlock. YMMV, of course, since this kind of thing is super subjective, but I would have appreciated a simpler narrative.

Anyway, this was still a really good time, and now that I've cleared the campaign I might try my luck in some of the challenge arenas -- on easy, of course. :)

Oh, and Marauders are the worst. Whoever designed them obviously hates fun.
This is one of those rare games that you can almost physically feel yourself getting better at as you go.

Short Summery: All around a Good game
Long Summery (This isn't a review if you where looking for one continue scrolling, but this is a rant.): The game is very flowy, if your good at it. I say 'if your good at it' lightly, many people will say things like: 'Get good' or 'you only had the game for 30 hrs (as of the time I am writing at), give it a little more time'. I am what people call a 'casual gamer'. And the game is good to play if your trying to kill time. I have only played the game for 30 hrs and I already have 22/33. But the game has a few things that I wouldn't account as bad. I started the game on Nightmare and as of the cultist base, I had to put the game on a lower difficulty (Hurt me plenty). Later I got all the challenges done all the collectables to far collected, maxed out suit, almost maxed out weapons, all the codexes found, most of the secrets found, etc.
I haven't even tried out the multiplayer (nor do intend too). Yet the gameplay feels more like pouring a cup of water in a sink, then the river of flowyness (if you count it as a word) I first thought this game was going to be. But just because it didn't live up to my level of hype for it, doesn't mean it let me down in most assets. Yes, the Con-makr boss make me want to die and I haven't finished the Icon of Sin level. But yet again I had 15 lives before the Con-makr but at the end I was finding myself panicing and trying to headshot a Makr drone for health, so I don't die and have to restart (I mean I used all of my lives). Might be that I refused to look at something in order to fight her/him efficiently or I am just bad, might be the ladder. This and I repeat, This Does Not Mean I Think The Game Is Bad, I am Just Complaining. Lets end this with something I though of now. Doom Eternal is not a river. It is a dam, some of the gameplay flows and provides power. The other parts of the content are held back and you have to go out of the way. And sometimes even that flows and provides power. It just depends on what kind of fish you are (don't care if this is factually correct, just a metaphor).

It's more Doom. So far I've preferred Doom 2016.

Tutorials suck: It commits a sin in my book for stopping gameplay completely with pop up tutorials. And warns you that you will miss crucial information if you don't have them. This should be a slider. ALL on, new features only, and all off.

Stopping gameplay and forcing a player to look at a tutorial is bad game design.  Make it optional in the game (ie. press ALT to learn to wall climb) or introduce it to gameplay. Every other Doom game successfully blended the tutorials into the game. 

Lack of ammo sucks: I hate the lack of ammo in the beginning. These chainsaw murder pinatas should be more of a last resort. The challenge should be movement and the right weapon at the right time. Not a lack of ammo. It's Doom. 16 shotgun shells and one of the first mods is an automatic upgrade?   In doing so, it limits the fun. You want challenges, fine. But save that for the harder difficulties. Sometimes you just want to rip and tear and Doom really limits that.  

Overall: It's Doom. Gory fast chaotic fun. But kinda 'meh for me.  Still early in this game, and it'll probably grow on me.

Ridiculously hard for me even on easiest level. I watched the YouTube videos, but I can't even get past Mission 2 Celestial Locator where there is all the lava. Real shame, as I was enjoying the game up until now. I've been trying to beat that darn level all day! And it's only the second mission. I used to enjoy shooters such as the early Quake and Doom's, but not this. I'm not a hardened gamer, but I have just completed Dishonored 2 on medium level.

Edit: I went back to the beginning (twice). Got a little better. Made sure to practice every new move and every new mod as they came along. Changed my rune to the one that slows things down a little and gives you a few seconds to blast/run away when you are about to die. Also increased my health to 125. This was just enough to get me through that lava/platform level! 

But I still feel the game forces you to play a certain way. The chainsaw is not an option - it's a must (for ammo). Same with the glory kill (for health) and flamethrower (for shields). And this gets repetitive after a while. Dashing and jumping (away from danger) are also not optional. And then you have to remember to switch between weapons during the same battle (and also their mods!). That's a lot of finger movement on my XBOX PC controller.  Most weapons are crap and feel underpowered. 

The devs have programmed the game so you'll need to take out the "weak" part of enemies with turrets/missile launchers (i.e. destroy their turrets/missile launchers first) before they weaken and you can shoot/kill them. This is lame. It's really tough to aim and shoot their little turrets/missile launchers. Makes the game harder than it should be.

Edit 2: The platform section with all the jumping a bit later on totally p issed me off and this poor Mario Brothers with guns game has been uninstalled. One of the worst games I've ever played. Total waste of 20 hours of my life.

DOOM Eternal is nothing like any previous DOOM game.

[h1] The Doom Slayer [/h1]
The new Doom Slayer looks really ugly. Why is he wearing less armour than before now? Also it seems like the Doom Slayer now cares about the story, which makes him a lot less cool than the Doom Guy from DOOM (2016) who didn't care about anything except killing demons.

[h1] The Guns [/h1]
For some reason the Doom Slayer downgraded all his guns. They have barely any ammo capacity so you constantly run out of ammo. The game wants you to use the chainsaw to get ammo, but where's the fun in having to chainsaw a demon every two minutes? Why not just make the demons drop emmo when you glory kill them? Despite this mechanic however, I did manage to beat the first two levels without ever using the chainsaw.

[h1] The Levels [/h1]
There's parkour now. Why? I don't know. Also you don't die anymore when you fall into a hole, you just teleport back to safety.
The arenas you fight in aren't as obvious as before but now there are demons everywhere which isn't that much better because it turns the entire level into an arena.
Some levels also include some purple goo that slows you down and prevents you from jumping. Because DOOM, a game about movement, needs goo that slows you down.

[h1] The Story [/h1]
My biggest question while playing was "what happened between DOOM (2016) and this game?". In the 80 minutes I played, no question were answered. Overall, I didn't really care about the story since I was going to get a refund anyways.

TLDR: More colourful, more camp and more arcade-y than its predecessor. If you loved 2016, it's still worth a try but get it on a sale. 

[b]UPDATE[/b] - I think I figured what this game needs; difficulty settings. Give me more ammo and health but keep the difficult AI.

For me: [b]Less fun than DOOM 2016[/b]

[b]Pros:[/b]
- Graphics are gorgeous, the game is also optimised like no other. Every vista could easily be in a metal album cover.
- Music is still industrial metal, although with not quite the memorable tracks that the first one had.
- Fun to rip and tear as usual, some new interesting mechanics / weapons added.

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Arcadey yet difficult at the same time. The pacing feels very weird. 
- Weapons are no longer found naturally as part of the story (remember picking up the shotgun from the dead guy in 2016?), they are literally glowing up in the middle of the room ol' DOOM / Quake like.
- Less ammo, you need to be more accurate with your hits. Not a bad thing per se but there's less of that "Rip & Tear™" feeling unfortunately. The game kinda forces you to concentrate on "weak points" and instead of blasting away you now try to snipe parts of enemies.
- Enemies are bullet sponges, again, unless you're hitting them at the right parts you waste precious (limited) ammo. 
- A LOT of weight given to traversing / platforming. Essentially the game is 3 parts platformer and 2 parts shooter. You dash/doublejump avoid obstacles, solve riddles to open doors then you get rewarded with a couple of battles.
- The game is trying to build up some epic mega fantasy lore around DOOM. A lot more reading, a lot more politics and the story is actually really dumb. The whole appeal of 2016 was that Doomguy gave no shits about the politics and just wanted to crush some demon skulls. Combine this with the arcade style and it all feels weird, as if they were parts of the game developed by different teams. 

I don't know my dudes, maybe give this one a miss until it goes on sale. My heart's broken. 

I'm really conflicted. I will finish it for sure but I find myself quitting the game more often and not enjoying it as much. CS:GO Deathmatch mode is more fast paced to give you an example.

The graphics and sound of Doom Eternal is superb.  However, for me, it is not a fun game to play.  Once you are spotted all the monsters continually attack you and there is no opportunity to plan an attack or sneak upon an enemy.  So basically, the entire game consists of running around continually jumping and shooting monsters (i.e. very boring).  And you will die a lot.  I have been playing video games for over 35 years and have enjoyed several 1st person shooting games.  However, the Doom series is just like the Serious Sam franchise - run around, jump and shoot.
For me, the most fun I have is games like FarCry where you approach a fort and can methodically plan your attack and slowly sneak up on an enemy, kill him and then hide the body so it is not discovered and alert others.
I will continue playing the game until completed; but I don't see myself buying any future Doom games.

I pre-ordered the deluxe edition of this game before it got delayed, and I have no regrets. This is the game that made me actually feel legitimately excited for a video game for the first time in a long time. DOOM Eternal makes 2016 look easy and boring in comparison (As much as I love 2016). This game is literal FPS perfection and here's why:

- REALLY fun and a lot more challenging then DOOM 2016. To the point where I'm actually considering playing in the Ultra-Nightmare difficulty since you actually have something to work towards, unlike in 2016 (You can earn a golden skin for the DOOM Slayer if you beat the game on Ultra-Nightmare).
-Since it's a lot more challenging than 2016, you are are gonna get your ass kicked. A lot. But once you figure out the maps, learn to master the fluidity of the game's combat, learn each enemy's strengths, weaknesses, etc, you can completely DOMINATE the battlefield and feel like an absolute motherfucking badass doing so!
-Encourages you to manage your resources. Some examples: Glory Kill enemies to get health, use the shoulder mounted flame thrower (AKA, Flame Belch) to get armor, chainsaw fodder demons to get ammo, etc.
-Unlike 2016, where you could just beat the game with only 2-3 of your weapons, every weapon and their mods in Eternal feels useful. Which is great, because it encourages you to use every single tool at your disposal, and I really like that. 
-Pretty much the ultimate power fantasy. You are the DOOM Slayer, a being who is pretty much badassery incarnate and is feared by all demons. You are a man of action, not words. You don't give a fuck about anything else going on around you. You have a mission that's clear; to save the Earth (And possibly the rest of the universe) from demonic corruption and a higher being's arrogance.
-All the secrets in the game feel like they're worth collecting, encouraging you to explore every nook and cranny of each level, all while adding to making you feel like a true predator on the hunt (90's DOOM reference totally intended).
-Graphics look AMAZING! Even on low settings! I'm currently able to play the game at 1440p at an uncapped frame rate with most of the settings on high. 
-There are no microtransactions in DOOM Eternal (Well except for maybe the Twitch Prime skins, though I don't really know if those would count as microtransactions). Every skin can be earned by just playing the game. As it should be.
-Soundtrack is GODLY and metal as fuck! Mick Gordon (Composer of the game's soundtrack) has really outdone himself this time! Some of my favorite tracks include BFG 10K, Super Gore Nest, Meathook, Gladiator, Metal Hell, and more. The best part? Mick got to hire a bunch of metal vocalists to include their vocal talents into most of the tracks. If that doesn't make DOOM Eternal the most metal game ever, then I don't know what does. 

In conclusion: DOOM eternal has become one of, if not, my favorite games of all time. It's really fun, challenging, rewarding, and is definitely my game of the year for 2020. Cannot recommend this game enough!

In the first age, in the first battle, when the shadows first lengthened, one stood. Burned by the embers of Armageddon, his soul blistered by the fires of Hell and tainted beyond ascension, he chose the path of perpetual torment. In his ravenous hatred he found no peace; and with boiling blood he scoured the Umbral Plains seeking vengeance against the dark lords who had wronged him. He wore the crown of the Night Sentinels, and those that tasted the bite of his sword named him... the Doom Slayer.

Отличный шутер!

Если сравнивать с предыдущей частью, то бои значительно улучшились. Перестрелки стали еще динамичнее и интереснее за счет серьезного ограничения патронов у каждой пушки, открытых арен и добавления уязвимых точек врагам.

Теперь для того, чтобы эффективно уничтожать полчища демонов, нужно применять определенное оружие против конкретного вида демонов. Какодемонам стрелять из гранатомета в открытую пасть, бронированному Манкубусу сшибать защиту ударом кулака, а от чарджа Пинки уворачиваться и отстреливать хвост из дробовика. Так же, многим демонам можно отстрелить оружие, это сильно их ослабляет. Вам не дадут стоять на месте и расстреливать врагов из любимого оружия. Нужно постоянно перемещаться, жонглировать оружием и искать нужные припасы на аренах. Главному герою добавили паркурных способностей, что дополнительно повышает динамику.

К сожалению, минус прошлой части остался без изменений, а возможно, что даже усилился. Все еще надо искать секреты по всей карте и почти на каждой арене. Это сильно ломает динамику игры. Вот ты только что мощно месил и разрывал демонов под металл, весь такой заведенный готов дальше бежать и врываться на следующую арену, но нет. Будьте любезны остановиться на 3-5 минут и разглядывать стены в поисках подсказки, как найти тот или иной секрет. Это не сложно, но не понятно зачем, игра же не про секреты. Игнорировать их не получится, так как часть прокачки оружия и способностей запрятаны как раз в этих секретах. Не хочется пропускать часть контента, поэтому приходится заниматься этой фигней.

Стрелять и сражаться с демонами весело и интересно, если бы не бесполезный эксплорейшн, цены бы не было этой игре. Ну и финал затянут.

Do NOT buy this game if you were hoping for a sequel to Doom 2016.

It has to be by far one of the most disappointing games in the past few years. Everything that made Doom 2016 awesome has been forgotten about and replaced with new mechanics that makes it an entirely different game.

The enemy design is absolutely awful. In Doom 2016, the enemies had a purpose in combat and certain "formation" in the way they attacked -- in Doom Eternal, there are just swarms of enemies that feel more like combat in Warframe or Diablo, than a first person shooter.

Removing mechanics doesn't make it fun. There are several instances of this happening in the game -- the most prominent is the goo on the ground which makes it so you move incredibly slowly, and can no longer jump or dodge, bringing any combat pacing you had to an absolute crawl. Another example is the terrible shield enemies (of which there are multiple), that break the flow of combat completely.

The design of this game is completely the opposite of Doom 2016, and takes far too much influence from other genres and has lost a good chunk of identity in the process.

At least it got me to reinstall Doom 2016 I guess.

I don't quite like the aesthetic of this game compared to DOOM 2016, but combat feels MUCH better with the additions of new movement abilities and more well-designed arenas. One gripe I have is that ammo management is particularly hard at the start of the game. Before you can upgrade your ammo capacity, you're stuck with a shotgun that runs out of shells after about 16 shots or so (I think). Unlike in DOOM 2016, you don't have any weapons with infinite ammo, so there isn't a very good alternative to the shotgun when starting out. Aside from a rocky start, DOOM Eternal is an absolute BLAST to play, with incredible gameplay, incredible graphics, an incredible soundtrack, and incredible sound design. I give the game a 9/10.

Side note: the game is quite a bit harder to run than DOOM 2016. I was able to run DOOM 2016 with high graphical settings at over 60 FPS very consistently, but in DOOM Eternal, with a mix of medium and high settings, the framerate has dropped into the 50's during the more intense encounters. Keep in mind that if you could run DOOM 2016, you might not be able to run DOOM Eternal quite as easily.

Finally beat Ultra Nightmare, time to review this game again at around 70+ hours of game time...

The DOOM 2016 formula has been reworked and it works great. 

After playing all of the content available in the game as of now, 7/4/2020, I can confirm that this is my favourite shooter of all time and that I'm waiting very excitedly for either snapmap, more of the dlc campaigns or multiplayer to keep playing this game for a long time. If snapmap or multiplayer make it in, there will not be a reason to go back to DOOM 2016 in terms of extended community created content (in my opinion).

Now then, let's begin

COMBAT:

Every aspect of the game has been polished to the point where combat formula, the gameplay loop, feels perfect.

You need ammo? You get a chainsaw stock every 30 seconds or so, which comes nicely with the heavily nerfed ammo stock you carry. This might be a controversial point but it definitely allows for routing and smarter play and it's an incentive to use more of your weapons overall. Initially, my first playthrough was dominated by low ammo into no ammo situations, since I was playing with the 2016 mentality that one weapon could carry you forward to the entire game, however, this strict design decision incentivized me to use every single weapon for every single ammo type instead of just allowing me to dominate with the SSG and Gauss Cannon. If you're not convinced about this, perhaps I should explain why you can feel rewarded for playing like this.
There are now weak spots on certain demons that deactivate certain moves that they could use. This is a very important part of the game and it basically meant that I have to use the sniper mod for the rifle a LOT. The game knows that it's asking a lot from you so it has implemented certain key sounds for you to confirm that you broke a part or so you can notice that a special demon spawned.
Aside from the fact that the sniper mod in the rifle is mandatory from the beginning of the game (unless you 'stick' to the sticky grenades mod in the combat shotgun) this game distributes the sweet spot and weakness mechanics to several weapons, be it their capacity to stagger enemies, initiate an instant glory kill or allowing you to flat out kill them in one use of their weakness.
It's wonderful and the new equipment, the ice grenade helps a lot if you need a few seconds to think. The tools in this game are great overall.
Your equipment has now become a mechanic and, personally, I never used it in 2016, but now I'm inclined to learn to use it in order to survive Nightmare and Ultra Nightmare difficulty. I love it all, and the grenades feel very non-intrusive. With the right setup you can quickly use all of the tools comfortably.



You need armor? Find that perfect spot to blow fire on many demons with the flame belch to sustain yourself for a few moments (sometimes this is all that you need to play more relaxed, and this combos nicely with a well placed grenade on fodder demons). It's important to mention that all launchers and equipments are used from your shoulders, so you can activate all of these without needing to stop the shooting or aiming, meaning that it's always possible to use that life saving tool you had.

You need health? Nightmare difficulty isn't unfair anymore where the numbers are lowered, you can get around 60HP from a glory kill and it still feels fair and hard because of how complex the fights are. Go ahead and glory kill for that sweet health. Instead of being an unfair numbers game with the health, Nightmare and UN difficulty give back the heavy amounts of health that you lost fairly, allowing you to maintain that aggresiveness with demons, with 5 HP and 5 Armor per unit, meaning that those resource explosions will sustain any further hits as you absorb them.

Added to the game is a reworked regular melee attack called the blood punch, which is a risky (for harder enemies) but useful stun, damaging, AOE attack that can one shot a certain demon and hurt some other weak spots. It does need to charge up though. One gripe with this mechanic is that sometimes the blood punch will NOT come out, meaning that you will be punished heavily in harder difficulties (and maybe you will flat out die because of this momentum killer). This happens mainly with the mancubus though, so try to save your ice grenades for them as a small tip.

The demons are smarter and come in more quantities than before, which means that movement options are necessary and, thankfully, there are new movement options! The air dashes (and regular dashes) are an incredible tool for combat (and exploring) and it allows you to play faster and more creatively than ever. Whilst in 2016 you basically needed in flight mobility or seek and destroy to warp around the map in a more free-form manner, the suit upgrades based on dashing and the immense distance you can go through with the 2 uses of the dash allow you to add more versatility to your build with the other runes.

Before speaking about runes, it's important to mention that glory kills have been nerfed by the smarter AI in this game. Not only do the glory kills take longer (which makes them feel good, not gonna lie), but they now allow enemies to reposition themselves in order to (generally) disadvantage you or your movements options. There will be times where you will need to learn when to kill the enemy and when you can save ammo and go for the glory kill. If you ask me, you should investigate which glory kills are the fastest in order to still get the extra health, ammo saving and (if you light the demons up) armor as quickly as possible.

Now then, about runes! Before anything, all runes are static, and they cannot be upgraded, which does feel a bit sad, since you don't have much to look forward to in terms of rune challenges during gameplay. Apart from that, there are no longer rune unlock challenges, which makes the game feel slightly more focused (less loading screens and no strange combat arena), even if it does sacrifice some of the hellish mood. But what do the runes offer?
This time, the runes are divided in 3 slots: Glory kill buffs, equipment buffs and qualityy of life buffs. You can choose more mobility with glory kills (as well as making them faster) and a handy speed boost, or you might choose to get a cooldown reducer that incentivizes more effective usage out of your equipment, as well as giving you more conditions to use them (health from blood punch). If not, you might also want to defy gravity and time (and even death with a one use saving throw) by allowing you to move mid jump and letting you stop time in the air so you can aim and think in peace (This is kind of necessary with how hectic the game is... more on that in a bit). Any way you look at it, this game allows for several builds for the slayer, and even if you aren't convinced by most, you can change it up whenever you want.

But what about everything else?

Exploring is better than ever, and it feels fresh to look at with all of the new and more detailed areas. At times it feels like Metroid Prime, it even feels like they sampled the save station music. Some people seem to dislike the exploring but I really enjoyed it since there's always places to look at and many nods and fun references to other games from Id.

About the difficulty, I strictly believeD* that one should be playing in nightmare to accept the challenge and become a great player, however there are many bosses that are somewhat difficult to understand, and you probably have to die a couple times to learn the patterns since they have insane damage outputs. That would definitely be a small downside. Still, though, apart from certain questionable enemy spawns that COULD be my fault for sometimes standing still, it's a fair game. Kinda... play in a difficulty where you're comfortable with the mistakes you can make, as N or UN demand knowledge of everything. Thanks for reading!

Having been a fan of Doom since the beginning I have mixed feelings about this Doom.

First, I don't do a lot of multiplayer anymore.  I'd rather play with friends than just hop into random servers.  Most of my experience is with single player.  For that, the game looks great, sounds great, and plays great.  Everything is very responsive and the mix of shooting and puzzly-platformer stuff is interesting, but not so difficult that folks who don't play platformers should have too much difficulty.

id certainly carried over a lot of mechanics from the previous Doom, while adding and reworking some things.  Most every gameplay feature from the previous game is here, plus some new ones.  It's nice that there are more options, but the game also seems to expect you to make full use of all of those options.  That means if you aren't managing your grenades, chainsaw, flame thrower, dashes, and general shooting all at the same time, you might have trouble with a lot of the bigger encounters.  It all just gets a little fiddly and takes away from pure run and gun skill and makes it more micro-managing.

The bigger encounters can be a problem too.  In the olden days you didn't have the big arena-type set piece encounters except for boss fights.  If you like that sort of thing, then this game does it about as much as the previous one.  I understand why they do it.  It allows them to make fun little battlegrounds.  At the same time it breaks the flow a bit.  You end up confined in a small space dealing with a bunch of baddies when there's the whole rest of the world out there you could be running through to try and manage them.  It's not a big complaint and it may not bother you at all.

Other than that, the story is fun and the environment definitely carries the hellish feel through quite well.

Dumb version of 2016 Doom, wouldn't buy this even at the lowest of sale prices. Gun combat feels lifeless, never enough ammo, gun mods also not fun, forced tutorials that break the vibe by transporting you to little metal rooms - no idea what all the positive reviews are seeing....

[b][u]~ Conclusion ~[/u][/b]
Doom 2016 was excellent. Doom Eternal once again is a fantastic shooter and a fantastic game, it's a true credit to the genre and one of the best modern solo-shooters in existence, as was 2016 Doom. Unless you just hate shooting games as a rule, this game is a MUST BUY. If you liked the last Doom, you have no reason not to play it.

In and of itself, DOOM Eternal is a good game. It's obviously a labor of love, with fun mechanics, a great soundtrack, amazingly well-crafted scenery and lots of innovative stuff.

The problem is that it's the sequel to an earth-shattering wild ride of a game. And 2016's DOOM was better in most ways that matter.

For Eternal, it seems the developers came up with a bunch of fun ideas to improve the experience, and then decided to stick every single one of them into the game. That would probably have been okay, if they didn't then go on to design the game in such a way that you just HAVE to use all these mechanics.

We've got more guns, more ways to use them, more grenades and tools and extras and a flamethrower. And that would have been great if it had only meant you could figure out which tools fit your playstyle the best. But instead, you're forced to utilize pretty much every single thing all the time. Unlocking the cheat codes lets you play with e.g. infinite ammo, which to be honest is a lot more fun than just playing the regular game, since you're not constantly switching guns and chainsawing demons to get more bullets for things.

Another problem is that those wonderfully crafted surroundings have allowed the devs to put in a bunch of puzzles. SO MANY PUZZLES. At times it feels more like you're playing a Super Mario game, bouncing around from platform to platform and swinging around in the air. Fine, puzzles can be fun. But you also have to solve them exactly the way the devs demands of you; this is especially evident in the Mars Core level. "You found a clever shortcut so you don't have to jump across ALL the platforms? Too bad, we'll stick an invisible wall in the way. Now go back and solve this the way we wanted you to solve it."

But for all that, it's still a good game. But when you're following up on perfection, the flaws become so much more evident.

An incredible followup to DOOM (2016). This game expands on just about everything that was done right on it's predecessor. It's essentially just more of the same incredible gameplay from the last game with a changed arsenal, and a heavier reliance on using the chainsaw to recover ammo. You are encouraged to use all the weapons available and i think the game is much better for it. This game also has a heavier reliance on thinking on your feet, as certain enemies simply cannot be brute-forced on any difficulty. The exploration is very fun, and I am someone who never finds all collectibles, but I found 100% of all collectibles in this game. This is probably the best shooter game in years. A masterpiece of a game. Highly recommended.

I was skeptical at first but I am quite glad I decided to purchase this game. I am enjoying it. I am plying it on nightmare (the hardest difficulty) without any modifiers. I may end up playing it with some of the difficulty modifiers later on. It seems fun enough. 

I really dislike the whole melee animation kills. It is a way to provide you with additional health and ammo. I like the cooldown management aspect of things, but the way they go about it sort of detracts from the Doom formula. Basically Doom was always an arena shooter type, but it was more about avoiding damage and resource management. Now all of the resource management is absorbed into the cooldown management. I am feeling almost no resource management in the game at all. 

However, the game is balanced extremely well around the systems it has in place. as far away from Doom as the current formula is, it ends up with the same level of excitement. Just different. More short bursts of extreme adrenaline rather than long and lingering adrenaline the older games revolved around. You can die a million times and not have to worry about it. But the encounters are made to be much more exciting. I am squeezing tighter than if I was taking a shower in a federal prison. For this reason I am recommending it. 

I still stand by my opinion that the melee kill animations and constant flow of health/ammo is a bad direction. Everything else though makes up for it. The game is beautiful, challenging, and fun. I would go 8/10 from first impressions.
